title: Deals and Discounts
description: BOTSWANA PACKAGED -- Acacia Travel, a San Diego company, has a Botswana package that includes seven nights in deluxe Gametrackers camps, a night in Johannesburg and air fare from New York for $3,570 a person, double occupancy, from Sept. 1 to Dec. 11. (Daytime temperatures can exceed 100 degrees at this time of year.) Travelers may stay in one, two or three of the camps, which are operated by Orient-Express Hotels and are situated in Moremi Game Reserve, Chobe National Park and the Okavango Delta. The cost also includes game viewing, transfers between camps by light plane and three meals a day. The camps have overhead fans and electricity. Departures are on Mondays. Information and reservations: (800) 243-6996.

title: Hearing the Laughter in Women's Lives
description: SUNDA CROONQUIST used to be a private detective. Maureen Langan was a reporter for a business news service. Ann Stengel works as an office manager in investment banking, and Poppi Kramer is a bartender. But all four women have one thing in common: they think they are funny.

title: Some Men Make Waves
description: The gulf between the suit-and-tie man and the dress-down guy who wears a suit with an open-neck shirt and sandals was apparent last week at the New York men's wear showings for next summer. Terry J. Lundgren, the president of Federated Department Stores, above left, was one who didn't let the intense heat unknot his tie. Others threw off the harness, stripping to bare chests at Cynthia Rowley's poolside show. At show's end, a model in evening shirt and trousers leapt spontaneously into the water, quickly followed by the other models -- and Ms. Rowley herself. A photographer, Dino Scrimali, above right, attached a small fan to his lens, focusing the breeze on himself.

title: Mitchell Walks Out on Jets
description: At 6 o'clock this morning, while his Jets teammates were trying to wring out the last ounce of needed sleep in their dormitory rooms, Johnny Mitchell packed his gear, carried it to the locker room and piled it there. Then he walked out of the team's life for the second time in four years.

title: Shopping Center Plan Hits Bump, or Maybe a Block
description: Opponents of a plan to turn the dilapidated Washburn Wire Factory on Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive into a shopping center were quick to claim victory two weeks ago, when the City Planning Commission told the developers to revise the proposal by this coming Wednesday. ''We stopped the bloody thing in its tracks,'' said George H. P. Dwight, a member of a small group that wants to see the factory incorporated into a mixed-use redevelopment of the site.

title: U.S. Companies Are Wary Of Contracts in the Balkans
description: AS government officials gathered in Washington and Brussels last week to pledge billions of dollars in aid to reconstruct the Balkans, American companies said the political deck appeared to be stacked against their winning many lucrative rebuilding contracts, and wondered whether some are even worth pursuing.

title: Mystic
description: Mystic is a village divided, many times a day, by a bridge. When the bell rings, its staccato clapper often accompanied by a toot or two from approaching boats, the classic bascule bridge across the Mystic River rises to let boats through and traffic on Main Street, vehicular and pedestrian, comes to a stop.

title: Youth Camp Is Ordered Closed After Mistreatment Is Charged
description: Connecticut authorities have suspended the license of a youth camp in East Haddam after substantiating five instances of what they are calling the neglect or abuse of campers, who are mentally retarded or have other special needs.

title: Helping to Keep Families Afloat
description: THE New Haven woman, 38, thought she had followed the new welfare rules. When Connecticut required parents to work for benefits, she found a six-month culinary training program and last April got a full-time job as a baker for $8.22 an hour plus benefits. Her paycheck meant she would lose the $800 a month from the state she got for her five kids.

title: House and Senate Tax Cut Bills Would Give Businesses Billions in Long-Sought Benefits
description: As House and Senate leaders try to reach a deal on tax cuts, it is not just the average taxpayer who has something at stake. A wide array of businesses and industries is fighting to protect tens of billions of dollars in special benefits that have made the competing tax cut bills the most lucrative for business in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADRO, PROSPERO
description: PADRO-Prospero. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Prospero Padro, associated with The Times from 1974 until retiring in 1994.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUER, FREDA
description: LAUER-Freda, of Blessed Memory passed away ''tu bav'' before dawn interred same day. Wife of the late Aaron D. Lauer of Blessed Memory. Mother of the late Rabbi Elias Lauer of Blessed Memory. Survived by daughter Faige (Phyllis) Eisner, son-in-law Rabbi Saul Eisner, former daughter-in-law Ilse Klirsfeld, sister Sadie Lewis, brother William Klaristenfeld, grandchildren, Dr. Simeon and Dr. Ruth Lauer, Dr. Alan and Dr. Barbara Listhaus, Andrew Jay and Aleeza Lauer, 12 great grandchildren. Shiva will be completed on Staten Island Saturday night after ''shabbos'' until Tuesday morning. ''Thay nishmasah tzrora bitzror hachaim''.

title: Abigail Gertner, Christopher Lee
description: Abigail Sarah Gertner, the daughter of Dr. Nancy Gertner and Dr. Joseph Gertner of Guilford, Conn., is to be married this afternoon to Christopher Harold Lee, the son of Kathleen Lee and Dr. James Lee of South Easton, Mass. title: The Other Retirement Choice
description: MANY middle-aged Americans have taken to heart the advice to plan for retirement -- by socking money away in 401(k) plans, I.R.A.'s and other investments. But few have given much thought, experts say, to a long-term plan for their lives -- how they'll spend their time and energy. With longevity increasing, that can be just as important.

title: In Washington, a Tax Break for Homebuyers
description: WHEN Debbie Chewning started searching for her first home last year, she often drove from her rental apartment here to the bucolic streets of Takoma Park in Maryland, just across the border from northwest Washington, where she hoped to live. ''I really liked it there,'' said Ms. Chewning, who has lived in the Washington area since 1981. ''It was one of the first places I looked when I decided I needed to stop renting.''

title: Wild Card Contenders Snatch Up Pitching
description: The baseball world already knew tonight's non-waiver trading deadline would not produce the kind of impact deal made exactly one year ago when Randy Johnson moved from Seattle to Houston. But pitchers were on the move nonetheless, and they did not all go to the Mets.

title: July 25-31; Making Cancer Grow
description: Molecular biologists have finally succeeded in a seemingly simple task: to turn a normal human cell into a cancerous one. In the end, it took just three genes, two that are associated with cancers and a third that allows cells to keep doubling without limits. Scientists hope to use these precisely engineered human cancer cells to find better ways to detect and treat cancer. GINA KOLATA

The fox trot, the mambo, the tango -- Joe Saladak and Candy Galewski were doing them all, moving around the fountain at Playland here like Fred and Ginger sans tuxedo and sequined chiffon.

description: Only months after tighter restrictions on satellite exports took effect, concern is growing within the aerospace industry and in Congress that the new rules are entangling manufacturers in red tape, delaying launches and hurting American satellite makers in foreign markets.

title: Nantucket Worries That Its Past Is Being Renovated Away
description: On Orange Street, a winding thoroughfare in the historic Old Town, carpenters are gutting a 19th-century Federal house. They have stripped off the original plaster walls and jacked up the well-worn wide floorboards, replacing them with freshly sawed lumber. The rat-a-tat-a-tat of a nail gun rips through the salt-swept air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMAN, CONSTANCE FRIESS, M.D.
description: HOLMAN-Constance Friess, M.D. The faculty and staff of New YorkPresbyterian Hospital and Weill Medical College of Cornell University are saddened by the passing of their esteemed colleague, Dr. Constance Friess Holman. Graduating at the top of her class at Cornell University Medical College in 1932, Dr. Friess was also the first woman to be named chief resident in medicine at The New York Hospital. Subsequently, she had a long and distinguished career in private practice in Manhattan while continuing on the medical staff and voluntary faculty of The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. She and her late husband, Dr. Cranston W. Holman, also a distinguished member of the faculty and medical staff, were much beloved by patients, friends, and colleagues alike. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the entire family. New York-Presbyterian Hospital David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman, President & CEO Weill Medical College of Cornell University Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. The Stephen & Suzanne Weiss Dean Ralph I. Nachman, M.D. Chairman, Department of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSAR, BENEDICT T.
description: LASSAR-Benedict T. Dr. Benedict T. Lassar, 93, died peacefully in Puebla, Mexico on July 26. Born in New York, he was a scholar, a lawyer, teacher and psychologist. title: Marley Vale Puts the Pieces Together in Test at Saratoga

description: A Brooklyn landlord and a Queens real estate broker have settled lawsuits filed by a Manhattan fair housing organization that accused them of racial discrimination.

title: The Little White Bombshell
description: Margaret Talbot makes a compelling case for RU-486 having the potential to change the debate over abortion (July 11). Part of that potential, however, derives from the assumption of anonymity associated with a physician prescribing, and a woman taking, a prescription drug. Such anonymity is threatened, if not already gone. The prescribing records of individual physicians are being used today to direct the marketing efforts of pharmaceutical companies, and there is well-founded anxiety among physicians that the records will be used for physician profiling by managed-care organizations (presumably to identify and exclude ''high-cost providers''). It is axiomatic in our society that if information exists, it will find its way into the public domain. How long will it take for a list of RU-486 prescribers to appear on the Operation Rescue Web site?

title: A Vote to Expand M.S. 141 Leads to Charges of Racism
description: Amid charges of racism, Community School Board 10 in the northwest Bronx, the city's largest school district, has voted to expand Middle School 141 in Riverdale to accept students from the 6th through the 12th grade.

title: Let's Make a Deal
description: Opportunity knows no boundaries of place or time. The enterprising have found clients, investors, employees and employers in the oddest of settings -- chance meetings on the subway, supermarket checkout lines or even after a fender-bending collision. What is the most unusual place where you managed -- or at least tried -- to further your fortunes? Or where someone else tried to pursue business with you? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Nation: Fears of Rape and Violence; Women Newly Seeking Asylum
description: NO one denies that their stories are horrific: beatings, rape, genital mutilation or the threat of it. But foreign women seeking asylum on these grounds have received a mixed welcome in the United States.

Under the low ceiling of the Yankees' dugout, they could see Shane Spencer chasing a lazy fly ball toward the left-field corner, until both were hidden from view by the stands.

title: School Bus Seat Bill Deja Vu
description: When City Councilman Stephen J. Fiala, a Republican from Staten Island, entered the Council chamber on July 21 and picked up a meeting agenda, he saw an item that stunned him. It was a bill introduced by Councilman Noach Dear, a Democrat from Brooklyn, to require the Board of Education to provide a seat for every child on a New York City school bus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LODES, FREDERICK G.
description: LODES-Frederick G., born August 15, 1916, deceased July 28, 1999. Graduate of Fordham University. Master of Chemistry Columbia University. Youngest of 9 children. Co-founder of Precision Valve, Yonkers, NY. Co-owner of The Water Wheel Inn, Ardsley, NY. Lifetime member of Knollwood Country Club, Maidstone Golf Club, Winged Foot Golf Club. Past president of The Winter Golf League, Palm Beach, FL. Past board of directors, Bank of New York. Former world consultant on aerosol production. Past president National Chemical Society. Survived by his son Peter Lodes, daughter Patricia Otis, five grandchildren & five great grandchildren. Graveside service, at 1 P.M, Monday, August 2 at Holy Mount Cemetery, Eastchester, NY.

title: The Parent Trap
description: The runaways' parents have their fingers on what causes so many young people to take drastic measure -- only they don't know it. Kids rebel because their parents don't trust them enough to let them breathe, not because they happen to know one boy with the wrong haircut. We in the Denver area recently witnessed what can happen when kids feel isolated and cornered. Unfortunately, the response of your parent interviewees, like that of the Denver school authorities, can only exacerbate the problem. More control, more restrictions and pointing a finger at such trivialities as eccentric costumes can only increase paranoia and isolation. Young people need more choices, not more rules, and a broad base of socializing experience; unless, that is, we want to continue the trend toward living in walled-in communities where schooling and shopping will take place via cable television and where individual difference and the urge to experience the world outside are criminalized.

title: Interpreting the Rocks of New Haven

title: A Life, After Death at Serbs' Hands
description: The green countryside here is strangely quiet; the sounds of children only intermittently pierce the silence. The Yugoslav tanks and Serbian police cars that intimidated the Kosovo Albanians who live here are gone and NATO's troops are scarcely felt or even needed.

title: O.K., Everyone Hold Hands!
description: Q. Save me. My company recently brought in a ''team-building expert'' to work with my department. The guy was straight out of a ''Dilbert'' cartoon, asking us to share all kinds of personal stories and participate in goofy trust-building exercises. I thought the nightmare would end when he left, but my boss seems to have bought into this stuff. She started this morning's staff meeting by having us go around the table and share something about ourselves ''that no one else knows.'' How can I make it clear that I'm uncomfortable with this touchy-feely stuff without alienating my boss?

title: Finally, a Smooth Trip
description: As the Mikhail Gorbachev of American Airlines, after the long, sometimes bare-knuckled rule of Robert L. Crandall as chief executive, Donald J. Carty is finding that glasnost can lead to chaos (labor unrest, late flights, service with a snarl). Even events that seem foolproof have run into annoyances: At a ceremony in March where Mr. Carty announced that Dallas's new arena would be known as the American Airlines Center, one of the airline's new Boeing 777's swooped so low over the site, dipping its wing in salute to those attending, that traffic on a nearby freeway was snarled and nervous residents called the city's emergency number.

description: Muscadet, as Eli Gontmacher might say, is value for money.

description: TELLING

title: The World: Out of Control; The Internet Changes Dictatorship's Rules
description: IT used to be easier to spot the telltale signs of a revolution in the making. There were the Molotov cocktails, the placard-bearing protesters, the fiery speeches, the subversive tapes made by shadowy underground leaders with ski hoods and thrilling stage names. If and when they succeeded, revolutionaries often tightened their grip on power through the mass media: the heroic movies, stirring music raining down from communal loudspeakers, television news cut and tailored to suit the regime.

title: Correction

title: Science Fiction
description: Science fiction once held the franchise on space travel. The first moon landing turned decades of let's-pretend into breaking news. But the dream of sending people to explore nearby worlds seems no closer to reality today than it did in 1969. With the future of manned space exploration on hold -- for lack of funds or lack of vision -- science fiction writers have moved to recapture one of the genre's central themes.

title: A Welcome Perch for Early-Bird Diners
description: VALUE, quality and quantity are what most early-bird diners seek, and they find them at Jonathan's in Garden City Park (742-7300). Its $15.95 three-course fixed-price meal offers not a culinary adventure, but an abundance of wholesome food served with dispatch in a restaurant that consistently displays a spirit of generosity. In keeping with that spirit, Jonathan's does not hide its early bird (as do many) by limiting it to an hour or less on the two or three slowest days of the week. Instead, it is available Monday through Friday from 4:30 to 6:30 P.M. That same outlook is evident at entree and dessert time when diners can choose from 11 main courses and any sweet. A house salad or the soup of the day is the appetizer selection.

title: Word for Word/TV Weather Segues; It's Not the Heat; It's the Verbal Cruelty

title: Delta Seeks Remedy For Excessive Bumping
description: Delta Airlines took the top spot for leaving ticketed passengers behind in the first three months of 1999. The line bumped -- could not board -- 8,144 of its ticketed passengers, while the nine other major airlines together bumped a total of 9,167. Delta's rate was 3.33 passengers for each 10,000 boarded, while the rate for all 10 airlines in the Department of Transportation report was 1.44 for each 10,000. Trans World Airlines had the second-worst rate, with 1,409 passengers bumped, or 2.56 for each 10,000. Continental did best, with a rate of 0.31. Delta's rate for the first quarter a year ago was 1.14 for each 10,000.

title: Lives; House of Cards

Dads with their pale legs showing sip vodka tonics and admire the grill. Elderly aunts wave tissues against the heat. So it was at my cousin's 30th-birthday party, held deep in the work-boot suburbs of Connecticut. I'm not a fan of these functions, though I feel compelled to add that it's not because I don't love my family. It's my family's secrets that trouble me, the way we bury our mistakes in silence, rewrite our private shames through public denial.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Pass the Tums
description: If there's such a thing as a socially acceptable food snob, Robert O. Williams is it. Williams is a diner snob, and in his quest for the best pie, the friendliest waitress, the shiniest expanse of neon and tin, he seems to have covered every inch of the Northeast, from Pennsylvania, where he works as a photographer for The Philadelphia Inquirer, all the way up to the Maine border. As his first book, HOMETOWN DINERS (Abrams, $29.95), demonstrates, Williams has very particular standards. The building itself is crucial. (It helps to have a pedigree from one of the classic manufacturers like Silk City or O'Mahony.) Size counts too, though not in the usual way. (''My take on what makes a hometown diner would exclude any diner that could seat that whole hometown.'') And then there's the ineffable question of atmosphere; even in this age of political correctness, he's nostalgic for ''the mingled smell of coffee and cigarettes.'' Williams does full justice to the finest diner exteriors, but it's his glimpses of the people inside that ice the cake. True to the spirit of across-the-counter banter, he provides detailed captions to tell their stories: the state representative who doubles as a short-order cook at the Capitol Diner, the amateur Santa who climbs on top of Daddypop's Diner every Christmas, the Cordon Bleu chef with the Super Duper Weenie Truck, the folks at the Deerhead Diner in Queens who look as if ''they've just answered a call for a Scorsese movie.'' Williams appreciates the illogic of diners: the Nite Owl is only open from 6 A.M. to 2 P.M.; the garbage at the Melrose is refrigerated. He's judicious on the subject of the great hamburger war between two New Jersey diners and amused by the reactions of the regular patrons at a Massachusetts diner who rebelled every time more ''healthy choices'' appeared on the menu. His own preferences are best suggested by a sign he photographed from the Tick Tock Diner: ''EAT HEAVY.'' Alida Becker

title: The Wearing of the Mantra
description: Partygoers at the Tibet Fund's Aug. 12 dinner at the W Hotel in honor of the Dalai Lama's visit to New York will take home something more tangible than words of wisdom and stomachs stuffed with food prepared by Roger Verge and Emeril Lagasse. The 350 expected to attend, including Richard Gere and Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys, will receive a pendant donated by Me & Ro, a New York jewelry company. A sterling-silver disk on a cotton cord, the pendant is engraved with the Dalai Lama's mantra, ''Om Mani Padme Hung,'' in Tibetan script on one side and in roman characters on the other. (The mantra invokes the lotus, or padme, which symbolizes wisdom.) ''It is the mantra of compassion for all living beings,'' said Caroline Finnegan, the program associate of the fund, which raises money for Tibetan refugees and promotes awareness of Tibetan culture. The necklace, $75, will be available at the fund's Web site (www.tibetfund.org) and Me & Ro's site after Wednesday (www.meandrojewelry.com), or from (877) 632-6376. Proceeds go to the fund. LAUREN DAVID PEDEN

title: July 25-31; Umpires Flip-Flop

Barred from striking, though, they just submitted resignations en masse -- certain that this would be a devastating tactic. But the leagues said, go ahead and quit; we'll hire replacements. No, wait, the umpires said, we didn't mean it. But it was too late: a third of the 66 union umpires are out of the game, though their leader still vows a ''fight to the death.'' HUBERT B. HERRING

This year's ambitious projects include ''The Soft Bulletin,'' on which the Flaming Lips expect listeners to hear their studio effects as a commentary on the tunes and vice versa. Some New York City restaurateurs, calling it a ''crisis,'' are going so far as to offer health insurance to their waiters and establish training courses because they can't hire experienced personnel. And Wall Street sent stock prices reeling last week on the latest news that wages are up slightly more than expected. The market fears that the Federal Reserve will interpret any increase as a reason to be cautious and raise interest rates.

title: Blackboard: Freshman Survival; Everything You Never Knew You Needed
description: College administrators have long sought innovative ways to welcome first-year students into the fold. Thirty years ago, for example, female freshmen at St. Lawrence University were greeted with boxes of Summer Blonde hair dye. ''Everyone showed up to dinner that first night with bottle-blonde hair,'' recalled Nancy Serrell, an alumna. ''My hair stayed blonde for years.'' Today's freshmen orientation kit is thick with policy statements on illicit substances, schedules, campus happenings and other informational essentials, as well as little extras that speak volumes about the college experience. Students at Penn State's distance-learning World Campus get a squishy stress ball and a mouse pad. Students assigned to the Forbes College residential hall at Princeton get fleece jackets. Harvard and Yale, on the other hand, don't give their students anything (except maybe nightmares). ABBY ELLIN

title: The Transformation of Andre Dubus
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY'S ''In Another Country'' was one of Andre Dubus's favorite short stories. It's minimalistic, like many of Dubus's own stories, and it involves the military, a common theme in Dubus's writing. It is set in a wartime hospital in Milan, and its central characters are the narrator, a young American soldier, and an Italian major. Both have been injured, though not fatally. The right hand of the major, who had been Italy's greatest fencer, has been shriveled to the size of a small child's, while the American, a former football player, has lost his calf entirely and can no longer bend his knee. In the hospital are machines that a doctor assures them will heal their damaged limbs. And so the two men meet every day at the machines, the major teaching the American the subtleties of Italian grammar. In the story's final scene, the major suddenly explodes in anger and storms out of the room. He returns to apologize and explain his outburst: his wife had contracted pneumonia and died unexpectedly within just a few days.

title: Tips on Building a Retaining Wall
description: GROUND with a steep pitch or slope can become a problem area if it is often eroded by runoff water from heavy rains. One way to contain the erosion is by leveling the slope with a terrace, then building a retaining wall to hold back the earth at the edge of the terrace. Retaining walls must be strong to hold back the pressure of the earth and water behind them. They may be built of stone, poured concrete, concrete block or rot-resistant lumber. Do-it-yourselfers will find it easier to build a retaining wall of either stone or rot-resistant lumber.

title: Traveling Children
description: To the Editor: I read with dismay ''Taking Children to Exotic Places'' (June 27). As the wife of a physician-researcher, I have also spent much time living and traveling with children in exotic places. Based on my experience, plus information from my husband and colleagues, I am concerned that the author, Martha Stevenson Olson, paid insufficient attention to risks. Yes, travelers with children should be alert to acute problems such as diarrhea and dengue fever. But too many may overlook chronic ills that emerge slowly, such as intestinal parasites or some infectious diseases. And the author did not mention one of the most important steps for all travelers: regular tetanus boosters.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Apocalypse Now
description: Laurence Cosse's witty and casually profound new novel, A CORNER OF THE VEIL (Scribner, $23), is about what happens when a hastily scrawled six-page manuscript lands in the mailbox of a French priest named Bertrand Beaulieu. No ordinary letter, this manuscript contains miraculous, irrefutable proof of the existence of God. Those who read it are instantly transformed, and there is hope that the good news will ''lift both human consciousness and human liberty to their highest level.'' Cosse's novel, deftly translated from the French by Linda Asher, takes us on a tumultuous ride through the Machiavellian worlds of modern French theology and political maneuvering. Cosse skillfully reduces the drama to its bare bones; she brings together a group of French Government ministers to represent the various fields of human power and shows us how they react to this startling document. The Finance Minister fears people will have no reason to work and the economy will collapse; the Justice Minister frets about how the absence of evil will affect the legal system; the Foreign Minister foresees international upheaval as other religions denounce Christian fanaticism and the denial of their own theologies. The Prime Minister, who has read the letter, is more interested in roses and his much-neglected wife, certain ''a world of harmony is about to come into being.'' While the politicians haggle, Beaulieu and his fellow priests try to decide how to handle the document, how best to spread the message while at the same time keeping it under wraps until the perfect moment. That the conflict is resolved by a deus ex machina is only fitting; the irony of a greater -- but not the greatest -- agent's intervention is a spectacular capstone for this fin de si cle romp in the fields of the Lord. Erik Burns
