title: Chestnut Is Gone; Owner Wants to Stay
description: Back in 1994, a campaign ad that featured a telegenic golden retriever named Chestnut helped George R. Nethercutt, a Republican, win Washington State's Fifth Congressional District from the powerful, long-entrenched Democratic incumbent, Speaker Tom Foley. In the spot, Mr. Nethercutt said that Mr. Foley, desperate to win, had accused him of ''everything short of kicking my dog.''

title: IN ECLIPSE -- A special report.; Empty Isles Are Signs Japan's Sun Might Dim
description: After a dazzling century in which Japan emerged on the globe first as a feared military power and then as a formidable economic one, its influence may be on the wane.

title: July 25-31; Indictment for Tripp
description: Linda R. Tripp was indicted by a Maryland grand jury on two charges of illegal wiretapping related to her secret tapings of conversations with Ms. Lewinsky. Mrs. Tripp's spokesman said she would plead not guilty and was the victim of a ''campaign of politically motivated vengeance.'' DAVID JOHNSTON

title: When It Comes to Tax Cuts, Torricelli Thinks of Elections
description: The current debate on Capitol Hill over tax cuts is one of those grand hand-wringing spectacles that Congress does best. Return the surplus to hard-working taxpayers, or shore up Social Security and Medicare? Target cuts to the middle class, or scatter them about everywhere? Protect against future deficits, or stimulate the economy?

title: French Web Site
description: To the Editor: After reading ''Rio to New Delhi, by Desktop'' (June 27), I wanted to tell about another Web site for travel advice: Bonjour Paris, our project, at www.bparis.com. It offers hundreds of articles about France. Bonjour Paris also is a place to share tips, rants, raves and opinions in our chat room and on our discussion boards -- in both French and English. For four hours each week, our chat room is devoted to instruction based on that week's on-line French lesson.

title: Cheryl Belmont, Neil Nichols
description: Cheryl Anne Belmont, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Judson R. Belmont of Meredith, N.H., is to be married this afternoon to Neil Scott Nichols, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Nichols of Roslyn, N.Y. Rabbi Arthur Starr is to officiate at the Goddard Chapel at Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

title: He Went the Distance Before This Race Began
description: Lance Armstrong burst out of Cancerland last week, bicycle wheels buzzing, to win the Tour de France and an immediate place in several different icon queues; not only is he an inspiration to patients and another example of American resurgence in the world sports arena, he is also a role model for celebrities -- he had actually completed the mythological hero's journey that was once the qualifying tournament for superstars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, BENJAMIN
description: LEVITT-Benjamin, Hon. On Thursday, July 29, 1999. Age 94. Devoted and beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father of Col. (Dr.) Morton H. Levitt, and dear fatherin-law of Cynthia Lynn. Cherished grandfather of Lisa Michelle and step grandfather of Nicole Valerie and Tamara Lynn. Graveside ceremony for family only.

title: Restaurant Association Sees Its Persistence Pay Off
description: Standing on a ballroom stage in Las Vegas, Nev., earlier this year, Herman Cain, president of the National Restaurant Association, sang to his members, crooning in a rich baritone: ''If I can see it, I can do it; if I just believe, there's nothing to it.

title: Glorifying Governments Is Also an Art
description: ALL governments engage in, even require, propaganda to reinforce their authority and disseminate their policies. Made by human beings, governments naturally like to look good. They show distinct preferences for glory, no matter what their actual circumstances. So the powers that be build monuments, put victory and liberty on coins, establish patriotic celebrations, fabricate myths.

title: The Road to Vietnam
description: In 1945, as Ho Chi Minh drafted a speech declaring Vietnam's independence from France, his inspiration was not Karl Marx but Thomas Jefferson, from whose Declaration of Independence he quoted extensively.

title: Plan for Elite School in Westchester Divides Haves and Have-Mores
description: On the surface it seems like the kind of straightforward development that most towns would welcome. An elite private day school here, Rippowam Cisqua, wants to build a new high school on more than 100 acres, with a dozen athletic fields and two rambling structures designed to fit in with this town's New Englandy temperament.

title: A Movable Feline
description: To the Editor:

title: Lottery Dispute Chills Workers' Camaraderie
description: The workers at the Pratt Car Service in Brooklyn were singing a sad ballad about money and obsession on Thursday night. Accompanying them on guitar was a fellow worker, Emilio Leyva, the man they blame for a sudden rise -- and a disastrous fall -- in their fortunes.

title: Free Agency Could Reunite Hardaway and O'Neal
description: He could be headed to Toronto for Charles Oakley and Tracy McGrady. Or to Washington for Mitch Richmond. Jerry West met with him last week in Los Angeles, and even though the Lakers appear to be out of the sweepstakes, who knows how sentimental Shaquille O'Neal is for his long-lost teammate?

title: Linguistic Shifts Have Been Around Awhile
description: Timothy Perry's July 25 article on the eastward spread of Brooklyn's linguistic hegemony into Suffolk County [''Brooklyn Tawking Patterns Spread East''] notes a process that has been under way for most of the last century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODLIN, MARA LEIGH WECHSLER
description: MODLIN-Mara Leigh Wechsler. Beloved daughter, granddaughter and sister. We all love you. We will all miss you. Visiting Sunday, 7-9 PM. Service Monday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Laura and Bernie, Norman, Sherri and David, Sid and Esther, Suzanne and David, Nina and Ted, Debbie and David

title: The View From/Bridgeport; With Ridership Rising, Ferry Gets a New Ship
description: THE Bridgeport-Port Jefferson ferry has been growing in popularity as more and more people abandon the hassel of driving to and from Long Island. Indeed, the increase in ridership on the ferry has been so rapid that the Bridgeport-Port Jefferson Steamship Company, which had operated two car-carrying ferries since 1983, has just added the P. T. Barnum -- its biggest ever.

title: Sally Thurston, Mark Power
description: Sally Ann Thurston and Mark Jeremy Power were married yesterday by the Rev. John H. Nieman, a Lutheran pastor, at the Diamond Point Community Church in Diamond Point, N.Y.

title: Funds for Poor Residents To Provide Relief From Heat
description: Because of the recent heat wave, New Jersey will receive $9 million in Federal money to help low-income elderly and disabled residents buy fans or air-conditioners and pay electric bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, MAE
description: FRANKEL-Mae. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend and colleague who, for almost four decades, helped guide MDA and inspired us to do our best for those we serve. Jerry Lewis, National Chairman Robert Ross, Executive Director Jerry Weinberg, Director of Field Organization Muscular Dystrophy Association

title: Setting Federal Policy A Town at a Time
description: It's late and I am locked in a room with barons from AT&T;, discussing a series of consumer-friendly amendments to their cable franchise agreement. Hovering outside of the room are similarly elevated executives from their rivals, SBC Communications, America Online and GTE.

title: Board Delays Vote on Carting Law
description: IT was supposed to have been a vote ending nearly two years of work to keep organized crime out of the garbage carting industry. Instead, last week the Board of Legislators, acting on concerns raised by County Executive Andrew J. Spano, postponed the vote on a licensing law for carters.

title: Traffic? What Traffic?; State May Improve Road to Casino, but Towns Balk
description: THE traffic whizzing past the Rev. Charles Spillers' home on Route 2 in North Stonington is so heavy that the Episcopal priest says he has to pray his way out of his driveway.

title: Traveling Children
description: To the Editor: I spent three months traveling with my baby daughter in India, and have one tip contrary to Martha Stevenson Olson's advice: forget disposable diapers for travel and use cloth diapers instead.

title: Ms. DeCresce And Mr. Ghosh
description: Maureen Elizabeth DeCresce, the daughter of Kathleen and Thomas P. DeCresce of Jersey City, is to be married this afternoon to Subhendu Ghosh, the son of Chitra and Subrata Kumar Ghosh of Calcutta, India. The Rev. Geoffrey B. Curtiss will officiate at All Saints Episcopal Church in Hoboken, N.J., with Pandit Newal Prashad, a Hindu priest, taking part.

title: HUD Vows Suit Over Charas Renovation Money
description: A week after the city completed the sale of the Charas community center to a private developer, a Federal agency said it would demand that the city return grant money used to renovate the building.

title: Of Earlier Times, Both Hers and Music's
description: JAN DEGAETANI: EARLY-MUSIC RECITAL

title: It's the Traffic, Not the Heat, That Makes Miami Torpid
description: While driving in Miami may be a red-faced, stress-filled, curse-under-your-breath-as-you-glare-hatefully-at-other-drivers nightmare, parking has never been easier here in the nation's third-most-congested city.

title: Steps Taken to Prevent Sewage Plant Spills
description: WITH a report in hand pinpointing ways to improve the county's sewage-treatment plants, County Executive Andrew J. Spano has taken several steps to prevent the kind of mishap that last summer caused 120 million gallons of partially treated sewage to spill into the Hudson River.

title: The Parent Trap
description: Let me get this right: these kids aren't allowed to go to the mall and they have 4 o'clock curfews at age 15 (July 11)? What are their parents going to do when they go to college -- move into the dorm with them? I can't blame their kids for running away -- they wanted a couple of days without suffocating parents intent on micromanaging every aspect of their lives.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH J.
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah J. Seven long, lonely, heartbroken years since you left us. No more hugs, kisses or telephone calls-only sweet memories of your kindness and caring. So much we want to tell you, but we say them to your pictures. Your love, compassion and devotion will forever be imprinted in our hearts. Love forever and ever. Mom and Dad

title: New Ferry Is Bigger And Faster
description: FACED with the prospect of a four-hour drive on a recent hot and hazy Saturday morning, Bruce D'Alessio made what he decided was a very wise alternate choice; he drove 20 minutes from his home in Fort Salonga to Port Jefferson, where, still in his car, he boarded a ferry for the one-hour trip to Bridgeport, and then drove another 20 minutes to pick up his daughter, who had spent a week visiting friends in nearby Fairfield.

title: No More Summerfun for Producers
description: ''After 28 years, we've done the trick,'' W. Scott MacConnell said last week about the closing of Summerfun Theater in Montclair, a few days after he announced his resignation from the stage on Tuesday night. The play that night was, eerily enough, ''The Last Night of Ballyhoo,'' and it ended its run last night.

title: A Vote for Day-Trading Screens
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers board approved a rule last week that would require day-trading firms to screen customers to determine if they are suited to the lightning-fast trading style.

title: Ruling Allows Black Employees to Sue Metro-North Railroad in Class Action
description: A Federal appeals court has cleared the way for a class-action suit by minority employees of the Metro-North Railroad who accuse the agency of racial discrimination, particularly in disciplining and promoting employees.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-1-99: Questions for Janeane Garofalo; Cheap Laughs
description: Q: This seems to be one of those moments when everyone in the country is discussing the state of your profession. What do you make of this much-discussed trend toward ''gross-out humor''?

title: We Deserve a Tax Cut, but at What Price?; Exaggerated Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Violations
description: A Yonkers tortilla manufacturer must pay $100,000 in back wages and damages to 12 employees under a consent judgment issued by the Federal District Court in White Plains. The judgment also requires the defendants to pay $5,490 in post-judgment interest and a $2,400 child-labor penalty.

title: Tired of the Same Old Lettuce? Compose a Salad
description: ''IT has been said that the effect of eating too much lettuce is soporific,'' wrote Beatrix Potter at the beginning of ''The Tale of Peter Rabbit.'' Indeed, green salads -- especially those made with the now ubiquitous mesclun mix -- may be good for you, but they can also be quite boring.

title: In Providence, Spring Rolls to Pizza
description: TEN years ago Providence was known for three things: highly regarded colleges, an unmatched trove of Colonial and Federal architecture and Al Forno restaurant. But in recent years this historic port city has been on a tear, restoring the downtown riverfront, erecting shiny new office towers and, most notably for travelers, sprouting a crop of appealing new dining spots.

title: Mahler's Testament To the Abiding Unity Of God and Nature
description: THE Third Symphony is a test of the perfect Mahlerian's devotion,'' wrote the English critic Sir Neville Cardus. Of the same work, the English musicologist Deryck Cooke observed, ''The first movement is the most original and flabbergasting thing Mahler ever conceived.''

title: Seven Beauties
description: OPEN CITY

title: A No-Frills Place for Seafood in Harrison
description: A DINER beleaguered by architectural food and waiters who announce their names may choose Gus's, a relic of a simpler, more direct dining time. In operation for 70 years, the place has changed little, its worn, dark-stained walls and red vinyl reminiscent of the finished basements called rumpus rooms of more than 50 years ago. The place in the Franklin Park section of Harrison is frayed and old-fashioned, to be sure, and an enthusiastic clientele clearly likes it that way.

title: Belly Up
description: They were a bunch of guys who shared a similar quest: to discover good bars for beer. And in 1995, when they created a Website dedicated to this crusade, they could count on one hand the taverns in New York City that had diverse menus of rich-bodied beers, and proprietors who knew that fine ales should not be served at Arctic temperatures.

title: Advertising Is Motive To Keep Sidewalk Sheds Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Loosening the Yoke of the Benchmark
description: LET'S call a truce in the seemingly never-ending war between those who think the market can be beaten and those who don't. Here are the terms: First, all investors must agree to invest major portions of their portfolios -- half or more -- in index funds. Second, devotees of index funds must stop demanding that we sink every single penny into them and, instead, allow us to use active fund managers, those who try to beat the market, for part of our investing.

title: An Unfair Grade
description: To The Editor:

title: Endpaper; They Are Watching Us
description: A middle-class teacher and her working-class student face each other in a large, drafty, grimy high school. The walls had been a bilious green once, before they acquired so many smudges they took on a dappled look. The stairs are basically sturdy, but broken-off linoleum makes them unsafe. The floors have not been swept thoroughly in a long time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERK, SHIRLEY
description: BERK-Shirley. Wife of the late Dr. Alexei, adored mother of Dr. Betsy Kahan and Alexander Berk. Cherished grandmother of Jessica and Rebecca Kahan, Jillian, Matthew and Simon Berk. Services to be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday at 11:30 A.M.

title: Arms Aide Who Quit Assails U.N. on Iraq
description: In a defense of his troubled tenure as chief of the United Nations Special Commission responsible for disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction, Richard Butler has accused Secretary General Kofi Annan of trying to destroy the commission because it was ''too independent.''

title: July 25-31; New Reporting Rules For Shipboard Crimes
description: Facing rising concerns in Congress and elsewhere about crime on ships, the cruise-ship industry adopted a uniform standard for dealing with the investigation and reporting of crimes.

title: Patricia Maloney, Thomas Butler 2d
description: Patricia Marie Maloney and Thomas Clifton Butler 2d were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Brian Barr performed the ceremony.

title: Sandra Denton and Anthony Criss
description: IN many ways, the rappers Sandra (Pepa) Denton, of Salt-n-Pepa, and Anthony (Treach) Criss, of Naughty by Nature, live up to their nicknames. She is peppery, and he seems treacherous.

title: Margaret Wyrwas, Peter Thorner
description: Margaret Ethel Wyrwas, a financial executive, and Peter Thorner, a retailing executive, were married yesterday at their house in Westport, Conn. The bride's father, the Rev. Dr. Gerald G. Wyrwas, a Presbyterian minister who is the director of pastoral care at Holy Family Hospital in Methuen, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Trial With Fire
description: The practice space for the Mock Trial team of Bushwick High School in Brooklyn is a storeroom for pen-scarred desks and ruined textbooks. Paint-caked rollers and pans sit on out-of-commission lockers. The one gesture toward a simulated courtroom is the makeshift podium of 2-by-4's and fake pine paneling.

title: Bad Day at the Coffee Shop
description: After 15 years of struggle, Leocadia Milanes's life in the United States was going pretty well. Until last Tuesday.

title: Liberties; Pretty Mean Woman
description: On Friday afternoon I went to see ''Runaway Bride.'' It wasn't hooky. It was work.

title: Pettitte's Still a Yank; Leyritz Is Again
description: The Yankees reacquired Jim Leyritz today to augment their bench, and even though the trade dominos remained in place right up until the midnight trade deadline for a possible swap of Andy Pettitte, the Yankees retained the left-hander rather than deal him to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Heavy Smog Adds Insult To Misery
description: As New Yorkers endure one of the hottest summers on record, they are also suffering a curse that compounds their lethargy and sense of ill-being: the worst smog in more than a decade.

title: July 25-31; A Spot for the Ethically Challenged
description: Oh, how this society loves its sports stars! It pays them in a single day what, say, a good music teacher earns in a year. It puts them on towering pedestals. It deifies them.

title: Mets Bolster Their Bullpen and Outfield In a Flurry of Deals at the Deadline
description: Mets General Manager Steve Phillips said he was not done dealing after he obtained Kenny Rogers from Oakland eight days ago. He was telling the truth.

title: After Chinese Spy Scandal, New Support for Test Ban Treaty
description: In the wake of the Chinese spy scandal, support is growing in the United States for ratification of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, a global accord meant to end the development of new kinds of nuclear arms. The process of treaty deliberation and approval had been moribund for nearly two years, but is now showing signs of life.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMON, WILLIAM
description: SIMON-William. August 1, 1992. Bill, our wonderful memories & love for you will always keep you alive in our hearts & minds. Mom & Elli

title: Theo Fleury: Little Big Man
description: For me, the essence of Theo Fleury emerged in an interview with Linda Baker, his Manitoba kindergarten teacher. I was researching my biography of the well-known, little-understood National Hockey League player who recently signed with the Rangers. Linda had vivid memories of that shrimp of a kid who sat before her so quietly in his obvious hand-me-down clothes, the smallest boy in a tiny country school.

title: Where the Rickey Still Reigns
description: A fountain drink once synonymous with New York, the lime rickey has disappeared from all but a handful of local restaurants. With reports from East Harlem, the East Village, Gramercy Park, Union Square, Times Square, Chelsea, Woodside, Coney Island and Riverdale.

title: Ideas & Trends; 'Rages' Maybe Aren't What They're Cracked Up to Be
description: WHEN Mark O. Barton, a securities day trader, walked into two Atlanta brokerage firms on Thursday and shot and killed nine people, it surely seemed to some like another gruesome indicator of a trend toward workplace violence and rage.

title: What They Say About Stanley Kubrick
description: Peter Bogdanovich's article on Stanley Kubrick (July 4) describes an incident involving Kubrick and me as told by Lee Ermey. While the anecdote is interesting, it is false. I was much too young and inexperienced to have ever challenged a great filmmaker like Kubrick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, HELEN GUZIK
description: ROSENZWEIG-Helen Guzik. On July 31, 1999. She was a resident of Florida for 19 years, originally residing in Queens, NY. Beloved wife of William. Loving mother of Laura and Ardie, Mickey and Barbara. Dear sister of Eleanor and Florence. Cherished grandmother of Joshua, Melissa and Brett, Stacie and Steven. Services Monday, 12 noon, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expy., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Criticism and the Age
description: REMEMBERING RANDALL

title: Ericka Bloomfield, David Herman
description: Ericka Joslin Bloomfield, a daughter of Andrea and Matthew Bloomfield of Great Neck, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to David Abraham Herman, the son of Louise and William Herman of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman is to perform the ceremony at Temple Judea in Manhasset, N.Y.

title: The World; Latin America's Leftists Say Adios To Revolution
description: IF looks alone were what mattered, Jose Mujica could still play a Tupamaro rebel in some new Costa Gavras film about Uruguay's desperate revolutionaries. Never mind that this one-time guerrilla is now a member of Congress who monitors the budget of the same military that once tortured him. True to his old style, Mr. Mujica still chain smokes, rarely shaves and wears grubby, carelessly fitted blue jeans to the office.

title: Fit for a New Start
description: As more businesses find clients over the Internet, and as customers increasingly take to the Web to compare prices and offerings, traditional face-to-face sales representatives are finding their jobs endangered. Two sales-intensive businesses where the future may be dim are insurance and investments.

title: The Bellagio
description: To the Editor: After a delightful weekend at Bellagio Resort Hotel in Las Vegas, we were dismayed to read Peter Marks's article about it (''Playing Poker With the Medicis,'' June 13). We couldn't disagree more.

title: A Chance for Different Worlds to Meet
description: Zecharia Smith was 9 years old when she spent part of the summer of 1992 with Catherine Drake and her husband, Richard Levine, as part of a Fresh Air Fund program. She had not spent much time outside her Harlem neighborhood, so when she arrived at the family's home in Toms River, N.J., her first request was to be taken to the park.

title: FILM; A Little Piece of Paradiso On a Plaza in Hoboken
description: A MOVIE lets out in a dusty Sicilian village, and a clamoring crowd screams for a second showing, pounding with clenched fists on the doors of the Cinema Paradiso. The owner says it is closed, so the theater's devil-may-care projectionist turns to his young apprentice and, smirking, proceeds to turn the movie projector to one side. As if by magic, the image slowly moves from the screen in the shuttered cinema to its adjacent wall, then outside the window from one building to the next, finally landing on the front of a pensione opposite the town square. The mob runs the length of the square, shouting with glee.

title: St. Louis Exhibits Tell Stories of City and Arch
description: The wait to ride the tram to the top of the Gateway Arch in St. Louis has become more entertaining with the addition of two new exhibitions in the waiting area.

title: July 25-31; Benefits for Beijing
description: Relations between China and the United States are at a low, but the House voted 260 to 170 to extend trade benefits for another year. The annual renewal of trade privileges came amid allegations that China stole American nuclear secrets, and critics said the move would reward an oppressive Government. But supporters said engaging China was more productive than isolating it. ERIC SCHMITT

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 18 about Stanley Kubrick and his unmade film ''A.I.'' misstated the given name of a digital effects consultant from Industrial Light and Magic who met with Kubrick. He is Ned Gorman, not Ed.

title: The Other Brittens, Not So Well Known
description: AS a composer, Benjamin Britten is not without detractors among critics and concertgoers. But by any reasonable measure he is a major figure, a 20th-century master whose arresting operas, brilliant symphonic works, inventive chamber music and literate songs hold deserved places in the repertory.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Kings Point home of the composer George M. Cohan misidentified the structure shown. It is the carriage house on the Cohan estate, not the mansion itself.

title: Finding a Metaphor for Life in a Trip to a Funeral
description: PART enfant terrible and part national treasure, Patrice Chereau has built a formidable reputation in France, with three decades of groundbreaking work in theater, opera and, increasingly, film. His latest movie, ''Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train,'' had just had its premiere at the Cannes International Film Festival last year when Mr. Chereau went out to buy a book in Paris.

title: Crime Takes a Holiday in a Precinct, but the Police Don't
description: Local residents say one of two things has happened in the 111th Precinct: either the police have done an excellent job of reducing auto theft or there are no cars left in the Douglaston, Bayside, Little Neck and Oakland Gardens neighborhoods of Queens.

title: Be Kind to Some Little Ravenous Guests
description: AS the month of August begins, gardeners may have a tendency to relax. After all, they have been busy all spring and summer and it would now seem the time to step back and view the rewards.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: More Buyers Asking: Got Milk Without Chemicals?
description: TIMES were tough in 1994 at the Straus Family Creamery. ''The price we were getting for our milk wasn't paying the cost of production,'' said Vivien E. Straus, who struggled along with her father and brother to keep their then 50-year-old farm in Marshall, Calif., solvent.

title: In the Internet Gold Rush, Fund Customers Find a Research Treasure
description: CLICK on ''buy.'' Click on ''sell.'' Click on ''payoff.''

title: Quiz; The 39 Questions
description: 1. In the psychological thriller ''Spellbound,'' who collaborated with Hitchcock on the dream sequences, which included a game of 21 played with blank cards?

title: Gun-Control Deal Uncertain For Bills in House and Senate
description: As Americans puzzled over the latest deadly shooting spree, House leaders appointed representatives on Friday to a conference between House and Senate lawmakers on gun control, a long-delayed, pivotal step toward the enactment of any new restrictions on firearms by this Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNN, VICTOR M.
description: LYNN-Victor M. On July 28, 1999. Beloved husband of Raquelle, father of Nicholas and Giannina. His extended family included daughters Barbara and Wendy, and sons-in-law Gary and Chris and grandchildren Lauren, David and Jenny. He had a productive and successful career as an account executive at a number of prominent New York advertising agencies. Later he was a Senior V.P. of Marketing and Planning at R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, from which he retired in 1989. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St on Tuesday, August 3, 3:30 P.M., when friends & family will celebrate an extraordinarily beloved man and a life filled with intellect and compassion. Donations in his honor may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-1-99: On Language; Bill-o' Rights
description: Sir William Blackstone, working away at his ''Commentaries on the Laws of England'' in 1765, had to deal with a list of stated rights passed by Parliament in 1689 in ''An Act Declaring the Rights and Liberties of the Subject and Settling the Succession of the Crown.'' Just as Parliament settled on William and Mary of Orange as King and Queen, Blackstone settled on the list of powers to which their subjects were entitled as ''the bill of rights.''

title: Hearing on Museum Adjourned
description: A court hearing in the dispute between factions of the Bergen Museum board was adjourned on Thursday morning. Lawyers for both sides sought the adjournment, said Judge Gerald C. Escala of State Superior Court in Hackensack.

title: A Filmmaker's Paean to Jones Beach at 70
description: LIKE millions of others who live in the area, George Pozderec had fond memories of his childhood visits to Jones Beach.

title: Life Among the Lifers Was Good
description: Alan August spent 19 years of his life locked in conversation with convicted murderers. Not only didn't he mind it, he misses it.

title: Laundry Room Services
description: CO-OP and condominium boards are generally considered to be sticklers for detail when conducting the business of their buildings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, GILBERT
description: ROSENBERG-Gilbert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Gilbert Rosenberg, associated with The Times from 1968 until retiring in 1984.

title: Latest in Technology Keeps a Sharp Eye On a Changing Sea; Five Miles Off the Coast of Tuckerton, One of the Most Intimate Looks at the Atlantic
description: ARMED with the latest high-tech wizardry, including swimming robots and equipment that evolved from the search for the Titanic, scientists and engineers have opened an undersea window about five miles off the New Jersey coast.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: HOLLYWOOD CARTOONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREISMAN, BERNARD
description: GREISMAN-Bernard age 82, of Fort Lee, N.J. Survived by his devoted wife Ruth of 58 years, cherished children Stewart, Cheryl and Andrew Konstandt; and adored Poppy of Matthew, Brad, Courtney and Sami. Services are 12:30 P.M. Sunday Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. #

title: Finding His Missing Desire in the Mountains
description: Lance Armstrong's victory last Sunday in the three-week Tour de France was especially dramatic because of his return from testicular cancer that had spread to his abdomen, lungs and brain.

title: Miss Moran, Mr. Van Leuven
description: Margaretta Gary Moran and Thomas Carter Van Leuven were married yesterday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Joseph P. O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: The A la Carte column last Sunday misstated the date of the opening of Tellers, a restaurant in Islip. It opened in mid-July, not mid-May.

title: Valerie Oltarsh, Robert McCarthy
description: Valerie Daniels Oltarsh and Robert McCarthy were married on Friday in New York at the home of the bride's parents, Naomi and Kenneth Oltarsh. Judge Robert J. Ward of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Placing Bets On the Red And Green
description: IN a city of 11,000 intersections with traffic signals, many of them busier than this one, it may seem like a little thing. But not to the residents of Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, where pedestrians have long been obliged to outrun the traffic when walking across Bartel-Pritchard Square, at the 15th Street entrance to Prospect Park.

title: Cheating Death, Uruguayan Style
description: You don't have be able to tell the murga from the candombe, and it's not necessary to understand Spanish to get the message of ''Tiene la Muerte Atada'' (''They've Got Death Bound Up'').

title: The Flying Scotsman Returns After 3 Years
description: The first steam locomotive to haul a passenger train nonstop from London to Scotland is back in service after three years of restoration. From London, passengers can now take luxury day trips aboard Pullman-style carriages to various destinations.

title: A Man at Home Wherever There's a Melody
description: BEHIND every great pop artist is a great backup group. Its leader, who may also sing and even play, is aptly called the M.D., for music director. At Westbury Music Fair on Saturday, Roberta Flack will be the one out front, but behind her will be a group directed by Shelton Becton, a mild-mannered but electrifying pianist who conducts, composes, sings, arranges charts and transforms ordinary tunes into blazing numbers that lift you off your seat.

title: 'Devolving' to the States Isn't the American Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Attention, Wannabe Gazillionaires; A Company That Captures the Spirit of the Age
description: To: Potential Investors

title: Gilbert Barclay Mustin, 78, Developed Fleer Baseball Cards
description: Gilbert Barclay Mustin, who led the Fleer Corporation, creators of Dubble Bubble gum, in successfully challenging the dominance of Topps Chewing Gum Inc. in the multimillion dollar baseball card business, died Wednesday at a hospital in Bryn Mawr, Penn. He was 78 years old and lived in Haverford, Penn., and Westport Point, Mass.

title: Media Companies Adding Web Cachet
description: INVESTORS in search of long-term growth in Internet companies may want to heed this adage: Brands rule.

title: All He Wanted Was a Little Respect
description: MAYOR Milton Milan was on vacation last week, having wrapped up a stressful game of chicken with the state of New Jersey. He went to the office anyway and, shirtsleeves rolled up, was able to reflect on why he had filed for his city's bankruptcy and challenged its overseers in Trenton to take over his operation.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Munsey Park, N.Y.; High Standards, Eye to Tradition
description: HOMEOWNERS in less exalted parts of Long Island haul their trash to the curb, mindful of collection schedules that must be met.

title: Commercial Property; The Garment District Tries on Some New Togs
description: THERE is a battle under way for the soul of the garment district, that famously congested segment of Manhattan between Times Square and Penn Station, Fifth and Eighth Avenues.

title: Giants' Johnson Recovers And Finds Himself at No. 1
description: Last year, LeShon Johnson spent the end of July in a hospital bed awaiting the third of seven chemotherapy treatments. He had lost 20 pounds in 10 days and all the hair on his head.

title: Fassel Has Urgent Lesson Plan for Success
description: This is how good a teacher Giants Coach Jim Fassel is: He has not only worked out the kinks in the throwing arm of Kerry Collins, but he is also ironing out the creases in the quarterback's head. When Collins was with the Carolina Panthers he was known more for his drinking and his sloppy play than anything else. Today his former teammates might not recognize him; Collins looks like a completely different person.

title: Partners in the Engine Room of Rap
description: POP-MUSIC history tends to focus on glamorous vocalists and visionary songwriters, but the evolution of black pop is another story: it's as much about changes in rhythm and production. From the distinctive house sounds of Motown and Philadelphia International to the Chic Organization's streamlined disco style, it's a history made by session musicians and studio technicians: producers, engineers, and, not least, their machines. Typically, a rising producer finds unforeseen potential in the latest technology, rewrites the rules of rhythm and dominates the soundscape for several years.

title: Estate Becomes Parkland
description: AFTER three years of delicate negotiation that brought together municipal, county and state governments in an unusually cooperative coalition, the property formerly known as the Gaisman Estate here becomes public parkland tomorrow.

title: Miss Clara, No Pit Bull, Is Finally Vindicated
description: LOOKING back on the legal imbroglio involving the $16 million dog, what really rankles is not the anxiety, or the agita, or even the bills. It's the sheer unfairness of it all. Because Clara was a complete cream puff.

title: Chance to Be Immersed in Choral World
description: ESTABLISHED professionals meet with emerging artists at the second annual Dennis Keene Choral Festival -- and music lovers are the beneficiaries.

title: July 25-31; Clinton Fined for Contempt
description: President Clinton settled Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit last year for $850,000, hoping to be done with the sordid business that ultimately led to his impeachment. But the Federal judge who would have presided over the Jones trial had it not been settled added to that cost last week.

title: Man Accused of Sex Attack at Woodstock
description: A New York prison guard has been charged with sexually assaulting a 15-year-old who had left the rampaging crowds at Woodstock '99 last weekend to find a bathroom, officials said.

title: Land of the Free Market
description: The conservative dictum that urban sprawl is but the collective expression of the free market is more fiction than fact (Michael Pollan, July 11). Let us not forget that it was the Government, in an attempt to resuscitate a crippled economy in the 1930's, that deliberately jump-started America's taste for suburbia. The Government has historically promoted suburbia and its attendant necessities through programs that provide guaranteed loans and mortgages to home builders and home buyers and financing for highway construction over public transportation. It also provides public infrastructure to residential developments in ever more remote exurbias. In a ''free market,'' equally informed consumers make choices among a number of options. But it is nonetheless clear that Government has always played a role in limiting or opening up certain of these options.

title: Families Are Key to Better Care for the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Damian Loeb and Moby; Life Imitating Art Imitating Life
description: AT Damian Loeb's spare TriBeCa studio on a recent Saturday night, Mr. Loeb, a painter, was putting some final strokes on a work for an upcoming show in London. His best friend, Richard Hall, the electronic music star known as Moby, zoned out before a large-screen television hooked up to a spy camera, allowing him to watch people walking by on the street, a form of entertainment that Mr. Loeb prefers to real television.

title: The Star Treatment
description: With new fall duds and personal stylists, these babes are ready for their close-ups.

title: 'Casino Mentality' Linked To Day Trading's Stresses
description: The pause in the relentless stream of stock tips scrolling up the screen in the Internet chat room called Daytraders was brief, and it was mechanically enforced. But after the shooting spree this week at two Atlanta firms that specialize in the rapid-fire buying and selling of stocks known as day trading, several hundred on-line investors observed a virtual moment of silence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, ROBERT BENJAMIN, DR.
description: PFEFFER-Robert Benjamin, Dr. Clinical Professor of Surgery at New York University School of Medicine, and former President of the Medical Board and Chief of Surgery at Beth Israel Medical Center North, died Friday at Tisch Hospital of the New York University Medical Center. An open memorial will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapels, 333 Amsterdam Ave. (at 76th St.), NYC, at 12 noon on Tuesday, August 3.

title: New Housing That Doesn't Break the Bank
description: WHEN the subject is housing, ''project'' is a word Frank J. Carito hates. ''It conveys a negative image of low-cost housing,'' he said. ''For years we've been working to get rid of the assumption that low-cost housing is undesirable housing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELIS, LILLIAN
description: MICHAELIS-Lillian. The Officers, Directors and Administration of the Gurwin Jewish-Fay J. Lindner Residences extend their sympathy to Seymour Rubin, fellow board member, on the loss of his beloved sister, Lillian. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Martin Eglow, President Joseph Gurwin, Chairman Herbert H. Friedman, Exec V.P.

title: On Foot In Inishmore
description: ONE thing I wondered, as the boat plowed over the sea to Inishmore: Was I capable, at 5 foot 1 and 47 years, of doing the kind of walking tour I wanted to do? Solo, with no one to carry my pack, stopping where I felt like it? I had slimmed my load down to about 20 pounds; I had carried it halfway around the globe. Was that preparation enough?

title: Sweaty July in New York City Goes Down as the Worst Ever
description: July was the hottest month ever recorded in New York City, meteorologists said yesterday. And barring a late-night storm, it was also the driest.

title: 'Galleries' Duck Liquor Rule
description: Getting a liquor license often involves a long and expensive application process and heavy community opposition, especially in neighborhoods with many bars, like the easternmost blocks just below Houston Street.

title: A Bonding Fest for Saturn Owners
description: IF America's streets and highways seemed devoid of Saturns on Friday and Saturday, it was because tens of thousands of the cars were converging on sleepy Spring Hill, Tenn., with headlights shining and horns honking.

title: The Mayor's Makeover
description: As I sat in the office of New York's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, on a blazing morning early last month, the Mayor's press secretary, Sunny Mindel, kept impatiently rattling a copy of a local tabloid. It was evidently some kind of prop, but at first Giuliani ignored her.

title: Let the Humans Be Minimalists
description: New at the dog run: Pet Gem, gold-plated earrings for dogs and cats that clip onto ears, fur or collars. First distributed in regional Midwestern pet stores last fall, the jewelry's popularity spurred its wider release last month, in New York at Petco stores and overseas (for orders, 877-773-8436).

title: Ellen Hyde, Anthony Pace
description: Ellen Troy Hyde and L. Anthony Pace, advertising executives, were married last evening at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York. The Rev. Robert P. Hyde Jr., a brother of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Service Providers Offer Many Options and Many Prices
description: DEVELOPERS, owners and managers of residential buildings -- even residents themselves -- confront a mind-bending array of information technologies and service providers. Just how confusing is the field? Consider the main competitors for residential television service in Manhattan right now -- cable and direct satellite service, or D.S.S.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: EAST VILLAGE

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Aleister Crowley The Beast Demystified. By Roger Hutchinson. Mainstream/Trafalgar Square, $35.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WRACK

title: To Read Trash, Greenwich Goes to Dump
description: ON a recent sweltering hot Monday morning, the Jaguars and Mercedeses were pulling into the parking lot in Greenwich one after the other. Never mind that this was not a party under a striped tent overlooking sculptured English gardens.

title: Where Are the Beret Factories of Yesteryear?
description: FRANCE ON THE BRINK

title: Celebrating an Impresario of the Outdoors
description: TO many New Yorkers, Lincoln Center Out of Doors has always been there -- an extravaganza every August that offers a diverse fare of free dance, music and theater. The forthcoming series, Carnival of the Century, starting Friday through Aug. 29, is solidly within that tradition. It includes the jazz pianist Dave Brubeck, a Greek blues singer, Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, music of the Jewish Diaspora, a Peruvian dance company and the Colorado String Quartet, plus entertainment for children.

title: Child-Friendly Store With Young Minds in Mind
description: Manhattan's second branch of the Noodle Kidoodle toy store opened in June at 2407 Broadway (between 88th and 89th Streets). The bright yellow store carries a variety of toys, games and videos intended to help children learn.

title: New Construction Of Habitat Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: IN MY... LAPTOP CASE/DAVID SAMUEL
description: To catalogue the toys that David Samuel carries in his oversized laptop bag, it may make the most sense to start with the yo-yo and work up to the bite-sized portable music player that stores songs on a computer chip.

title: Bad Start and Worse Finish Send Mets Back to 2d Place
description: He is tantalizingly close to his first post-season appearance in the major leagues. But to hear Mets Manager Bobby Valentine tell it before today's game, there is no fun in baseball; it is just a job.

title: Children Flying With Allergies
description: DR. PHILIP R. FISCHER of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., believes that at least 15 percent of all children have significant allergies. But these children are divided into two groups, experts emphasize: those whose parents are aware and expect to cope, and the rest, who have not yet met their allergens and may do so far from home, creating a crisis.

title: A Potentially Costly Lawsuit
description: The decision by Louis Navellier, the fund manager, to press a lawsuit against the independent directors who tried to oust him from the Navellier Aggressive Small Cap Equity fund in 1997 might prove expensive -- for either the fund's shareholders or Mr. Navellier himself.

title: Export Rules Are Said to Be a Threat to Satellite Industry
description: Only months after tighter restrictions on satellite exports took effect, concern is growing within the aerospace industry and in Congress that the new rules are entangling manufacturers in red tape, delaying launchings and hurting American satellite makers in foreign markets.

title: Proposed Music Center Breeds Disharmony
description: ARE violins and vegetables incompatible? As the Perlman Music Program prepares to start its fifth season in the Hamptons this week, it is embroiled in a dispute that could affect both its own future and the landscape of Sagaponack, a onetime farming community now under pressure from residential development.

title: Streetscapes /1 Wall Street; A Bank's Art Deco Signature
description: A DECADE ago, the Bank of New York took over the Irving Trust Company, in a move that gave it not just another bank, but, last year, a new headquarters address: Irving Trust's 1931 skyscraper, 1 Wall Street. Now the Bank of New York is spending $1.9 million to repair the outside of the Art Deco limestone structure, which also has a striking set of little-known Art Deco interiors.

title: While Some Live for Art, Others Live in It
description: Sandwiched between a parking garage and warehouses a few hundred yards from crumbling piers on the Hudson, the building at 436 West 15th Street hardly looks like a candidate for an art commune. But if Bob Vila and Marcel Duchamp were to collaborate on an experiment in free living, it might be something like the installation by the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija at Gavin Brown's gallery here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, DOROTHY
description: SCHWARTZ-Dorothy. On July 31, 1999, at 95. Wife of the late Murray Schwartz. Mother of Barbara Machlin. Grandmother of Jason Sheckley. Private cremation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRACKETT, ALMA
description: BRACKETT-Alma. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alma Brackett, associated with The Times from 1947 until retiring in 1983.

title: Propelling Exchanges Into the Era Of the Chip
description: AMERICA'S biggest securities exchanges are under attack for the way they do business. The day of the buttonwood tree, under which the New York Stock Exchange was founded in 1792, are long gone, and the days of the specialist seem to be fading. The era of the button -- otherwise known as electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s -- seems to be moving in fast.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRANKEL, BERTHA
description: FRANKEL-Bertha. Dearest Mom, seven years have gone by. Miss you and think of you always. Your loving daughter.

title: Emily Epstein, Paul Landau
description: Emily Sarah Epstein and Paul Stuart Landau are to be married today at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Judge David G. Trager of Federal District Court in Brooklyn is to officiate.

title: Albert Harrison Jr., Maritza Okata
description: Maritza Uloma Barroso Okata, the daughter of Sueli McMurray Barroso Okata of Rio de Janeiro and Levi Ohazurume-Eze Okata of Enugu, Nigeria, was married on Thursday to Albert Leroy Harrison Jr., a son of Luvinia L. Harrison and Mr. Harrison Sr., both of Richmond. The Rev. Delbert W. Blair, a minister of the Deliverance Evangelistic Association, officiated at Destiny, a house in Montego Bay, Jamaica.

title: Plain Clothes for Police Unit Considered
description: A tentative plan to put some Street Crime Unit officers back in plain clothes is being greeted by many New York City police officers as an important first step in restoring the unit's effectiveness.

title: Protecting Computers, and Privacy
description: The Clinton Administration is right to concern itself with protecting America's computer networks against cyber attacks by terrorists or foreign governments. But a draft plan now being considered by the White House could lead to Federal monitoring of much of the nation's governmental and commercial computer communications. Such broad governmental surveillance is not a reliable way of assuring computer security and intrudes too deeply into the privacy of law-abiding Americans.

title: Calais Replies
description: To the Editor: Marialisa Calta's article about St. Andrews, ''In Canada, a Resort Town by a Bay'' (June 27), was recently brought to my attention. I agree that St. Andrews is a wonderful spot, but I was sorry to hear about the terrible experience she had in Calais. It was not indicative of how our Calais people are. I've lived here for 24 years by choice because of the area's charm, but also because of the warmth of the people.

title: Agricultural Board
description: The Board of Legislators passed a law last Monday creating the County Agricultural and Farmland Protection Board.

title: The Little White Bombshell
description: In Margaret Talbot's article regarding RU-486, there was only a passing mention of the Preven emergency contraceptive pill. This legal and F.D.A.-approved alternative can eliminate the need for women to have to make a decision at all about abortion, and it is available in 9 out of 10 of all the major pharmaceutical distribution chains in the United States now. Most women in the U.S. do not even seem to realize that this prescription is available, and that they can request it from their doctors and keep it on hand. The emotional and physical trauma of abortion no longer needs to be endured.

title: Recent Works With an Air of Familiarity
description: ''IN THE OLD STYLE'' is the title of a 1998 diptych by Barbara Klein, but its title gives a clue about why this year's New Jersey Fine Arts Annual is such an unengaging exhibition. Although the painting itself is among the better things at the State Museum here, the dowdy context seems to take the air out of even much of the best work on view.

title: Is It Only a Game?
description: Right in the middle of a game, Brian Bell realized he had lost his motivation to play football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLACTER, ARTHUR BERNARD
description: SCHLACTER - Arthur Bernard. Age 78. On July 30, 1999. Of Boca Raton, FL. Previously of Forest Hills, N.Y. Beloved husband of Regina. Loving father of Arlene Morelli and Jeffrey Saks. Dear father-in-law of Benedict Morelli & Rita Saks. Devoted grandfather of Justin and Alexander Morelli and Oliver Saks. Brother of Irwin Schlacter. Services 10:45AM Monday at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Friends may visit 7-9PM Sunday. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations in Arthur's memory be made to a cancer research foundation of one's choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROENER, ANITA
description: KROENER-Anita. This gracious lady was born on February 28, 1911 in Vienna, Austria. She passed away peacefully on July 20, 1999. Anita was the beloved wife of the late Otto Kroener and the late Dr. Stefan Kornhauser. She was the sister of the late Erika Anderson. She is survived by her nephew Dr. Herbert A. Schneider (Diane), her grandnephews Dr. David Schneider and Kenneth Schneider (Marcia Jarmel), her grandniece Jana Hopfinger and her great-grandnephew Mica Jarmel Schneider. She will be remembered with joy and tenderness by the many friends whom she left behind. Her warmth and outgoing personality uplifted the spirits of all those whom she touched. She was a true woman of valor and will be sorely missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DABNEY, MARIAN JEAN
description: DABNEY-Marian Jean. Died unexpectedly July 28 in Peoria, IL. Daughter of James V. Tomai and Cecilia Ziegler Tomai, and wife of the late Seth M. Dabney III. She grew up in Glen Rock, NJ and graduated from Montclair State Teachers College and NYU Law School. She practiced law with AT&T for 39 years between 1945 and 1984, at which point she retired and moved to Peoria. She was a member of The Country Club of Peoria, The Peoria Women's Club, The Peoria Symphony Guild and Westminster Presbyterian Church of Peoria. She is survived by two sons, Seth M. Dabney IV of Oxford, MS, and James W. Dabney of Ridgewood, NJ; a brother James V. Tomai Jr. of Wyckoff, NJ; and three grandchildren. Contributions may be made in her memory to NYU Law School, 161 Avenue of the Americas, 5th Floor, NYC, 10013. Services are being held August 1 at 5 PM at Westminster Presbyterian Church of Peoria.

title: We Deserve a Tax Cut, but at What Price?; Help the Overtaxed
description: To the Editor:

title: Defending Kubrick
description: To the Editor:

title: In Russian East, Chinese Help for Toiling Farmers
description: Zhuang Yimin reaches into the pigpen and pulls out a piglet, which squeals frantically as he clips its tiny teeth with gardening shears. He drops it onto its mother's ample belly and picks up its sibling for another deft display of the pig-management skills he brought here from Harbin, China.

title: A Suburban Shelter Just for Children
description: WHEN two of her three daughters died in a plane crash with John F. Kennedy Jr., the mother of Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Lauren G. Bessette decided she could at least help other children through her family's loss.

title: Lime Rickey, Drink of Yore
description: While the egg cream has become the official beverage of New York nostalgia, another fountain drink once synonymous with the city, the lime rickey, has been all but forgotten. Yet this blend of fresh lime, seltzer and cherry syrup was once a staple on local menus.

title: Carousel of History To Spin at Station
description: CAROUSELS have long been woven into American mythology: Where else can you reach out from your station toward an elusive brass ring and snatch a free ride? Starting on Friday, Grand Central Terminal will be the temporary home of an exhibition, ''The Turn of the Century: A Carousel Celebrating 100 Years of Ups and Downs.''

title: Revenge of the the Lawn Rager
description: IT was a beautiful day in the neighborhood. The sun was shining down on an eclectic collection of watering devices that were whirring, chipping and fanning away at the lush, green holy grails of suburbia: the lawns.

title: Good Reason to Hold On to That Early Stephen King
description: BROWSING at a book fair one day, Chris Offutt, the author of ''Out of the Woods,'' a collection of short stories, discovered the value of his library of contemporary fiction. ''I'd pick something up and it was marked $100,'' he recalled. ''And I said, 'Hey, I have that, only my copy is signed.' '' Now he treats his books with a new respect. ''I figure they can help put my kids through college. Writing won't.''

title: The World; Welcome Home, Pacifist. Ready to Fight for Power?
description: IBRAHIM RUGOVA, where have you been?

title: Late to Bed, Early to Rise Makes a Teen-Ager ... Tired
description: In the rolling hills of affluent northern Westchester County, students at John Jay High School face a daunting daily challenge: They get up at 5:15 A.M. -- in the dark much of the year -- to catch buses that get to school in time for their first class, at 7:15. After three classes, including intellectual minefields like calculus, they eat lunch at 9:30. Kids call it brunch, though it is apt to be spaghetti.

title: Whispering 'Discount'
description: Loehmann's may be on the way out, and with it all the group dressing rooms and merchandise mayhem of conventional discount outlets. On the way in: Find, a new outlet boutique in Chelsea, which offers a 50 to 80 percent discount on overstocked clothing by designers like Daryl K., Helmut Lang, Tocca, Pixie Yates and Vivienne Westwood in a Wallpaperesque environment, complete with dressing rooms, green tea and -- gasp -- knowledgeable sales help. Housed in an airy loft at 361 West 17th Street, once the Rodriguez deGranier Art Gallery, Find has become the latest resource for fashion stylists and editors. ''They carry all the of-the-moment brands,'' said Selene Milano, a fashion editor at Elle magazine, who recently bought two pairs of Stephane Kelian shoes there. Designers like the idea because it allows them to unload overstock without the trouble of a sample sale or an image-tarnishing display in a bargain-basement store. ''Outlets aren't appealing to designers,'' said Paige Novick, who designs for Frou. ''Find manages to be a hip forum for current merchandise, without being mass market.'' ELLEN TIEN

title: July 25-31; A Killing Spree Leaves A Trail of Bodies in Georgia
description: A 44-year-old independent stock trader went on a shooting rampage in Atlanta, killing 9 people at two office buildings before killing himself as the police tried to arrest him. Another 12 people were injured, 7 from gunshot wounds. The police later discovered that he had bludgeoned his wife and 2 children to death in an apartment in suburban Stockbridge.

title: Ildiko Shinkle, Kevin Nielsen
description: Ildiko Shinkle, a daughter of Csilla and John T. Shinkle of Hong Kong, was married yesterday to Kevin Dunleavy Nielsen, the son of Darragh and William J. Nielsen of Glen Head, N.Y. The Rev. Carla Bailey performed the ceremony at the Church of Christ at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H.

title: What They Did Last Summer
description: There has been a long line of visitors to the Jersey Shore, and we don't mean the traffic on the Garden State Parkway. In fact, the beach drew traffic long before the parkway was built. ''The Shore Chronicles'' is a collection of writing about the shore, from 1764 to 1955, the year of a travel article on the brand-new parkway (''a miracle ride through a surprisingly scenic state''). Some of the earliest accounts show how much things have changed (in 1764, many drank ocean water for their health) and how little (in 1884 two women complain of a man's ''startling knock at the door'' owing to his ''overdose of opium and mint juleps''). Many comment on the abundance of wildlife, among them, in 1829, John James Audubon, who should know. And wild life: Stephen Crane in 1892 describes an ''observation wheel'' in Asbury Park ''filled with maniacs.'' The book, edited by Margaret Thomas Buchholtz of Long Beach Island and published by Down the Shore Publishing, costs $26.95 and is available at bookstores or from www.down-the-shore.com

title: The City Overheats
description: July in New York this year was like living in the hot breath of a big dog -- a subjective measure, true, but just as precise in its own way as any of the indices that try to put a number on how hot it really feels. It hasn't yet been as scorching as it was on July 9, 1936, when the temperature reached 106 degrees in Central Park. There haven't been three consecutive days over 100, as there were in July 1993 and August 1948, nor have there even been as many July days over 90 as there were in 1993, when there were 20. What makes this the hottest July on record isn't the extremes of temperature. It's the average, which has been more than 4 degrees higher than normal, nearly 82 degrees, the highest since the previous record in 1955.

title: PULSE; Not Quite New: Dry Shampoo
description: The latest bit of down-market chic to hit the uptown beauty world is a no-fuss, no-muss, no water shampoo. Hair Powder from Bumble & Bumble is sprinkled onto dry hair and brushed through to absorb oil and make hair appear cleaner, though technically it doesn't actually lift dirt from hair. While dry shampoos aren't a new concept, they used to carry a stigma, as though used by people who didn't have the means or inclination to keep their hair clean. But now the fashion elite is adopting the tacky stuff, which was worn by models at the BCBG men's show last Monday.

title: Camp Uses Dance to Reach Children
description: IT was the start of a new day at Ailey Camp, and the Bernhard Center at the University of Bridgeport was full of the sounds of drums and piano. Breakfast had just been cleared away, and 52 campers were at work in the spacious building, walking across a mirrored studio two by two -- ''very regal, very proud,'' the teacher stressed -- or bouncing on bent knees in West African dance class, held on the center's stage.

title: Officer's Growing Goatee Helps Break Barriers
description: Christopher M. Letz was suspended from the state Park Police for growing a goatee in keeping with his Islamic faith [''Muslim Officer Suspended Over Goatee,'' July 4].

title: Day Trading's Underbelly
description: FEW, if any, people have ever quit their day jobs to go to Las Vegas and earn a living playing blackjack. So why have thousands of people from many walks of life decided to junk their jobs and trade stocks all day to pay the mortgage and the gas bill?

title: Down-Home Boy Gives Hollywood's Worst His Best (and Silliest) Shot
description: When masked killers go a-stalking, when hideous creatures are rampaging, and when inexplicably employed movie stars start overacting, one man can be relied upon to appreciate their special contributions to the cinematic arts. He is Joe Bob Briggs, drive-in movie critic. No matter how grotesque these edited-for-television shockers get, there's no reason to be alarmed. There's always an extra seat at Joe Bob Briggs's Texas trailer, where the evils of the world are put safely in their place inside the small screen of your television.

title: Clare Donohue, Michael Coyne
description: Clare Marie Donohue, a daughter of Eileen and William E. Donohue of Spring Lake, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Patrick Coyne, a son of Mary and Michael Coyne of Farmingdale, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Dietz, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Splashing Around in the Shallows of Whitewater
description: THE evidence is unimpeachable. Two stubbornly left-wing adults who should know better have conspired to commit satire on the person, the prosecutions, the very idea of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel. Their confessions are on tape, and this referral submits substantial and credible information on their doings. It consists of several parts: five narratives and six excerpts from the incriminating tapes.

title: What World Needs Now Is Burt, Fans Say
description: THE SETTING -- More than 5,000 people came to Asser Levy Seaside Park Thursday evening for a Burt Bacharach concert, paying a few dollars for a seat near the bandshell or listening free on the lawn. Mr. Bacharach accompanied various singers on the piano, playing from his vast body of work, including ''Do You Know the Way to San Jose?'' ''What the World Needs Now'' and ''Walk on By.''

title: Toomer Reaps His Reward
description: In his first two seasons with the Giants, wide receiver Amani Toomer mystified his coaches. Although he missed time because of injuries, there was talk of missed assignments and improperly run pass routes. Toomer, a second-round draft pick in 1996, slipped to fifth on the Giants' five-man depth chart at receiver.

title: Whose Hamptons Are They Anyway?
description: THEY are everywhere in the Hamptons, crowding the main streets of once-quaint towns, ice-cream cones and shopping bags in hand. They are drawn by the area's natural beauty, sophisticated restaurants, luxury shops and the chance to glimpse, or even to rub elbows with, celebrity residents like Kim Basinger and Alec Baldwin, Martha Stewart and Steven Spielberg. They bring business to the merchants but also traffic and congestion to the roads and the beaches. On hot summer days, wilting in shorts and T-shirts, they look much the same as everyone else, including the New York City dwellers who swarm eastward in the summer and do their own bit to turn the Hamptons into a wall-to-wall parking lot.

title: Coin-Fumblers Compound Nuisance of Bags on Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEIN, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: SHEIN-Joseph, M.D. The Department of Pediatrics at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset sadly acknowledges the death of one of its senior pediatricians, Joseph Shein, M.D. Dr. Shein passed away July 15, 1999 at the age of 83. Dr. Shein received his medical degree from Witwatersand University in Johannesburg, South Africa. He joined the staff at North Shore University Hospital in 1954 as a Founding Physician. Dr. Shein served the Great Neck community as a solo practitioner from 1950 and was well known for his dedication to his patients. His long association with our institution was an inspiration to all of us who knew him. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his family. Mervin Silverberg, M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Pediatrics

title: Robokitty
description: The security guards at the night entrance seemed to be just about the only people left inside the fluorescent catacombs of the Advanced Telecommunications Research Institute, in the ancient Japanese capital of Kyoto. But then Hugo de Garis emerged from a cubicle and strode quickly down the deserted hallways. Lanky and intense, dressed in green shorts and a pale short-sleeve shirt, de Garis confidently led me to the research laboratory's innermost sanctum, stepped inside and let the door wheeze shut behind us. Grinning exultantly, he reached out his hand and began stroking his brain.

That was the case with Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia just before World War II. He was expected to be a challenger for Alexander Alekhine in 1938, though the outbreak of hostilities made any championship match impossible.

title: VIEW; Fat Debates, Sustacal Shakes: It's Life in the Diet Blender
description: RELUCTANTLY, I have agreed to go out to dinner with friends. This is going to be tricky. I plan to arrive at the restaurant early. When I get there, the antipasto table mocks me. I quickly head past it into the bathroom for refuge. In the privacy of the cramped room, I unpack my purse and create my liquid meal: eight ounces of skim milk, a packet of vitamin-rich Sustacal (the powder hospitals administer to patients whose jaws are wired shut) and two capfuls of fish oil, dispensed from a dark brown bottle. In my portable plastic container, I shake it up, then drink it down, praying no one comes in. Aaaah. I can now sit with my friends, pick on a dry salad and pretend I'm enjoying life.

title: Legislation by Stealth
description: Soon after the Republicans swept to power on Capitol Hill in 1994, they adopted a strategy of attaching last-minute legislative proposals, or riders, to essential appropriations bills. The point is to insure passage of controversial changes in policy that might not survive if subjected to full hearings and debate as freestanding bills. The Democrats have used this profoundly undemocratic device, but the Republicans have perfected it -- especially the Western Republicans, who once again have produced a batch of anti-environmental riders aimed at helping their allies in the oil, gas, timber, mining and ranching businesses.

title: Critic's Notebook; Taking on Illness and 3 Rendell Mysteries, All at Once

Between spurts of pain and the cushion of painkillers, I was in no shape for heavy reading and mysteries seemed just undemanding enough yet sufficiently diverting to occupy my weakened constitution.

title: A Surge of Sexism On the Rock Scene

Four rapes have been reported at the festival, including one said to have occurred near the stage during Limp Bizkit's set. This abominable news would be more shocking if not for the rampant displays of vicious male behavior throughout the festival weekend that began on July 23, from the lone fan who scrawled a demand for oral sex across his chest to the many who shouted at female performers like Sheryl Crow to expose their breasts onstage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAMA, HAROON
description: GRAMA-Haroon (Harry) A. Born July 4, 1930, succumbed to illness on Saturday, July 31, 1999, at UCLA Hospital, Los Angeles, CA. A long time resident of Beverly Hills, CA, and more recently Las Vegas, Harry Grama had provided highly valued interior furnishings for homes of many renowned personalities. His activities included serving as Founder and President of the Yemenite Jewish Congregation of Los Angeles as well as other philanthropic endeavors. He was a US Army veteran. He is survived by his loving wife, Renee, and their four sons, Ronald, Brian, Darryl, Bruce and his wife, Susan, in addition to seven younger brothers, Nathan, Rabbi Israel Grama, Ezra, Herbie, Joseph, Hazan Yishiah Grama and Rabbi Shimon Grama and four sisters, Lilian Afromowitz, Adina Greenfield, Naomi Godfrey and Miriam Breslauer. His passing will be sorely missed by the large extended family to whom he endeared himself.

Sally Hemings probably played a role as well, exercising at least some influence over how the Master of Monticello was laid out and put away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, JUDITH ELWYN
description: POPKIN-Judith Elwyn. 45, of Canterbury, NH. Died Saturday, July 31, 1999, of breast cancer. She was the daughter of George and Sally Popkin of Freeport, NY. Judy Popkin was a healthcare worker and longtime activist for reproductive rights, breast cancer advocacy and women's health awareness. Judy was known for her wit, caring and commitment; for being a movie buff and the staunchest of competitors in family games. Many were warmed by her friendship, touched by her talents as an organizer and moved by the depth of her integrity and values. In addition to her parents, she is survived by her daughter, Rachel Eades, and her family of friends: Juliana Eades, Jordy Cornog, BJ Entwisle, Julie, Dewdney and Christopher Cornog, all of Canterbury. Judy is also survived by her sister Annie Popkin and her brother, David Popkin and his family. She was predeceased by her younger sister, Susan Popkin. A memorial service will be held Saturday, August 7, at 2 PM at the Unitarian Church on Pleasant St. in Concord, NH. Memorial donations may be made to The Concord Feminist Health Center, 38 South Main St., Concord, NH 03301 or The New Hampshire Breast Cancer Coalition, 18 Belle Lane, Lee, NH 03824.

Soloway is a recent recruit to the team, but the other five have now won this prestigious title in six years out of seven, an astonishing record. A-CMI, which will now be called Alcoa Automotive Castings, has operations in Kentucky, Michigan and Norway and was formed in 1995 as a joint venture of Pittsburgh-based Alcoa and CMI International. Hayes Lemmerz, based in Northfield, Mich., bought CMI in February. Alcoa Automotive Castings has about 900 employees. Shares of Alcoa rose $1.5625, to $61.4375. Shares of Hayes Lemmerz fell 43.75 cents, to $28.50.

title: First Lady Seeks Political Equilibrium With Jewish Voters
description: Fourteen months ago, Hillary Rodham Clinton declared that the establishment of an independent Palestinian state was ''very important for the broader goal of peace'' in the Middle East. The Administration disowned her remarks the next day, and she was attacked by Jewish groups.

title: Man Shot to Death After Robbing a Bank Using a Toy Pistol
description: A retired New York City police officer shot and killed a bank robber who was attempting to escape in a waiting taxicab today, but the gun the robber had brandished turned out to be only a toy, the police said.

description: To the Editor:

title: House Cuts Could Force S.E.C. Layoffs
description: At a time when record numbers of Americans are investing their money and their trust in the stock and bond markets, a House panel has recommended a budget for the nation's top securities regulator next year that would require it to cut its work force by 10 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIDERMAN, JOSEPH
description: LEIDERMAN-Joseph. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Noah Fleschner, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREIBER, HOWARD F.
description: TREIBER-Howard F. Of Old Brookville, NY and Colleton River Plantation, Hilton Head Island, SC on July 31, 1999. Chairman of The Treiber Insurance Group, one of the largest family owned insurance agencies in the country. Beloved husband of Hope.
