In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to St. Christopher Ottilie, Winthrop University Hospital or Long Island YMCA. Further information, Whitting Funeral Home.

title: How to Keep Toilet Training From Being a Power Struggle
description: One way or another, we all learn how to use the toilet when nature calls. But the routes taken to achieve that critical milestone have varied greatly through the years. The passive, let-the-child-tell-you-when-it's-time approach that prevailed at the turn of the century was discarded in the 1920's and 1930's in favor of a rigid method dictated by parents.

title: First Lady of Texas Plays a Firm Second Fiddle
description: In an era when political spouses like Hillary Rodham Clinton and Marilyn Quayle harbor great ambitions for their husbands, Laura Bush is a throwback. She is a former librarian with little interest in politics. She says she never dreamed that her husband would run for office, or emerge this early as the candidate to beat for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Parched Eastern Farms Win A Promise of Federal Loans
description: After the television reporters finished their stand-ups in the fields of stunted corn and the orating politicians departed the shade of the front porch, the Harshmans still had a drought on their hands and a farm crisis the family described as the worst since the Great Depression.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGAR, TALIA
description: NAGAR-Talia. Shabbat brought you rest and peace. You will always be with us. E. Sherry Miller

title: PROFIT GAIN AT HSBC
description: Europe's largest bank, HSBC Holdings P.L.C., reported a 10 percent increase in earnings for the first six months of 1999, to $2.69 billion, better than expected. The London-based bank attributed the advance to the turnaround of its Asia business as the economy there rebounded. HSBC, which owns HSBC Bank USA, formerly known as Marine Midland Bank, also said it had lowered its exposure to bad loans in Indonesia and Thailand. The bank set aside $1.08 billion as a cushion against potentially bad loans in 1999, down from $1.15 billion a year earlier.

title: Defense Team Seeks Dismissal Of Charges in Diallo Case
description: The lawyers for the four officers accused of killing Amadou Diallo last February have filed motions asking for the dismissal or reduction of charges in the case, arguing that there was not enough evidence to indict their clients.

title: Three Die in Staten Island Arson; Brooklyn Fire Kills One
description: Three people were killed early yesterday morning when a fast-moving fire that officials said was intentionally set tore through a Staten Island row house.

title: Deutsche Bank Predicts Growth And the Euro At $1.15 in 2000
description: FRANKFURT  Confidence in Europe's economic upswing and its common currency gained new adherents Monday when Europe's biggest commercial bank gave an upbeat outlook for the first year of the next millennium.

title: Speaking for Trees in the Concrete Forest
description: LAST weekend was not miserable in Iceland.

title: Risking Nature
description: An irreconcilable tension seems to govern human attitudes toward nature. We think of it both as an innocent refuge from the corruption of human society and the savage condition from which civilization is an escape. These views have always orbited each other, like twin stars, and they are reflected in most periods and at every level of our culture, from Jean-Jacques Rousseau to Walt Disney and Steven Spielberg.

title: Of Meddling Deities And a Demanding Devil
description: The Salzburg Festival is a big musical event in what is essentially a small town. The huddled masses in front of Mozart's birthplace on the Getreidegasse add to the general pedestrian gridlock, but the chestnut trees along the riverbank are as comforting as ever. One accepts the elaborate politeness, grateful to have neither the time nor the need to explore beneath it.

title: I.B.M.-3Com Accord on Patents Is Expected
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the 3Com Corporation will license each other's patents in an agreement that a person close to the planning said would generate more than $1 billion in sales.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Alan Rabinowitz; Indiana Jones Meets His Match in Burma Rabinowitz
description: If Indiana Jones, the daredevil hero of Steven Spielberg's adventure-film trilogy, had been invented as a zoologist rather than an archeologist, Dr. Alan Rabinowitz would have made an ideal model.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, DOROTHY
description: ELIAS-Dorothy. It is with heartfelt sorrow we record the passing of a dear resident of the Home, beloved wife of the late Oriel Elias. Dorothy and Oriel were Founders of the Home and dedicated benefactors. Dorothy was a member of the Board of Directors of LASHA. We extend our sincerest condolences to her children, grandchildren and loving family. Sephardic Home Robert A. Cohen, Pres. title: Edison Schools Seeks Public Offering
description: Edison Schools, the private operator of public schools, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to offer $172.5 million worth of stock in an initial public offering.

description: HARNER-William H. On August 1, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Devoted father of Gerald and William. Proud grandfather of Kenneth, Douglas, Thomas, Kris and William. Viewing Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave, Brooklyn. Funeral Wednesday, 10AM.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: A Man, a Plan and a Robot That Makes Eye Contact
description: Meeting Cog for the first time can be an unsettling experience. Cog, the creation of Rodney Brooks, the director of the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is a legless, human-shaped robot that looks like an ungainly ancestor of C3PO.

title: Silly Season Could Last 15 Months
description: IF the nascent race for United States Senator stays on the same track for the next 15 months, we may all want to follow the Mayor's lead and run off to faraway Arkansas, this time for the duration.

title: Colorado Reverses Course, Resumes State Gun Checks
description: After scrapping its own criminal background checks of gun buyers to use a system the Federal Bureau of Investigation began eight months ago, Colorado has resumed the efforts, certain that the Federal system has weaknesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, JEAN
description: ALEXANDER-Jean. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to Connie and Harvey Krueger and their entire family on their great loss. We share your sorrow with our most profound sympathy. title: Nago Journal; Next Year's Battle of Okinawa: For Hotel Rooms
description: When Japan's Prime Minister announced recently that the site of the conference of leading industrial nations next year would be this charming little city in Okinawa, the Mayor danced a jig at City Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLINE, BUNNY
description: KLINE-Bunny. We mourn the loss of someone who has been our close friend for almost half a century. Goodbye Bunny-we'll never forget you. Blanche and Alvin

title: MERCK IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE SIBIA NEUROSCIENCES
description: Merck & Co. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the biotechnology company Sibia Neurosciences Inc. for about $87 million. Merck, the pharmaceutical giant based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said that it intended to keep Sibia's existing operations in La Jolla, Calif., where Sibia is based. Sibia's stock price soared Monday on news of Merck's $8.50-a-share offer. Shares were up 59.9 percent, or $3.094, to $8.344, on the Nasdaq stock market. Merck shares were down 25 cents, to $67.375.

title: Nirad C. Chaudhuri, Author, Dies at 101
description: Nirad C. Chaudhuri, whose first book in English, ''The Autobiography of an Unknown Indian,'' was written when he was 53 and thought his life would soon end, died on Sunday at 101. In the five decades of grace he received after completing the autobiography, he saw it acclaimed as a classic and wrote many other provocative, crotchety and elegant works of prose, completing his most recent book in his 99th year.

title: Pataki and Top Legislators Agree on $378 Million in Tax Cuts
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders today agreed to $378 million a year in new tax cuts as part of this year's budget, including an expansion of the state's tax credit for 1.1 million working poor adults, most of whom have children.

title: Veterans Deserve the Best Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNULTY, SUSAN
description: McNULTY-Susan. The partners of Herrick, Feinstein LLP extend their deepest sympathy and condolences to our dear friend Daniel McNulty on the sudden and unexpected death of his beloved wife, Susan. Dan, we are at a loss for words but want you to know that we deeply feel your shock and pain. Our heartfelt thoughts are with you, your darling children and, thank God, with your large and wonderful family.

title: Porfirio Delgado, 85, a Maker of Guitars
description: Porfirio Delgado, a luthier whose guitars were used by several generations of classical, Latin and pop performers, died on Wednesday at his home in East Los Angeles. He was 85.

title: When Antibiotics Are Used Too Often
description: Antibiotic resistance is a growing problem in the United States as overuse and incorrect use of antibiotics causes bacteria to become resistant to the medicines that are supposed to destroy them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARY XAVIER
description: MURPHY-Mary Xavier, Sister. Sister Mary Xavier Murphy, beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, died on Monday August 2, 1999. Reposing at Convent of Mary the Queens, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY Tuesday 1-8PM. Funral mass Wednesday, 9:30AM at the Convent with interment following at St. Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, N.Y. 10471 would be preferred.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press on Sunday about a private school in Burlington, N.J., that will be saved from closing by a loan from the state misstated the school's name and affiliation. It is St. Mary's Hall-Doane Academy, not St. Mary Hall. It is an independent school, not a Roman Catholic school.

title: Reed Is in Top Form as Mets Gain a Share of First Place
description: Other than the absence of walks, Hideo Nomo looked pretty much like the Hideo Nomo the Mets released during spring training, not the revitalized right-hander who had carried a 9-3 record into tonight's game.

title: An Elusive Peace in Congo
description: Civil war has torn the giant African nation of Congo for a year. The fighting, which erupted shortly after the insurrection that toppled the country's longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, has endangered Congo's people, blocked the revival of its economy and effectively partitioned its territory between government- and rebel-controlled areas. It has also divided much of Africa, with five nearby nations militarily backing one side or the other. An end to the fighting may now be possible. But to achieve it, Rwanda and Uganda must press their rebel clients to sign a pending peace deal.

title: Umpires To File Labor Charges
description: The American League accepted the resignations of Drew Coble and Greg Kosc because they told the league orally they were resigning, a league official said yesterday. The umpires' lawyer, however, disputed that explanation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, ELSE NEE FEITEL
description: ADLER-Else nee Feitel. Peacefully in her 90th year, at home on July 25, 1999 in Great Neck, NY following a long illness. Wife of the late Dr. Hans Adler. Survived by her children: Madeleine Conway of Westport, CT, Dorothy Bennett of Falls Church, VA., and Jacqueline Adler Walker (Arthur) of Scarsdale, NY. Devoted grandmother of Ann Bennett, Andrew Conway, Victoria Newman and Alexandra Conway and beloved great grandmother of Zachary, Arielle, Jonathan and Jared. Contributions in her name may be made to the charity of your choice. Private services were held.

title: Tax-Cut Negotiators Are Apart On Approach to Reducing Rates
description: Republican leaders from both houses of Congress began settling on a common tax-cutting plan today but did not resolve their differences over what kind of reduction in income tax rates they should support.

description: KATZEN-Harry, Rev. Dr., 99. Survived by daughters, Joanna Becker and Judith Stern, sister, Shirley Mostel, brother, Solomon Katzen. Service 1 PM today, August 3, Hellman Memorial Chapel, 15 State St., Spring Valley, NY, 914-356-8600.

title: 2 Insiders Named to Top Posts at Warner
description: Saying he wanted ''seasoned entertainment executives with the right mix of business and creative savvy,'' Gerald M. Levin, the chairman of Time Warner Inc., turned to two insiders today to run the Warner Brothers studio.

title: Hundreds Die When 2 Trains Crash Head On in North India
description: Two crowded trains hurtled head on into each other early this morning, killing at least 210 people -- many of them soldiers -- at a railroad station in eastern India near the border of West Bengal and Assam, railway authorities said.

title: Blast by Jeter Caps a Big Night for Pettitte
description: The burden of the unknown was finally lifted one minute past midnight on Sunday morning. Andy Pettitte was not traded, even though the Yankees had seriously discussed it by having conversations with 10 teams. But Pettitte was spared from being relocated, with the Yankees clinging to the hope that he can resurrect himself and be an influential factor this season.

title: Shots Were There, Microphone Was Not
description: So last night's Tiger Woods-David Duval exhibition on ABC offered a nice round of golf. Nothing sensational, no tense 50-foot putts with everything on the line and just one memorable shot: Duval's perfectly placed fairway shot that landed beneath a rock in the middle of the course, which ruined any possibility of Duval's catching up to Woods. A dramatic rock. Who knew?

title: Musical Frolic That's Meant To Shake Up The Senses
description: If you try to find sense in it, you're sunk. ''Squonk,'' the charmingly thought-free diversion that runs at Performance Space 122 through Aug. 28, proudly avoids making any appeal at all to the conscious mind.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Pushing new arthritis drugs, Monsanto and Merck step up sales calls to doctors.
description: DOCTORS are accustomed to offices crowded with patients, but in the last several weeks, salespeople from Merck and Monsanto have also been vying for their attention to promote new arthritis drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, NATALIE
description: ABRAMS-Natalie, 76. Of Cranbury NJ, on August 1. title: For Talk Magazine, Eclectic Party and a 'Hip' List
description: The party on Liberty Island last night was as eclectic as the magazine it introduced: Models rubbed elbows with politicians, movie moguls chatted with authors, and all of them gathered at the behest of a celebrity editor.

description: LUKOVITCH-Toni. Beloved and devoted mother of Richard Scheer. Mother-in-law of Greta. Loving grandmother. Services today 11:15AM at ''Parkside'' Chapel, Queens Blvd and 66 Ave, Forest Hills.

description: Regent Communications, which owns and operates 35 radio stations in the United States, agreed to acquire 9 New York stations from the closely held Forever Broadcasting for $44.8 million in cash and stock.

description: Tiffany Young, a backup guard on Purdue's 1999 championship team, was killed Saturday night in a car accident in Gary, Ind.

title: DAEWOO CREDITORS TO TAKE EQUITY
description: The domestic creditors of the South Korean conglomerate Daewoo Group plan to swap debt for equity in the Daewoo Heavy Industries Company's profitable shipbuilding unit, the first step toward halving the 59.9 trillion won ($49.9 billion) owed by the group.

description: LINKER - Robert. Of Delray Beach, Florida. Beloved father of Ellen and Joni. Devoted grandfather of Yanni, Alec, Peter and Bruce. Loving brother of Alice. Services private. Call RiversideNassau North Chapels for further information 516-487-9600.

description: To the Editor:

title: Program Aims to Counter Lack of Physical Fitness
description: Before she arrived at Empresa Elementary School in Oceanside, Calif., Callie Tuck thought physical education classes were a bore. ''At my old school we didn't really do anything for gym,'' she said. ''We just went out in the playground and stood around.''

title: For Leaf-Cutter Ants, Farm Life Isn't So Simple
description: Leaf-cutting ants and their fungus farms are a marvel of nature and perhaps the best known example of symbiosis, the mutual dependence of two species. But the textbook accounts, it turns out, do not tell even half the story. From research in the past five years the ants' symbiosis has emerged as far more intricate than it appears, involving not two but at least four species, their lives knotted together in a ruthless yet highly successful struggle for survival.

title: Crew of Ukrainian Freighter Stranded in New York Harbor
description: For three and a half months, a Ukrainian freighter has been stranded in New York Harbor, her cargo holds and fuel tanks empty, her master awaiting orders that never come, her 26-member crew idle and recently unpaid, food and supplies dwindling -- a ship dead in the water, caught in a ghostly maritime limbo.

title: AMSTED INDUSTRIES BUYING VARLEN, PARTS MAKER
description: After raising its unsolicited offer, Amsted Industries, which makes products for the rail, truck and auto components industries, said it would acquire the Varlen Corporation for $740 million in cash. Amsted, based in Chicago, will also assume $50 million of Varlen's debt. Varlen, which is based in Naperville, Ill., makes products and components for the transportation industry. Amsted said the boards of both companies had approved the acquisition, which values Varlen at about $42 a share, or about 62 percent above the share price of Varlen on May 17, the day before Amsted began its hostile takeover attempt. Shares of Varlen rose $3.89, to $41.77, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Amsted is a privately held, employee-owned company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARX, KATHRYN
description: MARX-Kathryn. Photographer and friend mourned and missed by Evelyne Daitz. The Witkin Gallery

He and his dear Sally continued the Reform tradition through service and membership in New York and Los Angeles. Service and interment were in Los Angeles, CA. For information, R.L. Malinow-Glasband-Weinstein, 800-300-0223.

title: Prices Slip a Bit for Treasuries; 30-Year's Yield Up to 6.12%
description: Prices for Treasury bonds fell yesterday, with demand sapped both by concern that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again and by the prospect of at least $42 billion of expected debt sales.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption about a collision of two planes at an air show in Oshkosh, Wisc., in some editions on Friday misidentified one of the planes. It was a Corsair F-4U, not a P-47, that crashed into a Bearcat, critically injuring the Corsair's pilot.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an art review and picture caption in Weekend on Friday about exhibitions in the Hudson Valley misspelled the surname of a sculptor whose work is on view at the Fields Sculpture Garden in Omi, N.Y. He is Alexander Liberman, not Lieberman.

description: RUFF-William ''Billy'' Of Mahwah, N.J. Beloved husband of Pauline (nee Levin). Cherished son of Pearl and the late Arthur. Devoted father of Tami Furlong and Allison Durocher. Dear brother of Jayne Joseph. Loving grandfather of Andy, Morgan and Emme. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, today at 10am. In lieu of flowers contributions to American Heart Association.

title: EUROPEAN INTERNET DEAL
description: Britain's largest carrier of Internet traffic, Energis P.L.C., will buy the pan-European telecommunications alliance Unisource N.V. for $:60 million, or $97 million. The move is Energis's first expansion of its network beyond Britain and into Continental Europe where the market for Internet and data traffic is growing rapidly. Unisource, a joint venture of Swisscom A.G. and the former Dutch and Swedish monopolies KPN N.V. and Telia A.B., has been somewhat troubled, and two other companies, AT&T and Telefonica S.A. of Spain, quit the alliance recently.

title: No Raise for Potvin
description: Felix Potvin, the Islanders goalie who struggled through an injury-plagued 1998-99 season, signed a one-year deal yesterday worth $2.7 million, the same amount he earned last year.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Dumb Old Party
description: Columnists for this paper are not allowed to endorse politicians, but I'm going to break that rule just once and come out and say it: I'm a Trent Lott man. Really.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHOF, MARK, REVEREND
description: FISHOF-Mark, Reverend. On August 2, 1999. Cantor and Mohel for 30 years at Temple Beth El in Hackensack, NJ. Survivor of the Holocaust. Beloved husband of Edith Fishof. Loving father of David and Joseph Fishof. Survived by brother, Rabbi Eliezer Fishof and sister, Mrs. Rufka Klein. Also survived by grandchildren, Chaim, Shira, Yonina, Joshua, Sholom, Chavie and Ilana Fishof. Services 11:15 AM, Tuesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Cantor Fishof's memory to be made to Cantorial Council of America, C/O Yeshiva University, 500 West 185th Street, New York, NY 10033.

title: Asian Luxury Hotel Is Near a Rare Sale
description: In a relatively small deal with broad implications, an investment firm connected with the Rockefeller family appears set to buy a luxury hotel on the island of Bali from a company controlled by one of Indonesia's own wealthy industrial dynasties, according to people close to the buyer and seller.

title: KOREAN BANK SHARES
description: Hanvit Bank, South Korea's No. 2 commercial lender, sold $1 billion of global depository receipts at a discount of 25 percent to Friday's closing share price. The sale, which had collapsed Friday because the Government balked at selling at the steep discount, was revived after the stock fell by as much as 12.5 percent yesterday and the Government allowed a price equivalent to 6,500 won, or $5.3897, a share.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: LEAVITT-Jeanette G. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Peter Leavitt and Lonni Cacchione. Cherished grandmother, great-grandmother and great great-grandmother. Service today, at 2 PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Richard Leavitt Children in Need Fund, C/O Temple Beth-El, 220 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, N.Y. 10514 in her memory.

title: INAMED AGREES TO ACQUIRE COLLAGEN AESTHETICS
description: The Inamed Corporation, a maker of breast implants and medical devices, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Collagen Aesthetics Inc. for about $142 million, broadening its range of products. Collagen Aesthetics, of Palo Alto, Calif., makes Zyderm and Zyplast, which are injected under the skin to smooth facial wrinkles and scars. For Inamed, of Santa Barbara, Calif., the purchase is a move into the collagen market. The deal values Collagen shares at $16.50 each. Collagen shares rose $3.875 yesterday, to $15.875, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Inamed rose 93.75 cents, to $20.875.

title: Woods Triumphs in Match Made in (TV) Heaven
description: It ended on the 17th green, with darkness falling on the golf course and Tiger Woods enjoying another moment in the spotlight.

title: The Giants Train and Come Out Fighting
description: There are always a few brawls during a pro football training camp. This afternoon, the Giants packed a month's worth of fighting into roughly five minutes of practice. There was the usual punching and face-mask twisting. There was kicking and a spur-of-the-moment death threat that didn't seem to turn any heads.

title: Sports of The Times; A Monument Lives On In Silence
description: THERE was no way for Diana Munson to have known that her husband's dressing stall remained in the Yankees' clubhouse, silent and vacant, a timepiece in tribute. She was not one to ask, too proud, too involved in her own delicate process of balancing the past and the present back home in Ohio.

title: Much-Troubled Missile System Passes Second Test in a Row
description: In a second straight success, an experimental missile defense system intercepted a target today at a New Mexico test site, prompting the Pentagon to predict that the system would graduate to its second stage of development next year.

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS UNIT TAKING OVER GENERAL HOUSEWARES
description: The General Housewares Corporation, a maker of scissors and kitchen tools, agreed to be bought by the Corning Consumer Products Company, a unit of the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, for $28.75 a share. Corning valued the deal at $145 million. General Housewares is based in Terre Haute, Ind., and makes Chicago Cutlery. Corning, which is based in Elmira, N.Y., and markets products under the Corningware, Corelle, Revere, Pyrex and Vision brands, has been part of Kohlberg Kravis since April 1998, when the buyout company bought it from Corning Inc. Corning Inc. still owns 8 percent of the business. Shares of General Housewares rose $7, to $27.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Accountability in School Construction
description: After a 16-year-old girl was killed last year by a falling brick at a school construction site in Brooklyn, investigators declared that the agency in charge of school building, the School Construction Authority, had grown ''numb to mediocrity.'' Mediocrity is in some ways an improvement over the years when school construction in New York City was an even more dangerous and deeply corrupt enterprise. But despite reforms in 1988, the system suffers from a chronic lack of accountability. City schools for 1.1 million students are built by a faulty, politically charged bureaucracy that prefers finger-pointing when things go wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARACK, EVELYN GARCY
description: LARACK-Evelyn Garcy. December 25, 1896-August 1, 1999. Survived by daughters Doris Rosenthal, Gloria Steinberg, Audrey Stone, seven grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren. Long-time member Women Jurors Assn, champion of women's rights and liberal causes. A pioneer and success in 1-parent family raising three daughters to college degrees during Depression, with their cohesive love and devotion. Adieu Chere Maman. Graveside service at Beth El Cemetery, Forest Ave, Paramus, N.J. 2PM August 3. Info. 212-362-6600.

title: NOMURA TRADING SUSPENSION
description: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest brokerage firm, was banned from trading stock on its own account for one week, beginning Aug. 6, as a penalty for conducting trades that resulted in the manipulation of stock prices in 1995, the Financial Supervisory Agency said. Separately, the Ministry of Finance said it would suspend Nomura from participating in Government bond auctions and underwriting issues for the same week and for the same offense.

title: Town Appeals to Keep Secret Its Policy on Pursuit by Police
description: This New Haven suburb is fighting a state order to make public its policy on police chases of suspects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAD, SOMERS, SUSANNE PETRA
description: SCHAD-SOMERS-Susanne Petra. Of New York City and Amagansett. A psychotherapist, died July 29, 1999. Born January 17, 1939 Berlin, Germany. Studied at University of Frankfurt. Ph.d in Sociology from Columbia University 1971. Taught at New York City Community College (1963-5), Rutgers University, Newark (1965-71). Elected Fellow of the American Institute for Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis 1974. Author of many articles, three books: On Mood Swings: the Psychobiology of Elation and Depression (1990); Sadomasochism: Etiology and Treatment (1982, 1996); Empirical Research in Weimar, Germany (1972). A co-founder of New York N.O.W., member of Board of Directors of the Homosexual Community Counseling Center, founder of the Women's Psychotherapy Referral Service, Inc, New York. Faculty of the Human Relations Work Study Center at the New School for Social Research, N Y C, 1973-1997. She is survived by two brothers, Thomas and Niko Schad and by nieces and nephews. She will be remembered with love, joy and tenderness by her many friends and patients. Interment was private. Gifts in remembrance to the World Wildlife Fund or the Ladies' Village Improvement Society of Easthampton.

title: Use of Soy For Babies Is Focus Of Debate
description: Sales of infant formula based on soy protein rather than cows' milk have risen in recent years, driven in part by the vegetarian allure. But some parents are worried that the estrogen-like substances found in soy, a popular alternative to pharmaceutical hormone replacements among menopausal women, may not be good for a baby.

title: Start-Up Offering iMac's to Lure Customers
description: A Los Angeles-based start-up company said today that beginning next month it intended to give away one million of Apple Computer Inc.'s popular iMacs to customers who sign up for its Internet service. The news briefly sent Apple shares to a new 52-week high, but they had settled back by the close of the market.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS STEADY. The dollar was mixed and relatively little changed against the Japanese yen and the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 114.22 yen, down from 114.48 on Friday, and the euro fell to $1.0683, from $1.0705.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a television review of ''Restless Spirits,'' a movie on the Showtime channel, reversed the names of two of the people shown. Michel Monty was on the left, wearing the eye patch, and Lothaire Bluteau was in the center.

title: Wondering About a Wonder Drug  Susan Love, a breast surgeon, is the author of ''Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book.''
description: Women with breast cancer or at high risk of developing it consider the drug tamoxifen to be a lifesaver. The drug is able to counter the cancer-promoting effects of the hormone estrogen, which has been shown to aid the growth of about half of breast cancers. But a new study has shown how tamoxifen can reverse its colors and stimulate the growth of cancer cells after two to five years of use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEFFER, ROBERT BENJAMIN, DR.
description: PFEFFER-Robert Benjamin, Dr. Clinical Professor of Surgery at New York University School of Medicine, and former President of the Medical Board and Chief of Surgery at Beth Israel Medical Center North, died Friday at Tisch Hospital of the New York University Medical Center. An open memorial will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapels, 333 Amsterdam Ave. (at 76th St.), NYC, at 12 noon today August 3.

title: Sam Ash May Acquire Manny's Music Store
description: Manny's Music Store, the West 48th Street shop in Manhattan that sold musical instruments to legendary performers like Jimi Hendrix, Duke Ellington, Chuck Berry and the Beatles, is in talks to be acquired by its larger rival, Sam Ash.

title: A Cub Reporter Outgrows the Gardening Column
description: A STRANGER IN THE EARTH

title: BRAZIL MEDIA DEAL
description: The investment arm of Globo, Brazil's largest media company, sold a controlling stake in its telecommunications equipment unit, NEC do Brasil, to its Japanese partner, the NEC Corporation. The transaction, which is expected to make it easier for Globo to service roughly $1.2 billion of debt, is part of a wider strategy of focusing on television, newspaper and Internet businesses. Terms of the acquisition were not released.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMETEK INC. , Paoli, Pa., a maker of components for electrical appliances and motors, acquired the closely held Patriot Sensors and Controls Corp., Detroit, a maker of sensors and gauges, for $70 million in cash.

title: NISSAN EXITS TELECOM BUSINESS
description: In another step aimed at focusing on its troubled automotive operations, the Nissan Motor Company will transfer stakes in nine mobile telecommunications companies to the DDI Corporation and the Japan Telecom Company. Nissan, which forged an alliance with Renault of France earlier this year, said it decided to quit the telecommunications business because the future costs of research and development were too large.

title: As Goethe's City Is Honored, Buchenwald Lurks Nearby
description: Always a crucible of the best and worst in Germany, this small town has emerged a decade after the fall of the Berlin wall as a focus of national questioning and conflict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUOHY, MARIAN E.
description: TUOHY-Marian E. Age 87 on July 30, 1999. Sister of Helen T. Ives and the late John J. and Thomas F. Tuohy Jr.; aunt of John P. Tuohy, Anne E. Scriptunas and Jane Tuohy. For further information, Frank E. Campbell 212-288-3500

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO BEEF DISPUTE
description: Tariffs as high as 200 percent have been imposed on some United States beef exports sold in Mexico, the second-largest export market for United States producers. Beef producers in Mexico, who are accusing their northern counterparts of selling below cost, have steadily lost business over the last decade as sales of United States beef have risen. Rick Wills (NYT)

title: Refugees Differ Over Whether Aid They Get In U.S. Is Ample
description: They fled the rubble of Kosovo, eluding Serbian soldiers for months before crowding into camps in Macedonia with leaky tents and meager rations. They did not let themselves hope for something better until May 21, the day they stepped off the last plane carrying refugees to Fort Dix, N.J.

title: Weather Worries
description: To the Editor:

title: Young & Rubicam designates a new executive lineup.
description: THE next generation of top leadership was designated yesterday by Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, one of the world's largest agency companies. And while the new leaders are not new faces, the succession has its surprising elements.

title: AIRPORT OPERATOR'S PROFIT
description: BAA P.L.C., the operator of Heathrow and Gatwick airports in London and the world's largest airport operator, said its first-quarter profit had risen 6.3 percent as economic growth in Europe and North America encouraged more people to travel. BAA said net income in the three months that ended June 30 was $:118 million ($191 million), or 10.9 pence a share, compared with $:111 million, or 10.4 pence a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 21 percent, to $:585 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, DR. BERNARD E.
description: SIMON-Dr. Bernard E. August 1, 1999, beloved husband of the late Bitten H. Simon, loving father of Cathy and her husband Michael Palmer & John Simon. Cherished grandfather of Sarah Palmer. A Memorial Service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Dr. Bernard E. Simon and Bitten H. Simon R.N. Scholarship Fund, at The Johns Hopkins University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERGER, IRVING
description: GOLDBERGER-Irving, 88. Of Sarasota, Florida, formerly of New Rochelle, died on August 1, 1999 in Harrisburg, PA. He was retired president of Kate Greenaway Frocks, New York. Loving father of Lynn Zeitlin, Neil, Roger, and Peter; beloved grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of four. Graveside services Tuesday 11 AM at Montefiore Cemetery, Queens. For information, Reese Funeral Home, Harrisburg. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jewish Home of Greater Harrisburg, 4000 Linglestown Road, Harrisburg, PA. 17112.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, DEWITT C.
description: LEWIS-DeWitt C. Beloved husband of Joan. Retiree of Wien & Malkin. Services private. Contributions in his memory to Alzheimer's Association, Fairfield County Chapter, 607 Main Ave., Norwalk, CT. 06851.

title: Unusual Case of Swallowed Toy Flashlight
description: An unusual letter appears in the Correspondence column of this week's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine: two doctors from Children's Hospital in Worms, Germany, wrote about a 10-year-old patient who was admitted to the hospital after complaining of stomach pains.

title: ARCO MOVING TO SELL SOME LATIN AMERICAN PROPERTIES
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, which is being bought by BP Amoco P.L.C., said it was in talks to sell oil and gas properties in Ecuador, Colombia and Peru to Burlington Resources Inc. of Houston. ARCO, which is based in Los Angeles, said it would not sell its stakes in Venezuela. The companies said they hoped to complete negotiations this month. Any agreement would require the approval of their boards and the governments involved. Shares of ARCO rose 62.5 cents, to $90.625. Shares of Burlington fell $1.875, to $42.3125.

title: Scramble to Fix Computer Security Flaws
description: Three giants of the computer industry Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer -- found themselves scrambling today to address a rash of serious security vulnerabilities in software designed to interact with Microsoft's Internet Explorer Web browser.

title: CITING CHILDREN, E.P.A. IS LIMITING USE OF A PESTICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today banned most uses of a pesticide applied widely for years on fruits and vegetables and tightened restrictions on another, in the first regulations intended specifically to protect children.

title: Senate Votes as One to Curb Wily Sweepstakes Practices
description: By a unanimous vote, the Senate tonight approved new restrictions and penalties for companies that try to tempt people into buying magazine subscriptions and other products by sending them mail filled with grand, sweet promises of millions of dollars in ''sweepstakes'' winnings.

title: Two Accused of Insider Trading In S.E.C. Case at Morgan Stanley
description: A former analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and a longtime friend have been charged with insider trading that generated $54,000 in profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, ADELINE BERBIAR
description: WEINSTEIN-Adeline Berbiar. Beloved wife of Martin. Mommy of Ophra Charnas and Bonnie Bernstein. Bubby of Yohonoson and Simcha Charnas, Adam and Alissa Bernstein. Services are at the Sons of Israel, 33-21 Crescent Street, Astoria at 1:30 P.M. on Tuesday.

title: Review/Fashion; Who Was That Man In the Dull Trousers?
description: As Marc Jacobs put it shortly before the first of his models ambled out in boyish T-shirts and dull brown trousers, ''You don't really want to notice what a guy is wearing.'' But he was putting it mildly. By the time the New York spring men's wear shows had ended last week, you could scarcely remember what anybody was wearing, so banal were most of the collections.

title: Together Again, Zen Cowboys on Cosmic Trails
description: The Flatlanders are a country-folk supergroup in reverse. When the group from Lubbock, Tex., formed to record one stunning album in 1972, few music fans had heard of its members: Joe Ely, Jimmie Dale Gilmore and Butch Hancock. But after the group disbanded, each member went on to make a name for himself with a distinguished solo career: Mr. Ely for his dark, muscular country and Tex-Mex rockers, Mr. Gilmore for his delicate Zen ballad singing and Mr. Hancock for his wise, clever songwriting.

Attended Duke University and Wharton Business School at University of Pennsylvania. He was a U.S. Marine Corp veteran and commanded an artilery battery. He was the owner of several businesses, vice-president of several others. Survived by sons, Donald J. Richardson II, Pleasant Grove, UT, David Richardson, Tampa, FL and Dirk Richardson, Amherst, NH, daughter Debbie Osborn, Sydney, Australia. Funeral will be held Wednesday, August 4, 11:00 AM, The John C. Tindall Funeral Home, Syracuse, NY. Burial, Oakwood Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAWTHROP, ROBERT S.
description: GAWTHROP-Robert S., The Honorable. On August 1st, 1999, of Philadelphia. Son of Robert S. Gawthrop, Jr. & the late Elizabeth H. (Campbell) & stepson of Janet (Borden) Gawthrop; brother of Elizabeth Gawthrop Riely and Emily Gawthrop Klarberg. Also survived by one niece and three nephews. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, IRVING
description: LEVINE-Irving. Age 84. Died on August 1, 1999, Albuquerque, N.M. Bronx born, architect & professor at Pratt. During World War II he drove a truck over the Burma Road and edited two Army newspapers. He felt his greatest accomplishment, in addition to his marriage and children, was his writing, including three books of poetry; he was also an avid fiddler. Survived by his wife, Peg Gerard; his children, Matthew, Elena and Michael; his stepchildren Sheila Mints and David McHaffey; four grandchildren, Daniel, Jack, Gem and Roxanne. Donations may be made to the National Yiddish Book Center, 1021 West Street, Amherst, MA. 01002.

title: City Council's Riposte to Giuliani's Arkansas Flag Maneuver
description: Acting on its anger over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's raising of the Arkansas flag over City Hall last week, the City Council has drafted legislation that would limit the display of flags and other decorations at City Hall to matters of ''governmental purpose'' or for furthering ''the city's interests,'' Council officials said yesterday.

title: Tests Trace Turin Shroud to Jerusalem Before A.D. 700
description: An analysis of pollen grains and plant images taken from the Shroud of Turin, believed by many Christians to be the burial shroud of Jesus, places the cloth's origin in or near Jerusalem before the eighth century, scientists said here today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, BUTLER, GRACE K., PH.D.
description: PRATT-BUTLER-Grace K., Ph.D. Retired Professor, Long Island University. Extraordinary Minister and Lector, Church of the Visitation, Bronx. On August 2, 1999. Loving goddaughter of Bro. Francis R. Bowers, F.S.C. Friends may call at the Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx on Wednesday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday in the Church of the Visitation at 10 AM. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: OCEAN ENERGY IS SELLING NATURAL GAS FIELDS
description: The Cross Timbers Oil Company and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to buy natural gas fields in Arkansas and Oklahoma for $235.3 million from Ocean Energy Inc. Cross Timbers, based in Fort Worth, estimates current daily production at the properties to be 55 million cubic feet of natural gas. Ocean Energy, based in Houston, said it would use the money from the sale to reduce its outstanding debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLANO, ANNA
description: CASTELLANO-Anna. Age 82, widow of Louis A. Castellano, beloved mother of Barbara Taylor and Dr. Robert Castellano, died on Monday, July 26 in Southhampton, New York. After a long and heroic struggle with emphysema. Her family and friends mourn the loss of this remarkable woman.

title: Byars Back to Bail Out (Who Else?) Parcells
description: Once again, Bill Parcells has reached into his grab bag of favored geezers, and this time he has plucked Keith Byars out of retirement to shore up the suddenly depleted new F-back position.

title: Mozart For Baby? Some Say, Maybe Not
description: True or false: Brain research shows that playing classical music for 2-year-olds makes them smarter.

title: Hedge Fund May Seek Sale of U S Airways
description: Tiger Management L.L.C., the largest investor in U S Airways, may seek to have the airline sold after recent earnings stumbles and a stock price slide.

title: Late Selling Pares Early Gains, With Dow Off by 9.19
description: Stock prices ended lower yesterday after a bout of late selling erased what had been healthy gains.

title: Romance Novelists: Profits Without Honor
description: ''Often women's accomplishments are overlooked,'' Kelsey Roberts, the author of 28 romantic suspense novels, told her audience at the Romance Writers of America conference here last week. ''But that's no longer true in terms of murder. We're starting to kill people almost as often as men do.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My pastures are nonexistent, just dried-up exercise yards for the livestock.''

title: Chase Hires Equity and Asset Manager
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Neal S. Garonzik as a vice chairman to lead the equity and asset management businesses, adding expertise that could help Chase enter stock underwriting.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Even if You Build Them . . .; . . . the Chinese May Not Come to Theme Parks
description: On a recent afternoon, only a few customers could be found wandering around the American Dream, a sprawling theme park on the outskirts of Shanghai.

title: For Some Children, It's an After-School Pressure Cooker
description: With September on the horizon, families are making plans for the new school year as well as for the new after-school year. My family included.

title: CATCHING UP: Summer at P.S. 41; Optimism and Anxiety As Test Time Closes In
description: A little after the school day began yesterday, Shawn Hunt introduced yet another vocabulary word to her third graders in mandatory summer school: optimistic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, LEON (LENNY)
description: WEISS-Leon (Lenny). On July 31, 1999. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Devoted father of Gail and Ron Marsh and Eric. Loving grandfather of Corey and Dylan. Brother of Marilyn. Services were held on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASKEY, SYBIL
description: LASKEY-Sybil. Loving wife of J. Larry Laskey, devoted mother of Amy, Tom, mother-in-law of Debra Rothschild and sister of Martin Tomberg. She will be warmly remembered for her culinary skills, keen mind and vibrant personality. She reveled in the accomplishments not only of her children but also of her nephews and nieces. Services August 3, 12:30 PM, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS RISE. Soybeans surged after Midwest crops received less rain than expected, diminishing the potential for bumper harvests. In Chicago, soybeans for November delivery jumped 30 cents, to $4.6325 a bushel.

title: CBS Says Earnings Surged Along With Ads and Ratings
description: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings had surged as its television network finished first in the prime-time audience ratings and as demand increased for advertising on its radio stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROW, RUTH L.
description: CROW-Ruth L. Ackerman, 81 years old, a longtime Palm Beacher, former Washingtonian and Manhattanite, died peacefully at home, Saturday, July 31, 1999 after an extended illness. During World War II, Mrs. Crow was the U.S. answer to ''Tokyo Rose,'' while assigned to the OSS in Honolulu. She graced the January cover of Town and Country Magazine in 1942. 1950 found Ruth proudly assisting Eleanor Lambert as a fashion show consultant. A sheer joy, here Ruth was at her happiest. From 1966 until 1984 the government agency founded by Roosevelt, EEOC, was Ruth's employer. Ruth is survived by her daughter, Lydia Reed Crow. A Scripture Service was held on Monday, August 2, 1999 at Quattlebaum-HollemanBurse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in Ruth's name may be made to Hospice By The Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Road, Boca Raton, Florida 33486 or Medway Plantation Trust, 300 Medway Road, Goose Creek, SC 29445. A Tuttie Miei Amici Grazie, Ruthie. To All My Friends, Thank You, Ruthie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'MALLEY, COLEMAN C.
description: O'MALLEY-Coleman C. On July 29th, 1999. Survived by his wife Marilyn, his sister Madeleine, many beloved nieces & nephews and Sarah. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Southold Animal Shelter, POB 297, Southold, N.Y. 11971 and/or to the attention of A. Cameron, M.D., Cardiology, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, 1111 Amsterdam Ave, New York, New York 10025.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, FREDERIC HOUSTON
description: WILLIAMS-Frederic Houston. 64, of East Hampton, NY and Vero Beach, FL, died Sunday, August 1 at home in East Hampton. Born in Detroit, MI, Mr. Williams was the son of the late Katherine Woodroofe Carre and the late Admiral Frederic Houston Williams. He was the husband of Gail Dillingham Williams. Mr. Williams was Chairman of the Board of Williams, Jones & Associates, Inc. in New York City, an investment management firm he founded. He was a graduate of Philips Academy, Andover, MA; Yale University and Harvard Business School. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Juilliard School. A member of The Maidstone Club, East Hampton, NY; Johns Island Club, Vero Beach, FL; and The University Club, New York City. In addition to his wife, Mr. Williams is survived by two daughters, Lisa Williams Hartman of Rolling Meadows, IL., and Daphne Kay Williams of Stamford, CT., and two sons, Frederic Houston Williams III of East Stroudsburg, PA and Jeffrey Paul Williams of Darien, CT. He is also survived by stepdaughters Melinda Gow Haffeman, Margaret Gow Trautmann, Marcie Gow Pajolek, Karen Baldwin Zimmerman and fifteen grandchildren. Services will be held on Wednesday, August 4 at 11:00 A.M. at St. Luke's Episcopal Church at 18 James Lane in East Hampton. In addition, a memorial service will be held in September in New York City, time and location to be announced. Memorial contributions may be directed to the Frederic Houston Williams Scholarship at The Juilliard School, 60 Lincoln Center Plaza, New York, NY 10023.

title: Top Gore Aide Resigns in Shift Toward 2000
description: Vice President Al Gore said today that his chief of staff, Ron Klain, was resigning to become a partner in the Washington office of O'Melveny & Myers, a law firm based in Los Angeles. Mr. Gore named Charles Burson, a longtime friend and counsel in his office and former Attorney General of Tennessee, his new chief of staff.

title: Deal in Albany On Overhaul In the Schools
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature have reached an agreement to overhaul the state's special education program, seeking to prevent schools from engaging in the much-maligned practice of placing disabled students in segregated classrooms.

title: Autonation to Shed Car Rental Businesses
description: Trying to raise a sagging share price, H. Wayne Huizenga announced today that Autonation Inc., the giant automotive retailer that he controls, would spin off or sell its struggling car rental businesses, which include National Car Rental and Alamo Rent-a-Car.

description: Azem Selmani and his family lost everything when Serbian neighbors burned down their comfortable house in Pristina. They have no money to rebuild that house and no jobs waiting for them.

title: China Tests a Missile And Berates the U.S.
description: China said it successfully test-launched a new type of long-range missile, and then it excoriated the United States for selling military equipment to Taiwan in the middle of a major diplomatic crisis.

title: Pettitte Isn't in Clear, But the View Improves
description: When Andy Pettitte woke up in a Boston hotel room Sunday morning, he was still a member of the Yankees. He had survived the midnight trading deadline and the owner-instigated attempt to make him, his mediocre record and his high salary disappear onto someone else's payroll.

title: Postal Service Settles With Pitney Bowes
description: Pitney Bowes Inc., the maker of postage meters, received $51.75 million from the United States Postal Service to settle a lawsuit the company filed over revenue from its electronic postage-resetting system.

title: 2 Small-Aircraft Makers Told To Reduce Export Subsidies
description: In a ruling that shook the burgeoning $55 billion market for small passenger jets, two of the world's leading small-aircraft manufacturers, Embraer S.A. of Brazil and Bombardier Inc. of Canada, were told by the World Trade Organization today to scale back export subsidy programs.

description: In percent

description: NEWS

title: Still Hope for Gun Control
description: A Congress that is not eager to do very much about gun control is rapidly approaching its last chance to do anything at all. After a long delay, the House has appointed its representatives to a conference committee that will reconcile differences on gun-control issues between the House and Senate. There is a huge gap between them. The Senate has approved a slim but useful package of reforms as part of a larger bill dealing with juvenile crime. The House's juvenile-crime bill contains not a word about gun control. The conference thus represents a final opportunity to respond positively to the public's clear wishes for meaningful legislation.

title: Are We Eating Ourselves Happy?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Plea Deal, a Banker Outlines Money Laundering in Caymans
description: A routine investigation into cable television piracy has evolved into an exploration of the secret world of offshore money laundering, giving investigators what one agent called an unprecedented insight into banking in the Cayman Islands.

title: Barak and Palestinians in First Dispute Over Peace Pact
description: The Palestinians and the new Israeli Government of Prime Minister Ehud Barak clashed openly for the first time today as they traded blame for an abrupt breakoff of negotiations on Sunday night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Insiders Selected to Lead Warner Brothers Studio

title: Corrections
description: The Family Fare column in some editions of Weekend on Friday misstated the location of the Storm King Art Center, a sculpture park in Mountainville, N.Y. It is in Orange County, not Westchester.

description: GOROVOY-Norma. Age 71, of Tuxedo Park, New York. Mother of Leslie Kenney & Cliff Gorovoy, beloved grandmother of Sarah & Soroush, Lauren, Justin & Charlie. Services are 12:30PM today Cedar Park Mausoleum, Forest Avenue, Paramus, N.J. For additonal information call Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 201-843-9090.

title: TSR Names A Co-Chairman
description: TSR Advertising in New York yesterday named Robert Kantor, 42, to the new position of co-chairman, joining Steve Rotter.

title: 6 Phone Companies Seek to Cut Fees for Long-Distance Carriers
description: Six of the country's largest telephone companies have proposed to cut the fees local companies charge long-distance companies to complete calls by a total of about $5.6 billion a year for five years.

title: Whitman Urges Careful Use of Water
description: After one of the hottest, driest Julys on record, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman issued a drought warning today and appealed to all state residents to use water more carefully.

title: If Wall Street Is a Dead End, Do Women Stay to Fight or Go Quietly?
description: Faced with what she contends is sex discrimination because she was denied a promotion to managing director, Allison K. Schieffelin took her case against Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. She chose to stay with the firm as a senior saleswoman as a way of ''trying to reform the institution,'' her lawyer told a reporter last week.

title: Big Stones and Small
description: Q. Farmers often have to clear their fields of big stones. Is this because the stones keep working their way up?

title: MONTGOMERY WARD EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation emerged from bankruptcy court protection yesterday after being acquired by GE Capital Inc., a unit of the General Electric Company, for more than $650 million. Montgomery Ward, the Chicago-based retailer, has closed more than 100 money-losing stores, shortened its name to Wards and begun renovating stores and upgrading its product lines. Under a reorganization plan approved by a Delaware bankruptcy court, GE Capital, which already owned 53 percent of Wards, is acquiring the remainder and is giving up more than $1 billion in claims against Wards. Unsecured creditors are getting about 28 cents on the dollar for their claims.

title: In 3 Months, Giuliani Raises $2.5 Million
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has raised more than $2.5 million for his potential United States Senate campaign since April 1, half of which came from a single fund-raising dinner, his aides said yesterday.

title: Fancy Pirouettes In Sync With Salsa
description: What a visual experience Gilberto Santa Rosa offers, and how tied up in music it is! Headlining a show billed as ''The Millennium Latin Concert'' at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, Mr. Santa Rosa, thick-bodied inside an elegant, three-buttoned charcoal suit, placed himself exactly in the open middle of a V-shaped band.

title: National News Briefs; Request From Congress Delays Huang Hearing
description: A hearing at which the Democratic Party fund-raiser John Huang was expected to plead guilty to making illegal campaign contributions was postponed today after the judge was asked to allow Mr. Huang to testify before Congress.

title: Line Is Blurring for Medicine and Candy
description: A walk down the aisle of any decent-size drugstore offers the best evidence of the changes taking place in the children's drug market, estimated at $450 million a year.

title: Russians Pressed by Barak on Technology to Iran and Iraq
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel pressed Russian leaders at the Kremlin today to stanch leaks of advanced-weapons technology to Iran and Iraq, and he received the same reply that the Kremlin has given the United States -- that no such leaks have occurred or will occur, if Russia can help it.

title: Wages and Panic Buttons
description: Financial markets reacted with alarm last week to an unexpectedly large increase in the compensation of the American work force. For Americans who work for a living and also invest in financial markets, this reaction may seem perplexing and even perverse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKHOUSE, BELLE

title: Long Sentences for 2 Chinese Dissidents
description: A court in Beijing sentenced two prominent dissidents to lengthy prison terms today, punishing them for plotting to subvert the Communist Party's monopoly on political power.

description: The low point, Pat Mahomes said, was last summer. He was in another manager's doghouse, in another country on the other side of the globe, working out with minor leaguers while sitting on the bench in Japan.

title: RULING BOLSTERS CHRISTIAN GROUP
description: In a victory for the beleaguered Christian Coalition, a Federal judge rejected most charges today in a Federal lawsuit that accused the group of illegally distributing millions of voter guides and mailings to promote Republican candidates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SIMONE, CLEMENT
description: DE SIMONE-Clement. On August 1, 1999, of Sugar Loaf, NY, formerly of Upper Saddle River, NJ. Husband of Wanda (Zelazny). Father of Adam, Andrew, Christian and Danielle. Brother of Donald and Robert. Grandfather of Devon. Mass will be celebrated Thursday, August 5th, 1999 at 10 A.M. at St. Gabriel's Church, Saddle River, New Jersey. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 at Van Emburgh Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey. Interment Ascension Cemetery, Monsey, New York. Contributions to Hospice of Orange and Sullivan Counties, 800 Stony Brook Court, Newburgh, New York 12550.

title: Manufacturing Still Hums, But Growth Rate Is Slower
description: Manufacturing grew at a slower rate in July as new orders and production declined, according to a survey of executives released today, offering a sign that the Federal Reserve may bide its time in raising interest rates again.

title: Healdsburg Journal; A Maker of Wine for Body and Soul
description: On a bright day, the sunlit vineyards in the Alexander Valley in Sonoma County may be enough to inspire a biblically minded person to ponder a phrase from the Psalms, the passage in the 104th, thanking God for ''wine to gladden the human heart.''

title: Summations Given in Parole Official's Trial
description: A Federal prosecutor asserted yesterday that a member of the New York State Parole Board lied to a grand jury to protect himself and Pataki administration officials in an investigation of possible corruption at the board.

title: By Design; Bold Prints, for That Retro Look
description: Little by little, prints have been creeping back into fashion consciousness. The trend accelerated after Gucci's spring show in October last year, with its bold florals evoking the days of flower power. Now, you can find all manner of retro patterns that recall the 1960's and 70's.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Control Center for Smells

title: Grey Expands Role with Hasbro
description: Grey Advertising in New York said yesterday that it had expanded a relationship with a client and expanded its ownership of an affiliated agency.

title: Gene That Gives Power to Flower Is Found
description: Whether an elaborate orchid, a simple daisy or a many-petaled garden rose, the world's flowers are all variations on one simple plan.

title: PEARSON EARNINGS FALL
description: The British media group and educational publisher Pearson P.L.C. reported a 38 percent fall in earnings for the first half of 1999, to $61.4 million, largely because of higher costs associated with its $4.6 billion purchase last November of the Simon &Schuster textbook division. Part of the decline was considered cyclical because profits from textbook sales come in the second half of the year when students return to class. The company forecast greater earnings growth as it expands Internet investment to a projected $193 million this year, linked to a major expansion of FT.com, the Web site of its newspaper, The Financial Times.

title: Strawberry Suspension Cut a Week
description: Darryl Strawberry's 120-day suspension from Major League Baseball was reduced by one week yesterday, and he will start a rehabilitation assignment tomorrow at Class AAA Columbus. The Yankees are not certain how long Strawberry will rehabilitate because they have to monitor the condition of his left knee and see whether he can effectively play the outfield.

title: Body Cream Linked to Premature Puberty
description: The playful little boy scrambled all over his father's body-building equipment and mats -- normal behavior for an active 2-year-old exploring his world.

title: INSIDE
description: Clash in Israel Talks

title: Trading Begins in the N.B.A. Bazaar
description: The Atlanta Hawks finally pulled the trigger yesterday on the long-rumored deal involving the All-Star shooting guard Steve Smith. Sending Smith and the reserve Ed Gray to Portland, the Hawks acquired Isaiah Rider and Jim Jackson on the second day National Basketball Association teams could sign free agents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVATS, MARION, T. (NEE RANCH)
description: KOVATS-Marion, T. (nee Ranch). Lifelong NYC resident, died peacefully of cancer on August 1,1999 (age 80). She joins her husband, Frank and grandson, Jed in heaven. Beloved mother of Karen K. Nicholson (Atlanta) and Robin Ann Dellarmi (Cold Spring, NY). Grandma of Kimberly, Nicole, Colin and Claudia. Surviving sisters are Dorothy, Gladys and Elizabeth. Brothers, Joseph and Frank Rench. Reposing Chas. Peter Nagel F.H., 352 E. 87th St., NYC on Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Thomas More, RC Church, 65 E. 89th St., NYC on Wednesday, 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Thomas More Church in her memory.

title: New Essex Prosecutor Revamps Major Squads
description: Donald C. Campolo, who was named the Acting Essex County Prosecutor last week, said today that he had reorganized the office's homicide and narcotics squads in his first steps to improve the operations of the busiest prosecutor's office in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGER, AARON
description: BURGER-Aaron. Died August 1 at age 87 in Lenox, Mass. Beloved husband of the late Vera Burger for more than 50 years. Loving father of Harold Burger, Ph.D., M.D. and father-in-law of Barbara Weiser, M.D. Devoted grandfather of Genevieve and Isabelle BurgerWeiser, Uncle of JoAnn KolmesFath, Karen Sclare and Donald Sclare. A teacher at Columbus High School in NYC for many years, he graduated from City College in 1932 and from Columbia University in 1933. He will be deeply missed. Services August 3 at 2pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BANK OF MONTREAL, Toronto, named Tony Comper, its chief executive, to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Matthew Barrett, who was named chief executive of Barclays P.L.C.

title: Remembering to Never Forget
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Baby Asteroid May Be Piece Of Other Rock
description: The camera-shy asteroid visited last week by a United States spacecraft is divulging some of its secrets, including that it may be related to a well-known, larger space rock orbiting beyond Mars, scientists said today.

title: The Clintonesque George Bush
description: Bill Clinton's impact on the American polity was never more evident than in the major address that the Republican Presidential aspirant George W. Bush gave in Indianapolis last week. The speech was, well, Clintonesque.

title: Fears About Fat Prompt a Call to Improve the Labeling on Sugar
description: A coalition of leading health experts and organizations, concerned about the climbing rates of obesity and the rising level of sugar consumption in the United States, asked the Food and Drug Administration yesterday to require that food labels provide more information about added sugar. The group also asked the agency to set a recommended daily intake for added sugar.

title: Struggling M.L.S. Replaces Commissioner
description: Major League Soccer's lack of progress has cost its commissioner, Doug Logan, his job.

title: Requiring Standard Tests for Graduation: 2 Views
description: In June, thousands of 11th graders in New York State took a six-hour English test so familiar and so dreaded that it is known by just two words: the Regents.

title: Taipei Journal; Color Taiwan Red, White and Blue? (He's Serious)
description: Even with all the various versions of ''state'' being bandied about in Taiwan these days, it still comes as a surprise to hear someone actually talk about statehood.

title: BORG-WARNER TO GET EATON FLUID POWER UNIT
description: Borg-Warner Automotive Inc., the maker of automatic transmissions, agreed to buy the Eaton Corporation's Fluid Power Division for $310 million in cash. Fluid Power, with annual sales of about $190 million, makes fan-drive cooling systems, mostly for trucks like sport-utility vehicles and vans. It is based in Marshall, Mich., and employs 1,050 workers in North America, Europe, South America and Asia. Borg-Warner had 1998 sales of $1.84 billion. Eaton generated 1998 sales of $6.6 billion.

title: Chateau Where Lichine Once Ruled Is Sold
description: I HADN'T been to Prieure-Lichine very often in recent years. Alexis Lichine, who had owned the Bordeaux chateau since 1951 and gave it his name, died in 1989. His son, Sacha, who took his place, had moved to Switzerland, leaving the running of the place to a manager. Only occasionally could we get together in the chateau garden to share some Champagne and talk about the old days.

title: KOBE STEEL TO SELL UNIT
description: Kobe Steel Ltd., Japan's fifth-largest steelmaker by output, said it would sell a machine-tool unit to the Mitsubishi Materials Corporation for 14 billion yen ($122 million) to help reduce debt. The unit, Shinko Kobelco Tool, makes drills and cutting tools used in the auto, industrial machinery and electronics industries. Mitsubishi Materials is Japan's largest maker of cutting tools.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: XOOM.COM TO ACQUIRE LIQUIDMARKET FOR $46 MILLION
description: Xoom.com Inc., an on-line direct-marketing company, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Liquidmarket Inc. for about $46.8 million in stock to add comparison-shopping technology to its Web site. Xoom.com, based in San Francisco, has 9.2 million members and offers free Web pages and E-mail to users who agree to receive advertising for products. Los Angeles-based Liquidmarket's software is intended to search for the best prices for products being sold by major Internet retailers and also will let Xoom.com collect information about the buying patterns of its customers.

title: For a Horse Lover, It's a Life at the Races
description: A morning with Mary Ryan along the jockeys' path at the Saratoga Race Course here is a lot like sitting with the grand marshal on the reviewing stand at a parade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIKE, LAURENCE B.
description: PIKE-Laurence B. In Brattleboro, VT on August 2. Retired partner at Simpson, Thacher and Bartlett law firm. Longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY. Survived by his wife, Norma Eklund Pike, his daughter, Barbara Pike and his sons William, Jeffrey and Alan. Donations to the Leukemia Society of America, 600 Third Avenue, NYC 10016. Funeral services Saturday 10AM at Ker, Westerlund & Fleming Funeral Home, 57 High St, Brattleboro, VT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, PAULINE FRANCES (PAULA, TO THE WORLD)
description: RICHMAN-Pauline Frances (Paula, to the world), on August 2nd, 1999 at age 94. She left us as she lived, peacefully and with dignity. Survived by her son, Gilbert; daughters-in-law, Janice and Ruth; grandchildren, Howard and Jill; great-grandchildren, Betsy and Lee; friends, associates and her special friend and companion, Megan. Services Wednesday, August 4th, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. The family will receive guests prior to the service from noon till 1:15 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association or your favorite charity.

title: Special Tax For Nassau May Reduce Big Deficit
description: The State Legislature reached agreement tonight on a financial rescue for Nassau County, approving a new countywide tax that could generate more than $50 million to reduce Nassau's huge budget deficit, but omitting any of the fiscal oversight measures that Democrats had long sought.

title: Umpires File Charges Over Their Lost Jobs
description: While the umpires' lawyers were tossing every variety of unfair labor practice charges at Major League Baseball and its two leagues, real umpires talked yesterday about the real ramifications of their mass resignation strategy that led to an unexpected result.

title: Clear Channel Buying 5 FM Radio Stations
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc., the No. 2 American radio-station owner, said it had agreed to buy five FM radio stations from the closely held Trumper Communications II L.P. for $55.5 million in cash to enter the Albuquerque, N.M., market.

title: LEADERS OF G.O.P. REACH COMPROMISE ON A TAX-CUT BILL
description: Republican leaders completed work tonight on a revised tax-cut proposal, adopting a new approach to cutting income taxes as they prepared for a showdown with President Clinton.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN I began devising the menu for Beacon, I wasn't sure what potato side dish to serve. I wanted to offer just one that everyone would love and that would work well with every entree. I considered french fries, home fries, mashed potatoes and baked potatoes. Then I thought of scalloped potatoes and knew I'd hit on something just right. After all, there's a reason almost all Western cuisines have a baked cheese and potato dish laced with butter or cream.

title: Annual Cost of Treating Gunshot Wounds Is Put at $2.3 Billion
description: Gunshot wounds cost the nation $2.3 billion a year in medical treatment, and almost half that sum is paid for with taxpayers' dollars, a study by a group of economists has found.

description: THE THINGS WE USED TO SAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURCKHARDT, RUDY
description: BURCKHARDT-Rudy. We are deeply saddened by the death of gallery artist and dear friend Rudy Burckhardt. An extraordinarily gifted photographer, painter and filmmaker, Rudy was admired and beloved by a community of artists & writers of all generations. A gentle man of great dignity, vitality and humor, his presence in our lives is missed. Our love and thoughts to Yvonne, Jacob, Tom, Yoshiko, Kathy, Hugh, Keno and Rudy's many friends. Andrew H. Arnot, Eric Brown and Philippe Alexandre Tibor de Nagy Gallery

title: Way Opening Up for Holbrooke's Posting to U.N.
description: The 14-month struggle of Richard C. Holbrooke to win confirmation as chief American delegate to the United Nations appeared near a successful conclusion today when the last of four Senators to block the nomination suggested he might allow a final vote before the Senate begins its summer recess this weekend.

title: Thomas Buys Control Of C.B.A. With Eye Toward N.B.A. Link
description: Isiah Thomas agreed yesterday to buy control of the Continental Basketball Association for $10 million. He hopes to expand it from nine teams and turn it into the minor league of the National Basketball Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLMAN, IRVING
description: MILLMAN-Irving. Died August 3, 1999 in Queens. Adored husband of the late Sylvia. Beloved father of Joan (and the late Edward), and of Richard. Cherished grandfather of Leslie (and Rob), Russell (and Terry), and Fred. Greatgrandfather of Sam and Danielle. Born in Russia, November 17, 1909. Feisty and independent for all of his days, Irving Millman passionately sought and shared knowledge, whether it was from the Torah, Shakespeare, or this morning's news. We were lucky to have him. Services August 5, 12 Noon, Parkside Chapel, Queens Blvd at 66th Ave., Rego Park; 718-896-9000. Burial at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Cone Is Dogged, but Jays Are Better
description: The images that dominated Yankee Stadium 17 days ago were of David Cone chasing perfection with an assortment of nasty pitches, finally achieving that perfect game and then kneeling in front of the mound before tumbling into Joe Girardi's arms. The images were priceless because Cone was perfect.

title: Plan for Mentally Ill
description: In Albany, an agreement was reached on a plan to give the courts authoity to force mentally ill people to undergo treatment. Page B1.

title: KLM PROFITS FALL
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines reported a sharp fall in its first-quarter profits, which it attributed to industry overcapacity and competition. Earnings per share were 0.55 euro, down 57 percent from 1.29 euros in the quarter a year earlier and below market forecasts. Operating income was 75 million euros, down 37 percent from 199 million euros a year earlier, and the full-year figure is expected to be well below last year's level, KLM said.

title: High Roller Hooked on Russian Roulette, Literary Style
description: Casino gambling obviously isn't as glamorous a pastime today as it was in the late 19th century, when magnificently dressed, jeweled aristocrats surged through Europe's grand hotels squandering untold fortunes at roulette. At least that's the way the Hungarian director Karoly Makk's entertaining film ''The Gambler'' imagines those glitzy old days. As the elegant players succumb to the rush of gambling fever as to a drug, their eyes glaze over, and they are consumed by lust for just one more chance to win or lose a gleaming mountain of gold.

description: A small town in which James Levine, James Conlon and David Zinman, to name only conductors (and only some of them), roam the streets at the same time? Salzburg, Austria, perhaps?

title: Brutal Bands of Rwandans Bar Way to Peace in Congo
description: The search for peace in Congo depends on disarming the very men who attacked a young woman named Alima Asami a week ago. Her scalp looks like a baseball coming unseamed, with brown stitches holding together three slices from a machete. Two fingers on her right hand, and one on her left, were hacked off.

description: New U.S. Flights to Cuba

description: FOR restaurants, August has traditionally been the slowest if not the cruelest month. In the past, owners simply closed and went fishing.
