description: NEWS

title: For Soy, the Time May Have Finally Come
description: IT has taken 30 years for soy to lose its hippie image. There has been no mainstream movement to replace hamburgers with soy burgers or pork with tofu. But thanks to a number of studies suggesting that foods made from soybeans may have impressive health benefits, soy is finally getting some respect.

title: The Attack of the Human Paranoids
description: Adults, more than children, are likely to find stimulation, provocation and controversy in ''The Iron Giant,'' the polished new animated film from Warner Brothers.

title: JONES APPAREL TO CLOSE FACTORIES AND CUT 1,910 JOBS
description: Jones Apparel Group Inc. said yesterday that it would close several factories and cut 1,910 jobs to reduce costs after its $1.5 billion purchase of the shoe retailer Nine West Group Inc. Jones, a maker of women's clothing, is closing factories in Kentucky and Indiana that employ 550, a factory in the Dominican Republic that employs 1,170 and Nine West's St. Louis administrative office, which employs 190. The cuts represent 21 percent of Nine West's 8,900 employees. Jones, based in Bristol, Pa., sells clothing under labels including Lauren by Ralph Lauren, Ralph by Ralph Lauren, Jones New York and Polo Jeans. Nine West, based in White Plains, markets shoes that include the Pappagallo and Easy Spirit brand.

title: Caustic and Loose in a British Way, With Soul
description: The noise from the crowd in the Supper Club was deafening on Monday night, but it's doubtful many American ears heard it. The occasion was a rare club show by the Beautiful South, a band that has amassed a British-born fan base over the course of seven albums yet remains as esoteric as a dish of bubble and squeak here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHRECK, MICHAEL HENRY
description: SCHRECK-Michael Henry, 98. Internationally recognized artist, died peacefully August 2nd in his home in Florida. His life was dedicated to his family and his art. He will be greatly missed. Mr. Schreck was a member of The Royal Society of Arts, London Accademia Italia, The American Federation of Arts. His work is in many fine art museums. He is survived by his loving wife Lizzi, daughter Evelyn Wyman of Roslyn, NY, son Peter Shreck of Cornwall, UK, five grandchildren and his great-grandson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, F. KELSO
description: DAVIS-F. Kelso, 83. Of Boca Grande, FL and Essex, CT, died August 3 after a brief illness. Born on February 23, 1916, in Hartford, CT, he is survived by his wife, Joanne Manzani Davis and his five children: Jay Davis of Belfast, ME, Philip Davis of Westbrook, CT, Debbie Neely of Milton, MA, State Rep. Jefferson Davis of Pomfret, CT., and by Nelle Davis of Lyme, CT. and New York City. A memorial service will be held Friday, August 6 at 11:30 at St. John's Episcopal Church in Essex. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the CT River Museum, Essex, The Middlesex Hospital, or The Oxford Academy, Westbrook, CT.

description: It was promoted as an omen of the new era in Palestinian-Israeli relations ushered in by the election of Prime Minister Ehud Barak.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Cigarette Deal to Rival Philip Morris
description: Brushing aside falling sales and legal challenges to big tobacco, British American Tobacco P.L.C. said today that it would buy the 58 percent stake of Imasco Ltd. of Canada it does not already own for $6.8 billion. The deal reflects British American's goal of displacing Philip Morris as the world's largest cigarette maker.

title: Smoke in Cabin Forces Delta Jet to Make Emergency Landing
description: A Delta Air Lines jet headed for Atlanta made an emergency landing at Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning when one of the engines started to malfunction and the cabin began to fill with smoke shortly after takeoff from La Guardia Airport, officials of the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Protecting Our Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Zapruder Heirs Get $16 Million For Dallas Film
description: A divided Federal arbitration panel announced today that the Government must pay the heirs of Abraham Zapruder $16 million for his film of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, the highest price ever paid for a historical American artifact.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNARD, ROBERT L. DR.
description: BERNARD-Robert L. Dr. November 18, 1960-August 4, 1997. Loved, remembered and sorely missed. Mom, Dad, Samantha, Chelsea, Cliff & Les and Aunts

title: Violence at Woodstock
description: To the Editor:

title: Commercial Real Estate; Cigar Company Is Expanding on Madison Avenue
description: Davidoff of Geneva, a major manufacturer and seller of premium cigars, luxury goods and other tobacco products and accessories, is giving up its small retail store on Madison Avenue to move just a bit south and undertake a large expansion.

title: Richard Olney, 71, a Writer Of the Joys of French Cooking
description: Richard Olney, one of the first food writers to introduce the simple joys of French country cooking to American readers, was found dead yesterday at his home at Sollies-Toucas in Provence. He was 71.

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Are Not Bad Themselves
description: IN New York, we have quite a baseball season going. By definition, there cannot be a dull day from now into October.

title: NATWEST EARNINGS RISE
description: Britain's third-largest bank, National Westminster Bank P.L.C., reported a 12 percent increase in first-half earnings, to $1.25 billion, on strength in its investment banking and bond and currency trading businesses. The improvement was better than expected but investors sent Natwest shares down 5.3 percent, to 1,205 pence ($20.12), on fear that the bank's costs were rising and the earnings strength might be unsustainable. Natwest's retail banking business is also growing at a slower rate than its other units because of a $315.9 million investment in 54 new cash and check-processing centers.

title: Waste Management May Lower Its Earnings for First Quarter
description: Waste Management Inc. said today that it might restate first-quarter earnings, lowering them by $55.4 million, or 9 cents a share, because of mistakes in calculating reserves for environmental cleanup and the value of some garbage dumps.

title: House Approves Renewing Trade Benefits for Vietnam
description: The House today renewed limited economic ties with Vietnam for another year, a week after Washington and Hanoi reached a tentative trade accord that brings Vietnam a step closer to full trading privileges with the United States.

title: Britain's Spirited Young Masters
description: IN a country synonymous with eccentricity, nothing could be more eccentric than Britain's food culture. Notoriously indifferent to good food, the English nevertheless feast on some of the best television cooking shows anywhere in the world. Traditionally resistant to eating out, they lavish love and attention on their favorite chefs, who rise to a prominence that Emeril Lagasse can only envy. When Delia Smith made omelets on her television show a few months ago, egg sales in Britain rose by the millions. It did not seem preposterous when the chef Antony Worrall Thompson announced last month that he was considering a run for Parliament.

title: A Cutting Board With the Right Stuff
description: WITH the rapid flow of professional cooking equipment into the home kitchen over the last few years, it is hard to believe that anything could have been overlooked. Especially something that has been unchanged for a quarter-century and can be found in almost every restaurant kitchen, whether Chinese, French or American.

title: Giants and Strahan at Odds Over Bonus and Years
description: The impasse in the contract extension talks between the Giants and the Pro Bowl defensive end Michael Strahan concerns both the length of the contract and the size of what could be a record signing bonus, according to persons with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Murphy Oil Sells 60 Retail Gas Stations
description: The Murphy Oil Corporation, a gas and oil producer and refiner, said today that it had sold 60 retail gasoline stations to two undisclosed buyers for $31.5 million to reduce debt and focus on its service-station venture with Wal-Mart Stores Inc.

title: Boy Is Fatally Stabbed On Street Corner
description: A 14-year-old boy was fatally stabbed on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday evening during an argument, the police said.

title: Europe Gets Back In Gear
description: Europe is finally back on track. You don't see it much in the headlines yet, but watch for the strong seedlings of growth and reform to be springing up all over the European landscape. Most notably, after almost two decades of status quo politics in Germany, the Government is tackling some of the right issues to get the Continent's largest economy moving again.

title: A Plea of Guilty in Olympic Scandal
description: A Utah businessman pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court to a misdemeanor tax violation in the first criminal case to result from the investigation into whether vote buying was involved in Salt Lake City's winning bid for the 2002 Winter Olympic Games.

title: 4 Months Late, Albany Passes Budget for 2000
description: Four months overdue, the Legislature completed passage of a $73.3 billion state budget early this morning that was incubated in partisan anger and hatched in weary compromise. It provides large increases in aid to schools and child care for the poor, and makes none of the cuts originally sought by Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Familiar Motives and Foot Dragging
description: When the New York Legislature began approving the state budget tonight, it ended months of partisan trench warfare that could have readily been avoided in late winter. Back then, well before the April 1 deadline, the path to the eventual compromise was clear, and the leaders here knew it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENNY, ETHEL K.
description: DENNY-Ethel K. In Lenox Hill Hospital, New York, August 1, 1999. Ethel K. Denny, wife of the late James H. Denny, survived by nephews, Kenneth A. Hiller of Stamford, CT, Barrie R. Hiller of Closter, NJ, Roger L. Hiller of Flushing, NY. Also survived by several cousins and predeceased by several brothers and sisters. Calling hours Thursday morning, August 5, 9 to 11 AM, at the Leo P. Gallagher and Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St, Stamford, CT. Funeral services to follow at 11 AM. Entombment in Long Ridge Union Cemetery, Stamford. Contributions in her memory to BideA-Wee, 410 E. 38 St, NYC 10016.

title: Trading Is Mixed as Internet Shares Fall Sharply Again
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, but traders said investors remained extremely skittish about high valuations and the direction of interest rates.

title: ASTRAZENECA PROFITS
description: AstraZeneca P.L.C., the pharmaceutical and agricultural chemical company formed by the merger of Zeneca of Britain and Astra of Sweden, posted strong first-half sales in its drug business but failed to maintain momentum on the profit line because of increased costs. Sales from operations rose 12 percent, to $9.04 billion, in the first six months of 1999, compared with sales of the constituent parts of the company a year earlier, but pretax profit rose only 6 percent, to $1.47 billion. Excluding restructuring charges of $822 million, the results were at the lower end of analysts' expectations.

title: PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF HUMANA TO RESIGN
description: Humana Inc., the health insurer for more than six million people, said its president and chief executive, Gregory H. Wolf, was resigning after a year in which the company's shares tumbled following a profit warning. The company appointed its chairman, David A. Jones, a former chief executive, as an interim chief executive, and Humana's board is seeking a permanent replacement for Mr. Wolf. The shares of Humana, based in Louisville, Ky., have fallen more than 40 percent in 1999. Trading in the shares was halted yesterday, after they fell 50 cents, to $10.25, before the news was announced.

title: Cut Taxes? First, Cut the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Notebook; Staying the Course
description: Virginia Commonwealth University is so concerned that its master's candidates in advertising will be lured away by agencies that it is requiring all 60 incoming students this fall to pledge to complete the two-year program before taking a permanent job.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Reflections
description: Monica Lewinsky gave her side of the story. President Clinton spoke for the grand jury's unfriendly video camera. Now, in a puzzling interview with Talk magazine, Hillary Rodham Clinton has provided her own view of her husband's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky. That view is both highly forgiving and deeply ambiguous, and it has sparked a lively and predictably partisan debate as to whether Mrs. Clinton has damaged her campaign for the Senate. If there has been damage, this is one case in which the First Lady cannot demonize the press. She had her say in the context of an article that was both militantly laudatory and unanalytic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYCE, ROBERT P.
description: JOYCE-Robert P. Of Harrison, New York. On August 2nd, 1999. Husband of Janet (nee Burrell). Devoted father of Robert, Stephen, James, William and Daniel. Brother of Richard & grandfather of nine. Reposing Wednesday and Thursday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck. Funeral Mass Friday, 10AM at St. Gregory's R.C. Church followed by interment at the Greenwood Union Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the assassination of a politician in Sri Lanka who had been seeking an end to the country's civil war misspelled his given name. He was Neelan Tiruchelvam, not Neelam. The accompanying article misspelled the surname of a law professor who had taught Mr. Tiruchelvam. She is Savitri Goonesekere, not Goonefekere.

title: Notx The Same Old Ribs
description: NEXT to pork ribs, lamb ribs are the best down-and-dirty grill item I know. They're also the cheapest: where I live, it's hard to pay more than a dollar a pound for them. But if you don't see lamb ribs in your supermarket, the chances are that they're being tossed into the rendering bin; both demand and profit are evidently so slim that they are not worth processing and putting out in the case. So to make this dish, you may have to ask your butcher for them in advance.

title: Nasdaq Wins Battle to Build Huge Video Sign
description: The great Times Square sign battle ended Monday afternoon, when an arbitrator ruled that Nasdaq, the electronic stock market, could erect the largest video screen in the world on the new Conde Nast skyscraper in Times Square despite objections from S.I. Newhouse Jr., the magazine publishing tycoon.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''These are our neighbors, and if their water is polluted, so is ours. There is nothing more basic to peaceful coexistence than that.''

title: Cut Taxes? First, Cut the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: When Health Care Goes Lacking
description: To the Editor:

title: House Approves a Bill to Restrict On-Line Sales of Liquor
description: The House today overwhelmingly passed a bill that would restrict on-line liquor sales, overriding objections from California lawmakers that the proposal favored liquor wholesalers over small wineries and breweries trying to broaden their reach through electronic commerce.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MECHANIC, SAMUEL
description: MECHANIC-Samuel, Fannie, and Sylvia G. ''And until we meet again, may God continue to hold thee in the palm of His hand.'

title: Calendar
description: Milkshakes of the Month

title: Please Hold: The Swordfish Marinade Will Be Right With You
description: ANYTIME you call a restaurant to make a reservation, being put on hold is almost a given. You half listen to the background music while you wait, hoping you won't be forgotten.

title: Where Some See Rusting Factories, Government Sees a Source of Solar Energy
description: The Energy Department has a new idea for what to do with derelict, polluted urban industrial properties that no one wants to pay to clean up: cover them with solar panels.

title: Byars Is Happy Again As Parcells Calls Him
description: At 35, with 13 National Football League seasons behind him, Keith Byars had been working out in recent weeks, hoping to play again. But he had no team, and he did not want just another team.

title: Loans to the World's Poor Can Enrich Everyone
description: OAK BROOK, Illinois  The Human Development Report recently issued by the UN Development Program indicates that the gap between the world's wealthy and poor has significantly increased. The report makes the alarming observation that if you add up the wealth of the world's poorest 2 billion people, it matches the cumulative wealth of the richest 200.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINKER, ROBERT
description: LINKER-Robert. You were my first student and a lifelong friend. I and so many others will miss your caring and your good cheer. Stanley H. Kaplan

title: Court Overturns $4 Million Award and Finding of Liability in Attica Rebellion
description: A Federal appeals court panel yesterday overturned a $4 million award stemming from the bloody Attica prison rebellion in 1971, and chastised a lower court judge and the State of New York for allowing a suit filed by 1,281 inmates to drag on for 25 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEIGH, CHRISTOPHER R.
description: McVEIGH-Christopher R. Of Montclair, New Jersey, formerly of Somers, New York, died August 2 at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital in New York City. Mr. McVeigh worked as VP of Marketing for Prudential Insurance Company in Newark, NJ for the past two years. Mr. McVeigh was born on August 24, 1965 in Brooklyn, NY to Robert & Marie Murphy McVeigh. He attended Regis High School in New York City, graduating in 1983. He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics from Holy Cross College in Worcester, Mass. in 1987. Mr. McVeigh lived in Montclair, NJ for the past year. Mr. McVeigh lived in Somers, NY from 1992 to 1998. He was a parishioner of St. Cassians Church, Montclair, New Jersey. Mr. McVeigh is survived by his wife Joann K. (nee Gleason) of Montclair, NJ, father of Colleen Anne and Kevin Robert. Son of Robert A. and Marie B. McVeigh. Brother of Laura Masi of Stamford, CT, Gregory McVeigh of Fairfield, CT, Jenifer Maggiacomo of Quincy, MA and Maureen McVeigh of Vienna, VA. Stepson of Eileen C. McVeigh of Somers, NY. Son-inlaw of Kevin and Mary Virginia Gleason of Englewood, CO. Brother-in-law of John Gleason of Englewood, CO, Mary Carol Gleason of Englewood, CO, James Gleason of Denver, CO, Daniel Gleason of Montclair, NJ, John Masi of Stamford, CT, Jenifer Smith McVeigh of Fairfield, CT and Steven Maggiacomo of Quincy, MA. Three nephews and two nieces. Mr. McVeigh is predeceased by his mother Marie B. McVeigh, who died in 1996. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Cassidy Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, NY. The funeral is Friday 10 AM, at St. Joseph's Church, Croton Falls, NY. Interment will follow at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Croton Falls, NY. Friends may send memorial donations in memory of Christopher R. McVeigh c/o Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARROW, BERNIE
description: BARROW-Bernie. Gone 6 long years but always in our hearts. Love, Joan and the children

title: U.S. to Allow 2 More Cities To Set Flights To Havana
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it would permit direct flights to Cuba from both New York and Los Angeles, the latest step in the Administration's effort to open informal contacts with the island nation.

title: That Gap in the Nixon Tapes? Maybe a Teen-Age Cry of Love
description: Not to get too solemn about it, but ''Dick,'' an uproariously dizzy satire that reduces the Watergate scandal into a goofy Nancy Drew caper for starry-eyed teeny-boppers, would probably not have been made had Monica Lewinsky never slunk into the Oval Office. Who was it who observed that history repeats itself as farce?

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN RISES. Corn reached a six-week high after a Government report showed that a Midwest heat wave did more crop damage than expected. In Chicago, corn for December delivery rose 4.25 cents, to $2.3075 a bushel.

title: VODAFONE AIRTOUCH AND BELL ATLANTIC TO SPLIT VENTURE
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and Vodafone Airtouch P.L.C. agreed yesterday to split Primeco Personal Communications L.P., their cellular-phone joint venture. The agreement would give Bell Atlantic Primeco's networks in New Orleans; Richmond; and Miami, Jacksonville and Tampa, Fla. Vodafone Airtouch gets Chicago, Milwaukee, Dallas, San Antonio and Houston. Bell Atlantic decided in April to break up the Primeco venture, three months after it lost a bidding war to Vodafone Group P.L.C. of Britain to buy Airtouch Communications Inc., Bell Atlantic's original partner in Primeco.

title: Rudy Burckhardt, 85, Photographer and Filmmaker, Dies
description: Rudy Burckhardt, whose 60-year career as an artist and a friend of artists connected several generations and esthetic factions of the New York School, drowned on Sunday in a pond near his home in Searsmont, Me. He was 85 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOYTE, LENON (NEE HOLDER)
description: HOYTE-Lenon (nee Holder). Also known as Aunt Len. Retired art teacher and founder of Aunt Len's Doll and Toy Museum. Passed away Sunday, August 1. Beloved sister of Dr. Oliver Holder and wife, Juanita. Cherished aunt of Valerie Cuyjit, Kevin and Kirk Leftwich. Visitation Friday, August 6, from Benta's Funeral Home, 630 St Nicholas Ave. Funeral services will be held Saturday, August 7, at 10 AM, from Benta's. Interment in Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, N.Y.

title: U.A.W. to Seek Strike Vote Aug. 17 at All Ford Plants
description: Seeking to reassure its members that it is taking a hard line in labor talks, the United Automobile Workers union plans to hold strike authorization votes at all Ford Motor Company factories on Aug. 17, in preparation for the expiration on Sept. 14 of national contracts with all auto makers here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: World Wrestling Federation Plans an Initial Offering

title: Hurtful to Taiwan
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Postal Service Approves Capital Plan
description: The Board of Governors of the United States Postal Service approved a $4 billion capital plan for fiscal year 2000.

title: Our Towns; In Stamford, Just Call It Starbooks
description: HILDA NICOLL may not be the last person in America to have become hip to Starbucks, but she surely was part of a select remnant. She lost her corporate-ubiquity innocence on a bench in front of the Stamford public library, the Ferguson Library, where she was sitting beneath a huge ''Coming Soon'' poster featuring the chain's circular logo of a smiling, two-tailed siren.

title: Clinton Hears Success Stories of Ex-Welfare Recipients
description: President Clinton listened today to more than a dozen former welfare recipients recount their life-changing experiences working for companies including a CVS drugstore and the Bank of America. And he heard their employers praise them as highly reliable workers.

title: Airlines Offer Discounts Through Web Sites
description: United States airlines are tempting bargain-hunters with discounts of as much as 10 percent to book tickets on the airlines' Web sites, a cost-cutting effort that travel agents contend is weeding them out of the process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ALEXANDER
description: GOLDBERG-Alexander. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, he will remain in our hearts forever. His greatness lives on. For information call Schwartz Brothers at 718-263-7600.

title: Trial in Gay Killing Opens, To New Details of Savagery
description: Five months after Billy Jack Gaither's charred and battered body was found by the side of a creek not far from here, prosecutors told a jury today of a hate-inspired conspiracy by two construction workers to murder him because he was gay.

title: Experts Unsure of Effects of a Type of Contaminant
description: A panel of experts convened to study a class of environmental contaminants including some pesticides and components of plastics has concluded that not enough is known about them to determine whether they cause health problems at the low levels in which they typically occur in the environment.

title: The First State Is Running Second
description: Ever since Delaware passed a law mandating that its Presidential primaries be held four days after New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primary, the two states have been feuding.

title: A Dubious Campaign Ruling
description: In a disappointing decision that could lead to new campaign fund-raising abuses, a Federal judge has cleared the Christian Coalition of charges that it illegally helped several Republicans in recent elections. Judge Joyce Hens Green of Federal District Court in Washington found that in distributing voter guides and mailings, the coalition exercised free speech and did not violate limits on campaign contributions. The ruling makes it all the more urgent for Congress to enact a new set of reforms that curb the corrupting power of money in elections while respecting the First Amendment. Indeed, Judge Green almost seemed to be inviting Congress to act.

title: BRUSSELS ALLOWS BANK DEAL
description: Overruling a Portuguese Government veto, the European Commission authorized the alliance between Spain's largest bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano, and four big Portuguese financial services companies controlled by Antonio Champalimaud, one of Portugal's richest people. Brussels said the deal, announced in June, was compatible with European Union competition rules because the proposed alliance would not have a dominant position, exceeding 20 percent, in the Portuguese banking or insurance sectors. Lisbon had adamantly opposed the deal over reported irregularities in the accord in which Banco Santander would pay 1.2 billion euros ($1.27 billion) for about 40 percent of the Champalimaud Group, which includes Banco Pinto e Sotto Mayor, one of Portugal's biggest banks. Al Goodman

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Thinking Big on 59th St.

title: 2 WARY NEIGHBORS UNITE TO CONFRONT NORTH KOREA ARMS
description: North Korea's preparations to test a new long-range missile this month have led to a dramatic change of course in military planning and diplomacy for Japan and South Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOVNICK, ADELE K.
description: PLOVNICK-Adele K. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Queens, NY, died August 2, 1999 in Boca Raton, FL. Mrs. Plovnick was a member of B'nai B'rith Women, We Care Organization, Hadassah and past president of the Mansfield Condo Association in her community. Loving and devoted mother of Phyllis Solomon of New York City and Myra Pfeifer of Wantagh, Long Island. Loving and devoted mother-in-law of Gerry Solomon and Michael Pfeifer. Cherished grandmother of Jordan and Perry & great-grandmother of Amanda & Jaime, dedicated sister of Sylvia Levine of Jericho, New York, and beloved aunt to many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, August 4th, 1999, at 12:00 P.M. at the Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York. Interment will follow at New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn, New York. Please consult the family for days and times of their mourning period observance.

title: Restrictions on Water Use Are Ordered in Bergen County
description: Water restrictions were imposed today on 51 of the 70 towns in Bergen County, limiting the watering of lawns and golf courses and banning noncommercial car washing and the spraying of streets, driveways, tennis courts, patios and other paved surfaces.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO. CONSOLIDATED , Charlotte, N.C., agreed to buy Lynchburg Coca-Cola Bottling Co., Lynchburg, Va., for an undisclosed price.

description: To the Editor:

title: Notebook; A Case for Diversity
description: Hoping to make an argument for colleges and universities that espouse race-conscious admissions, researchers yesterday released a survey of two prominent law schools in which about 90 percent of students said diversity in the classroom gave them a better educational experience.

title: When Health Care Goes Lacking
description: To the Editor

title: SARA LEE TO ACQUIRE 2 BRANDS FROM DAWSON
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, maker of clothing brands that include Hanes and Playtex, will pay $95.7 million in cash to buy two businesses from Dawson International P.L.C. to increase its European sales. The companies signed a letter of intent last month and have received American regulatory approval. Dawson, based Scotland, said it was selling its Duofold and J E Morgan brands to focus on making cashmere products. With the purchase, Sara Lee, based in Chicago, expands its business in brand-name clothing, which generates more than a third of its annual revenue, and extends its foothold in Europe. The company, which also makes Sara Lee baked goods and Jimmy Dean meats, had revenue of $20 billion in fiscal 1998.

title: U.S. Undercuts Arms Control Efforts, Global Panel Finds
description: The failure of the United States and other nuclear powers to ratify an international treaty that bans nuclear testing, while they have weakened pacts against other weapons of mass destruction, undercuts decades of arms control and is making the world much less safe, says a report by nuclear arms experts commissioned by Japan.

title: Ventura and His Bat Show the Way to First Place
description: Bill Pulsipher insisted it was just another game.

title: AUTO PARTS MAKER PURCHASED
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, a leading engine parts supplier, bought one of it main rivals, Sabo Industria e Comercio Ltda. of Brazil. With the acquisition of Sabo, Federal-Mogul, based in Southfield, Mich., enlarges its grip on the market for engine seals, used to prevent leaking in automobile cylinders. The sale of Sabo, a $180 million company with factories in Latin America and Europe, is part of a wider trend in Brazil of family-owned industrial concerns selling control to foreign competitors.

title: GLOBAL TO BUY OFFSHORE CONSTRUCTION COMPANY
description: Global Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the international offshore construction company ETPM S.A. for $265 million from Groupe GTM, an affiliate of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. of France. As part of the deal, Global Industries, based in Lafayette, La., which constructs and dismantles offshore oil and gas drilling platforms, will assume $2 million of ETPM's debt. Global will also lease GTM's interest in two vessels and purchase that interest in January 2002 for $25 million.

title: Ex-Official Sues Police Over Job, Citing Her Refusal to Alter Report
description: A former deputy police commissioner who investigated complaints of workplace harassment filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday in which she claims that she was forced from her job after resisting pressure to revise a report that criticized a high-ranking police official.

title: Global Crossing Sharply Narrows Loss
description: Global Crossing Ltd., which is buying the American long-distance phone company the Frontier Corporation for about $12.9 billion, sharply cut its loss in the second quarter as sales almost doubled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, LEO V.
description: BERGER-Leo V. We were deeply saddened to learn of the passing of Leo V. Berger, a humanitarian who cared deeply for others. His support of both Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore University Hospital was exemplary. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his family. Saul Katz, Chairman, Board of Trustees John S.T. Gallagher, Chief Executive Office David R. Dantzker, President North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Manny's, Haven for Musicians, Is Sold to a Chain-Store Rival
description: Autographed head shots from the most popular musicians of the last 50 years line the walls at Manny's Music Store, whose family owners said yesterday that it had been sold to a longtime rival.

title: Stalemate on Gun Shows Makes New Law Unlikely Before Recess, Armey Says
description: The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey, said today that disagreements between Republicans and Democrats about how extensively to regulate gun shows remained serious enough that Congress was unlikely to pass any new gun-control legislation before the beginning of a monthlong recess on Saturday.

title: Art Museum Names 2 Agencies
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York has named two agencies to handle the creative and media parts of its account, which had been handled for seven years by LaPlaca Cohen Advertising in New York and a predecessor, LaPlaca Design. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Clint Youle, an early television weatherman, misstated the year he left ''The Camel News Caravan'' program. It was 1956, when the program ended, not 1959.

title: China to Allow Debt-for-Stock Swaps in State Companies
description: Faced with more than $200 billion in bad debt at moribund state-owned companies, Chinese officials said today that they would begin a broad program of debt-for-equity swaps that could include some foreign ownership.

title: State Parole Board Member Convicted of Lying to Jury
description: A member of the New York State Parole Board was convicted yesterday of lying to a grand jury that was investigating whether contributors to Gov. George E. Pataki's 1994 election campaign had received or been promised favorable parole rulings for their imprisoned relatives.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: BRAZIL TRADING PROTEST
description: The Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro stock exchanges were shut down for a half-hour by hundreds of traders protesting a tax on financial transactions. Traders, along with the brokerage firms that employ them, complained that the 0.38 percent tax on each trade has led to a migration of trading of Brazilian stocks to the New York Stock Exchange and other exchanges where costs are cheaper. A banner reading, ''We Can't Bury the Brazilian Market'' was placed on the trading floor during the protest. The financial transactions tax is part of the Government's effort to narrow its budget deficit. Simon Romero

title: Yoshii Isn't All Smiles After Being Shifted to Reliever
description: Masato Yoshii was the last to know. On Friday, after he had allowed seven runs in one and a third innings in the shortest outing by a Mets starter in nearly two years, Yoshii was asked if he was worried that he was headed for the bullpen.

title: Sehorn to Miss First Preseason Game
description: The tangled saga of Jason Sehorn's stalled comeback from knee surgery took a new twist today when the Giants announced that the hamstring strain that had kept him from participating in training camp would keep him out of the first preseason game Aug. 13 and probably the second one. Sehorn then blamed himself for the injury, saying he did not stretch his newly sculptured, muscular body long enough before workouts.

title: Back to Amtrak Basics
description: To the Editor:

title: Protests in Georgia Derail Art Show Headed for U.S.
description: Politics in the Republic of Georgia, which faces parliamentary elections in October and a presidential vote in April, have scuttled a landmark traveling exhibition of Georgian gold and silver objects, illustrated manuscripts, religious icons and other art that had been due in the United States this fall.

title: Strong July and Rebates Position Auto Makers for Record Year
description: Auto makers dangled rebates in front of their customers last month, and like fish to bait, buyers snapped up new cars and trucks. That led to a brisk annual sales pace of 17 million vehicles and kept the industry on track for a record-setting sales year.

title: House Votes to Cut $2 Billion From Clinton Foreign Aid Plan
description: A $12.6 billion foreign aid bill was passed by the House today but faces a White House veto threat over its deep spending cuts and anti-abortion language.

title: Take the Money And Narrow the Field
description: It is an old political ploy for incumbents: raise enough money early enough and possible challengers will think twice before taking you on.

title: Port Authority Hits Jackpot as Big Game Players Cross the Hudson
description: Lottery officials in New Jersey said they would not know until today who, if anyone, won the $110 million jackpot in last night's Big Game drawing. But even before the winning numbers (4, 40, 42, 43, 48; big money ball, 8) were drawn there was one clear winner in the game yesterday: the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGISTER, ALBERT LAYTON III
description: REGISTER-Albert Layton III. Of Edgartown, Mass., formerly of Rumson, NJ, on July 27, after a long illness. Survived by his wife Hope Register, sons Croft of Wayne, PA, Frederick of Phoenix, AZ, daughter Candace Langan of Jamestown, RI, & six grandchildren, sister Cornelia R. (Porter) Hoagland of Noank, CT, brother William Barrett Register of New York City. Also stepchildren Kent Ransom Costikyan III, Timothy W., and Warren K. Services were held at The Edgartown Federated Church on July 30. Contributions may be made to Alzheimers Association of Massachusetts, POB 953, Barnstable, MA. 02630.

title: Oakley Talks to Knicks And Meets With Lakers
description: At odds since their parting, Charles Oakley and the Knicks seem to be getting along swell these days. The club's former power forward, traded to Toronto last summer, spoke to Knicks officials in the past two weeks about possibly rejoining the team as a free agent.

title: Liberties; The Boy Can't Help It
description: Pierce and Demi and Liam were there. And Quentin and Salman and Spike and Amber. I never actually saw any of them. I had to content myself with glimpses of Kevin Bacon's pouffy hair and Madonna's pouffy biceps.

title: Aid to Farmers Puts Parties In 'Political Bidding Contest'
description: Locked in what one Senator called a compassion competition, Republicans and Democrats struggled today over sending billions of dollars of emergency aid to American farmers.

title: Reorganization At Dentsu Y.& R.
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York and Dentsu Inc. in Tokyo said yesterday that they would make substantial changes in the ownership and top management of the Asian operations of their longtime joint venture, Dentsu Young & Rubicam.

title: For a Scandal-Scarred General, the Gleam Appears to Be Back on the Brass
description: At a level where there are few second chances in the United States military, Gen. Joseph Ralston has been not only redeemed but resurrected.

title: Indonesia President Accepts Assembly Election Results
description: Stepping in to end nearly two months of delays and squabbling by elections officials, President B. J. Habibie of Indonesia today officially accepted the results of a Parliamentary election on June 7.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Pro Wrestling Tries to Pin Down a Share Value
description: Finally, a part of professional wrestling that might not be rigged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIOFFI, ALBERT F., M.D.
description: CIOFFI-Albert F., M.D. Beloved husband of Margaret M. Cioffi, M.D.; father to Vincent, Mary, Theresa, Peggy; and grandfather to Mitchell, Jeremiah, Michael, Savannah and Gabriel. Dr. Cioffi is also survived by his beloved sister, Marie. There will be a wake at Reddens Funeral Home in New York City on Wednesday, August 4, 7-9 PM and Thursday, August 5 from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be held Friday, August 6 at Our Lady of Pompeii Church on Bleecker St., NYC, at 10:15 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONICBERG, LILLIAN
description: GONICBERG-Lillian. Died August 2. Loving sister of Madeline Leudesdorf and Jerome Gonicberg, aunt of Beth Leudesdorf LaBaw, Lawrence Leudesdorf, Paul and Robert Gonicberg. Services on Wednesday, 12 noon at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: SFX to Buy Apollo Leisure for $254 Million
description: SFX Entertainment Inc., a leading producer of live music, theater and sporting events, agreed yesterday to buy Apollo Leisure Group for $254 million in securities to add arenas and theaters in Britain and Ireland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTOF, ROSE
description: ORTOF-Rose. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute extends heartfelt sympathies to Trustee Phyllis Rosen and her family on the passing of her beloved mother, Rose Ortof. May your memories of her offer comfort to you. Our sincerest condolences to Phyllis, Leonard, their children and grandchildren. David Taub, Chairman of the Board David Glaser, President

title: A Majority Over 45 Say Sex Lives Are Just Fine
description: A new survey finds that more than half of Americans 45 or over say they are satisfied with their sex lives, but that sexual activity and contentment diminish with age, largely because of declining health and the loss of partners.

title: Correction Officers Disciplined After Escapes
description: Three correction officers have been suspended and two others have been reassigned after two escapes in the last 10 days from a lower Manhattan jail, city correction officials said yesterday.

title: Dolphins Cut Wheatley in First Week of Camp
description: The curious case of Tyrone Wheatley continued yesterday, with the Miami Dolphins cutting the former No. 1 draft pick of the Giants before Wheatley even got to finish out a week of training camp for Coach Jimmy Johnson.

title: Reforming Special Education
description: The United States Department of Education threatened earlier this summer to withhold more than $300 million in aid unless New York State changed a funding formula that encouraged school districts to dump as many children as possible into special education classes. The formula gave districts extra money for putting children in special education. But the dumping that resulted violated Federal law. The New York State Legislature has now changed the formula, giving districts a financial incentive to begin mainstreaming the disabled by putting them in general classes. This is a useful first step. But more needs to be done to overhaul a special education system that is both discriminatory and educationally unsound.

title: Albany Agrees On Monitoring Of Mentally Ill
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders have agreed on a plan that gives the courts new authority to force mentally ill people to undergo treatment or face hospitalization against their will.

title: Foes in Seoul Say 'Mr. Clean' Is Losing Fight On Corruption
description: SEOUL  Foes of President Kim Dae Jung have a new complaint to add to their criticism of him nearly 20 months after his election as the hero of South Korean dissidents and the darling of sympathetic liberals abroad.

title: INTERNET CURRENCY TRADING
description: Freeserve P.L.C., the British subscription-free Internet access provider, will introduce a way to trade currencies on line in the fall. Freeserve, which has just issued shares of the company to the public, hopes to replicate the success of on-line trading firms like E*Trade in the foreign currency exchange market by substantially lowering the commissions on transactions. Globalnet Financial.com, which developed the software to run the currency trading, will operate the Freeserve service, called Matchbook FX. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Cut Taxes? First, Cut the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Pediatricians Suggest Limits On TV Viewing by Children
description: Children under 2 years old should not watch television, older children should not have television sets in their bedrooms and pediatricians should have parents fill out a ''media history,'' along with a medical history, on office visits, according to recommendations by the American Academy of Pediatrics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUDERER, FAY G.
description: KAUDERER-Fay G. Of Lynbrook, New York. On July 31, 1999. Beloved mother of Bruce Kauderer and Carol Meltzer. Adored grandmother of Laura and Sarah Kauderer and Alison and Danielle Meltzer. Devoted sister of Irwin Glantz and sister-in-law Gene Glantz. Services were held August 1, 1999 at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre. A dedicated psychiatric social worker for more than 20 years and a unique and special individual who will be deeply missed by her family and many friends.

title: NISSAN BUYS MAZDA STAKE
description: The Nissan Motor Company, an affiliate of Renault S.A. of France, said it would buy the Mazda Motor Corporation's stake in the Japanese companies' automatic transmission joint venture. The move could help Nissan cut costs by developing transmissions with Renault. Mazda, an affiliate of the Ford Motor Company, will sell its 34.7 percent stake in Jatco, based in Shizuoka, near Tokyo, to Nissan, according to a Nissan spokeswoman, Ritsuko Harimoto. The price was not disclosed.

title: Mitchell Banned Until April 1
description: Dennis Mitchell, the former Olympic bronze medalist who won the United States 100-meter title in June, was banned from competition yesterday until next April 1 for failing a drug test.

title: Notebook; More Student Soldiers
description: To meet what it says is a growing demand from high schools, the Army is planning to double its Junior R.O.T.C. program.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about possible misinterpretation of neuroscience studies by advocates of early childhood development programs misstated the year a White House Conference on Early Childhood Development and Learning was held. It was 1997, not 1977.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN FALLS. The yen fell after Japan's Finance Minister suggested that Japan and the United States were ready to coordinate sales of yen to stem its strength. In New York, the dollar settled at 115.28 yen, up from 114.22.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENWALD, HELEN NEWMAN
description: GREENWALD-Helen Newman, 92, of Great Neck, NY on August 3, 1999. Beloved wife of Herbert. Devoted mother of Rose Landowne, grandmother of Dena & Jay Bailey, and Lea, Shifra and Aryeh Landowne & great grandmother of Micha & Keren Bailey. Services 1:30PM, Wednesday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W.76 St., NY.

title: Nets Sign Feick and Waive Seikaly

Dr. Simon served the institution & its patients for more than sixty years and was also an admired & respected teacher for generations. He was a dedicated and talented surgeon who demonstrated an extraordinary concern for others throughout his career. Following his retirement from pratice in Plastic Surgery, he remained involved in teaching and professional organizations and also continued his writing. He was honored with the Jacobi Medallion at Mount Sinai and received many other awards for his outstanding achievements. He was a beloved member of our Attending Staff and has earned a lasting memory in our hearts. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR SETS PRICE FOR CYRIX UNIT
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that the price of its Cyrix personal computer processor business, which is being sold to Via Technologies Inc. of Taiwan, had been set at $167 million. National Semiconductor, based in Santa Clara, Calif., paid $570 million for Cyrix in 1997, lost money on the business and set June 30 of this year as a deadline for either closing it or selling it. That day, it announced a preliminary agreement with Via Tech, which makes chips that act as translators between a PC's microprocessor and its peripherals. Via Tech said it would pay part of the sales price at the close of the deal, with remaining payments based on future revenue from the Cyrix product line.

It's a file cabinet of sorts, a catch-basket for ideas that emerged over nearly four years of writing. On a recent afternoon, Mr. Bolcom fished in the tub among myriad scraps of paper and extracted one. On it were a few bars of notes and the scribbled title ''Eddie's Pride.''

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; REFINANCING BY MEXICO
description: The Mexican Government sold $400 million in bonds that mature in 2016 and used the proceeds to repurchase $510 million in outstanding debt at a discount. The refinancing reduced Mexico's debts by $110 million and will cut an additional $80 million from the country's debt-servicing costs over time, the Finance Ministry said. The move was seen as another step in the Government's effort to strengthen Mexico's finances and reassure foreign investors so that they won't withdraw capital ahead of the presidential elections next summer. News of the refinancing helped rally the Mexico stock market, which advanced for the first time in four days. The main market index rose 1.4 percent. Rick Wills

title: ST. PAUL TO TRIM 1,000 JOBS TO REDUCE EXPENSES
description: The St. Paul Companies said it would cut 1,000 jobs, or 7.4 percent of its positions, as part of an effort to reduce expenses by $100 million. St. Paul, an insurance company based in St. Paul, plans to take a charge against earnings related to the costs of the layoffs in the third quarter and will make most of the cuts by the end of the year. St. Paul and other insurers are cutting costs in response to declining rates. The cost-cutting is separate from St. Paul's plan, announced last month, to sell most of its personal insurance business to Met Life Auto and Home, a unit of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

title: Reading Mac Disks On Windows Machines
description: A few years ago, when Brian Landwehr was trying to sell software that enabled PC's to read Macintosh floppy disks, people probably thought he was crazy. Here was a product based on two technologies that surely would soon vanish: Apple computers and floppy diskettes.

title: Hope Rises in Syria for Peace With Israel
description: From here, only a few coils of barbed wire lie between Syria and the sliver of its land that has been held by Israel for 32 years. To Syrians the high-tech observation posts on surrounding hilltops seem to laugh down at them, a boast about just who controls the Golan Heights.

title: Sharing Ol' Blue Eyes Three Ways
description: How is a young male performer to approach the legacy of Frank Sinatra without sounding like an inferior parodist of something that can't be duplicated? Eric Comstock, a rising young cabaret singer and pianist, has found a way in his utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is what Scouting taught me: Goodness will prevail.''

title: Do You Have Enough RAM? It Depends on Which Kind
description: RAM is good. As is the case with friends, you can never have too much random access memory, that magical substance that allows us to process our words, calculate our spreadsheets, surf the Web and destroy invading alien nations.

title: A Web Site That Shows How Your New Gadget Works
description: Many product manuals are written in at least eight languages, none of them comprehensible to the average user. With the introduction of the Live Manuals site (www.livemanuals.com), the answer to how to get rid of the blinking lights on your VCR could be just a click away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDSTEIN, MORRIS (MURRAY), M.D.
description: FELDSTEIN - Morris (Murray), M.D., formerly chief of Opthalmic Surgery and on the staff of Mt. Sinai Hospital, in New York City on August 2, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Lucille Dee Rubin. Loving uncle of Marion Malakoff of Philadelphia; Fred and Joy Malakoff of Miami Beach, FL; Philip J. Rubin of Landenberg, PA; and Carolyn & Steven Barg of Chappaqua, NY. Brother-in-law of Eugene and Arlene Rubin of Newton, MA. Graveside services on Monday, Aug 9 at 1:45 p.m. at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. Gifts in his memory may be made to Mt. Sinai Hospital, 100th St and 5th Ave, New York, NY 10029. For information, please contact the Levine Chapel, Brookline, MA.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Briefing column last Thursday about Tonga's receiving Security Council approval for its admission to the United Nations misstated China's position, because of an error by Agence France-Presse. China did not threaten to vote against Tonga because of Tonga's position on Taiwan; in fact, Tonga has relations with China, not with Taiwan. (In the end, the council approved Tonga by acclamation; there was no vote.)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the actress Kathleen Chalfant and her husband as he was shaving her head for her final week of performances in the play ''Wit'' misstated his given name. He is Henry Chalfant, not David.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMMERMAN, ROBERT E.
description: TIMMERMAN-Robert E. Died July 29, 1999 at the Greenwich Hospital of Alzheimer's disease. Mr. Timmerman was a long-time resident of Greenwich, Conn., but also maintained homes in Palm Beach, Fla., and Kennebunkport, Me. Mr. Timmerman was the son of the late Hearst Publisher Edward W. Timmerman and Maude Ayer Timmerman of Chicago. He is survived by his wife, Paula Reid Timmerman. Mr. Timmerman attended the Taft School and Brown University. During World War II, he was an officer in the Air Corps. During his lifetime, Mr. Timmerman had an active career in the field of advertising, holding senior positions with a number of agencies in New York City. At the time of his retirement, he was a senior vice president with Needham, Harper, Steers. In addition to his business interests, Mr. Timmerman was active in a number of social clubs including the Kennebunk River Club, Greenwich Country Club, Metropolitan Club and the Everglades Club. A private family service will be held in Rhode Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Foundation would be preferred.

description: To the Editor:

title: Web Sites for Class Reunions Strengthen Old School Ties
description: LIVING in London, Carolyn Band Mehta did not attend her 20th high school reunion in Newton, Mass.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pfizer Assigns Account to Deutsch
description: Pfizer Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had named Deutsch Inc. in New York to handle creative, direct marketing and interactive duties for its Zyrtec anti-allergy drug, with billings estimated at $75 million. The previous agency for creative duties was HMC in New York, part of Omnicom Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIMANN, LORRAINE GALLAGHER.
description: FREIMANN-Lorraine Gallagher. A long-time resident of Palm Beach, Fla., and former resident of Chicago, Fort Wayne, Ind., and New York City, died at her home on Tuesday, August 3, 1999. She is survived by two daughters, Mrs. Danielle F. Basil of Palm Beach, and Mrs. Francine F. Snyder of Chicago; six grandchildren, Monique B. Refkin, Michelle B. Rodwell, and Paul, Lorraine, Stephen and David Snyder; and three great - grandchildren, Courtney Refkin and Ashley and Jessica Rodwell. Mrs. Freimann served as the president of the board of trustees of St. Mary's Hospital for many years, and was presently an Honorary Life Trustee and member of the Intracoastal Health Foundation Board of Trustees for St. Mary's and Good Samaritan Medical Centers, West Palm Beach, Fla. She also served as a board member of the American Cancer Society of Palm Beach as well as ''Thrift Inc.'' of Palm Beach. A former board member of the Society of the Four Arts, Palm Beach, Mrs. Freimann was also an honorary board member of Rosarian Academy, West Palm Beach. Identified with Catholic Charities locally and in former residences, she was a Dame of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a Lady of the Knights of Malta. Mrs. Freimann served on the board of St. Mary's College, Notre Dame, Ind., and was a board member of the Art Council of the University of Notre Dame. She held an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from St. Joseph's College, Van Rensellear, Ind. Among locally received honors was the philanthropic ''Award of the Year'' given by the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce, the award for philanthropy from the Salvation Army, and the ''Woman of the Year'' award from Noreen McKeen Residence, West Palm Beach. Mrs. Freimann was a board member of the Stehlin Foundation for Cancer Research, Houston, a founding member of the Junior League of Fort Wayne, and also served on the National Board of the Junior Leagues of America. She attended St. Mary's College, Notre Dame, and was graduated from the University of Chicago with a bachelor's degree in philosophy. Mrs. Freimann was a member of the Everglades Club of Palm Beach, the Women's Athletic Club, Chicago, and the Metropolitan Club of New York. She was a member of St. Edward's Catholic Church, Palm Beach, and was active with the St. Edward's Guild. Mrs. Freimann was the donor of the St. Edward's Parish Hall to the Diocese of Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers, those who wish may make a contribution to the charity of their choice. The Funeral Mass at St. Edward's Catholic Church, Palm Beach, and the entombment at Our Lady Queen of Peace Catholic Cemetery, Royal Palm Beach, will be held privately. For further information, contact Quattlebaum - Holleman - Burse Funeral Home, 561-832-5171.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EDELMAN, SYLVIA
description: EDELMAN-Sylvia. August 5, 1998. You're always in my thoughts. I love you so very much. Barbara

title: Day Traders as Gamblers
description: The tragedy of Mark Barton in no way proves that day trading, in which he lost a lot of money quite rapidly, is evil. But it is a reminder that technological advances have made it easier to treat stock trading as something like casino gambling. It must be closely regulated, particularly to assure that the gamblers understand the risks.

title: Frequent Fliers To Get Extension
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said today that the airline's frequent-flier miles would no longer expire provided that a customer took part in the program once every three years.

title: NEW JERSEY COURT OVERTURNS OUSTER OF GAY BOY SCOUT
description: Equating the Boy Scouts with such public accommodations as restaurants, libraries, schools and theaters, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the organization's expulsion of a gay Eagle Scout in 1990 violated the state's antidiscrimination law.

title: Judge, Faulting Agencies, Halts Logging Deals
description: Five years after the Clinton Administration hammered out a landmark plan to settle legal and environmental disputes over logging across the Pacific Northwest, the region's timber wars are flaring up again.

title: On-Line Medical Information Does Poorly on Accuracy Exam
description: The growing field of on-line medical information was recently given an exam, and the results were not good. According to a study published this week in the journal Cancer, more than a third of the medical sites scrutinized had not been subjected to peer review. And at least 6 percent of them contained wrong information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTER, REGINA
description: LICHTER-Regina. Temple Israel, Lawrence, NY, mourns the death of its member and extends deepest sympathy to the family. Alan J. Hartstein, President Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi

title: Crew and Giuliani Are Set to Meet Again
description: A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sent a terse letter to Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew over his cancellation of six scheduled meetings, the two officials agreed yesterday to meet next week.

title: In Blow to G.E., Agency Finds Fish in Hudson Unsafe to Eat
description: In a major step toward a possible order to dredge the Hudson River, the Environmental Protection Agency reported today that PCB's pose an unacceptably high risk of cancer and other ills in people who eat fish from the river's northern reaches.

title: Keep Your Ears on the Road
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Agencies Make Acquisitions
description: Four New York-based agencies have made acquisitions.

title: BRITISH ECONOMIC STRENGTH
description: Healthy growth in Britain's services industry provided the newest evidence that the economy, seen as heading for stagnation a few months back, is on the rebound. Figures from a purchasing-supply trade group showed services grew in July at the fastest rate in more than a year. The figures strengthened analysts' forecasts that the Bank of England, which has cut interest rates five times since last October, will decide to leave the benchmark rate unchanged at 5 percent when its policy makers convene today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWER, CLOTHILDE DE VEZE,
description: BOWER-Clothilde De Veze, 92, of Delray Beach, FL, and formerly of Bronxville, NY, on August 1, 1999. Beloved wife of Marvin Bower and devoted mother of E. Richard Gledhill.

title: For Mourners in Atlanta, Some Solace but No Answers
description: There were no explanations inside the big white church today as the city officially remembered the victims of last week's shooting spasm. The only solace offered seemed to be the collective nature of the quandary, an admission that no one could truly comprehend why 13 lives were lost when a mind slipped its bounds.

title: Dubuque Journal; The Slight That Years, All 75, Can't Erase
description: It has always struck the people of this proud old Iowa town as an awfully snooty remark.

title: Congress Close to Spending Most of Next Year's Budget Surplus
description: Congress tonight moved closer to spending most of the projected surplus in next year's budget with two ''emergency'' measures to aid farmers and conduct the 2000 census.

title: OBITUARY : Geoffrey Nicholson, 70, Acclaimed Sports Writer
description: Geoffrey Nicholson, 70, an acclaimed writer about bicycle racing and rugby, died Tuesday in Wales after a long battle with cancer.

title: So Little Feet Can Reach the Floor
description: SCALE is everything -- and not just in Wonderland. It's hard to be creative if your feet don't reach the floor. Children's furniture should be not only durable but also tactile, so children will want to handle the pieces and interact with them. (Washable is good, too.) In the words of Riaz Jurney, the owner of Skools Inc., a children's furniture company, ''We don't just make smaller versions of adult furniture.''

title: The Big City; Do Daddies Get as Good As They Give?
description: IN his analysis of parenthood, Chris Rock does not rely heavily on the methodology of Gary Becker, the Nobel laureate economist. Mr. Becker's 1991 book, ''A Treatise on the Family,'' has more math than you will find in Mr. Rock's new work, ''Chris Rock: Bigger and Blacker.'' But they have independently reached some similar conclusions.

title: Economic Scene; Oil and Those Slippery Anti-Dumping Laws
description: On Monday the Commerce Department is scheduled to weigh in on a trade dispute that a number of economists say could take the country's fair-trade laws to new heights of absurdity.

description: In percent

title: TWO ACQUISITIONS BY PALLADIUM'S MEDIA PACKAGING UNIT
description: The Mediapak Corporation, the world's largest maker of compact-disk cases and a unit of Palladium Equity Partners L.L.C., a closely held investment firm in New York, said yesterday that it had acquired two closely held companies for $299 million in cash, stock and notes to expand its product lines in the United States and Europe. Mediapak, which is based in Atlanta, bought Alpha Enterprises and the Joyce Molding Corporation in two separate transactions. The combined media packaging company will have revenue of about $250 million and supply packaging products for compact disks, VHS videocassettes and DVD disks. It will be based in Atlanta and will have eight manufacturing sites in the United States and Europe.

title: Two Lessons in One Deal From a Tournament Final
description: Six decades ago, a Chicago businessman named Walter Jacobs won two national titles and retired from the game. He was the founder of the Hertz Corporation, so he had plenty of business to attend to. By a curious coincidence, another Chicago businessman named Jacobs heads a major limousine company and is now making his mark in bridge.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 25 about safety in private airplanes misstated the frequency with which they are involved in fatal accidents. Each year there is, on average, one fatal accident for every 600 planes in America, not every 300. The article also misstated a Federal Aviation Administration requirement for pilots. To carry passengers, a pilot must have completed three landings and takeoffs in the previous 90 days, or fly with an instructor. A pilot does not need to meet those requirements to fly alone.

title: Rescue Time at the Apollo: Time Warner to Control Board
description: State officials are working out final details of an arrangement that would give Time Warner a controlling role in rescuing Harlem's financially troubled Apollo Theater, officials and corporate executives said yesterday.

title: AMERICA ONLINE IN $100 MILLION PACT WITH CARD MAKER
description: America Online Inc. said it had reached a $100 million agreement making Americangreetings.com the sole provider of greeting cards on America Online's Web sites. The agreement, for five and a half years, extends an existing arrangement to the America Online Web services AOL.com, ICQ, Digital City, Netscape Netcenter and Compuserve, as well as America Online's services in Canada, Britain, Australia, Japan, Germany and France. The original deal covered only basic America Online service. Americangreetings.com is a unit of the American Greetings Corporation of Cleveland.

title: Brazil Steelmaker to Add U.S. Link to Pan-American Chain
description: Gerdau S.A., one of Brazil's biggest steelmakers, moved to expand its manufacturing operations into the United States today with a deal to acquire control of the Ameristeel Corporation.

title: A Manhattan Match
description: International cricket comes to New York tomorrow in an all-star matchup.

title: Bigotry in the Boy Scouts
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has issued a powerful ruling against anti-gay bigotry in the Boy Scouts of America. No organization that recruits schoolchildren and says it is guided by honesty and respect for others has any right to ban homosexuals. While courts in other states like California have allowed the Boy Scouts to skirt civil rights laws, the New Jersey Court showed wisdom in refusing to sanction bigotry by this important civic institution.

title: TURF; Oh, by the Way, We're Taking the Stove
description: IN the Hamptons these days, it seems that you can take it with you.

title: A Clear Case of Clinton Fatigue
description: If Hillary Clinton's remarks to Talk magazine connecting the President's infidelities to childhood emotional abuse were calculated to lift her poll numbers in New York, she was misguided.

title: CARLISLE IN $350 MILLION DEAL FOR TITAN INTERNATIONAL
description: The Carlisle Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Titan International Inc. for stock worth up to $350 million. Carlisle will also assume debt of $250 million to $300 million. Carlisle, which is based in Syracuse, makes products for the construction and automotive industries. Titan, in Quincy, Ill., makes wheel and tire assemblies for off-road vehicles. The deal is intended to capitalize on new Titan technology for the off-highway wheel and tire business.

title: Cell Phone Craze Has Italy Humming
description: The gentleman buying an espresso at The Friends Art Cafe in Rome looked a bit startled when the male cashier called him ''amore'' as he handed over his change. But the cashier pointed to the tiny cell phone in his ear and explained that he was talking to his girlfriend.

title: A Calm Front Threatens, but Two Buildings Charge In to Quicken the Pulse
description: Just when it seemed as though cool minimalism was on the upswing here, Rios Associates has completed two buildings that show there is still plenty of sizzle: Rock, a new restaurant (interior and exterior, above left) and the 3-D Terminator 2 attraction at Universal Studios Hollywood (above far right).

title: France Says Algeria Is Emerging From the Ordeal That Began in '92
description: When Abdelaziz Bouteflika was elected President of Algeria in April, in a one-candidate vote that hardly seemed likely to end a civil war that has killed 100,000 people since 1992, the French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, expressed ''concern.''

title: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO BUY BACK BONDS AND SAVE INTEREST
description: Like a family that suddenly finds itself with enough cash to pay off both its credit cards and its mortgage, the Clinton Administration moved today to take advantage of projected Federal budget surpluses by overhauling the way the Government handles its finances.

title: Whitman Sets Rules On Bottled Water Quality
description: After a surge in consumption of bottled water that predates this summer's drought, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced a series of measures yesterday to insure the quality of bottled water.

title: A Friendly Game Leads to a Charge of Murder
description: Jacquelyn Woods was on the telephone, as usual, with her friend Efrain Casas one evening last January, and she could hear Efrain and his high school buddy Eduardo Rivera playing with two semiautomatic pistols owned by Efrain's father.

title: Most Off Welfare Get Jobs, but Not All Long Term
description: Two-thirds of the people who left New York State's rapidly declining welfare rolls found jobs within the year after they stopped receiving public assistance, according to a new study commissioned by the state.

title: NATO Appoints British Defense Chief to Its Top Civilian Post
description: Defense Secretary George Robertson of Britain, who began his working life organizing whisky workers for labor unions in his native Scotland, was appointed by the 19 NATO allies today to be NATO's next Secretary General.

description: Riverfront Art

title: Council Speaker Criticizes Proposals to Amend City Charter
description: A Mayoral commission considering changes to the City Charter is advocating revisions that would weaken the city's legislature and increasing the Mayor's powers, the City Council Speaker charges in testimony to be delivered at a public hearing tonight.

description: Deal Near on Apollo Theater

title: Internet Showing its Value In Remote Alaskan Villages
description: FROM this remote town about 30 miles north of the Arctic Circle, six doctors serve a dozen villages in an area the size of Indiana. With the help of the Internet, diagnosing health problems has become just a little easier.

title: Downshifting in Argentina; Recession and Rivalries With Brazil Stall the Economy
description: When Fiat S.p.A. inaugurated its giant Cordoba auto plant less than three years ago, Argentine Cabinet ministers clinked champagne glasses with senior Fiat executives from Turin. They gave union leaders hearty bearhugs and toasted the computerized, robotized assembly lines never seen here before.

title: The Seattleization Of Scandinavian Design
description: Conceived by the Swedish-born designer Asa Sundland and fabricated by her Seattle-born husband, Preston Singletary, these vases meld the robustness of Scandinavian design with the skills of a Seattle glassworker. They are among the contemporary items newly available at the OK store, a treasure trove of classic modern and contemporary design. They include Flowerpot (left, from $400 for a vase 9 inches high to $600 for one 12 inches high) and the Genie collection (right, $3,500), designed by Mr. Singletary. OK is at 8303 West Third Street; (323) 653-3501.

title: Delta and United Considering Major Expansion at Kennedy
description: In what could lead to a fresh wave of construction at Kennedy International Airport, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that Delta Air Lines and United Airlines were discussing major investments in new and expanded terminals at the airport.

title: Overcrowding A Deathtrap On Wheels In France
description: Aboard a train from Paris to Limoges, the jumble of characters in Patrice Chereau's new film can be found literally bumping into one another, captured by the hand-held camera as they break up and make up to the accompaniment of an eclectic (from Nina Simone to P. J. Harvey to Gustav Mahler), busy soundtrack. There are those who admire French films just for the way they avoid such things, but stylishly diffident soap opera is on the rise in France, too. In lovelorn ensemble stories like Arnaud Desplechin's ''My Sex Life (Or How I Got Into an Argument)'' or Olivier Assayas's ''Late Summer, Early Autumn,'' friends mix and match with nonstop complications. Mr. Chereau means to one-up that formula by having his characters do that on wheels.

title: Clintons Try to Quell Debate Over Interview
description: President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton both said today that they were not trying to make excuses for Mr. Clinton's marital infidelities, as may have been suggested by Mrs. Clinton's recent comments that he was abused as a child.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EMERSON RADIO CORP. , Parsippany, N.J., a maker of home electronics products, said it planned to sell its stake in Sport Supply Group Inc. to Oaktree Capital Management Corp., Los Angeles, for $28.9 million.

description: Q. AOL's Instant Messenger program automatically installed itself when I upgraded my Netscape browser. How can I remove the icon for it from my PC's taskbar?

description: He is the unfamiliar guy standing next to the court, a stranger just waiting for his chance to get in the next pickup game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNELL, HARRIET WILKES.
description: CORNELL-Harriet Wilkes. Cornell University mourns the loss of a devoted friend and supporter, Harriet W. Cornell. Mrs. Cornell and her husband, George D. Cornell, were honored as Foremost Benefactors of the University for their steadfast support which helped to establish the Edward Cornell Law Librarianship, the Edward Cornell Chair of Law, and the Derek Bryceson Scholarship Fund in the College of Human Ecology. The Cornells also supported the renovation of Bailey Hall and made one of the most generous scholarship gifts in the University's history, establishing the George and Harriet Cornell Scholarship Fund. Harriet's devotion to the needs of deserving students inspired all who came in contact with her, and she was always pleased to meet with the grateful students who had benefited from her good works. Harriet had a profound love for animals, as evidenced in her support for Cornell's Veterinary College and such projects as the wildbird rehabiliation center at the Dreher Park Zoo in Palm Beach, FL. The entire Cornell community is greatly diminished by the loss of this compassionate and sensitive friend. We extend our profound sympathy to George D. Cornell at this time of great loss. Harriet Cornell will be greatly missed. Hunter R. Rawlings, III President, Cornell Univ. Harold Tanner, Chairman of the Board Cornell University

title: Pricing the Past
description: From one perspective it is easy to see how a Federal arbitration panel, in a binding 2-to-1 vote, could conclude, as it did this week, that the Zapruder film of John F. Kennedy's assassination was worth $16 million, or more than $615,000 a second. That is what the Justice Department will have to pay the Zapruder family to compensate it for permanently retaining, as law now requires, the home movie shot by Abraham Zapruder, who died in 1970. If the only standard of the film's value is what the market will bear, then $16 million may turn out to be something of a bargain. Auction fever and Kennedy fever are both running high, and there is no telling what price the Zapruder film would have brought had it been put up for public sale.

title: Under-Age Gambling Costs Player Her Money
description: The Atlantic City Hilton agreed yesterday to pay a $10,000 fine for allowing under-age gambling, closing the book on the story of a woman who won more than $200,000 but wound up owing money because of it, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHICK, NINA
description: SCHICK-Nina. Age 90 of East Hampton, New York died on July 27th, 1999. Mrs. Schick trained as an artist in Paris and London, and studied with Serge Soudekine in New York. In 1947 she founded the Green Thumb Flowers Inc., which was a leading floral designer in New York for the next thirty years, furnishing flowers for many elite social events and the homes of the leading hostesses of the day. After selling the Green Thumb in 1980, Mrs. Schick resumed painting and exhibited at the Benson and Clayton-Liberatore galleries on Long Island and in Paris, France. Her paintings hang in several notable collections. She leaves a beloved husband, Alexandre, two devoted children, Janine Luke and Anthony Evnin, two grandchildren, Luke and Timothy Evnin, and two great granddaughters, Alexandra and Caroline Evnin. Whoever came into her life was enriched by her kindness, generosity and joie de vivre.

title: LTV TO BUY A METAL FABRICATION COMPANY IN CHICAGO
description: The LTV Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Welded Tube Company from Smorgon Steel Group Ltd. of Australia for an undisclosed sum. Welded Tube, based in Chicago, makes structural steel tubing products. It had sales of about $130 million in the year that ended on June 30 and is building a tubing plant in Portland, Ore., that will increase its capacity by nearly 50 percent. LTV, the steel manufacturer and metal fabricator based in Cleveland, reported revenue of $4.27 billion for 1998. LTV said the acquisition would provide it with a line of tubular products and increase its ability to serve the nonresidential construction market.

description: Solar eclipses don't just happen every day, and they can't be seen from just anywhere.
