description: Is your child having trouble with the fax modem? Maybe Mattel can help. The giant toy maker announced this week that it will release desktop computers with Barbie- and Hot Wheels-themed cases.

title: Campbell-Ewald Gets Conoco Work
description: Conoco Inc. in Houston said yesterday that it had awarded its new corporate account to Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., part of Interpublic Group. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Melding of Minds Among the Roses
description: ONE day in early June on Long Island, I was thunderstruck by the big pink roses climbing up a pergola in a Bridgehampton garden that's like a second home to me. The luminous, satiny double blossoms hung like lush petticoats from the crossbar over my head, and I gaped up at them, chanting: ''I want that rose. I want that rose.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Dwindling Market in U.S. Treasury Bonds
description: For nearly two decades, the Government securities market has grown exponentially as Uncle Sam has regularly relied upon it to help finance the nation's $5.5 trillion in debt. But looking ahead, the financial markets are heading into strange territory, a landscape in which Treasury securities -- a mainstay of professional hedging strategies, an influence on consumer and corporate borrowing costs, and a safe haven for those with no appetite for risk -- will become increasingly scarce.

description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it was acquiring the Union Carbide Corporation for $9.3 billion in stock in a deal that would join two household names and create a chemical giant second only to DuPont in size.

The New York Times asked the group's guitarist, Tom Morello, to write about his reaction to the festival and its aftermath: four reports of rape to police and a post-festival melee during which some audience members set fires, looted trucks and leapt through the flames until hundreds of New York State Police troopers arrived.

title: INTERNET SPEED
description: The quest for the LAN-speed record continues. Last week, computer scientists at Duke University announced that they had developed a system for standard Internet communications over a local area network, or LAN, that moved at a rate of more than one gigabit (one billion bits) per second. According to Jeff Chase, an assistant computer science professor at Duke, that's about twice the speed of the current fastest LAN and about 20,000 times faster than communication through a telephone modem. ''What we have done is provide the software support that's needed to allow others to achieve similar speeds on other networks that will arrive in the future,'' Dr. Chase said

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIKE, LAURENCE B.
description: PIKE-Laurence B. The Partners of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett are deeply saddened by the passing of their retired partner, Laurence B. Pike. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Norma, and to his entire family. The Partners of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett

title: Popular Teachers Become Pipeline to Corporations
description: DON HYATT is a 52-year-old high-school teacher, but lately his job is starting to resemble that of a high-powered sports agent. He gets phone calls from some scouts looking for fresh talent. He gets E-mail from others hoping to tap into his contacts. He has parents coming to him for advice.

title: Europe Isn't Taking a Needed Fiscal Step
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH BANK'S PROFITS TUMBLE
description: The British bank Standard Chartered P.L.C. reported a 30 percent decline in profits for the first half of the year, to $300 million, as the Asian economy forced the bank to set aside $388 million as a cushion against potentially bad loans. Economic problems in Asia have hit Standard Chartered harder than most big British banks. Its shares fell nearly 2 percent, to 941 pence, or $15.62, on concern that the bank's business in Asia, particularly in China, will suffer.

title: SEGA LOOKS TO AT&T
description: Sega Enterprises Ltd. of Japan said it was negotiating a partnership with the AT&T Corporation to provide an on-line service next month for American buyers of Sega's Internet-compatible Dreamcast video game player. Dreamcast, which will be sold in the United States beginning on Sept. 9, is the world's first home video game with a modem and is intended to capture a foothold in a $15 billion market dominated by the Sony Corporation's Playstation. Shoichiro Irimajiri, the president of Sega, called himself an ''Internet believer'' at a recent news conference announcing the company's on-line plans.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE RISES. Orange juice rose on concern that hot weather may harm the Florida orange crop, the nation's largest. In New York, orange juice for September delivery rose 1.65 cents, to 81.65 cents a pound.

title: Albany Tries Again to Aid Hasidic Village
description: Despite court rejections of three earlier laws intended to accomplish the same goal, the New York Legislature passed provisions in its budget bills early yesterday morning intended to provide funds for a public school district for handicapped Hasidic children in the upstate village of Kiryas Joel. A spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki said he would sign the new provision.

title: Sharing the Music
description: To the Editor:

title: Nebraska Students Getting a Look at the Innards of the Internet
description: THE cables, circuits and switches that make up the Internet are invisible to most people. But starting this fall, engineering students at the University of Nebraska at Omaha will get a firsthand look at exactly what route those Web pages and E-mail messages travel before appearing on their computer screens.

title: Veterans' Health System Can't Be Replaced
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIM, ESTHER
description: HAIM-Esther. On August 3, 1999 at home in Neponsit, NY. Loving wife of the late Samuel. Beloved mother of Marilyn (Stuart) Zerner, Gladys (Kenneth) Yoblon, Susan (Thomas) Robbio, Wendy (Dr. Ira) Kotler. Cherished grandmother of Adam and Andrew Yoblon, Paul and Jennifer Zerner, Joanna Kotler, Craig (Christine) and Dr. Jonathan (Jennifer) Yoken. Devoted sister of Edythe Fayman and Lillian Schwartz, and dear deceased brother and sisters Leo Fenster, Pearl Friedman, Martha Huberman, Frances Robbins and Selma Blane. Her nurturing, warmth and generosity endeared her to all. She will always be in our hearts. Service at Riverside, W.76 Street, Thursday, August 5th, 1:15 PM.

title: Ruling Party In Mexico Could Face 8-Party Front
description: After months of bickering, Mexico's main opposition parties -- which embrace widely differing ideologies -- are reporting surprising progress in negotiations to form an alliance against President Ernesto Zedillo's governing party in general elections next year.

title: First Lady Hears of Economic Fears, but Marriage Is Hot Topic
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton resumed her exploratory trip to New York today, listening to an assortment of complaints about the sluggish economy of western New York and facing a barrage of media questions about comments she made in a magazine article about her husband's marital infidelity.

title: Limits Urged For Managers Of Pensions
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed a rule to curb political contributions by managers of public pension funds in a bid to prevent a practice called pay to play.

title: Internet Selloff Brings Nasdaq A Correction
description: The technology-laden Nasdaq market slumped for the fifth consecutive session yesterday as Internet stocks suffered another pummeling.

title: With What Surplus?
description: If Congressional Republicans prevail, spending for farmers and the 2000 census could wipe out next year's $14 billion surplus before it ever materializes. Page A20.

title: GO2NET BUYS DOGPILE FOR $55 MILLION IN STOCK AND CASH
description: Go2Net Inc., which runs an Internet directory and a network of Web sites, said that it had acquired the closely held Dogpile L.L.C. for $55 million -- $40 million in stock and $15 million in cash -- to improve searches on its shopping and auction Web sites. The purchase price may increase if Dogpile reaches certain undisclosed performance goals in the next 18 months. Dogpile makes software that lets people search the Internet for information like the title or author of a file. Go2Net, which is based in Seattle, said users would be able to use Dogpile's technology to search for specific businesses, categories and products on Go2Net's HyperMart, Virtual Avenue and Haggle Online Web sites. Shares of Go2Net rose $1.625, to $50.75.

title: Christian Right's Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Johnny Can't Blink
description: C hildren under 2 years old should not watch television, older children should not have television sets in their bedrooms and pediatricians should have parents fill out a ''media history,'' along with a medical history, on office visits, according to recommendations by the American Academy of Pediatrics.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Post-Communist Media Deal Is Torn by Personal Dispute
description: When Central European Media Enterprises Ltd. signed a merger agreement with SBS Broadcasting S.A. in March, the partners hoped to become one of the most powerful media networks in Central and Eastern Europe.

title: Mets Prove Tougher Than Some, but the Rest?
description: The level of the opposition has been suspect for three weeks, but that doesn't matter much to the Mets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CASPER, MANNY
description: CASPER-Manny. August 5, 1912. Remembering you dad with much love on your 87th. Love, Andrea and family

title: Dollars vs. Emotions
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislature to Consider Tightening Lobbying Law
description: Legislative leaders said for the first time today that they would support tighter restrictions on lobbying state lawmakers, abruptly shifting course after it was disclosed that lobbyists for Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette maker, had spent tens of thousands of dollars in recent years on gifts for lawmakers.

title: Skipdoctor Tool Offers Cure For What Ails Damaged CD's
description: Just when you thought you could identify all the gadgets in your favorite consumer electronics stores, here comes a challenge. At first glance, Digital Innovations' Skipdoctor looks like a hand-held vacuum cleaner, or perhaps an industrial-size tape measure. At second glance, a Salad Shooter.

title: There's Something Almost Natural
description: Shiny lawns and spindly palm trees may be identified with the landscape here. But some landscape architects are doing imaginative variations on verdant. One of the most interesting is Jay Griffith, who has designed a string of gardens, mainly for private clients, that fuse painterly composition and color with witty found objects. One project featured a fountain that had ''water'' made of glass beads.

title: VULCAN TO INVEST $355 MILLION IN ALLEGIANCE TELECOM
description: Allegiance Telecom Inc. said yesterday that Vulcan Ventures Inc., the investment group of Paul Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, would invest as much as $355 million in Allegiance. Upon receipt of antitrust clearance, Vulcan will buy 1.5 million shares from investors at $50 each and has an option to buy as many as 5 million more shares at $56 on or before Nov. 1. Allegiance, based in Dallas, sells local, long-distance, high-speed data and Internet services to small and medium-size businesses in markets in many parts of the United States. Vulcan has invested in about 100 digital sound, music and video companies. Shares of Allegiance fell $3.75, to $42.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: It's Summer, and Cadbury's Bottler Is Unable to Meet Demand
description: When Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the owner of soft-drink brands like Dr Pepper and 7-Up, announced 18 months ago that it was buying two Midwest bottlers for $730 million, investors were relieved. The bottlers, to be renamed the American Bottling Company, were expected to consolidate the fragmented independent bottler network on which Cadbury heavily depended to get its products into stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, R. INSLEE JR.
description: CLARK-R. Inslee Jr. Of Riverdale, New York, died August 3, 1999 at Gaylord Hospital in Wallingford, Connecticut. Mr. Clark was undergraduate Dean of Admissions at Yale University from 1965 to 1970 where he admitted the first class of women in 1969 and initiated a ''need blind'' admission policy. In 1970, Mr. Clark became Headmaster and later President of the Horace Mann School. Under his leadership, Horace Mann re-introduced co-education & oversaw the expansion of the school, nearly tripling its enrollment. For 50 years, Mr. Clark was closely associated with Camp Dudley in Westport, NY, serving in many capacities including head of leadership training. Mr. Clark was a member of Christ Church Riverdale where he served on the Vestry, and, most recently, as a Warden. He is survived by three brothers: Jonathan of Greenwich, CT; Christopher of Dallas, TX; and Anthony of Alexandria, VA. A vigil service will be held Friday, August 6th from 79PM at Christ Church Riverdale, 5030 Henry Hudson Parkway at West 252nd St. The funeral service will be held at 10AM Saturday, August 7th at Christ Church Riverdale. A memorial service will be held at Camp Dudley on Sunday, August 8th at 8PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to Camp Dudley, Westport, New York 12943.

title: League Turns to N.F.L. For New Commissioner
description: After spending the last three years trying to convince people outside the United States that a football was oblong and not round, Don Garber yesterday accepted the task of selling pro soccer to Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KANDEL, ETHEL
description: KANDEL-Ethel. Gone seven years, but always in our hearts. Love Myrna, David, Robert,Andrew, Jeffrey, Gary and Marla

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRISTOW, ANNE THOMPSON BABCOCK.
description: BRISTOW-Anne Thompson Babcock. Of Upper Black Eddy, PA. On August 2, 1999. Mother of Karin Bristow and sister of Geraldine Boone and Betsy Moulton. Arrangements private.

title: INDONESIAN BANK RESTRUCTURING
description: Shareholders of Bank Niaga of Indonesia approved an 8.85 trillion rupiah ($1.3 billion) rights issue that is likely to make the bank 99 percent Government-owned. The issue entitles shareholders to buy 99 shares for every one they now hold, with the Government agreeing to buy any new shares they do not take. The Government is likely to end up buying almost all the shares, since Bank Niaga is already technically insolvent.

title: AIRBUS ENGINE DEAL
description: Defying an industry trend, Air France said it would outfit 15 new Airbus Industrie A-318 single-aisle planes that it had on order from Airbus with engines by CFM International, a joint venture of the General Electric Company in the United States and Snecma S.A. of France. Airbus had said it would offer only Pratt & Whitney engines on the A-318, and its competitor, the Boeing Company, has said it would offer only G.E. turbines on its 777-200X and 777-300X. Air France argued successfully that it could cut costs by outfitting its new planes with the same engines used on its other single-aisle Airbus planes.

title: Goat of Spring Now Boy of Summer
description: The evolution of Hideki Irabu from an uncaring and often puzzling pitcher to a devoted and usually reliable pitcher continued at Yankee Stadium yesterday. The once valid questions about Irabu's desire, his consistency and his pedigree for starting games in the post-season drift farther away every time he does what he did in an 8-3 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSON, DAVID J., DR.
description: SELIGSON-David J., Dr., died on August 3, 1999, of a brief illness in his native New York City. His discerning wisdom, love of God, and abiding faith in the beauty and goodness of human beings will be missed beyond measure. His intelligence, spirit and fortitude will inspire us and give us strength, as he has inspired so many in his 92 years-as Rabbi of Central Synagogue, spirtual leader far and wide, Chaplain and Lieutenant Colonel, U.S. Army, and as our own beloved father and grandfather. Services will be held at Central Synagogue Community House, 123 East 55 St., on Friday, August 6, at Noon. Contributions may be made in his name to the Rebuilding Fund of Central Synagogue. Michelle Seligson Jill Seligson Braver Charles Braver Sally Helen Seltzer Jon David Seltzer Rachel Braver

title: North Korea's Dangerous Missiles
description: North Korea threatens to escalate tensions in Asia and heighten its own isolation if it goes ahead with another long-range missile test in the next few weeks. The Taepodong 2 missile, first tested last August, has a range of 3,700 miles, which makes it capable of hitting Alaska and Hawaii as well as Japan and American military targets throughout the Western Pacific. A second test would rightly be taken as a return to belligerent behavior by a country that recently seemed to be signaling an interest in more constructive relations with the outside world.

title: Youth Killed As He and a Friend Play With a Gun on Bronx Roof
description: A 16-year-old boy was fatally shot on the roof of a Bronx apartment building last night while he and a 12-year-old friend played with a gun, the police said. The 12-year-old, who was not identified, was in police custody last night and was expected to be charged, said Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman.

title: Looking Down on Traffic, Linking Two States of Mind
description: How can one make a bridge between the civic core of downtown Los Angeles and the historic Mexican district centered on Olvera Street, neighborhoods split by the 101 Freeway? A recent contest gave top prize to the Santa Monica-based architecture firm of Morphosis (in partnership with the artist Jenny Holzer and AIJK architects and urban designers), which proposed a symbolic answer: a 250-foot armature (rendering, left) in the middle of the freeway, bearing L.E.D. readouts, mirrors and video screens beaming messages to each side. The winning design also incorporates a restaurant looking out onto the traffic whizzing past. The budget is $5 million -- if the bridge is built. There's no starting date yet.

title: Where Bricks Are What They Used to Be
description: THERE was no Home Depot in the 17th century, when the French Huguenots settled along the fertile banks of the Wallkill River in what is now New Paltz, N.Y. Only willpower, combined with clay, sand and stone.

title: Hardaway Tentatively Agrees to Join the Suns
description: Anfernee Hardaway, the Orlando Magic's four-time All-Star guard, tentatively agreed to a seven-year, $86 million contract with the Phoenix Suns yesterday. But the deal had to be approved by the Magic and the National Basketball Association before Hardaway could be signed by Orlando and traded to Phoenix.

title: In Danbury, Employees Fear Cutbacks
description: The quarter-mile-long headquarters of the Union Carbide Corporation, which soars out of the Connecticut woods with such angular, metallic starkness that locals call it the Battlestar Galactica, had symbolized the resilience of a city that once was ''The Hat Capital of the World,'' but lost manufacturers decade by decade.

title: Monsanto Faces Growing Skepticism On Two Fronts
description: After spending more than $8 billion in the last two years to acquire some of the world's largest seed companies and millions more to pioneer in the development of genetically engineered foods, the Monsanto Company is facing growing skepticism about its debt management and mounting resistance to some of its bio-engineered crops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHARDT, SOL
description: STEINHARDT-Sol. The Board and staff of the American Friends of the Israel Museum, and of the Israel Museum, Jerusalem are saddened by the death of Sol Steinhardt, father of our esteemed board member Michael Steinhardt. The Steinhardt family has been a mainstay of the Israel Museum. We send our sincere condolences to Judy and Michael, David, Daniel, Sarah and David Berman and the entire family. Maureen Cogan, International Chairman James S. Snyder, Anne & Jerome Fisher Dir., IM Carolyn Cohen, Exec. Dir., AFIM

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REILLY, JOSEPH G.
description: REILLY-Joseph G. Of Shelter Island, N.Y., on August 3, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Patricia Lyons Reilly. Devoted father of Judith, Liza, Joe Jr., Jim, Chris and Gina. Cherished grandfather of ten. Loved by his nieces, nephews, cousins and many friends. Visiting hours 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday at the Shelter Island Funeral Home. Mass 11 AM Saturday at our Lady of the Isle Church. Interment in Our Lady of Isle Cemetery.

description: Seashore Plantings

description: GILMAN-Sylvia P. On August 4, 1999, at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of the late Howard and Charles Jr. She is survived by members of the Gilman, Phillips and Marcus families. Services and interment private.

title: As U.S. Relations With U.N. Languish at a Low Point, Is Clinton or Congress to Blame?
description: Relations between the United States and the United Nations are at one of their lowest points in years, say diplomats, senior United Nations officials and foreign policy analysts, with many blaming President Clinton and his Administration for the growing tensions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SMITH, FRIEDA AND LOU.
description: SMITH-Frieda and Lou. Your 50th was celebrated with everyone around. Now you celebrate your 65th with those in the ground. Your gifts were plentiful with food to go around, Now the gift I give you, just look what I found. The papers near you I did see that leaves no place for me by thee. So while you sit around, do say ''So why such a price did I pay?'' Rhoda

title: CRITIC'S MUSING -- In the Kingdom of Sinusitis; For Unheard-Of Opera, Is There a Bald Soprano in the House?
description: From dusty piles of manuscripts in the basements of European libraries, forgotten Baroque operas continue to emerge. The newest phantasmagoric discovery, made by the husband and wife musicological team of Johnson and Johnson, is Otto von Bismarck Merck's ''Titus Pharmacoligus.'' The libretto by Franz Xavier Squibb, after a fragment by Seneca, confirms the early 18th century's continuing fascination with classical mythology and history. It bears examining.

title: Some Immigrants Have Angry Words for Queens Billboard
description: These 17 words on a bright-red billboard in a racially diverse Queens community have evoked fury and even tears: ''Over 80 percent of Americans support very little or no more immigration. Is anyone listening to us?''

title: Ergonomics Study Finds Hazards in Browsing Web
description: Can Web browsing be hazardous to your health? A recent ergonomics study suggests that it can be, even more than other computer tasks.

title: PAPER COMPANY DEAL IN DOUBT
description: Nine institutional shareholders of Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd., led by the mutual fund manager Trimark Investment Management Inc., said they had enough votes to kill a plan to combine the company, a paper maker based in Vancouver, British Columbia, with other international holdings of Fletcher Challenge Ltd. of New Zealand. The proposal to create a company with assets of $3.4 billion was announced in mid-July. It requires approval by a majority of the minority shareholders of Fletcher Challenge Canada, which is 51 percent owned by the New Zealand entity, a resource and construction giant. The nine financial institutions, which control 52 percent of the minority shares, say the proposed terms are unfair.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the creation of a new opera, ''A View From the Bridge'' by William Bolcom, for Lyric Opera of Chicago misstated the year of Mr. Bolcom's ''McTeague'' opera. It opened in 1992 at Lyric Opera, not 1994.

description: COUNTRY.COM'S CENTURY OF COUNTRY(Starworks; $29.98; Windows 3.1, 95 and 98.)

title: Abdul Wahab al-Bayati, 73; Iraqi Poet and Innovator in His Art
description: Abdul Wahab al-Bayati, an Iraqi poet who was a major innovator in his art form, died on Tuesday in Damascus, Syria. He was 73 and had lived in Damascus since leaving Amman, Jordan, earlier this year.

title: A Tightrope Act Over Taiwan
description: As is often the case in scraps between China and Taiwan, the United States finds itself in the middle.

title: Medal Stripped From Sotomayor After Drug Test
description: The latest casualty in the sports war against drugs is one of the biggest names in track and field.

title: CHASE TO BUY MELLON BANK'S HOME MORTGAGE UNIT
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the residential mortgage business of the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh, making Chase the largest mortgage servicer in the nation. Chase and Mellon did not disclose terms of the deal, which includes a $55 billion loan-servicing portfolio. Chase, operating through a subsidiary, the Chase Manhattan Mortgage Corporation, currently ranks third among mortgage servicers, firms that collect mortgage payments. It became the nation's biggest provider of new home mortgages this year. With the purchase, Chase's mortgage business will have more than 3.1 million customers and a loan portfolio of $292 billion, the bank said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBEY, RAE
description: TOBEY-Rae. Dear wife of the late Daniel. Beloved and devoted mother of Helaine, Jane and Irene. Loving mother-in-law of Norman Pressman, Lawrence Momo & Ethan Silverman. Adoring grandmother to Daniel, Edie, Andrew, Ben, Lucas, Alexander and Theodore. You will be missed dearly. May your soul find peace. The light that shines in you will guide us always. Services Thursday 9:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: AIR CANADA EARNINGS
description: Canada's largest airline, Air Canada, reported a 19.7 percent decline in second-quarter earnings, to $73 million (Canadian) or $48.2 million (United States), and said it would take a $30 million (Canadian) charge in the third quarter because of business it lost last month when 5,100 flight attendants threatened to strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLMAN, BILL
description: HILLMAN-Bill. Leader, colleague, and friend, former President of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists and Chairman of the Trustees of the AFTRA Health & Retirement Funds. His vision and selfless dedication were instrumental in uniting both management and labor in creating, safeguarding and perpetuating outstanding health and retirement benefits for thousands of his colleagues and other performers and broadcasters who work in the television, radio and the recording industries. Our loss is great, his contributions were immense. American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (AFL-CIO) AFTRA Health & Retirement Fund

title: BASEBALL; Yankees Still Have Blue Jays' Number
description: The visiting clubhouse was so quiet you could hear a stirrup drop. Most of the Toronto Blue Jays left Yankee Stadium in a somber mood yesterday after losing the final game of this series, 8-3, solidifying the impression that although the Blue Jays still have a shot at the American League wild card, they have little chance of making a run at the Yankees for first place in the American League East.

description: To the Editor:

title: Despite the G.I.'s, Kosovo Town Is Purged of Serbs
description: Half of the homes in this once-mixed village gape emptily now, purged of all their Serbs in one of the failures of the American peacekeeping mission in Kosovo.

title: Equitable Distribution
description: To the Editor:

title: $700 MILLION DEAL IN HEALTH CARE PROPERTIES
description: Health Care Property Investors Inc. agreed yesterday to buy American Health Properties Inc. for about $700 million in stock, creating the largest real estate investment trust focused solely on health care properties. Health Care, in Newport Beach, Calif., will also take on $300 million in debt. The deal values American Health, which is based in Denver, at about $20.18 a share. The combined company will own nursing homes, assisted living centers, hospitals and medical office buildings in many parts of the United States. Health Care shares fell 68.75 cents, to $25.1875, while American Health rose $1, to $19.

title: Preventable Suicides
description: To the Editor:

title: The Trendy Discover NoMad Land, And Move In
description: THE fashionistas are on the move, this time to a neighborhood so anonymous it hardly has a name. On the maps in city taxis that show Manhattan neighborhoods -- Chelsea, Greenwich Village, the Upper East Side -- this area is conspicuously gray. Historically minded people may refer to it as Rosehill, after an 18th-century farm belonging to John Watts, a Tory sympathizer, that covered roughly the same acreage. George Trescher, the fund-raiser, who lives in the area, calls it Curry Hill, because of the many Indian and Bangladesh restaurants. Others call it NoMad, for north of Madison Square Park.

title: Rarities and Favorites On Period Instruments
description: The New London Consort was started by the recorder player Philip Pickett in 1976 and has become familiar to period-instrument fans through a series of remarkable recordings on the L'Oiseau Lyre label. Its repertory runs from medieval rarities through Baroque favorites, and like most British period-instrument bands it draws its players from a vast pool of freelancers, expanding and contracting as the repertory demands.

title: Neuberger Berman's Net Down 5.8%
description: Neuberger Berman L.L.C., a New York-based money manager planning to sell $250 million in common stock in an initial public offering this fall, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing late yesterday that net income for the first six months of the year was $141.1 million, a 5.8 percent decline from the 1998 period. Pro forma net income was $65.7 million for the first half of 1999 and $143 million for all of 1998.

title: Nurses Plan Strike Monday At Columbia Presbyterian
description: The union representing 1,600 registered nurses at Columbia Presbyterian Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital has called a strike for Monday as management and labor negotiators continue to clash over the union's demand to increase the ratio of nurses to patients.

title: Green's Ailing Knee Adds to Parcells's Worries
description: Eric Green, one of the best tight ends of the decade and one of the new Jets who upgraded the team over the off season, missed today's two-a-day practice because of a chronic left knee problem. Both Bill Parcells and Green expressed concern with the knee, although the coach seemed surprised by the seriousness of the problem, which he declined to call an injury.

title: Brazilian Chemistry: A Samba Beat For 'Carmen'
description: Carmen herself is still recognizable as the tragically alluring Gypsy, but the toreador has been transformed into a soccer player and all the famous arias are sung to a syncopated 2/4 beat. There have been many productions of Bizet's ''Carmen'' over the last 125 years, but never one quite like Augusto Boal's samba version.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR SLIDES. The dollar fell against the yen on growing doubt that the United States would join Japan in its efforts to weaken the currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 114.29 yen, down from 115.28 on Tuesday.

title: Vivid Colors in the Palm of Your Hand
description: THE display on your cell phone or palmtop organizer may be a rigid, black-and-white affair now, but that's going to change, some experts say. Portable displays of the future will be both brightly colored and flexible, with screens pliant enough to roll up like place mats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOTZER, VERA P.
description: GLOTZER-Vera P., 94. Died on August 4, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Samuel; loving mother of son David and daughter in-law Sheryl; adoring grandmother of Matthew and Lauren. She Will be deeply missed by family and friends. Services at noon, Friday, August 6, Sunset Chapel, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, New York.

title: In America; Hot Enough for You?
description: We can do it. We can keep our heads buried in the increasingly hot sand until we're all as crisp as french fries.

description: Bernard E. Simon, the last of a group of American plastic surgeons who donated their services to help the ''Hiroshima Maidens,'' 25 disfigured and maimed survivors of the American bombing of Hiroshima, died on Aug. 1 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, where he had worked for more than 40 years. He was 87.

title: HOECHST REPORTS LOSS
description: Hoechst A.G., which plans to unite with Rhone-Poulenc S.A. in November to form Aventis, the world's biggest drug maker, slid to a second-quarter loss as its ailing chemicals businesses wiped out rising drug profits. Hoechst lost 188 million euros ($202 million), in contrast to a profit of 348 million euros, a year earlier. Hoechst hopes its $21 billion merger with Rhone-Poulenc will help it develop winning products to compete in the $300 billion drug market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADTKE, JANEL MARIE.
description: RADTKE-Janel Marie. Born in Milwaukee, WI. July 8, 1952 passed away August 3, 1999 in Nyack, NY. Beloved daughter of Florence and the late Joseph, sister of Jeffrey & his wife Diane, and life partner of Sherri Eisenpress. Founder and partner in Radiant Communications, a public relations firm dedicated to helping non-profits and foundations communicate more effectively. Our Janel, a writer and teacher is best remembered for her love of nature, animals, the ocean and beauty. Her friends will continue to be inspired by her strong sense of spirituality. A memorial service will be held on Thursday at 11AM at the Hannenmann Funeral Home, Inc. of Nyack. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Nature Conservancy, Girls Incorporated, or The Humane Society.

description: Sometime in the next week or so the population of India, which adds more people to the world each year than any other nation, will officially cross the one billion mark, just in time for Indian Independence Day on Aug. 15, according to United Nations demographers.

title: CANADIANS BUY BP AMOCO ASSETS
description: Two oil companies based in Calgary, Alberta, Canadian Natural Resources Ltd. and Penn West Petroleum Ltd., will buy the western Canadian oil properties of BP Amoco for $1.1 billion. BP Amoco will remain Canada's largest producer of natural gas and a major supplier of gas liquids and petrochemicals. Canadian Natural Resources will pay $690 million for most of the properties, and Penn West will buy the remainder.

description: The number of American workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose last week, while the less-volatile four-week average fell to its lowest level in four months.

title: Yeats, a Poet Who Kept Trying On Different Identities
description: Nothing turns a man into a statue more effectively than a combination of fame, death and the passage of time. Together they join hands and hoist him up on a high cold plinth. If the man is a writer, he disappears into the official editions of his work, all polish and (ideally) perfection, the fits and starts and wrong turns folded out of sight like the hem on a pair of dress pants.

title: As Drought Rules Conflict, Confusion Grows on Parched Ground
description: At noontime, the Hudson County Executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, was deep into a news conference explaining the drought emergency he had just declared for the county's 12 towns. Suddenly, word filtered in that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was an hour away from declaring an emergency for the entire state.

description: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement today on a significant revamping of the Department of Energy, establishing a new agency within the department to oversee nuclear weapons programs in response to accusations of Chinese espionage.

description: Treasury securities rose for the second consecutive session yesterday, as the pricing of a huge debt issue by Wal-Mart Stores Inc. failed to hurt the sale of United States Government paper.

title: With Senate Gone, Albany Has a Deal
description: The Legislature ended its 1999 session by forging a last-minute deal with Gov. George E. Pataki. The Governor and the leaders of the Assembly and Senate agreed on a few outstanding issues, but jettisoned others that proved too nettlesome. The leaders' accords came after the Senate ended its session, so the bills will not become law until Dec. 1.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERGER, ROSE
description: WEISSBERGER-Rose. On August 4, 1999 in her one hundredth year died peacefully at home. The devoted wife to both the late Irving Weissberger and the late Samuel H. Weinstein. She is survived and her memory cherished by her sons Alvin (Ruth) Wayne, Edgar M. (Ann) Wayne, Dr. William B. (Marie) Wayne. She was the loving grandmother of Mitchell Wayne and Elizabeth Rappaport, Karen Wayne, the late Steven Wayne, Samuel Wayne, Meredith & Matthew Wayne and the adored great grandmother of Gillian and Nicole Wayne & Genna and Philip Rappaport. Her love, warmth and concern for her family and friends was expressed by her parting words, ''You should all live and be well''. She will forever be the star by which we sail. The family requests memorial contributions to Mercy Hospice, 1220 Front Street, Uniondale, New York 11553. Services at 12 noon on Sunday, August 8th at Gutterman's Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Residential Real Estate; Rental Complex Offers Open Space in East Village
description: Amid the densely packed streets of the East Village, a two-building rental complex is taking shape that will offer amenities unusual for the neighborhood. Prime among them is open space.

description: People fleeing large cities in the East for the beach or the mountains this summer are finding as much smog on vacation as they left at home, a survey of Government monitoring data by environmentalists shows.

title: PROFIT DOWN AT BARCLAYS
description: Britain's second-largest bank, Barclays P.L.C., reported that profit declined 21 percent, to $1.13 billion, in the first half of the year because of charges related to the company's revamping in May, which cut 6,000 jobs. Barclays said profit at its investment-banking unit, Barclays Capital, rose 14 percent. Sir Peter Middleton, chairman and acting chief executive of Barclays, announced that the company planned to cut 1,000 more jobs. Shares of the company rose nearly 1 percent, to 1,768 pence.

description: Finally calming the partisan tensions that have buffeted it all year, the State Legislature ended its annual session early this morning by forging a last-minute deal with Gov. George E. Pataki on a handful of outstanding issues.

description: As a playwright, Sid Frank steps up to the figurative plate seven times in his evening of one-act plays running on Monday and Tuesday nights at the Studio Theater on Theater Row.

description: South Africa's flagship black empowerment company, recovering from an investor revolt that ousted its chairman, has announced a reorganization that creates more accountability to shareholders but means the company no longer will be controlled by blacks.

The world, in short, has been demystified by digging -- all the world, that is, except at least one area: moviemaking.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the poor relationship between the United States and the United Nations misidentified the state represented by Jesse Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who has sharply criticized the United Nations. It is North Carolina, not South Carolina. Because of another editing error, the article also misstated the year in which President Clinton gave a speech in San Francisco at the 50th anniversary celebration of the United Nations' founding. It was 1995, not 1996.

title: Nominee to Fed Board
description: President Clinton nominated Carol Parry, the Chase Manhattan Corporation's expert on community development lending, to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, the White House said today. She would fill a post left by Susan Phillips in June 1998. Ms. Parry has been the executive vice president for community development at Chase, overseeing compliance with the Community Reinvestment Act, a 1977 Federal law that encourages lending in low-income neighborhoods.

description: A carriage horse ran down a midtown street yesterday after losing its driver and struck two pedestrians, one of whom was pinned beneath the carriage. Neither the pedestrians nor the horse and driver were seriously injured, the police said.

title: Rosenbluth Buys Big Stake In Business Travel Web Site
description: Rosenbluth International said yesterday that it had bought a majority stake in Biztravel.com, a leading site for making business travel arrangements over the Internet.

description: The United States remained the world's biggest arms exporter in a sluggish market last year, as the weak economies in Asia and among oil producers in the Middle East dragged global sales to developing countries to the lowest level since 1991, according to an authoritative Government report.

title: ESTEE LAUDER SAYS IT HAS AGREED TO BUY STILA COSMETICS
description: The Estee Lauder Companies, the top American maker of cosmetics sold in department stores, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Stila Cosmetics Inc. for an undisclosed amount. The line of Stila, which is based in Los Angeles, is available in limited distribution in the United States, Britain, France, Australia, Hong Kong and Japan. Estee Lauder, which is based in New York, has about 40 percent of its sales outside the United States. It said the acquisition would increase its presence in European perfumeries and add to its appeal with women between 20 and 30. Estee Lauder shares rose 62.5 cents, to $47.0625.

title: F.C.C. WILL PERMIT OWNING 2 STATIONS IN BIG TV MARKETS
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted yesterday to relax rules that have limited television-station ownership for most of the century, allowing for the first time a single company or network to own two stations in the nation's largest cities.

description: COHEN-David, died peacefully the morning of August 5th at his home in Allendale, New Jersey after battling cancer, according to family friend and colleague Jerry Kaplan. Mr. Cohen, age 54, was an exceptionally bright business man and beloved husband and father. During his 23 years as a magazine executive with Meredith Corporation, he was involved in the creation of many of the company's most successful publications, including Traditional Home, Country Home, Wood, and Golf for Women magazines. For the last three years of his tenure there, Mr. Cohen oversaw Meredith's New Media department. In 1998, Mr. Cohen moved to Primedia, where he was Vice President of New Media. He is survived by his loving wife Joan, and two daughters, Sharon and Jaime. Services will be held at noon today August 6th, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rte. 4 (East) Paramus, NJ.

Set in 1983 in Dutchess County, New York, the movie gets deeply under the skin of Sebastian (Adrian Grenier), a bright, attractive, energetic high school student reacting badly to the seismic jolts when his family unexpectedly comes apart.

But the linchpin of 125th Street is the Apollo Theater, a music venue known around the world that has grown shabby and technically obsolete through years of neglect. On top of these troubles, the theater's board has been sued by the state for questionable financial practices.

title: Face Look Familiar? Spotting the Forged Antiquity
description: It's harder to be a forger these days than it used to be, at least in the field of antiquities. Technical tools like X-rays, gamma rays and ultraviolet light have made faking it more of a challenge. And so has the increasing sophistication of the scholar's eye. Still, one should never underestimate the ego of forgers. If they can't find acceptance for their own work, they take perverse pride in how well they can imprint on the work of larger talents, while leaving their own spoor. That, added to the greed of dealers who encourage them, the gullibility of art world professionals, and the credibility of collectors, make forgery a problem that is here to stay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATES, DONALD WARREN, CAPT.
description: GATES-Donald Warren, Capt. 76, of Sea Level, North Carolina, formerly of Middletown and Little Silver, NJ, died at the Sailors Snug Harbor, Sea Level on Monday, August 2. He had been disabled since suffering a stroke in 1988. He was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1922 and graduated from Erasmus Hall High School in 1940 and New York State Maritime Academy in 1942. During World War II he served as first officer on merchant ships in convoys in the South Pacific and in the North Atlantic including the Murmansk run. He later served as Captain with United States Lines for seven years. Captain Gates began an onshore career in 1950 with the Board of Underwriters of New York, Philadelphia Office, which became the National Cargo Bureau in 1952. Serving in the ports of Philadelphia and the home office, New York City, he advanced to become Senior Vice President and Chief Surveyor, and retired in 1987 after 37 years of service. He served as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations International Maritime Organization (IMO) Subcommitteee on the Carriage of Dangerous Goods. For this work he received the Coast Guard's Public Service Commendation in May 1973 and the Meritorious Public Service Award in October 1987. Captain Gates was appointed by both Governors Brendan Byrne and Thomas Kean to serve as New Jersey State Commissioner of Pilotage (DEP) for a period of 6-1/2 years, beginning in 1978. He was active in United Methodist Churches in Springfield, PA and Little Silver, NJ and the First Presbyterian Church of Hilton Head, SC. He is survived by Margit Johansen Gates of Little Silver, NJ, his wife of 52 years, a son, Donald C. Gates of Atlantic Highlands, NJ, and a daughter, Joanne Kristine Bruno of Little Silver. He was predeceased by his mother, Elsie Gates in 1966, his father Earl I. Gates in 1976 and a brother Earl I. Gates, Jr. in 1980. Memorial services will be held at Sailors Snug Harbor, his last residence, on August 5 and at Tower Hill Presbyterian Church, 10:30 am, Red Bank, NJ, on August 23, 1999. Burial at sea will be held privately. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Church World Service, 475 Riverside Drive, New York, NY 10115. For information, Munden Funeral Home & Crematory, Morehead City, NC.

title: A Renoir Masterpiece, Refurbished and Timely
description: One of the most haunting of all war films features only a single casualty, and that of a man who dies in bed. Yet Jean Renoir's classic 1937 ''Grand Illusion,'' an oasis of subtlety, moral intelligence and deep emotion on the cinematic landscape this summer, remains an implicitly devastating indictment of battle. Though its World War I story unfolds among French and British soldiers and their German captors at prison camps, ''Grand Illusion'' is extraordinary in refracting the battles raging outside through the apparent civility of the prisoners. It is from this film that ''Casablanca'' took the noble idea of Frenchmen risking punishment for the chance to sing their anthem, ''La Marseillaise.''

title: He's Downright Lovable. Sure. Just Run for Cover.

Mr. Rock's ''Bigger and Blacker'' was the kind of star triumph that 99.9 percent of all stand-up comedians can only dream about. Mr. Hughley's ''Going Home'' has to be compared with its recent predecessor, if only because he and Mr. Rock deal with a lot of the same comic subjects: violence in white schools, gun control, the battle of the sexes, the state of the black family and the differences between black and white culture and attitudes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, RAYMOND E.
description: SNYDER-Raymond E. Born on February 22, 1912, passed away in Naples, Florida on August 2, 1999. A native of Findlay, Ohio, Mr. Snyder received a B.S. degree from Miami University, Oxford, Ohio and his M.B.A. from Harvard University. Mr. Snyder had a 36 year association with Merck Pharmaceutical where he served on the Board of Directors and as Senior Vice President. Mr. Snyder was also trustee of the Committee for Economic Development, a director of the National State Bank of Elizabeth, New Jersey, the New Jersey Manufacturers Insurance Company, the Arkwright-Boston Insurance Company and the Federal-Mogal Corporation of Ohio. Mr. Snyder retired to Naples, Florida where he served on the Board and as acting president of the Royal Poinciana Country Club and was on the Board of the Conservancy of Southwest Florida. Mr. Snyder was preceded in death by his first wife, Helen Rognon in 1959, and his second wife, Dorothy Linton in 1994. He is survived by his son, Stephen Culley Snyder, & his daughter Lesley Jody Snyder, his step-son, Jim Van Natta, and stepdaughters, Sue Pasteris and Lynn Van Natta and eight grandchildren. For information, Hodges Funeral Chapel, Naples, Florida, 941-261-1237.

title: Tangled War In Congo Now Snares Namibians
description: Militarily, the brief battle on Monday in Katima Mulilo, a small town in the Caprivi Strip in Namibia, did not mean much, but it was an example of the domino effect of the war in Congo.

title: A Battlefield of Dreams for Iowa Farmers
description: All that really happened here is that someone shot a movie.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Renzo Piano Revisits Texas

title: Captain Kirk And Friends Grounded In Neverland
description: Prolonged adolescence of the sort built on inextinguishable obsession with ''Star Trek,'' ''Star Wars,'' ''The Brady Bunch,'' Stephen King novels, mini-series like ''The Winds of War,'' comic books, movie posters and action figures finds its justification in the slight, bright, clever romantic comedy ''Free Enterprise.''

title: Intimacies Shared In a Breezy Groove
description: Some singers can make each performance seem like a whispered disclosure, offered in love and trust. Such intimacy comes not from technical perfection but from the careful exploitation of individual quirks, the deployment of range and tone to express personality. Joan Armatrading, the veteran English singer-songwriter who appeared at Town Hall on Wednesday night, is a masterly creator of such artistic confidences.

title: Supermen: Hapless, Loony Cartoons
description: Like Austin Powers, the self-styled superheroes of ''Mystery Men'' have only the dimmest suspicions that they are anything short of cool. The way they see it, the world was running out of superheroes, and, well, it was a dirty job but somebody had to do it. Even somebody armed with forks, a shovel, a bad temper or a bowling ball. The kind of paragon who might solemnly intone, as William H. Macy's Shoveler does: ''We've got a blind date with Destiny -- and it looks like she's ordered the lobster.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPONE, LOUIS R.
description: CAPONE-Louis R., age 85, a personal manager who discovered and managed Tony Bennett, Vic Damone, and Alan Dale, died on July 6th in Queens. He is survived by a wife, Eileen, a son, Arthur Nelson, a daughter, Helene, a brother, Joseph, and a sister, Corrine.

title: Mohammed Hadid, 92, an Iraqi Who Long Backed Democracy
description: Mohammed Hadid, an Iraqi economist and cabinet minister who advocated democracy but was buffeted by his country's autocratic governments, died on Tuesday in London, where he moved in 1995. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSON, DAVID J., DR.
description: SELIGSON-David J., Dr., died on August 3, 1999, of a brief illness in his native New York City. His discerning wisdom, love of God, and abiding faith in the beauty and goodness of human beings will be missed beyond measure. His intelligence, spirit and fortitude will inspire us and give us strength, as he has inspired so many in his 92 years-as Rabbi of Central Synagogue, spirtual leader far and wide, Chaplain and Lieutenant Colonel, U.S. Army, and as our own beloved father and grandfather. Services will be held at Central Synagogue Community House, 123 East 55 St., on Friday, August 6, at Noon. Contributions may be made in his name to the Rebuilding Fund of Central Synagogue. Michelle Seligson Jill Seligson Braver Charles Braver Sally Helen Seltzer Jon David Seltzer Rachel Braver

title: State Official Paves Way for 5 Charter Schools to Open in Fall
description: In a move that paves the way for New York State's first charter schools to open in the fall, State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills announced yesterday that he had worked out some final details and approved five schools.

title: Officiating Pointers Courtesy Of N.F.L.
description: Sandy Alderson, whose plan to establish an evaluation system for major league umpires was a major reason for their mass resignation last month, has quietly been exploring how that system might work.

title: China and the Sect: More Talk Than Action
description: China's fierce-looking crackdown on Falun Gong, the spiritual movement that claims tens of millions of followers, is turning out to be far less severe than it first looked, with more propaganda than action.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: 'Plain Air'
description: Barbara Gladstone Gallery

title: School Agency Ignored Report, State Says
description: State investigators said in court papers filed this week that school construction officials were warned of structural problems at a Bronx elementary school two weeks before a section of its wall collapsed in the spring.

title: Ancient Art Fashioned Of Feathers
description: Try to imagine Ellsworth Kelly, Josef Albers and Mark Rothko working 2,500 years ago in Peru. They would be using the same lexicon of abstract art -- concentric circles, stripes, squares and triangles -- but working entirely with exotic feathers instead of paint.

title: U.S. War Colleges Hone Peacekeeping Skills Along With Fighting Reflexes
description: Once, soldiers who hoped to become generals came to the military's colleges to study the theory of war and the history of military alliances, and to hone their skills to survive -- and kill if necessary.

title: Mines and NATO Bombs Still Killing in Kosovo
description: The danger from mines and unexploded bombs in Kosovo is far greater than previously thought, and casualties have soared to alarming levels, according to international aid agencies and mine-clearing organizations here.

title: Botha Meets Briggs at a Crossroads
description: Francois Botha had never been knocked out. He wondered what it would feel like, and he feared it more than any opponent. His fear did not make him more cautious because he walked chin-first into Mike Tyson's right hand and awoke with the referee standing over him delivering the 10 count.

title: As 3-Bank French Brawl Winds Down, Outcome Is Murky
description: With only a day left before investors must choose sides in France's three-way bank struggle, Banque Nationale de Paris appeared to inch closer to victory in its hostile bid for Paribas, one of two rivals it is seeking to control.

title: Using Surplus Forces Clinton To Sign Bills, DeLay Says
description: Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority whip and conservative field marshal, said today that Republicans would spend next year's anticipated $14 billion budget surplus -- and had intended to do so all year long.

title: WHITMAN IMPOSES WATER USE LIMITS
description: With little significant rain in sight and calls for voluntary conservation failing to slacken demands on New Jersey's dwindling water supply, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today declared a statewide drought emergency and imposed strict rules on outdoor water use.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bear Stearns Agrees to Pay Fines of $38.5 Million

title: Class Ends, and the Wait Begins; Test Results Will Determine Whether Pupils Move Up
description: The spirit of summer finally invaded the stuffy air of Room 224 yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GTE CORP. , the local phone company being acquired by Bell Atlantic, said it would buy back as many as 26 million shares to offset shares issued under employee benefit and dividend reinvestment programs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about teen-agers' summer jobs misstated the location of Murry Bergtraum High School. It is in Manhattan, not the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the At the Movies column in Weekend last Friday about Michael Mann's new film, ''The Insider,'' misstated the director's association with the television show ''Miami Vice.'' Mr. Mann was the executive producer of the show, not the creator.

title: Some in G.O.P. Join Democrats On H.M.O. Bill
description: A group of dissident Republicans reached agreement with House Democrats today on a comprehensive bill to regulate the managed health care industry and predicted they would have enough support to force the Republican leadership to bring their measure to a vote.

title: Debate Over Gun-Control Bills Is Delayed Until After Recess
description: Senate and House lawmakers on a conference committee that is expected to hammer out new gun control legislation met for the first time today, only to postpone their work until they return on Sept. 7 from a monthlong Congressional recess.

title: Mortgage Rates Up Again
description: The benchmark home mortgage rate rose to the highest level in more than two years this week, according to a weekly survey released by Freddie Mac today. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage advanced to 7.89 percent in the week that ended Friday from 7.70 percent the previous week. It was the second consecutive weekly rise and put the rate at the highest level since the last week of May 1997, when it was at 7.94 percent. Freddie Mac said the average rate on an adjustable mortgage rose to 6.09 percent from 5.99 percent the previous week, and 15-year mortgage rates rose to 7.45 percent from 7.29 percent.

title: New Video Releases
description: Shakespeare in Love

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, MARTHA
description: WOLF-Martha. On August 3, 1999. Beloved wife of the late John, dear mother of James and his wife, Catherine, loving sister of Florence and John. Grandmother of Susan, James and Cathy, greatgrandmother of Sarah, Jamie, Kenneth and Rebecca. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC, Friday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30 AM, Church of St. Luke in the Fields. Interment in Mount Olivet Cemetery, Maspeth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSNER, MICHAEL
description: RESSNER-Michael. Of Hewlett Neck, N.Y. On August 4th at Lenox Hills Hospital in New York City. Dearest, devoted sweetheart and husband of Natalie (nee Godnick). Adoring father and special friend to John Walter Ressner and dear father-in-law of Laura Bemben. Loving brother-in-law of Enid and Bud Van Raalte, Bob Godnick. Cherished uncle of Dr. Polly Van Raalte, Susan and Dr. Elliott Hershman; fun loving grand uncle to Todd and Danny Hershman. Extraordinarily gifted painter and musician. Graduate of Pratt Institute. Board of Directors American Institute of Architects, New York Chapter, Associate Member and winner of their Harry B. Rutkin Memorial Award for Service to the Profession. Creator of the Rocky Jones, Space Ranger TV and Comic Book series. Former Deputy Mayor, trustee, past and present Road Commissioner of the Village of Hewlett Neck. Founder and President of the Barr Road Civic Association, he was instrumental in saving 165 acres of Borman's Island in Hewlett Bay at the foot of Barr Road, as a wildlife sanctuary in perpetuity, thereby preventing commercial development and a proposed bridge. Member of the Board of Directors, Easter Seals of New York. Marketing Director, Israel Seinuk, P.C. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to the New York Foundation for Architecture (AIA NY Chapter), 200 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10016, as an annual prize will be established in his name. Funeral services on Sunday, August 8, 11AM at Beth Moses Cemetery, in Farmingdale, NY. ''This above all: to thine own self be true, And it must follow, as the night the day, Thou canst not then be false to any man''.

title: Tax-Cut War Games
description: Are the Republicans, or perhaps the Democrats, driving off a political cliff on the $792 billion tax cut adopted by Congress today?

title: Congo Cease-Fire Imperiled As Rebel Charges Bomb Raid
description: The leader of one of the two main rebel forces in Congo appeared ready today to call off a cease-fire accord he signed just days earlier, in what would be another blow to the shaky process of bringing peace to Africa's third-largest country.

title: Judge Won't Free Terrorism Case Witness
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to release a man who was jailed in May for refusing to testify, on religious grounds, before a Federal grand jury investigating Osama bin Laden and the bombings of the United States Embassies in Africa last August.

title: Abercrombie & Fitch extends a print campaign to TV.
description: ONE of the most successful current print campaigns -- notorious among some for its youthful sensuality -- is arriving on video with a celebration of singlets, sweat and skin.

title: PIER 1'S SHARES DROP 33% AFTER WARNING ON EARNINGS
description: Shares of Pier 1 Imports Inc. fell 33 percent yesterday after it said on Wednesday that fiscal second-quarter profit would miss Wall Street estimates and that its chief financial officer had resigned. The shares fell $2.875, to $5.875, a 52-week low. Pier 1 said a slump in sales would push down profit to 12 cents to 14 cents a share in the quarter ending this month; the company was expected to earn 18 cents. Pier 1 also said it ended acquisition talks with an unidentified company. Stephen F. Mangum, Pier 1's chief financial officer, will be replaced by Charles H. Turner, the chain's senior vice president for stores. The company did not give a reason for the resignation.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; A Fatal Crash's Repercussions, 100 Years Later
description: IN a season of anniversaries -- 30 years since the moon landing, 25 since Nixon resigned -- Heward Grafftey is pitching one more. Next month is the centennial, he says, of the first recorded auto fatality.

title: Kosovo's Costly Disorder
description: Two months after the arrival of the first NATO forces, Kosovo remains lawless and violent. There are no local police or judges, United Nations police are just beginning to trickle in and NATO is doing an uneven and unsatisfactory job of preserving order. Unless the trend toward anarchy is quickly checked, international plans for constructing a democratic civil society in Kosovo could be doomed.

title: Market Alone Won't Help Exploited Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Restaurants column on Wednesday, which reviewed the Berkeley Bar and Grill in Manhattan, misstated the surname of the restaurant's previous chef. She is Patricia Williams, not Patricia Weaver.

title: Album of the Week
description: MACY GRAY; ''On How Life Is'' (Epic). Macy Gray has a degree of talent, originality and vision wrapped in a familiar package. The problem with having this, as anyone from well-knowns like Bruce Springsteen to unknowns like Mary Cutrofello can tell you, is that the music business is so hungry for this type of performer that it's hard to live up to the fanfare and expectations on a first album. So if ''On How Life Is'' doesn't meet its impossible criteria as the introduction of a seminal new voice that rhythm-and-blues fans will be listening to for decades, it is at the very least a musical success in its time, 1999, as something new delivered in a classic mold.

title: REVISED DEAL FOR NEWCOURT
description: A New Jersey company, CIT Group Inc., said it had signed a new agreement to acquire Newcourt Credit Group Inc. of Toronto through an exchange of shares valued at $1.8 billion, 34 percent lower than the value set in March. After Newcourt, a Canadian leasing company, turned in a disappointing quarterly performance in mid-June, CIT began to renegotiate the terms. Under the new agreement, one Newcourt share will be exchanged for seven-tenths of a CIT share. Newcourt shares fell 1.3 percent, to $23.10 (Canadian). In New York, its shares fell slightly, to $15.4844. CIT shares fell 7 percent, to $24.25.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Giants' Brown Will Have Surgery
description: This year's Giants training camp is not where you want to show up with an injury. Albany is a hospitable place, but this year the environment has the Giants' most celebrated players with infirmities limping back to the hospital rather than from it.

title: CORNING CONSUMER IS PAYING $133 MILLION FOR EKCO
description: The Corning Consumer Products Company, a unit of the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, said yesterday that it would buy Ekco Group Inc., a maker of pots, pans and brooms. Corning, which makes kitchen goods like Pyrex and Corningware glassware, is to pay $7 a share, or $133.7 million, for Ekco's 19.1 million outstanding shares, a 56 percent premium to its closing price of $4.50 on Wednesday. Corning will also assume about $150 million of Ekco debt. Shares of Ekco, based in Nashua, N.H., rose $2.25, to $6.75. On Monday, Corning Consumer, based in Elmira, N.Y., said it would buy General Housewares Inc. for $145 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: Senators Say 'Errors' Plagued U.S. Investigation of Possible Nuclear Spying by China
description: The Government's investigation into how China got American nuclear weapons secrets was plagued by widespread mistakes and misjudgments but there was no political interference, according to the two ranking members of a Senate commitee that held closed hearings on the investigation.

title: Republican Cousins
description: To the Editor:

title: Silicon Parkway; In New Jersey, Technology Industry Sprouts a Start-Up
description: By the door to his disheveled office in a thoroughly standard office park, Satish M. Sharma has posted a form letter he received a few months ago from the Katharine Gibbs School.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: EUROPE

title: To a Beloved Native Son, A Mississippi Farewell
description: The mourners said the same thing, over and over: Willie Morris should have been here, to tell about this.

title: Foreign Affairs; Kosovo's Three Wars
description: Watching the latest cycle of ethnic revenge being played out in Kosovo, this time with Albanians murdering Serbs, is a graphic reminder that there were actually three wars in Kosovo this year. The first war we lost, the second war we won and the third war is yet to be decided.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, PETER K.
description: KIMMEL-Peter K. On August 3, 1999. Dear son of David and June Kimmel. Loving stepbrother, uncle, nephew and cousin. Services were private.

title: SENATE CONFIRMS U.N. APPOINTMENT AFTER 14 MONTHS
description: The Senate voted today to confirm Richard C. Holbrooke as chief American delegate to the United Nations, ending a 14-month nomination battle that left the Clinton Administration without a high-profile representative to the United Nations during military conflicts in the Balkans and the Persian Gulf.

title: Robbery Suspects' Use of Con Ed Van Leads to Their Arrest
description: It was largely their choice of a getaway car, investigators said, that tripped up two armed men who went on a spree in Greenwich Village early yesterday morning and robbed a bookstore and bagel shop within a half-hour.

title: Vast Advance Is Reported In Preventing Heart Illnesses
description: The death rates from cardiovascular diseases have plummeted by 60 percent since 1950, a Federal agency is announcing today, making advances against this leading killer of Americans one of the major public health achievements of the 20th century.

title: Listening to Hillary Clinton; President's Childhood
description: To the Editor:

title: CARDINAL HEALTH AGREES TO BUY DRUG PACKAGER
description: Cardinal Health Inc., the No. 2 United States drug wholesaler, said yesterday that it would buy Automatic Liquid Packaging Inc. for about $390 million in stock, adding a company that packages medicines for drug makers like Pharmacia & Upjohn and Pfizer. Cardinal expects the acquisition to bolster earnings in its first fiscal quarter, which ends Sept. 30. Cardinal said it would not assume any debt for Automatic Liquid, which packages liquid drugs that can be swallowed, inhaled or applied to the skin. Automatic Liquid, which employs about 400 people, is based in Woodstock, Ill. Cardinal shares were unchanged at $67.0625. They have slipped 12 percent this year.

title: Congress Passes a Tax Bill Along Largely Party Lines
description: Congress gave its final approval today to a Republican plan that would lower the taxes of all Americans who pay income taxes.

title: South Africa Commission Grants Amnesty for 2 Apartheid Cases
description: A former Cabinet official, a former head of the national police force and the former head of the brutal Vlakplaas police unit were granted amnesty today for their roles in blowing up a church headquarters in Johannesburg in 1988 and falsely implicating an anti-apartheid activist in the bombing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, SYLVIA P.
description: GILMAN-Sylvia P. On August 4, 1999, at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Loving mother of the late Howard and Charles Jr. She is survived by members of the Gilman, Phillips and Marcus families. Services and interment private.

title: Front-Loading Curb Brings a Backlash
description: Under rules set by the Democratic National Committee, no state may hold a Democratic Presidential caucus or primary before next March 7, with the traditional exception of Iowa and New Hampshire. Pleas from a number of state parties for a waiver to vote earlier, and thereby gain more influence in the nominating process, have been repeatedly rejected.

title: PUBLISHER'S EARNINGS DROP
description: Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the British-Dutch publishing giant, said first-half pretax earnings fell 10 percent, to $601 million. The company also said it foresaw no likelihood of earnings increases in the second half. The company faces problems in its scientific and business publications divisions while its business information services face pressure from Internet companies offering similar information free or at low cost.

title: David J. Seligson, a Reform Rabbi, Dies at 92
description: Rabbi David J. Seligson, a nationally known Reform rabbi and an eloquent orator who held the pulpit at Central Synagogue in Manhattan for 20 years, died on Tuesday on the way to a hospital in Manhattan. He was 92 and had lived for the last two years at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan.

title: A Multi-Ethnic Kosovo Doesn't Make Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds That Rare Cancer in Amoco Employees Is Probably Work Related, Company Says
description: After a three- year study, medical investigators working for the BP Amoco Corporation said today that an unusually high incidence of a rare brain cancer among some employees at a research center near here was most likely work related.

title: AMRESCO CAPITAL TRUST AGREES TO BUY IMPAC COMMERCIAL
description: Amresco Capital Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Impac Commercial Holdings Inc. for about $55.5 million in stock. Amresco, a Dallas real estate investment trust, will swap 0.661 share for each Impac Commercial share. The deal values Impac at $6.61 share, a premium to its closing price of $5.8750 on Wednesday. Shares of Amresco fell 31.25 cents, to $9.6875, while shares of Impac rose 18.75 cents, to $6.0625. The merged real estate investment trust is expected to be managed by the Fortress Investment Corporation, which manages Impac. Fortress is expected to buy about 1.5 million Amresco shares, giving it a 15 percent stake in the combined company.

title: Barthelmes Are Cleared
description: A Mississippi circuit court on Wednesday dismissed charges of cheating at blackjack against the writer Frederick Barthelme and his brother Steven.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OBLEDO, EVA
description: OBLEDO-Eva. Happy sixth anniversary. I love you as much as ever. Think of you daily. Love, Jess

title: A Lost Chance To Let Attica Rest in Peace
description: WILL the ghosts of Attica ever find rest? Not the way New York State officials and the courts have been going, it would seem. The latest sign came this week with a Federal appeals court's ruling that suggests this long, sad affair will gnaw at our collective conscience into the new century.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on July 29 about the history of the Sony Walkman misstated the function of an orange button on the original model. When pressed, the button enabled two users of a single Walkman to speak to each other through a microphone; it did not activate a second headphone jack.

title: United Airlines to Offer Its Coach Passengers More Legroom
description: With airplanes growing more crowded and passenger complaints soaring, the nation's biggest airline said yesterday that it would offer its best customers more of what has become an increasingly scarce commodity: legroom.

title: Swedish Hurdler Returns to the Track While Battling Breast Cancer : She Knows This Is a Run for Her Life
description: MONTE CARLO  It has been a summer for improbable sporting comebacks, and even Lance Armstrong, the testicular cancer victim turned Tour de France winner, may have met his match in the race to stretch credulity and medical boundaries.

title: With 2 Months to Go, Clemens Remains a Puzzle
description: There will be the peripheral issues for Manager Joe Torre in these last two months of the Yankees' regular season, the Darryl Strawberry sideshow and Andy Pettitte's crisis of confidence and the overpowering intensity of Tino Martinez.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHSLER, JEANNE L.
description: WECHSLER-Jeanne L. Age 95, on August 5, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Arnold; loving and devoted mother of Robert, Lawrence and Stephen; dear sister of Irving, Mae, Doris, Frances, Abraham, and the late Morris, Harry and Mal; adoring grandmother of Sharon, Alisa, Jonathan, Michael, Amy and Jodi; and proud greatgrandmother of Emma, Cassidy and Zoe. Lovingly remembered by family and friends. Services will be held at Gutterman's, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, 9:45 AM, Friday, August 6. Contributions may be made in her name to the American Cancer Society.

title: Berlin Journal; Skirmish in the Store Wars: The Souvenir Caper
description: Called everything from Rambo to an apostle of German freedom, his courage compared to that of the people who brought down the Berlin wall, a middle-aged department store executive with a very big mustache has emerged as the most talked-about man in Germany.

title: On My Mind; Partying With Saddam
description: Often this week I found myself wondering how Saddam Hussein would celebrate Aug. 5, the first anniversary of his spectacular victory.

title: Republican to Oppose Whitman for Senate Seat
description: A former Libertarian gubernatorial candidate, Murray Sabrin, made it official yesterday: he is running for the United States Senate as a Republican.

title: Stanley Stahl, a Bank Owner And Real Estate Investor, 75
description: Stanley Stahl, a New York real estate and banking magnate, who prosecutors say was the target of a failed murder-for-hire scheme devised by Abe Hirschfeld, another prominent businessman, died yesterday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 75 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Theater Is Just the First Act
description: When summer comes and the golden yarrow is blooming, this impossibly tidy New England town revels in its nickname, ''The Village Beautiful,'' and in the usual tension of dramas that divide twins, trap lost souls, rile shrews and inspire neutrons to burst into song.

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; NEW DOUBTS ABOUT TV MERGER
description: Central European Media Enterprises Ltd. has come one step closer to losing its prize asset, TV Nova, the hugely successful Czech commercial station. Vladimir Zelezny, who was dismissed as the station's director but who seized control of TV Nova's broadcasting license pending a court decision, said he would no longer use the services of Central European Media's Czech subsidiary. The move was seen as increasing the risk that Central European Media's planned $615 million merger with SBS Broadcasting S.A. might have to be renegotiated or abandoned. Ladka Bauerova (NYT)

title: European Net Use to Soar
description: The number of Europeans who use the Internet will almost quadruple by 2004, climbing to 121 million from 34 million last year, according to Fletcher Research Ltd. Germany will be the biggest single market in Europe, with 30 million users, followed by Britain, which will have 25 million, the company said. Those countries, along with France, Italy and Spain, will account for 75 percent of Europe's Internet market.

title: Under the Stars: A Camping and Beach Party
description: It's 3:47 on Friday afternoon when we pull away from the curb. The prospects for fun and for disaster are equal. The mini-van is crammed to the steel-stretching, rivot-bursting limit with our camping equipment. At some point, my wife, Fran, and I are going to have to carry all that. On the other hand, the children aren't crying, screaming or whining. And I've got a full cup of coffee.

title: Swiss Lawyer Is Set to Head U.N. War Crimes Tribunals
description: A Swiss lawyer with wide experience in fighting money laundering and organized crime is expected to be named chief prosecutor of the international war crimes tribunals for the Balkans and Rwanda.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Ground Fires Scorch Acres of the Hudson Highlands
description: Virtually inextinguishable ground fires continued to spread across hundreds of acres of forest today along the western bank of the Hudson River, near the United States Military Academy at West Point.

title: Executive Promoted At New York Times
description: Alyse Myers, vice president for promotion and marketing communications at The New York Times, has been promoted to vice president for marketing services, effective immediately. The announcement was made by Janet L. Robinson, president and general manager of the newspaper, to whom she reports.

description: To the Editor:
