description: THE question is not what took Mark McGwire so long to get off the stuff. The real question is what is taking baseball so long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOVEN, NATALIE (BILLOWITZ).
description: SLOVEN-Natalie (Billowitz). Of Rockville Centre, Long Island. Died on August 4, 1999 after a long illness. Born July 13, 1920 in Hurleyville, N.Y. She is survived by three children: Larry Sloven of Hong Kong, Jane Sloven of Portland, ME., & Mark Sloven of Rockaway, N.J. Her grandchildren Jared, Lucas, Blake and Gus, her brother Philip Billowitz and many fond nieces and nephews and friends. Services Friday, 10AM at Gutterman's Inc., 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be made to the Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, N.Y. 11590.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURCKHARDT, RUDY
description: BURCKHARDT - Rudy. The Boards of Trustees and Governors of the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture mourn the passing of Rudy Burckhardt, long-time friend and former faculty member of the School, husband of Showhegan Governor Yvonne Jacquette and father of Skowhegan alumnus Tom Burckhardt. Our sincerest condolences are extended to Yvonne, Tom and the rest of the family.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Crime on Wall Street
description: Stealing money from investors is not nearly as simple as robbing a bank. The criminals often need the cooperation of legitimate professionals who are willing to look the other way.

title: At Panel's Public Hearing, Green Opposes Charter Change
description: Making an impassioned defense of his office and its position next in line to the Mayor, the city's Public Advocate, Mark Green, accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani last night of trying to change the City Charter to settle ''a political vendetta.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ELIZABETH FORSLING.
description: HARRIS-Elizabeth Forsling. The Women's Forum records with sorrow the death of its longtime member and first President. Gail Blanke, President

title: When Russia Uncovered Exotic Jewish Cultures
description: In the late 19th century, when Russia completed its conquest of the Caucasus and Central Asia, three unknown Jewish communities were discovered by Russian ethnographers checking out local populations. The Bukharan Jews of Uzbekistan, the Mountain Jews of Azerbaijan and Dagestan, and the Jews of Georgia had been ensconced in these regions for maybe two millenniums, but no one knew much about them. Legend had it that they were part of the 10 lost tribes of Israel.

title: Now on Film: Raised Fists And the Yogi Love Letters
description: Tommie Smith and Yogi Berra. How many times have those names been uttered in the same sentence? Smith's fame exploded one day in October 1968, when he raised a gloved fist to the sky on the 200-meter medal stand at the Summer Olympics in Mexico City. Berra's renown as a squat catcher with a funny name, a bad-ball hitter, a bizarre linguist and a beloved guy just keeps expanding.

title: Short Stories, Nasty and Brutish, of Life in Edinburgh
description: The operating philosophy of the Scottish slum dwellers who growl, spit, curse and brawl through Paul McGuigan's nastily amusing film, ''The Acid House,'' could be boiled down to a single acerbic slogan: it's kind to be cruel. Becoming inured at an early age to the human savagery at the bottom of the social ladder is the only way to survive the meanness and degradation so flamboyantly exhibited in these three vignettes evoking the lower depths of North Edinburgh.

title: World Wrestling Chief: Not the Usual C.E.O.

title: Death Is the Winner in Africa's Wars
description: Recent months have brought hopeful signs in Africa, from elections in South Africa and Nigeria to budding peace initiatives in Congo, Ethiopia and Eritrea, and Sierra Leone. But these positive steps aside, Africa remains torn by 11 wars involving 16 nations, and countless rebel and splinter movements. Largely internal in origin, these have a nasty habit of metastasizing into regional conflicts. Eight million refugees and uncounted millions more internally displaced people bear witness to the awesome toll of conflict. Africa's heartland, from the Red Sea to the South Atlantic, remains at war.

description: A Spanish-led consortium announced that it would pay $261 million for a 15 percent stake in and management rights of a state-owned Mexican company, Grupo Aeroportuario del Pacifico, which runs 12 airports in western Mexico. The still-unnamed consortium includes roughly equal stakes from the Spanish construction firm Grupo Dragados S.A., the state-run Spanish airport authority A.E.N.A., the Spanish utility Grupo Fenosa, and the Mexican holding company Grupo Angeles, a Dragados spokeswoman said. The Mexican Government is expected to ratify the sale next week and sign the contract by early September.

description: Mark McGwire disclosed Wednesday that he has stopped using the dietary supplement androstenedione because he was worried about the possible influence that his continued use of the controversial supplement could have on children. title: JABIL CIRCUIT IN $250 MILLION DEAL FOR GET MANUFACTURING
description: Jabil Circuit Inc., a maker of circuit board assemblies, said yesterday that it would acquire GET Manufacturing Inc. for $250 million in stock as it fulfills plans to expand into China. GET Manufacturing is a privately held electronics manufacturing services provider in Hong Kong. The company also has operations in Mexico and California. Jabil, based in St. Petersburg, Fla., has manufacturing sites in Florida, Michigan, California, Scotland, Malaysia and Mexico. Shares of Jabil rose 13 percent, or $4.875, to $41.50.

title: The Place Where The Grass Is Greener
description: When Representative Michael P. Forbes of New York abandoned the Republican Party and became a Democrat three weeks ago, he left Republican Congressional leaders with a seat to fill on the House Appropriations Committee, where membership is much coveted. At least 10 House Republicans have expressed an interest in the seat, but it appears all would be well advised to keep their expectations in check.

title: Backstage With a Cast Of Foibles and Follies
description: ''Illuminata'' is John Turturro's enormously fond homage to the world of acting, beguilingly presented and filled with knowing backstage humor. And Mr. Turturro, who directed the film and wrote its screenplay with Brandon Cole, from Mr. Cole's original play, has done a fine job of drawing his cast into the spirit of celebration. The players' enthusiasm for this material is palpable as ''Illuminata'' summons the stock characters of behind-the-scenes theater stories and affectionately invests them with new life. The actor who is asked, ''You can't cross left to right?'' and answers, ''Not emotionally, no'' may be a familiar type, but he's not one who'll ever go out of style.

title: A 60's Caper Made Glitzier
description: ''This is an elegant crime done by an elegant person,'' somebody in the very 90's remake of ''The Thomas Crown Affair'' says -- none too elegantly -- about an art heist committed by the title character. What that apparently means is that Crown stays natty even when sliding under a museum's security gate, that he is heard calmly betting $100,000 on a golf shot, that his house on a tropical island is atop the highest hill and that he and this story's heroine share their most honestly amorous moment when they go clothes shopping a deux. If the film had been shot in 3-D Imax, it would be dangling price tags that the audience could reach out and almost touch.

description: Sterling Commerce Inc., which makes software for conducting business on the Internet, said yesterday that it would dismiss about 200 employees, or 8 percent of its work force, as it reorganizes its product development, marketing, sales and services departments. The company will take a charge of $25 million to $30 million in its fiscal fourth quarter, which ends Sept. 30, for the dismissals and other realignment costs. As a result of the reorganization, Sterling Commerce expects fourth-quarter sales of $150 million to $155 million and earnings of 40 cents to 42 cents a share. Analysts had expected 45 cents a share.

Joe Torre, the Yankees' manager, watched the televised highlights of Strawberry's game with Columbus on Wednesday and agreed that, while stealing a base, Strawberry ran better than he did at any point in spring training.

title: A Guitar More Democratically Inclined
description: Guitarists tend to be tinkerers, both by nature and necessity. Their instrument, in its classic form, is comparatively soft-spoken, even when played with full force, and its string layout and tuning make certain kinds of chord voicings and counterpoint more difficult to realize than on the more democratically constructed keyboard. Jazz and rock musicians have escaped the instrument's limitations by amplifying it and inventing electronic devices to sustain, distort and color its sound in every way imaginable. Classical guitarists have been more conservative: some use discreet amplification systems, and some have added strings, usually to the bass range.

The move will create 1,000 jobs in the next two years to help Providian, based in San Francisco, handle the million-plus accounts it is adding every quarter. Providian, which already has an office in Louisville employing 500 people, said the Kentucky state government granted preliminary approval for $20 million in tax credits for the new office.

title: Inside a Greenwich Mansion, One Man's Xanadu Disintegrated

Mr. Frankel appeared to be earning huge profits from his string of insurance companies, and he lavished fur coats, jewelry, and even Mercedes cars on a widening circle of consorts, small-time businessmen and hangers-on. Most lived off his largess, professed their loyalty to him and knew little, they say, about his business dealings, which authorities now say they believe involved the wholesale theft of the insurance companies' assets.

Allen has an insatiable desire to be a daredevil, and he does not want to be outdone by his son, Rod, in harness racing's most prestigious event.

title: Primo Levi's Plunge: A Case Against Suicide
description: Sometime after 10 A.M. on Saturday, April 11, 1987, on the fourth floor of a late-19th-century building in Turin, the concierge rang the doorbell of Primo Levi's apartment. Levi, who was born in that apartment 67 years earlier, opened the door and collected his mail, just as he did every day. He smiled, thanked her, and closed the door. The concierge descended the spiral staircase, occupied in the middle by a caged elevator. She had barely reached her cubicle on the ground floor, she later told the police, when she heard Levi's body hit the bottom of the stairs by the elevator. It was 10:20. The autopsy established that he had died instantaneously of a ''crushed skull.'' No signs of violence unrelated to the fall were found on his body. At noon I heard the news on the radio in Rome. There was already mention of suicide, a conclusion later reached by the police inquiry.

title: What Will Happen Next? It Seems Nobody Knows
description: Dance companies unaccountably often put their second-best foot forward in debut seasons in New York, choosing repertory for their opening night that does not fairly represent them. title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC CUTS ITS 1999 PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation, one of the biggest makers of angioplasty products, said yesterday that it was reducing its 1999 earnings expectations by about 8 cents a share after a product recall. The company said that after six reports of malfunction it was voluntarily recalling its Rotablator Rotalink Advancer and Rotalink Plus rotational atherectomy systems, which are used to break up plaque deposits in blood vessels. Boston Scientific said it had sales of $60 million for the recalled devices and related products in the first half of the year. Officials said they expected the recall to hurt earnings in the second half. The shares of the company fell $6.50 yesterday to $30.

title: NORWOOD PROMOTIONAL TO BUY ADVERTISING UNLIMITED
description: Norwood Promotional Products Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Advertising Unlimited Inc., a unit of R. L. Polk & Co., for about $150 million in cash as part of Norwood's effort to become the world's No. 1 promotional products company. Advertising Unlimited, based in Sleepy Eye, Minn., is the No. 6 United States supplier of promotional products and a leader in desk accessories and calendars. It has annual sales of about $120 million. Closely held Norwood, based in Austin, Tex., is the No. 1 United States supplier of decorated promotional items like keychains, mugs and clocks. Norwood said that the companies would have had combined 1998 revenue of about $400 million.

description: RESSNER-Michael. Of Hewlett Neck, N.Y, August 4th. Dearest, devoted sweetheart and husband of Natalie (Godnick). title: LYCOS PURCHASES CLOSELY HELD MEDIA SCIENCE
description: Lycos Inc., the Internet search directory, bought the closely held Media Science Inc. for $38.8 million in stock to bolster its Web site with software that plays music downloaded from the Internet. Lycos will issue 1.1 million shares to Media Science, a San Francisco-based company that is incorporated as Internet Music Distribution Inc. Media Science makes Sonique, a software device that allows users to play songs converted into so-called Mp3 computer files on their personal computers. The acquisition will help Lycos exploit the growing popularity of music content on the Web and fortify it against larger rivals that also are adding music-related features.

title: Shulamit Katznelson, 80; Teacher of Arabs and Jews

title: INVESTMENT IN EARLY-STAGE E-BUSINESS IS STARTED
description: The International Business Machines Corporation made its first investment in early-stage E-business companies yesterday through the purchase of a $45 million stake in Internet Capital Group Inc. Internet Capital, based in Wayne, Pa., is an incubator for E-business companies, providing them with capital and expertise in areas like recruiting, marketing and sales. Internet Capital completed an initial public offering earlier this week, and its shares began trading on Thursday. In conjunction with the stock sale, I.B.M. purchased 3.75 million Internet Capital shares at the initial offering price of $12 each. Yesterday, Internet Capital shares rose $5.875, to $39.375.

title: ACQUISITION OF PRUDENTIAL HEALTHCARE IS COMPLETED
description: Aetna Inc., the biggest United States health insurer, said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of Prudential Healthcare for about $1 billion, after wrestling with outside objections to the acquisition for more than half a year. The purchase, Aetna's third of a managed health care company since 1996, will add about 5.5 million health insurance customers. The transaction also lets Prudential Healthcare's parent, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, shed a money-losing business as it converts to a stock company from one owned by policyholders.

title: Albany Plan Widely Expands Sampling of Criminals' DNA
description: New York State will embark on one of the nation's most aggressive programs of collecting DNA samples from convicted felons, building a computer database that the police can use to solve crimes, under an agreement reached late Thursday night by Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders.

title: LIFE INSURER INSOLVENT
description: South Korea's financial watchdog agency declared the Korea Life Insurance Company insolvent and pledged roughly $1.1 billion in public funds to shore up its capital base. The Financial Supervisory Commission has conducted three rounds of bidding for the failing insurer since April but failed to find a buyer. The commission said the delays in selling the insurance company had led to policy cancellations and ''a sense of panic'' among workers.

title: Recalling When Betty Friedan Was Opening Minds
description: There's something depressing about having Joan Lunden, in all her blond morning-television perkiness, introduce the life story of Betty Friedan, the original, serious don't-call-us-girls era feminist. But this is Lifetime's ''Intimate Portrait'' series, not known for its depth or stunning insights. Normally the series is not known for featuring particularly important women either; next week, for instance, Lifetime viewers will have a chance to see ''Intimate Portrait: Kelly Preston.'' Ms. Friedan is the subject tomorrow night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, SYLVIA PHILLIPS
description: GILMAN-Sylvia Phillips. The Board of Trustees and staff of the American Friends of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art mourn the passing of our respected and dear friend, Sylvia Phillips Gilman. She was a dedicated supporter of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, and will long be remembered for her kindness and generosity. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and loved ones. Uzi Zucker, Chairman Tamar Rudich, Vice Chairman

title: Win or Lose, Valentine Still Carries a Burden
description: Years and years from now, fans of the 1999 Mets will tell their grandchildren the tale of how, 55 games and three fired coaches into the season, Bobby Valentine declared to the world, ''In the next 55 games, if we're not better, I shouldn't be the manager.''

title: Kosovar Vengeance Has Roots in West
description: To the Editor:

title: Tucker Wins Gold
description: The bantamweight Gerald Tucker of Cincinnati easily outpointed Neouar Cermeno of Venezuela, 15-3, to win a gold medal. He was the only American champion in six bouts, with Arthur Palac of Hamtramck, Mich., losing to Yohason Martinez of Cuba in the middleweight division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOREL, CLAUDETTE MARGUERITE
description: SOREL-Claudette Marguerite. Renowned concert pianist, teacher and author died at her home in Hampton Bays, NY Friday, August 6th, 1999 at age 66. No immediate family members survive. It was her request that no funeral service be held. Memorial contributions may be made to the Elizabeth and Michel Sorel Charitable Organization which supports opportunities for women in music. Their address is: 28 West 44th Street, Suite 711, New York, New York 10036.

title: Mental Illness Is Private
description: To the Editor:

title: For Birthday Parties or Legal Parties; Dividing Things Fairly Is Not Always a Piece of Cake
description: You want to cut a cake fairly? Take a knife, count the people at the party, cut the slices and hand them out. Even if the pieces are a bit uneven, who cares? What person above the age of 10 would have the nerve to stop a party and complain that his slice wasn't as big as someone else's?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, IRVING (IRV)
description: CANTOR-Irving (Irv). On August 5, 1999 due to complications of pneumonia. He is survived by his devoted wife of 58 years, Frances; cherished daughter, Jane C. Nicholson; son-in-law Alan Seigenfeld and by his beloved grandson, A. Reid Nicholson of Los Angeles, CA. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Saturday, 7-9 PM. Interment private.

title: Nairobi Embassy Blast Survivors Still Struggling
description: Until Aug. 7, 1998, one year ago, Douglas Sidialo was a car salesman who drove around Nairobi for his job. He tells a dark little joke about why that line of work is closed off to him now. ''If I drove cars,'' he said, ''I would knock people over.''

title: Fleisher Leads by One, And Ties Course Record
description: On the 17th tee at the Meadow Brook Club today, a spectator shouted to Bruce Fleisher: he had a chance to capture the course record in the Lightpath Long Island Classic. The news went in one ear and out the other, Fleisher said, the sort that matters more to players who are accustomed to a place in the record book.

title: Banque Nationale Merger Bid Seems Only Partly Successful
description: Banque Nationale de Paris all but acknowledged today that it was likely to snare only half the prize in its five-month-old struggle for control of two French banking rivals, Societe Generale and Paribas.

title: Bronze for U.S. Men
description: The United States men edged Canada, 2-1, to win the bronze medal. Carlos Bocanegra drove in a header off a cross from Cory Gibbs in the seventh minute. Then 17-year-old forward Landon Donovan of Bayer Leverkusen in Germany added a second off a rebound in the 60th minute.

title: Co-Leader of Talent Agency Resigns After Disagreement
description: Jim Wiatt, co-chairman of International Creative Management, one of Hollywood's top talent agencies, unexpectedly resigned today after disagreements with his partner, Jeffrey Berg. Mr. Wiatt's departure could lead to defections of some of his movie star and director clients to rival agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKEL, SAMUEL
description: FRANKEL-Samuel. On August 6, 1999 of Massapequa, LI. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Ronni and Martin Begleiter, Jeffrey and Doreen Frankel. Dear brother of Morton and Ben. Loving brother-in-law of Herbert, Evelyn and Phyllis Kaplan. Cherished grandfather of Wendy, Tori, Adam and Hilary. Services Sunday 11:30am at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKNIS, ESTELLE R.
description: JACKNIS-Estelle R. Beloved wife of Nathan. Loving mother of Dr. Ira Jacknis, Rabbi Ian and Suri Jacknis, and Jocelyn. Cherished grandmother of Noam, Yael and Nava. Dear sister of Dr. Morton Kupperman. Services Sunday August 8, 1pm at Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, Roslyn Rd at The Northern State Parkway. For further information please call I.J. Morris at: 516-499-6060.

title: Giuliani Vows To Veto Bill Regulating Food Markets
description: The City Council and the Giuliani administration are heading for a showdown over proposed legislation that the Council says would protect the rights of employees at New York's wholesale food and produce markets.

title: MERGERS AND POLITICS
description: The British Trade Secretary, Stephen Byers, announced a plan to try to prevent political concerns from influencing decisions on whether mergers inhibit competition. He said his office would no longer have a hand in determining whether mergers -- except those involving newspapers or national security -- would be referred to the Competition Commission.

title: Hearst to Buy San Francisco Chronicle
description: The Hearst Corporation, the owner of The San Francisco Examiner, said yesterday that it was buying The San Francisco Chronicle, increasing the likelihood that San Francisco will join the growing list of one-newspaper cities.

title: No Mismatch in San Antonio As Nickell Team Earns Title
description: On paper, the Spingold Knockout Team Championship final in San Antonio a week ago was a mismatch. On one side was a group of world champions: Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell. By the time the final was played, after a week of play, they were well rested. Most of their opponents had been heavily defeated, and had resigned themselves to the inevitable before the match was over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENYUK, LARUSSO, ANNE E.
description: MENYUK-LARUSSO-Anne E. On July 31, 1999. Beloved sister and aunt. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her.

title: Indian Report Blames Individual In Killing of Missionary and Sons
description: The killing of an Australian missionary and his two young sons by a frenzied mob in January was instigated by an individual and not by any Hindu right-wing group associated with the governing Bharatiya Janata Party, according to a summary of a judicial inquiry issued today by the Indian Government.

title: Failed China Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, HERBERT
description: CHASE-Herbert On August 5, 1999. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Nancy Ann, Herbert, Leslie and Debra. Dear brother of Arnold, Lydia, the late Harold and Gordon. Adoring grandfather of Richard, Gregory, Rebecca, Benjamin and Dylan. Herbert graduated from Yale, served in the Army as Captain during WWII and was a creative inventor and business manufacturer. Service private.

title: Let's Turn Off the TV and Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite the Dry Look, There's Still Hope for Lawns
description: The bad news for lovers of velvety lawns is that much of the grass underfoot these blistering summer days looks and feels like Shredded Wheat -- harsh on the eyes and splintery on the bottom of feet. And if they are not crispy now, lawns will be once the use of sprinklers is banned, as is the case in New Jersey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: REDUCTION IN PRICE SET FOR FOLGERS COFFEE
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would cut the price of its Folgers brand coffee for the first time in more than a year to reflect lower prices for raw beans. As of Sept. 13, the company's recommended retail price for Folgers regular ground, the nation's best-selling brand of coffee, will fall by 10 cents, to $2.20, for a 13-ounce can, according to Sydney McHugh, a company spokeswoman. A 13-ounce can of decaffeinated coffee will also fall by 10 cents, to $2.90.

title: Mrs. Clinton Criticizes Plan To Cut Taxes
description: Offering a sharp condemnation of the tax-cut package passed by Congress this week, Hillary Rodham Clinton finished her fourth so-called listening tour of New York State here today, and refused to immerse herself directly in a discussion about the politics of next year's race for United States Senate.

title: N.F.L. May Bypass Los Angeles for Houston
description: Los Angeles's bid for the National Football League's 32d franchise is approaching its demise and Houston's chances are looking better every day.

title: A Test for Korea
description: The near-collapse of Daewoo Group, one of the large conglomerates that dominate the South Korean economy, is presenting a test for the Government of President Kim Dae Jung. Its performance so far is not reassuring.

title: About New York; Aspiring To the Worries Of Success
description: LORD FINESSE and Walter Velasquez were sitting in Mr. Velasquez's apartment at the Forest Houses, a South Bronx housing project, talking about the burdens of wealth.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising Column in Business Day on July 30 about stagnant sales of ice cream misstated the financial performance of Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc. The company posted a profit in the most recent quarter, which ended June 26. It did not have two consecutive money-losing quarters.

title: Jobs and Pay Grow, Stoking Inflation Fear
description: Employers hired new workers at a surprisingly robust pace last month and had to pay substantially more to find them, the Government reported today.

title: After Much Slugging, Yankees Emerge on Top
description: The Yankees and Mariners engaged in a long game that turned ugly in the last two innings tonight, with a bench-clearing brawl that stretched the proceedings to just over four hours.

title: The Holocaust as Hype? Dissenting From a Dissent
description: THE HOLOCAUST IN AMERICAN LIFE

title: An Inevitable, but Reluctant, Move by a Governor
description: From any perspective, Gov. George E. Pataki's announcement yesterday that he would support Rudolph W. Giuliani in a likely Senate race next year, instead of Representative Rick A. Lazio, was a critical moment both in the Senate race and in the feud between two New York Republicans with competing national ambitions.

title: Police Officer Rescues An Invalid From a Fire
description: A police officer carried a woman in a wheelchair down three flights of stairs in a burning house yesterday, the police said.

title: Security Issues May Delay Los Alamos Case, U.S. Says
description: The Energy Department has sought a delay in the Government's decision on seeking an indictment against a former Los Alamos scientist in connection with the mishandling of nuclear secrets, officials said today.

title: Kosovar Vengeance Has Roots in West
description: To the Editor:

title: With Fiscal Battle Plans Drawn, Lawmakers Begin Recess
description: With passage of a $792 billion tax cut secured, Congress left for its August recess early today and set the stage for a high-stakes autumn confrontation with President Clinton over the nation's fiscal priorities in the new era of projected Federal surpluses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, STANLEY
description: STAHL-Stanley. The Directors, Officers and Staff of the Apple Bank for Savings mourn the passing of Stanley Stahl, a man of remarkable spirit, warmth and sincerity. He achieved great distinction in business both as a successful real estate investor and as owner of Apple Bank. In all matters, he conducted himself with rare dignity, integrity and intelligence. He will be greatly missed by all of us who knew him as an employer and as a friend. We extend our profound condolences to his family and pray that they may find consolation in his memory.

title: Space Station Astronauts Report Illnesses
description: On the last mission to the new International Space Station, several astronauts suffered nausea, headaches and other symptoms that have NASA scrambling for solutions to a suspected air-quality problem before another crew visits the growing outpost.

title: S. H. Woodson, Assembly Chief And Pastor, 83
description: The Rev. S. Howard Woodson Jr., who in 1974 became the first black to lead the lower house of a state legislature, died July 28 at a hospital in Trenton. He was 83.

title: Let's Turn Off the TV and Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Counts the Years? Opposites Still Attract
description: Not many people own a copy of ''School Days,'' a recording made by a quartet including the soprano saxophonist Steve Lacy and the trombonist Roswell Rudd playing Thelonious Monk's music. It was made in 1963 on a cheap tape recorder at the Phase Two Coffee House in Greenwich Village, released in 1975 in a small quantity on a tiny label and again several years ago on a CD that has since passed out of print. So the significance of Mr. Lacy and Mr. Rudd's reunion, which started earlier this year on the West Coast and continues this week, may pass by even some fairly astute followers of jazz. But it's a warm, welcome combination, and it works as well as it ever did. The pair play through tomorrow at Iridium, 44 West 63d Street in Manhattan, in front of Mr. Lacy's normal rhythm section of Jean-Jacques Avenel on bass and John Betsch on drums.

title: All Eyes on Jarrett as Nascar Prepares for Brickyard Race
description: Dale Jarrett is speeding down the front straightaway of the Nascar Winston Cup season. He holds a 254-point lead over Mark Martin and a 283-point lead over Bobby Labonte entering Saturday's Brickyard 400, and only a major collapse -- or a serious run of bad luck -- over the final 15 races of the season could keep Jarrett from winning his first Winston Cup championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROSS, LEE
description: CROSS-Lee. Age 57, of Brooklyn. On August 5th, due to pneumonia. She was an Acting Justice of the New York Supreme Court sitting in Queens' county. She is survived by her loving husband, Bill Brodsky, her two children Sarah Cross, 21, and Rachel Brodsky, 20, as well as her parents Dick and Peggy Cross of Princton and her siblings Jim, Alan, Annie, and Janey Cross. All of whom will miss her dearly. Lee graduated from Milton Academy in 1959, Swarthmore College in 1963, and then spent two years in the Peace Corp in Thailand. She graduated from Harvard Law School in 1968 and went on to a career as a criminal lawyer in New York. She was a staff attorney on the National Commission on the reform of federal criminal law, and then became an Assistant US Attorney in Washington DC. In 1976, She formed the firm Arkin, Arisohn & Cross, in New York. She was appointed a judge in October 1990. A funeral will be held Sunday, at 2PM at Congregation Mt. Sinai, 250 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Planned Parenthood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, R. INSLEE, JR.
description: CLARK-R. Inslee, Jr. The Horace Mann Community sadly mourns the loss of its esteemed colleague and longtime friend R. Inslee Clark, Jr., who served both as Headmaster and President of Horace Mann from 1970-1991. During his two decades of service his impact on the school was great. He not only oversaw the merger of Horace Mann with both the Barnard School and New York Nursery Years, but he also reintroduced co-education to the school. A brilliant, dynamic teacher, he taught an Urban History course and took students into prisons and courtrooms to learn first hand about the complex urban issues confronting New York City. His inspirational leadership, his ebullient personality, his devotion to the thousands of students he reached out to and his personal commitment to Horace Mann are remembered by all of us. His impressive intellect and passion for baseball are legendary. He was a man of true valor and we will miss him. We extend our sincere condolences to his brothers Jonathan, Christopher and Anthony. Services will be at 10 AM Saturday, August 7, at Christ Church Riverdale, 5030 Henry Hudson Parkway, Riverdale, N.Y. Michael D. Hess '58, Chair Board of Trustees Dr. Eileen Mullady Head of School

title: Moneyline's New Look; Yes, Willow Bay Is an Ex-Model, but One With an M.B.A.
description: When Rick Kaplan became president of CNN/U.S.A. in late 1997, he wanted to make a splash with three prime-time programs he was creating in concert with Time, Fortune and Entertainment Weekly, magazine siblings in the Time Warner corporate family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHARDT, SOL
description: STEINHARDT-Sol. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Sol Steinhardt, beloved father of our good friend and supporter Michael Steinhardt. We extend our deepest condolences to Michael, his wife Judy, grandchildren David, Daniel and Sara, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Another Day, Another Milestone
description: In what seems to be baseball's nightly milestone, Tony Gwynn of the San Diego Padres took his long expected place among the game's great hitters last night, stroking the 3,000th hit of his career at Olympic Stadium in Montreal. He was the 22d player to reach the 3,000 plateau and the first to do it outside the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARNOVSKY, LESLIE
description: KARNOVSKY - Leslie. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member Leslie Karnovsky, and offer their deepest sympathy to her husband, Dr. Terry Karnovsky, her children and the entire Karnovsky family. Alpine Country Club Michael Bergstein, President

title: In the End, Agreements on Crime and the Environment
description: The package of bills endorsed by Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders on Thursday night calls for far-reaching changes in a number of areas -- from crime to the environment -- affecting the lives of millions of New Yorkers.

title: Religion Journal; Lutherans to Vote Again on Link to Episcopalians
description: As anniversary dates go, a notable one in the ecumenical movement among Christian churches comes up on Aug. 18.

title: PRODIGY'S RETURN
description: He was once a promising musician, but became an art critic, and the piano gathered dust in his apartment. Then his old flame was reignited, luring him into a national competition and a confrontation with the life he might have led. A report by Michael Kimmelman, in The Times Magazine.

title: Teachers Gather, Putting the Maps Away
description: The topic was stress management in the classroom, but as the professor began his case study, about a New England school coping with the death of a child in a storm, his students desperately wanted to read aloud from the pages of their own lives.

title: The Coming Budget Blowup
description: Capitol Hill is having a tough time putting together an honest budget this year. Republicans have passed the biggest tax cut in two decades, disproportionately rewarding the richest Americans, who do not need it. The fact that only high-flying G.O.P. donors and special interests really want this tax cut was acknowledged by a top party strategist who commended fellow lawmakers for defying public opinion by passing it. Meanwhile, Republicans have slashed children's health, school aid, crime-fighting and other vital programs, while employing budget gimmicks to avoid even more cuts. The whole exercise is designed to please the hard right and precipitate a confrontation with the White House.

title: Roaring Through the Wilderness
description: What good is wilderness? Almost 40 years ago, Wallace Stegner argued that we need wilderness protected on our public lands -- wherever wilderness might still be found -- not ''merely'' as a reservoir of biological diversity and for the opportunity wilderness provides for uncrowded, quiet recreation, but also as an idea: as one of the elements that helped form the American character.

title: He Vowed to Return, And Now Wallace Has
description: Ever since John Wallace was unhappily shipped north of the border in 1997, he vowed to return to New York. Less than two years later -- and with more than a little help from the Knicks -- the franchise's former first-round draft choice made good on his word.

title: Jones's Anonymity Is on the Line as He Gets a Starting Job
description: The Giants' first pick in the 1996 draft was the fifth over all, the highest the team has selected in 15 years. The choice was defensive end Cedric Jones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSH, LAWRENCE
description: HERSH-Lawrence. Died August 5, 1999, peacefully at home after a long illness. Beloved husband of Carol, cherished father of Amy and Edward, loving father-in-law of Hilary, devoted grandfather of Aaron. Founder of Forrest Engraving Co. in New Rochelle. He was proud of his army service in WWII and devoted to community service to The Yorktown Jewish Center, The Yorktown Volunteer Ambulance Corps, and Lions Club.

title: Disclose Contributions
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth F. Harris, 77, the First Publisher of Ms.
description: Elizabeth Forsling Harris, who was briefly the first publisher of Ms. magazine, died on July 14 in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 77.

title: Deal by America Online
description: The Wit Capital Corporation, an on-line investment bank, will offer after-hours stock trading through America Online Inc. under an agreement that gives Wit exclusive access to America Online's 17 million customers. Wit will pay America Online an undisclosed sum to be the sole tenant for six months on its after-hours center, which is scheduled to open by Nov. 1 as part of the company's personal finance site. America Online will sell ads for Wit and will promote securities research done by Wit.

title: FDX GLOBAL UNIT TO ACQUIRE GEOLOGISTICS AIR
description: The FDX Global Logistics Inc. unit of the FDX Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Geologistics Air Services for about $116 million. The Geologistics Corporation, a privately held provider of shipping services based in Golden, Colo., said it was selling its air services unit because it no longer fit in its business plan. Geologistics Air Services, based in Greensboro, N.C., provides air freight forwarding services between the United States and Puerto Rico. FDX Global Logistics, through its Caliber Logistics subsidiary, offers global transportation management services. FDX, based in Memphis, also is the parent company of the Federal Express Corporation.

title: Russell Inslee Clark Jr., 64, a Dean at Yale
description: Russell Inslee Clark Jr., who as dean of undergraduate admissions at Yale University presided over the enrollment of Yale's first women in 1969, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Wallingford, Conn. He was 64 and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: On Like Popcorn and 100 Degrees Cooler
description: In the 1980's the Bad Brains were like a child's game demonstrating the concepts of slow and fast. A black group from Washington led by the rastafarian singer H. R. (Paul Hudson), they'd rock at ferocious velocity, spitting slogan lyrics about eating the bourgeoisie, then stop and play a downtempo reggae song as religiously numbed out as it gets.

title: Disclose Contributions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASTOR, JOSEPH H.
description: KASTOR-Joseph H. On August 1, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Helen (Banner) Kastor. Devoted father of William, James and Bruce. Loving grandfather of Dawn, Michelle, Lisa and Jasmin. Service and burial at Maimonides Cemetery, Bklyn, N.Y. August 9, 1PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to Glens Falls Senior Citizens Center, 380 Glen St, Glens Falls NY 12801 or Glens Falls Hospital, 100 Park St, Glens Falls NY 12801.

title: Volvo to Buy Another Swedish Truck Maker for $7.4 Billion
description: In a $7.4 billion deal that will create the world's second-largest maker of trucks and buses, Volvo A.B. of Sweden is buying one of its archrivals, the Swedish truck maker Scania.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMANN, HAROLD
description: HERMANN-Harold. Died on August 6, 1999 at age 84. Devoted husband of Dorothy, caring father of Barbara Clapp & Kenneth Hermann, grandfather of Adrian Clapp & Laura Clapp. We will miss his steadfastness and his ability to make us laugh. His loving generous spirit will live in our hearts.

title: A Striking New Design For Poulenc's Nuns
description: The Santa Fe Opera, now in its 43d summer season, regularly draws over half of its audience from out of state. The quality of the productions is usually high. But what particularly brings visitors is the company's spectacular open-air theater in the mountains north of the city, and its commitment to unusual repertory.

title: GIULIANI RECEIVES PATAKI'S BACKING FOR SENATE RACE
description: Seeking to avoid a civil war that could poison the Republicans' chances next year, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday put aside his antipathy toward Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, endorsed him for United States Senate and urged the other major Republican contender to abandon the race.

title: Man Accused Of Assisting Wife's Suicide
description: A 75-year-old man was charged yesterday with helping his ailing wife commit suicide by attaching a rope to a ceiling beam in their Queens apartment and tying it into the noose she used to hang herself early Thursday morning.

title: SWEETENED BID FOR LUMBER COMPANY
description: In an escalating takeover bid for Le Group Forex Inc. of Montreal, the Boise Cascade Corporation sweetened its offer from $31 to $33 (Canadian) a share, for a total of $808.7 million (Canadian) or $538 million (United States), topping the bid of $31 (Canadian) a share from the Louisiana Pacific Corporation. Both companies want Forex for its mills that make a plywood substitute used in floors, roofs, siding and house foundations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYMAN, MARTA
description: SNYMAN-Marta. Marta Snyman, a retired stockbroker and teacher, died on July 7th, 1999 of a brain hemorrhage at Tulane University Medical Center in New Orleans. She was 57. Ms. Snyman was born in New York City and lived in New York City and New Orleans. She was a graduate of Clearwater High School in Clearwater, Florida and the University of Florida at Gainesville. She was an actress and art patron. Survivors include her companion, Tom Lawton. Memorial services will be held privately in New York City and New Orleans.

title: Caring for the Caregivers
description: Some 90 percent of the hired care that old people get, either in their own homes or in nursing homes, is given by nurses' aides. The aides do the basic, intimate things, the waking, toileting, bathing, dressing, feeding and bedding down for the night. It is their eyes, their voices, their manner and touch that form the texture of daily life for millions of dependent old people -- a population that suffers not only from collapsing mental and physical states, but also from simple, profound feelings of loneliness and depression.

title: Let's Turn Off the TV and Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: Banking Expert Nominated To Be Fed Vice Chairman
description: President Clinton yesterday nominated Roger W. Ferguson Jr., a management and technology expert whose monetary views are not widely known in the investment community, to be vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Memo From Moscow; Formation of Rivals' Alliance Exposes Yeltsin Decline
description: In his eight years as Russia's first popularly elected President, Boris N. Yeltsin has shown that he can stomach vicious criticism, manage a virulent Communist opposition and emerge bloodied but whole from a disastrous civil war.

title: Then and Now, the Most Precious Commodity
description: Droughts of varying severity seem to come every 10 years or so in the Northeast. Though the current dry period may be the worst on record in some states, previous water shortages created hardships -- and controversy. Reservoirs and wells went dry, and local officials took some heat.

title: Violence Among Israelis Sets Off National Wave of Soul-Searching
description: His hair a shellacked, platinum blond, his face framed by a pair of hoop earrings, Miki Abutbul, 16, an Israeli from a working-class suburb, was sprawled with friends on plastic chairs in a crowded pedestrian walkway in central Jerusalem just after midnight this morning, talking about violence in Israel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Job Creation Surged in July; Jobless Rate Unchanged

title: Truce Among New York Republicans
description: To the dismay of Hillary Rodham Clinton's supporters, peace seems to have broken out between the two squabbling Republicans vying to run against her for the Senate seat from New York. With only 10 days to go before Representative Rick Lazio of Long Island was scheduled to announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination, Gov. George Pataki exercised his prerogative as titular head of the party, endorsed Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and even asked Mr. Lazio to drop out if Mr. Giuliani runs. Mr. Lazio's office says he is still in the race. But since the Congressman had said he would withdraw if asked by the Governor, it looks like easy sailing for New York City's Mayor.

title: CARLTON COMMUNICATIONS PLANS REAL IMAGE INVESTMENT
description: Carlton Communications P.L.C.'s Technicolor unit, the world's biggest maker of videos, will invest as much as $83 million in the closely held Real Image Technology Inc. to start developing digital film for movie studios. Carlton, based in London, said it agreed to take an initial 49 percent stake in Real Image, a Los Angeles-based start-up founded by Hollywood movie executives, for $23 million in cash. Carlton may invest $60 million more and take an additional 11.5 percent of Real Image on the basis of successful trials. Real Image is developing technology to store and encrypt digital film so it can be shown on a projector.

title: In Pair of Races, 3-Year-Olds Vie to Replace Charismatic
description: Some have been rested after grueling Triple Crown campaigns, others needed more time to develop and were prepped in lower-profile stakes races. But the race for the title of the best, or at least second-best, 3-year-old in the land resumes tomorrow when two compact fields go off in the Haskell Invitational and the Jim Dandy Stakes.

title: Domain Concern To Release Data
description: Network Solutions Inc., which has been battling the Federal Government over the company's monopoly on registering Internet addresses, or domains, agreed Thursday to open its data base -- the equivalent of the Internet's telephone directory -- to public use while negotiations over its monopoly continue.

title: Malaysia's Merger Plan Stuns Bankers
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Just over a week ago, a parade of Malaysia's top bankers rolled up to the central bank here in their chauffeured cars to learn their fate. Six groups of executives were summoned at half-hour intervals and were ushered into a meeting room where they were introduced to their future corporate partners.

title: New Jersey's Dinosaur In Need of a New Look; Replica From Hadrosaurus's Heyday Is Outdated, According to Expert
description: Unheralded, unappreciated and just plain unattractive, New Jersey's state dinosaur, the Hadrosaurus foulkii, has never approached the marquee status of prehistoric megastars like Tyrannosarus rex or Velociraptor.

title: In Colombia, Drugs and War Are Linked
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Washington Battle Awaits

title: Japan's Ruling Party Ends Standoff on Bond Policy
description: The ruling Liberal Democratic Party said today that it would not press the Bank of Japan to buy Japanese Government bonds that are likely to be used to finance further fiscal stimulus programs.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a plan by United Airlines to offer its best customers more legroom in the economy sections of domestic flights misstated the percentage of the airline's annual sales that are contributed by business travelers. Frequent business travelers make up about 9 percent of United's customers but account for 46 percent of its sales, not 36 percent.

title: 30-Year Yield Is at Highest In 20 Months
description: Yields of United States Government bonds surged yesterday to their highest level in 20 months after the Labor Department's July employment report added to the mounting concern that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this month.

title: U.S. Colonel's Wife Named In Bogota Drug Smuggling
description: In April and May, Laurie Anne Hiett, the wife of an Army colonel in charge of all United States military operations in Colombia, mailed six packages to New York City from the American Embassy in Bogota. Each was sealed in plain brown paper and weighed several pounds.

title: Pastor of Harlem Church Nominated to Head SUNY at Old Westbury
description: The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d has been formally nominated to be president of the Old Westbury campus of the State University of New York, a job he said he would welcome. He would retain his role as pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, one of New York City's most influential religious institutions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, DORIS
description: MARKS-Doris. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the death of Doris Marks. We extend our sincere sympathy to her grandson, Evan Marks, esteemed colleague and member of The Hebrew Home Board of Directors, his wife, Dr. Janice Marks, and the entire Marks family. Evan's commitment to the aged was fostered by his long and caring relationship with his grandmother. We hope that warm memories of times together will ease your sorrow during this time of sadness. Milton A. Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOLEY, ELIZABETH A.
description: GOOLEY-Elizabeth A. Age 79, a retiree from GTE, died on Wednesday, August 4, 1999. Services were private.

title: I.R.A. Denies Role in 2 Gun Cases Delaying Progress on Ulster
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that it was not responsible for two incidents that have led Protestant officials in Ulster to call for the expulsion of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A. political wing, from the Northern Ireland Assembly.

title: Deutsche Telekom to Expand Into British Market
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. agreed to buy the British cellular telephone company One 2 One Ltd. today in a deal worth $11.1 billion. The deal is the German phone giant's first big foray abroad since its ill-fated attempt to buy Telecom Italia S.p.A. collapsed three months ago.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR SLIPS. Sugar fell after a London trading house raised its estimate of the global market surplus because of higher-than-expected production in Brazil. Sugar for October delivery fell 0.21 cent, to 5.99 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSON, DAVID J., RABBI
description: SELIGSON-David J., Rabbi. The Brotherhood of Central Synagogue deeply mourns the loss of our beloved Rabbi,and Chaplin David Seligson. As he stood on the bima, his long life was our link with the past. As he blessed our children, he traced that history into the future. Victor P. Muskin, President Richard C. Kandel, Chairman Theodore J. Freiser, Vice Pres. Stephen Karasik, Vice President Howard Slonim, Vice President

description: William James Fadiman, the Hollywood producer, script editor and book reviewer, died on June 30 at his home in Bel Air, Calif. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERGER, ROSE
description: WEISSBERGER-Rose. On August 4, 1999 in her one hundredth year died peacefully at home. The devoted wife to both the late Irving Weissberger and the late Samuel H. Weinstein. She is survived and her memory cherished by her sons Alvin (Ruth) Wayne, Edgar M. (Ann) Wayne, Dr. William B. (Marie) Wayne. She was the loving grandmother of Mitchell Wayne and Elizabeth Rappaport, Karen Wayne, the late Steven Wayne, Samuel Wayne, Meredith & Matthew Wayne and the adored great grandmother of Gillian and Nicole Wayne & Genna and Philip Rappaport. Her love, warmth and concern for her family and friends was expressed by her parting words, ''You should all live and be well''. She will forever be the star by which we sail. The family requests memorial contributions to Mercy Hospice, 1220 Front Street, Uniondale, New York 11553. Services at 12 noon on Sunday, August 8th at Gutterman's Rockville Centre, New York.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: As the ill-fated Paris courtesan who aspires to respectability and forbidden love in CAMILLE (1937), Greta Garbo drew the most enthusiastic reviews of her luminous career. Under George Cukor's astute direction, the actress reached her emotional peak, quietly complimented by a young Robert Taylor (above, with Garbo) as the infatuated Armand, in this Alexandre Dumas tale of passion's ways. Fine support comes from Lionel Barrymore as Armand's concerned father and Elizabeth Allan, Laura Hope Crews and Lenore Ulric as fairweather friends of the stricken Camille. Henry Daniell adds a convincing touch of villainy - Thursday at 6 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies.

Neither his family or friends will forget him... nor will we. Children, Grandchildren & Joyc

description: LIKE many bands, this one had its genesis as a bunch of teen-agers playing music in a basement. Unlike most, this band has played gigs in Hartford, New York City and even Havana and its current six members will be finishing its first compact disk later this month.

description: ON a muggy Monday night last month, some 80,000 classical music fans ignored forecast thundershowers and flocked to Central Park to enjoy the music of Dvorak and Tchaikovsky. Meanwhile, businesses across North America are deploying similar symphonies to drive people away.

title: Beer and Burgers In a Hudson Cafe
description: Patrons at the Hudson Beach Cafe, a new bar and grill in Riverside Park near West 103d Street, have a view of ''the second-best sunset on the Hudson,'' said one of the owners, Michael O'Neal. (Mr. O'Neal was referring to his other Hudson dining spot, the 79th Street Boat Basin Cafe.)

title: Ideas & Trends; Muddling Fact and Fiction and Policy
description: A FRIEND recently noticed that I take one route going to the gym and another coming home. That's good, she told me. It will make you smarter. When I asked her why, she said scientists say that varying the routine helps the brain sprout new nerve connections and that, in turn, makes people more intelligent.

title: Elizabeth Stein And John Ruark
description: Elizabeth Jessica Stein, the daughter of Mary and Bradford Stein of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday at her parents' house in West Copake, N.Y., to John Douglas Ruark, a son of Cynthia and Bill Ruark of Berkhamsted, England. The Rev. Janice Arlene Rost, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: Staci Bockstein, Steven Frankowitz
description: Dr. Staci Michelle Bockstein is to be married this evening to Steven David Frankowitz at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Morrison is to perform the cermony.

title: BEING THERE WHEN IT COUNTED
description: OFTEN a search for the unexpected turns out to be a trip down the road more traveled. Over the last 30 years tourists have stormed the Great Wall and the Berlin Wall. They've rediscovered South Beach and Vietnam, worn Patagonia in Patagonia and become so excited about nature that environmentalists fear that they are loving it to death. Call it eek-o tourism.

title: A Park's Progress From Drug Market to Playground
description: It was perhaps the most notorious of East Harlem's forgotten parks, but neighbors say it is about to get the attention it deserves.

title: August 1-7; A Post Filled After 14 Months
description: After a drawn-out nomination battle, the Senate voted to confirm Richard C. Holbrooke as chief American delegate to the United Nations. The 14-month delay left the Clinton Administration without a high-level representative at United Nations during military conflicts in the Balkans and the Persian Gulf. The Administration hopes Mr. Holbrooke can improve relations with the organization.

title: Ellen Tillotson, Frank Turner
description: The Rev. Ellen Louise Tillotson, the rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Torrington, Conn., and Dr. Frank Miller Turner, the John Hay Whitney Professor of History at Yale University, were married yesterday at Trinity on the Green Episcopal Church in New Haven. The Rev. Andrew Fiddler, the church's rector, officiated, and the Rev. Tacy French, an American Baptist minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: August 1-7; China's Missile Test
description: Nothing makes China go ballistic as much as moves by Taiwan that look like a step away from Beijing's goal of reunification. China tested a new long-range missile that has the capability of reaching America. The launch comes in the middle of a crisis over Taiwan that started last month when President Lee Teng-hui asserted that his country will now only talk with China on the basis of ''special state-to-state relations.'' The test occurred the same day Beijing excoriated Washington for selling military equipment to Taiwan. SETH FAISON

title: Our Towns; Neighborhood Is Superseded By Superstore
description: TO make way for the New York region's third Ikea furniture superstore, this city has officially declared a patchwork of working-class homes and mom-and-pop factories ''blighted,'' fit for no better fate than the crunching bulldozers of urban renewal. But go tell Ruth McGruder that her neighborhood is blighted and she'll give you a tart piece of her mind.

title: Musical Works in Progress
description: IT is a tryout for musicals and a tryout for audiences, too.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Andrew J. Filipowski, the software entrepreneur, misstated the month that one of his companies, Platinum Technology International, was acquired by Computer Associates. The deal was completed in June, not last month.

title: Habitats/21 West Street in Lower Manhattan; A Temporary Apartment, With Furniture to Match
description: EVERYWHERE, there is evidence of a life being lived. A futon has been crammed into the home office, used for a while by a pilot friend who was getting divorced. Under the desk sits a case of diet soda, and by the door are some bottles of whisky, left over from a Super Bowl party. Stacks of books delineate a twisting pathway to the desk chair.

title: Celebrating an Architect, Hailing an Artist
description: ARCHITECTS who consider themselves artists are understandably delighted when their work is featured in museums, but Richard Meier, the designer of the Getty Center in Los Angeles, has special reason to feel honored. The Musee du Jeu de Paume in Paris has chosen Mr. Meier, an American, as the subject of its first-ever architectural exhibition. And in doing so, it has set out to reinforce the notion that architecture is art.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Shot in Face While Sitting in Car Near Shop
description: An off-duty police officer was shot in the face yesterday morning in Queens and then drove to a station house to report what had happened, the police said.

title: Prospering in Deco, Not Disco
description: THE Rubell family, whose most famous member Steve Rubell, co-founder of Studio 54 -- proved that hotels could become as fashionable as discotheques, still speak of their trade as more art than business. Since selling his shares in Manhattan hotels like the Royalton, the Paramount and Morgans after his death in 1989 and shipping their money, and themselves, south, the Rubells have become leaders in restoring Art Deco hotels here -- hotels as trendy as those back in New York.

description: If all goes as planned, on Sept. 22, John Martini Sr. will be strapped to a gurney in the Capital Sentence Unit at New Jersey State Prison in Trenton, wheeled into the execution chamber and put to death by lethal injection.

description: On two recent days at La Guardia Airport, the eight parking spots reserved for disabled drivers at the front of the main garage were frequently taken by limousines and car-service sedans displaying handicapped parking permits.

title: Black Mothers' Mortality Rate Under Scrutiny
description: Eight months pregnant, Deborah Edwards smoothed a thin hospital gown over her bulging belly, nibbled at a graham cracker and ticked off the reasons she had spent a week confined to the maternity ward of George Washington University Hospital here, a month before her baby is due.

title: Sports of The Times; Going, Going, Gone! Now, the Comeback
description: THE sports highlights came on, featuring Mark McGwire reaching another statistical milestone and Darryl Strawberry making another sobering comeback. McGwire hit his 500th home run Thursday night, an achievement Strawberry would have long since reached had he not become baseball's home office for waste.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about a proposal to expand Middle School 141 in Riverdale and build a new middle school in Marble Hill referred incorrectly to the district represented by Councilman Jose Rivera. It does not include Marble Hill.

title: Weeklies' Publisher Sees Papers as a Force
description: WHILE newspaper circulation remains static around the United States, three weeklies in the county published by Deborah G. White -- The Scarsdale Inquirer, The Rivertowns Enterprise and The Record-Review -- are enjoying an increase in readership. And all three recently received awards from the New York Press Association -- one, The Record-Review, was named the best community newspaper in the state.

title: 'The Psychs' of August Are Back for Summer Retreats on Cape Cod
description: Banish any image of a Shrinkland where the streets are peopled by bearded, strategically taciturn men and motherly but penetrating women all asking each other, ''And how did that make you feel?''

title: Eddie Was Murdered. Sam's Doing 70 Years. But Who Is to Blame?
description: DOLORES MANZIE stood up, dazed, as the pedophile accused of seducing her son was led from the courtroom. On this July afternoon, the Superior Court judge had just dismissed all but two minor charges against the defendant, Stephen P. Simmons, for lack of evidence. Leaning limply against a bench in the Monmouth County courtroom, Mrs. Manzie said, ''We'd be better off if we'd done nothing.''

title: A Country Station Worth a Stop
description: THE train has not stopped at the Water Mill railroad station for decades, and the quaint country station house has been a dining destination for the last 15 years. It was first called the Station at Water Mill, but later owners gave it a French spin and changed its name to the Station Bistro. This summer brought more changes. The name is now the Station, and the restaurant says it is ''celebrating Mediterranean cuisine.''

title: As a Feminist, a King; as a Ballerina, a Klutz
description: THE movie marquee in the Los Angeles County Museum of Art says, ''Now Showing: Eleanor Antin.'' Beneath it are a few stills of Ms. Antin's most famous roles, plus a free-standing cutout of her in full ballerina regalia. If you can't find Eleanor Antin in your movie guide, try the deadpan dictionary, the feminist gazette, the lexicon of subversive notions or, better still, the catalogue named after her by Howard N. Fox, curator of ''Eleanor Antin,'' the first retrospective of 30 years of this artist's work (through Aug. 23). A lot of this show stars Ms. Antin on video as the marquee promises, and even more of it is theatrical in a quirky way, fleshing out the female role in the human comedy with laughter and cultural smarts and a deep curtsy to despair.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Westchester Briefs column on July 25 about a proposed county contract for middle managers referred incorrectly to the cost. The contract would not necessarily raise taxes $8.8 million over six years; the money could be raised by other means.

title: Beyond the Sock Market
description: WOMEN all over New York are still searching for Roberto Vascon. In the early 90's, his richly colored handmade purses attracted a cultlike following around the city, especially on the Upper West Side. But high rents and construction forced him to close his flagship Columbus Avenue store in 1995, and a self-service laundry took over the space.

title: The Business of War in Africa
description: In many African nations, the natural resources that should be used to feed and educate people are instead being used to destroy them. The Government and guerrillas in Angola, for example, are selling the country's oil and diamonds to buy weapons and pay soldiers in a 30-year civil war that has made the nation perhaps the most miserable in the world. In Congo and Sierra Leone as well, natural wealth is fueling catastrophic conflict. But no warring party can make an arms deal alone. Outside nations and companies are also profiting. They should be helping instead to limit the ability of African warlords to sell a country's patrimony and to block the flow of weapons to Africa's conflicts.

title: Old-Style German Bakery Closes, and So Does an Era
description: Fifty years ago, when East 86th Street was known as Sauerkraut Boulevard, there were German bakeries aplenty as well as pastry counters in most of Yorkville's delicatessens and restaurants.

The results, announced in May, followed too many other tests with unhappy results, including one in which American eighth graders ranked below South Korea, the Czech Republic and two dozen other countries in math and science performance.

title: The Nation: Standing Pat; Compromise Takes a Holiday
description: CONGRESS went home for the August recess late last week with little to show for itself beyond an arsenal of political sound bites stockpiled to serve as campaign themes for a high-stakes election that is still more than a year away.

title: Steve Martin, In Revision
description: Steve Martin tells a joke. It's a painful moment. This joke arrives so unexpectedly -- and in the middle of a lunch that, while cordial, has hardly been a picnic -- that it's almost inexplicable. He is a forbidding man, a man without a molecule out of place, a person capable of composure even when exhausted. Martin got off a plane this morning from Las Vegas, where he was advising a casino interested in creating a new sort of circus extravaganza. And now he sits almost gloomily at the Four Seasons in Beverly Hills, fully composed save for a repeated nervous gesture: quick, furtive swipes of Chapstick over his lips. Never mind the joke itself, something about the sex act. Let's just note that the joke triggers an awkward silence. It's the one time when he seems to be doing what's expected of him instead of what he wants.

title: Gore Still Sees Discrimination, But Also Progress for Blacks
description: Vice President Al Gore, wooing blacks and liberals at a conference organized by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, said today that America had ''not openly acknowledged'' its legacy of discrimination, especially ''the pain of slavery.''

title: Eyes of Texas Are on a Ranch Bush Wants
description: In any other year, the news that the Governor was shopping for a weekend getaway ranch would not have amounted to much of a story. But when word leaked out that Gov. George W. Bush was negotiating for a 1,550-acre spread in central Texas, it prompted an obvious, if tantalizing, question:

title: Viola Sheely, 41, Dancer Praised for Range

title: Misha and Trisha, Talking Dance
description: THE dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov and the dancer-choreographer Trisha Brown have a lifetime of dance in common, though his has been in classical and only lately in modern, while hers has been wholly in modern. They performed together in Ms. Brown's 1996 duet, ''You Can See Us.'' Since then, among many projects, Ms. Brown, 62, has directed an opera, Monteverdi's ''Orfeo,'' produced a book of drawings and presented the premiere of her latest piece, ''Five Part Weather Invention,'' a collaboration with the composer-trumpeter Dave Douglas and the artist Terry Winters, at Jacob's Pillow. She will perform in her own work at Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Friday.

title: Burned by Gold? Consider a Hedger
description: ANGLOGOLD LTD. produces about 10 percent of the world's gold, but the yellow metal may not be its most valuable asset.

In her 20's, while teaching the fourth grade in Chappaqua, N.Y., she was so busy coming up with songs, stories and lessons for her students that she failed to notice that she had practically no love life.

title: A City's Artists on the Cusp Between the Past and the Future
description: ALTHOUGH Paterson's art scene ranks with the well-publicized ones of Montclair and Jersey City, it has little notoriety. One reason is that its existence has never been tangibly demonstrated. Millennium-watchers may see the ''Eclectic Selections: Art in Paterson at the End of the 20th Century,'' at the Paterson Museum, as something of an 11th-hour revelation, but it is also laying a foundation to build on.

title: Correspondence/South Africa and Guns; Armed and Fashionable In Johannesburg
description: NOT long ago, outside the razor-wire-topped fence around our house here, I drove past a man in street clothes with a large pistol tucked in the leather holster at his waist. After a second, I decided he must be a security guard. But I looked at that gun and scoffed. What was he going to do with such a puny gun, and holstered besides? Up the street was a guard pacing a driveway with a pump-action shotgun. Now that might do some good.

title: Where Nora Joyce Fell For a Talented Nobody

title: A Monumental Film Suddenly Appears Brighter
description: FREQUENTLY called one of the ''best films of all time,'' Jean Renoir's ''Grand Illusion'' (''La Grande Illusion''), released in 1937, can be something of a surprise. Not that there is any particular reason to dispute the ranking, but there is a simplicity, if that's the word, and a kind of sprightly directness that can be startling in a work deemed so towering.

title: People's Choice Awards
description: In 1922, Walter Lippmann, already well on his way to establishing himself as journalism's pre-eminent mandarin, published his book ''Public Opinion,'' which asserted that the general populace was too fickle and too easily manipulated to decide weighty public questions. Instead, Lippmann wrote, these ought to be handled by ''a specialized class'' of experts working closely with top Government officials. Today, such a notion of good government sounds haughty and simplistic. But something very like Lippmann's construct was adopted, just a few years later, by an organization leading the budding consumer movement. This time, the mandarin approach was a great success.

title: Wetland Protection
description: The Board of Legislators has unanimously endorsed a resolution calling on the New York District of the United States Army Corps of Engineers to help safeguard wetlands by prohibiting work permits being issued on small properties in the New York City watershed.

Colored trousers and madras plaids were a 1950's favorite.

We rented a seven-passenger van, to move a chunk of our family and its luggage at once. The price was stiff. With an extra-driver charge, license and battery surcharges, and taxes on top, it came to $451 for a week. But if we had purchased Avis's collision damage waiver, which we did not because we were covered otherwise, it would have cost $18.99 a day extra, and our total would have come to $592.

She was active in fund-raising and teaching about the Holocaust. Survived by her sons, Harold and Herbert and daughter-in-law Harriet, grandchildren Eric and Sara Juli; also survived by her husband Jack Cohen. Contributions in Paula's memory may be made to a charity of your choice. Services today 12 noon at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: TELEVISION/RADIO; Reclaiming a Little of a Lost Silent Masterpiece
description: ERICH VON STROHEIM never fully recovered from the mutilation of ''Greed.'' The director's cut of his 1924 silent masterpiece ran nine and a half hours, but the studio executive Irving Thalberg scissored it to two hours and fifteen minutes. Stroheim had been successful as an actor (mostly playing nasty, bootheel-clicking huns) and as a director (with sophisticated classics like ''Foolish Wives'' and ''The Wedding March''), but the confrontation with Thalberg left him a broken man.

title: Italian Airline Starts New York Service
description: Few Americans are likely to have heard of AirEurope, even though the Italian airline is almost 10 years old. But it may soon lose its anonymity, now that it has begun six flights a week between New York and Venice and Pisa. To help spread the word, it is offering a round-trip fare of $425 between Kennedy International Airport in New York and either Italian city through next month. Tickets must be purchased by Aug. 30 and other restrictions apply.

description: The drought in New Jersey has turned brush into kindling along roads and railroad lines, and in forests and parks, as a surge in unusually large brush fires has caused extensive traffic and rail delays and further diminished the state's dwindling water supply.

title: August 1-7; Film Fetches $16 Million
description: A divided Federal arbitration panel decided that the Government must pay the heirs of Abraham Zapruder $16 million for his film of President John F. Kennedy's assassination. The award, about halfway between the $30 million sought by the family and the $1 million offered by the Justice Department, was the highest price ever paid for any American historical artifact.

title: Bridging a Chasm In the Modern Canon
description: ALTHOUGH he is best known as Stravinsky's Boswell, collaborator and aide-de-camp, Robert Craft, along with Leonard Bernstein and John Cage, has been one of the main shapers of American musical taste in the second half of the 20th century. Even before he met Stravinsky in 1948, Mr. Craft decided that Stravinsky and Schoenberg, living in separate worlds just a few miles from each other in Los Angeles, had more in common than anyone had imagined. While most musicians of the time felt that they had to choose sides, Mr. Craft championed both masters as the supreme composers of the century.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-8-99; A Shock to The System
description: Ever since the first studies were published linking strong electromagnetic fields with serious health problems, the public image of power plants has been on a downward trajectory -- from symbols of modernity and convenience to symbols of death and destruction. Informed citizens across the land undertook righteous protests at the local electrical substation, motivated by fear for their children's health, not to mention their own property values.

title: Schoenberg's Cool Eye For the Erotic
description: STANLEY KUBRICK'S ''Eyes Wide Shut'' has arrived just in time to illuminate the music of Arnold Schoenberg, the focus of the Bard Music Festival over the next two weekends. For its 10th season, the festival at Bard College, in Annandale-on Hudson, N.Y., is bringing all its accustomed interdisciplinary tools to bear on a composer who, nearly 50 years after his death, remains the most angst-inspiring emblem of musical modernism. Between concerts, the world's leading Schoenberg scholars will discuss the cultural, historical and political aspects of the music.

title: Inclusive America, Under Attack
description: Of all the triumphs that have marked this as America's century -- breathtaking advances in science and technology, the democratization of wealth and dispersal of political power in ways hardly imaginable in 1899 -- none is more inspiring, if incomplete, than our pursuit of racial justice. The milestones include Theodore Roosevelt's inviting Booker T. Washington to dine at the White House, Harry Truman's desegregating the armed forces, Dwight Eisenhower's using Federal troops to integrate Little Rock's Central High School and Lyndon Johnson's electrifying the nation by standing before Congress in 1965 and declaring, ''We shall overcome.''

title: Talk About Thank You's. . . .
description: A postscript on the Talk magazine debut party last week: Lavish as it was, it relied heavily on what could be called television game show financing, giving plugs and getting goods. ''Thank you Donna Karan for making this dress and then I had to pull myself into it,'' said Tina Brown in a speech, referring to her velvet and silk devore crystal-accented dress from Ms. Karan, a friend of Ms. Brown's and a prominent Talk advertiser. Ronald A. Galotti, the publisher, thanked Robert Mondavi for the wine, Evian for the bottled water and Tommy Mottola of Sony for the music.

title: In the Region /Westchester; High Prices, Low Inventory Slow Home Sales a Bit
description: AFTER several years of record sales for residential properties in the county, the pace seems to have slowed somewhat in this year's second quarter, primarily because of rising prices of single-family homes and a lack of inventory.

title: Britain's Old-Fashioned Pubs Are Undergoing a Makeover
description: Four years ago, when Amanda Rimmer took over as landlady at the Bull and Last in north London, it was, she said, ''a really run-down pub with a bit of a reputation'' as a rough sort of spot. The decor was dowdy. Brawls were not unknown. People came to drink and, well, drink. So she set about making it over.
