description: The top Presidential candidates are courting Latino voters by speaking their language -- or at least trying to. A panel of renowned linguists rates their performances in two recent speeches.

title: Style; Compound Interest
description: At first glance, the white-shingled buildings shown here look as if they had settled into their lush green surroundings long ago. Only upon closer inspection can you see that while some of the structures are indeed very old, others are new. They owe their seamless integration to Steven Harris, a New York-based architect whose salient stylistic trait is that he has none. Not that he doesn't have Style; he just doesn't have a style.

title: Briggs-Botha Ends in Draw
description: In the end, Shannon Briggs was bleeding from a cut above his left eye and from a nasty cut on his right ear, and Francois Botha had a large purple bruise on his forehead and a small cut under his right eye. But the way they looked in their heavyweight fight in Atlantic City last night wasn't nearly as ugly as the judges' decision following the 10-round bout.

title: The Precarious Triumph of Human Rights
description: The age of human rights is upon us. This spring, the United States fought a war in the Balkans in the name of human rights and humanitarian imperatives -- the first war in recent memory, as President Clinton has said, waged in the name of values rather than strategic interests. Similar sentiments have been voiced by America's allies in Europe. Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has been campaigning for ''a new internationalism based on values and the rule of law.'' In these post-Communist, post-modern times, human rights seems to have become the dominant moral narrative for thinking about world affairs.

title: The Body, Ever the Subject, Never Out Of Style
description: WHEN the Whitney Museum of American Art dropped ''The Great American Nude'' from its schedule, the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield picked it up, renaming it ''The Nude in Contemporary Art.'' (One advantage the Aldrich had over the Whitney is that it can show art from outside the Americas.)

title: A Disney Dissenter Shuns Song and Dance
description: ONCE upon a time, 21 years ago, there existed at the Walt Disney Studio in Burbank, Calif., a couple of rooms called ''The Rats' Nest.'' In them dwelled young, idealistic and ambitious animators -- a restless faction unhappy with the bland animated features Disney was producing in those days.

title: Gifted and Prolific yet Neglected

Next Sunday, the Lucerne Festival will perform Schoeck's one-act opera ''Penthesilea.'' Yet outside his native land, Schoeck's music is little known, performed infrequently in Europe and rarely in the United States.

title: August 1-7; Ruling Creates Logjam In the Pacific Northwest
description: Various species of snails, salamanders and the red tree vole, a small rodent, could take on the importance of the famed northern spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest's continuing battle over logging. The same Federal judge who once halted logging in the old-growth forests in the Pacific Northwest to protect the owl ruled that two Federal agencies had failed to insure the monitoring and protection of 77 other species. William L. Dwyer of the Federal District Court in Seattle blocked nine major logging deals and threatened to hold up more than 100 others. Hailing the decision, environmental groups said Judge Dwyer had stopped the agencies from ''putting logging activities ahead of their responsibilities to protect wildlife, fish, clean water and old-growth forests.''

title: Prodigy's Return
description: Sometime last winter, while I was preparing to give a piano recital in New York, my teacher, Seymour Bernstein, handed me an application for a new piano competition. It was to be held late the following spring in Fort Worth, and it was for amateurs. Would I like to participate, Seymour asked? I was focused on the recital. My first child was about to be born. The competition was months away. I agreed to enter it without really thinking. I didn't realize at the time that it would cause me, during the course of several ulcer-inducing days in June, to reflect on the entire course of my life.

title: Up the St. Croix, With a Paddle
description: MY friend Nick paddled quietly while I stared at the river bottom through the ripples under the bow. Long yellow river grass stretched out and waved with the current. We were in a canoe on the St. Croix River at the easternmost edge of New England. To our right was Maine, to our left, New Brunswick, Canada. Stone cairns in the river marked the international boundary. The river curved south toward the Bay of Fundy. Osprey dived for fish. A bald eagle perched in the top of a tree watched us float by, no sound but Nick's paddle dipping in the water.

title: Corrections

title: The Ethicist
description: Randy Cohen's answer to a query about a bank overcredit astounded me (July 18). The reason the money cannot be used, Cohen argued, is that it's known to whom the money belonged, unlike simply finding a bag of cash on the ground. That seems right to me. But why not pick an example that's analogous to the situation: what if I found a bag of money with John's name on it, but John refused to take it back? I spent hours knocking on his door, trying to leave the money with him, but he simply did not respond to my efforts? Would I not also ''eventually'' have the right to spend the money? It is hard to see why not. (Indeed, would I have an obligation to keep the money safe?) In any case, if I did spend the money we would surely want to distinguish that from ''theft.''

title: August 1-7; Gun Toll in Dollars
description: Most discussion about gun violence focuses on the human toll. But a new study shows that when guns are fired, everyone gets hit -- in the wallet. It costs $2.3 billion a year to treat America's gunshot wounds, said a study by a group of economists that appeared in The Journal of the American Medical Association. Nearly half that cost is picked up by taxpayers. ''It is really everybody's problem,'' said the study's chief author, Dr. Philip J. Cook of Duke University. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Kathryn Murray Dies at 92; Coaxed Many to 'Try Dancing'
description: Kathryn Murray, the hostess of ''The Arthur Murray Party,'' which used comedy and celebrity to sell ballroom dancing to the masses in television's infancy, died on Friday at her home in Honolulu. She was 92.

title: Downsized 'Pimpernel' Restyles Itself for Broadway Reopening
description: RON BOHMER mused about life's ironies as Ruth Pongstaphone, a makeup artist, shaped a Romanesque nose on his fine-featured face. Mr. Bohmer, who will play the title character when ''The Scarlet Pimpernel'' reopens on Broadway on Sept. 10, was preparing for a dress rehearsal at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College here. Not that the show ever played for an audience in the Pepsico Theater, where actors, directors and crew recently assembled for a run-through. Rather, the theater was being used to scale down ''Pimpernel'' from its proportions at the Minskoff Theater, where it closed last May (to make room for ''Saturday Night Fever''), to the smaller Neil Simon Theater.

title: A Life of Performing and Teaching
description: IN the 1930's, long before televisions appeared in the modest living rooms of West Philadelphia, Parthenia Milner and her two older sisters furnished their own evening's entertainment by reading aloud from a well-worn and much loved volume of poetry given to them by their mother. Turning the frayed pages, the daughters of Mattie Byrd Milner, a schoolteacher from Athens, Ga., recited the verses in impassioned voices, transforming quiet nights in their mostly black urban neighborhood into gala family affairs.

title: Failing Dictator
description: Ideal casting saved CONQUEST (1937) from being a dull historical drama. A superb portrayal of Napoleon Bonaparte by Charles Boyer (above, with Greta Garbo) sustains the arrogance of a man used to having his way, and Garbo brings great warmth to her role as the Polish countess who gave up everything to accompany the exiled French Emperor. The romance is further enhanced by the harsh opening, when the Warsaw estate of the countess and her husband (Henry Stephenson) is taken over by the French General and his henchmen. The final scenes between the co-stars are played with such conviction and style that the story becomes an authoritative, moving drama - Wednesday at 6 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies.

title: A Bassist Who Is No Mean Tenor

Not so Jim Ferguson, whose first album, ''Not Just Another Pretty Bass,'' is the most distinctive recording debut since Diana Krall came along four years ago with ''Only Trust Your Heart.'' Mr. Ferguson, who grew up in South Carolina, is a balladeer with a high, sweet tenor voice whose accent is as Southern as the smell of fresh-cut mint on a hot summer day; though he can swing hard, he prefers to amble lazily through wistful songs like ''I Get Along Without You Very Well'' and ''Early Autumn,'' singing in the pensive manner of a man who has spent his share of sleepless nights wondering what might have been.

title: Ernest Hemingway's War Wounds

The fact that he created well in his earlier years despite alcohol and depression is testimony to the fact that he was a genius, and that alcoholism, as we now know, is a progressive and deadly disease.

title: Bombing Elephants
description: Does anyone really need another Vietnam War novel? Probably not. But few novels in any genre are as lucid, or as memorably spooky, as Jerome Gold's new book, SERGEANT DICKINSON (Soho, $20); it belongs on the high, narrow shelf of first-rate fiction about battlefield experience. The novel's laconic narrator is Ray Dickinson, a radioman with a Special Forces unit in the Central Highlands of Vietnam. His camp is encircled by the North Vietnamese Army, and a full-scale assault is expected any day. What little information Dickinson can glean about the war, or about his unit's hope for reinforcements, arrives over his radio, and much of what he pulls in sounds like madness. (''Plei Mrong reports seeing an elephant bombed and strafed by six sorties of American aircraft, wants to know what that was about.'') All around him, Dickinson sees madness, too: some American ground troops, for example, have begun to shoot at their own planes -- they're that envious of ''men who could just fly away from it all.'' Gold, who served in Vietnam as a Special Forces sergeant, writes spare and elegant prose that belies the brutality and the claustrophia he evokes here. His slim novel is a carefully chosen assortment of details and impressions; he expertly dismantles the myth -- dear to civilians as well as to soldiers -- that if you do everything right no harm will come to you.'' Dwight Garner

title: Sharper Images
description: The daguerreotype, a photographic image made on a small, highly polished silvered copper plate, was the first popular form of photography. The process was invented, patented and disseminated in Europe and exported to the United States in 1839. Before long Americans improved the new technology by eliminating the need for the deadeningly long exposure times, and daguerreotype portrait studios spread and prospered across the country. AMERICA AND THE DAGUERREOTYPE (University of Iowa, paper, $37.95), a generously illustrated collection of essays, portrays photography as both the reflection and the builder of 19th-century America's self-image. The book focuses for the most part on portraiture, starting with an essay by its editor, John Wood, on the power of the face to inspire and captivate. Wood, a professor of English at McNeese State University in Louisiana, argues strongly for the importance of daguerreotype art and ascribes great potency, sexual and esthetic, to this fragile and miniature photographic form. Two hundred handsome reproductions, 28 in color, show images not often seen in daguerreotypes -- cats, cattle, sleeping children, gold miners, towns, landscapes and even a scalp photographed in St. Paul. Nudes, still lifes and landscapes by contemporary artists are also included. Daguerreotype photography, reputed to have produced some 30 million images in the United States between 1840 and 1860, became obsolete as soon as photography advanced to the point where multiple images could be made. Wood would argue that this is America's loss. Rosemary Ranck

These slices are not the ususal slices; made without cheese, they are fragrant with gresh herbs, vegetables and extra-virgin olive oil. And they're served cold, the way Italian children eat them for breakfast.

Overnight the American and his Guardian Bank and Trust Company became the worst nightmare of the British protectorate's bankers. The Caymans are the world's fifth largest financial center because of strict confidentiality laws, no taxation and a determined non-cooperation with American tax probers.

George Pataki and the New York Legislature tied the record for the latest budget in Albany's history, the $73.3 billion package negotiated last week is cause for at least modest celebration. The Legislature resisted the urge to spend last year's $1.8 billion surplus, saving it instead to cover the cost of previously enacted tax cuts. title: Trying a Fairer Way
description: When reserving a tee time at public golf courses, it's the short game that counts. That is, those who can get through to the automated phone reservation system in the shortest time after the lines open get the coveted early morning times. Bergen County's four courses have 237 total tee times a day and 4,500 daily calls, says Kevin Purcell, the county golf administrator. That means the winners have fast fingers -- but mainly they own a computerized speed dialer programmed to provide the right information in the right order. To foil the speed dialers, the county is following other public systems in upgrading its reservations software: starting Oct. 1, callers will get a time randomly distributed within a three-hour period, rather than first call, first served. The county is also considering requiring dialers to provide the Social Security numbers of all members of their golfing groups, to keep each player in a foursome calling to see who gets the best time. But what would really help, says Mr. Purcell, is a lot more golf courses. The county is considering adding two or even three, he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESSNER, MICHAEL
description: RESSNER-Michael. Of Hewlett Neck, N.Y, August 4th. Dearest, devoted sweetheart and husband of Natalie (Godnick). Adoring father and special friend to John Walter Ressner and dear father-in-law of Laura Bemben. Loving brotherin-law of Enid and Bud Van Raalte, Bob Godnick. Cherished uncle of Dr. Polly Van Raalte, Susan and Dr. Elliott Hershman; fun loving grand uncle to Todd and Danny Hershman. Extraordinarily gifted painter and musician. Graduate of Pratt Institute. Board of Directors American Institute of Architects, New York Chapter, Associate Member and winner of their Harry B. Rutkins Memorial Award for Service to the Profession. Creator of the Rocky Jones, Space Ranger TV and Comic Book series. Former Deputy Mayor, trustee, past and present Road Commissioner of the Village of Hewlett Neck. Founder and President of the Barr Road Civic Association, he was instrumental in saving 165 acres of Borman's Island in Hewlett Bay at the foot of Barr Road, as a wildlife sanctuary in perpetuity. Member of the Board of Directors, Easter Seals of New York. Marketing Director, Ysrael A. Seinuk, P.C. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to the New York Foundation for Architecture (AIA NY Chapter), 200 Lexington Avenue, NY, NY 10016, would be appreciated, as an annual prize will be established in his name. Funeral services Sunday, August 8, 11AM Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Reception at home immediately following. ''This above all: to thine own self be true. And it must follow, as the night the day, Thou canst not then be false to any man.''

title: An Empty Paradise

title: Battling the Return of an Unloved City Bus Depot
description: When the 100th Street bus depot, once the bustling home of 150 city buses, closed last year, its neighbors quickly grew used to the newfound calm. ''This block became a whole new neighborhood,'' said Albert Baime, who lives across the street on Lexington Avenue. He does not miss the old days. ''You could smell the bus fumes coming through your window,'' he said, ''and they made noise at all hours of the night.''

title: Its How You Play the Game
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Compressed Data; London Is Logging On To Cybercafe Venture
description: Intently pecking away at a keyboard, Jon Woolfson tried to screen out more than 400 other Internet surfers who packed Easyeverything, the new super-cybercafe in London's Victoria district that looks more like a scene from Star Trek than anything from this galaxy.

title: Secret Videotapes Unnerve Athletes
description: Unauthorized videotapes of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of naked male athletes in the locker rooms of more than 50 universities are being produced, sold and distributed on sexually oriented sites on the World Wide Web, according to a lawyer representing 200 of the men who were taped.

title: Jerry Yulsman, 75, Novelist Who Imagined World Without Nazis
description: Jerry Yulsman, a tail gunner on World War II bomber flights who later wrote a ''what if'' novel in which Hitler is killed in 1913, died on Friday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 75 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Dramatic Special Effects, Courtesy of Nature
description: John Copley, who directed the new production of Mozart's ''Idomeneo'' for the Santa Fe Opera that opened last month, had a powerful ally for Thursday night's performance: Mother Nature.

title: At Magazines, the Art of Stirring Debate Seems Lost
description: Willie Morris, the editor of Harper's Magazine from 1967 to 1971, was both back-porch storyteller and urban intellectual, a Rhodes Scholar who was at home sipping tea in the Waldorf-Astoria and slugging back bourbon in the bars of Jackson, Miss. As a young editor during the late 1960's, he helped oversee an especially provocative period in American journalism, publishing dozens of articles that reflected the energy and turmoil of the era and, more importantly, got people talking and thinking.

title: Brosius' Focus Is Also on Father
description: The commercial flight the Yankees were scheduled to take to Oakland tonight was delayed, so most of the players sat and ate and watched a movie -- ''There's Something About Mary'' -- in the visitors' clubhouse here. Derek Jeter and Jorge Posada and others lounged on the couch and laughed.

title: The Grand Manner (Curls and Feathers Flying)
description: ''It's just like a rock concert,'' a dance fan said with a happy sigh, as he surveyed the crowd that jammed the Damrosch Park Band Shell, standing several layers deep at its sides and back, on Saturday night for the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. And the audience, estimated by a festival official at 7,000 to 8,000, cheered with something near the fervor of attendees at a rock concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOCKTON, HENRY HAINES
description: STOCKTON-Henry Haines. 83, of Spring Lake, NJ, died Friday at home. Retired sales executive, Equitable Life Insurance. A lifelong resident of New York and New Jersey, Mr. Stockton was an avid tennis supporter and the first American national player to wear shorts. Founder of the Lawrenceville School Umpires Association, he also umpired numerous tournaments including Davis Cup matches. Mr. Stockton was a direct descendent of Richard Stockton, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. He was a greatgreat-grandson of Commodore Robert Field Stockton, who as a member of the U.S. Navy was instrumental in establishing civil government over California. His great-grandfather, John Potter Stockton, was appointed U.S. Minister to Rome by President Buchanan. His grandfather, Richard Stockton, served at Rotterdam and thereafter as Charge d'Affaires at the Hague. Surviving are his wife Janet M. Stockton of Spring Lake Heights; a son, Robert Potter Stockton of Spring Lake, NJ, and a daughter, Lois Stockton Rice of Reston, VA; stepchildren Sharon Prudhomme of Lancaster, PA, and Wayne Merkel of Hackettstown, NJ; and grandchildren Sara Gonzalez, Nicolas Gonzalez, Jason Merkel and Elizabeth Stockton. Visitation 10-10:30 AM, Tuesday, First Presbyterian Church of Manasquan. Funeral services 11 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to hospice or charity of your choice.

title: At Home Abroad; South African Reality
description: If anyone can see South Africa plain, without romance or sourness, it is Dr. Mamphela Ramphele. She is the vice chancellor of the University of Cape Town, the first woman and the first black to head that great institution, and she is famously outspoken. So when I asked her how she thought the new South Africa was doing, her answer had an impact.

title: The Tarnished Legacy of Lenny Bruce
description: Lenny Bruce's sad life and short career are by now solidly entrenched in legend. Having won audiences by mocking the hypocrisy of official attitudes toward obscenity, this comedian suffered the revenge of the law and succumbed to his own worst temptations. He died in 1966 of a drug overdose. His story, as told in ''Lenny Bruce: Swear to Tell the Truth,'' Robert B. Weide's appreciative documentary, makes it easy to understand his appeal yet raises questions over the role of social critic with which he was invested.

title: As Rosalind Grows, So Does an Actress
description: For a moment it looks like Oscar night all over again. There she is in a Grace Kelly ball gown, as pale and luminous as a moonbeam. Yes, it's unmistakably the same swan-necked Gwyneth Paltrow who accepted the Academy Award for best actress for ''Shakespeare in Love'' earlier this year. Yet there's something not quite right about the picture.

title: Internet Sale of Nazi Books in Germany Assailed
description: Contending that the two largest on-line booksellers are violating German laws against the distribution of hate literature, the Simon Wiesenthal Center has called on Barnesandnoble.com and Amazon.com to stop selling books like ''Mein Kampf'' to customers in Germany.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COREY, MARGARET BETH
description: COREY-Margaret Beth. September 25, 1943 to August 9, 1997. Your favorite nephew, Amedeo, loves you and says your name. We miss you everyday. Corey/Cohen and Berman/Barosin

title: At Camp for Migrants, The Living Isn't Easy
description: They call it Camp Somerset, and each July it springs to life, filling with 700 people. But despite the pickup soccer game each evening, it should not be mistaken for a summer camp.

title: Deutsche Bank Part of Group Seeking to Buy Cable Network
description: Deutsche Bank A. G., the world's largest bank, said today that it and Vereins-und Westbank planned to bid for part of Deutsche Telekom A. G.'s cable television network, as the bank tries to create a large cable company it can sell to investors.

title: Investigator Of Microsoft Unrelenting In His Pursuit
description: The marquee stars of the Government's antitrust assault on the Microsoft Corporation have been David Boies, the trial lawyer who proved a master at catching Microsoft witnesses off-guard, and Joel I. Klein, the chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division.

title: The Lethal Icon That Is Turning Upon Its Worshipers
description: The people are at least as scary as the weapons in ''Gun Nation,'' an exhibition by the British photographer Zed Nelson currently at Newseum/NY, a photojournalism gallery in Manhattan (and at a Newseum in Arlington, Va.).

title: Jets' Ferguson: Outsider to Man in Middle
description: The Jets' new 3-4 defense will be unveiled when they open their exhibition season Saturday night in Green Bay, completing a transition begun last year from the 4-3.

title: Star-Struck Girls and Mexican School for Scandal
description: Karina Yapor's parents fight back tears as they recall how their daughter left home when she was 12, carrying her Bible and her school bag, to begin music lessons at a boarding school run by the manager of Gloria Trevi, Mexico's most famous rock star.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHICK, NINA
description: SCHICK-Nina. Age 90 of East Hampton, New York died on July 27th, 1999. Mrs. Schick trained as an artist in Paris and London, and studied with Serge Soudekine in New York. In 1947 she founded the Green Thumb Flowers Inc., which was a leading floral designer in New York for the next thirty years, furnishing flowers for many elite social events and the homes of the leading hostesses of the day. After selling the Green Thumb in 1980, Mrs. Schick resumed painting and exhibited at the Benson and Clayton-Liberatore galleries on Long Island and in Paris, France. Her paintings hang in several notable collections. She leaves a beloved husband, Alexandre, two devoted children, Janine Luke and Anthony Evnin, two grandchildren, Luke and Timothy Evnin, and two great granddaughters, Alexandra and Caroline Evnin. Whoever came into her life was enriched by her kindness, generosity and joie de vivre.

title: Pesticides and Politics
description: In 1996, in a rare display of bipartisanship and without a single dissenting vote, Congress passed the Food Quality Protection Act, ordering the Environmental Protection Agency to review nearly 500 pesticides and ban or restrict those that posed hazards to human health. Then the real fight began -- translating a broad mandate into specific regulations that were almost certain to displease somebody. Last week, Carol Browner, the E.P.A. administrator, fired her first shot, announcing tough new restrictions on two widely used pesticides. Her decision may ultimately improve the safety of America's food supply, especially for children. But it was merely the opening round in what is sure to be a long, politically charged regulatory struggle. Her best hope in this fight is to be sure-footed in her science.

title: Judge Writes a Happy Ending To Brothers' Gambling Story
description: Frederick and Steven Barthelme, the two Mississippi writers who have shared an obsession for blackjack tables in the gambling palaces that straddle their state's Gulf Coast, now have a happy ending in the latest chapter of their personal lives.

title: Muzzling Dissent in Iran
description: Iran's conservative mullahs have silenced the student protest movement that surged through the streets of Teheran last month and are now moving against its leaders with arrests and threats of long imprisonment. By using the clerically controlled courts and police to intimidate supporters of Iran's reform-minded President, Mohammad Khatami, religious conservatives hope to strengthen their own authority within Iran's divided power structure and undermine reform candidates in parliamentary elections early next year.

description: Japan is pressing North Korea to scrap its plans to test-fire a new long-range ballistic missile, holding out a harsh economic threat: preventing Koreans living in Japan from sending home cash or goods -- estimated at $600 million to $1 billion a year. The loss of those remittances would have dire consequences for the Communist country whose economy is in shambles and whose people face dire food shortages and even famine. Members of the Liberal Democratic Party and the main opposition Democratic Party say they plan to submit the needed legislation, which has wide support, to the Parliament before it closes for summer recess on Friday.

title: In 15-Minute Rampage, Tornado Fells Trees and Rips Roofs on L.I.

It tore roofs and porches off several houses, flattened hundreds of trees, sank or damaged 20 boats, crushed a picturesque old windmill, left thousands of homes without power and terrified those who saw it.

title: Folk Music Flaunts A Wilder Persona
description: A lot of folkloric music from around the world is united by a single characteristic: it's a little slender. Whether it's the fault of too-genteel performers, too-curatorial producers or the specific cultural demands of the audience, the music can be prim in its awareness that popular culture has gone vulgar, overmodest in its striving for an esthetic of purity. There's no reason, however, why the folkloric can't be performed from the gut, with all the flirtatiousness and gamesmanship of the popular, and this is what Susana Baca did at Central Park Summerstage on Thursday night.

title: Teddy Roosevelt Betrayed

In attacking what they cherished -- not just their money but also their sense of entitlement and superiority -- he was challenging the class system, not the capitalist system, turning the upper-class world upside down. As far as these plutocrats were concerned, T. R. had betrayed his own class to the point of no return.

Mass Mutual, which merged in 1996 with the former Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, based in Hartford, now has more than 3,700 workers at its Springfield headquarters and more than 1,100 in Hartford. title: Woes of the Long Island Rail Road
description: The Long Island Rail Road operates the nation's largest suburban commuter line in a complicated and unforgiving environment. Nine of its branches on Long Island converge on one station at Jamaica, Queens. From there its trains must funnel into and out of Manhattan through four tunnels, two of them shared with Amtrak, and can linger only a few minutes at Amtrak's Penn Station before they must pull out to make room for the next train. These conditions and bottlenecks cause congestion that defies easy solution. But they should not be used as an excuse to be lethargic about simpler problems the L.I.R.R. can deal with to head off the growing disenchantment of riders.

title: Corrections

title: COMCAST TO DOUBLE STAKE IN JONES INTERCABLE
description: The Comcast Corporation, the No. 3 United States cable-television company, said yesterday that it would double its stake in Jones Intercable Inc. for about $840 million in stock, taking advantage of the recent decline of Jones's shares. Comcast, which in April bought 39 percent of Jones, will swap 1.4 shares of its class A common stock for each Jones class A and common share, or $50.31 each. Jones's class A shares had slumped about 26 percent after hitting a record high in May. The move comes as cable companies seek larger regional subscriber groups to cut costs, and as they offer more features like Internet access and phone services. Jones, based in Englewood, Colo., has about one million subscribers in 17 states. Its common stock rose $2.625 a share, to $47.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Milton Brumer, 97, Engineer For Famed New York Bridges
description: Milton Brumer, an engineer who managed the construction of such mighty bridges as the Verrazano-Narrows over New York Bay, the Throgs Neck over the East River, and the Walt Whitman over the Delaware, died Thursday at a hospital in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 97 and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRETTI, ANGELA
description: FERRETTI-Angela. On August 8, 1999. Beloved daughter of the late Giovanni and Columba, loving brother of August and the late Thomas, Lorence, and Marie. Also survived by ten nieces and nephews. Visitation is on Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9 at McLaughlin & Sons, 83rd St at Third Avenue. Mass of Christian burial on Thursday, at 10 AM, at St. Anselm's Church.

title: SUPERFOS GETS OFFER
description: The owner of the largest United States highway contractor, Ashland Inc., offered $636.7 million in cash for Superfos A.S., a Danish company with a large United States construction business. The offer by Ashland, based in Covington, Ky., tops an expected bid from CVC Capital Partners Ltd., Europe's largest management buyout company. The offer of $21 a share for Superfos represents a premium of 43 percent over Superfos's share price on July 13, when the Danish company said it expected a bid from the London-based CVC.

title: Numbers Tell Sad Story
description: METROSTARS

title: Sarajevo Is at Peace, but Its Old Zest Is Lost
description: The marks of war are nearly erased from Sarajevo. Sheets of glass have been fitted into the high-rises, and the shell holes have been plastered over.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO SLIDES. The dollar rose against the euro after President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia dismissed Prime Minister Sergei Stepashin and his Government. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0712, down from $1.0756.

title: Yet Another Giants Runner Is Hurt
description: The Giants' starting running back has been sidelined by injury.

title: Method Camping: Hunger, Fear, Stardom
description: MICHAEL WILLIAMS didn't know he was auditioning for a horror film when he went to the first casting call for ''The Blair Witch Project,'' this summer's phenomenon, but he did notice that it was paid work -- $1,000 for being scared to tears, literally, in a creepy stretch of the Maryland woods. He was just glad to have the money because there were moments when he didn't have the $3 round-trip subway fare for another audition. Even when the film opened in mid-July, Mr. Williams was still making his real living moving furniture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, MORRIS J.
description: LEVY-Morris J. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of Phyllis Mandell and Stephen Levy. Cherished grandfather of Lindsay Mandell, Meryl, Brian, Daniel and Samantha Levy. Services private.

title: Patients' Rights Bill Will Force Up Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Head of Talent Agency Emerges to Lead a Rival
description: Only three days after resigning as co-chairman of International Creative Management, a top talent agency, James A. Wiatt was named president of the rival William Morris Agency today.

title: Tradition of Local Justice Ends in Ohio
description: By Superior Court fiat, judicial gavels are being snatched from the hands of small-town mayors across this state, striking down an old tradition and leaving Mayor Richard Ellison ruefully asking what's wrong with local justice proving more kindhearted than blind.

title: Jack Rosenthal to Follow Gelb As Head of Times Foundation
description: Jack Rosenthal, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times, was named yesterday to succeed Arthur Gelb as president of The New York Times Company Foundation. The announcement was made by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., chairman of The New York Times Company.

title: Japan Now Officially Hails The Emperor and a Rising Sun
description: In a move that speaks of strongly rising nationalist sentiment among Japan's politicians, the upper house of Parliament voted resoundingly today to designate the rising-sun flag and longtime unofficial anthem as legal symbols of the nation.

title: Surplus Dreams; A Debate Over Dividing Tax Dollars Yet to Be Collected
description: The heated battle over how to use projected Federal budget surpluses has exposed deep rifts between the two parties, both in political and economic terms.

title: DEUTSCHE TELEKOM'S EXPANSION
description: Europe's largest phone company, Deutsche Telekom A.G., said that it planned further acquisitions after last week's purchase of One 2 One Ltd. for $:8.4 billion ($13.6 billion) and that it would sell shares in its mobile phone business to help finance global expansion. The Bonn-based company said selling shares in its mobile businesses would bring financial flexibility to finance acquisitions with cash or stock. Telekom, which is also planning a share sale for its Internet unit, said it would keep a majority stake in both businesses. It did not give a time frame.

title: New England as Soothing Myth For a Nation That Wanted One
description: Think of American beginnings, and what comes to mind? New England, probably, and with it a flood of associations. Pious Pilgrims and feisty Minutemen. Yankee farmers and Transcendentalist poets. Whaling ships and white-steepled churches with ''their air of sparse, sincere rebellion,'' as the Boston-born poet Robert Lowell put it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, DR. BERNARD
description: KAHN-Dr. Bernard of Boca Raton, Florida. Died August 9, 1999. Beloved husband of the late May (Horovin) Kahn. Cherished father of Dr. Judith Kahn of Charlottesville, Va., Roberta Kahn of Brooklyn Heights, N.Y., Maxine Lerman and son-in-law Manuel of Manchester, Ct. Loving brother of Charles Kahn of Lauderhill, Fl. and the late Harold Kahn. Devoted grandfather of Sharon and Elliot Lerman. Dedicated physician for sixty years with practices in Wesbury, L.I., Brooklyn, N.Y. and Tamarac and Deerfield Beach, Fl. Served his country in World War II as Medical Officer in Panama and transport surgeon on the Queen Elizabeth I, attaining the rank of Lt. Colonel in World War II. Services will be conducted graveside at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastingson-Hudson, Friday, August 13 at 11AM.

title: Shelters Are Said to Strain Under New Welfare Rules
description: New York State's homeless shelters have experienced an increase in demand in recent years as growing numbers of poor people have dropped off the state's welfare rolls, according to a new study released by advocates for the homeless.

title: Metro Business; Vornado Buys Hotel
description: Vornado Realty Trust, the largest office landlord in New York City, has bought the remaining 20 percent stake in the Hotel Pennsylvania for $42 million in cash and debt from Planet Hollywood International Inc.

title: Viagra Helps Women Avert Tough Choice
description: Some women who need to take antidepressant medications find themselves forced to make a difficult choice: treat their depression or enjoy a satisfying sex life. Sexual dysfunction is a common side effect of antidepressant treatment, and some women end up deciding that taking the drugs is just not worth it.

title: Injury to Knee Ends Rookie's Year
description: The promising season of the Carolina Panthers rookie cornerback Tony Booth ended with a knee injury that will require surgery and at least six months of rehabilitation.

title: Gray Eminence Compels Respect and Even Fear
description: Vladimir V. Putin is not a household name.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Who will take any Prime Minister seriously if they are changed like gloves?''

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Friday on a Public Lives profile about Vincent McMahon of the World Wrestling Federation misstated his title. He is the chairman, not the chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about on-line sales of literature banned in Germany omitted the given name of the associate dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center. He is Rabbi Abraham Cooper.

title: Beijing Rejects Vatican's Bid For Papal Trip To Hong Kong
description: China has turned down efforts by the Vatican to arrange a visit by Pope John Paul II to Hong Kong when he tours Asia later this year, dashing hopes among Catholics in China that ties between Rome and Beijing might improve.

title: K.G.B. VETERAN IS IN
description: As the race to succeed him next year threatens to slip out of his control, President Boris N. Yeltsin tipped his hand, and Russia's political apple cart, by firing his Prime Minister today and replacing him with a former K.G.B. officer and loyal aide who he said was his favorite to become the next president.

title: Of Kidney Failure and Cups of Herbal Tea
description: Two women taking Chinese herbal preparations to treat eczema have suffered kidney failure, according to a report in the current issue of The Lancet, a British medical journal. The cases raise new questions about remedies' safety, the report said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Thoreau, or at Least the Next Best Thing, Is Alive and Well
description: It is only a summer fantasy, but such an uplifting one. Transcendent. A bit pagan. In a fancy word, Thoreauvian.

title: High Oil Prices May Bring Windfall for Iraq
description: Rising world oil prices coupled with a big increase in its production could earn Iraq a record $6.3 billion in the current six-month phase of the program that allows it to sell oil to raise money for food, medicines and other civilian goods, officials and diplomats said today.

title: Culture Resists Top-Down Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Criminals' DNA Samples
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHSBAUM, MORITZ
description: BUCHSBAUM-Moritz. Of New York. Formerly of Frankfort/ Main. Beloved husband of Madeline. Died August 7, 1999. Also survived by his sister Rose Lieberman of Kew Gardens, many nieces, newphews, great nieces and great nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, WILLIAM
description: GREENBERG-William. August 7, 1999. Beloved husband of Sonia, loving father of Amy and Bennett, Toby, Neal and Lee. Dear brother of Henrietta, the late Tobie and Marvin. Cherished grandfather of Emily, Alex, Stephanie, Glenn and Sophie. We will forever hold dear your laughter and love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, BARBARA SUE
description: GIBSON-Barbara Sue. The Division of Substance Abuse and Adiction Medicine of the Department of Psychiatry of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine-Montefiore Medical Center express sincere condolences on the sudden accidental death of our colleague and friend, Barbara Sue Gibson and her mother, Susan Gibson. Barbara was a consumate professional and cared deeply about quality care for the patients we treat and was devoted to upgrading the skills of those who work in our programs. Our deepest sympathy to our friend and Einstein Berle Award Recipient, Dr. Beny J. Primm and to her family, friends and colleagues. Ira J. Marion, Executive Director

title: Claudette Sorel, 66, Concert Pianist and Teacher
description: Claudette Sorel, a pianist who was at her best in music that demanded delicacy and lyricism but who also gave highly regarded performances of difficult contemporary works and big Romantic showpieces, died on Friday at her home in Hampton Bays, N.Y. She was 66.

title: INCHCAPE PROFIT DROPS
description: A British-based car distributor and retailer, Inchcape P.L.C., said its profits fell 32 percent in the six months that ended on June 30 because of weak demand for vehicles in Asia and Latin America. Profits from operations in the half year fell to $:23.9 million ($38.4 million) from $:32.5 million a year earlier. Sales fell 15 percent, to 2.41 billion. Inchcape has sold bottling and other nonauto businesses in the last two years to concentrate on vehicle distributing, importing and retailing.

title: Starr Expects to Issue Report On Clintons by Fall 2000
description: Kenneth W. Starr said today that he planned to conclude his long-running investigation of President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton before the November 2000 elections by filing a final report.

title: Arabesques Touched by Abracadabra
description: Mark Morris emerged as a master magician this afternoon when his dance group performed at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. The program, at the Ted Shawn Theater here, opened with Mr. Morris's pulling a big, bright bouquet (''My Party'') from his choreographic magician's hat, followed by two dark, mysterious animals (''The Argument'' and ''Greek to Me''), a pair of pajamas (''Silhouettes'') and a cocktail served in a gaily painted juice glass (''Dancing Honeymoon'').

title: Times Co. and Amazon Settle a Legal Dispute
description: Amazon.com and The New York Times Company have settled their legal dispute over the on-line bookseller's use of the newspaper's weekly best-seller list to sell discounted books.

title: Washington Promises to Help Kentucky Uranium Workers
description: The Energy Department will expand its promise of finding and compensating workers made sick in its bomb-production factories to include employees at a giant Kentucky plant that processed uranium for bombs and military reactors, the Energy Secretary, Bill Richardson, said today.

title: Gore Pursues Black Voters in a Texas Foray
description: Vice President Al Gore continued his efforts to woo black voters today as he again ventured into Texas, seeking to position himself for what he hopes will be an eventual Presidential race against the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush.

title: Tonality Catches A Breeze From Afar
description: Gidon Kremer's Kremerata Baltica took its repertory as far as Latvia, Estonia, Russia and Argentina on Friday night; but no matter how far the trip, a firm sense of tonal center was always nearby. This was the second of two chamber orchestra programs at Alice Tully Hall. The first had made its way to Hollywood with music by Bernard Herrmann, and here on Friday were further proofs that tonality has perhaps survived its predicted exhaustion and found new energy in a deep past.

title: Will Brookhaven Destroy the Universe? Probably Not.
description: Amid the summer news doldrums, what could be more invigorating than a warning that physicists may be on the verge of destroying the world?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARKER, SIDNEY
description: PARKER-Sidney. Love never dies. Sleep well, our sweet prince among men. Your loving family

title: MICHAEL FOODS EXPLORING STRATEGIC OPTIONS
description: Michael Foods Inc., one of the largest United States egg producers, said yesterday that it had hired the investment bankers United States Bancorp Piper Jaffray and Merrill Lynch & Company to help it explore strategic options, including an outright sale. The food processing and distribution company said other alternatives include strategic alliances, acquisitions and the sale of some of its businesses. Michael Foods said it was trying to raise its share value. Its shares have fallen 21 percent so far this year. Michael Foods' shares rose $1.125 each, to $23.5625. At that price the company's stock market value is $408 million. The Minneapolis-based company had $1.02 billion in revenue in 1998.

title: J.J. Johnson to Sit With Strain
description: Running back J.J. Johnson, the Miami Dolphins' top draft pick, is expected to miss up to 10 days after straining his left hamstring in a weekend scrimmage.

title: New Albany Charter School Is Only One Regents Oppose
description: After four hours of debate, the State Board of Regents yesterday approved the opening of all but one of five charter schools this fall, saying that the school's district did not have enough time to prepare for the loss of hundreds of students.

title: Labs Close In on the 'God Particle'
description: The race to find an elusive but all-important particle called the Higgs boson heated up last week when Europe's most powerful accelerator reached an energy that may bring the target within range.

title: Patients' Rights Bill Will Force Up Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: BID FOR FIBER UNIT
description: The Dutch chemical maker Akzo Nobel N.V. received an offer of 825 million euros ($883 million) from CVC Capital Partners Ltd. for its Acordis unit. Acordis, Akzo's fiber unit, was created after Akzo took over Courtaulds of Britain and merged the fiber businesses of the two companies. It had been expected that Akzo would sell the business. Under the deal, CVC will buy Acordis and establish it as an independent company, keeping the current management, and Akzo will be given the option to purchase up to 20 percent of the shares. CVC is an independent investment firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUEL, SARAH H.
description: SAMUEL-Sarah H. On August 6, 1999, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Sam. Loving mother of Raphael. Dear sister of Henry Hollenberg. You will be sorely missed by all who knew you. Raphael Samuel

title: With Internet in Mind, EMC Buys Memory Disk Maker for $1.1 Billion
description: Offering the latest evidence of the Internet's enormous impact on all facets of the computer industry, the EMC Corporation, a leading producer of data storage equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Data General Corporation, in a stock swap valued at about $1.1 billion.

title: Peering Into the Brain To See Pain at Work
description: Under circumstances that may seem reminiscent of medieval torture, a hardened band of volunteers is undergoing excruciating tests to help researchers understand how pain works and how to to stop it.

title: Treasury Yields Near 2-Year Highs With Big Auctions Due
description: Treasury bond yields continued to move higher yesterday, approaching two-year highs.

title: The Secret Treasure of City Hall; Significant Art Collection Goes Mostly Unnoticed by Visitors
description: Archeologists keeping a step ahead of the bulldozers churning the earth during renovations to City Hall Park have found all sorts of historic artifacts. But far more valuable treasures are secreted away inside City Hall itself: the city's little known but extensive collection of 19th-century portraits and other artwork, which is rarely seen by the public that owns it all.

title: THE CONTENDERS: Running Toward 2000; Dole Fights to Recapture Her Early Star Status
description: When Elizabeth Dole ventured into Iowa in February, she was not greeted like another mere Presidential candidate but like a superstar. Television cameras trailed her every move. In nearby Ames, she drew an unheard of outpouring: more than 2,000 Iowans at one event, pressing to get close to the first woman to wage a potent bid for the White House.

title: GE MEDICAL TO BUY OEC, MAKER OF SURGICAL EQUIPMENT
description: GE Medical Systems has agreed to buy OEC Medical Systems Inc., which makes imaging equipment used in surgery, in a stock swap worth $480 million. GE Medical, a leader in medical diagnostic equipment and services, is a unit of the General Electric Company. Shareholders of OEC would receive $36 a share in G.E. stock. The number of GE shares that each OEC holder would be eligible to receive would be determined by the average trading price of G.E. stock for a period before the deal's closing. OEC's stock rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to $34.1875. GE Medical, based in Milwaukee, specializes in medical diagnostic equipment like magnetic resonance, ultrasound, and conventional and digital X-ray gear. (Reuters)

title: Grimsley Receives A 3-Game Suspension
description: Jason Grimsley was suspended for three games by the American League today for hitting Seattle's Edgar Martinez with a pitch Friday, two pitches after Alex Rodriguez slugged a home run.

title: An Artist's Work Blurs Lines Between Art and Science
description: We are remarkably good at recognizing objects, but science has no explanation for how we do it.

title: New Questions Plague Nuclear Waste Storage Plan
description: For more than 20 years, scientists have been trying to figure out if Yucca Mountain, a barren desert ridge in southern Nevada, is a suitable burial ground for the nation's deadliest radioactive waste.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHARDT, SOL
description: STEINHARDT-Sol. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations extends its condolences to its esteemed friend Michael Steinhardt on the passing of his beloved father. To the entire family, our prayers that they will find comfort at this time of their loss and be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm I. Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Top Prospect Selects Pirates
description: Eddie Griffin, rated by some as the top high school basketball prospect in the nation, has chosen Seton Hall over such powerhouse programs as North Carolina and Connecticut.

title: Sneaky Charter Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Other Side of the Moon and the Wall
description: Roger Waters, former leader of Pink Floyd, who took his first tour in 12 years to Jones Beach on Saturday, has ferried millions of rock fans into the murky waters of introspection. More illicit drugs have been consumed and more tentative philosophies expounded to the reverberations of Pink Floyd's perpetually popular masterwork ''Dark Side of the Moon'' than to any other rock album. Generations of would-be dropouts have raised their fists in solidarity with Mr. Waters's anti-establishment lyrics on ''The Wall.''

title: Advice for Sports Exercise: Go Ballistic
description: Fitness experts call them ''explosive'' or ''ballistic'' training exercises. And according to the American College of Sports Medicine, the lightweight, high-speed techniques are a good way to increase strength.

title: 2 Charged With Robbery Of Landmark Village Bar
description: A man walked into McSorley's Old Ale House in the East Village yesterday, ordered a drink and then grabbed a money bag that the owner was preparing to take to a bank.

title: Low Fares and Empty Seats Hurt British Airways' Results
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that its first-quarter pretax profit had fallen 84 percent as discount fares and a decline in the number of first-class and business-class passengers hurt results.

title: TRACK AND FIELD; Running Down the Past
description: In the summer of 1983, in the span of 20 days, Jarmila Kratochvilova of Czechoslovakia lowered the world record in the 800 meters and the 400 meters and won two gold medals and one silver at the first world track and field championships in Helsinki, Finland.

title: Chinese Officials Suspend Import of Wine From France
description: In a move that baffles French officials and businessmen, Chinese customs authorities have suspended the import of all wine from, of all countries, France.

title: Harry Walker, 80, Is Dead; A Fidgeter With a Purpose
description: Harry (the Hat) Walker, who made baseball history twice when he won the National League batting title in 1947, died Sunday at University of Alabama Hospital in Birmingham. Walker, who lived in Leeds, Ala., was 80.

title: Hoover Account, Is Placed in Review
description: The Hoover Company, part of the Maytag Corporation, said yesterday that it had placed its vacuum cleaner account in review after 11 years at Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PROGNOSIS; Expecting the Best Is Good for the Heart
description: Optimism and self-confidence may prove potent weapons in staving off a recurrence of heart disease, if a new study by Carnegie Mellon University researchers is any indication. Patients in the study who had a positive outlook, greater self-control and higher self-esteem after angioplasty were less likely to suffer a heart attack, undergo bypass surgery or require a second angioplasty in the next six months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, MADELEINE ELEANOR
description: O'BRIEN - Madeleine Eleanor. Died August 2nd, in NC. Daughter of the late Bernard and Mary K. McGann Duffy of Sacred Heart Parish, Bx. Retired school principal and teacher. Survived by husband, Michael J. O'Brien, brother James Duffy, sister Ellen Duffy, nieces and nephews. Memorial Mass noon, Saturday, August 14th, at St. Benedict's, Bx, followed by reception. Memorials to St. Joseph HS, 80 Willoughby Street, Bklyn.

title: Sales by Wholesalers Rise 19%, Outpacing Growth in Inventory
description: Sales rose faster for the nation's wholesalers in June than at any time in more than two years, outpacing a buildup in inventories, Government figures showed today.

title: Lukas Gets His Turn, And Enters The Hall
description: D. Wayne Lukas, the most successful and at times the most second-guessed trainer in racing, was inducted into the sport's Hall of Fame today and said, in an upbeat and otherwise healing speech that drew standing ovations, ''I make no apologies for what we do.''

title: Boy Scouts Mocked Idea of Free Association
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Safety Confusion
description: A year ago the National Academy of Sciences warned that the current governmental structure for protecting the public from unsafe or mislabeled food was a fragmented mess. Responsibility for administering the dozens of laws concerning food safety is scattered among a dozen different agencies, each with a different approach to its regulatory mission. The resulting gaps and inefficiencies impede a rational deployment of inspectors and other resources, thereby jeopardizing the nation's public health.

title: Colombia's Struggles, and How We Can Help
description: The death of five American and two Colombian soldiers in a plane crash during a counternarcotics mission in Colombia last month put the spotlight on our stake in South America's most troubled country.

title: Banks' Recovery in Indonesia Is Complicated by Scandal
description: The head of the powerful agency entrusted with bailing out Indonesia's graft-ridden financial system offered to step down today as accusations of corruption threatened to discredit his own organization.

title: A Welcome Oil Decision
description: If someone had wanted to make America's trade laws look ridiculous, he might have come up with the strategy that was used by a group of small domestic oil companies when they asked the Government for relief from the ''dumping'' of cheap crude oil into America. It is good that the Commerce Department yesterday dismissed the petition, but the fact that it could be filed at all shows that the anti-dumping law is far too broad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSHBERG, BEATRICE
description: HERSHBERG-Beatrice. On August 8, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Sheldon. Caring mother of Ken, Lisa and Cathy. Loving grandmother of Beth, Drew, Leslie and Shelby. Cherished mother in law of Skip, Barbara and Seth. Faithful companion of Ben Nuchman. Funeral Service Tuesday 12:30 P.M. at Frederick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway, (1/4 mile west of the Robert Moses Causeway). Interment in Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I.

title: A Place To Plumb Jewish Roots
description: THE Hillary Rodham Clinton road show came to town yesterday, but one place the First Lady did not get to was the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square. Too bad. She could have picked up a few pointers there about how to go about exploring her Jewish roots.

title: All Washed Up but Knows the Score
description: Half a dozen different downtown subcultures came together when Justin Bond and Kenny Mellman performed their weekly show, ''Have Another,'' at Fez on Sunday night.

title: A Girl's Life, in a Family Unhappy In Its Own Way
description: THE LAST LIFE

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Urbane Songs That Express Emotional Embattlement
description: In song after song during Aimee Mann's tetchy performance at Tramps on Saturday, she sang in the second person to anyone who had hooked her with impressive overtures and then insulted her by making her a low priority. In all of these songs, her embattled emotional position remained the same: she deserves respect, but she feels fated to receive only the half-baked, temporary sort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, WILLIAM R. JR.
description: MAYER-William R. Jr. On August 7, 1999. After a valiant 23 year struggle with primary liver cancer. Beloved husband of Nancy (Anne) Manning Mayer. Devoted father of William T. III and Robert Anthony. Cherished son of Florence Burr Mayer and the late William Taft Mayer. Bill was honored as Paul Harris Fellow by Rotary International. Bronx Chamber of Commerce Businessman of the Year. National Conference of Christians and Jews Distinguished Service Award. Century Club. Member of New York Athletic Club. Member of The Club, Pelican Bay, Naples, FL. The family wishes to acknowledge with profound gratitude the skill, dedication and compassion of the staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, and in a special way, Dr. Joseph G. Fortner. Friends may call at Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave, White Plains, NY, on Monday and Tuesday, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of the Resurrection Wednesday, 10 AM, at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

description: In percent

description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; STATE REGULATORS HAVE HARSH WORDS FOR DAY TRADING
description: Many day-trading firms use deceptive marketing practices to lure customers into a rapid-fire stock trading strategy that will probably cause them to lose money, and then they help to keep them trading by arranging what could be illegal loans, a group of state securities regulators said today.

title: Q & A
description: Holes in the Cheese

title: A Day After a Tornado Strikes North Fork, One Big Problem Is Sightseers
description: A day after a tornado roared through Long Island's North Fork on Sunday, officials were counting their blessings. Although the tornado had winds that reached 155 miles an hour, according to the National Weather Service, it swept off only a handful of roofs and capsized boats at their moorings but caused no serious injuries.

title: Colorado Killers Inspired Youth In Georgia Shooting, Note Says
description: A 15-year-old boy charged in the shooting of six classmates at his high school here on May 20 had left a letter under his bed expressing admiration for the two teen-agers who killed 12 students, a teacher and themselves at a Colorado high school exactly a month earlier, according to testimony in a juvenile-court hearing today.

title: Minor League Goalie Agrees to Terms
description: The Rangers agreed to terms yesterday with a minor league goaltender, Jean-Francois Labbe.

title: International Audience For Huge Eclipse Show
description: The solar eclipse that will sweep across Europe, the Middle East and the Indian subcontinent on Wednesday promises to be one of the most watched in history. The European portion of the itinerary alone reads like one of those if-it's-Tuesday-it-must-be-Belgium tours: Cornwall, Paris, Stuttgart, Munich, Vienna, Budapest and Bucharest are all within or near the 60-mile-wide path of totality, where the moon will completely cover the sun.

title: Is It R.I.P. for N.F.L. In Los Angeles?
description: Contrary to its muscular image and television ratings, the National Football League is not omnipotent. It can't persuade Barry Sanders to unretire, can't keep Al Davis from filing lawsuits, can't make the Pro Bowl matter, can't make geographic sense of its divisions and can't put a franchise in Los Angeles.

title: On Admissions, More Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: Boos Begin Early as Mets Fall Out of First Place
description: The game was about 10 minutes old and Orel Hershiser could already hear boos floating around Shea Stadium last night. Four of the first five Dodgers he faced reached base, two scored and the fans who wanted to see the Mets remain in first place for another night were agitated. Obviously, they were a bit antsy, too.

title: Metro Business; Bell Atlantic Takes A Step in Phone Deal
description: Bell Atlantic Corporation, the largest local telephone company in the country, says it has cleared a major hurdle in its effort to enter the $80 billion long-distance market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFEVRE, EDWIN JR.
description: LeFEVRE-Edwin Jr. Age 96, died August 7. A memorial service will be held at the United Church of Dorset and East Rupert on Sunday, August 15, 2:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, KITTY SUDEROV
description: MARGOLIS-Kitty Suderov. Beloved mother of Richard Suderov of Patchogue, N.Y. & step-mother of the Margolis family of Woodmere, N.Y. Cherished grandmother of Gail and Andrew. Graveside services Tuesday 2 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: ELF CHIEF CONSIDERS MERGER
description: The chairman of Elf Aquitaine S.A., Philippe Jaffre, said he would consider merger talks with a rival oil company, Total Fina S.A., if Total would discuss spinning off the combined chemical business. Elf's desire to create a separate chemical business is the distinguishing feature of its plan to combine the two companies. Elf's $50.6 billion offer for Total, Europe's third-biggest oil company, is the first instance of a French company's trying to block a hostile takeover by bidding for its predator.

title: Champion of Free Kosovo Now Urges Moderation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINERMAN, JEROME I., DR.
description: KLEINERMAN-Jerome I., Dr. 75, An internationally renowned scientist in the field of pulmonary pathology whose research led to a better understanding of environmental lung diseases, died Friday (August 6) in Arcadia, FL, following an auto accident. Dr. Kleinerman was professor emeritus of pathology at Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine. He served as Chairman of the Department of Pathology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine of the City University of New York from 1978 to 1986. He also was Director of Pathology at Mount Sinai Hospital and was named the Irene Heinz Given and John LaPorte Given Professor of Pathology. Deeply concerned about the health of people in the workplace, Dr. Kleinerman was a driving force in setting nationwide standards for diagnosing lung diseases including the coal workers pneumoconiosis, asbestosis, byssinosis, and other occupational hazards. These standards still are being used today. Formerly of Shaker Heights, Ohio, he was professor of pathology and environmental health sciences at Case Western Reserve University from 1986 to 1995 before retiring to Palm Beach Gardens, FL, where he worked as a consultant. His research and association with numerous groups worldwide underscored the need for safe work conditions in coal and asbestos mines as well as other industrial settings. He did extensive research in the effects of smoking on lungs. During his career, Dr. Kleinerman served on the editorial boards of numerous notable publications including the ''American Journal of Pathology'' and ''Cancer.'' He chaired the executive committee of the distinguished American Registry of Pathology, Armed Forces Institute of Pathology from 1995-1996, and advisory committees for the Bureau of Mines U.S. Department of the Interior, National Institutes of Health and other government agencies concerning occupational health. Dr. Kleinerman is survived by three daughters. His wife of 50 years, Seretta Miller, died in 1995. The funeral will be at 11 A.M., Tuesday at Fairmount Temple, 23737 Fairmount Boulevard, Beachwood, OH 44122. Burial will be at Mayfield Cemetery in Cleveland. Material tributes may take the form of donations to the Seretta Miller Kleinerman Memorial Endowment Fund in care of Fairmount Temple. For information, Berkowitz-Kumin-Bookatz, Inc., 1800-448-2210, www.obitdetails.com

title: Sifting a Cultural Hero's Life to Define Puerto Ricans
description: The singer Hector Lavoe came to New York from Puerto Rico as a teen-ager in the late 1960's and became a cultural figure, his high pure-as-air voice riding salsa's drums. Then he dissolved in a stew of drugs and hard living. Lavoe died in 1993, and now his life, his musical excellence and his death at 46 are being mined for meaning and money. ''Quien Mato a Hector Lavoe?'' (''Who Killed Hector Lavoe?''), which is playing at the 47th Street Theater through the end of the month, is in one sense a conventional musical, linking some of his songs with dramatic interludes that explain his personality. But it is also an attempt by Puerto Rican intellectuals to figure out and reassess the image of a cultural hero.

title: BLOCKBUSTER RAISES $465 MILLION IN AN INITIAL OFFERING
description: Blockbuster Inc., the world's largest chain of videocassette rental stores, raised $465 million in an initial public offering that capitalizes on the company's name even as doubts linger over challenges to its core business. Blockbuster, owned by Viacom Inc., sold 31 million shares to the public at $15, $1 below the $16 to $18 range set before the sale. The offering represents an 18 percent stake and valued Blockbuster at $2.63 billion. Viacom, which retains about 82 percent of the Blockbuster shares following the sale, plans to spin off the remainder of these shares to its own shareholders. Blockbuster will use the proceeds to repay debt owed to Viacom.

title: SLUMPING SALES CAUSE OAKWOOD HOMES TO CLOSE PLANTS
description: The Oakwood Homes Corporation, the largest United States retailer of manufactured housing, said yesterday that it had reduced its work force by 695 workers this summer because of slumping demand. The company closed its factory in Ennis, Tex., and production has ceased at its plants in Richfield, N.C., and Moultrie, Ga. Those sites employed 545. Earlier, the company reduced its work force at its Greensboro, N.C., headquarters and at factories in Fort Morgan, Colo., and Albany, Ore., by 150 workers. Oakwood said it closed the plants because sales had dropped and competition had increased.

title: Chesapeake Bay's Vital Signs
description: Chesapeake Bay, one of America's most beleaguered estuaries, is showing signs of better health this summer. Improved water quality in some tributaries is allowing the regrowth of underwater grasses, the striped bass have returned and the oyster population, as recently reported in The Times, is on the upswing -- a big gain for the bay because oysters act as a natural filter for impurities in the water. Meanwhile last week an environmental group and a timber company agreed to preserve 76,000 acres of Chesapeake watershed lands that might otherwise have been developed.

title: Recreating a Taste Of Summer in Liguria

The delicious, strongly flavored sauce must be used in such small quantities that it adds practically nothing in the way of bulk to the dish. That's why pasta with pesto is almost always best served as a first course, the way it is in Italy. It is not substantial enough to work as a main course.

This program of Mozart, Beethoven and Dvorak, part of the Mostly Mozart Festival, was passionately stroked, lunged at and generally overwhelmed with affection. The crowd loved it.

title: With 13th Visit, Dalai Lama Has Gone From Obscurity to Celebrity

He and his colleagues went to Battery Park, and the Dalai Lama stood on the pier and gazed across the water, apparently not even recognized by passers-by. He gave talks at various churches and Buddhist centers to a total of 1,000 people, without security guards, police escorts, or trailing photographers.

title: 13 Needless Deaths
description: The deaths of 13 farm workers in a vehicle crash in Five Points, Calif., underscores the need for better enforcement of the laws that protect farm laborers. The circumstances of Monday's accident are shocking but not uncommon -- an unlicensed driver ferrying 15 people home just before dawn in an overloaded van. It defies common sense that vans used for the express purpose of transporting such laborers are not required to have seat belts. Farm workers often have no alternative means of transportation to and from the fields.

title: 24/7 MEDIA BUYS E-MAIL MARKETER TO EXPAND DATA BASE
description: 24/7 Media Inc., an Internet advertising company, acquired the electronic-mail marketer Consumernet for $52 million to expand its data base of consumers' E-mail addresses and spending habits. The closely held Consumernet markets consumer information. It has more than three million names in its data base, which includes in-depth profiles on consumers and their buying patterns. More than 125 Internet sites use the data base to tailor ads and promotions to individual site visitors. Adding Consumernet will allow 24/7 Media to offer advertisers and Web publishers a wider array of E-mail marketing services. Shares of 24/7 Media fell $2.25 each, to $22.875.

title: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL TO BUY COPLEY FOR $220 MILLION
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. of Israel said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Copley Pharmaceutical Inc., a maker of generic and branded drugs, for about $220 million. Teva, based in Jerusalem, said the acquisition would strengthen its position in the United States generic drug market. The company is Israel's largest pharmaceutical concern, with 80 percent of its sales outside Israel, mainly in the United States. The deal values Copley, of Canton, Mass., at $11 a share. The shares gained more than 21 percent, rising $1.9375 each, to $10.8125, in Nasdaq trading. The German drug maker Hoechst A.G., which holds about 52 percent of Copley's shares, has agreed to tender its shares to the offer. Copley had 1998 sales of $133.5 million and profits of $7.1 million. Teva shares rose 18.75 cents, to $48.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTEN, MARVIN
description: GERSTEN-Marvin. He was a father, a husband, a hilarious, incredibly generous, ultra-charismatic, whip-smart and very good looking man. Marvin Gersten died comfortably in his home, at the age of 60, of malignant melanoma, August 10, 1999, surrounded by his family. A self-made man, Marvin grew up in Bensonhurst. He worked his way through City College of New York (graduated 1961) & Brooklyn Law (graduated 1963), waiting tables summers in the Catskills. Marvin went on to become the senior partner in his own reputable law firm, Gersten, Savage & Kaplowitz, which he founded 26 years ago, and to establish his residence on Park Avenue. Most recently, he led the firm's litigation and regulation divisions. Marvin's career fasttracked early with his appointment as New York's Commissioner of Purchase in the John Lindsay administration at the age of 28, the youngest person ever to hold that position. He then joined the revered firm of Borden & Ball for a number of years to practice law before starting his own firm. As an avid, consummate and influential New Yorker, a dedicated Knicks fan and a lover of the good life, Marvin was as likely to be seen debating sports with a stranger in the street as dining at Montrachet, his favorite restaurant. Marvin is succeeded and will be sorely missed by his wife, Diana, son, Gregory and daughter, Nikki, as well as a host of other loved ones and dear friends. Service Thursday, August 12, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC.

title: CINERGY'S CHIEF SAYS IT MAY QUIT POWER SUPPLY BUSINESS
description: James Rogers, the chief executive of the Cinergy Corporation, which lost $73 million during a heat wave in late July that forced it to default on power contracts, said yesterday that his company could leave the power supply business. His statement, made to a group of analysts in New York, diverged from the company's assertion a day earlier that it would remain in the power-marketing business. ''We are either going to fix this business, or we are going to exit,'' Mr. Rogers said. The company, based in Cincinnati, said it would announce a decision in late October or early November. Cinergy officials said the company's power supply business included trading and marketing of wholesale electricity for users outside of its own service territory.

He was knighted by the King of Greece in January 1956; decorated Comendatore of the Republic of Italy December 10, 1960; honored by the Grand Officiale Republic of Italy July 25, 1964; named Chevaliere de L'Order of Leopold-Belgium October 14, 1960; given the Sovereign Military Order of Malta December 1, 1956; and named Chevalier de Tastivin. He was a member of the Ridgewood Country Club, Paramus, N.J.; Ekwawok Golf Club of Manchester, Vt.; New York Athletic Club; Key Biscane Yacht Club, Key Biscane, Florida; and a Charter Member of the Rockefeller Center Lunch Club. title: VALE OF TEARS -- A special report.; Kashmir a Crushed Jewel Caught in a Vise of Hatred
description: Sadly, alarmingly, endlessly, there is trouble in paradise. The Vale of Kashmir, once exalted for the lotus blooms in its lakes and the yellow tapestry of its mustard fields, has become a valley of despair -- a place haunted by senseless murder and hideous torture, wherever the famously sweet winds blow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JOHN
description: MILLER-John. On July 19, 1999, loving father of Suzanne, Rachel & Vanessa Gonzalez. Also survived by sisters Blythe Miller and Akilah Toure (of Miami, Florida) & many nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass will be at St. Francis Assisi Church, West 31st Street, New York City, on Saturday, August 14, 1999 at 10 AM.

title: OAK FORECASTS PROFIT SHORTFALL, AND ITS STOCK DECLINES
description: Oak Industries, which makes electrical components for telecommunications systems, said yesterday that it expected third-quarter net income to fall short of analysts' estimates, setting off a 32 percent decline in its stock price. The company said it revised its estimate to 40 cents to 42 cents a share, down from its previous estimate of 49 cents to 52 cents, which was in line with the average estimate of four analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. Its shares fell $13.25, to $27.75. Oak, which is based in Waltham, Mass., attributed the shortfall to a loss of revenue at its Lasertron fiber optics division.

description: Once you attached your new PC-based DVD player to your television, your first reaction might not have been ''What a great picture'' but ''Great -- another wire to trip over.''

description: Toms River East's run at another Little League championship hit a speed bump from the Bronx last night in the Eastern Regionals.

description: Remy Charlip is an enduring figure in American modern dance, a longtime performer and a choreographer with a gift for quirkily evoking intense emotions with ordinary movement and a few vivid props. For many, however, Mr. Charlip is best known as the writer and illustrator of children's books.
