description: ''WHAT'S astounding to people is my Silver Queen corn,'' Barbara Schwartz said, pointing to a bumper crop -- 10 teeny ears -- growing 16 stories up on the terrace of her Park Avenue penthouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, JOSEPH
description: ABRAMS-Joseph. Of Bedminster, NJ, 63, died August 11 of cancer. He was born in New York City on February 2, 1936. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School and an MBA from New York University, he was a founder of AGS Computers Inc., and served as its President and Chief Operating Officer until his retirement in 1990. He was active in several charities including The Valerie Fund and was a board member of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and was on the executive committee and served as Vice President of the United Jewish Federation of MetroWest, NJ. He is survived by his beloved wife Judith, loving children Brad and Douglas and Miranda and nephews and nieces Robert and Janet and Penny and Joel and Andrea and Virgina. The funeral will be held at 2PM, Thursday, August 12 at Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Ave. Maplewood, NJ. 973-763-3505 for directions. Donations should be made to the The Valerie Fund, 2101 Milburn Ave., Maplewood, New Jersey, 07040.

title: Opening Shot in P.G.A. Turns Out to Be a Ryder Zinger From Crenshaw
description: Even before the first tee shot, the atmosphere surrounding the 81st P.G.A. Championship has become confrontational, compelling and charged with controversy.

title: Mrs. Clinton 'Listens,' This Time to House Prices
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton, in the midst of her ''listening tour'' around New York State, has limited her house hunting to Westchester County, where she stopped at an open house in Greenburgh yesterday.

title: Seoul Delays Announcement of a Plan to Revamp Daewoo
description: In a move that gave many investors a sickening sense of deja vu, the South Korean Government put off the announcement of a much-awaited revamping plan for the troubled Daewoo Group that had been expected today.

title: Historic Designs, Modern Colors
description: Annie Sherburne, a rug designer in London, looks to the past for motifs and to the present for color. ''Sometimes, a rug is based on a traditional image, a circle, or petals, or an Egyptian lotus,'' she said. Her rug, top right (6 by 7 feet, $2,200), was inspired by a mandala, but the colors come from a flower shop near her home.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee rose as a cold front in Argentina posed a potential threat to Brazil and the world's largest crop. In New York, coffee for September delivery rose 2.95 cents, or 3.2 percent, to 96.7 cents a pound.

title: Many Latin Stocks Leave Home, Trading on Wall Street
description: For the first time since he started trading stocks 16 years ago, Helio Ozaki, the chief trader at a small securities firm here, is shifting his focus to Manhattan. His firm is planning to move much of its trading of Brazilian shares to the New York Stock Exchange because declining volume and high transaction costs have sapped much of the activity on the local stock market.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LEAP WIRELESS INTERNATIONAL, San Diego, which engages in wireless telecommunications businesses and ventures, sold its Australian subsidiary, Ozphone, for $16.3 million to AAPT Ltd.

title: Another Court Tangle in the Perelman-Duff Custody Case
description: The custody and child-support battle between Ronald O. Perelman and Patricia Duff that has raged in court for more than 15 months derailed again yesterday when one of the chief lawyers representing Ms. Duff abruptly asked to quit the case.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CITIGROUP INC., New York, named Thomas W. Jones to head its newly combined global asset management and private banking operations. He had been chief of asset management.

title: Hype About Hunger
description: The Federal entitlement bureaucrats are in despair at their shrinking empire. First, the 1996 welfare law made work a prerequisite for cash assistance. Now the latest bad news: people are shunning food stamps. Since 1996, the food stamp rolls have dropped nearly 30 percent, more than the decrease in official poverty. Many former welfare recipients are deciding to go it on their own.

title: Economic Scene; The ins and outs of putting a price tag on product safety.
description: WE'RE just like numbers,'' one juror said last month after voting to order the General Motors Corporation to pay $4.9 billion to six people severely burned when the fuel tank of their 1979 Chevrolet Malibu exploded after a drunken driver ran into them. The award is an understandably human reaction to evidence introduced during the trial that purported to show that General Motors had a policy of forgoing safety features that cost shockingly little, perhaps no more than $2.40 a car.

description: A Federal judge sentenced the former Mayor of Camden yesterday to six months of house arrest and three years of probation for arranging to be paid two months of his salary as school Superintendent after becoming Mayor in 1994, officials said.

title: Use of Police in Parole Raids Stirs Praise, but Also Concern
description: Late one night last month, police and parole officers swarmed down on more than 20 parolees in two Brooklyn housing projects, rousing them from their beds before questioning them about crimes in the area and forcing them to give urine samples to test for drugs. Those who tested positive or failed to give samples were taken to the local precinct house for further questioning.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of a concert on Monday by the Takacs Quartet misstated the site of the performance. As the review reported correctly, it was at Avery Fisher Hall, not Alice Tully Hall.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL BUYS CREDIT CARD PORTFOLIO
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation agreed yesterday to purchase a $120 million private-label credit card portfolio from the Citgo Petroleum Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Associates, which is based in Irving, Tex., will acquire the consumer credit card loans of Citgo and issue, process and service the oil company's 1.3 million accounts. The acquisition will increase Associates' gasoline-card accounts to about 11.3 million and give it a 42 percent share of the market. Associates bought the card portfolios of Shell Oil and BP Amoco earlier this year and owns Texaco Inc.'s portfolio.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We want to stand up and say to them both, 'Thank you for loving us, but spare us the honor of being your battleground.' ''

title: Solomon Dutka, 75, Founder Of Marketing Research Firm
description: Solomon Dutka, who started a marketing research firm in a one-room office in New York City in 1953 that grew into one of the largest companies in the industry, died on Saturday at his home in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Saturday about Gov. George E. Pataki's announcement that he would support Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for United States Senate misstated the role of Kieran Mahoney, a Republican consultant. He is an adviser to Mr. Pataki, not to Mr. Giuliani.

title: Rolston Wins Arbitration
description: Forward Brian Rolston was awarded a new two-year, $2.77 million contract after an arbitration hearing yesterday. Rolston, who made $750,000 last season, was seeking a one-year pact worth $1.7 million while the Devils offered $2.08 million over two seasons. His new pact will pay him $1.3 million in 1999-2000 and $1.47 million in 2000-2001.

title: A Counterproductive Double
description: The grand old man of bridge journalism is certainly Albert Benjamin of Scotland, who celebrated his 90th birthday in April. After World War II he began a daily bridge column in The Glasgow Evening Citizen and would probably still be writing it if the paper hadn't died after 28 years.

title: Republicans and the Gay Vote
description: Gay men and lesbians may be born homosexual, but they aren't born Democrats. They have often voted that way, however, because the national Republican Party has been so hostile. Now, in the ebb of the great cultural wars mounted by conservatives for the last two decades, that seems to be changing. The most prominent Republican candidates for President in the next election, as Katharine Seelye reported yesterday in The Times, are taking positions that are ''subtly but fundamentally more inviting'' to gay and lesbian voters than at any time before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMIERI, JOSEPH
description: PALMIERI-Joseph, of Manhasset, N.Y. Died August 10, 1999. Beloved husband of Ethel. Dear father of Guy. Brother of Norma Totani. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. title: Revenge of a Studio Pawn: A Comeback, After 55 Years
description: Looking back on her meteoric movie career, Luise Rainer said, ''I should have done more. I did too little of everything.'' As she spoke, she sighed deeply with regret that was almost tangible.

title: BROADCOM TO BUY A MAKER OF COMMUNICATION SOFTWARE
description: The Broadcom Corporation, a maker of high-speed communications chips, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Altocom Inc. for 1.62 million class B common shares. Altocom, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes software that aids data and fax transmissions over modems. Broadcom's chips are used in devices ranging from personal computers to cable modems and set-top boxes. Broadcom's class B shares, which are not publicly traded, are identical to the class A shares except for certain voting rights. The class A shares closed at $111.50, up $6.625. Broadcom is based in Irvine, Calif.

title: Man With a Past of Racial Hate Surrenders in Day Camp Attack
description: Buford O. Furrow Jr., a white supremacist suspected in the shooting of five people at a Jewish community center here, turned himself in to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Nevada this morning, saying he wanted the attack to send a message to the nation, law-enforcement officials said.

title: How to Spend an Allowance Without Leaving Home
description: JORDAN RAY, age 10, faced a shopping dilemma. Too young to go to the toy store by himself, Jordan, of Brooklyn, had to pester his dad to drive him there whenever he wanted to check out a new video game.

title: Improv Animation's Software Takes Cartoons to New Level
description: Jar Jar Binks aside, it seems only a matter of time before film actors themselves are replaced by pixels. Making that even easier is Improv Technologies, a software company that develops high-end production applications for use in the film, television, multimedia and computer game industries. Its Improv Animation System software took center stage at the Siggraph '99 computer-graphics conference in Los Angeles this week.

title: F.A.A. Will Propose Removing Flammable Insulation From Big Jets
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will propose extensive, delicate modifications on 700 large jets to remove insulation that is covered with a material that can turn small sparks into fatal fires, the agency said today.

description: Warren Beatty, who played a senator crazy enough to speak the truth in the movie ''Bulworth,'' said yesterday that he was considering running for President in 2000.

description: People on California's central coast have decided that gridlock and congestion just do not mesh well with their life style.

description: Whitney Darrow Jr., a witty, gently satiric cartoonist for The New Yorker for 50 years, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Burlington, Vt. He was 89 and lived with his wife, Mildred, in Shelburne, Vt.

description: Shares of Blockbuster Inc. closed unchanged yesterday from the offering price after the video rental chain's $465 million initial public stock offering, reflecting investors' view of the company as a well-known name offering few surprises.

description: Andy Richter, the affable and inscrutably funny sidekick to Conan O'Brien on NBC's increasingly successful ''Late Night,'' will leave the show next spring, he and Mr. O'Brien said yesterday.

title: LIBRARY/JOB-HUNTING SOFTWARE; Resumes That Meet Digital Demands
description: WHEN a management consultant arrived for his interview with a Big Five accounting firm, he was appalled to find that all the bullet points on the resume he had sent by E-mail had morphed into little pencil symbols when the interviewer printed out the document. The candidate had to waste the first few minutes of the meeting explaining that what the hiring manager held in his hand was the result of some sort of technical glitch, not a lack of professionalism.

description: BEFORE electronic navigation equipment became commonly available a few years ago, anyone sailing a midsize boat could have used a few extra arms to handle the helm, check the radar, take compass bearings and plot a course on a paper chart.

description: If you are one of those PC users who is green with envy over the iMac's teal shell, don't fret. Marketing experts around the world are not about to miss the Bondi Blue wave.

title: Mets' Hamilton Is Taking The Big City in Stride
description: Darryl Hamilton was searching for a place to eat breakfast on the Upper East Side of Manhattan yesterday morning when a fellow pedestrian stopped him, stared at him and said: ''Hey, you're Hamilton, the new guy with the Mets. Keep doing what you're doing.''

title: Knicks Get the Man Who Drafted Stockton and Malone
description: Fourteen years ago, when Dave Checketts was president of the Utah Jazz, he relied on a 20-something assistant coach for guidance. Twelve teams had passed on drafting Karl Malone, and Checketts wondered if the Jazz should do the same. But Scott Layden, an assistant coach for Utah, assured Checketts that Malone was the man for the Jazz.

title: Gunman at School To Be Tried as Adult
description: As his schoolmates went back to classes today, 15-year-old T. J. Solomon learned he would be tried as an adult for the May 20 shooting of six students at Heritage High School here.

title: Helping Electronic Devices Make Beautiful Music Together
description: THE music industry is now battling over which technology -- MP3, Real Jukebox or some other scheme -- should become the standard for listeners who want to download small, secure, good- quality audio files from the Internet.

title: MICROSOFT OFFERS ON-LINE DISCOUNT AT COSTCO
description: The Microsoft Corporation said this week that it was offering MSN Internet access at a 40 percent discount to its regular price through the Costco Companies, a leading chain of warehouse-club stores, as fees for online services continue to fall. Three months of service are being offered for $35.97, or $11.99 a month, compared with MSN's regular fee of $19.95 a month, said Deanna Sanford, Microsoft's lead product manager for MSN. Microsoft, the world's biggest software maker, is moving to cut Internet access fees as it competes with the No. 1 on-line service provider, America Online Inc. In recent months Microsoft has formed partnerships with Staples Inc., Micro Center and Lan Plus Inc. to offer free PC's in exchange for MSN Internet service.

title: Returning Gleam To Marble Church; Crumbling Piece of City History Is Getting Its Stones Restored
description: If any church in New York City ought to have its stonework in good repair, it is the one called Marble.

title: BOARD FOR KANSAS DELETES EVOLUTION FROM CURRICULUM
description: The Kansas Board of Education voted yesterday to delete virtually any mention of evolution from the state's science curriculum, in one of the most far-reaching efforts by creationists in recent years to challenge the teaching of evolution in schools.

title: Markets Rebound Sharply, With the Nasdaq Gaining 3%
description: After some early hesitation, stocks bounded higher yesterday as computer-related shares lifted the Nasdaq market by slightly more than 3 percent, its biggest gain in eight weeks.

title: Sports of The Times; A New Era Opens, But Old Issue Lingers
description: THE Knicks' news conference yesterday was heralded as the announcement of a new era. Scott Layden, the respected 41-year-old general manager of the Utah Jazz, would be the Knicks' new executive vice president and general manager.

title: Pushing the Bleeping Envelope: Fox Flirts With Serious Outrage
description: Chris Thompson, the creator of the new television series ''Action,'' a scabrous insider look at the cutthroat world of Hollywood, still recalls his first meeting with Doug Herzog, president of the Fox Entertainment Group.

title: Global Rules Now Apply to Peacekeepers, U.N. Chief Declares
description: Overriding objections from a number of countries that contribute peacekeeping troops to the United Nations, Secretary General Kofi Annan has ordered that all forces operating under the organization's command abide by international laws protecting civilians and governing the conduct of soldiers in war.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column in Sunday Styles on Aug. 1 with a report about the final night of Midsummer Night Swing, a dance series on the plaza of Lincoln Center, misspelled the name of a bakery that provided cakes. It was the Greyston Bakery, not Greystone.

title: U.S. Changes Policy on Searching Suspected Drug Smugglers
description: Faced with lawsuits charging racial bias in body searches, the Customs Service today announced changes intended to revamp how the agency examines thousands of people suspected of smuggling drugs into the United States.

title: Alcoa Seeks To Acquire A Competitor
description: In the second consolidation shock to hit the aluminum industry in two days, Alcoa Inc., the largest producer, said yesterday that it wanted to buy the Reynolds Metals Company, a troubled competitor that is nonetheless the third-largest player.

title: Errors Turn Fund-Raising Coup Into Embarrassment for Giuliani
description: The aides handling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's fund-raising operations bragged of scoring a coup in March when a New Jersey developer, best known for his ties to President Clinton and other national Democrats, agreed to hold a fund-raising event for the Republican Mayor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRAVIN, MICHAEL S.
description: PRAVIN-Michael S. Vice President of Russian Television Network (RTN) died on Tuesday August 10, 1999 in the morning of stomach cancer in Stamford, CT. Mr. Pravin, who immigrated with his family to the U.S. from the former Soviet Union, was one of the first successful businessman in Russian in the post-Glasnost era. In America Mr. Pravin who became a U.S. citizen was co-creator of the first Russian language TV network to serve Russian speaking immigrants to America. Mr. Pravin was V.P. and Programming Director of RTN from 1991 until his death. Under his guidance RTN and later WMNB, which are now services of Sky View World Media Group, became some of the largest ethnic TV services in America and the largest locally originate services in the greater New York metro area. Mr. Pravin is survived by his wife Faina, his two sons Zinovy and Leonid, his father Semen, and his sister Raisa. The funeral services will be held on Thursday at 12PM in Gallagher's Funeral Home on Summer St. in Stamford, CT. A service will also be conducted Thursday night at Pravin's home in Stamford.

title: Homeless Families May Go To City Hospitals Overnight
description: The Giuliani administration plans to begin using rooms at two public hospitals -- North Central Bronx Hospital and Harlem Hospital Center -- to house homeless families overnight if the need arises, officials said yesterday.

title: Clinton to Commute Radicals' Sentences
description: Under continued pressure from minority politicians and human rights activists, President Clinton agreed today to commute the sentences of 16 members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group that was involved in more than 100 bombings of political and military installations in the United States at least 15 years ago.

title: Drought Forces Farmers Into Unprofitable Livestock Sales
description: The endless bawling of calves being separated from their mothers sounded doubly pitiful today here at the auction block. For the cattle ranchers were hurting, too, as they unloaded their livestock at an emergency sale in order to cut their mounting losses from the deepening drought.

title: Look Who's Paying Estate Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: No Indictment Seen In Inquiry on Babbitt
description: An independent counsel has concluded that there is insufficient evidence to seek grand jury indictments in the investigation of Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and his role in the department's rejection of an Indian casino application, several lawyers knowledgeable about the inquiry said yesterday. Article, page A14.

title: For Boards: Yep. Bamboo.
description: Bamboo is being used in objects other than chopsticks, steamers and window blinds. Gary Young, above, has introduced a surfboard made of bamboo laminate around a recyclable foam core. In the late 70's, he made surfboards coated in fiberglass. ''Then there was the oil shortage,'' Mr. Young said. So he switched, first to wood laminate, then to what he calls Lamboo, a bamboo laminate. His 6-foot-4-inch, three-finned Lamboo surfboard ($500) weighs under six pounds. Information: (805) 687-8769.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZMAN, MARY
description: SCHWARTZMAN-Mary. On August 9, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Dear sister of the late Gertrude Solomon. Loving aunt of Bonnie Jaro and Peter Solomon. Services Thursday, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Raising Teacher Salaries
description: To the Editor:

title: The Feel of Cinema, but a Game at Heart
description: VERY few people realize that computer games are not interactive movies. The average non-gamer sees a moving image on a screen, sees some sort of input device, be it a keyboard, mouse or joystick, and figures that two plus two equals four. But new media is never a matter of simple addition. Television does not equal radio plus pictures. Games and movies are as different as newspapers and sky writing. Maybe more so.

title: MetroStars Finally Score, but Still Lose
description: Two plays in the first half tonight underscored the kind of season the MetroStars are having.

title: LOSS AT PAY-TV CONCERN
description: Europe's second-largest pay-television company, British Sky Broadcasting Group P.L.C., reported a loss of $9 million for its fourth quarter as it tried to attract new customers to use its new digital satellite service by subsidizing much of the cost. The company, 40 percent owned by the News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, said it had gained 1.2 million subscribers for the Sky Digital service. In May, B Sky B removed the fee of 320 [pounds] ($515) for the digital set-top box required to view the service. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 22 about efforts by the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to combat illegal gun dealing misspelled the surname of the bureau's director. He is John W. Magaw, not McGaw.

title: HIGHER RATING FOR MEXICO
description: For the first time in nine years, one of the world's leading bond rating agencies has upgraded Mexico's credit standing, bringing it to one notch below investment grade. Moody's Investors Service said it upgraded Mexico partly because of a sharp increase in exports that had enabled the Mexican economy to grow despite a lingering banking crisis. The improved rating will help lower the cost of borrowing on international bond markets by the Mexican Government. Joseph B. Treaster

title: CHECKPOINT TO BUY METO OF GERMANY FOR $265 MILLION

It will also assume debt of $35 million. The deal would double Checkpoint's size, increase its European business and move it into the business of bar code labeling. Meto provides security tags and other ''electronic article surveillance'' systems to retailers. The combined company is expected to have annual revenue of more than $750 million. Checkpoint is based in Thorofare, N.J., and Meto is based in Heppenheim, Germany. The company was spun off in June by Esselte A.B. of Sweden.

But this pop-art melodrama, which today begins a one-week run at the Film Forum with a new 35-millimeter print, isn't half as sentimental as James Dean's weepy portrait of a misunderstood kid. With its garish neon colors, jump-cut editing and use of hand-held cameras, along with a honking rock-and-roll score, the movie connects two very different ''new wave'' movements: French 1960's cinema with its freedom of the camera, and the blaring graffiti-influenced style and nihilistic attitude of the post-punk rock culture.

title: Willful Ignorance on Evolution
description: Deep sadness is the most sensible response to this week's decision by the Kansas Board of Education to downgrade the teaching of evolution in the state's public schools. Religious and cultural conservatives on the board may have thought they were taking a bold stand against a scientific theory they regard as a threat to ''creationist beliefs'' in the origins of the universe and all life within it. But the real losers here will be the very schoolchildren the board members thought they were protecting. If local school boards follow the state board's lead, bright students who might be inclined to pursue scientific careers may now reach college age with little or no exposure to the fundamental organizing principle of modern biology, and all students will be the poorer for lacking scientific literacy.

title: Political Memo; Tax Cut Poses More Risks for Giuliani Than for Mrs. Clinton
description: Across the nation, Congressional Republicans fanned out this week to rally support for the $792 billion tax cut -- the cornerstone of their 2000 election effort -- that President Clinton has pledged to veto. Across New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton, advocating the Democratic line as she prepares for a probable run for Senate, denounced the same bill as a threat to Medicare, Social Security and the nation's financial health.

title: Finding the Saint In a Musical Devil

As president of Bard College, conductor, and now the music director of the American Symphony Orchestra, Mr. Botstein has over the last decade evolved a valuable and lively event, the Bard Music Festival, heaping discussions atop performances, all centered on a single composer, for two overflowing weekends in the summer and a Saturday in the fall.

title: SUPERIOR TELECOM TO CLOSE 3 PLANTS AND CUT 469 JOBS

The closings will result in elimination of 469 jobs, or about 6 percent of the company's total work force. Superior Telecom, based in New York, said it would close plants in Pauline, Kan; Glendale, Ariz., and Tiffin, Ohio. The closings complete a previously announced consolidation within Superior's electrical wire segment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, BARBARA
description: WHITE-Barbara. It is with joy and sadness that the Founders, Trustees, Staff and Artists of the Vermont Studio Center acknowledge the passing of our friend, fellow artist, colleague and benefactor, Barbara White...Joy at having known her and sadness for not being able to know her longer. As a painter and philanthropist, Barbara has been and will continue to be an inspiration to all of us who had the good fortune to know and work with her. Her legacy will also reside in the future generations of artists and writers at the studio center who will benefit from her great generosity through Artists' Fellowships and the creation of two studio buildings, the Barbara White Painting Studios and the Elias Schultz Sculpture Studios (honoring her uncle Eli). Barbara's intelligent, grounded compassion coupled with her clear common sense backed by an unusual sense of personal philanthropic responsibility made her a special friend we will always honor. Her guidance as a long-time VSC Trustee and Board Chair from 1996-1999, her strength of spirit, her strong, colorful paintings and her abiding faith in art and community will be missed by every one of us. We extend our gratitude to Barbara and our hearts to her entire family. Jon Gregg, Louise von Weise VSC Founders Wolf Kahn, Emily Mason VSC Honorary Founders Nadine Goldsmith VSC Board Chair

title: A Weakness For Rockers In Ghoul Makeup
description: Apparently there are no bigger Kiss fans than the band members themselves, who are helpfully involved in a feature-length valentine to their enduring greatness. ''Detroit Rock City'' is a film in which teen-age Kiss worshipers prove that they will do anything, preferably anything nasty, to see the band they love. The idea might have promise if it had even a trace of self-mockery, but no such luck. Sample hagiographic dialogue: ''You know, in 1973 Kiss was opening for Blue Oyster Cult. One year later, Blue Oyster Cult was opening for Kiss!''

title: The Car You Covet: Was It Totaled?

When the car developed steering problems, the nursing student took it to a mechanic, who gave her more bad news. It needed a new transmission and its electrical systems required an overhaul because it had been flooded. The seat belts were not even bolted down, she said.

title: TEXACO PLANS TO INCREASE NUMBER OF JOB CUTS TO 2,500
description: Texaco Inc., the third-largest United States oil company, has increased the number of jobs it will cut to 2,500, or 10 percent of its work force, from the 1,400 it estimated last year. Most of the jobs will be cut by the end of next month, Texaco said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company took a second-quarter charge of $67 million, largely for severance costs for the dismissals, voluntary departures and early retirements. Texaco had about 24,600 employees at the end of last year. It announced job cuts in December, citing the fall in oil prices that began in October 1997. Last month, Texaco said it expected the cost-cutting to save more than $620 million before taxes this year, 38 percent more than originally forecast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASTON, ROBERT
description: EASTON-Robert. A retired engineer at Bell Laboratories and longtime teacher at Fortune Society, died yesterday at his home of a heart attack. He was 68 years old. Mr. Easton was born in Munich, Germany, moved with his family to Chicago where he was in the Hutchins Program at the University of Chicago, and received a Master's Degree from Cal-Tech. He joined Bell Labs in 1954 and specialized in underwater cable development. Mr. Easton was also active on the Board of the Village Community School. In addition to his wife Paula and son Matthew, Mr. Easton is survived by his sister, Eda.

title: Teach Evolution -- And Ask Hard Questions
description: The debate leading the Kansas Board of Education to abolish the requirement for teaching evolution has about the same connection to reality as the play ''Inherit the Wind'' had to the actual Scopes trial. In both cases complex historical, scientific and philosophical issues gave way to the simplifying demands of the morality play. If the schoolchildren of Kansas and other states are to receive a good science education, however, then we'll have to forgo the fun of demonizing each other, take a deep breath and start making a few distinctions.

The Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission agreed to let Nextel pursue plans to buy spectrum owned by Nextwave Personal Communications Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June 1998. title: The Bruce Babbitt Case
description: Not everyone may agree with the reported decision to clear Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt in a case that grew out of the 1996 campaign finance abuses. But at least the conclusion that there is insufficient evidence to indict Mr. Babbitt or Harold Ickes, one of President Clinton's top campaign operatives, was made by an impartial, independent prosecutor. Unfortunately, that was not so for other abuses in Bill Clinton's re-election campaign. A serious failure of this Administration was the stubborn and misguided refusal of Attorney General Janet Reno to allow any other independent counsel to investigate the array of sordid campaign practices, especially the donations from foreign sources.

description: Pepsico Inc. has been ordered to close part of a bottling plant in Amman, Jordan, after three complaints from Government officials about objects found in Pepsi-Cola soft drinks, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: SHOP AT HOME SAYS IT MAY SELL SIX TELEVISION STATIONS
description: Shop at Home Inc. said yesterday that it was considering the sale of some or all of its major-market television stations. The company, based in Nashville, cited the shift in Federal television station ownership regulations for its decision. Last week, the Federal Communications Commission decided to allow broadcast companies to own two stations in one market so long as the market retains at least eight independent stations afterward. Shop at Home owns six television stations in major markets that could be attractive to a network: San Francisco; Boston; Houston; Cleveland; Raleigh, N.C., and Bridgeport, Conn. The company's stock rose $1.28125 a share, to $8.96875.

title: Teammate Collects Dollar Bills for Bradley
description: THE center of the world for the many surprising millions of dollars that Bill Bradley is raising for his Presidential campaign is here on a blah stretch of suburban road in West Orange, N.J., where a sign announces that ''Fund-Raising is the First Primary'' and an avid clutch of underpaid young staff members work on future $1,000-a-person parties in Minneapolis, Louisville and the Upper East Side home of the director Spike Lee. Overseeing it all is one of the few grown-ups in evidence: Richard L. Wright, 56, Mr. Bradley's national finance director and his former basketball teammate at Princeton.

title: The Many Flavors of Love, For Just About Any Taste
description: What could be more delicious than chocolate? Why sex, of course, preferably combined with dreamy romantic love. And in Anne Wheeler's giddy, occasionally dopey but extremely good-hearted comedy ''Better Than Chocolate,'' that combination comes in more flavors than Baskin-Robbins ice cream, with an array of mechanical accessories thrown in to provide extra pleasure for everyone, even those without partners.

title: No Pool and No Room Service, Among Other Things

Her character, Alice Marano, is a spoiled, selfish recent high school graduate who takes a defiant pride in being impulsive, dishonest and uncommitted to anything beyond her own instant gratification. When she and her best friend, Darlene Davis (Kate Beckinsale), decide to go on a short overseas vacation after graduation, Alice persuades Darlene to lie to her family and say they are visiting Hawaii when they are really going to Bangkok, a destination Darlene's family would have vetoed.

title: Dagestan Skirmish Is Big Russian Risk
description: The mountain villages of Dagestan, scene of Russia's latest military clash with Chechen and Dagestani rebels, are extraordinarily remote. The people of the Botlikh region, a high corner on the Chechen-Dagestani border, are unique to their valley and speak their own language. The stark, barren crags of the Great Caucasus mountain range where they live are even more impenetrable than the wooded mountains of Chechnya.

But their most intriguing move of the day was working out Lazaro Borrell, one of four basketball players who defected from Cuba during last month's Olympic qualifying tournament in San Juan, P.R.

Upon returning to India, he served as a member of the Monopoly and Restrictive Trade Practices Commission (MRTP) of the Government of India. title: Making Osama bin Laden's Day

The rhetoric, both in Washington and in the Muslim world, is veering perilously close to shouting ''fire'' in a crowded theater -- so close that it would be prudent to reflect on another terrorist milestone that will pass this year: the 20th anniversary of the sacking and burning of the American Embassy in Pakistan.

title: A Stronger Civilian Review Board

The plan would end the department's policy of ''reinvestigating'' charges of police brutality that have already been investigated and referred to police for disciplinary action by the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: POTOMAC BUYS DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS IN NETHERLANDS
description: The Potomac Electric Power Company has bought 21 natural-gas distribution networks from municipal governments in the Netherlands for $724 million in cash, further expanding in Europe's deregulating energy markets. Potomac, a Washington-based utility with 700,000 electricity customers, made the purchases last month and disclosed them this week in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The systems are owned by about 50 Dutch cities and towns, which run them through four corporations. Potomac already owns a stake in a power plant in the Netherlands. Potomac agreed to lease back the systems to the municipalities for 25 years.

Cervejaria Brahma of Brazil, Latin America's biggest brewing company, by 8.2 percent, to 116.6 million reais, or $62.7 million. The better-than-expected results were achieved despite a decline in beer consumption compared with the year-earlier quarter, when World Cup matches fueled an increase in Brazilian beer drinking. Despite a sluggish economy, Brahma's fortunes are seen improving because of its expected merger with Cia. Antarctica Paulista, Brazil's second-biggest beverage producer.

Some are pieces of beauty and originality. But what makes a tour of this year's exhibitions interesting is not so much the level of artistic quality, which is not, on the whole, overwhelmingly high, but the wonderful variety of relationships produced between art and the urban environment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAEL, LILY
description: MICHAEL-Lily, 87. Died peacefully August 6 at St. Luke's Hospital after suffering a heart attack. Mrs. Michael, a former artist, received her art training at the School of Painting & Sculpture at Columbia University. Mrs. Michael was a member of the American Abstract Artists Association, one of the oldest abstract groups in the United States, and the Tirca Karlis Gallery in Provincetown, MA. She was also a member of Gallery ''256,'' a nationally known association of artists which started as a summer art colony in Provincetown in 1953. She participated in numerous exhibitions throughout the U.S. and abroad and was an avid collector of African tribal and pre-Columbian art. Beloved wife of Charles, she is survived by her daughter, Marsha, two grandchildren, loving cousins, other relatives and friends. Burial at sea will be held privately.

title: ICG SAYS IT IS SELLING SATELLITE UNIT TO ATC TELEPORTS
description: ICG Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its satellite services unit to ATC Teleports Inc. for about $100 million. The unit, which employs about 90 people, includes ICG's Maritime Telecommunications Network, a provider of communications and other broadcast capabilities to the cruise industry, the Navy and offshore oil and gas platforms. ICG, based in Englewood, Colo., provides local telephone services to businesses. It had revenue of $397.6 million in 1998. ATC Teleports is a unit of the American Tower Corporation, which is based in Boston. American Tower owns about 5,000 wireless communications towers in the United States.

title: Expert Guilty in Scheme to Steal Tiffany Glass From Tombs

title: In a Thriving Metropolis, All Is Well With the World

title: DAEWOO TO KEEP ONLY AUTOS

''All Daewoo units that can be separated from the group will be spun off and sold by the end of this year,'' Lee Hun Jai, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Commission, said. ''In the end, Daewoo will keep only its automobile-related businesses after the restructuring.'' Daewoo has debts totaling about 60 trillion won ($49.9 billion).

title: JUNK RATING FOR COLOMBIA
description: Already reeling from its worst economic crisis in 70 years, Colombia has had its credit rating bumped down two notches by Moody's Investors Service, to a level below investment grade. The action means the country will have to pay higher interest rates on new foreign loans, but since the Government has already completed borrowing for this year, no immediate impact is expected. The Colombian economy contracted by 5.9 percent in the first quarter of this year, deficits have been growing, and negotiations for a $3 billion credit line from the International Monetary Fund have just begun.

title: Protecting Rich Bankrupts

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERENZIO, PETER B.
description: TERENZIO-Peter B., Sr. Age 83 of Moorings Park, Naples, FL and Madison, CT, died Thursday, August 12, 1999 in Florida. He was the husband of Eileen Alma (Mosher) Terenzio. Mr. Terenzio was born March 6, 1916 in New York City, son of the late Vincent Marianna (Piantino) Terenzio. Mr. Terenzio was a veteran of World War II serving in the Army Air Corps as a Captain. He attended Yale University from 1934-'37 and obtained his Judicial Degree from UCONN in 1940. Mr. Terenzio passed the Connecticut Bar Exam in 1941 and had a practice in New Haven from 1945-'48. He then went on to receive his Master's from Northwestern University in Chicago in Hospital Administration. He was the Executive Vice President and Director of Roosevelt Hospital in New York City from 1953-'76. In 1976, he became the President of The Hospital Bureau Incorporated in Pleasantville, NY. During his career, Mr. Terenzio served as President of the American Hospital Association, President of the New York State Hospital Association and President of the New York City Public Board of Health. In addition to his executive roles, Mr. Terenzio was a professor at Columbia University. He also taught at The New School in New York City and Pace College in Briarcliff Manor, NY. He continued teaching for a number of years after retiring. Besides his wife, Mr. Terenzio is survived by one brother, Joseph V. Terenzio of Miami, FL, two sons, Vincent J. Terenzio of Clinton, CT, Peter B. Terenzio Jr. of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, two daughters, Mary Ellen Alecci of Pleasantville, NY, Nancy T. Britton of Madison, CT and seven grandchildren. The funeral procession will leave the Swan Funeral Home, 825 Boston Post Road, Madison, CT, Monday at 10:30 AM followed by a Funeral Liturgy at St. Margaret Church, Madison, at 11 am. Burial will be in West Cemetery, Madison. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 188, North Haven, CT 06473-0188 and/or The American Parkinson's Disease Association, Inc, 1250 Hylan Boulevard, Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305-1946.

title: The Vacation, A Measure Of Behavior And Values
description: Once upon a time the rich played when the mood struck, and almost everyone else worked their farms and confined relaxation to the Sabbath. Although August is now established as prime vacation time, few Americans realize that their treasured paid vacation is a fairly recent phenomenon. The very concept reflects ever changing American ideas about work, leisure and the markers of middle-class status.

title: Corrections

Holyfield, the promoter Don King and television executives met in June, not on Thursday, to discuss a rematch with Lennox Lewis. Their first fight, to unify the heavyweight title, ended in a draw. A date for the rematch has not been announced.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM PLANS SEPARATE CHEMICAL UNIT
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, an oil, natural gas and chemical company, is forming a separate company for its specialty chemical operations, which expects to issue a new class of common stock to employees. The new company, the Occidental Industrial Specialty Chemicals Corporation, will have about $600 million in assets and 700 employees. While it will remain an Occidental unit, its operations will be ''separate and distinct'' from the parent's, Occidental said. Analysts say Occidental may eventually sell the specialty chemicals business to investors.

title: A Worsening Crisis Over Taiwan
description: With tensions mounting dangerously across the Taiwan Strait, both sides need to step back and consider the risks they are courting -- Taipei by its reckless declarations and Beijing by its unacceptable military threats. Taiwan and the mainland have escalated the crisis by repeatedly flying warplanes in the direction of each other's territory. Chinese publications now regularly report on Beijing's preparedness to assault Taiwanese-held territory, and Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, holds to his provocative demand that China deal with his island as a separate sovereign state.

description: The Dana Corporation, the world's largest maker of light-truck axles, bought the closely held Innovative Manufacturing Inc., a metal-parts maker, expanding its business in components for golf carts, lawn mowers and other outdoor power equipment. Terms were not disclosed. Innovative Manufacturing employs fewer than 50 people at a plant in the Columbus, Ohio, suburb of Blacklick. The company makes machined parts for Dana's Spicer Outdoor Power Equipment Components division plant in Fredericktown, Ohio. Dana has been reorganizing its plants that make parts for and manufacture outdoor power equipment.

title: PENTAIR, A TOOLS MAKER, IS MAKING ACQUISITION
description: Pentair Inc., a diversified maker of professional tools, agreed yesterday to acquire the air power tools unit of Chicago-based Falcon Building Products Inc. for $460 million in cash. Pentair said the acquisition of the DeVilbiss Air Power Company will increase the annual sales of its professional tools and equipment business to $1.5 billion and raise its total sales to around $3 billion. DeVilbiss, based in Jackson, Tenn., makes air compressors, pressure washers and generators. The company had sales of $470 million in the 12 months ended June 30. Falcon Building Products is 90 percent owned by the Bahrain-based investment firm Investcorp.

title: Israel's History Textbooks Replace Myths With Facts
description: Few ideas are as deeply ingrained in Israeli culture as the one summed up by the Hebrew phrase ''meatim mul rabim,'' or ''the few against the many.'' Schoolchildren have long been taught that the Jews have always been surrounded by enemies and that their victory over five Arab states in the 1948 War of Independence was a near miracle of David-and-Goliath proportions.

description: As fighting continued in southern Russia, the new Prime Minister today threatened to launch air strikes against Islamic militants in the breakaway republic of Chechnya, risking a widening of the seven-day-old conflict in a neighboring region, Dagestan.

title: Rawalpindi Journal; Women Still Segregated, but Now at Grad School
description: The young women, some stylishly dressed in high-heeled sandals and colorful tunic-and-pants ensembles, others shrouded completely in black, spilled out of the gleaming white Victorian mansion that houses Pakistan's first and only publicly financed graduate school for women.

title: Racist Shootings Test Limits Of Health System, and Laws
description: The mental health system in Washington State got an extensive look at Buford O. Furrow Jr. in the months before he admitted to having opened fire on schoolchildren in a Jewish community center and having killed a postal worker in Los Angeles on Tuesday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: FIRSTCITY FINANCIAL IS SELLING MORTGAGE OPERATIONS
description: The Firstcity Financial Corporation said yesterday that it planned to sell its mortgage operations, saying the business did not ''fit the company's long-term strategy.'' Firstcity, which is based in Houston, said that for the last nine months, it had been exploring strategic alternatives for its mortgage business, which operates through its Firstcity Financial Mortgage Corporation and Firstcity Capital Corporation units. Firstcity also said that its Financial Mortgage unit was in default on certain lending agreements. The company added that it was trying to negotiate with its lenders to waive the default or amend the lending agreement.

title: DISTILLER IN TAKEOVER TALKS
description: The maker of Famous Grouse whisky, Highland Distillers P.L.C., said it had been approached by a potential buyer, sending its shares up 26 percent, their biggest one-day gain. The approach ''may or may not lead to an offer,'' the Glasgow-based company said in a statement. Highland, which has a market value of $:487.6 million ($786 million), declined to identify its suitor or comment further.

title: A Vote for Gun Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Should Recording Calls Be Illegal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BREEN, DANIEL
description: BREEN-Daniel. August 14th, 1998. It's been a long, hard year for all of us without you. Doing my best to watch over Tom and the rest of the family. Love, Howard

title: No-Hitter Lifts Toms River
description: Casey Gaynor, who earned glory with his Toms River East teammates in winning the Little League World Series last summer, excelled again last night at the Eastern Regionals.

title: Man Is Charged in 1958 Killing of a New Jersey Officer
description: Putting an end to an investigation that has spanned four decades, a Pennsylvania man was arrested Thursday night in the 1958 killing of a police officer in Rahway, N.J.

title: FIGHT FOR GROUPE FOREX ENDS
description: A bidding brawl for Groupe Forex Inc. ended when the Boise Cascade Corporation said it would not further sweeten its offer for the Quebec maker of oriented strand board, a plywood substitute. Boise Cascade's withdrawal cleared the way for a rival, the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, to buy Groupe Forex for $33 (Canadian) a share. Boise Cascade had twice topped previous Louisiana-Pacific offers but said its own $32-a-share offer, made last week, was fair.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO WEAKENS. The euro slipped against the dollar on news that July's increase in United States producer prices was less than had been expected. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0564, down from $1.0669 on Thursday.

title: Journal; What Tony Soprano Could Teach Bill Clinton
description: At this late date in the Bill Clinton melodrama, it's no scoop that the man has long been in serious need of a good shrink. If anything, the compulsive lying may be the least of his aberrations. I'm still amazed that so little has been made of this curious sentence in the Starr report: ''The longer conversations [between the President and Monica Lewinsky] often occurred after their sexual contact.''

title: TAG AVIATION IS SET TO PURCHASE WAYFARER
description: TAG Aviation USA Inc. will buy Wayfarer Aviation Inc., a closely held aircraft-services company, as it seeks to expand across the United States and Europe. Terms were not disclosed, though closely held TAG will pay less than $20 million in cash, said Carole Helms, a Wayfarer spokeswoman. The combined company will have as much as $300 million in annual revenue, and about 130 aircraft at more than 50 sites worldwide. The two companies provide management, maintenance, personnel, sales and charter services for corporate aircraft. Founded in 1956 by the Rockefeller family to handle its airplanes, Wayfarer is based at Westchester County Airport in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Iowa Underdogs Vying to Bear Standard of the Religious Right
description: Becky Bell, a corn and soybean farmer from Malvern, Iowa, bounded up to Patrick J. Buchanan at the State Fair here today with words of encouragement on the eve of the Republican Party's straw poll.

title: Appeals Court Says Residents Can Challenge Plans for Park
description: A state appeals court has ruled that a group of Brooklyn residents can challenge city plans that would transform Dreier-Offerman Park, near Coney Island.

title: On the Internet, Balancing Free Flow of Data and Profits
description: Imagine a day when you get on the Web, and every time you check a stock price, read an article or get a phone number, some hidden cookie charges a fee to your credit card. Then imagine that you've been running a nice business compiling a directory of services in your area when suddenly your list appears on the Web, free.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-5

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SBARRO INC., Melville, N.Y., a national chain of family-style cafeteria-type Italian restaurants, said shareholders had approved its proposal to merge into a newly formed entity owned by Sbarro family members. Nonfamily shareholders will receive $28.25 a share in cash for about 13.5 million shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFA, MAY S.
description: JAFFA-May S. On August 13, 1999 in her 102nd year. Beloved wife of the late Charles Jaffa. Devoted mother of Carol J. and Maurice Feinberg, the late Rose J. Snyder and Howard E. Jaffa. Adored grandmother of Margaret Scully, Nancy Feinberg Tobin, Hope Schroy and David Feinberg. Sprightly great-grandmother of Jason, Gregory, Brian, Jacob, Rebecca, Charles, Nina and James. Friends may call 7-9 PM Saturday, August 14, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, with services 9:30 AM Sunday.

title: Parcells Is Planning to Have Jets Do Things by the Numbers
description: Nothing makes Bill Parcells as uncomfortable as having things go a little too well, so perhaps it's predictable that the coach of the Jets was talking about five concerns of equal importance as his team prepared for its exhibition opener tonight at Green Bay.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article in some editions on Thursday about the Fifth Avenue apartment of Gale Hayman, the cosmetics entrepreneur, reversed the identities of Ms. Hayman and Milly de Cabrol, her decorator. Ms. Hayman was seated, and Ms. Cabrol was standing.

title: Sports of The Times; Old Man of Medinah Has Shot to Win P.G.A.
description: WITH a red 5 next to his name on the scoreboard, Hale Irwin was walking to the 17th tee yesterday when a voice in the grandstand yelled, ''You're not 50.''

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Mexicans in U.S. Say Wiring Money Can Be Costly
description: Like millions of Mexicans, Miriam Sagaon Rojas worked for a time as a factory laborer in the United States to earn dollars when things were hard back home. And like millions of Mexicans, she dutifully sent some of her earnings back to her parents, using a Western Union wire transfer.

title: Sports of The Times; For Graf, A Time To Thaw Out
description: IN the early morning yesterday, New York time, came word that Steffi Graf was announcing her retirement from tennis after 17 years.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The teamsters' union is as free of corruption as any great institution. ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, MARGARET (MAGGIE)
description: FISCHER - Margaret (Maggie). The Saltaire community is grieved beyond measure at the sudden and tragic passing of Maggie Fischer. Her brightness, compassion and gentle nature were a joy in all our lives. She leaves us with memories we shall always cherish. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Maggie's parents, Bob and Mary, her brother Chris, and all her family and friends. Mayor and Trustees Village of Saltaire

description: To the Editor:
