description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, BERNARD
description: HIRSCHHORN-Bernard. My father and my friend, whose voice I heeded to the end. With gratitude, Herbert

title: For Iridium, A Quick Trip Back to Earth
description: Just eight months after it started an ambitious satellite telephone service that promised to communicate ''with anyone, anytime, virtually anywhere in the world,'' Iridium L.L.C. has filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Whitman Turns to Reno In Bid to Fill Trooper Post
description: Trying to end her prolonged search for a new commander for the New Jersey State Police, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman met today with United States Attorney General Janet Reno and asked Justice Department officials to set aside the conflict-of-interest concerns that have prevented an F.B.I. supervisor in New York City from accepting the job.

title: Should Recording Calls Be Illegal?
description: To the Editor:

title: INDONESIAN CEMENT TROUBLE
description: Talks to reorganize about $1.3 billion in loans at Indonesia's third-largest cement maker, Semen Cibinong, collapsed. The company was reportedly close to a deal with creditors -- including ABN Amro Bank, Chase Manhattan, Deutsche Bank and the Export Import Bank of the United States -- when the company told bankers that up to $250 million was missing from its books. Confidence in Indonesia's prospects has already been undermined by news that a bank under Government control paid $70 million to a company connected to Indonesia's ruling party to recover loans already guaranteed by the Government.

title: Corrections
description: The Residential Real Estate column yesterday, about the renovation of a town house at 25-27 Beekman Place into condominiums, misspelled the given name of the architect. He is Constantin Wickenburg, not Constantine.

title: KOREAN BANK INQUIRY
description: The South Korean Government will investigate whether executives and major shareholders at five banks closed last year accepted bribes for extending risky loans. The state-owned Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation said the inquiry will focus on violations of lending rules and the origins of the private holdings of bank officials and shareholders. The Government plans to expand its investigation into debt-ridden securities firms and insurance companies closed last year.

title: Food-Stamp Decline Is a Real Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: Youths Charged With Slashing Neck of Boy, 8, in His Queens Yard
description: Two 12-year-old Queens boys have been arrested and charged with slashing the neck of an 8-year-old boy as he played in the front yard of his family's home in Long Island City, the police said.

title: Bossa Nova Updated and Spiced With Hints of Bach
description: Trio da Paz, a group of Brazilian jazz musicians based in New York, sounds like an updating of Baden Powell's sound in the later Bossa Nova era of the mid-1960's: guitar-based, fleet-fingered music that connects jazz technique with Brazilian rhythms.

title: Pettitte Plays Hardball on a Softball Kind of Night
description: Andy Pettitte hardly gazed at the giant scoreboard in left-center field while pitching against the Minnesota Twins last night, even though the numbers were incredibly positive for the Yankees. Pettitte kept his eyes mostly on the grass and rarely moved away from the pitcher's rubber. He had to keep working, no matter how lopsided the score.

title: LOSS AT LOEWEN
description: The funeral chain Loewen Group, operating under bankruptcy protection laws in the United States and Canada, reported a second-quarter loss of $105.3 million, including $95.8 million of charges related to its revamping plan. A year earlier, the big operator of funeral homes and cemeteries earned $10.2 million. Its chairman, John Lacey, said the company, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, had an operating profit before interest and revamping charges of $28.4 million. Operating profit a year earlier was $51.2 million.

title: Beyond Gangster Rap: Getting Along Together
description: Artistic undergrounds usually grow in dim, cool corners. The California experimental hip-hop scene, which emerged in the early 1990's as an alternative to gangster rap, has yet to prove its ability to take root nationwide. But the three groups that performed as part of the Word of Mouth tour at Tramps on Wednesday have cultural horticulturists enthusing about the new breed.

title: Plants and Trees at Arboretum Struggle to Survive Without Rain
description: At the United States National Arboretum, a mainstay on Washington's cultural landscape for more than 70 years, the distress signs are everywhere.

title: Political Notes; Borough Chief Weighs Run for Mayor
description: With the 2001 municipal elections already on the political horizon, there is no shortage of officials placing their names in circulation as potential candidates for mayor. The latest is C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan Borough President, who is joining at least a half-dozen other political figures who are in some stage of mulling over their would-be candidacies.

title: Producer Price Index Numbers Ease Investor Fears
description: The stock and bond markets surged yesterday after the Government released a reassuring report that showed a modest increase in prices at the wholesale level in July, easing investor concerns about inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORE, CHESTER A.
description: GORE-Chester A. 8/14/18-4/19/97. We miss you on your Birthday and everyday. Love, Eloise and Gerie

title: Age Rules as Medinah Turns Cuddly
description: On a day when the leaders shot in the 60's, a player born in the 50's led the way.

title: Revised Military Guidelines Fail to Quell Gay Concerns
description: The Pentagon today announced its first major revision of guidelines for its ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy on homosexuals in the military, including a new requirement that commanders seek approval from senior civilian officials at the Pentagon before opening certain types of investigations of troops who acknowledge that they are gay.

title: Religion Journal; Dalai Lama to Officiate at Sacred Rite of Initiation
description: Since arriving in New York this week, the Dalai Lama has maintained a busy intellectual schedule, devoted mainly to many hours of public teachings.

title: Should Recording Calls Be Illegal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANZONE, JOSEPH A., M.D.
description: LANZONE-Joseph A., M.D. On August 11, 1999 of Point Lookout, New York. Formerly of North Valley Stream, New York. Beloved husband of the late Wanda; loving father of Francis J., M.D., John A., M.D., Theresa C., M.D., Joan A., D.D.S., Wanda J., D.M.D. and Joseph A., M.D.; loving and devoted grandfather of eleven grandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th Street, Garden City, NY Friday 79PM, Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10:30AM, Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, Point Lookout. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Donations to the Make A Wish Foundation appreciated.

title: CORT BUSINESS SERVICES ACCEPTS HIGHER OFFER
description: The Cort Business Services Corporation, a furniture renter in Fairfax, Va., that agreed to a buyout offer from a management-led group in March, accepted a higher bid of $376 million from the group after a big shareholder criticized the price. Cort's board supported the offer of $25 in cash and $3 in preferred stock plus assumed debt even though it has an all-cash offer of $28 a share from the closely held Brook Furniture Rental Inc. Fund managers at Baltimore-based T. Rowe Price Associates Inc., the second-largest holder of Cort shares, are studying the new offer and weighing whether to drop their opposition, a spokesman, Edward F. Giltenan, said.

title: Flawed Pain-Relief Bill
description: In a misguided effort to legislate against physician-assisted suicide, a bill awaiting action in the House Judiciary Committee could discourage doctors from providing aggressive pain relief to patients with terminal illnesses. Last year's version of the bill, which was worse, would have allowed the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration to investigate and punish any doctor who prescribed drugs with the intent of assisting in a patient's suicide. That bill would have caused doctors to withhold medication for fear of Federal sanctions.

title: A Reynolds Bid From Left Field That Is Higher Than Alcoa's
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, it seems, is now officially in play.

title: Satellite Event Begins Today
description: Professional tennis begins its annual stint in the Bronx today. The GHI Bronx Tennis Classic, a satellite tournament for men and women, gets under way in Crotona Park with the qualifying event. The event, which does not charge for admission, also offers free lessons each day from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. on a first-come, first-served basis.

title: Parody on the Web Mocks Giuliani's Senate Hopes
description: At first click, it appears to be the official Web site of Rudolph W. Giuliani's United States Senate campaign.

title: China's Leader Flexing Muscle on Several Fronts at Once
description: These are politically perilous days for President Jiang Zemin. Yet he is deliberately fighting on several fronts at once, using an atmosphere of crisis to exert his personal authority in new ways.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Good News on Inflation Sends Markets Up Sharply

title: Editorial Observer; Adolf Eichmann's Diary, and His Fading Echo
description: Adolf Eichmann, hanged by Israel in 1962 for organizing the Nazi deportation of millions of Jews eastward to the gas chambers, was by his own description the epitome of the bureaucratic mass murderer. This week the German daily Die Welt began publishing excerpts from a recently discovered diary Eichmann wrote during his imprisonment. Eichmann details a life of obedience -- to his father, to the military and to his Nazi superiors, a life in which apparently even the prospect of freedom to choose his own path left him panicked and bereft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERENZIO, PETER
description: TERENZIO-Peter. Greater New York Hospital Association regrets the passing of Peter Terenzio, former Executive Vice President of Roosevelt Hospital. Mr. Terenzio, a true visionary, was deeply committed to improving the health care of all New Yorkers and former Chairman of Greater New York Hospital Association. He was influential in the expansion of ambulatory care to children and one of the first to recognize the critical importance of research in teaching hospitals. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. Mark J. Mundy, Chairman Kenneth A. Raske, President Greater N.Y. Hospital Association

title: PARKER DRILLING WILL SELL 13 ONSHORE RIGS
description: The Parker Drilling Company agreed yesterday to sell 13 of its American land-drilling rigs to the Unit Corporation for $40 million cash and $8.4 million in Unit shares. Parker Drilling, based in Tulsa, Okla., said the sale included all of its United States onshore drilling assets except for those in Alaska. The company said it wanted to focus more on international land-drilling markets and on the American offshore market. After the sale closes, Parker Drilling will have 83 rigs worldwide. Seven of the rigs to be sold are in the Rocky Mountains, three are in Louisiana and three are in Texas. Unit, also of Tulsa, said the acquisition would open up a new market in the Rockies and expand its Gulf Coast operations.

title: Food-Stamp Decline Is a Real Concern
description: To the Editor,

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Saturday about the new anchors for the CNN business-news program ''Moneyline News Hour'' misstated the year that both CNN and the program were founded. It was 1980, not 1984.

title: Bush Takes Campaign Door to Door on Eve of Straw Poll
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas swept into the home of Bob and Shirley Lester in this town amid the cornfields of central Iowa tonight to partake in a tradition of Presidential politics in this state: one-on-one campaigning.

title: Investing the Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: L. L. Bean Casts About For Ways To Grow; New Clothing Lines; Updated Web Site; More Retail Stores
description: First came the indoor trout pond. Then there was the barnlike addition devoted to children's clothes and accessories. Now comes what is perhaps the ultimate sign that L. L. Bean, the 87-year-old arbiter of what's what in rugged outerwear, is going after cosseted baby boomers in a big way: the company's Maine Hunting Shoe, its first product and essential icon, has been revamped to make it more comfortable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLASFELD, ICHABOD
description: KLASFELD-Ichabod. The Board of Directors and Staff of NYC & Company and its division, the New York Convention & Visitors Bureau, extend their deepest sympathy to their colleague and friend David Klasfeld on the passing of his father, Ichabod. Our condolences to his entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, JOHN BASSETT
description: LANE-John Bassett. Age 89, died August 11, 1999 in New Canaan, CT. A long time resident of Riverside, CT, he retired as Director of Real Estate Administration from the Sperry Rand Corp. He was a member of the Association of ExMembers of the Squadron A, the Riverside Yacht Club and vestry of St. Paul's Church, Riverside. His wife, Katherine Manning Lane, died in 1977. He is survived by two daughters, Barbara Wilson of Chatham, NJ, Josephine Vanderhoeven of Santa Fe, NM, five grandchildren and four brothers, William H. Lane, Jr. of Naples, FL, Edward V.Z.Lane and Alfred A. Lane of Palm City, FL, and Francis C. Lane of Reidsville, NC. A memorial service will be held Friday, August 20, 11:30AM, at St. Paul's Church in Riverside. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. Paul's Church or a charity of your choice.

title: Victory by Women's Team Is Last Hurrah for Britain
description: The centrifugal tendencies in modern Britain, exemplified by new Parliaments in Scotland and Wales, have now reached the bridge tables. In future international championships, England, Scotland and Wales will have separate teams.

title: Graf, Still Near Top of Tennis, Leaves It Behind
description: Down and almost out of her 1999 French Open final, Steffi Graf narrowed her eyes, squared her shoulders, stalked to her changeover chair at the tennis tournament and gave herself a terse pep talk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, BARBARA WHITE
description: FISHMAN-Barbara White. With deep sorrow, the Board of Trustees, faculty, students and staff of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, mourn the death of Trustee Barbara White Fishman. A gifted artist, a devoted alumna of The Cooper Union School of Art, she endowed visiting art scholars and art critics, greatly enriching the education of our art students. We will miss her friendship, counsel and inspiration. Robert A. Bernhard, Chairman John Jay Iselin, President

title: Dawdling on Judges
description: A year has gone by since Chief Justice William Rehnquist, deploring the backlog in untried cases, pleaded with the Senate to act in a timely and orderly way on President Clinton's nominees for the Federal bench. In response, the Senate began to make progress in reducing judicial vacancies. But its recent record is indefensible.

title: Fiddling With Mozart in Salzburg
description: It would be too much to say, as one is tempted to do on the day after a spectacular solar event swept over the German-speaking lands, that Mozart has been eclipsed at the Salzburg Festival. But it seems that as the festival has grown more adventurous in both repertory and style of presentation in recent years, under the leadership of Gerard Mortier, Mozart, a native son of the city and long the mainstay of its cultural if not its commercial life, has at least had some problems.

title: Pullout From Panama and Venezuelan Reluctance Leave Gap in U.S. Air War on Drugs
description: The withdrawal of the United States from military bases in Panama, combined with the refusal of Venezuela's new Government to let its airspace be used for American surveillance and pursuit flights, has created a huge gap in regional drug interdiction that trafficking cartels are exploiting, American officials say.

title: In Eye of China-Taiwan Storm, an Island Is Calm
description: If military conflict breaks out between China and Taiwan any time soon, military experts say, it is as likely to begin on this little island as anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALORT, ANTHONY F.
description: SALORT-Anthony F., on August 13th. Dear husband of Marie. Devoted father of Dorinda Zaloom. Adoring grandfather of Chloe and Colette. Beloved father-in-law of Richard. Reposing at the HornDannecker Funeral Home, 336 W. 23rd St., Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial wil be from the Guardian Angel Church, 10th Ave. and W. 21st St., Monday at 10 AM. Burial to be private.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  UNGER, FREDA
description: UNGER-Freda. August 14, 1902July 31, 1970. Dear mother, it's been so long. You are always so missed and so loved. Happy Birthday. Dian

title: A Third Workout Planned for Borrell
description: Two private practice sessions with Lazaro Borrell have not been enough for the Nets. Intrigued by the athleticism and shooting ability of the Cuban small forward, the Nets have invited the 6-foot-8-inch Borrell back for a third workout on Monday.

title: An Agreement and a Division Among the Yankees
description: Eight days have passed since Chad Curtis criticized Derek Jeter for what he considered inappropriate behavior during a nasty brawl between the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners. After tense talks that night and another discussion that included an apology from Curtis two days later, the Yankees stressed that the disagreement was history. But, apparently, there is still a chill between the players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONSTADT, ROBERT
description: KRONSTADT - Robert. Passed away on August 12 from complications from Alzheimers. He was 79 years old. He is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years, Sylvia, and his loving sons, Michael and Daniel. His family and friends will miss him dearly. Services private, memorial to be held later. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The Adelphi Breast Cancer Support Program.

title: Tracing Twisted Path of Pistol Used in California Killing
description: The Glock semiautomatic pistol that Buford O. Furrow Jr. used to kill a mail carrier after shooting five people at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles was sold last year by an unlicensed vendor at a gun show near the north Idaho compound of the Aryan Nations, the neo-Nazi group to which Mr. Furrow belonged, according to interviews.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about the artist Keith Piper's show at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo misstated the given name of a boxer featured in his work. He is Mike Tyson, not Joe Tyson.

title: National Parks: Crowded Now, and Crowded Then
description: This summer, as in many years in the recent past, the press is reporting on the overcrowding in the national parks: more traffic jams, congested campgrounds, longer lines. Yes, the problem is perhaps more acute than ever before, but the parks have a long history of struggling to provide the solitary beauty of nature to crowds of eager visitors.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, ANN B.
description: POWELL-Ann B. On our 50th anniversary golden memories remain. Our love, your class and wit, then, now and forever. Love, Harry

title: GPU Buyback Program
description: GPU Inc. said this week that it would reinstate a $350 million stock buyback program that had been suspended after $102 million in shares had been repurchased. The company, a utility holding company in Morristown, N.J., cited a recent decline in its stock price and concerns about possible future rate reductions as reasons for reinstating the stock repurchase plan. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. Shares of GPU hit a 52-week low this week on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: After Years of Division, Cherokees Get New Leader
description: As a member of the Cherokee Nation and a student of its history, Chad Smith need only look to his family tree to find a famed leader of his tribe. Redbird Smith, his great-grandfather, was a patriot who went to prison rather than accept the Federal policy that deprived the Cherokees of millions of acres.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Vienna Hop
description: The taffeta waltz skirt is back, without the Johann Strauss formality, a casual look the designer Claire McCardell pioneered in the 40's. Today's full skirts rustle over the dance floor beneath laid-back tank tops and sweaters. Designs by Steven Stolman of Southampton, whose $325 skirts are built on a waistband, were the rage at the town's recent hospital benefit. Other designers use drawstring waists (center left), a bit risky for exuberant dancing.

title: August 8-14; India Shoots Down A Pakistani Jet
description: An Indian jet fighter shot down a propeller-driven Pakistani naval surveillance plane, killing its 16 passengers and sending the subcontinent into yet another moment of nail-biting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKUN, MAXWELL
description: OKUN-Maxwell Of New York City, died August 9, 1999. Mr Okun was pre-deceased by his loving wife Sally J. Okun. He is survived by many nieces and nephews and will be missed by all who knew him.

title: A Pirate Radio Station's Crusade Is Stepping on the Jazz
description: Some jazz aficionados in Brooklyn have discovered that when they try to tune their radios to their favorite music, all they can hear are religious stories from Lubavitch Hasidic leaders. Listeners have complained that a pirate radio broadcast at 87.9 FM is interfering with the reception of WBGO, a Newark public radio station that plays jazz at 88.3 FM. The Federal Communications Commission is investigating.

title: Lives; The Zen of Alzheimer's
description: Mom died of Alzheimer's yesterday. As I sat by her hospital bed, watching her body slowly lose its color, a blasphemous thought struck me: in many ways, her disease had been a blessing.

title: The Wonder of It: The West Just So
description: CARLETON WATKINS would rank among the great enigmas of late 19th-century American art even if his life weren't so mysterious and sad. The pictures he made of scenic glories in the West during the 1860's and 70's have been the sublime standard for generations of landscape photographers. Ansel Adams, for one, worked in his long shadow.

title: Going Behind the Music With 60's Band
description: At the beginning of VH1's first original movie, ''Sweetwater,'' a man fights off a television reporter trying to get him to talk about his band, which played before half a million people at Woodstock 30 years ago and then disappeared. Why won't he open up? ''Because,'' he scolds the reporter, ''a whatever-happened-to piece with a balding, middle-aged construction foreman telling war stories has humiliation written all over it.''

title: Sharing a Staff With a Ghost
description: You were recently brought in to replace the head of a department who was let go because of conflict with upper management. Despite your predecessor's rocky relations with her supervisors, she was popular with her staff. Now you're faced with trying to motivate a group of workers demoralized by the loss of their leader, one or two of whom, you suspect, regard you as the enemy. Do you address the problem or ignore it and hope everyone eventually adjusts?

title: Increasingly, Mayor Asked To React to Clinton Actions
description: Touching on cases of sedition and espionage that could be of concern to Puerto Rican and Jewish voters in next year's race for the United States Senate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he did not have enough information to form an opinion on President Clinton's decision to commute the sentences of 16 members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group that carried out bombings in the 1970's and 80's.

title: Deciding on the Manager, and Making It Work
description: Always candid and first class, Phil Garner said the Milwaukee Brewers were justified in firing him as their manager last week. The same cannot be said for all decisions to fire managers or general managers, or to retain them. This season offers various evidence of that reality.

title: Stranger Than Most Fiction

title: Bush Triumphs In a Straw Poll By Iowa G.O.P.

Grandmother to Mara. Friend to all. She devoted her life to working with children of all ages and spent the last 42 years at the Bronx House Jewish Community Center where she touched the lives of countless numbers of children. She continued to work part time up until the end of February of this year. Known for her vibrant personality and love of life, she will be remembered for her great kindness, her wisdom and understanding, her laughter and most of all for her endless generosity of spirit. Those she touched will never forget her. Because of her strength of character she fought the good fight. She will be loved and remembered always. title: MUSIC; A Venerable Idyll Of Opera Enters A New Era
description: THE Glyndebourne Festival, now 65 years old, was and is an operatic institution unlike any other: an inspired, inspiring product of initial eccentricity and high professional exigence. It began in 1934, with six performances of ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' and six of ''Cosi Fan Tutte.'' The next year ''Die Entfuhrung aus dem Serail'' and ''Die Zauberflote'' were added, and Glyndebourne was on its way (though interrupted after six seasons by the outbreak of war). It has been influential both in the international repertory and in summer companies that have things in common with it (among them, the Santa Fe Opera, the Opera Theater of St. Louis and Glimmerglass). Glyndebourne itself remains special.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, BARBARA WHITE
description: FISHMAN-Barbara White. Artist and Philanthropist. Ms. White's career as an art director began shortly after her graduation from Cooper Union. She was a designer in an architectural office, designed fabrics for a textile company and worked at CBS in her early career designing advertisements for the network. Later, as an art director, she designed album covers and liner notes for CBS records for everything from pop to classical. Ms. White won many awards for her work from AIGA, The Art Directors' Club of New York and had her work shown in Graphis magazine. Her later career experience was in pharmaceutical advertising. She began as an art director at William Douglas McAdams Inc., and included career moves to L.W. Frolich Intercon., Levey/ Wolff/Swift and Grey. She rose to the position of Vice President, Art Group Supervisor, supervising four art directors. She designed and organized campaigns for the introduction of new pharmaceutical products. She was a pioneer in her profession, blazing the way for younger women in the field of advertising. She retired from full time advertising in 1988 and went into business as a dealer in French and English antiques at Le Vieux Monde Antiques on Lexington Avenue. Ms. White left the antique business in 1990 to devote herself full time to painting, her first love. Early along in this pursuit she had shows at Katarina Rich Perlow Gallery, and most recently showed her work at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton. Ms. White became involved in philanthropy in 1992 through her interest in establishing a place for young artists to develop their work. She was in Vermont painting and met John Gregg and was enamored with the idea of building and expanding his vision of a retreat for artists at all levels in their careers. The concept of a place where artists, poets and writers could work uninterrupted by the everyday demands of family and work appealed to her greatly. She was the Chairman of the Board of the Vermont Studio Center. Ms. White openly acknowledged her battle with breast cancer and decided to dedicate her energies to helping other women in a position similar to her own. Her artistic vision led her to establish an in-patient floor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering that would have a personal and gracious environment. She was involved in the design and decoration of the floor, from choosing carpeting and fabrics to adorning the walls with her own photographs and paintings. She was similarly involved in an out-patient facility for women at Memorial Sloan-Kettering. At the time of her death, Ms. White was on the advisory board of the Sloan Kettering Institute, was a trustee and Board member at the Cooper Union School of Art, a Board member of the Friends of LaGuardia High School (formerly the High School of Music and Art), and a member of the Board of the Parrish Museum in Southampton. Ms. White leaves her sons Neil, Leslie and Daniel, her devoted companion Jack Talan, and her sister Mimi Inorio. She was formerly married to Dr. Jack Fishman of the Strang Clinic.

But the hostess, in a beige silk Bill Blass suit and simple Harry Winston diamond earrings, had two faces. To her high-powered guests -- Wall Street men and media moguls, and women in linen and soft cotton -- she showed a radiant smile. ''It's so nice to see you,'' she said to one dark-haired man as he arrived. ''Let's get Lee Ann to get you a drink.''

title: Pony Skin, Now Tamed
description: Pony skin may be the rage, but some tidier types find the fabric too shaggy and unkempt. This could explain the unexpected popularity of Frederic Fekkai's new pony skin tote, with its neat black-and-white windowpane pattern. ''Conventional pony skin with big black splotches can look messy,'' said Lucy Sykes, the fashion editor of Allure magazine, who owns the Fekkai bag. ''The graphic pattern brings order to the disorder of regular pony skin.'' Part of his fall collection, the $595 bag hit Mr. Fekkai's boutique at 874 Madison Avenue (71st Street) at the end of July. All 35 bags in the original shipment sold out the day they arrived. A second shipment, mostly already sold, is expected this week, and a third is due in late August. Although the tote also comes in chestnut and gray, the crisp black-and-white version is the most sought after (888-333-5524 to order). ''It's a great shape and holds lots of stuff,'' Ms. Sykes said, ''including my Manolo Blahniks.'' ELLEN TIEN

That doesn't, however, suggest that one size is necessarily better than another, but that the cook has to gauge and then imagine. And reimagine.

But now a small but growing number of towns are requiring -- and at least one county is aggressively advocating -- that the centers have a more appealing design, signaling a departure from the gray cracker box strips of the past.

title: The Women Who Wrote the Songs That Made Grown Men Sigh
description: One of the greatest movie songs ever written, ''A Fine Romance,'' was introduced by Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire in the 1936 musical romp ''Swing Time.'' In a snowy mountain retreat, two sweethearts whose budding romance has been temporarily sidetracked taunt each other with some of the sauciest erotic challenges to be found in a 30's pop song. In a witty sexual duel that has a jaunty melody by Jerome Kern and funny, incisive lyrics by Dorothy Fields, the woman more than holds her own.

title: Ms. Presbrey And Mr. Wylie
description: Katherine Mattson Presbrey was married yesterday to Paul Stanton Wylie at the Christ Chapel in Centerville, Mass. The Rev. David S. Bullock, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-15-99: The Ethicist; Family Business
description: I am seven weeks pregnant and looking for a new job. When should I tell prospective employers? Is it unfair to look for a job at this time? / L.C., Rhode Island

title: Lucy Haverland And Craig Joffe

The Rev. Vincent Gartland, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Jasna Polana, a golf club. Rabbi Julie Greenberg took part in the ceremony.

title: A First Lady for the Ages
description: WHO is the woman of the year? Ask around. Don't be surprised if Eleanor Roosevelt comes off a strong contender. In a world where equality is theoretical -- just one of those words, words, words -- Mrs. Roosevelt demonstrated in her louder-speaking actions that the rich and poor, the white and those of color, were one, and she was never treacly about it; no way. She was a force, an independent fighter, a feminist who perfected the art of reinvention.

title: Following Shackleton, In Far More Comfort
description: Marine Expeditions, one of the largest operators of voyages to the Antarctic and the Arctic, is offering a 21-day trip this fall that retraces Sir Ernest Shackleton's foray to Antarctica in 1914.

description: Here's a pretty political paradox: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican, has raised nearly $40 million toward his Presidential campaign and all right-thinking commentators are aghast.

title: Teen-agers Call on Cabbies
description: Rows of yellow cabs idled in the taxi pool near the Delta Airlines terminal at La Guardia Airport as the drivers, waiting to be summoned to their next jaunt, read newspapers, caught a snooze or chatted. Six teen-agers toting clipboards moved through the parking lot, sizing up the cabbies to find the potential crime fighters among them.

title: August 8-14; It Was Lead, Not Mercury
description: People keep the strangest souvenirs. In 1815, an admirer of Andrew Jackson was given a snippet of the great man's hair, and those revered strands somehow survived to the present day. They never blew away in a gust of wind, never got lost in the sock drawer -- and eventually found their way to the Hermitage, Jackson's Tennessee home.

title: Rowing on the Passaic (That's Right), and Helping to Clean It Up
description: The Passaic River at Rutherford is not a stretch of waterway that elicits a picture of bucolic nature. Along one bank sits a concrete abutment supporting Route 21, while the other is lined with suburban homes. Between them sits the sluggish Passaic, on whose dull surface floats cans, plastic bottles, scrap wood, tree branches -- and rowers threading their sculls among it all. Tucked along the banks between an empty lot and modest homes sits the Nereid Boat Club, whose members have been rowing since before there was much detritus to thread through.

In August 1996, she found herself with a rare opportunity to make her pitch to a member of the Clinton Cabinet: Attorney General Janet Reno, a fellow Parkinson's sufferer.

title: Angst in the Great American Middle
description: ''The American Middle, Just Getting By'' (Economic View, Aug. 1), by Louis Uchitelle, discussed the feeling of many middle-class families that they are not sharing in the national bounty as earlier generations did. The column drew many responses.

description: A group of wealthy Roman Catholic entrepreneurs, concerned that the nation's religious radio programming is dominated by evangelical Protestants, has started a radio network intended to broadcast a conservative Catholic spin on politics, news, personal problems and spiritual questions.

title: Washing Away Illness, Care, Grime and the Occasional Sin
description: THE SETTING -- St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church on Mace Avenue, where an outdoor grotto dedicated to the Virgin Mary has drawn pilgrims since its construction in 1939. The water that flows down the face of the rocks is believed by some to possess miraculous powers to cure illness. The church and the Archdiocese of New York make no such claims, although the water is blessed every year.

He asked them all the same question: If you could give me advice for life, what would it be?

Even if cooler days have displaced the heat wave, this month, despite its name, is always something to be got through.

title: Cell Phones Find a Calling
description: As digital cell phones catch on, what happens to the old, unused analog models? Since the beginning of the year, Bell Atlantic Mobile has been working with community groups in the metropolitan area to collect them, reprogram them to dial only 911 and distribute them to victims of domestic violence, school crossing guards, park supervisors and others apt to witness a crime or be the victim of one. Through July, a total of about 6,000 phones have been collected in drives by 27 organizations -- police departments, firefighters, prosecutors' offices, schools, houses of worship, and so on -- and 19 of them are in New Jersey. The biggest haul by far has been that by Zonta of Bergen County, a professional women's group that took in more than 1,900 phones to aid domestic violence victims. Once Bell Atlantic is done with the phones, Zonta will give them to the Bergen County Prosecutor's office and two shelters for victims. Any remaining phones will go to the New Jersey Coalition for Battered Women. To find a local drive, call Bell Atlantic Mobile at (914) 365-7535.

The project will create an estimated 335 jobs and draw more than $6.2 million in additional investment.

description: IT is hard to imagine that in this handsome space, previous generations came not to dine but to buy Chevrolets. Its industrial past, apparent in the ducts in the ceiling, is softened by deep color, mellow lighting and dark woods in sturdy library chairs, wainscoting and an unapologetically ornate bar, rescued, we were told, from Chez Louis in Manhattan.

title: Division of Perennial Favorites
description: Perennial doesn't mean forever. Some favorite hot-colored flowering plants must be propagated every three years for continued vigor. Like other members of the iris family, Crocosmia Lucifer can quickly form a congested clump and needs division when flowering diminishes. The best time to divide is after flowering in mid- to late summer, when foliage may need to be cut down because of spider mite damage.

description: GIVEN the play's human nature and forgiving spirit, ''The Tempest'' is a well-tempered title. In his last work, Shakespeare purged all violence and vengeance from his soul, creating his own story, with no borrowings of plot or character from history or legend.

description: After seeking for 15 years to escape cramped and outmoded quarters in Brooklyn, state and city court officials say they have finally found the answer: a 32-story, $350 million courthouse that would rise in the commercially reviving heart of Downtown Brooklyn.

title: August 8-14; Customs Announces Changes In Its Search Policy
description: After years of complaints and lawsuits, United States Customs Service officials said the agency would change the way it conducts personal searches of thousands of people who arrive in the United States each year and are suspected of smuggling narcotics. Customs has adopted tighter criteria to determine who will be subjected to body searches in place of an unwieldy system that agency officials said permitted searches of anyone who looked too nervous or too calm.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR; New Superheroes on Wall Street
description: AT age 76, Stan Lee is a popular guy. Fresh from signing autographs last week for hordes of fans at Siggraph, the country's premiere computer graphics show, the creator of Spider-Man, the Fantastic Four, X-Men and other modern superheroes was trying to conduct an interview outside the Convention Center here. But he kept getting sidetracked by well-wishers.

title: Is Ex-Borough Historian's Home History?
description: For years Henry F. Ludder, the official historian of Queens, had led efforts to save historic buildings from the wrecking ball. But in May he quietly sold his mansard-roofed Victorian home on 150th Place and moved out of town, leaving his preservationist colleagues and the Borough President's office puzzled.

title: Breaking the Iraq Deadlock
description: When Richard Holbrooke takes over as America's representative to the United Nations, one of the most important issues he will face is the stalemate over Iraq. The Security Council has been in disarray on Iraq, and Saddam Hussein has been taking advantage. With no international arms inspectors present, he has been free to rebuild his purchasing networks and resume production of toxic and nuclear weapons and missiles to deliver them.

title: Ideas & Trends: In the Beginning; It's a Fact: Faith and Theory Collide Over Evolution
description: EDUCATORS and scientists may find it shocking or merely tedious that politicians are still fighting over whether evolution should be taught in school. But those who champion scientific over religious explanations might strengthen their case if they conceded a point to the opposition: Since evolution is indeed a theory and not a fact, it can be taught side by side with creationism. The result would be a wider appreciation that creationism isn't even a theory, and that what evolution's opponents consider its weakness is actually its strength: Like all of science, it is based on malleable human knowledge.

Protesters have been camped outside the studios of KPFA, Pacifica Radio's 50-year-old flagship station of listener-supported peace, freedom and cultural diversity. Many wear gags to represent violations of free speech, proffer ''Free KPFA'' T-shirts and operate their own 50-watt micropower transmitter.

title: Tempting Ingredients, a Touch of Adventure

The premises are simple but thoughtfully arranged, with copper pots glistening on one wall, baskets artfully arranged on high shelves. And the perfect-sized menu -- neither too short nor too long -- is full of dishes with tempting ingredients and Asian accents that beckon the diner to be adventurous.

title: The Russian Devolution
description: Seated around the long table on the first floor of the modest dacha, the young men were relaxed, laughing a lot, talking excitedly, sometimes all together. They barely noticed as, guided by their chairman, I skirted the table and took a seat in a little room off their conference chamber to wait for a break in the proceedings. As I sat there, I marveled at the hilarity and occasional cacophony that fairly shook the wooden walls.

title: City Sidewalks Make the Heart Beat Faster
description: NEW YORK is a city of paradoxes. It's a place where eccentrics are commonplace and where ordinary Americans tend to look foreign. It's a transportation center in which getting anywhere is often impossible. It's both the setting for ''Friends'' and the capital of loneliness. And though it seems to restrict bodily movement at every turn, it produces some of the most physically vigorous people around.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YELLIS, JOSEPH, DR.
description: YELLIS-Joseph, Dr., August 1, 1917-December 23, 1998. Dr. Yellis practiced podiatry near Carnegie Hall for more than 30 years, treating artists, business, and professional people, and neighbors in Brooklyn, Bayside, Great Neck, the Jersey shore & South Florida. His orthopedic devices were prized by dancers and other sufferers from chronic foot problems, but it was his sense of humor and gentleness that were most valued by his patients, family, and friends. Dr. Yellis took Christian Science class instruction and read in several New Jersey and Florida churches. He also wrote memoirs of his childhood and professional life and his poems appeared in the Christian Science Sentinel and Journal. He followed politics closely & rooted avidly for the Dodgers and later, the Mets. Husband of the late Sylvia Bravman Yellis and the late Evelyn Zenstein Yellis. Joe Yellis is survived by four brothers, Ben Ellis, and Morris, Jack, and David Yellis, his sister Sue Applestein, children Ken Yellis and Stefanie Gandolfi, and stepdaughter Saunee Navlen and their respective families. Anyone who knew Joe Yellis to cordially invited to attend an informal brunch gathering in joyous remembrance, Sat., August 28, 1999, 10:30 am to 12:30 pm, The Inn at Great Neck, 30 Cutter Mill Rd, Great Neck, NY. Please bring a photo or story to share; children most welcome. Rsvp to Ken Yellis at 203-865-4899, 500 Prospect Street, #

title: After 'Trainspotting,' a Truer, Darker Comic Vision
description: WITH its savvy soundtrack, cypnotic direction and a charismatic cast of heroin-hooked hooligans, the 1996 film ''Trainspotting'' made substance abuse look like exhilarating fun. Based on the Scottish writer Irvine Welsh's novel of sex, drugs and rock-and-roll, the film was a seductive tour through life's skids. From its rapid-fire opening scene following a pack of fleeing thieves (accompanied by Iggy Pop's ''Lust for Life'') to its lulling evocation of an overdose (to the tune of Lou Reed's ''Perfect Day''), ''Trainspotting'' transformed Mr. Welsh's bleakly comic narrative into a toe-tapping head trip worthy of MTV. Yet it was precisely that slick sensibility that Mr. Welsh intended to avoid when asked to write the screenplay for ''The Acid House,'' his second work to be brought to the screen.

title: When the Spice of Choice Was Sin
description: ''I WISH to join the Legion of Decency, which condemns vile and unwholesome moving pictures. I unite with all who protest against them as a grave menace to youth, to home life, to country and to religion.'' So began a pledge written in the spring of 1934 by the Archbishop of Cincinnati, John T. McNicholas. Distributed in Roman Catholic churches across America, the petition garnered some four million signatures within a month.

title: Fitting and Installing Basement Doors
description: MANY older homes have exterior basement doors made of wood. Unless they are maintained properly, these old doors can become an eyesore, and as the boards age they will shrink and allow rainwater to leak through. If you have such a door on your basement entry well, consider replacing it with a modern heavy-gauge steel door. It is more durable than a wooden one; it also provides a stronger barrier against intruders and requires less maintenance.

title: The Hateful Agenda of Ignorance
description: Buford Furrow Jr., the man who attacked a Jewish community center in Los Angeles last Tuesday, is something of a throwback, even among white supremacists. The trajectory of his simple, malevolent faith is expressed in two photographs, one taken of him wearing an Aryan Nations uniform in northern Idaho, the other of him wearing police handcuffs in Los Angeles. It is doubtful that Mr. Furrow would have prospered as a campus recruiter for Aryan Nations. It is also unlikely that he could have done much to further the supremacist movement's growing presence on the Internet, except, of course, as hero and, if convicted and sentenced to death for the murder of Joseph Ileto, as martyr. Mr. Furrow embodies the attributes, amounting nearly to stereotype, that have made it all too tempting to regard white supremacy as a fading, peripheral irruption within normal society.

But no, it was an invitation straight from the headquarters of Mammon himself. Speakers from the American Association of Retired Persons and the banking world, together with various financial journalists and a person described as a ''futurist,'' promised to explain ''the most important issues and trends that will affect your life in your retirement.''

Victor DeNoble, a former pharmacologist hired to design a safer cigarette, blew the whistle on Philip Morris for censoring his research about the addictiveness of nicotine; he now works as a flight instructor. And Jennifer Long, an auditor, testified before Congress about systemwide abuses at the Internal Revenue Service; despite a recent attempt to fire her, Long has held onto her job. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; What Balanchine Wrought
description: The New-York Historical Society's exhibition devoted to the New York City Ballet was a bedazzling parade of photographs, souvenirs, ephemera and breathtakingly rare film clips documenting the long and spectacular history of the most important dance company since Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes. DANCE FOR A CITY: Fifty Years of the New York City Ballet (Columbia University, $50), alas, is not a comprehensive catalogue but a companion volume containing six essays, transcripts of a group of vivid interviews with George Balanchine conducted by Nancy Reynolds in 1974 and 1975, a complete list of the stage works of Jerome Robbins and, last but not least, some of the black-and-white photos on display in the exhibition (as well as several others not seen there). The illustrations range from a 1952 magazine cover depicting Maria Tallchief's legs to three witty drawings from Edward Gorey's ''Lavender Leotard; Or, Going a Lot to the New York City Ballet.'' Some of the best images in the show are inexplicably omitted -- I especially missed Robbins's harrowing portrait of Tanaquil LeClercq, Balanchine's last wife and the company's greatest and most photogenic ballerina, made not long after polio forced her to retire from the stage in 1956 -- and certain of the essays that take their place, including Jonathan Weinberg's apologia for George Platt Lynes's soft-core porn dance photographs, seem beside the point. But others are first-rate, particularly Charles M. Joseph's ''Making of 'Agon,' '' while the pictures are so good that you may want to buy two copies of ''Dance for a City,'' one for reading and the other for clipping and framing. Terry Teachout

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Sex and Oxygen
description: Sex doesn't equal love -- or does it? If it doesn't, then why do we expend so much energy on merging our bodies with others' while we so rarely connect in spirit? If it does, then why isn't sex enough to bind two people together against the world's insistence on ripping them apart? Such questions are among the chief preoccupations of PRAYERS OF AN ACCIDENTAL NATURE (Coffee House, paper, $13.95), Debra Di Blasi's arresting second book of fiction. Her characters struggle with the dichotomy of body and soul, the clash between the urges of the flesh and the desires of the heart and the inequalities of class, ethnicity, sex and age that magnify these conflicts. In ''An Interview With My Husband,'' an American woman marries a younger man from Argentina. Their lovemaking is perfect, they are in love -- surely this will last a lifetime? A year later, she finds herself on a rooftop, begging him not to leave her. In ''Where All Things Converge,'' an extraordinary beauty gives up sex when it fails to bring her love; the lonely heroine of ''Blind'' recalls a past love even as she realizes that the passing of youth and beauty will now rob her, too, of sex. The pull of the flesh can't be denied: at times, sex may be only a surrogate for love, but it can be as essential to that emotion as oxygen is to life. In clear, resonant prose, laced with bittersweet humor, Di Blasi imparts her understanding of love's multiple ironies. Zofia Smardz

Perched on a cluster of rocks in the water, an egret flapped its wings. ''That's Sheets Creek, there's Manorhaven,'' Mr. Blumenfeld said. ''You get these vistas all through. It's going to be a beautiful spot.''

title: August 8-14; China-Taiwan Tensions
description: China and Taiwan are sending military planes flying over the 100-mile-wide straits separating the two rival nations, and the United States is urging both sides to calm down. The situation is ''dangerous'' and ''very delicate,'' said one official. Washington fears an accident or a misunderstanding could set off acts of war. China has considered Taiwan a renegade for 50 years, and refuses to renounce violence as a means to bring it back under mainland control.

title: Cartoons for the Inner Child
description: Tomorrow and Tuesday will be devoted to celebrating the child within every adult, along with real children, at the O'Plenty Shore Thing Animation Fest at Monmouth Mall in Eatontown. The first festival of its kind in the area and the third largest in the United States, it will feature cartoons that, in this case, are more appropriately called animated films.

title: A Day in the Water, Floating on Air; A Swimmer Finds That Manhattan's 12 Municipal Pools Are Oases Where All Cares Dissolve
description: IN John Cheever's short story ''The Swimmer,'' a man named Ned hits upon the idea of swimming home. He goes from swimming pool to swimming pool, splashing his away across an entire suburban county. With ''portages'' in between, he makes it in one long day.

description: As with the peace talks in Ireland that inspired them, negotiations between the Spanish Government and the guerrilla movement that has been fighting for independence for the Basque region have stalled, but that has not stifled hopes for peace in a long and bloody conflict.

title: Real Campaign-Finance Reform
description: Anonymous campaign financing is an intriguing idea (Jack Hitt, July 25). Indeed, now that Prof. Ian Ayres of Yale and Jeremy Bulow of Stanford have made the case for it, it seems self-evident. In the light of this ultimate reform, arguments about hard and soft money are seen for what they really are -- debates about just how corrupt we should allow our government to become. Anonymous, unlimited campaign financing is about zero corruption.

At that time, Underwood was a smiling, proud man who showed no indication that he was having second thoughts about playing professional football.

title: In Africa, a Small Step To Bigger Game Parks
description: ONE of the dreams of the creators of African game parks is to tear down national borders and let the animals roam freely so that migration habits and grazing patterns determine a park's boundaries. Naturally, politics gets in the way, whether it's the politics of cartographers in the Colonial Office during Victoria's reign, or the touchy border disputes of modern African states.

description: A Rwandan under indictment for genocide by an international war crimes tribunal in Africa made a final plea to the Supreme Court on Friday to avoid deportation from the United States, American officials said yesterday.

description: IN a less robust economy, Chase Manhattan Bank's announcement in June that it would be vacating 620,000 square feet of leased space in two Jericho buildings over the next two years might have caused major concerns in the Long Island office market.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-15-99; Body Count
description: Asked to quantify the social transformation of New York City in the 1990's, many New Yorkers would turn to two obvious figures. One would be the Dow Jones industrial average, which has ascended from the vicinity of 3,300 in 1993 to over 11,000 this year. The other would be the statistic constantly touted by the Mayor and police officials: the murder rate for the five boroughs, which has fallen from a high of around 2,000 per year in the early 1990's to 628 in 1998. Multiply the paper wealth of the city's professional classes by 3, reduce our fear of random death by a similar factor, and there you have it, the city's change of mood in a nutshell: we feel prosperous and secure.

title: Music and Fireworks Draw Fireworks From Hoboken
description: Loud music from Chelsea Piers, the sports and entertainment complex, has occasionally drifted over the Hudson River to disturb the peace of Hoboken, N.J. Elected officials in Manhattan forwarded the complaints to pier managers last month, saying the music was just the latest in a long list of problems, but the managers insisted that they were being good neighbors.

title: Skipper Experiences a Sea Change
description: It was all-white polo shirts and preppy faces here Friday when the Young America team announced its official challenge team for the 1999-2000 America's Cup trials. The gathering on the rolling lawn of the New York Yacht Club annex looked more like a crisp advertisement for Helly Hansen, the team's apparel sponsor, than a sweaty gathering of sports jocks. But make no mistake, America's Cup crews have their combative side, too.

The 3-5 favorite to win the $400,000 Sword Dancer Invitational and continue on to become the country's champion grass horse was Yagli, owned by Allen Paulson, trained by Bill Mott and ridden by Jerry Bailey, the people who brought Cigar to his glory.

Wilson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr Community Church.

title: Some See Too Much Fog Over City Plans for Navy Port
description: It has been six months since the city accepted six proposals for redeveloping the 36 waterfront acres of the Navy Home Port, which the Pentagon closed in 1994. Since then, the list of viable projects has been narrowed to four: a sports and entertainment center, a hotel and entertainment complex, a residential development with stores, and a film production studio. But the agency has been otherwise quiet about its plans -- too quiet for the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce.

Allen. The Rev. James J. Midgley performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: SERIES OF RULINGS EASES CONSTRAINTS ON SUING H.M.O.'S
description: In a string of rulings over the last 20 months, judges across the country have begun allowing patients to sue health maintenance organizations for medical malpractice, after years in which such claims were repeatedly rejected by the courts.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Obstructions to New Rental Projects Are on the Rise
description: ON Sept. 14, a referendum will be held in New Canaan. If it succeeds, the voters will have blocked a $5 million appropriation meant to cover the cost of moving the town's public works garage to a landfill area, thus scuttling plans for a fully approved 104-unit apartment complex by Avalon Bay Communities of Alexandria, Va., that is to be constructed on the garage site.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cold Spring, N.Y.; Historic, Rustic And on the Hudson
description: WHEN Alison Rooney, 40, and her husband, Arthur Austin, 48, lived in New York City, they frequently took the train up to Cold Spring in the Hudson Highlands. An industrial era village that has gradually revived its historic downtown with an eclectic array of antiques shops, cafes and restaurants, Cold Spring appealed to the couple's artistic sensibilities. They often thought about moving to the romantic setting on the banks of the Hudson, but they could not quite warm to the idea of a 75-minute commute.

title: For This Weekend, Pack Really Light
description: At Empire Haven Nudist Park, visitors leave their pretenses at the door, along with their clothes. Especially this weekend.

title: Yes, They Want No Banana
description: A small place with a vibrant name on West 50th Street has alarmed some Community Board 4 members, who hope the restaurant and bar, Electric Banana, will not be as loud as its name sounds to some. The owner, meanwhile, has promised to be a good neighbor. But first she will have to convince the state liquor authorities.

title: Neighborhood Treasure Hunt
description: THINK you know a lot about Greenwich Village, or are you interested in learning more about it? Randy Levinson, a resident and devotee of the neighborhood, is making a game of urban exploration with a Greenwich Village Treasure Hunt. This Saturday, for about three hours, teams of two to five people can follow written clues that take them to landmarks and hidden corners of the Village. There are a total of 14 clues that lead to a location where team members will find a small, hidden token that they can redeem at the end of the hunt. Team members have to stay together; the idea is for them to work creatively and collaboratively. One can enter as part of a team or as an individual looking to meet new people.

title: Summer Camp With Strings Attached
description: After 10 seasons of directing a Saturday music school, Isaac Malkin decided to do the summer thing. Mr. Malkin, 51, a Russian-born violinist who teaches at the Manhattan School of Music during the week, has just completed ''a wonderful first summer'' with his fledgling camp, the Academy of Music Summer Festival at Ramapo College in Mahwah.

title: New Police Leader
description: In January, Police Chief Eugene Tumolo of Peekskill will become the second Westchester official to serve as president of the New York State Association of Chiefs of Police.

title: Children's Books; Born in a Watermelon
description: Judy Sierra, author of several clever and energetic children's books, has now applied her storytelling skills to a funny, spunky retelling of a traditional Japanese folk tale, which she calls TASTY BABY BELLY BUTTONS (Knopf, $17; ages 4 to 9). The heroine is a brave little girl named Uriko-hime, or ''melon princess,'' because her parents found her inside a watermelon. When the town's babies are kidnapped by oni, terrible horned ogres who like to snack on bellybuttons, Uriko sets off on a daring rescue mission with her dog, her sword and a sack of dumplings. Along the way, a pheasant and a monkey join their ranks, and the sturdy band confronts the ogres at their castle in a comical fight scene in which the small, agile invaders triumph over their large, bumbling opponents, then liberate the babies and return stolen treasure to the townsfolk.

title: Loose Grip on a Ball, Tight Grip on a Dream
description: The first pitch moved through the night like a butterfly drunk on tequila, floating blithely past the catcher. The second pitch sailed about like a party balloon sputtering helium. The sixth pitch tripped and fell somewhere near home plate, bouncing off a batter's shin.

title: Sabbath Act Threatens Coalition In Israel
description: Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel permitted a huge part of a metal turbine to be transported on the Jewish Sabbath today, defying an Orthodox party that is a crucial member of his coalition and raising concerns about a possible Government crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEVIRTZ, MILTON
description: GEVIRTZ-Milton. A loving husband, supportive father and grandfather, and former president of the Men's Club of the Garden Jewish Center in Queens, died August 13 at the age of 78. A World War II veteran who served with the Signal Corps in Europe, Milton was a mensch. He had a kind heart, enjoyed debating politics and the day's news, was a good dancer and liked Big Band music. A graduate of the New York City schools, Milton worked for the U.S. Navy at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and later, for the New York City Retirement System before he retired in 1991. In later years, he was a member and volunteer at the Crescent Hill Synagogue in Lake Louise Marie, NY, and had homes in both South Fallsburg, NY, and Tamarac, FL. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, Gloria; a daughter, Leslie; a son, Clifford and daughter in-law Alison, as well as two grandsons: Theodore and Graham. Donations may be sent to either the Hebrew Day School in Kiamesha Lake, NY, or the American Heart Association.

title: Confessions Of a Frugal Spendthrift
description: FRUGALITY has never been my problem. I've always made enough to cover my rent or mortgage. I pay my bills on time. I've never been in serious debt. And yet, compared with my parents, I'm a spendthrift.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 18 about accounting techniques that can mask a company's actual performance misstated the month in which the exposure of irregularities at the Cendant Corporation caused the stock to fall by half. It was April 1998, not April 1997.

title: Saris and Statuettes, All Made in India
description: For almost 22 years, Purushottam Goyal ran the Goyal Dress Shoppe at 770 Broadway, but when the building was sold last summer, he was forced to move. In June he reopened the shop, which carries fashions and home accessories from India, at 218 East Fifth Street (between Cooper Square and Second Avenue). The store carries colorful hand-embroidered shawls and saris, and quilts and bedsheets with traditional floral patterns. It also has paintings and jewelery, and small statuettes, like a clay figurine of the Hindu god Shiva, for $20. The merchandise is exported by Mr. Goyal's son, who lives in Delhi.

title: An Outsider's Views of Mexico
description: THE reputation of Mexico's once-influential muralists continues to stagnate, but the international fame of its photographic tradition is still on the rise. That tradition has been enriched by the number of foreign-born practitioners drawn to Mexico by artistic or political fervor; Tina Modotti is the best known of them. ''On the Edge of Time,'' at the Monmouth Museum here, is an opportunity to become acquainted with another of these photographic emigres, Mariana Yampolsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, CORINN (NEE MACCREADY)

Fox, Deanie McCarthy, John J. Fox, Edward J. Fox and Bart Johnson. Adoring grandmother of Corinn McCarthy, William J. McCarthy, Irene S. Fox, J. Ford Fox, David Johnson and Laura Johnson. Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY, Tuesday, 24 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 AM, Church of St. Augustine. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to Aquinas High School, 685 East 186th Street, Bronx, NY 10457 would be appreciated.

description: LAND-Edgar Law (Bud). Of Madison, New Jersey on Tuesday, August 10, 1999. Husband of the late Agnes Land. Loving father of Edgar Law Land, Jr. of Barto, PA; Margurite Blanck of Brooklyn, N.Y.; Anthony Land of West Redding, CT; Justina Leler of Austin, TX; Zachary Land of Madison, N.J.; Benedict Land, of Northampton, MA; Matthew Land of Madison, NJ, and Kevin Land of Bechtelsville, PA. Edgar is also survived by his sister Helen Land of St. James, New York and fourteen grandchildren and one great grandchild. A Memorial Service will be held at the Museum of Early Trades & Crafts, Main Street, Madison, NJ on Saturday, August 28th from 11:00 AM until 1:00 PM. Information: Burroughs, Kohr & Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main St. Madison, N.J. description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel watched his team's surprising preseason rout of the Minnesota Vikings from his mother's room in the intensive care unit of an Arizona hospital Friday night, excited that his charges had played well and, in turn, confident that he had made the correct decision to leave the team to be at his mother's bedside.

description: THE school colors of Hillside Elementary in Hastings-on-Hudson and Collydean Primary in Glenrothes, Scotland, are the same: green and yellow. That is a nice coincidence, David Felberbaum, a teacher at Hillside, said recently -- nice because he and a Collydean teacher, Alison Syme, are changing places for a year as part of a teacher exchange of the Fulbright program.

description: The view from the disputed corner is desolate. The wide boulevard is pockmarked with empty lots, the few remaining 19th-century buildings stripped of cornices and other architectural details. Standing at the corner of West 117th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, one gets a picture of a Harlem abandoned by landlords, razed by arsonists, forsaken by the body politic.

title: Habitats/Loch Sheldrake, N.Y.; To Get a Country Home, She Learned to Drive
description: THERE are, believe it or not, country places that do not cost a fortune. They may be small. They may not offer lots of privacy, or easy access to goat cheese with peppercorns. But they have their charms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHLAN, SIDNEY Q., DR.
description: COHLAN-Sidney Q., Dr., 84. Of New York on August 12th, 1999. Beloved husband of Dr. Shirley Stone, loving father of Dr. Barbara Cohlan Perlmutter, Deborah Cohlan and John Cohlan, adored grandfather of Andrew and Lisa Perlmutter and Alexander Stone Cohlan, and caring father-of-law of David Perlmutter and Louisa Winkelman Cohlan. A compassionate and devoted pediatrician, scientist and teacher with 51 years of caring for the sick, 40 years as a member of the New York University School of Medicine faculty and 30 years as Director of Pediatrics at the Tisch Hospital at New York University Medical Center. Pioneer in teratology, consultant on congenital malformations to the National Institute of Health & past president of the Teratology Society. He, with his wonderful wife, Dr. Shirley Stone, taught generations of medical students and supported countless patients and their families through physical and emotional crises. He will be greatly missed by all he touched. Service Monday, August 16, 12:30PM, at the ''Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Dr. Sidney Q. Cohlan Pediatric Memorial Fund, C/O of Faculty and Friends Campaign, NYU Medical Center, 550 First Avenue, New York, New York 10016.

title: Style; Fendi for Themselves
description: Silvia Venturini is the bad girl of the Fendi clan. She bailed out of boarding school at 17, then left home and nearly ran away to South America for love. And it is just that rebel spirit that inspired her to create the Baguette bag, the hottest accessory of the moment and an elixir for Fendi, the 74-year-old Rome-based fashion house, which built its reputation on luxurious furs.

title: The Bump in a Midsummer Night: Is It a Dream?
description: EVERY Thursday night since January, cognoscenti have been flocking to a sassy dance-theater performance at the Pyramid Club in Manhattan's East Village. ''The Donkey Show,'' conceived by Randy Weiner and directed by Mr. Weiner and his wife, Diane Paulus, is an adaptation of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' as interpreted through the lyrics of disco music and the dances these catchy tunes inspired, including the hustle, the bump and the freak. The choreography was created by the company under the supervision of Ms. Paulus, who danced with the New York City Ballet as a child.

The film depicts the actress's pathetic attempt at a comeback and the writer's downfall as he becomes hopelessly entangled with the psychopathic situation. Nancy Olsen as the young love interest is very effective--as is Erich von Stroheim, who plays the one-time director, former husband and current butler of the fallen star. The expert acting, combined with a pungent screenplay and masterly direction, make for a powerful film, right up to its shattering climax.

title: All the Presidents Stink
description: You almost have to feel sorry for Bob Woodward. Yes, he is a best-selling millionaire author who has been deified by Robert Redford and satirized by ''Dick'' on-screen, but even millionaire authors sometimes must cry all the way to the bank. With each passing year, Woodward gets less respect. The reviews of his books have become more dismissive, with this summer's best seller, ''Shadow: Five Presidents and the Legacy of Watergate,'' even coming in for harsh criticism on the op-ed page of his own newspaper, The Washington Post. Woodward's previous book, an account of the Dole-Clinton race titled ''The Choice,'' was deconstructed by Joan Didion as ''political pornography'' in The New York Review of Books. Other critics routinely argue that while Woodward's facts almost always hold up, they are spun and slanted by his sources or distorted by you-are-there re-creations of ''actual'' dialogue that is as human as the audioanimatronic Presidents at Disney World. Woodward's most hyped recent revelations -- Hillary Clinton communing with Eleanor Roosevelt, Bill Clinton's anguish over his daughter reading the Starr report -- are hardly smoking guns to rival those with which he and Carl Bernstein nailed Richard Nixon back in the heady era of ''All the President's Men'' a quarter-century ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKE, ROBERT BEATTY
description: PARKE-Robert Beatty. Beloved husband of Margaret. Died at his home in Bedford, NY, on August 11. He served as a B-17 pilot during WW II and flew transports to Japan and Greenland in post-war activities. He was awarded two Air Medals and a Distinguished Flying Cross. In 1952 he entered the aviation publishing field, spending 35 years with Flying magazine and served as its editor and publisher for 15 years. In 1978 he became associated with Businesses/Commercial Aviation magazine, working on assignments both in this country and abroad. He retired in 1997 at the age of 80. He is survived by his son James and his daughter Robin, and eight grandchildren. He will be remembered with gratitude and joy. title: MUSIC; At 40, Still a Vital Portal to Jazz
description: MINGLED with bittersweet memories of driving a battered Buick station wagon (much too fast), learning to flirt with girls (at a somewhat slower pace) and suffering through high school angst, there's the sound of an album with a dogeared cover that a friend yanked out of my father's record collection. ''This is a classic,'' my buddy explained. Surprised, I noted it wasn't Bruce Springsteen, punk, reggae or any of the other musical currents of the mid-70's. Between the scratches and pops of old technology (Dad must play this one a lot, I recall thinking) a stark, twilight world opened itself to me, one that I recognized even though the sound was far simpler and sadder than any of the peppy, big band music I then called jazz.

title: Worker Killed and 3 Hurt as Platform Falls

title: PULSE; Feet First
description: In the world of massage, feet have never been bigger. Reflexology, the ancient art of easing bodily pain and tension through the foot, is everywhere, from Rockport shoe stores where reflexologists give free 10-minute foot massages on the weekends, to dentists who hire them to supplement the Novocain. Now, for novices who would like to try their own hands, there are Reflexology Sox, one-size-fits-all Lycra booties with a map of reflex points and their corresponding body parts, $20 a pair at Barneys. Designed by Michelle Kluck, a massage therapist who has worked on the soles of Joe Pesci and Sigourney Weaver, the socks come with an instruction booklet (massaging the toes, it says, helps the sinuses; pressing on the ball of the foot stimulates the thyroid) and foot trivia (on an average day you walk 7,000 steps). But Barbara Morrison, a co-owner of Angel Feet, a reflexology day spa at 77 Perry Street, says reflexology isn't just press by numbers. ''You can't just read a book, press on a point and say, 'Oh, look what that does!' '' she said. ''It should be done by a trained professional.'' LOLA OGUNNAIKE

title: A Legendary City Updates Itself

And no place on the Iberian Peninsula is changing at a pace to match Oporto, plain Porto to the Portuguese. Renewing itself from the inside out with European Union and World Heritage money, this former entrepot of British wine merchants and Portugal's second city (and the one, along with ancient Cale, from which the country takes its name), has even been designated, with Rotterdam, Europe's Cultural Capital for 2001.

title: An Author of a Certain Age
description: At the age of 82, Penelope Fitzgerald has an instantly appealing face: fine-boned, gracious, modest. She is wearing a shirt that is striped in pink and white, just like the Nelly Moser clematis in bloom by the path to her small carriage-house flat, which is attached to the Victorian home of her younger daughter in the staid Highgate section of London. Her hair is a tousled white aureole, and her gray eyes dim and brighten without warning. When she shuffles to the door in red plaid slippers, each adorned with a red bow, she seems the most informidable person in the world. But her looks, like her books, are deceptively simple.

It is more durable than a wooden one; it also provides a stronger barrier against intruders and requires less maintenance.

title: Return of the Timber Wars
description: For the past two years, Mike Dombeck, the chief of the United States Forest Service, has struggled to change the culture of a notoriously stubborn agency that has long favored the harvesting of timber in the national forests at the expense of wildlife protection and other environmental values. But old habits die hard at the Forest Service, no matter who is in charge. That is the unhappy subtext of Federal District Judge William Dwyer's recent ruling that the Forest Service has been violating a landmark 1994 plan to protect the spotted owl in the old-growth forests of the Pacific Northwest, mainly by failing to conduct wildlife surveys on Federal land before approving logging contracts. The decision, which also faulted the Bureau of Land Management, could halt logging on more than a half-million acres of Federal land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, NATALIE (NEE KATZ)
description: RUBENSTEIN-Natalie (nee Katz). We mourn the loss of our mother who died August 11 in Far Rockaway, NY. She was 77. Supervising science reference librarian, she helped build and lead the Science and Business Division of Mid-Manhattan Public Library where she served for over 21 years before retirement in 1992. Her family and community life was devoted to mitzvot. She was a lifelong member of Hadassah and an independent and original thinker who inspired the feminism of her children. She will be deeply missed by her children Asa and Fortune Rubenstein of Brooklyn, NY, Diane Rubenstein and Philip Protter of West Lafayette, IN, and Susan Rubenstein and Carl Sabath of Gaithersburg, MD. She greatly enjoyed her granddaughter Rachel Protter. She had the gift for friendship and the art of listening and will be profoundly missed by her friends and colleagues. Donations may be made to Memorial SloanKettering Library Fund, the Gilbert M. Rubenstein Memorial Fund, English Department, Pace University and Haddassah.

title: Biotech Expert's New Job Casts a Shadow on Report
description: A scientist directing a crucial study on genetically engineered crops at the prestigious National Academy of Sciences left last month for a job with the biotechnology industry, angering environmental scientists who fear that the final report will be biased toward the industry's points of view.

Bush's victory was decisive but not the rout that the Bush campaign had hoped for, raises the possibility that the Texas Governor may face competition from fellow Republican Steve Forbes in six months when Iowa holds its nominating caucuses.

description: The violent path of Buford O. Furrow Jr., the white supremacist who wounded five people last week at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles and killed a letter carrier there, highlights another aspect of the nation's guns laws: members of hate groups, even those that espouse attacking others, can legally buy firearms or become, as Mr. Furrow did, licensed firearms dealers.

description: The imaginary characters in Toni Morrison's first book for children live in a pretty brown box, decorated with beanbag chairs and stocked with pepperoni pizza and Bubble Yum.

title: Corrections

The student is Rashad Williams, not Rashid; he raised pledges of $40,000, not $18,000. The race took place across the city of San Francisco, not across the Golden Gate Bridge.

If he didn't, after having had a five-stroke lead on the 12th tee, he would suddenly be tied with the 19-year-old Spanish prodigy, Sergio Garcia, going to the final hole in his struggle to win a second major title, alias the 81st Professional Golfers' Association Championship.

It is an unusual debit card. On the front is a picture of her smiling shyly. The familiar black magnetic stripe on the back gives her access not to a checking account, but to $448 a month in government food credits and cash.
