description: British Airways P.L.C. confirmed today that it was considering bringing lawsuits against several European competitors over incentives to travel agents and that it would cut some jobs.

description: There is probably only one man in the history of the game who has been in the top flight in every area of it: player, teacher, writer, administrator, lawmaker and tournament director. He was an Englishman named Harold Franklin, and he died in January at the age of 83. He represented Britain in international competition, but he is best remembered as a tournament director. He was in charge of world championships for 15 years, retiring in 1986.

title: International Sleuthing Adds Insight About Bach
description: The story of the long search for the musical estate of Johann Sebastian Bach's second son, Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, is straight out of a bad cold war novel. The estate, discovered by scholars this summer in a Ukrainian archive, included hundreds of unpublished scores by J. S. Bach's sons and forebears and had been feared lost or destroyed. In fact, it has been in Ukraine since the Red Army took the documents from Germany as a trophy after World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRKLAND, LANE
description: KIRKLAND-Lane. The officers, members and staff of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union mourn the loss of retired AFL-CIO president Lane Kirkland. He was a champion of working people not just in the United States but throughout the world. His words and actions gave voice to the yearnings for dignity, democracy and freedom of those whose own voices were all too often muted by intimidation in the workplace at home or by the abuse of power abroad. Lane Kirkland believed in the dignity of work and working people and devoted his life to the struggles for justice and freedom. We witness his legacy every day wherever working people strive for, achieve and enjoy the rights and freedoms they deserve. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife, Irena. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, UFCW, AFL-CIO, CLC Stuart Appelbaum, President Charlie Hall, Sr., Secretary-Treasurer Lenore Miller, President Emeritus

title: Compressed Data; New Way to Travel the Web While Leaving Few Footprints

Many have sought the counsel of Internet consultants, while others have felt compelled to wade through stacks of dot-com and E-business books -- bought, no doubt, at Amazon.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDEMAN, ARTHUR LOUIS, CAPTAIN
description: HOLDEMAN-Arthur Louis, Captain. 82, of Galveston, TX, passed away Saturday, August 14, 1999, at UTMB Hospital. Funeral service will be 10 AM, Wednesday, August 18, 1999 at First Presbyterian Church in Crowley, LA, with Reverend Wilmer McNair officiating. Burial will follow the service at Woodlawn Cemetery, also in Crowley. Visitation will be Monday, August 16, 1999, at Malloy & Son Funeral Home from 5 until 8 PM. Visitation will also be held on Tuesday, August 17, 1999, at Geesey-Ferguson Funeral Home in Crowley, LA, from 4 until 9 PM. Mr. Holdeman was born May 9, 1917, in Lake Arthur, LA. He was a resident of Galveston for over 30 years and a member of the Protestant faith. As an example of labor solidarity, and to help foster democracy in the Middle East, he strengthened ties between the US labor movement and Israel's General Federation of Labor-Histadrut. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Irena, and to the entire family. National Committee for Labor Israel Jay Mazur, President Jerry Goodman, Exec Director

As a result of his Holocaust experiences, he understood the singular importance of standing firm against all manifestations of intolerance and bigotry. He was a friend and an inspiration. They returned for the first day of classes at Columbine since the terror of April 20 when two classmates stormed their school, killing 15 people including themselves.

title: Why Russia Risks All in Dagestan
description: Russia's assault on Chechen and Dagestani rebels in its southern republic of Dagestan is but one new chapter in the larger, bloodstained history of the Caucasus and the Caspian Sea. As the Russians resume their centuries-old battle with Muslim warriors in the North Caucasus, many in the region believe they are also trying to destabilize Georgia and Azerbaijan, two former Soviet states, to the south. These are strategically important countries, future conduits for large quantities of oil from the Caspian Sea. Their regimes are sufficiently unstable that it might not take much to topple them, especially if the West fails to pay sufficient attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUTZNICK, PHILIP
description: KLUTZNICK-Philip M., Ambassador. The officers and directors of the American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology (ATS) mourn the passing of Philip M. Klutznick of Chicago, Illinois. Ambassador Klutznick was a legendary philanthropist and leader of the world Jewish community and a distinguished and noted statesman. He served as U.S. Secretary of Commerce during the Carter administration and was appointed by President Kennedy as Representative to The Economic and Social Council of the United Nations (ECOSOC) from 1961-63. He served many years with distinction as International President of B'nai B'rith; co-founded the B'nai B'rith Youth Organization; was a founder of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations and authored a book on contemporary Jewish communal issues. He was a great and righteous friend of the people of Israel. Ambassador Klutznick made history in the field of urban development. Personally as well as professionally passionate about the field of urban planning, he and his wife, Ethel, demonstrated the highest level of commitment, becoming Guardians of Technion through the establishment and sustained support of The Philip M. and Ethel Klutznick Center for Urban and Regional Studies. Jews worldwide will miss this selfless man and beloved advocate, who was an inspiration to us all. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire Klutznick family. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence Jackier, Esq, President Irving Shepard, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive V.P. Joel Rothman, Esq, Chicago Chapter President Jerold A. Jacover, Esq, Chicago Chapter Chair Fred Greenberg, West Central Region Director

title: GAS TARIFF SCRAPPED
description: Mexico eliminated its tariff on natural gas imports from the United States and Canada, making it possible for American and Canadian companies to compete with the Government petroleum company, Pemex, on an equal basis. In late June, in retaliation against a dumping complaint by independent American oil companies, Mexico reversed an earlier promise to lift the tariff. When the complaint was dismissed by the United States Department of Commerce last Monday, Mexico said the tariff would soon be eliminated. Analysts said the elimination of the tariff was likely to lead to a surge in foreign investments.

title: EASTERN, GAS UTILITY, MAY OFFER ITSELF FOR SALE
description: Eastern Enterprises, which is buying two other natural gas utilities in New England, said yesterday that it might put all or part of itself up for sale to stay competitive in the region's deregulating energy markets. Eastern said that it had hired Salomon Smith Barney, Citigroup Inc.'s investment banking unit, to help review its options, which also include buying back stock and forming joint ventures. The company has a market value of about $894 million. Eastern, based in Weston, Mass., the owner of the Boston Gas Company, expects to complete its purchase of the Colonial Gas Company this month and of EnergyNorth Inc. in mid-2000. The company's shares rose 10 percent, gaining $4.125 each, to $43.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURFEIN, RUTHE
description: GURFEIN-Ruthe. The Board of Governors and members of Hampshire Country Club are deeply saddened by the passing of our esteemed member, Ruthe Gurfein. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her dear husband Louis and to all her family. Hampshire Country Club Board of Governors Norman Zarkin, President

title: Rwandans and Ugandans Meet on Congo
description: Rwandan leaders traveled to Uganda and held talks tonight aimed at easing tensions after troops from the two nations, once firm allies, fought for a third day in the Congolese city of Kisangani.

title: School Violence Shows a New Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLMES, FAY
description: COLMES-Fay. Loving wife of the late Louis. Beloved mother of Susan and Stephen Braitman and Alan Colmes. Adored grandmother of Gary, Mark and Ellen Braitman and David Shapiro. Great grandmother of Lilith Shapiro. Graveside services Tuesday, 10:30AM New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn New York

title: New York City Decides Not to Press Tobacco-Money Suit
description: New York City has decided not to pursue its lawsuit over how to divide the state's $25 billion share of the national tobacco settlement, officials for the city and the state said today, moving much of the nation an important step closer to the money beginning to flow.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press on Feb. 25 about a study of bias in heart care cited a statistic incorrectly. The study, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, showed that doctors were 7 percent less likely to order cardiac catheterization tests for female or black patients than for male or white patients -- not 40 percent less likely. The error is discussed in the current issue of the journal. Editors of the journal told the A.P. that they ''take responsibility for the media's overinterpretation'' of the study, which used an unusual statistical method.

title: School Violence Shows a New Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Feminist Professor Isn't Fighting a 'Backlash'
description: To the Editor:

title: Champions Win; Bronx Loses
description: Eric Campesi and Jeff Burgdorff each hit three-run homers and Casey Gaynor pitched a two-hitter to propel the defending world champion Toms River, N.J., to a 7-0 victory over State College, Pa., today in the quarterfinals of the Eastern Regional Little League tournament. Toms River will face the Capital City All-Stars from Washington, a 4-0 winner over the Rolando Paulino All-Stars of the Bronx, on Tuesday.

title: Celestine Sibley Is Dead at 85; Columnist Embodied the South
description: Celestine Sibley, an Atlanta newspaper columnist who for 55 years wrote about the commonplaces of Southern life in a prose as soothing as the hum of cicadas in summer, died on Sunday at her vacation home on Dog Island, Fla.

title: Increasing Foreign Aid Would Help Prevent Wars, Clinton Tells V.F.W. Convention
description: In a speech to the Veterans of Foreign Wars, President Clinton said today that American troops would have a better chance of being spared fighting in war if Congress would spend more money on foreign aid.

title: Sports of The Times; Reese Has His Heirs Even Today
description: THE tributes roll in from fans who rooted for Pee Wee Reese and players who competed against him in that raucous little playpen called Ebbets Field. Everybody knows Reese was as good a man as his legend would have it -- courteous, kind, inspirational, and he could execute the hit-and-run, too.

title: School Violence Shows a New Face
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Fund Manager Planning to Come Off the Sideline
description: It has been a busy summer for Julian H. Robertson Jr., who runs $11 billion in several hedge funds at Tiger Management. The hedge-fund manager is fighting to remove the chairman of the SK Telecom Company, the largest mobile-phone company in South Korea, while he tries to raise the sagging stock price of one of his largest holdings, U S Airways Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, MAX
description: RABINOWITZ-Max. On August 15, 1999 at 91 years. Loving uncle of Mike (Myron) Kaplan, dear cousin, brother of the late Ida Kaplan, late Samuel Rabinowitz and late Abraham Rabinowitz. Service today 11:30 a.m., ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, near ave V.

title: Warner Music Group Gets New Chief
description: Seeking to end years of management troubles in its record business, Time Warner Inc. yesterday named Roger Ames, the former president of the Polygram Music Group, as the chairman and chief executive of the Warner Music Group.

title: Water Consumption Drops 24% in New Jersey
description: Residents of New Jersey, who ignored pleas to conserve water voluntarily before being ordered to do so, now seem to have embraced the conservation ethic, with consumption steadily declining over the last two weeks.

title: In Straw Poll, Dole Got Help From Her 'Sisters'
description: Rose Kleyweg Mitchell was never much interested in politics until she heard that Elizabeth Dole was running for President. But what really got Ms. Mitchell excited about the candidate was not so much her positions on issues or her experience as a Cabinet Secretary or her Harvard law degree, but her affiliation with a women's fraternity: Delta Delta Delta.

title: San Francisco Agency Offers Gun Control Ad
description: In the wake of some recent high-profile shootings nationwide, a small agency in San Francisco, Red Ball Tiger, has created a television commercial advocating gun control. Agency executives are offering the spot free to any person or company that agrees to spend at least $5 million to run it.

title: P.G.A. a Hit With Viewers
description: Tiger Woods's victory over Sergio Garcia in the Professional Golfers' Association Championship produced the highest overnight rating since CBS began broadcasting the tournament in 1986.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: DEUTSCHE BANK A.G., Frankfurt, named Monte Koch and Donald Johnston co-heads of global mergers and acquisitions. Mr. Koch had been a managing director at the advisory unit of Bankers Trust and Mr. Johnston had been head of European mergers and acquisitions and will continue to serve as co-head of global investment banking in Europe.

title: Crescent in Accord on Hospital Operator
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, headed by the billionaire Richard Rainwater, said today that it had reached an agreement whereby an affiliate will take control of the struggling psychiatric hospital operator Charter Behavioral Health Systems L.L.C.

title: Accounts
description: * Visto Corp., Mountain View, Calif., to Left Field, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle the account of the Web-based personal information service. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: For Lamar Alexander, the End of the Line
description: Lamar Alexander abandoned his dogged six-and-a-half-year quest for the White House today, while top supporters of former Vice President Dan Quayle bolted from his campaign. Both candidates are suffering from an early Republican stampede to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas that has helped significantly cut short the traditional nominating process.

title: Testing That Buddhist Serenity in New York
description: IT is always easy to spot Nicholas Vreeland in a restaurant. And it's not just because he will be the only one draped in the maroon robes of a Buddhist monk. It's because he will be the calmest-looking guy in the whole place.

title: Jet Order for Bombardier
description: Bombardier Inc. said today it had sold 20 of its 50-passenger Canadair regional jet aircraft to Atlantic Coast Airlines for $430 million. Bombardier, which is based in Montreal, said the sale raised to 63 the number of the aircraft ordered by Atlantic Coast, 20 of which have been delivered. Bombardier said that Atlantic Coast, based in Dulles, Va., holds options to buy 27 more of the planes, which are twin-jet craft.

title: The New Republican Landscape
description: The Iowa straw poll, though it drew only 23,685 participants, has jostled the Republican Presidential field and clarified some issues. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas remains the strong front-runner, but after losing nearly 7 out of 10 votes in the poll he looks a little less invincible. Steve Forbes showed that he could use his money effectively to undercut Mr. Bush. Elizabeth Dole has regained some of the credibility she lost earlier in the year, and Gary Bauer has emerged as the favorite of religious conservatives.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 8 about Viola Sheely, a dancer and singer, misstated the relationship of a survivor and omitted a reference to four others. The survivor, Jessye, is her son, not her daughter. She also leaves her brothers Michael, Jerry, Joe and Larry, all of Belle Glade, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASS, SERENA
description: BASS-Serena. The partners, associates and staff of Thurm & Heller, LLP, note with sadness the passing of Serena Bass, beloved mother of our colleague Clifford I. Bass, and extend sincerest condolences to the family.

title: Regally Appealing Makes Her Case
description: The big shootout between the training superstars Bob Baffert and D. Wayne Lukas fizzled in the dust of old Saratoga today while John Kimmel was winning the Adirondack Stakes, the career-building race for 2-year-old fillies, with the 7-1 outsider Regally Appealing.

title: I.M.F. Urges Indonesia Leader to Act Quickly in Bank Scandal
description: The International Monetary Fund insisted today that President B. J. Habibie of Indonesia order a quick and thorough investigation of a banking scandal that has threatened to undermine the fund's $40 billion bailout of the nation's economy.

title: French Bank Stalemate Spurs Talk of a Foreign Takeover
description: The stockholders may have voted, but the five-month takeover battle involving three of France's biggest banks barely paused today.

title: Shares Close Higher in Sluggish Trading
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose for a fourth day yesterday, led by Hewlett-Packard as investors speculated that the company would report profit surpassing analysts' forecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REESE, HAROLD
description: REESE-Harold (Pee Wee). The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on August 14 in Louisville, Kentucky. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: LEADERS IN BOSNIA ARE SAID TO STEAL UP TO $1 BILLION
description: As much as a billion dollars has disappeared from public funds or been stolen from international aid projects through fraud carried out by the Muslim, Croatian and Serbian nationalist leaders who keep Bosnia rigidly partitioned into three ethnic enclaves, according to an exhaustive investigation by an American-led antifraud unit.

title: Remedy for All That Abuse? Snipe, Snipe, Snipe
description: ''Jar the Floor'' is set in a household that's run on negative energy, a place where survival depends on getting in one's full quota of daily digs. Cheryl L. West's combustible comedy-drama, which opened last night at the Second Stage Theater, assembles four generations of black women for a 90th-birthday party for the family matriarch, which is less an occasion for cake and candles than snipes and snide asides.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABERMAN, REBECCA
description: HABERMAN-Rebecca. A week ago when her pain was extreme, Rebecca Haberman expressed a wish to simply go to sleep and ''slip into paradise''. Last friday, August 13, 1999, a few weeks past her 79th birthday, she realized her wish, slipping away after a painful night. A remarkable woman loved by all who knew her and admired for her long and valiant fight against a non-Hodgkins' lymphoma that finally overwhelmed her, she leaves behind her stricken husband of 51 years, Harry, her devoted daughter Louisse, and innumerable grieving friends and relatives. At her request there is to be no funeral.

title: Where Are They Now? Sometimes, Even in Fashion
description: Fashion is a fickle business. One minute your name is on the door, above a runway, on a label -- and the next your backers withdraw support and you're wondering whether you should have got that teaching certificate after all.

title: Perfectly Matched at Medinah
description: The look of relief on Tiger Woods's face said it all as he tapped in a short putt on the last hole to win the P.G.A. Championship at Medinah Country Club outside Chicago on Sunday. It was not just that Woods had survived an inspired challenge by Sergio Garcia, a fearless 19-year-old Spaniard whose creative shot-making recalled the miraculous strokes of a young, charging Arnold Palmer. That alone would have made this a memorable afternoon of golf. But for Woods the greater significance lay in proving to himself and the world that his runaway victory in the 1997 Masters Tournament would not become just a symbol of unfulfilled expectations.

title: Primedia to Sell Publishing Group
description: Primedia Inc., a publisher controlled by the buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, which owns 83 percent of the shares, agreed to sell its supplemental educational publishing group to Ripplewood Holdings L.L.C. for $415 million to reduce its debt.

title: In a Tidy Town, Tiny Flags Make Waves; Neatness Counts in Stratford, Where Deli Fights Order to Furl Old Glories
description: Michael Reekie has a thing for American flags, especially miniature ones the size of school notebooks. ''I buy them by the case,'' he said proudly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLBER, LUBA
description: KOLBER-Luba (nee Kahan). In Fort Lauderdale, Florida on Sunday, August 15, 1999. Wife of the late Dr. Moses Isaac Kolber and the late Philip Lassar. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Senator Leo and Sandra Kolber, Samuel and Jacqueline Kolber of Toronto. Cherished granny Luba of Lynne Halliday and B.H. Barry, Jonathan and Irit Kolber of Israel, Daniel, Andrea and Tamara Kolber of Toronto. Loving great grandmother of Olivia Halliday; Benjamin and Daniella Kolber. Burial in Montreal.

title: Female M.D.'s More Open With Options, Patients Say
description: Female doctors are viewed as less authoritarian and more likely to involve patients in their health care than male doctors, according to a new study by Johns Hopkins University researchers. The study also found that black patients see white doctors as inviting less participation than doctors who are black.

title: Exhibiting the Art Of History's Dustbin; Dictators' Treasures Stir German Anger
description: Long kept from public view, more than 100 paintings collected by Hitler are on display here, offering an intriguing glimpse of the art he believed should adorn the 1,000-year Reich planned by the Nazis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATALANO, JOSEPH
description: PATALANO-Joseph.The Philharmonic Symphony-Society of New York, Inc., mourns the sudden and tragic passing of Joseph Patalano, a deeply valued member of the New York Philharmonic family and beloved brother of Stage Representative Louis Patalano. The Philharmonic extends its heartfelt sympathy to Louis and the entire family. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec. Director

title: Schoenberg The Demon In a Setting For Love
description: Festivals that are built around single composers usually take a predictably smooth road: the composer, almost invariably, is one whose music is widely loved, and however deeply a festival may delve into historical and biographical matters or rarely heard works, its essential function is to celebrate the communion between the composer and an admiring audience.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen rose against the dollar after Japan said industrial output in June rose more than initially reported. In New York, the dollar settled at 114.68 yen, down from 115.74 on Friday.

title: By Design; Fillips, in Whispers and Shouts
description: As minimalism has lost favor, designers are turning to decoration. A favorite is embroidery -- a mere touch, a scattering or all-over adornment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIGG, BEATRICE
description: WIGG-Beatrice, Forever Beeloved. Enshrined in our hearts

title: Lehman and Pate Complete U.S. Roster for Ryder Cup
description: With one pick that was anticipated, and one that was more surprising, Ben Crenshaw named Tom Lehman and Steve Pate today as the two captain's picks for the United States Ryder Cup team.

title: Commerce Dept. Seeks to Close Government Information Service
description: For almost 50 years a small agency of the Commerce Department has done business in the resale of Government documents and reports. Now the department is proposing to shut down the service, saying it is no longer viable because of the wealth of free information on the Internet.

title: The Electronic Block Party
description: It was bound to happen. Everything else is on line. So why not the neighborhood? More than an extension of the block party, it's become a way of life. You've heard of AOL? We're NOL.

title: MCI Net Snag Could Drive Small Providers Out of Business
description: The 10-day partial shutdown of MCI Worldcom's high-speed data network took a cataclysmic toll on dozens and possibly hundreds of small Internet service providers who were forced to close altogether last week. Some say they may go out of business as a result.

title: Toys 'R' Us Profit Off 25% in Quarter
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said today that its second-quarter profit fell 25 percent because of costs to develop its Internet division.

title: Energy to Count On; Fuel Cells Tapped as Power Source for Computer Systems
description: The lights may go out in the research labs at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York and may dim all over the East as voltage droops on hot summer days, but here, the juice never falters. Not since a cold day in early 1997, when power flickered briefly at the headquarters of the First National Bank of Omaha, causing a computer crash that executives vowed would never happen again.

title: Paying More for Water
description: To the Editor:

title: End to a Presidential Run
description: Lamar Alexander abandoned his quest for the White House, while top supporters of Dan Quayle bolted from his campaign. Page A14.

title: Hewlett Says Earnings Top Expectations
description: For the fourth consecutive quarter, the Hewlett-Packard Company has reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates. Hewlett-Packard officials who announced the figures today also predicted that the company would see 11 to 13 percent revenue growth in the next quarter.

title: Spacecraft Spots A Martian Storm, Plus Dust Devils
description: The canals that the 19th-century astronomer Percival Lowell believed he saw on Mars were thought to be evidence of an active civilization. Their existence was long ago disproved, of course, but Mars has been shown to be an active place nonetheless. It's just nature, not little green men, that is raising a ruckus.

title: For Giants, Playacting Is the Key To the Play
description: Tiki Barber, the Giants' running back, appeared in an Off Broadway play last winter. At the Giants' training camp this summer, he has been putting his acting experience to good use.

title: Tippecanoe and Trivia, Too: C-Span's Hail to the Chiefs
description: On a trip into the South after he assumed the Presidency, George Washington traveled through the countryside by coach. But on entering a new town, he would switch to horseback and make his entrance in a manner befitting a military victor: on a gallant white charger. Or so viewers of C-Span have learned on ''American Presidents: Life Portraits,'' that network's easygoing series about all 41 of them, which began in March with George Washington of Mount Vernon, Va., and is set to continue into December, when it concludes with Bill Clinton of Hot Springs, Ark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELMAN, GERALD M.
description: SPIELMAN-Gerald M. It is with great sadness that Congregation Beth Elohim mourns the sudden passing of its recent president, Gerald Spielman. For five years, ''Doc Gerry'' led the congregation with dedication and caring. His commitment to Jewish learning was an inspiration to all. As a pediatrician, he was devoted to his patients and to his prpofession. We extend our deepest sympathies to Phyllis, Jocelyn and Loren as well as to his parents and brothers. We have lost a dear and wonderful friend. Services Wednesday, August 18, 11AM at Congregation Beth Elohim, 8th Avenue and Garfield Place, Brooklyn NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Congregation's Kadima Fund. Paul Levy, President Gerald I. Weider, Rabbi

title: NBT AGREES TO BUY LAKE ARIEL BANCORP
description: NBT Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Lake Ariel Bancorp Inc. of Scranton, Pa., for $18.50 a share, a total of $92.8 million. NBT Bancorp owns NBT Bank, which operates 36 branches in central New York and has assets of $1.3 billion. Lake Ariel is the parent of LA Bank, which has 22 branches in northeastern Pennsylvania and assets of $500 million. After the merger, LA Bank will become a wholly owned banking unit of NBT. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Lake Ariel closed at $16.4375, up $3.4375 or more than 26 percent, while NBT shares closed down $1.125, or 5.5 percent, at $19.125.

title: Leaf-Proud New England Braces for a Brownish Fall
description: The vistas here in the Berkshire foothills are already brown. Shriveled oak leaves are crunching under the boots of hikers on the Appalachian Trail, and enough maple leaves have fallen on the village green to force a most unwelcome summer chore: raking.

title: For Brewers, Money Can't Buy Victories
description: The Minnesota Twins are making progress before their very eyes. In last place for 12 consecutive weeks, one week short of half the season, the Twins are now in third place in the American League Central, holding their largest lead over the fourth-place team. This is a team that has 9 rookies on its 25-man roster and has had as many as 12.

title: BURLINGTON RESOURCES TO BUY POCO PETROLEUMS
description: Burlington Resources Inc. said late yesterday that it would buy Poco Petroleums Ltd. for about $1.75 billion in stock, making it North America's fourth-largest producer of natural gas. It will also assume about $750 million in Poco's debt. Burlington, a Houston-based natural gas and oil exploration company, offered to pay 0.25 share of its stock, currently valued at $11.33, for each Poco share. Burlington wants Poco's natural gas reserves in Canada. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the year, Burlington said. Shares of Houston-based Burlington fell $1.375 each, to $45.3125, in New York. The Poco acquisition was announced after the close of New York trading.

title: Real I.P.O. Winners
description: To the Editor:

title: TALK OF MICROSOFT-GLOBO DEAL
description: Trading was halted in shares of Globo Cabo S.A., Brazil's largest cable television company, contributing to speculation it had struck a deal that would give the Microsoft Corporation a foothold in Brazil's nascent market for high-speed Internet access through cable TV. Shares in Globo Cabo, part of the Globo media empire, have surged nearly 50 percent in the last month on local reports that an alliance is imminent. Were Microsoft to buy a minority stake, it would get a jump on competition to equip Brazil's estimated 8.5 million pay-TV customers with advanced Internet services.

title: Of Wounded Mice and Rapid Recoveries
description: Scientists have discovered a way to speed the healing of wounds in mice, and the finding, they say, may eventually benefit humans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, RICA
description: SMITH-Rica (Nee Martens). Actress who appeared in such feature films as Living in Oblivion, Welcome to the Dollhouse and Box of Moonlight, and such Broadway shows as The Shrike and Laura, died August 11, 1999. She was the beloved mother of Laurel Smith and loving sister of Fred Martens, Evelyn, Ladick and Lotus Murphy. She was the greatest mother a daughter could ask for and a loyal and compassionate friend to those she loved. A memorial service will be held at MCC Theater, 120 W. 28th St. August 26, 7:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the American Lung Association, 1740 Broadway, NYC, 10019.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Don't Try to Rob Ex-TV Detective

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITTOFF, SYLVIA
description: RITTOFF-Sylvia. Passed away peacefully at age 92. She will be greatly missed and in our hearts forever. Beloved wife of the late George, loving mother of Phyllis Vietri and the late Terry Berger. Treasured grandmother to Brad and Greg Berger, Leslie Berger Mendell and Robert and Lewis Gutterman, great-grandmother (''G.G.'') to Nicole, Jason, Tara and Niki. Funeral services to be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, NY, Tuesday, 10 a.m. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to White Plains Hospital Center, Davis Avenue, White Plains, NY.

title: Rarely Bested Astronomers Are Stumped by a Tiny Light
description: Every night at their telescopes, astronomers invite the universe to a contest of wits. Surprise us, they say, with some teasing wink of light, some few cryptic clues to something unfamiliar and, better yet, an implied challenge to a cherished theory. In most cases, astronomers boast, we will have it figured out by dawn.

title: MARKEL TO BUY TERRA NOVA, ANOTHER SPECIALTY INSURER
description: In a deal that would combine two big specialty insurance companies, the Markel Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Terra Nova Holdings Ltd. for cash and stock valued at $905 million. Markel, based in Richmond, will pay $362 million in cash and 2.94 million of its common shares. Markel will also assume $175 million in Terra Nova debt. The deal values Terra Nova, which is based in Hamilton, Bermuda, at $34 a share. The stock jumped 20 percent, gaining $5.0625, to $31, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shareholders of Terra Nova will be able to choose between cash, stock or a combination for their shares. Markel dropped $8.50 a share, to $176.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, KATHLEEN
description: FOX-Kathleen of Brooklyn on August 15, 1999. Beloved daughter of Mary Fox. Loving sister of John, Patrick and Ellen Fox and Maura Frawley. Casey McCallum-Rice South Shore Funeral Home, 30 Nelson Ave, Great Kills, Staten Island. Friends will be received Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Habitat for Humanity appreciated.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULGER, HOWARD J.
description: BULGER-Howard J., age 80, of Hockessin, DE, died Sunday, August 15th, 1999. Mr. Bulger, a Marine Corps veteran, was a teacher and coach at Iona College. He graduated from Manhattan College and Columbia. He is survived by wife, Jeanne, 3 children, 4 stepsons and 14 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Manhattan College Track Program, Manhattan Parkway, Riverdale, NY 10471.

title: Selfless, Helpful and Intelligent: the Wasp; Yellow Jackets Much More Than the Evil Guests at the Picnic, Scientists Say
description: It is late summer, which means it is time to grit one's teeth, get outside for a little family picnic, and practice that ever-fashionable dance routine, the Yellow Jacket Jive. Herewith, some tips from a mistress of the form (ahem):

title: Big Lapses Found in Pentagon's Security-Clearance Check
description: The Pentagon is doing an incomplete job in conducting background investigations of its candidates for security clearances and in addition has built up a backlog of more than 500,000 such cases, according to preliminary findings by the General Accounting Office.

title: B. F.Goodrich to Cut Jobs and Close Plants
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company, the No. 1 United States maker of aircraft landing gear, said today that it would close plants in New Jersey and Connecticut and cut 275 jobs as it digests its $2.2 billion purchase of Coltec Industries.

title: Feminist Professor Isn't Fighting a 'Backlash'
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. Clears Way for Kennedy Train Project, Officials Say
description: Officials at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey say the money for the $1.55 billion passenger train system at Kennedy International Airport is finally secure with the approval today of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Beijing Journal; If It's a Comic Book, Why Is Nobody Laughing?
description: For the ordinary Chinese citizen who may be tiring of the Government's relentless crusade denouncing Falun Gong, the spiritual movement that was outlawed last month, there is now an easy-to-read version: the comic book.

title: School Violence Shows a New Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Ohio Supreme Court Voids Legal Limits on Damage Suits
description: Accelerating an intense battle in state courts around the country over laws to curtail damage suits, the Ohio Supreme Court struck down the state's sweeping three-year-old law yesterday.

title: VITAL SIGNS: AT RISK; Love Raw Sprouts? So Do Bacteria
description: They are tasty in salads, and make a crunchy addition to a turkey sandwich. But a new study suggests that the elderly, small children and those with weak immune systems should steer clear of raw sprouts, which are often contaminated with disease-causing bacteria like E. coli, B. cereus and salmonella.

title: Philip M. Klutznick, 92, Builder And a Leader in Jewish Affairs
description: Philip M. Klutznick, a Chicago real estate developer, investor and philanthropist who was long prominent in Jewish communal affairs and served as Secretary of Commerce in the Carter Administration, died on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELD, EFREM
description: FELD-Efrem, PhD. Died August 11, 1999. In gratitude for his many years of service to the Alfred Adler Center for Mental Health, Efrem Feld, PhD is mourned and will be missed by all who knew him. Joan Odes, LCSW Executive Director, AACMH

title: Ready for a Race, Mayor Goes to Saratoga
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani left behind his usual dark suits and trod among the men in linen suits and women in broad-brimmed hats here today, making one of the more genteel stops on the upstate political circuit with a day at the races.

title: The New Kid Is Garcia, But Woods Is the Man
description: Reflecting on Sunday's dramatic back nine of the P.G.A. Championship, Ben Crenshaw said what many people were thinking. ''That,'' said Crenshaw, ''was the future of golf.''

title: Patterns
description: A Fashion Wire Service

title: From Dance Fledglings, an Ideal of Africa and Family
description: ''We have begun our rehearsals for the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival,'' the message announced solemnly on the telephone answering machine of the Batoto Yetu dance company. And, indeed, an intense rehearsal was in progress one recent afternoon a few blocks north of the African dance company's headquarters on the Upper West Side. Dressed in T-shirts, baggy pants and mammoth track shoes, the dancers negotiated swirling patterns with surprising grace, only occasionally sneaking a side glance at the mirror.

title: CHINA AIRLINE ORDER
description: Taiwan's largest airline, China Airlines, signed contracts to buy $800 million worth of engines from the General Electric Company and CFM International to power planes it ordered from the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie. The airline said last week that it would buy as many as 24 Boeings and 12 Airbuses in the next four years. CFM is a venture of General Electric and Snecma of France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, BOWER, MARY F.
description: WHITE-BOWER-Mary F. Of Southampton, NY and West Palm Beach, FL. On August 15, 1999 at Southampton, NY. Survived by her loving husband of 66 years, Robert; predeceased by her son Robert E. Also survived by her sister Kathleen Mullen of Galway, Ireland, and several nieces and nephews. There will be a funeral Mass at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Church, 168 Hill Street, Southampton on August 17 at 11:00 A.M. Burial will follow at the church cemetery.

title: CASES; A View of 'the Other Side' Through Dying Patients' Eyes
description: I was a medical intern in 1976 when I met the Reverend, a fundamentalist preacher. The Reverend had no faith in medical technology or its practitioners, and had vowed never to enter the hospital. Life and death, in his opinion, should be left exclusively in God's hands.

title: Harnessing the Powerful Secrets of a Dog's Nose
description: Abbey loved to play, so much so that her distraught owner gave her to a dog pound. Who, after all, wanted a Chesapeake Bay retriever whose notion of fun was chewing up the curtains?

title: Dutch Concern to Buy Nielsen Media Research

title: Cancer Gene Tests Turn Out to Be Far From Simple
description: When scientists identified two genes, BRCA-1 and BRCA-2, as the culprits in most hereditary cases of breast cancer, the discovery prompted much excitement and hope. Women with family histories of breast cancer would at last be able to determine if they, too, were likely to get the disease. And so armed, they could take preventive action.

description: After one of the AT&T Corporation's big data networks, based on equipment from Cisco Systems Inc., failed last year, AT&T fully restored the system in about 24 hours.

description: GIBSON-Carol (nee Epp). Of Brightwaters, NY. On August 15, 1999. Beloved mother of Camille, Judith and Denise. Eucharistic minister at St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church, Bay Shore, committed advocate for the poor and disenfranchised of the community, among the original founders of the St. Patrick Hospitality Center; Chairperson of the Suffolk County Commissioner's Advisory Committee on Social Services and a recent recipient of the District 8 Legislator's Volunteer of the Year award. The family will receive friends at the White-Voltz Funeral Home, 364 East Main Street, Bay Shore, NY Tuesday 2-5, 7-9pm. Mass of the Christian Burial Wednesday 11am at St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church, Bay Shore. Interment, St. Patrick Cemetery, Bay Shore. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Patrick Hospitality Center, 9 North Clinton Avenue, Bay Shore, NY 11706.

description: For four years, John Martini Sr., a death row inmate, said to anyone who would listen that he could not wait to die. But yesterday, Mr. Martini signed papers instructing his lawyers to do everything in their legal power to keep him from being executed on Sept. 22.

title: Drug Officer Shoots Man; Suspect in Prior Sting Dies
description: A police officer shot and critically wounded a man on a Brooklyn street yesterday after an undercover drug operation went awry, the police said. The shooting was the second in two days by the police during a drug sting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN KIRK, W.
description: VAN KIRK-W. Philip, attorney, of Rye, NY and Williamsville, VT, died at home on August 15, age 79. A graduate of Columbia Law, he was managing partner at Burns, Van Kirk, Greene and Kafer in New York and, recently, of counsel to Meighan and Necarsulmer in Mamaroneck. Married to Dorothy Keane for 52 years, he is survived by his wife; three children, Leslie Clark, Philip, Jr. and Geoffrey; and four grandchildren. During WW II, he served as Captain, Army Intelligence, for the 412th Fighter Squadron. A private family service is planned. Gifts in his memory may be made to the Hospice of Westchester, 95 So. Broadway, White Plains, NY 10601-4403.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHLAN, SIDNEY Q.
description: COHLAN-Sidney Q., M.D. KiDS of NYU Medical Center mourns the passing of Dr. Sidney Cohlan. He was a gifted physician and teacher. His wisdom and generosity of spirit inspired us to create this organization. We, together with the countless children and families of KiDS, have lost a wonderful friend, but one whom we will always remember with enormous gratitude and love. Carla Magliocco, Founding Chair Alice Tisch, Chair KiDS of NYU Medical Center

title: HOCHTIEF AGREES TO ACQUIRE TURNER, U.S. BUILDER
description: Hochtief A. G., Germany's biggest builder by market value, agreed yesterday to buy the Turner Corporation, a United States builder, for $263 million to reduce its reliance on a sluggish home market. Hochtief will pay $28.625 for each Turner share. Turner officials said there were no plans to dismiss any of its 3,300 workers. Hochtief, based in Essen, which builds highways and nuclear power plants, is 66 percent owned by the German utility giant RWE A. G. Turner handles large-scale general construction. Turner's shares rose 13 percent, gaining $3.3125 each, to $28.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ELIZABETH FORSLING
description: HARRIS-Elizabeth Forsling. To Betty, the mother I always wanted, you opened the door on the real world for me and for others I will never meet. I love you and will be listening for your creative spirit for the rest of my own days on this earth. I know I'll never find another like you in this lifetime. Will be looking for you in the next one. Karen Olson

The wild fish from the Pacific has so much flavor that it needs little more than a sprinkling of salt. But the addition of oil or butter and a single herb, combined with a near-foolproof roasting technique, gives many more options.

title: PROGRESS ON BANK DEAL
description: Shareholders of Banca Intesa S.p.A. approved management's move to acquire Banca Commerciale Italiana and create the largest bank in Italy and and the 11th largest in Europe. The new company would have assets of around 279 billion euros ($295.1 billion), 3,511 branches in Italy and offices in 41 countries. Intesa's chairman, Giovanni Bazoli, told shareholders that the Bank of Italy, which regulates lenders, had given preliminary approval to the merger.

description: Jim Fassel indicated today that he expected the injured cornerback Jason Sehorn to miss the Giants' third preseason game, Aug. 28 against the Jets, which makes it possible, perhaps even probable, that Sehorn will not be ready to start the season opener Sept. 12 against Tampa Bay.

title: The Unlikely Star of the Summer of '99
description: IF swine had a Social Register, the two suckling pigs that were delivered by limousine recently to Chez Louis in midtown would rank as blue bloods. They were raised in Mount Kisco, N.Y., at a tiny farm co-owned by Jerome Kohlberg, a founding partner in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the investment firm. When the usual deliveryman was unavailable, the pigs were sent in style to the restaurant, where they fetched the aristocratic price of $29.95 a portion the next night.

title: Midsummer Night's Nightmare

title: Food You Remember, Service You Can't Forget
description: WOULD you eat here again?'' I asked a friend as we left Resto Leon, a tiny storefront restaurant that opened about two months ago in the East Village. He paused and then said, ''Yeah, I would,'' but he had to think before answering.

title: Panel Faults Hospital in Case of Schizophrenic Later Killed in Attack on Police
description: Kevin Cerbelli, a 30-year-old with schizophrenia, had been in and out of the psychiatric ward of Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens in the two years preceding the night of Oct. 25, when he walked bare-chested and barefoot into a police station house in Queens, armed with a screwdriver and carrying a rosary.

title: For Three Aspiring Prizefighters, the Prize Is Hope
description: The Bed-Stuy Boxing Center, the Brooklyn gym that is the center of Nanette Burstein and Brett Morgen's wrenching documentary ''On the Ropes,'' is much more than a neighborhood training facility for aspiring prizefighters. For the three eager young boxers whose lives are examined by the film, it is a starting point, both real and symbolic, for them to begin taking control of their lives and avoiding the self-destructive temptations of the street.

title: Account Decisions By 2 Advertisers
description: Two on-line advertisers have made decisions on their accounts.

title: MEADOWBROOK AND INVESTOR TO BUY KSL GOLF COURSE UNIT
description: Meadowbrook Golf Group Inc. said yesterday that it had teamed up with the financier Leon Black to acquire the golf course unit of the KSL Recreation Corporation, a resort owner. Terms were not disclosed, but Meadowbrook's chairman, Arnold Rosenstein, said his company and Mr. Black paid more than $100 million. The unit, the KSL Fairways Golf Corporation, owns 24 properties with 30 golf courses, mainly in Florida, Maryland, Virginia and Wisconsin. Meadowbrook owns three courses and leases or manages an additional 27. KSL, which is controlled by the leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, said it would focus on its high-end resort properties.

title: A High-Style Retailer's Affectionate Angst
description: ''OY,'' Jeffrey Kalinsky, the hot new retailer in town, is saying, plopping his head on the shoulder of the reporter he has just met. It is the news that 14th Street, the site of Jeffrey, his just-opened high fashion shop, is not actually in Chelsea, that is making for this faux collapse, though don't you worry, there will be others, genuine, not stamped, as they say in the fashion business, later on.

title: Texas Court Halts a Death To Determine Competency
description: Five hours before a convicted murderer, Larry Keith Robison, was scheduled to die by lethal injection, the highest criminal court in Texas granted him a stay of execution today to determine whether Mr. Robison, who is mentally ill, is competent to go to the death chamber.

title: Wildlife Agency Objects To Cranberry Bog Plan
description: New Jersey cranberry growers and Federal environmental regulators have reached agreement for the first time on a plan to expand the state's cranberry bogs into sensitive wetlands. But today, officials of another Federal agency said the proposal, released without much fanfare last month, was objectionable to them.

title: Liberty Wins Conference And Receives Playoff Bye
description: The Liberty had something to prove last night: that it could beat the Washington Mystics.

While the university has agreed to test Campus Pipeline's software with a small number of students, it has not contracted to adopt the software fully or have the company run the campus site.

description: As two Federal agencies review the AT&T Corporation's $58 billion bid to buy Mediaone Group, they face the central question of whether the combination is, in essence, too large to block.

description: Carlos Cachaca, one of Brazil's most prolific and beloved songwriters and a founder of the samba troupe whose creativity made Rio de Janeiro's annual pre-Lenten Carnival an international attraction, died here on Monday. He was 97.

description: For barely two weeks, Jim Leyritz carried a statistical torch passed to him by Mark McGwire. But now Leyritz has relayed it to someone else.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL SHEDS SOME NONVALVE BUSINESSES
description: Tyco International Ltd., one of the world's biggest makers of flow-control valves, said yesterday that it had sold some nonvalve portions of its flow-control business for an undisclosed price to a company formed by DLJ Merchant Banking Partners II L.P., a merchant banking fund of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. Tyco's chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, said last month that he expected to sell part of the flow-control business with about $800 million in annual sales for around $1 billion. The businesses sold include the Mueller Company and Grinnell Supply Sales and Manufacturing units. Donaldson Lufkin is part of AXA S.A.'s Equitable Companies.

title: Business Travel; It's possible to track airlines flights on a nearly real-time basis through the Internet.
description: AS the number of airline delays in the United States soars, travelers can go on line to track their flights or those of colleagues.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 28 about the Los Angeles Board of Education's debate over whether to abandon a $200 million school project because of environmental concerns misidentified the developer who is building the school. The developer is Temple Beaudry Partners; Kajima Urban Development is one of the partners that own Temple Beaudry. The article also misstated the developer's role in collecting soil samples from the site, which adjoins an abandoned oil field. Samples were collected by outside consultants hired by the school district. Temple Beaudry did not collect the samples.

title: FRENCH PRESSURE ON MERGER
description: The French Government is determined to force Societe Generale S.A. into a merger with Banque Nationale de Paris S.A. to create the world's biggest bank, a Societe Generale executive suggested. The country's banking regulator delayed for a week its decision on whether to let Banque Nationale keep a 36.8 percent stake in Societe Generale -- worth about $6.7 billion -- that it won after a six-month battle. France's No. 3 bank also won 65.1 percent of Paribas, defeating Societe Generale's friendly bid. ''This is a strong political message -- they want to take a week to explain to us that we should be reasonable, to try to find a very French solution to this problem,'' said Philippe Citerne, a managing director of Societe Generale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUNGER, JOHN D.
description: MUNGER-John D. Age 96, of New Canaan, CT, on August 12, 1999. Survived by his daughter Susan H. Munger, and one son, Hiram H. Munger. Memorial Service Saturday August 21st, at 11:30 A.M. at Saint Mark's Church, Route 124, New Canaan, CT.

title: FREESERVE STOCK TRADING
description: The British subscription-free Internet access provider, Freeserve P.L.C., announced it would offer on-line securities trading to compete with discount brokers like E*Trade Group Inc. and the Charles Schwab Corporation, which have established sites for British Web surfers. Freeserve, Britain's largest Internet provider, hopes the new brokerage service will help differentiate it from the proliferation of other subscription-free Internet providers in Britain, including America Online's entrant to be introduced this fall, Netscape Online.

title: Supplying Fresh Parts for Beloved Blenders
description: AS anyone who uses a blender or food processor comes to realize sooner or later, the motor outlasts everything else -- blender jars, gaskets, feed tubes, slicing disks, shredding disks, dough blades. But don't throw that appliance away when the parts go. Just click on www.culinaryparts .com for replacements. This is the Web site of Culinary Parts Unlimited of Pachego, Calif., which has been supplying kitchen gizmos since 1976, beginning with the Cuisinart Robot Coupe, for which it still has parts. All of the parts are factory-fresh, no matter how old the model may be.

title: When the West Was Wild, and Fish Were Fish
description: FOR those among the fortune-seeking forty-niners who survived scurvy and shipwreck on the voyage around Cape Horn, and for those who survived snow and starvation traveling overland, San Francisco presented a gaudy spectacle of freedom, where the restraints of the East fell away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, WELLES
description: WERNER-Welles. 80, of New York, died August 16, 1999 in Seattle, WA. He was born September 4, 1918 in Brooklyn, NY. He worked as a commercial interior designer for over 40 years in the New York area. Welles is survived by his daughters, April and Nancy Werner, and his sister, Estelle Kellerman. He was preceded in death by his wife of 55 years, Carolyn, in 1997. In keeping with his wishes, no services will be held. Memorials may be made to the Alzheimers Association, 12721 30th Avenue NE, Seattle, WA 98125.

When it also appears to be an environmentally responsible ice cream, it becomes irresistible. If every bite helps to preserve the rain forest, you have to keep eating.

title: THE CHEF
description: QUAIL is a small bird that makes a big impression. It has a sweet, mellow flavor that's slightly gamy, but not at all livery like squab. Quail can stand up to strong ingredients like bacon, spices and vinaigrettes, which makes it interesting to work with. And it holds its own when charred over a grill. In fact, the high heat and the charcoal actually accentuate a quail's sweetness rather than overpowering it. This makes quail perfect for summer grilling.

title: The Rural Life; A Moment Before Ripeness
description: I have been stung by nettles so often this summer that my hands have reached a state of continuous numbness -- not so numb, however, that I can't feel the next nettle bite. I go down without gloves to the vegetable garden in early morning when the dew is still thick, planning only to drink my coffee and watch the potatoes grow. But new nettles have always sprung up overnight, and old ones that lay hidden in the hops reveal themselves in the low sun. I can't help plucking them, even barehanded. ''Weeds of the Northeast,'' that indispensable book, prints a lurid photo of a nettle's stinging hairs. It adds, ''When the tip of the hair is broken off on contact with the skin, it acts as a hypodermic needle, injecting the toxins histamine, acetylcholine, and 5-hydroxytryptamine into the wound.'' Nettles prefer rich soil, so I acknowledge the compliment and heave them onto the compost pile.

title: Maverick Art Rears Its Tusks in an Old Tuscan Town

title: Sweetness Unpunished

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUTZNICK, PHILIP M.
description: KLUTZNICK-Philip M. The members, leadership and staff of B'nai B'rith International deeply mourn the passing of their esteemed past international president, Philip M. Klutznick. Klutznick was one of B'nai B'rith's and world Jewry's greatest leaders. From 1953 to 1959, he served as President of B'nai B'rith International, leading the organization's efforts to revitalize european Jewry and build Irsael in the years following the Holocaust. Earlier he was a co-founder of Aleph Zadik Aleph, now the boys' arm of the B'nai B'rith Youth Organization and served as its second national president in 1925-26. He later was a founder of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations and served as chairman of the World Jewish Congress. He was appointed to high level positions by several presidents and served a term as U.S. Secretary of Commerce for Jimmy Carter, 1979-81. B'nai B'rith will honor and always remember the contributions made by him and his late wife Ethel Klutznick in their commitment to the well being of Jews around the world. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Klutznick family. Richard D. Heideman, President Dr. Sidney Clearfield, Exec VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARRON, EUGENIE M.
description: MARRON-Eugenie M. 99 years old, of Palm Beach, FL, died on Monday, August 16, 1999 at a local hospital. Mrs. Marron had been a resident of Palm Beach for the past 50 years and was a former resident of New York, NY and Brielle, NJ. She received a Masters Degree in Fine Arts from Columbia University and was a noted artist and sculptor, studying under Alexander Archipenko, and exhibiting her works in Carnegie Hall and Wally Findlay Galleries of Palm Beach. In addition, The Smithsonian Institute requested one of her sculptures for display. Mrs. Marron was also a concert pianist, having performed in Carnegie Hall as well as an author, with two published books ''Albacora'' and ''Caught in the Act.'' She was a world renowned big game fisherwoman, holding five world records, one still unbroken (Swordfish, 722 lbs). Along with her husband, Louis E. Marron, she traveled the world for big game fish and assisted in research for M.I.T. and University of Miami Marine Laboratory relating to studies of the Giant Squid's nervous system. A generous philanthropist, Mrs. Marron was a former chairperson of the Palm Beach Heart Ball and was the founder of the Salvation Army Ball of Palm Beach and served as its chairperson for 10 years. She was a former member of the New York Metropolitan Club, the Bath and Tennis Club of Spring Lake, NJ, the Spring Lake Country Club, the Croquet Club of Spring Lake, the Brielle Country Club of Brielle, NJ, the Anglers Club of the Florida Keys, the Sailfish Club and the Bath and Tennis Club, both of Palm Beach, and was a current member of the Everglades Club of Palm Beach. Mrs. Marron was preceded in death by her husband, Louis E. Marron in 1969. She is survived by her nieces, Eugenie Wikberg of Ft. Lauderdale, FL and Suzanne J. Treacy of Deerfield Beach, FL; two grandnieces, Suzanne Ross and Christina Wikberg; a grandnephew, John William Wikberg, Jr.; and a greatgrandnephew, James Ross, IV. A Wake Service will be held at 7:00 P.M. on Thursday, August 19, 1999 at Quattlebaum-Holleman Burse Funeral Home, 1201 South Olive Avenue, West Palm Beach. The Mass of the Resurrection will be held at 10:00 A.M. on Friday, August 20, 1999 at St. Edwards Catholic Church, Palm Beach, FL. Entombment will take place in the St. Catherine's Cemetery of Wall Township, NJ. Friends may call at the funeral home between the hours of 6:00 to 8:00 P.M. on Thursday. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Salvation Army, 2100 Palm Beach Lakes Boulevard, West Palm Beach, FL 33409.

title: Beneath the Rubble

It was, in a way, the worst possible combination of circumstances, the most brutally powerful quake on record in the area striking at night in an urban region that appears to have built well beyond its capacity to respond to a civic disaster on this scale. But such a destructive earthquake, originating so close to a population center, would surpass the ability of any government to respond swiftly enough to limit the immediate loss of life. The number of dead and injured, already counted in the thousands, will surely rise in the days ahead as debris is cleared.

title: REBOUNDS BY SOUTH KOREAN BANKS
description: Emerging from losses last year, most South Korean commercial banks posted profits for the first half of this year, helped by strengthening financial markets, revamping efforts and a diminished need to set aside money for bad loans, the Financial Supervisory Commission said. Fifteen of South Korea's 18 commercial banks made money, generating a combined profit of 442.4 billion won ($367 million) in contrast to losses of 6.8 trillion won ($5.6 billion) in the corresponding period last year. The banks that posted losses included two big banks that have struggled despite extensive Government assistance: Seoulbank and Korea First Bank. Kangwon Bank was the third that lost money.

title: Sports of The Times; Coughlin's Rigid Rule Is Mellowing
description: TOM COUGHLIN has supposedly gone soft this year -- all hugs and kisses. When he was named coach of the Jacksonville Jaguars five years ago his players had to keep their chin straps buttoned at all times and both feet firmly planted on the floor during team meetings. His training camps were like eight weeks with the Marines and players dropped like flies. Coughlin was respected and hated all at once.

title: Study Warns Against Grand Transit Plans
description: With huge investments in new subway lines under consideration by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, an analysis released yesterday by New York City fiscal experts finds that such improvements may not be within the transit agency's financial reach because of looming budget deficits.

description: Brazil's economy showed fresh signs of recuperation today in a Government report indicating that the broadest measure of economic activity expanded for the second consecutive quarter.

title: CHINA ENDS WINE BAN
description: The Chinese Government ended its one-month ban on imports of French wine, a trade official at the French Embassy in Beijing said. The Government has accepted a French document certifying that wine from the Vaucluse, Drome, Ardeche and Gard regions contains no beef blood derivative products. French wine shipments have been blocked in Chinese ports since mid-July, after wine from southeast France was seized because of fears it was contaminated with beef blood and at risk of giving consumers mad cow disease. China imports an estimated two million gallons of wine a year from France.

title: Treasuries Rally on Moderate Rise in Consumer Prices
description: Bonds rallied sharply yesterday after a Labor Department report showed that consumer prices rose in July at the level that Wall Street had expected. Investors signaled their relief that prices had risen only moderately, making it likely that the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee would raise short-term interest rates only slightly when it meets next Tuesday.

title: A TBS Surprise
description: TBS Superstation's original movie ''First Daughter,'' a thriller starring Mariel Hemingway as a Secret Service agent who must rescue the President's daughter from terrorist kidnappers, delivered a pleasant ratings surprise to the Turner-owned network Sunday night. It attracted 5,309,000 households, the biggest movie audience ever for a basic cable network. Only the USA Network's mini-series ''Moby Dick'' surpassed it, reaching about 600,000 more homes on each of its two nights in March 1998. LAWRIE MIFFLIN

title: Zabriski to Be Missed As Met Open Tees Off
description: The 84th Met Open will be staged next week at the Tuxedo Club in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and while many of the area's top professionals and amateurs will be on hand, Bruce Zabriski, the two-time champion and the only club professional who survived the cut at last week's P.G.A. Championship, will not.

title: Washington Talk; Summer Wind on the Campaign Trail
description: This is the time of year when many Americans take vacations. After a summer of barbecue, balloons and a midsummer straw poll to forecast the result of a midwinter straw poll, Roger Salazar and Elizabeth Dole have done their fellow campaigners the service of showing that Presidential campaigns need vacations, too.

description: Oxford Health Plans has said that it and other health insurers in the New York area were subpoenaed again last month by the New York Attorney General's office.

description: A New Jersey man who fled overseas with a forged passport was sentenced yesterday to eight years and one month in prison on Federal charges that he bribed Defense Department officials to win contracts and tried to pass off everyday nuts and bolts for use in nuclear submarines and reactors.

title: MAJORITY OWNER OF SIMMONS TO ADD A BEDDING RETAILER
description: Fenway Partners Inc., an investment firm with a majority stake in the Simmons Company, the bedding maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the retailer Mattress Giant for an undisclosed price to strengthen its presence in the fast-consolidating United States retail bedding market. The closely held Mattress Giant, which is based in Dallas, has annual sales of about $170 million and 170 stores in 11 states. Fenway, based in New York, manages more than $1.4 billion in funds and focuses on food, industrial and service companies. Last year, it acquired a 71 percent stake in Simmons, one of the country's biggest mattress makers.

title: OFFICIAL ASSERTS SPY CASE SUSPECT WAS A BIAS VICTIM
description: The former head of counterintelligence at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico said yesterday that Wen Ho Lee, the American scientist who is the top suspect in the Chinese atomic spy case, was unfairly singled out for Federal investigation because of his ethnicity.

description: Following a battery of neurological tests, doctors said yesterday that Reyes Munoz had a pre-existing condition that led to his being knocked out by Arturo Gatti in the first round of a junior welterweight bout last Saturday night at Foxwoods Resort Casino in Mashantucket, Conn.

title: U.S. Appears Prepared to Indict 4 Gun Dealers in Chicago Sting
description: The sting operation that led last year to Chicago's $433 million lawsuit against the gun industry is expected to result as well in Federal indictments today against four firearms dealers in the city's suburbs.

title: CIBA'S PROFIT DROPS
description: The biggest maker of whiteners for detergents, Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G., which last year paid $2.3 billion for Allied Colloids P.L.C. to become a leader in water treatment, said its profit slumped as it struggled to integrate the British company. Ciba's first-half net income fell to 121 million Swiss francs ($80 million) from a restated 258 million francs a year earlier. Far from improving profitability at Ciba, the Allied Colloids purchase pushed expenses higher still.

The love and sweet memories he imparted will live on forever. Graveside services in Tamarac, Florida.

title: PHILIPPINE PHONE PROFITS FALL
description: A decline in revenue from international calls and losses in the cellular telephone business contributed to a 64 percent decline in first-half earnings at the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company, the country's dominant operator and one of its 10 largest companies. Analysts predicted the company's efforts to reduce delinquent subscribers would help strengthen its performance. Nonetheless, the news rattled investors, and the benchmark Philippine stock index fell to a four-month low.

description: Starting next month, Sports Illustrated, a Time Inc. magazine, will be moving just to the west of its present home on the Avenue of the Americas.

title: E*Trade Joins Push to Extend Trading Hours
description: The E*Trade Group, the big on-line brokerage firm, and Instinet, a stock trading network that serves institutional investors, said yesterday that they would team up to offer small investors the opportunity to trade stocks after the major exchanges close for the day.

title: PLANET HOLLYWOOD PLANS CHAPTER 11 FILING
description: Planet Hollywood International Inc., the theme restaurant chain associated with the actors Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone and Bruce Willis, said yesterday that it planned to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company, based in Orlando, Fla., said it was trying to get creditors to approve a plan that would bring in new capital of $30 million from a group that includes two of its largest shareholders, Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia and Ong Beng Seng, a Singapore hotelier. The group would own 70 percent of the reorganized company. The company, which runs Planet Hollywood and All-Star Cafe restaurants, had losses for four consecutive quarters. The shares, which sold for $18 when the company went public in April 1996, were unchanged at 75 cents yesterday before trading was halted.

title: A Crisis Without A Reform
description: At this time last year it seemed as if the global economy was hanging by a thread. Russia was defaulting on its debt, the first emerging market to do so since the Asian crisis had begun. The world's largest hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management, was hemorrhaging badly and would soon require a $3.5 billion bailout. And the Federal Reserve was preparing to lower interest rates to keep the world financial system from imploding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, SAMUEL WILLIAM
description: ROTHMAN-Samuel William. Beloved husband of Stella. Devoted father of Allen Joel Rothman and David Lawrence Rothman. Loving grandfather of Nancy, Larry, Paul, Laura and Will. Lt. Colonel U.S. Army Reserve (Retired), and served in Europe during World War II. Recipient of the Combat Infantryman's Badge, Meritorious Service Medal, Army Commendation Medal and Bronze Star, as well as many other commendations. He was past president of the 77th Division Reserve Officers Association, and past president of the Rockne Baewolfe Lodge of The Knights of Pythias. He was general manager of Manhattan East Apartment/Hotels, and worked for the company for over 35 years until his retirement. He will be greatly missed by all. Services tomorrow, August 19th at Gramery Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Avenue, New York.

title: Martin Wong Is Dead at 53; A Painter of Poetic Realism
description: Martin Wong, a painter whose meticulous visionary realism is among the lasting legacies of New York's East Village art scene of the 1980's and a precursor of the identity-driven work of the 90's, died last Thursday at his parents' home in San Francisco. He was 53 and had lived in San Francisco since 1994.

title: Corrections

description: LONG ago, when Larry Forgione decided to cook American, he looked for a place to do it, and when he found it, he called it An American Place. The name is as simple as Main Street, and like Main Street it has been around long enough that it seems almost timeless.

title: (Hallmark) Hall of Fame Moment
description: One by one this morning, the Giants emerged from their locker room, walking slowly toward the practice field. It was just minutes before 9 o'clock, early for a football player to be doing anything in haste. But as these Giants gazed across the grass they saw something that had been missing for five days, and it quickened their pace.

title: Pettitte Keeps Sparkling, but Royals Shine Brighter

But he could have envisioned that it was Manny Ramirez and Roberto Alomar or Ivan Rodriguez and Juan Gonzalez. That was what Pettitte could have imagined against the relatively anonymous Royals because those are the types of conquests he is chasing.

title: Food Lion to Acquire Hannaford Brothers
description: In a deal that continues the rapid consolidation of the grocery business, Food Lion Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Hannaford Brothers Inc. for $3.3 billion, forming the sixth-largest supermarket chain in the country.

title: Vacation Hot Spots Are Where People Can Cool
description: Everybody talks about the weather, but this summer lots of vacationers have been doing something about it -- namely, avoiding or minimizing the effects of a heat wave that has had much of the nation sweltering through one of the hottest summers in recent years.

title: Stravinsky's Neapolitan Twists
description: Just a few years after ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' Stravinsky shocked his audience again, not with hammer blows this time but with the silk slap of ''Pulcinella,'' a cheerful miscellany of songs and dances based on music from 18th-century Naples. The score was, he later said, his ''passport'' into the neo-classical territory he explored for the next three decades. It got him there, and it also demonstrated his alien status, for the way he treated his Neapolitan samples went boldly against the rules.

title: Euro RSCG Makes German Acquisition

Kremer Foerster has 28 employees working on accounts with estimated billings of $11.5 million from clients like Peugeot, PSA Finance and the German Caritas Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNES, MILDRED AKIN
description: LYNES-Mildred Akin. 89, died on August 18, in North Egremont, MA. Formerly of New York City. She was the devoted wife of the late Russell Lynes, beloved mother of George P. Lynes II, of New York, and Elizabeth L. Hollander of Providence, RI; cherished grand mother of Daniel and Rachel Hollander, and Joshua Rady Lynes; and great grand mother of Edith Needell Hollander. A graduate of Vassar College, B.A. in Art History, 1932, and New York University, Institute of Fine Arts, M.A., 1939, Mrs. Lynes was co-principal of the Shipley School (PA), 1937-42, and Lecturer, Director of Activities, and Membership Manager, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 195262. Funeral at two p.m., Saturday, August 21, at St. James Episcopal Church, Great Barrington, MA.

There is none of the juice here that distinguished the Kabuki performing of Tamasaburo, a member of the honorary Kabuki family of Bando, and made him a popular star in Japan.

title: Quiet Bank Swept Up In a Furor

And it is not a company typically found at the center of financial scandals. It is a conservative, well-regarded institution that earns steady profits from humdrum businesses like securities processing and trust management.

title: Art Bought During Boom Leaves Japan After Bust
description: With the stealth of a cat burglar, famous art is leaving Japan. Only a handful of bankers and art dealers know for sure where it is going, and they are not talking.

title: Tag Team (Ventura and Piazza) Sends Mets Home in First
description: It has become a sort of race within the race.

title: Stealing Bosnia's Future
description: International donors should be angered to learn that politicians from all three of Bosnia's main ethnic groups have stolen as much as $1 billion of the $5 billion in international aid given to the country since 1995. The unemployed and impoverished people of Bosnia should be furious. By diverting funds intended to rebuild homes and roads and to create jobs, the Serbian, Croatian and Muslim nationalist parties that pushed Bosnia into ethnic warfare are blighting its hopes for an economically viable peace.
