title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, GILBERT I., COL. RETIRED U.S. ARMY
description: ROSS-Gilbert I., Col. Retired U.S. Army. Died August 16, 1999 at age 97 at his home in Rye, NY. Col. Ross was born in New York City on March 24, 1902 to Gustave C. and Caroline Fleischman Ross. He grew up in New Haven, CT. In 1923 he graduated from Sheffield Scientific School of Yale University with a B.S. in Mechanical Engineering and an ROTC commission as Second Lieutenant in Army Ordnance. After graduation, he worked as a mechanical engineer for several years before opening his own consulting engineering firm. He lived in Belmont, MA, Cambridge, MA, and Norwalk, CT before moving to Rye, NY in 1938. Called to active duty in Army Ordnance in August of 1940, Col. Ross served during World War II as District Chief and Commanding Officer of the NY Ordnance District, and then as Deputy Chief and Commanding Office of the Tank and Automotive Center in Detroit attached to the Control Branch of the Chief of Ordnance at the Pentagon. He was awarded the Legion of Merit by the Army and the Conspicuous Service Medal by New York State for his wartime service. After WWII, Col. Ross returned to his commercial engineering career as officer and director of Ross and Co., Inc., and as proprietor of Ross and Co. Engineers & Consultants. He held license to practice as a Professional Engineer in various engineering disciplines in some 21 states. He was active in many professional organizations: Life Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, active in various divisions; Council Member and one-term president of the American Institute of Consulting Engineers; Fellow of Consulting Engineers Council. He planned industrial plants, distribution facilities and other works. He also held positions at various times as: President and Director of Manufacturing Industries, Inc.; Director of Maizewood Insulation Co.; Electroweave Manufacturing Co.; Fire Devices, Inc.; Haddam Manufacturing Co.; and special consultant to Vitro Corp. of America. He was honored in ''Who's Who in America'' and ''Who's Who in Engineering,'' received various engineering professional awards, and authored publications on professional practices, policies and techniques. Col. Ross was a former member of the Yale Club of New York City, and chaired his Yale class 60th reunion. He was a former member of the Rye Rotary Club and a member and former trustee of the Rye Presbyterian Church. Col. Ross is survived by his wife Loretta Kerwin Murtagh Ross of Rye, whom he married in 1975. He is also survived by three children and three step-children: Gilbert H. Ross of Burlington, VT, Robert F. Ross of Fayetteville, AR, Carol Ross Moran of Larchmont, NY, Robert Murtagh of Mahopac, NY, Cathy Murtagh Seumenicht of Mamaroneck, NY, and Barbara Murtagh LaMarte of Omaha, NE. Other survivors include: five grandchildren: Warren R. Ross of Fayetteville, AR, Lia Ross-Reyes of Bedford, NY, Audrey Ross-Sanders of Buffalo, NY, Dr. Pamela Ross-Carmichael of Poland, ME, Glenda Ross Washburn of Newport, VA; three step-grandchildren: Clifford W. Moran of Ridgefield, CT, Douglas G. Moran of Denver, CO, and Kathy S. Moran of Minneapolis, MN; five great-grandchildren, and eleven step great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his parents and brothers Jerome L. Ross and Milton J. Ross all of Hamden, CT; and his first wife Leslie Harrington Ross, to whom he was married from 1928 until her death in 1974. Funeral services are Thursday, August 19, 2PM at Rye Presbyterian Church, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, family suggests donations to Meals on Wheels or United Hospital Hospice.

Lewis, an insurance heir, said just as construction workers were revving up to add a $1 million indoor swimming pool to his 8,000-square-foot house in suburban Cleveland. Mr. Lewis, a director of the Progressive insurance company, founded by his father, had decided that the house was simply not distinguished enough for the swimming pool he had in mind: part Roman Baths of Caracalla, part Eastern European shvitz. Oh, and part art installation, too.

title: FOOTLIGHTS

title: Graduate Center Not Ready And Classes Start in a Week
description: As several thousand students at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York prepare to start classes next week, the center's spacious new quarters in the former B. Altman building on East 34th Street are not yet ready to receive them.

title: A Five-Year Effort in Queens Leads to a Custom-Built Club
description: A club that has been custom built for bridge purposes is a rare bird anywhere in the world, but New York City now has one. It is the Bridge Home of the Metropolitan Bridge Unit at Springfield Boulevard and 121st Avenue in Queens, a nonprofit registered charity, which opened on June 5 with much fanfare.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page yesterday misspelled the name of the advertising company that appointed Joseph Fisher president and chief executive and misidentified the officer he is succeeding. The company is Burson-Marsteller USA, not Burston-Marsteller. Mr. Fisher is succeeding Don Cogman, the chief operating officer, who had been performing the duties additionally -- not Graham Phillips, who was chairman at Burson-Marsteller before becoming chairman and chief executive earlier this month at a sister company, Young & Rubicam Advertising.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The yen surged against the dollar on expectations that international investors will continue to buy Japanese stocks. In New York, the dollar settled at 112.03 yen, down from 114.05 on Tuesday.

title: Iridium Proposes Bondholders Swap Debt for an Equity Stake
description: Iridium L.L.C., the global satellite telephone company, which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Friday, said today that it had proposed that a group of bondholders swap $1.45 billion of debt for a 33 percent stake.

title: Quick Destruction Follows Istanbul's Haste to Build
description: According to a neighbor who jumped out of bed when the floor beneath him began to shake and sway, the building across the street collapsed in 27 seconds flat.

title: Officer Is Said To Tell Jurors Police Beat Dead Suspect
description: According to a published report, an Orange police officer has told a Federal grand jury that fellow officers beat a 27-year-old man who died in custody after being picked up in connection with the shooting of another Orange police officer.

description: GEWIRTZ-George R. Gone five years today. Love you and miss you every day. Jeff

title: Fearing Deflation, Chinese Set Limits On New Factories
description: In a drastic move aimed at reversing a steady fall in prices, Chinese officials announced today that they would ban any new construction of factories that make a broad range of ordinary consumer items, from refrigerators and air-conditioners to candy, apple juice and liquor.

title: Small-Screen Help for Budding Filmmakers
description: COMPUTER programs to help screenwriters have been around for more than a decade, since writers began dropping the I.B.M. Selectric typewriter in favor of the Apple Macintosh. But in the last few years, they have come to include not only simple aides but also complex systems offering, like the hyperbolic movie industry itself, bloated promises that you'll soon be writing a blockbuster with ''passionate themes'' and ''unforgettable characters.''

title: McCumber's Nephew Gains
description: Josh McCumber stood on the 17th tee, knowing he had a chance to wrap up his first-round match in the United States Amateur Championship in Pebble Beach, Calif. He was swept by a nervousness that he had experienced only once before on a golf course.

title: Lipstick Politics in Iran
description: In Iran, nothing is what it seems to be. There are layers upon layers of meaning attached to every word, to every gesture, to every action.

title: Political Memo; Charter Panel, as Expected, Refocuses on Vacancy Law
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed a commission to study the possibility of revising the City Charter in June, he seemed to have one main goal: keeping Mark Green, the Public Advocate, from automatically succeeding him if he is elected to the Senate next year.

description: EUROPE

title: Daewoo's Creditors Form a Committee to Guide Negotiations
description: The Daewoo Group, the struggling South Korean conglomerate, met today with international creditors for the first time since its financial crisis erupted in mid-July and agreed to keep paying interest on $6 billion of foreign debt.

title: Peru's Drug Successes Erode as Traffickers Adapt
description: The days when drug dealers flew freely in and out of this little tropical town in the Apurimac Valley with thick wads of cash ended four years ago, right after President Alberto K. Fujimori ordered the armed forces to shoot down planes suspected of trafficking.

title: HYUNDAI IN TALKS ON INSURER
description: South Korea's largest conglomerate, Hyundai Group, is in exclusive talks with the Financial Supervisory Commission to acquire the Chosun Life Insurance Company, one of six troubled insurers that the Government is trying to sell. ''There's been a lot of progress in talks over the sale terms,'' said Lee Jong Koo, director general of the commission. Mr. Lee said the commission was proposing that Hyundai put up 100 billion won ($83.3 million) to buy Chosun Life, with the Government providing another 100 billion won.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, DR. DOROTHY INEZ
description: PARKER-Dr. Dorothy Inez. Died peacefully on July 30, 1999 at her home in White Plains, NY of congestive heart failure. Born in Traders Point, Indiana, January 23, 1910, she was the daughter of William C. and Clara Maines Parker. She is survived by a nephew Joe Carson Parker of Orlando, FL. Dr. Parker, who has a B.S. degree from Butler University and a Ph.D. in Botany from the University of Cincinnati, was an international authority on the development of agricultural libraries and information service networks. She retired in 1970 from the Rockefeller Foundation where she served as Associate Director for Agricultural Sciences. During her 25 years with the Foundation, she travelled widely and was instrumental in establishing agricultural libraries in Mexico and in other Latin American countiries as well as Africa and India. Burial will be in Traders Point, Indiana. A memorial service will be held in White Plains, New York in October.

title: Now Playing in the Catskills: 'Have I Got a House for You!'
description: MAYBE it's the tiny glossy photograph of the bowler hat and hatrack tacked to the wall of the foyer. Maybe it's the amber plastic beads substituting for a door to the funky aqua and white kitchen with the Italian molded chairs. Or maybe it's the young woman with shingled hair, a graphic designer/wire sculptor who wears her tank top and Dickies painter's pants with elan and who has turned the old plastics factory here in the Catskills into her personal retreat.

He is survived by his wife, Joan Einwohner; his daughter, Sara Giulietta Einwohner, of Cold Spring, N.Y.; his sister, Ruth Zavitkovsky, of the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, N.Y.; and his brother and sister-in-law, Henry and Helene Warner, of Annapolis, Md. The family will be at home from 2:30-6:00 PM Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

He will be deeply missed by his wife of 58 years, Annette Kreisler Grob, his children, Betsy and Steve Grob and Ellen Levy, son-in-law Mark Levy, grandchildren, Abigail and Eric Levy and Julia Grob and by his myriad friends and colleagues. title: CONTIFINANCIAL CUTS WORK FORCE AFTER BIG LOSS
description: The Contifinancial Corporation, an ailing financial services concern, said yesterday that it would cut about a third of its work force to refocus its mortgage origination operations. The company also posted a huge first-quarter loss and said it was continuing to negotiate with lenders about the pending expiration of its bank credit lines. The number of jobs being cut was not available, but the New York-based company, which provides home equity loans to high-risk borrowers, had 3,330 workers as of March 31. The company ran into trouble last year because of what it termed the ''flight to quality'' among investors. Contifinancial's stock fell 43.75 cents, to $1.50.

title: Martha Stewart Mantra: 'A New Month, a New Offering'
description: In July, Martha Stewart announced her company's plan to go public. This month, there's a new Kmart commercial showing her in bed in her pajamas, lounging (as if!). What's in store for September? The introduction of her first collection of home-decorating fabrics. The 18 patterns of softly hued florals, geometrics and solids come in cotton or cotton blends and in colors from off-white to green, blue, yellow and red. The fabrics, for upholstery and window treatments, will be $15 to $40 a yard. But don't look for them at Kmart or even in Martha by Mail. Instead, they will be available at Calico Corners (locations: 800-213-6366) and Jo-Ann Stores (locations: 330-656-2600). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: 5 Convictions in Hirschfeld Tax Fraud Case
description: After five days of deliberations, a Manhattan jury last night found a partnership controlled by the developer Abraham Hirschfeld guilty of filing false tax documents from 1989 to 1993.

title: Once Again, Suspicion Settles Into the Blocks
description: The world track and field championships will begin here in the heat on Saturday, and the thousands who will watch and perspire in person and the millions who will watch on television in cooler climes will soon have answers to these questions:

title: Bush, Irked at Being Asked, Brushes Off Drug Question
description: Fresh from his victory in the Republican Presidential straw poll in Iowa, Gov. George W. Bush today held what was supposed to be a routine news conference in Austin, Tex., to introduce his state education commissioner. He took a handful of questions on state issues until a reporter began to ask him about persistent questions that he had once used cocaine.

description: Harvey Houtkin fervently believes that securities regulators are out to get him. But he has no doubt that he will go down in history as a man who made Wall Street a better place for the small investor.

title: 30-Year Yield Slips Below 6% For First Time In a Month
description: Treasury bonds rose for a fourth day yesterday, driving yields below 6 percent for the first time in a month, on expectations that the Federal Reserve will not need to raise interest rates more than once to try to stem inflation.

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Controversy Is a Nonstarter
description: Two weeks ago, when her starting role had been taken away and her mind was filled with uncertainty, Sophia Witherspoon visited her close friend Pee Wee Kirkland, who is better known as a street basketball legend in New York City.

description: SOME historians believe you can't put a price on the past, but Henry F. Ludder knows better. He has just done the arithmetic, and the price turns out to be $100,000.

title: BRITISH RATES STEADY
description: Minutes from the Bank of England's monetary policy committee meeting on Aug. 5 show that the nine-person panel voted unanimously to leave interest rates at 5 percent. The committee was divided, though, about whether inflation would increase in coming months and whether rates should change. The group decided to take a wait-and-see approach as Britain's strong economic growth and low unemployment were offset by the pound's strength, keeping inflation below the target of 2.5 percent.

title: Judges Criticized Over Death-Penalty Conference
description: A conference for Federal and state judges on the death penalty, which begins on Thursday at a luxury golf resort near here, is drawing widespread criticism from defense lawyers for its emphasis on methods to speed up state executions.

title: LUCENT BUYING EXCEL SWITCHING FOR $1.7 BILLION
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the Excel Switching Corporation, a developer of programmable switches used in the communications industry, for $37 a share, a total of $1.7 billion. Lucent, the big networking company, will exchange 0.558 share for each share of Excel, which is based in Hyannis, Mass. Excel's shares jumped 26 percent, gaining $7.0625 each, to $34.625, while Lucent was down $2.3125 a share at $64.1875. Excel's switches are used for everything from prepaid calling cards to Internet gateways. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., has annual revenue of about $36 billion, while Excel's revenue is $149 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSLER, BENEDICT
description: TESSLER-Benedict. Died on August 11, 1999, in Palm Beach, Florida. He was born in Newark, NJ in 1908 and lived in Maplewood, NJ. His wife, Esther Lilien Tessler, survives him. They were married for 58 years. Additional survivors are his sons, Mark Tessler, of Maplewood; Alan Tessler, of Philadelphia; and a granddaughter and a grandson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERWICH, CARRIE (NEE GOLDFARB)
description: ERWICH-Carrie (nee Goldfarb). Wife of the late Oscar Kaiser. Died peacefully August 18. A brilliant, beautiful woman who inspired all who knew her. Adored by her children Ellyn and Dr. Burton Bronsther, and the late Dr. I. Howard and Ethel Kaiser, her eight grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. She taught us all about the beauty of life and the duty to share with others. Services at Boulevard-Riverside, Hewlett, L.I., Thursday 11:30 AM. May her soul be bound forever in the Book of Life.

title: MetroStars Manage to Put Two Goals on the Board in Another Pointless Performance
description: The most pathetic statistic for the MetroStars in this summer of deep discontent has nothing to do with their striking number of losses or the meager number of goals they have scored or even the large number of goals they have allowed. What hurts most is that the MetroStars have earned only 1 point out of a possible 45 in their past 15 games, the latest of which resulted in a 4-2 loss to the Columbus Crew tonight before a crowd of 7,246 at Giants Stadium.

title: WAL-MART FACES TAX AUDIT
description: The United States retail giant Wal-Mart Stores Inc., is facing a tax audit by the South Korean Government for refusing to accept credit cards at its Korean outlets. The Office of National Tax Administration said it would include Wal-Mart on its tax audit list because the retailer had received a large number of complaints from consumers about its refusal to accept credit cards. Wal-Mart accepts credit cards in the United States, and consumer organizations contend it is discriminating against Korean consumers.

title: Afloat, Like a Noodle in Soup
description: They are everywhere, those rods of extruded polypropylene called Pool Noodles. In fact, the inexpensive floats ($1.99 to $2.99 at supermarkets) are so popular that some pools have ''noodle-free hours.'' And they may be with us a long time (call it the half-life of Pool Noodles). Thomas H. Haines, a biochemistry professor at City University, said: ''Polypropylene is very resistant to any standard form of decomposition. It isn't a substance that microbes are interested in eating. Chemically, it is as tough as diamonds.'' Now, can someone explain the physics of it all, how one rod can keep even the largest adult afloat? MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Editorial Observer; The Coming Battle for Succession in Russia
description: The newly forged alliance between two of Russia's most cunning politicians, Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow and Yevgeny Primakov, the former Prime Minister, brings to mind the 1939 German-Soviet nonaggression pact that briefly linked the two nations at the beginning of the Second World War. The compact unveiled this week offers temporary tactical advantages to both men, but like the nonaggression pact that ended with the German invasion of the Soviet Union in 1941, it seems destined to be broken when either party decides it is no longer convenient.

title: Crowding Transistors Onto a Chip
description: INTEGRATED circuits 40 years ago had a handful of transistors wired together on a piece of silicon. Integrated circuits of 2005 will very likely have about 200 million transistors packed into each minuscule microprocessor.

title: New Owners of Saks Acknowledge Rough Spots
description: Saks Inc. said yesterday that it was not integrating the disparate parts of its swiftly acquired retail empire as smoothly as it had forecast at the beginning of the year.

title: CEL-SCI RECEIVES UNSOLICITED $124 MILLION BID
description: The Cel-Sci Corporation, a drug and vaccine maker in Vienna, Va., said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited cash offer of $124 million from a person in Argentina, causing shares to rise $1.0625 each, to $3, before trading was halted. Cel-Sci said in a statement that it had been unsuccessful in trying to reach the person who made the offer and that it was unable to determine whether the offer was legitimate. In a letter, Daniel Martino of Buenos Aires said Cel-Sci Acquisition Group would pay $7.75 a share for Cel-Sci, nearly four times the shares' closing price on Tuesday of $1.9375. Cel-Sci's drug Multikine is being tested for effectiveness in treating cancer patients.

title: Keeping Up With All the News Back in Anytown, U.S.A.
description: WHEN Thomas G. Nelson was teaching English in Malaysia last year, he was able to keep up with old friends and family in his hometown in Kansas every week by using his computer to read The Marion County Record, the local weekly newspaper, on line.

title: In Bali, the Gong (and Cymbal) Show
description: Bronze and brass percussion instruments from Bali have intrigued Westerners since Colin McPhee began to record gamelan groups in the 1920's, and the music is still very much alive. There are gongs, gong-chimes (left), cymbals and metallophones -- fat xylophone-type slabs suspended over resonators. At Sidha Karya, a factory in Blahbatuh known to musicians throughout the island, Ketut Suartini (right) helps English-speaking shoppers. A 10-inch gong, weighing four pounds, is $60. The largest gongs, like those at right, about 55 pounds, are $265. Add another $250 for a shipment, which can hold up to three large gongs. Sidha Karya takes Mastercard. Telephone (it's a 12-hour time difference): 011-62-361-942798. WILLIAM S. NIEDERKORN

title: CISCO SYSTEMS TO PAY $143 MILLION FOR MAXCOMM
description: Cisco Systems Inc., the world's No. 1 maker of Internet equipment, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Maxcomm Technologies Inc., in Chelmsford, Mass., for $143 million in stock, to expand its ability to provide high-speed Internet access to homes. Separately, Cisco, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said it had paid $49 million for a 4 percent stake in another closely held company, Akamai Technologies Inc., as part of an agreement to develop technology to increase the speed and reliability of Internet sites. Akamai, based in Cambridge, Mass., helps Web-site operators run faster and at higher capacity.

title: Political Briefing; Stars in Alabama? Not the G.O.P. Kind
description: The way Republican leaders in Alabama figured it, if they scheduled their own Presidential straw poll two weeks after the one held last weekend in Iowa, and then advertised it as the first and only early test of Southern sentiment, they could grab a lot of attention for Alabama and the Alabama Republican Party. But it looks as if that's not going to happen.

title: More Stock Sales At Waste Hauler
description: Executives of Waste Management Inc. sold $19.5 million in company shares in June in the second round of stock sales by insiders in the two months before the company, the largest United States trash hauler, issued a July 6 profit warning.

Because under this gargantuan roof were gathered 45,000 scientists, artists, engineers and designers whose careers are dedicated to computer graphics -- virtual reality, 3-D modeling and computer animation.

title: In California, a Skiing and Surfing Safari Under One Roof
description: In California, you can surf in the morning and ski in the afternoon. Soon, in Orange County, you will be able to do both, without making a two-hour drive to the mountains. The Gotcha Glacier, an indoor park for sports ranging from snowboarding to surfing (preliminary architectural drawings above), is to open in 2001 in a 435,000-square-foot structure in Anaheim being designed by F & A Architects. It will offer not only the country's first indoor artificial ski slope (550 feet long), the company says, but also an ice-skating rink, snowboarding and skateboarding parks, a rock-climbing wall and six pools with artificial surfing waves, all under one roof. It is the brainchild of an Orange County contractor, Brad Kinney, and partly financed by the Gotcha sports clothing company. Ground is to be broken in the fall, about a mile from Disneyland, by the home of the Mighty Ducks hockey team and Edison International Field. It is part of Sportstown, a complex to include shops and restaurants. Like Chelsea Piers in Manhattan, it will fuse retail and sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAVIOTO, HUMBERTO, M., MD.
description: CRAVIOTO-Humberto, M., MD. The Faculty and Staff of NYU School of Medicine and The NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of Humberto M. Cravioto, MD, Professor of Pathology, at age 75. Dr. Cravioto joined NYU in 1957 and served its community for 42 years. Dr. Cravioto was an accomplished neuropathologist best known for his work on the electromicroscopy of brain tumors. He was also a dedicated teacher and a gentle compassionate man who was well appreciated by his colleagues and friends. Dr. Cravioto is survived by his wife, Barbara and their three children, Stefanie, Jorge and David. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. Robert M. Glickman, MD Dean, NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff President, NYU Hospitals Center Vittorio Defendi, MD May Ellen and Gerald Jay Ritter Professor of Oncology and Chairman, Department of Pathology, NYU School of Medicine

description: Imagine taking a Nantucket fishing expedition without leaving home. Or how about hustling colleagues in a game of snooker between meetings? Starting this winter, armchair athletes will be able to ditch their traditional joysticks and keyboards for a new line of inexpensive sports simulation accessories called Real Feel from Miacomet.

title: MATTEL TO PRODUCE ENCYCLOPEDIA IN DISK FORMAT
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it had entered a $30 million agreement to make and distribute the Encyclopaedia Britannica on compact disk and digital video disk through 2001. Mattel and Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc., of Chicago, said they would develop three versions of the reference material to go on sale this fall. Each version will have the full text of the encyclopedia's 32 volumes, with added articles exclusively for the software. Mattel, the Novato, Calif., toymaker, said the software versions of the encyclopedia will be distributed through its Broderbund subsidiary. The companies will sell the titles in stores and to schools and computer manufacturers.

title: Starr to Quit Clinton Inquiry Soon; Panel Splits on Termination
description: Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, is quitting as early as October to resume his legal practice after a five-year investigation into President Clinton's personal and business affairs that led to the impeachment battle in Congress, Mr. Starr's associates said today.

title: PRISON TERM IN COPPER SCANDAL
description: Juan Pablo Davila, the former chief trader at the Chilean miner Codelco, was sentenced to eight years in prison for fraud in a trading scandal that cost the company, which is the world's largest copper producer, $218 million. Mr. Davila was also fined more than $200 million for charges that included falsifying documents and breach of fiduciary duties to Codelco. The charges were tied to millions of dollars in kickbacks from brokers who handled Mr. Davila's bets on the copper market as he racked up losses in 1993 and 1994. Mr. Davila is already in prison, close to completing a three-year sentence for a 1996 conviction of tax evasion in connection with the losses.

title: Where Old Sofas Go To Rest and Retool
description: THERE comes a time in every sofa's life when it has to get shaped up or shipped out. While upholstery may seem like a quick fix, it isn't always quick, and it's nowhere as simple as it seems.

description: In the largest drug bust by local law enforcement officers in New York City history, the police have seized 1,566 pounds -- or more than three-quarters of a ton -- of cocaine at a warehouse in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, officials said yesterday.

description: The Manhattan Borough President, C. Virginia Fields, was having lunch in a restaurant on the Upper West Side yesterday when her wallet was stolen from her handbag, her press secretary said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, JULIUS P.
description: MORSE-Julius P., 93, at his Brooklyn home, August 7, 1999. A lover of words, music, science, mathematics, and astronomy, he was a professional photographer and offset lithographer. He became an enthusiastic folk dancer, and an active member of the Senior Citizens League of Flatbush. He once appeared on stage with the Pina Bausch Dance Company, and was officially honored in 1997 as an Extraordinary Elder. He is mourned by his loving wife Anne, children Robert and Linda Heller, and two surviving brothers, Henry and Irving. His kindness, wit and good humor will be missed by family, friends, and all who had the good fortune to know him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BADIN, ALEXANDER
description: BADIN-Alexander. A physician and writer. On August 17, 1999 after a long and valiant battle with cancer, in Manhattan. Survived by his wife, Floria Constant Badin and his daughter Roxana Badin. Private funeral was conducted on August 20, 1999. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: LUTHERAN GROUP APPROVES A LINK TO EPISCOPALIANS
description: The nation's largest Lutheran denomination voted today to enter an agreement for full communion with the Episcopal Church, under which the two churches, which together represent nearly eight million American Protestants, would fully recognize each other's members and sacraments, exchange clergy when needed and join in missionary and social service projects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMANUEL, JOSEPH
description: EMANUEL-Joseph. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a cherished longtime friend and respected member of the community, whose deep commitment to Jewish education perpetuated the legacy of his distinguished family at YU and our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. The Benzion, Clara, Jacob, Sarah, and Joseph Emanuel Fund, established with the Yeshiva Endowment Foundation, Inc., provides scholarships for our undergraduate and graduate students. He was a kind, gentle, humble, and erudite man of great integrity, who will be remembered with reverence by all who knew him. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, ELINOR F.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKSTEIN, ROSALIND
description: DICKSTEIN-Rosalind. Died suddenly August 18, 1999. She was the beloved wife of the late Abe Dickstein and devoted mother of Steven and daughter-in-law Janet. A most loving and caring grandmother of Nate. She will be deeply missed by her twin sister, MarionReimer, her brother Irving Greenberg and wife Rita, and many nieces and nephews. title: A Schizophrenic's New Awakening
description: Getting into the mind of someone afflicted with schizophrenia is no easy assignment, but tonight's ''Dateline'' gives it a dutiful try. The mind is that of the 26-year-old Luca Moylan, who at the age of 14 lost a seemingly happy childhood to an existence of terrifying voices and hallucinations. At 17, he was diagnosed as suffering from schizophrenia.

title: Share Prices Move Lower On News of Trade Deficit
description: A report that the nation's trade deficit had unexpectedly worsened sent stocks into a skid yesterday and, despite a partial recovery, prices closed lower for the second consecutive session.

title: Mexican Contender Acknowledges an Out-of-Wedlock Child
description: Mexican voters, who will choose a President next year in the most democratic elections ever held in this country, are getting a chance early in the campaign to decide how much they care about candidates' personal transgressions.

title: Tranquil, Reflective Landscapes From a Quietist
description: In the history of art, the landscapist Dwight William Tryon (1849-1925) is hardly a star name. Not to be confused with the stagey French Barbizon painter Constant Troyon (1810-65), Tryon was one of the quietest artists of his era. In fact, the branch of American Impressionism to which he belonged is sometimes spoken of as Quietism, when it isn't referred to as Tonalism or Intimism.

title: Frederic Hsieh Is Dead at 54; Made Asian-American Suburb
description: Frederic Hsieh, the entrepreneur who used enticements of a ''Chinese Beverly Hills'' to turn a Los Angeles suburb into the first American city with an Asian majority , died on Aug. 8 while on vacation in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 54 and lived mostly in Hong Kong.

title: Carat Global Wins Schwarzkopf Work

title: Alcoa and Reynolds Reach Merger Agreement
description: Alcoa Inc., the world's oldest and largest aluminum company, announced yesterday that it had reached a definitive merger agreement with the No. 3 producer, the Reynolds Metals Company, in a relatively swift negotiation that left some Reynolds shareholders grumbling.

title: This Cartoon Didn't Come From Disney
description: Mima is a wide-eyed, chirpy-voiced young woman with ambition. It isn't enough that she's one-third of a fabulously successful Japanese Spice Girls-like pop music group, Cham, whose members bounce around the concert stage in pink dresses with huge bows in the back and long white gloves. Mima is leaving Cham to begin an acting career, and her story is ''Perfect Blue,'' a peculiar example of Japanese animation -- realistic drawing, childish voice, flashes of narrative skill.

title: How Did Earl Faison Die?
description: The killing of police officer Joyce Carnegie in Orange, N.J., four months ago was a tragedy for her family, the Police Department and a community that loved her well. But the investigation of that murder by Essex County Prosecutor Patricia A. Hurt was marked by a series of blunders, including the questionable death of a suspect in police custody. New Jersey's Attorney General and other authorities are looking into Ms. Hurt's handling of the case and the behavior of the police. They need to bring their inquiries to a speedy conclusion.

title: Study Bolsters Case for Pig-Donor Tests
description: For some time, scientists exploring the use of pigs as organ donors have faced intense criticism over fears that cross-species transplants could unleash a dangerous animal virus in humans. Now British researchers say they have encouraging evidence that pigs' organs are safe enough to begin testing in people.

title: Mr. Bush's Drug Dodges
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has run into a distracting and potentially dangerous patch in his Presidential campaign. The issue is whether he ever used cocaine or other illegal substances during his youth. Mr. Bush has been dancing around the question for several days, creating the impression that he probably did experiment with cocaine and that he believes evasion rather than an honest answer is the best response.

title: Going Upstate, Giuliani Backs Dairy Supports
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani flew into this Southern Tier town today and announced that he had changed his mind and now supported Federal legislation designed to prop up prices for New York's dairy farmers. Mr. Giuliani said he no longer feared that the legislation would lead to higher milk costs for downstate consumers.

title: Dollar's Drop Against Yen Renews Focus On U.S. Policy
description: An apparent shift in Japanese policy and the report of a record United States trade deficit helped send the dollar lower yesterday against the Japanese yen and the new European currency, the euro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTZ, REBECCA
description: MARTZ-Rebecca. Died August 18, 1999. Beloved wife of Lawrence. Devoted mother of her children Peter Martz, the late Wendy Goldhirsh and son-in-law Bernard Goldhirsh, Dr. Brian Martz and daughter-in-law Loren Martz. Adored grandmother of Lila, Brandon, Jesse, Benjamin, and Elizabeth. Cherished sister of Shirley Siroka, the late Benjamin Kaplan, and the late Gertrude Roseman. title: Korean Famine Toll: More Than 2 Million
description: North Korea appears to be emerging from a prolonged severe famine with the help of international food aid, but four terrible years of hunger from 1995 through 1998 may have cost the country two million to three million lives, according to accumulating evidence gathered by a range of experts. Many of the dead were old people and children, or urban dwellers of any age with no way to forage off the land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUREWITZ, HERBERT
description: GUREWITZ-Herbert. Of Suffern, NY. A retired member of the English Department of Spring Valley High School, died August 17 after a brief illness. He was 86 years old and lived for more than 25 years in Rockland County. Upon his retirement, Mr. Gurewitz, a lifelong activist, continued his involvement in social and political causes. He was a docent at the Rockland Center for Holocaust Studies in Spring Valley. Survived by his daughters, Riva Rosenfield, a social worker of Brooklyn, Lenore Conroy of San Francisco; grandsons Peter and Jonathan Rosenfield and Gregory Fleischer; granddaughters Emily and Susannah Conroy; great - granddaughters Hannah and Jessica; and a brother Raymond Gardner. His wife Gertrude Convel Gurewitz, a social worker, died in 1988. Contributions to The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, and the Urban School of San Francisco, 1563 Paige Street, San Francisco, CA 94117.

title: WELSH, CARSON IS BUYING $150 MILLION OF QUORUM DEBT
description: Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, a New York-based investment firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy $150 million in debt from Quorum Health Group Inc., an investment that could more than double its stake in Quorum. Quorum, based in Brentwood, Tenn., is the largest United States manager of not-for-profit hospitals. It said the transaction would lower earnings. The investment would convert into 13.3 million Quorum common shares at the conversion price of $11.25 a share. The conversion would make Welsh, Carson the largest Quorum shareholder, raising its stake to 24 percent from 10 percent. Quorum shares rose 43.75 cents, to $8.4375.

title: NEXTEL OFFERS $2.1 BILLION FOR RADIO SPECTRUM
description: Nextel Communications Inc., a nationwide wireless-telephone company, is willing to pay at least $2.1 billion for radio spectrum owned by Nextwave Telecom Inc. if it can reach agreements with Nextwave's creditors. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday, Nextel said it would pay $1.59 billion in cash to resolve claims by Nextwave's largest creditor, the Federal Communications Commission, on the licenses. Nextel offered to pay $400 million to $500 million to additional creditors. Nextwave, based in Hawthorne, N.Y., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in June 1998. The spectrum would give Nextel, which is controlled in part by Craig McCaw, the cellular pioneer, more capacity to handle rapid customer growth.

title: In a Showdown at the Apollo, Rangel Is Fighting to the End
description: In a move that stunned state officials, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel made a last-ditch effort yesterday to retain control of the Apollo Theater, turning his back on a plan that would have allowed Time Warner to take over the board of the Harlem landmark.

title: Breaking Fashion News With a Provocative Edge
description: When John Fairchild was sent to Paris in 1955 to run the European offices of his family's newspaper company, which included Women's Wear Daily, he found that his reporters were seated in the last row at the twice-a-year couture shows. Why not front and center? To the titans of French chic, Women's Wear Daily was little more than a trade rag devoted to ladies suits and corsets.

title: TXU INCREASES PLANNED STOCK BUYBACK TO $800 MILLION
description: The TXU Corporation said yesterday that it had increased the amount of stock it planned to buy back from investors to $800 million from $600 million. TXU, previously known as the Texas Utilities Company, has 282.3 million shares outstanding. Based on TXU's current $40.25 stock price, $800 million would buy about 19.9 million shares, or 7 percent of the company's outstanding stock. TXU, a Dallas-based utility, said it had bought back about 12 million common shares since October 1995. In May, TXU's board increased the company's repurchase program to $600 million from $350 million.

title: UNITED DOMINION IS ACQUIRING BRAN & LUEBBE OF GERMANY
description: United Dominion Industries Ltd., a maker of industrial equipment based in Charlotte, N.C., agreed yesterday to buy Bran & Luebbe, a German metering-device company, for an undisclosed price, and said it was in talks to acquire more companies in Europe. Bran & Luebbe, a closely held company based in Hamburg, Germany, had about $130 million in sales last year. It makes precision metering pumps and analyzing equipment, and has 850 employees in 11 countries, including the United States. The purchase would immediately add to earnings for United Dominion, which has annual sales of more than $2 billion and 12,500 workers in 20 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALKER, HARRY
description: KALKER-Harry. 97, of Boca Raton, Florida and South Street, Williamstown, Massachusetts, passed away at home, Wednesday, August 18, 1999, after a period of failing health. Born in Malden, MA on June 15, 1902, he was the son of Abraham and Ida (Katz) Kalker. He attended schools in Malden, graduating from Malden High School, class of 1919, and in 1923 from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, with a Bachelor's of Science in Civil Engineering. Mr. Kalker was Founder and President of the Sprague Products Company in North Adams, MA where he worked from 1933, until his retirement in 1968. He was also notable for his philanthropic contributions to many charities; most important to him among those contributions was his support of the development of the Foreign Service Training Institutes of MIT. In 1959, he and his brother Will formed the Great Eastern Life Insurance Company of Providence, RI, which merged with and became the 1st Colony Life of Virginia, where he continued as a member of the Board of Directors. He served as Treasurer of the Buxton School in Williamstown from the 1940's to 1961; was instrumental in forming the Pine Cobble School in Williamstown, where he also served on the Board of Trustees as Treasurer for many years; was active in the Williamstown Summer Theater; as well as numerous regional and community programs. He and his wife Leona donated monies for the Jewish Student Center at Williams College where the Leona and Harry Kalker Family Sanctuary was established. He was married to Leona Ruttenberg from 1930-1945, then married Clarice Fortgang Pollard from 1948-1957. He then remarried Leona Ruttenberg in 1957. He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Leona Kalker, of Williamstown; a son, Philip E. Kalker of Williamstown, Mrs. Samuel (Darce) Davis of Rye, NY and Ms. Avie C. Kalker of Williamstown; 6 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. A memorial service for Harry Kalker will be held on Friday, August 20th at 3:00 pm at the Leona and Harry Kalker Sanctuary at the Jewish Student Center at Williams College, Williamstown. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that contributions in Mr. Kalker's memory may be made to the Pine Cobble School, Williamstown, through the Geo. M. Hopkins Funeral Home, 61-67 Spring Street, Williamstown, MA 01267.

description: RISING incongruously from a farm field here along U.S. Highway 169 is the young red-brick headquarters of America's newest motorcycle manufacturer, which is also one of America's oldest motorcycle manufacturers.

title: INFLATION ANXIETY IN BRAZIL
description: A widely followed barometer of Brazilian inflation jumped unexpectedly and contributed to a fall in the value of the currency, the real, to the weakest level in nearly six months. The 30-day inflation rate in Brazil's financial capital, Sao Paulo, jumped to 1.13 percent, or an annualized rate of 14 percent. The increase raised concern that an economic recovery could stall.

title: Hanoch Levin, 56, Leading Israeli Playwright
description: Hanoch Levin, Israel's leading playwright, who spent more than three decades trying to strip the nation of self-congratulatory armor and force it to examine what he considered its hypocrisy and self-delusion, died on Wednesday of bone cancer. He was 56.

title: Toms River Turns Lone Hit Into Magic
description: Hard throwers do not scare Eric Campesi. They excite him. So as Campesi, the Toms River East Little League team's center fielder, watched Sam Cole warm up tonight by throwing fastballs that would make most 12-year-olds wince, he told himself he would be the game's star.

title: Why Dagestan Needs the Russians
description: Telling countries that they should never have gone into the business of empire is easy. Telling them how to get out of it without leaving an awful mess behind is much harder. This was true of the British in India and the French in Algeria -- and it's true of the Russians in the northern Caucasus.

title: NTL SAYS IT IS BUYING WORKPLACE TECHNOLOGIES OF BRITAIN
description: NTL Inc., a New York company that owns Britain's biggest cable company in number of subscribers, said yesterday that it would buy Workplace Technologies P.L.C. for $:81 million ($130 million) to enhance its range of phone and Internet services for business customers. NTL, whose shareholders include France Telecom and the Microsoft Corporation, will also assume $:20 million of the debt of Workplace, which designs data, voice and video networks. NTL is beefing up its portfolio of services to compete with British Telecommunications P.L.C. in phone and high-speed Internet markets.

title: On the Phantom
description: The No. 11 bus, known as the phantom to some of its patient riders, makes a loop through Manhattan's West Side from Abingdon Square in Greenwich Village to 145th Street in Washington Heights. A seasoned New Yorker takes the bus along its entire route, savoring the living theater and vivid characters.

description: Long John Silver's Restaurants Inc., the largest United States quick-service seafood chain, has received approval from a Federal bankruptcy judge for its plan of reorganization, which involves selling itself to A & W Restaurants Inc., the company said today.

title: STATEN ISLAND BANCORP IS BUYING FIRST STATE BANCORP
description: Staten Island Bancorp Inc., a New York bank with $1.4 billion in assets, agreed late on Wednesday to buy First State Bancorp for $84 million in cash as it seeks to build its business in New Jersey. Staten Island Bancorp said it would introduce automatic teller machines, debit cards, on-line banking and enhanced residential and mortgage services to First State clients. First State, based in Monmouth County, N.J., runs six branches and is opening two more. It has assets of $358.6 million and deposits of $315.6 million.

description: To the Editor:

description: RELIANCE STEEL AND ALUMINUM CO., Los Angeles, a metals processor and distributor, said it would buy the closely held Allegheny Steel Distributors Inc., Indianola, Pa., for an undisclosed price.

title: Safety of Florida's Storm Shelters Is Questioned
description: The very name shelter -- promises safety.

title: After Climb To Stardom, A Tumble, Then Death
description: Seen today, Otto Preminger's film ''Carmen Jones'' engulfs viewers in the quaint aura of the 1950's, with Bizet's music plopped down in a modern Army barracks, where characters burst into song on a Cinema scope screen. Even now, however, its entirely black cast (including a young Harry Belafonte) remains a rarity. And one other element has not aged. When Dorothy Dandridge sashays into view as the femme fatale Carmen, swinging her hips in a tight red skirt and gesturing with a single red rose, she is unmistakably a movie star. Like most stars, she conveys an enigmatic quality: Dandridge's delicate beauty and natural elegance add a hint of mystery to the languorous sexuality of her performance.

title: Linking Drop in Crime to Rise in Abortion
description: No one is certain why crime rates have plummeted in the United States over the last decade. But that fact has not prevented politicians from gleefully taking credit for the downturn, or academics from ruminating endlessly on its causes.

description: Imports surged in June, driving the nation's trade deficit to another record, as Americans, feeling flush in the strong economy, continued to splurge.

description: Every few months, small groups of local Democratic officials journey to special seminars to learn how to combat a party vulnerability: doubts among voters that the Democrats embrace mainstream family values.

description: More than 200 people in Minnesota and North Dakota have become sick -- and four children have died -- over the past two years after becoming infected with a drug-resistant germ that until recently had been confined to hospitals and nursing homes, Federal health officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREITAG, PEGGY R.
description: FREITAG-Peggy R., 96 passed away August 18, 1999 in Miami Beach of natural causes. Beloved mother of Buddy and Barbara Freitag, Selma and Robert Clein. Devoted grandmother of Larry and Debbie Freitag, Eve Freitag, Harry and Claudia Falk, Elizabeth and Peter Dranoff, Howard Clein, Ellen and Jim Holmes.
