title: Liberty Rewards Its Fans
description: The Liberty knew better than to take the Rockers lightly last night. A year ago, Cleveland spoiled the Liberty's chances of finishing first in the Eastern Conference. Last night, the Rockers came to Madison Square Garden with a 6-24 record, the worst in the league, but the Liberty refused to engage in presumptive thinking and focused on the opponent at hand.

title: Bats Are Quiet, But Fans Aren't As Yanks Lose
description: The foreign sound of the Yankees being booed at Yankee Stadium erupted in several sections yesterday once Jason Grimsley stumbled to a 3-0 count on Jermaine Dye in the 11th inning. The score was tied and bases were loaded in part because Derek Jeter had just committed another untimely error. It was an inopportune time for Grimsley to suddenly be searching for strikes.

title: BIG UTILITY DEAL
description: Europe's biggest private power producer, Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A., offered 7.5 billion euros ($8 billion) in stock and cash for the 49 percent it does not already own in Tractebel S.A., Belgium's biggest utility. Suez offered one share plus 16 euros in cash for each Tractebel share, according to a filing with the Belgian market regulator.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS TO CUT JOBS
description: Europe's largest airline, British Airways P.L.C., announced it would eliminate 1,000 jobs as it tries to cut costs by $:225 million ($361 million) in a move to increase profits after its worst quarter in seven years. The carrier, which employs 55,000 people around the world, said that it would eliminate 10 percent of its 3,000 management positions and that other cuts would come from back-office jobs.

title: Jones Wants Four Gold Medals, And She's Not Afraid to Say It
description: Marion Jones has been asked to address the same topics for months, and today, as she sat next to Michael Johnson and Maurice Greene on a makeshift stage with a microphone in her hand and a lazy stretch of the Guadalquivir River in the background, she was asked again by a much larger audience than usual.

title: Dream House Dreamscape
description: I had been enumerating the glories of the Inn at Shelburne Farms, a country estate in Vermont on the banks of Lake Champlain, practically since the day my friend Nate and I had met, and now, on a summer evening three years later, we were finally driving through the Green Mountains, an hour or so from arriving.

title: FINNISH PHONE COMPANY BUYS 9.1% STAKE IN POWERTEL
description: Sonera, Finland's top telephone company, said yesterday that it had bought 9.1 percent of Powertel Inc., the United States cellular phone operator, for $123 million. It acquired the stake from Ericsson A.B. of Sweden, the cellular phone maker. Sonera already holds 19.4 percent of the Aerial Operating Company, which like Powertel is one of the top four United States operators focusing on the global system for mobile telecommunications. Sonera plans to help Powertel, with 382,000 subscribers, introduce new services.

title: New Roots for Black Culture
description: IN villages across Africa, storytelling has long been an integral part of daily life. At nights, even to this day, people gather in circles in courtyards illuminated by a full moon and bright stars to hear gripping tales from wise men and indelible stories from adventurous young men who have returned to their hamlets from faraway places.

title: After a Breakup, Sehorn Comes Back Alone
description: When the Giants' training camp practices would end last season, Jason Sehorn, who appeared on the threshold of a breakthrough season, would usually leave the field hand-in-hand with his wife of six months, Whitney.

title: MOTOROLA AGREES TO BUY METROWERKS FOR $95 MILLION
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Metrowerks Inc., a maker of software programming tools based in Austin, Tex., for $95 million. The deal values Metrowerks at $6.25 a share. The shares gained 19 percent, rising 96.875 cents, to $6.03125, in Nasdaq trading, Motorola, the electronics and telecommunications company based in Schaumberg, Ill., said it planned to operate Metrowerks as a stand-alone unit and retain its current name and management.

title: People of Taiwan Are Right to Want Statehood
description: To the Editor:

title: Passion Before Popcorn: Wicked Men, Wanton Women
description: In these times of turpitude, it's helpful to realize that Hollywood's love affair with the forbidden is nothing new. Before the 1934 Production Code specified, among other things, that ''in general, passion should be so treated that these scenes do not stimulate the baser element,'' movies were rife with the naughty interludes that have since developed a special cachet. The Film Forum 2 now unleashes a 44-film glimpse at these early trespasses in its series ''The Joy of Pre-Code: Sex, Booze and Red Hot Jazz, 1930-1933,'' which opens today. It's billed as a ''festival of racy movies,'' and it lives up to that quaint description.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSON, HUGH, SIR.
description: CASSON-Hugh, Sir. The K. S. Giniger Company and its personnel, publishers of Sir Hugh's books on London, Oxford and Cambridge, mourn the passing of this distinguished author and illustrator and extends their deepest sympathy to Lady Casson and her daughters.

title: Self Possessed Skipping Trot
description: Self Possessed, who set a world record in winning the Hambletonian on Aug. 7, is bypassing the Yonkers Trot in Yonkers, N.Y., the second leg of the trotting Triple Crown.

title: On the Road: Outlaws and In-Jokes
description: Late in Thomas Jahn's exuberant road movie ''Knockin' on Heaven's Door,'' a pair of terminally ill young men, who have fled their hospital beds to embark on a jubilant crime spree across Germany, pause long enough from their rampage to sit down and make personal wish lists. Topping the list of Martin Brest (Til Schweiger), a sleepy-eyed hunk with an inoperable brain tumor that produces horrific seizures, is to purchase a Cadillac of the same model that Elvis Presley bought for his mother. The dream of the more timid Rudi Wurlitzer (Jan Josef Liefers), who has untreatable bone cancer, is to have sex with two beautiful women at the same time.

title: The Case of Wen Ho Lee
description: Troubling accusations have been made, and denied, in recent days that Wen Ho Lee, a Taiwan-born American citizen who is suspected of leaking nuclear secrets to China, was singled out for investigation and punishment because of his Chinese ethnicity. If those claims are true, it would be a repellent act of discrimination by Federal Government agencies. But based on the information now publicly available, it is not possible to reach a definitive conclusion about whether or not Mr. Lee was unfairly treated.

title: This Refined Briton, To Wed a Mafia Doll, Goes to a Trattoria . . .
description: Try as he might, Michael Felgate (Hugh Grant), a cultivated, mild-mannered Englishman engaged to the daughter of a genial Mafia chieftain, can't seem to deliver the phrase ''forget about it'' with the sinister heft that his future in-laws can. Michael's inability to give ''fuhgeddaboutit'' and other spicier phrases a suitably streetwise punch is one of the cute running of jokes of ''Mickey Blue Eyes,'' a lightweight comedy that has more than enough laughs to justify its silly, scatterbrained premise.

title: Venus Williams Plans to Dress for Success
description: Two years ago, Venus Williams made a smash debut at the United States Open, where she was the first unseeded finalist in four decades. But last year, when she designed a different dress for each of her seven possible matches, Williams fell a round short and never unveiled the red, white and blue costume she aimed to wear in the final.

title: Killer's House Is Searched for Clues in Other Slayings
description: A team of investigators using crowbars, handsaws and pickaxes tore through a house in this Union County city today, searching for evidence that might link its owner, already in jail for killing a teen-age girl in 1969, to the slayings of at least three more teen-age girls and a Rahway police officer.

title: Theater Found On the Fringes
description: Little Bo Peep wanders into Wonderland. This time there's no Alice, and the Red Queen wants to have her own tea party.

title: Shootout Injures Four
description: Four people were wounded yesterday afternoon during a shootout in the Bronx that sent terrified pedestrians running for safety, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LILLIAN LINDER
description: SCHWARTZ-Lillian Linder, 68, of Lenox, Ma. and Sarasota, Fl. Died on Tuesday, August 17, 1999. She worked as a teacher and guidance counselor in the N.Y. City School System. She was a fighter for peace, social justice and a better world. She leaves her husband, Sol Schwartz; a son, David Schwartz; a daughter, Risa Schwartz; and a grandson, John. Friends wishing to, may make donations to the Lenox Library Association for the Lillian Linder Schwartz Fund to provide large type and talking books for the visually impaired, 18 Main St, Lenox, Ma 01240.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, BEVERLY HIRSCH
description: LANDAU-Beverly Hirsch. The William B. May Company deeply mourns the loss of its dear friend and esteemed colleague. Bev's courage and determination continue to be an inspiration to us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Peter R. Marra President

title: Metro Business; World Trade Center Is Offered for Lease
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has begun the process of selling the master lease for the World Trade Center, the largest office complex in the country.

title: Davy Jones's Larder
description: Almost every restaurant serves seafood in some form, but the specialists are the most intriguing. Here are 12 where seafood comes first. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: Woman Fleeing Mutilation Savors Freedom
description: When Adelaide Abankwah fled the threat of genital cutting in her native Ghana, she thought she would find a better life in the United States. But instead, that life -- as for many other illegal immigrants -- unfolded in a detention center.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CITIGROUP INC., New York, named Julie Persily managing director at its acquisition finance group. Ms. Persily had helped set up the leveraged finance group at Banker's Trust, part of Deutsche Bank A.G.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, RICA (NEE MARTENS)
description: SMITH-Rica (Nee Martens). Actress who appeared in such feature films as Living in Oblivion, Welcome to the Dollhouse and Box of Moonlight, and such Broadway shows as The Shrike and Laura, died August 11, 1999. She was the beloved mother of Laurel Smith and loving sister of Fred Martens, Evelyn, Ladick and Lotus Murphy. She was the greatest mother a daughter could ask for and a loyal and compassionate friend to those she loved. A memorial service will be held at MCC Theater, 120 W. 28th St. August 26, 7:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the American Lung Association, 1740 Broadway, NYC, 10019.

title: Eli Chic or Boola Boorish?; Moral Crisis: Yale Club Goes Casual on Fridays
description: At the Yale Club in Manhattan, in the once-exclusive domain of the jacket and necktie, there are now short-sleeve tattersalls. There are tieless button-downs. There are yellow polo shirts. There are Top-Siders, not to mention Nike Airs. Khakis have been observed in the exclusive Roof Dining Room. There are jeans.

title: GROWTH IN SOUTH KOREA
description: Supported by brisk exports and strong investments and consumption, South Korea's economy grew by 9.8 percent in the second quarter, the Bank of Korea, the central bank, said in a preliminary report. The rate was much stronger than had been expected and returned South Korea's economy to growth levels that had prevailed before the financial crisis in late 1997. But economists said that the heavy indebtedness of the Daewoo Group, the big conglomerate that is to be broken up, could impede growth next year.

title: A Luscious Journey, Exhaustively Annotated
description: It is not a good sign when the most memorable thing about an exhibition is not the art on the walls but the artist's chronology in the catalogue. Such is the case with the exhibition of David Reed's suave, technically dazzling paintings at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City.

title: Of Hermes, Rolex and Oh, Yes, Murder
description: Japan's trade balance with the United States is not likely to be fattened by its export to the Screening Room of the literally bloody, figuratively anemic thriller ''Nobody.''

title: Ex-Broker Pleads Guilty In State and Federal Courts
description: Victor Wang, the former chairman of Duke & Company, a defunct New York brokerage firm, shuttled yesterday between Manhattan and Brooklyn, pleading guilty to three crimes in two courts.

title: Cone Puts Concerns to Rest
description: David Cone shook his right arm, arched his back and exhaled. There were two outs in the seventh inning, and Cone realized that his time on the mound on this splendid day had dwindled to almost nothing. He had one more out to secure and then he would be done.

title: Greek Orthodox Archbishop Resigns in Face of Dissent
description: The highest-ranking cleric of the Greek Orthodox Church in the United States, Archbishop Spyridon, who has dominion over a flock of 1.5 million, resigned yesterday after more than a year of unrest and dissension in the denomination and growing demands by priests and laity for his ouster.

title: Embezzlement Charges Filed Against Two In Brooklyn
description: Two top officials of a social services organization that operated small group homes for the retarded and for troubled juveniles were charged yesterday with stealing more than $2 million in government-provided funds through kickbacks and other schemes.

title: Weekend Warrior; Stalk a Hummer? Well, Don't Hum
description: I've always been attracted to land's end, the wild landscape where a rugged cape or promontory falls into the sea. Cape May County in New Jersey is such a place. Within three hours of New York and two of Philadelphia, the lower peninsula of New Jersey is living proof you don't have to drive far to feel far away. To be sure, we humans are not the only species attracted to Cape May, a body of land bounded on the west by Delaware Bay and on the east by the Atlantic. For birds, also, it's an ideal resting, if not nesting, spot.

title: SAMSUNG CREDITORS DEAL
description: The South Korean conglomerate Samsung Group told creditors it would provide 2.8 trillion won ($2.3 billion) to cover the debts of its failed car maker, Samsung Motors, if the four million shares in Samsung Life Insurance that have already been donated by the group chairman, Lee Kun-hee, are insufficient. Samsung, the country's third-largest conglomerate behind Hyundai and Daewoo, put Samsung Motors into bankruptcy protection in June and had resisted creditor demands to guarantee the carmaker's debts.

title: France Voices Dissatisfaction With U.S.-Led Bombing of Iraq
description: France vented long-simmering uneasiness today over the continuing American-led bombing raids on Iraq, setting the stage for what diplomats here expect to be a confrontation with the United States at the United Nations General Assembly next month.

title: More on the Boy And His Beagle
description: Once again a boy and his dog and their nice little movie, ''Shiloh 2: Shiloh Season,'' have infiltrated the nation's theaters, hung around for too short a time to be noticed by many people but just long enough to gather an accolade or two before beating a precipitous but well-planned retreat to more hospitable territory in video stores.

title: A Crusader for Mentally Ill Lost Old Allies
description: DJ. JAFFE has never quite got used to people calling him a Nazi. ''I have a thick skin,'' he says, smiling the quick, almost defensive smile that accompanies many of his sentences. ''But that doesn't mean it's easy to hear that. It's still hard.''

title: Richard W. Jennings, a Titan Of Securities Law, Dies at 91
description: Richard W. Jennings, who helped popularize the study of securities law in United States law schools and helped export concepts of market regulation to the postwar societies of Japan and Germany, died at his home in Piedmont, Calif., on Aug. 9 after a brief illness. He was 91.

title: Metro Business; Kodak to Pay Penalty
description: Eastman Kodak Company has agreed to pay a $775,000 penalty to New York and to correct what the state says are violations of environmental law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARPEL, PHOEBE BRAND
description: KARPEL-Phoebe Brand. On August 18, 1999. Cherished widow of Herman Karpel. Most beloved mother of Roberta and Robert Silman, Susan and Morton Levine, Victoria and Nathan Fisher; grandmother of Miriam and David, Joshua and Denise, Ruth and Timothy, Richard and Patricia, Gary, Michele, Gabrielle, Avram; and great grandmother of Meredith, Taylor, Mallorie. A truly great lady: indomitable, caring, witty, and a shining example to all who knew her. Funeral service at Beth-El Synagogue, North Ave. at Northfield Rd., New Rochelle, NY on Friday, August 20th at 10 AM.

title: Freeman Is Focused On Being the Greatest
description: Antonio Freeman joined the Green Bay Packers in 1995 as a third-round draft pick, as a ''project,'' as a kick returner rather than as a receiver. He was full of impatience and exhibited a spirited edge that appeared ruffian-like. His contract was for three years and included a $370,000 signing bonus as part of an $850,000 deal.

title: Treasuries Fall for the First Time in 4 Days
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the first time in four days, as traders reacted to the unexpected widening in the nation's trade deficit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINGHAM, WILLIAM LANE, LT. COL. (RET. U.S.A.F.)
description: BINGHAM-William Lane, Lt. Col. (Ret. U.S.A.F.) on August 15, 1999 in Nashville, TN. Survived by wife Virginia Potter Bingham of Nashville, son William L. Bingham, Jr. of North Salem, NY, daughters Margot B. Lash of Cornwall on Hudson, NY, Melinda P. Bingham of Croton on Hudson, NY, and Pamela M. M. Bingham of Nashville, TN, eight grand children, two sisters and three brothers. A memorial service will be held at the United States Military Academy at West Point on September 1, 1999 at 1:30 PM at the Cadet Chapel.

title: In Parcells's Book for Now, Farrior Nudges Phifer as Starter at Weakside Linebacker
description: For most Jets fans, it doesn't have the intrigue of who will be Vinny Testaverde's backup, but for Coach Bill Parcells, a more immediate concern is: who will be the starting weakside linebacker?

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The numerals are Roman, but the food is Argentine. LX, on East 60th Street in Manhattan, is a dark and handsome newcomer that goes beyond the gaucho-steak formula to explore regional Argentine specialties.

title: Lower East Shakespeare: Life Encroaches on Art
description: Were it not for the neighborhood it is in, the Expanded Arts company's production of ''Measure for Measure'' might drive an audience to distraction with its determination to turn this ambiguous, moody play into a laugh circus. But the robust neighborhood steps in with its own distractions often enough to make what is in effect a series of witty comments on this, the last production this year of the company's free ''Shakespeare in the Park(ing Lot)'' series.

title: More Logging Wars on the Horizon
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Glaxo Wellcome Inc., Research Triangle Park, N.C., part of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., to Robert A. Becker Inc. Euro RSCG, New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, to handle the account of the drug company's Serevent Inhalation Aerosol, an asthma treatment. Capitalized billings were estimated at $7.2 million.

title: Everyone Gets an A in the Dark Ages
description: There once was a nasty high school teacher who told Kevin Williamson he couldn't write, little dreaming that Mr. Williamson had the ''Scream'' movies, ''I Know What You Did Last Summer'' and ''Dawson's Creek'' in his future. As if these weren't hits with enough of a vengeance, Mr. Williamson also dreamed up a story about a teacher who is tied to her bed by three students and peppered with taunts like: ''You know, you hide behind your degree. But the reality is you're jealous of every student you teach!''

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday, based on the article, also referred imprecisely to the loss of $1 billion. It should have said that total included Bosnian public funds along with international aid.

title: When Times Are Tough, Yoshii Proves Tougher
description: Time after time, Masato Yoshii has pitched his best with his job in jeopardy. And not just this season.

title: Companies Cash In On New Pension Plan; But Older Workers Can Face Penalties
description: Corporate activism did not come easily to Bill Syverson. But like a lot of his strait-laced colleagues at I.B.M., the 49-year-old engineer found his cause this year after realizing his employer planned to cut his pension by what he estimates as 40 percent.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary, especially in August, when many close on Saturdays as well or open by appointment, and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Kim Perrot, 32, Leader of W.N.B.A. Champions
description: Kim Perrot, the tiny floor leader of the Houston Comets team that has won the first two Women's National Basketball Association championships, died here today. She was 32.

title: The Moral: War Is Bad, The Same Everywhere
description: ''We're all in God's hands,'' says the Chaplain. The old woman beside him answers, ''I don't think it has gotten that bad yet.'' At another point she observes, ''I have learned that nothing comes when you think it will, not even the season.'' At one point a major pays one of the woman's sons, whose name is Elvis, the highest compliment: ''You have the makings of a young Marcos.'' The woman describes her only daughter as ''half-G.I.'' She will eventually lose all her children to war.

title: U.S. Indicts Supremacist in Mailman's Killing
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted the white supremacist Buford O. Furrow Jr. on three felony counts in the killing of a Filipino-American letter carrier here last week, as the Government focused its prosecution on charges that could result in the death penalty.

title: GERMAN UTILITY MERGER SEEN
description: The shares of Viag A.G. and Veba A.G. were both sharply higher after the German monthly magazine, Manager Magazin, reported that the two large German utilities were in advanced discussions toward merging their businesses. The companies denied the report, but a member of Viag's board told the German news agency VWD that it was substantially correct. There have been widespread expectations that German utilities must consolidate to compete with European giants like Electricite de France.

title: Boy Killed, 2 Hurt by Gunmen on Bicycles
description: An 11-year-old boy was killed and two other people were injured last night, one critically, when three gunmen on bicycles fired onto a sidewalk in front of a Brooklyn housing project, the police said.

title: Justice Dept. Proposing Bill To Foil Computer Encryption
description: The Justice Department is proposing legislation that would make it easier for law enforcement agents to thwart computer encryption programs that they believe are being used to cover up crimes, department officials said tonight.

title: Has Texas Gun Law Kept Crime Down?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTIZ, FRANCES
description: ORTIZ-Frances. Passed away August 17. Beloved mother of Dennis. Funeral mass 10:30AM Friday at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, 980 Park Avenue, 84th Street.

title: Report Says Labor Market Tight
description: The number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose last week, while the less-volatile four-week average declined to its lowest level in more than a quarter-century, suggesting the pool of available employees remains relatively small.

title: White House Therapy: a Ticket Out of Office
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Raids at Bank of New York

title: Friends and Neighbors of Shooting Victim Recall a Polite, Sweet-Natured Boy
description: Kelvin McGinnis was like a lot of the other 11-year-old boys who lived in his neighborhood in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, playing basketball in his free time and watching professional wrestling on television, many friends and neighbors said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday misstated the closing date for the exhibition ''Dance for the City: 50 Years of the New York City Ballet'' at the New-York Historical Society in Manhattan. It closed on Aug. 15; it was not extended to Oct. 17.

title: Giants Look Forward to the Tough Preseason Opponents
description: It has only been three games, two of them in the preseason, but lately the Giants have been manhandled by the Jacksonville Jaguars. In three lopsided games the Jaguars have outscored the Giants by 102-39, and physically dominated them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, EDDY
description: WEINSTEIN-Eddy. Precious darling husband and best friend of Caryl and the late Nanette. Loving and beloved father of Clifford and Georgia, Richard and Wendy, Marc, Harvey, Richard and Marna, and Rachel and Robert. Adoring and adored grandfather of Dena and Scott, Jonathan, Kenneth, Alexandra, Tracie, Michael, Jordan, Joshua and Alison. Beloved brother of Larry and Helen. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 10:30AM, Sunday.

title: New Cable Channel to Present CBS's Top-Rated Soap Opera
description: CBS agreed yesterday to extend its contract to broadcast television's highest-rated soap opera, ''The Young and the Restless,'' in a deal that will enable Columbia Tristar Television, the studio that produces it, to use the program as a centerpiece in its plans to begin a cable channel devoted to soap operas.

title: Candidate for State Police Apparently Clears Hurdle
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's protracted search for a new commander for the troubled New Jersey State Police apparently cleared a major obstacle today, when Janet Reno, the United States Attorney General, and state officials resolved two bureaucratic problems that had prevented an F.B.I. agent in New York from accepting the job.

title: Teamwork Off the Court
description: Edna Campbell juggles the demands of her job with the responsibility of being a parent, a dual life complicated because she is also a single mother.

title: Michael Sveda, the Inventor Of Cyclamates, Dies at 87
description: Dr. Michael Sveda, a chemist who invented cyclamates, a noncaloric sweetener that became widely popular and then was banned by the Government as a possible carcinogen, died on Aug. 10 at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 87.

title: Why Nobody Likes A Loser; Failure? No, a Bump On the Road to Success
description: There is a curious inversion afoot in Silicon Valley, where Internet entrepreneurs whose start-up companies fail are more marketable to venture capitalists than those who have never failed at all. It is not how business is supposed to work, but there it is: in that corner of the economy, failure has become an asset, a resume-builder.

title: Spitzer Sues Lender After It Makes a Deal With Banking Regulators
description: State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer filed a sweeping Federal civil rights lawsuit yesterday against New York State's biggest home equity lender, accusing the company of enticing thousands of poor minority homeowners in Brooklyn and Queens into loans they could not afford.

title: A Do-or-Die Essence Fed by Love
description: The audience is often almost as much the point as the show in the free outdoor festivals that spring up each summer around New York. That was the case on Thursday night, when Philadanco performed at the Damrosch Park Band Shell at Lincoln Center Out of Doors.

title: Mayor Speaks on Weasels, Dog Owners and Politicians
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's weekly radio program, ''Live From City Hall,'' on WABC-AM (770).

title: Rally Against Milosevic Fails To Bind Opposition Parties
description: While opposition politicians spoke with pleasure today about the size and passion of Thursday night's rally against President Slobodan Milosevic, they continued to disagree on how best to harness that energy effectively.

title: Japan Merger Of Three Banks Signals a Trend
description: Japan signaled the start of a far-reaching consolidation of its bloated and debt-ridden banking system today with official word that three of the country's biggest banks would unite to form the world's largest financial institution.

title: White House Therapy: a Ticket Out of Office
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Intriguing Events
description: A look at some of the events that could be the most tightly contested in the world track and field championships:

title: Zolak Gets His Shot, but Now Mirer Joins the Field
description: With remarkable timing, Bill Parcells traded today for a backup quarterback, Rick Mirer, to shore up a problematic area of the Jets' offense.

title: Police Discover Car of Woman Who Vanished
description: A routine check to identify the owner of a car abandoned on a Brooklyn street has given Nassau County homicide detectives their first major break in the case of a pregnant Long Island woman missing since July 10, the police said today.

title: A Good Credit History, Indeed; Opening the Books on American Business, 1841-1891
description: With his large hands clad in delicate white gloves, Travis B. Blackman gingerly opened the sheepskin-bound book and blew gently on the onion-skin-thin pages to separate them. He treated the aged volume with the reverence normally reserved for a first-edition Dickens or Hemingway.

title: PAPER MAKER'S AMBITIONS
description: In a bid to become the world's largest forest products company, the Finnish-Swedish company Stora Enso said it planned to sell its noncore assets to finance further acquisitions so that it can overtake the industry leader, the International Paper Company. The company, Europe's largest paper maker, outlined its plan to sell power plants worth 2 billion euros, or $2.1 billion, as it focuses on manufacturing paper for newspapers and magazines as well as finer paper used for photocopying and packaging boards. The company, formed when Enso Oy of Finland merged with Stora A.B. of Sweden, also said it would buy back 5 percent of its stock.

title: Amid Reports of Funnels, Wind Rips an Island
description: Two people were injured and dozens of buildings on Long Beach Island were damaged yesterday by powerful winds, which witnesses described as a waterspout in the Atlantic Ocean that came ashore.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the planned acquisition of First State Bancorp by Staten Island Bancorp misstated Staten Island's assets. They are $4.1 billion, not $1.4 billion.

title: Franco's Role Uncertain
description: John Franco, who has a sprained flexor tendon in the middle finger of his left hand, made 100 tosses off flat ground yesterday and expects to be activated from the disabled list in the first week in September. But Manager Bobby Valentine would not guarantee that Franco would return as the exclusive closer.

title: Parents' Cram Course
description: On dozens of campuses, college administrators are gathering the parents of incoming freshmen in their own orientation programs.

title: POLYVISION, EDUCATIONAL CONCERN, TO EXPAND
description: The Polyvision Corporation, a maker of educational products, bought the A. Lawer Corporation, a closely held chalkboard and marker-board company, for $30 million in cash and stock. Polyvision, based in Long Island City, Queens, paid $24 million in cash and $6 million in preferred stock for Lawer, which is based in Corona, Calif. Polyvision's chief executive, Joseph A. Menniti, said the deal would reduce costs, though no dismissals are currently planned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, MORTIMER I.
description: METZGER-Mortimer I. Devoted father of Jane and Ken Laffend, Warren and Mary Pat Metzger. Dear brother of Lenore M. Klein and the late Judith M. Riggs. Adored grandfather of Lisa Anne, Edward I. and Karin Jane Laffend, Rosemarie and Jeffrey R. Metzger, and devoted great-grandfather. MIT class of '39. Retired from Scientific Design. Donations to the American Cancer Society. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: ROLLS-ROYCE TO BUY COOPER CAMERON STAKE IN VENTURE
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the world's No. 2 aircraft engine maker, agreed to buy the Cooper Cameron Corporation's stake in their gas-processing and transmission-equipment joint venture for $180 million in cash to increase its presence in the United States energy market. Rolls-Royce said the purchase would give it full control of Cooper Rolls, a joint venture with Cooper Energy Services, a unit of Houston-based Cooper Cameron. Cooper Cameron, the fifth-largest United States oilfield-services company, is quitting the business of making rotating-compression equipment -- high-horsepower devices that help move large amounts of natural gas over long-distance pipelines -- as it scales back activities to revive earnings hurt by slumping oil prices.

title: Soldiers Dying to Serve, And Die to Serve They Do
description: Anyone who has already succumbed to computer-borne paranoia in this year of Y2K foreboding had better brace for another jolt to the ganglia in the form of ''Universal Soldier: The Return.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, RICA
description: SMITH-Rica (Nee Martens). Actress who appeared in such feature films as Living in Oblivion, Welcome to the Dollhouse and Box of Moonlight, and such Broadway shows as The Shrike and Laura, died August 11, 1999. She was the beloved mother of Laurel Smith and loving sister of Fred Martens, Evelyn, Ladick and Lotus Murphy. She was the greatest mother a daughter could ask for and a loyal and compassionate friend to those she loved. A memorial service will be held at MCC Theater, 120 W. 28th St. August 26, 7:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the American Lung Association, 1740 Broadway, NYC, 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCANARNEY, KATHRYN BLANEY
description: McANARNEY-Kathryn Blaney of Watkins Glen, NY on August 18, 1999. Predeceased by husband Henry and daughter Kathryn M. Survived by daughters Elizabeth of Rochester, NY and Mary of Watkins Glen. Memorial Mass at St. Mary's of the Lake Church, Watkins Glen on Saturday, August 28 at 11:00 am. Memorials may be made to Children's Hospital at Strong, PO Box 23029, Rochester, NY 14692-9804.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee fell to its lowest price in more than five years amid concern that a glut in the United States is overwhelming demand. In New York, coffee for September delivery fell 0.45 cent, to 88.35 cents a pound.

title: Cracking That Enemy Code: A Romantic Prototype for the Hacker
description: Toward the end of Neal Stephenson's recently published novel, ''Cryptonomicon'' (Avon), two plot strands converge on attempts to crack a particularly knotty Japanese code from World War II. Toward the end of the war a brilliant mathematician uses a collection of abacuses and a primitive heat-producing vacuum-tube computer to untangle a code that has stymied the Allies' best minds. Then, 50 years later, the mathematician's grandson sits in a Philippine prison with his laptop computer, attempting to crack that same Japanese code, whose secrets have been lost. He must keep all results hidden from his captors' eyes, so the decoding itself must be encoded.

title: Italy's Junior Team Cruises To Victory Over Americans
description: World championship battles between the United States and Italy, which were annual events four decades ago, have returned in a different setting that may be a harbinger of the new millennium. The final of the World Junior Teams in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., ended Wednesday in a well-earned victory for the Italians.

title: Just Keep Testaverde Healthy, Because Jets' Plan B Is a Bust
description: Each time quarterback Vinny Testaverde feels a twitch, or has an aching muscle -- or even reaches across his couch to get the television remote control -- a Jets doctor had better be by his side. Because if anything ever happens to the Pro Bowl quarterback, the Jets' season is done.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on Thursday about options on the Dell Computer Corporation referred imprecisely to their trading at the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The options will continue to be traded on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange as well; they did not shift solely to Chicago.

title: Editorial Observer; Mr. Giuliani Works New York's Rural Precincts
description: Symbolism can lean heavily on a political event, which is why most campaigns try to avoid zoos and hot air balloons. So it seemed odd that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani found himself in a slightly uncomfortable position this week -- figuratively, of course -- at a steak roast outside Binghamton, N.Y. The Mayor, upstate for the evening as part of his coyly unannounced bid for the United States Senate, found himself penned between hot barbecue grills on one side and the hard questions of reporters on the other. As he spoke on tricky political issues like the Northeast dairy compact, clouds of smoke rolled over his head. As he adjusted his brash city tone to the softer hush of the countryside, cooks hawked steaks to customers behind him and yelled, ''medium, medium,'' like a chorus promoting the Mayor's moderated form of Republicanism.

title: 2,800 Years Old And Still Relevant
description: Now that it's back-to-school season at the malls, it's time for me to make up the syllabus for my fall-semester course in classical mythology. Last year, when I asked my students if they would like me to add or drop anything from the reading list, they requested more of what we were reading already: why not read the whole of ''The Aeneid''? Why not read all of Ovid's ''Metamorphoses''? So this year again, by popular demand, we will be reading the same old texts, all by dead white males.

title: TRACTABEL STOCK JUMPS
description: The stock of Belgium's biggest utility, Tractebel S.A., surged 13 percent after Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. offered 7.5 billion euros ($8 billion) for the 49 percent of Tractabel it does not already own. Suez offered one of its shares plus 16 euros in cash for each Tractebel share. Suez also offered 900 million euros in stock to buy the remaining third of Sita S.A., Europe's biggest garbage collector. Increased competition will continue to spur alliances and large acquisitions in Europe's utility industry, the Suez chief executive, Gerard Mestrallet, above, said yesterday at a news conference in Brussels.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about press inquiries on whether Gov. George W. Bush of Texas had ever used drugs referred incorrectly to the drug-related questions posed to job applicants at the Clinton White House. Prospective employees are asked to disclose any use of illegal drugs as far back as age 18 (not during the previous seven years or to age 18, whichever is more recent). Mr. Bush has declined to answer whether he could deny using illegal drugs since he was 18.

title: All the Other 12-Year-Olds Want to Beat Toms River
description: They have black and silver uniforms and a menacing nickname, the Beasts of the East, but the players from Toms River East do not appear to be an imposing bunch. They are not unusually big 12-year-olds, and their star pitcher, Casey Gaynor, is as shy and soft-spoken as he is effective on the mound.

title: Prayers and Donations for Turkey's Quake Victims
description: They are natives of Syria, Lebanon, Somalia, Egypt, England and the United States. But yesterday, they all gathered to pray amid the exposed wiring and unfinished walls of a house of worship that they had scrimped and saved to build in midtown Manhattan.

title: Halfway Houses Are Casualties of a Michigan Sentencing Law
description: As an unintended consequence of the state's truth-in-sentencing law, halfway houses around Michigan are being closed, leaving prisoners fewer chances to obtain job experience or training, drug-abuse treatment or other services to help them ease back into society.

title: Shifting Stand, A Prosecutor Steps Down
description: Patricia A. Hurt, the Essex County Prosecutor who defiantly vowed to fight last month's decision by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman to strip her of her powers, relented today and resigned.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He's no different from the rest of our hosts, who have a pretty high opinion of their own opinion and like to tell people what they think.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDS, MANNY
description: SANDS-Manny. Suddenly, on August 18, 1999. Beloved husband of Lucille; loving father of Patricia and Jeffrey; cherished grandfather of Jessica and Hillary; adoring father-in-law of Rita and the late Richard Smolick. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Hebrew Home For the Aged in Riverdale, are greatly appreicated. The world is a better place for his joy and kindness.

title: NO MORE BORING FASHION
description: In the last few years, fashion has become flabby, with an emphasis on supermodels and mass production. But last season some individuality started to return, sparked by a sense of fun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSLER, SONIA FELLNER
description: OSLER-Sonia Fellner. Born October 10, 1912 in Pruchnik, Poland; died August 16, 1999 in Columbia, Maryland. B.A. Hunter College, 1933, Ph.D. (Psychology), Johns Hopkins University, 1954. She had a varied career, serving as a manager with the New York City Housing Authority from the late 1930's until 1949 and later as professor of Psychology at Goucher College, Johns Hopkins University, and Adelphi University, from which she retired in 1978. She was an inspiring teacher and active researcher in the field of developmental psychology. Her friends, relatives, and associates will always remember her penetrating intelligence and critical judgement, as well as her concern with social progress. She leaves behind, Dr. Abraham G. Osler of Columbia, Maryland, her husband of 61 years, and daughter Dr. Margaret J. Osler of Calgary, Alberta, Can.

title: As Freshmen Work on Their Timetables, Parents Get a Short Course in Letting Go
description: Having said occasionally tearful goodbyes to their loved ones, the 160 newcomers to the lakeside campus pasted on their name tags and embarked on a two-day introduction to university life.

description: If there's anything callers to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's weekly radio program should know before dialing, it's this: Be careful what you ask.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, ADRIAN P.
description: REED-Adrian P. 68, farmer and philanthropist, died peacefully at his home, Lands End Farm, in Centreville, Maryland, Monday, August 16. The cause was cancer. Mr. Reed was long associated with local charitable causes and farm land stewardship. He was a dedicated conservationist and avid protector of the environment. He served on the Board of Directors of the Easton Memorial Hospital and Chesapeake College and was a supporter of the Cancer Center of Easton. Mr. Reed was born and raised in Greenwich, CT and Hobe Sound, FL, and attended Deerfield Academy and the US Military Academy at West Point. He served in the army after graduation from West Point. He was Treasurer of the Jupiter Island Club in Hobe Sound. Mr. Reed was an investment banker with White, Weld & Co in New York City before moving to the Eastern Shore of Maryland in 1964 where he bred Charolais cattle and farmed. He is survived by his wife of 33 years, Nancy Jane, and six children, Michael Reed of Andover, MA, Alixe Mattingly of Santa Barbara, CA, Diana Carey of Columbia, MD, Cynthia Klein of Andover, MA, Austin Reed of Kennett Square, PA, and Margery Reed of Durango, CO, and eight grandchildren. A peerless husband and father, and fishing enthusiast, he stood out for his old fashioned character, decency and integrity. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the Regional Cancer Center, Radiation Therapy Department, 509 Idlewyld Avenue, Easton, Maryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, HANNAH MARGOLIS
description: ALEXANDER-Hannah Margolis on August 19, 1999, of N.Y. City and East Quogue. Beloved wife of the late Josef; loving mother of Gregory, Jonathan, Matthew and the late Lewis.Cherished mother-inlaw of Karen, Hanita and Elaine. Adoring grandmother of Jessica, Gabriel, Daniel, Seth, Benjamin and Ethan. Devoted aunt of Phyllis, Doris, Leslie and Rita. Poet, author and loving friend. She will be profoundly missed. Her life was a celebration of creativity, beauty, kindness and thoughtfulness. Service Sunday 11am at the ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: HOME HARDWARE STORES TO TAKE OVER BEAVER LUMBER
description: Home Hardware Stores Ltd., a group of dealer-owned hardware outlets, said yesterday that it would acquire the assets of Beaver Lumber Inc. from Molson Inc., Canada's largest beer maker, for $68 million (Canadian), or $46 million (United States), in cash and debt. Beaver Lumber has 138 stores in Canada. Beaver operates one corporately owned store and a distribution center in Ontario. It owns 87 of the properties where the franchise stores are situated. Molson, which owns the Montreal Canadiens hockey team, has sold unrelated businesses in the last year, including a 25 percent stake in a retail venture with Home Depot Inc.

title: Paris Journal; Solidarity and the Price of Apricots
description: Sometimes the French really do seem to think differently.

title: Kiddie Pop: Raffi It's Not, But Just What Is It Anyway?
description: The sound of young girls screaming has been a main energy source in pop since bobby-soxers greeted the dawn of rock-and-roll. It is amusing to watch music industry moguls and pundits fall all over themselves ''discovering'' that prepubescents get infatuated with prettily packaged crooners like the Backstreet Boys: just another case of short memories making things seem new.

title: Sister Calls Suspect Sociopath Who Killed Officer in '58
description: The sister of Robert Zarinsky, a Linden, N.J., man suspected of murdering four teen-age girls and a police officer, has described him as a violent sociopath who beat family members and tortured animals.

title: SYNOVUS FINANCIAL IS ACQUIRING HORIZON BANCSHARES
description: The Synovus Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire closely held Horizon Bancshares Inc. for $19.4 million in stock to strengthen its business in the growing Florida Panhandle market. Horizon Bancshares, with $66 million in assets, is the parent company of Horizon Bank of Florida, based in Pensacola. Horizon Bank has three banking centers in Pensacola. Synovus, based in Columbus, Ga., with $11.2 billion in assets, will merge Horizon Bank with its Bank of Pensacola affiliate. Synovus operates 36 banks in the southern United States. Synovus also owns 80.8 percent of Total System Services Inc., an information technology processor of credit, debit, commercial and private-label cards.

title: Over Montenegro, Belgrade's Shadow Darkens
description: The rows of slate-gray missile boats rock at their moorings behind a chain link fence, the Yugoslav sailors shaded from the unforgiving sun by tarps over the back decks. Frigates patrol the emerald green waters off the coast and board incoming freighters for inspection.

title: Turkish Resort Tries to Tend To the Living and the Dead
description: This summer resort town on the Sea of Marmara lost more than 1,000 lives in the earthquake, and today the town square was full of survivors trying to figure out how to marshal the relief effort.

title: Former Chief of C.I.A. Is Stripped Of Right to Classified Information
description: The Central Intelligence Agency announced today that it had suspended the security clearance of its former Director, John M. Deutch, after concluding that as Director he had improperly handled national secrets on a desktop computer at his home.

title: Clinton, in Role Reversal, Helps His Wife as Fund-Raiser
description: For the first time in the strange odyssey of a sitting President whose wife is seeking public office, President Clinton stepped into the role of supportive spouse tonight to help Hillary Rodham Clinton build up a war chest for her likely Senate campaign.

title: The M.V.P. of Flushing, Inroads on the Bronx
description: On a sunny morning in Port St. Lucie, Fla., five months ago, Robin Ventura was gradually offering signs about the type of person he would be with the Mets. Cordial, quiet, humorous and, whenever possible, hidden. Each time Ventura was questioned about himself during a spring training interview, he provided brief answers or shifted the discussion to his new team.

description: At times today, Lance Armstrong hardly looked like the 27-year-old Texan who less than a month ago won the Tour de France. He huffed and puffed and ached and cramped. Every lap, he had to get off his bike and carry it for a hundred yards.

title: Nancy Guild, 73, Insouciant 40's Actress
description: Nancy Guild, a film actress who starred opposite some of the leading men of the 1940's and early 50's, died on Monday at her home in East Hampton, Long Island, after a long battle with emphysema. She was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBEY, HENRY
description: ABBEY-Henry. On August 20, 1999, of Aventura, Fl. Formerly of Lido Beach, NY. Beloved husband of Susan, dear father of Arnold, Richard, Susan, and Lisa. Adoring grandfather of Evy, Jody, and Jason. Great-grandfather of Rachel, Eric, Benjamin, Rebecca and Mitchell. Brother of Harold. Memorial service 6PM Monday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to a kidney foundation.

title: Banking Scandal Threatens Efforts to Change Indonesia
description: Displaying internal divisions that could hamper efforts to overhaul Indonesia's economy, lawmakers from President B. J. Habibie's own political party are taking sides against him over a widening banking scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZER, DEIRDRE
description: MAZER-Deirdre (nee McCorry) Age 31. Too young to leave us all so grief stricken. We will never forget your beauty and love. You were taken from our midst in the prime of your life. Always in our hearts. Lois Mazer, and MartinZelman Cathy and Kenny Gurny

title: Westerners See a Toothless Japanese Giant
description: The proposed merger of three Japanese banks into a behemoth with $1.3 trillion in assets poses little competitive threat to American or European banks, bankers and analysts said yesterday, nor will it do much to disrupt the push by foreign banks into Japan's home market.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a motor scooter on Thursday with an entry in the Business Digest about the sale of a controlling stake in Piaggio Veicoli Eu ropei, the maker of the Vespa scooter, was published in error. It showed the Velocifero, made by Italjet.

title: Political Memo; A Gregarious Bush Warms to Politicking
description: Former President George Bush's biggest problem, an old friend of his once suggested, was that he liked policy a lot more than politics.

title: A World-Class Week in Seville: Hot, Fast, Hotter, Faster
description: There is a painting by Gonzalo Bilbao in the Museo de Bellas Artes here that is called ''A Summer Night in Seville.'' It depicts people sleeping in the street in an attempt to cope with the heat for which the Andalusian capital is nearly as famous in Spain as for its Moorish monuments, elegant bullring, flower-filled patios and Sybaritic spring festival, La Feria.

title: Donald L. Mason, 74, Who Led F.B.I. Unit Tracking Stolen Art
description: Donald Louis Mason, an F.B.I. agent whose fascination with art inspired him to create a loosely organized unit within the bureau's major theft squad in New York that became the scourge of art thieves in the 1970's, died on Aug. 10 at his home in Haworth, N.J. He was 74.

description: MARK McGWIRE played in the World Series in his second, third and fourth seasons in the major leagues. He thought that was how his career would always be.

description: With the death toll from Tuesday's earthquake projected to soar into the tens of thousands and the vast dislocation of people showing no sign of ending, relief workers and Government officials today turned to the challenge of preventing the outbreak of disease.

title: American Navy Ships Carrying Aid to Turkey
description: Three Navy ships carrying more than 3,000 sailors and marines and tons of relief supplies are to arrive off the coast of Turkey this weekend, the spearhead of what is proving to be a large American military response to Turkey's devastating earthquake.

title: Milosevic Is One Problem. National Denial Is the Other.
description: Opposition political parties have joined forces across Serbia in recent days in an effort to oust Slobodan Milosevic, the man who drove their country to ruin. As James Rubin, the State Department spokesman, put it, the Serbs are realizing they would be better off ''if an indicted war criminal were no longer the President of Yugoslavia.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKSTEIN, ROSALIND
description: DICKSTEIN-Rosalind. Died suddenly August 18, 1999. She was the beloved wife of the late Abe Dickstein and devoted mother of Steven and daughter-in-law Janet. A most loving and caring grandmother of Nate. She will be deeply missed by her twin sister, MarionReimer, her brother Irving Greenberg and wife Rita, and many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by her brother Larry Greenberg. Her warm personality won her many friends who will miss her greatly. Funeral services on Sunday, August 22, 1999 in North Miami Beach, FL.

title: Dr. Robert Byck, 66, Expert on Smokable Cocaine, Dies
description: Dr. Robert Byck, a psychiatrist and brain researcher at Yale Medical School who in 1979 gave Congress an early warning that the United States faced an epidemic of smokable cocaine, died on Aug. 9 in a Boston hospital. He was 66 and lived in Gilford, Conn.

Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10AM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66 Street. Interment private.

title: Another Prime Minister Fired by Yeltsin Moves to Succeed Him
description: Former Prime Minister Sergei V. Stepashin emerged today as the leader of a new centrist alliance, as the unofficial race to succeed President Boris N. Yeltsin gathered momentum.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a forensics experiment in which piglet cadavers were buried in peat bogs misstated some of the procedure. The piglets remained undisturbed until excavation; they were not dug up regularly in the first few weeks.

title: Wild Rides on Stock Market Begin in Internet Chat Rooms
description: On-line stock traders, goaded by the leader of an Internet chat room, commandeered the shares of an obscure company this week, taking it on the kind of roller-coaster ride that longtime traders worry may harm investors and undermine faith in the overall stock market.

title: 11 Arrested in Video Piracy Crackdown
description: New York City police officials said yesterday that they had brought down the curtain on one of the largest video piracy operations along the East Coast, arresting 11 men and confiscating about 30,000 videotapes as part of a four-month investigation.

description: As many as 20 researchers from the United States are going to Turkey to see if there are any lessons relevant to the San Andreas fault in California.

title: About New York; At Zoo, a Benefactor's Tall Legacy
description: REGARDING summer babies of New York, there are probably none whose eyelashes are as long and lovely as those of James 11th, who arrived July 8, at the Bronx Zoo. He is a giraffe, and like all male giraffes born at the zoo is named for James Walter Carter, a benefactor who died in 1981, at age 85. As you may gather from the newcomer's name, there have been 11 James the giraffes born at the zoo since this practice began, shortly after the death of Mr. Carter.

title: BENTALL, A CANADIAN REALTOR, IS IN U.S. ACQUISITION
description: The Bentall Corporation, a Canadian real estate company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 487,000-square-foot office building in suburban Los Angeles for $111 million. Bentall, which owns and manages office properties, said the seller was a joint venture between Walton Street Capital of Chicago and the Whitehall funds of Goldman, Sachs & Company. The 21-story building, 1888 Century Park East, is currently 97 percent leased. The building's 40 tenants include Turner Broadcasting Systems.

title: Eugenie Marron, 99, Fishing Record-Holder
description: Eugenie Marron, a renowned big-game fisherwoman a half-century ago, died on Monday at a hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 99.

title: Latin America Confronts New Uncertainty
description: Latin America's currency and bond markets came under pressure today as worries over the possibility of default by Ecuador, one of the smaller Latin countries, collided with concern that political gridlock would slow the region's juggernaut, Brazil.

title: Vera Krasovskaya, 83, Historian And Critic of the Russian Ballet
description: Vera Krasovskaya, the dean of Russian ballet historians and a ballet writer who was highly respected in the West, died on Sunday at her home in St. Petersburg, Russia. She was 83.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the response of the Reynolds Metals Company to a takeover attempt by Alcoa Inc. misspelled the name of a French company that is merging with two other aluminum producers. (The three-way merged company was rumored to be considering a rival bid for Reynolds.) The company is Pechiney S.A., not Rechiney.

title: Sir John Hale, 75, Historian Of Europe and the Renaissance
description: Sir John Hale, a British historian who specialized in the Renaissance and was a former chairman of the National Gallery in London, died on Aug. 12. He was 75.

title: Majority of Summer Class Passes Promotion Tests
description: More than 60 percent of the students from the third, sixth and eighth grades who took the standardized tests at the end of mandatory summer school in New York City this year passed and will be allowed to move on to the next grade, according to preliminary results released yesterday, pleasing Board of Education officials but suggesting that thousands of children will be held back.

title: The Next Attack on Dirty Water
description: Under pressure from environmental groups, the Clinton Administration now plans to invoke a largely ignored section of the 1972 Clean Water Act to tackle the biggest remaining threat to the nation's waterways -- polluted runoff. Federal and state governments have greatly reduced the pollution that flows from readily identifiable sources like factories and waste treatment plants. But they have singularly failed to control polluted runoff from more diffuse sources like farms, city streets, even golf courses. Farm runoff in particular has been blamed for widespread fish kills and even human illness. It is also the main reason why more than two-fifths of the country's waters -- some 20,000 rivers, lakes and estuaries altogether -- are still too dirty for fishing or swimming.

title: Schools With A Slant
description: The high school where I teach is now debating whether to renew its contract with Channel One, the media service that gives schools free televisions and cable access in exchange for a captive student audience.

title: Bank of New York Offices Raided in 2 Cities
description: Federal investigators raided the Wall Street offices of the Bank of New York yesterday and took files of a top officer of the bank who has been implicated in an investigation of what is believed to be a major money-laundering operation involving Russian organized crime.

title: Touchy Issue for Barak: Peres's Role on His Team
description: Meetings have taken place at the highest levels, including several with Prime Minister Ehud Barak. Memos have been drafted, rejected, amended. And despite assurances that a deal is imminent, tensions remain high six weeks after the formation of the new Israeli Government.

title: Emergence of a Venezuelan Potentate
description: Venezuela is the world's largest oil exporter outside the Middle East, yet 80 percent of its people live in poverty. Hugo Chavez won the presidency nine months ago promising to end the corruption and mismanagement that has helped to squander Venezuela's riches. But while Venezuelans overwhelmingly supported radical reform, they should be very wary of the methods Mr. Chavez is using. He is drawing power into his own hands, and misusing a special Constitutional Assembly meeting now in Caracas that is composed almost entirely of his supporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZICHT, RHODA
description: ZICHT-Rhoda, on August 19th, 1999. Devoted wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Anita and the late Allen Fial and Lynne Winters. Beloved grandmother of Alison and Michael Greene, Barrie and Jonathan Fial, and Elizabeth Wurtzel. Darling great-grandmother of Jordan, Andrew, Dana, Darren, and Alex. Cherished sister to Bess and Ben Parmet, Zena and William Druss, the late Jennie and Cass Casyd, Edna and the late Murray Blumenfeld, and Jessie and the late George Druss. Dear aunt to many nieces and nephews. The cornerstone of the family, she will be remembered by all who were fortunate to know her for her warmth, strength and determination. Funeral services on Sunday, August 22nd. For information, call 516-487-9600.

title: LADY LUCK GAMING TO ADD LAS VEGAS CASINO AND HOTEL
description: The Lady Luck Gaming Corporation, an operator of dockside and riverboat casinos, said yesterday that it would buy the Lady Luck Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev., and the right to use the Lady Luck trademark from the chairman of Lady Luck Gaming, Andrew H. Tompkins, for $45.5 million. The purchase also includes Gemini Inc. and Marco Polo Services. Both are owned by Mr. Tompkins, who also has a 45 percent stake in Las Vegas-based Lady Luck Gaming. Gemini owns the Lady Luck name and operates the casino. The hotel includes 800 slot and video poker machines, 30 table games, 792 guest rooms and 4 restaurants. Lady Luck Gaming, with 1998 revenue of $141.8 million, owns a riverboat and dockside casinos in Mississippi. Mr. Tompkins established the Las Vegas casino in 1965.

title: Senatorial Race By Giuliani Poses a Problem For Top Liberal
description: No political party leader has been more central to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's success than Raymond B. Harding, the head of the state Liberal Party. Mr. Harding's decision to steer the Liberal Party line to Mr. Giuliani has twice lifted the Republican Mayor to victory, in a city with a huge Democratic edge. Giuliani repaid the favor by providing Mr. Harding with both entree to his inner circle and a roster of patronage jobs.

description: Gov. George W. Bush, finishing his first tough week on the Presidential campaign trail, tried today to use the stir over his answers about possible drug use as proof of the need to elevate American politics.

description: Shares of Dillard's Inc. fell 19.5 percent today amid declining sales and rising costs at former Mercantile stores being converted into ones for Dillard's.

description: WEINSTEIN-Edward. The Board of Governors and Members of Inwood Country Club record with sorrow the passing of Edward Weinstein, beloved husband of Caryl and we extend deepest sympathy to the family. Robert Scharf, President David Gruber, Secretary

It is in El Segundo, Calif.; a subsidiary, Broderbund, is in Novato.

title: Carolina Power May Be Buying Florida Utility
description: The Carolina Power and Light Company, the second-largest utility in North Carolina, is close to an agreement to buy the Florida Progress Corporation, the second-largest utility in Florida, in a deal worth as much as $5.3 billion, a person close to the talks said.

title: SAAB EARNINGS RISE
description: The Swedish maker of warplanes and aircraft parts, Saab A.B., said its second-quarter profit rose almost fourfold, partly because it booked a gain connected to the closing of regional aircraft production. Net income by the company, maker of the JAS 39 Gripen fighter, rose to 336 million kronor ($40.9 million) from 87 million kronor a year earlier. The company booked a one-time gain of 174 million kronor in the quarter. The gain was money that had been reserved for ending the production of regional aircraft and that Saab said it would not need to use.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, RONALD
description: HOWARD-Ronald W., 65, a resident of Arlington, VA and a long time administrator at The George Washington University died of cancer August 19th. Mr. Howard served as Director of the Alumni Admissions Program and was previously Director of Alumni Relations. A memorial service will be held Monday August 23 at 4pm in the Dorothy Betts Theater on The George Washington University campus.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 11 about the Navy's ties to the Tailhook Association misstated the military background of Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia. He served in the Navy in World War II, rising to the rank of petty officer third class, and served again in the Marine Corps in the Korean War as a communications officer, not as a pilot.

title: Altina Schinasi Miranda, 92, Designer of Harlequin Glasses
description: Altina Schinasi Miranda, who is credited with designing the flared-frame Harlequin eyeglasses, which first came into vogue in the late 1930's and which have made kitschy comebacks from time to time, died on Thursday at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 92.

title: Derided by Democrats, Dole and McCain Will Attend a Controversial Donor's Annual Picnic
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona and Elizabeth Dole plan to attend an annual Republican Party picnic on Saturday at a lush island estate near Seattle.

title: Rain Postpones McGwire's Home Run Derby for at Least a Day
description: Mark McGwire was waiting back in the clubhouse and thousands of fans stayed huddled under the Shea Stadium mezzanine for almost 90 minutes. But finally, more than two hours after pitcher Orel Hershiser concluded his warmup and as another sheet of rain began to descend, the Mets postponed last night's game against St. Louis and sent home an estimated 40,000 fans who had hoped to see McGwire's home run heroics, as well as some by a home team fighting for a playoff spot.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORTEL NETWORKS CORP., Brampton, Ontario, a maker of communications equipment, will shut down a research and development unit near Montreal, laying off up to 130 people and moving another 150 jobs.

title: Charles S. Joelson, 83, Congressman Who Saved School Libraries
description: Charles Samuel Joelson, a five-term Congressman from New Jersey who is best remembered for an amendment that spared thousands of school libraries in 1969, died Tuesday at CentraState Medical Center in Freehold Township, N.J. He was 83 and lived in Freehold.

title: Phelps Dodge Offers to Acquire Two Merging Copper Companies
description: Continuing a consolidation trend among basic commodity industries, the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the copper producer, made a bid yesterday and then sweetened it to acquire the Cyprus Amax Minerals Company and Asarco Inc., which themselves had just agreed to merge. The Phelps Dodge bid was promptly rejected.

title: E-COMMERCE VENTURE FOR CHINA
description: The News Corporation announced a strategic partnership between its joint-venture unit, the PDN Xinren Information and Technology Company, and the Oracle Corporation of Redwood Shores, Calif., to develop an E-commerce business in China. Under the agreement, Oracle will provide an Internet-based technology platform and E-commerce support services for Chinabyte, an Internet content provider begun by PDN. PDN is a joint venture between the News Corporation, the Australian media company led by Rupert Murdoch, and The People's Daily in China. Chinabyte.com specializes in information technology content.

title: Leigh Film To Lead New York Festival
description: The 37th annual New York Film Festival, which runs from Sept. 24 to Oct. 10 at Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center, embraces work by an international array of talents.

title: Who Needs Extra Batting Practice? Not Ledee and Williams
description: Nearly the entire roster of the Yankees' position players inhabited the otherwise empty Metrodome early this afternoon, for extra, and optional, batting practice, the echoes of ball meeting bat pinballing around the place.

title: PARTIAL EXONERATIONS IN SOUTH KOREA
description: A Seoul district court found two former top economic officials innocent of charges that they had neglected their duties during the economic crisis that forced South Korea to seek a bailout from the International Monetary Fund in late 1997. The court acquitted Kang Kyong Shik, former Minister of Finance and Economy, and Kim In Ho, former chief presidential economic secretary, of the charges brought against them. But the court found the two former officials guilty of separate charges that they had pressed banks to extend preferential loans to cash-short companies.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar was little changed against the yen and the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 111.52 yen, up from 111.40 on Thursday, while the euro rose to $1.0668, from $1.0630.

title: Crusader for Women in Science
description: The reason there are so few women in science is self-evident to David Gelertner, the Yale computer scientist: ''Women are less drawn to science and engineering than men are.''

title: Offering by Lionbridge
description: Lionbridge Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had raised $35 million in the initial sale of the company's stock to the public. The 3.5 million shares sold for $10 apiece, their expected price. Shares of Lionbridge closed yesterday at $12.625 on volume of 10.8 million on the Nasdaq stock market. Based in Waltham, Mass., Lionbridge provides multilingual versions of its customers' software, hardware and other related material.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SNELLENBURG, RENEE
description: SNELLENBURG-Renee. August 23, 1992. A dearly loved aunt whom I continue to think about daily. Mathilde Christato

title: Brunell Gives Credibility To Inconsistent Jaguars
description: The last time New York football fans saw the Jacksonville Jaguars, they saw a team that dropped the ball, kicked it and crumbled with turnovers in a 34-24 playoff loss to the Jets at Giants Stadium. That was seven months ago.

title: Seafood Staples and a Fickle Ambiance
description: THE Watermark, in East Hampton, can be a placid pleasure or a stressful bedlam of a place. I experienced both at this waterfront restaurant at 313 Three Mile Harbor Road (324-0000). On a relaxing weekday, we sat under a nautical blue awning on the outdoor deck overlooking the marina and harbor beyond, leisurely eating the smoothly served three-course $19.95 early-bird dinner. The deck, bordered by a privet hedge, held tables topped with paper-covered white cloths and fresh flowers. The setting sun glimmered on the water as a gentle breeze blew through the limbs of a majestic weeping willow nearby.

title: New Department Urged
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano called on the Board of Legislators on Tuesday to abolish the Department of Fire Safety Services and in its place establish a more inclusive Department of Emergency Services to oversee fire, disaster and emergency services.

title: Return of the Clintons, With Less Frenzy
description: OFFICIALLY, the White House describes it as a vacation, just like last year. But when President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton return this week for their second summer invasion of the Hamptons, the agenda's emphasis will again be on fund-raising over fun.

title: Scrap Over a Soup Kitchen
description: A long-simmering feud between an East Village block association and a ministry that runs a local soup kitchen has erupted.

title: Taking a Serious Approach to Italian Fare
description: FROM the paved walk with wooden benches outside the restaurant to the sparkling glassware and spotless table settings within, every detail at Il Pranzo in Branford seems to have been carefully planned. (The sheltering oak tree over the benches is a bonus.)

title: JERSEY DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

description: To the Editor:

description: The Los Angeles River

title: Pairing a Tax Break and Web Giving
description: SOME highly popular new Web sites have built impressive followings on a simple premise: If you stop at them before shopping on the Internet, some portion of what you spend will go to charity.

title: STATES CALLED LAX ON TESTS FOR LEAD IN POOR CHILDREN
description: Federal investigators say most states are flouting a 1989 law requiring that young children on Medicaid be tested for lead poisoning. As a result, they say, hundreds of thousands of children exposed to dangerously high levels of lead are neither tested nor treated.

title: Listening to Dinner
description: NONVERBAL communication is often difficult to get across. Chefs, in particular, try valiantly to communicate with diners by way of their food, as did Tita de la Garza, the main character in the novel and the movie ''Like Water for Chocolate.'' Effortlessly and often unknowingly, she spoke to her family and friends through tears of sadness in a cake batter or drops of blood from her broken heart in a rose-petal quail sauce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEARWOOD, ANNE
description: YEARWOOD-Anne. January 20, 1905-August 2, 1999. Teacher extraordinaire and all-around wonderful human being. She will be missed by Camille Johnson and family, many relatives and friends, and by her ''children,'' pupils of P.S. 54 and P.S. 20, Brooklyn. Services were held; a memorial will be held in the fall. 718-463-8687 for details.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZER, DEIRDRE (NEE MCCORRY)
description: MAZER-Deirdre (nee McCorry) Age 31. Beloved wife of Kenneth Mazer. Mother of Alexander. Daughter of Terrance & Maureen McCorry. Sister to Terry & Christopher McCorry. Daughter-in-law of Lois Mazer and Richard & Rosario Mazer. Sister-in-law to Laura McCorry, Cathy & Kenny Gurny, Peggy & Barry Ogden. Friends may call Saturday, 7-9pm & Sunday 2-4pm, & 7-9pm at the Edwin Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY. Funeral Mass Monday, August 23rd. 10am St. Mary's Church, 23 South High St. Mt. Vernon, NY. 914-664-5855. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Crohn's & Colitis Fndtion, 386 Park Av.
