title: Special Corner Of 2 Nations
description: CAPE FLATTERY is a sacred place. Or so it seemed to me, standing high atop the promontory that forms the extreme northwestern corner of the lower 48 states.

title: Russian Money-Laundering Investigation Finds a Familiar Swiss Banker in the Middle
description: At the intersection of illicit Russian money and the Bank of New York is Bruce Rappaport, a Swiss banker who has had brushes with governmental investigators in the past and who has long had an important connection to the bank.

title: Death of the Fashion Groupie
description: Whatever happened to fashion obsession? Whatever became of the hard-core fans who used to counterfeit tickets to runway shows? Has anyone lately spotted the drag queens who once named their ''houses'' after fashion designers? What about the Tokyo ''office ladies,'' the ones who scrimped for years to finance a 57th Street binge? Where did they get to? And what's become of our home-grown label junkies, the ''Double C'' ladies clad head-to-spectator-pump in Chanel? Are they holed up in a safe house somewhere, along with all the clown-garbed club kids and holdouts from the Cult of Models -- you know, the folks who hoard layouts of their favorite ''girls,'' torn from the back pages of, say, Bulgarian Vogue?

title: The Nation; Disaster Drills and Intercoms Barricading the School Door
description: As students at the nation's high schools begin taking their seats in classrooms for the new academic year, many are finding themselves deprived of prized possessions and surrounded by equipment that looks as if it belongs in a James Bond movie. Behind the changes is a demand for security in the wake of the school shootings in Littleton, Colo., and elsewhere last year. While some schools are taking more extreme measures than others, what follows is a partial listing of what's awaiting some students.

title: Debt: The Next Generation
description: BABY BOOMERS are returning to school in increasing numbers, to work on graduate degrees or to finish their undergraduate work as they try to advance their careers. But that zeal has created a unique financial squeeze that education experts say can only tighten: As they pay off loans for their own education, past or present, parents are taking on additional debt for their children's schooling.

title: Brodsky to Press Revaluation Fight
description: FOR years, Westchester County and local government officials have been talking about the need for an overhaul of the way property is assessed resulting in inequities to homeowners and large tax refunds to businesses, but this year, as in past years, talk apparently will not translate into action.

title: Ventura's Mission: Turning Two Into One
description: Jesse Ventura says he is tired of talking about whether he would rather be President than Governor of Minnesota. So he is spreading the word that for the foreseeable future he will grant interviews only to reporters who want to ask him about his latest Gopher State project.

title: Vreelandia!
description: All this began one night when Kenneth Jay Lane, the fake-jewelry king, leaned over at a dinner party and said, ''You know, Diana Vreeland would have loved these times.''

title: The Karma Bank
description: To the Editor: Daisann McLane's ''Pouches, Padlocks and the Golden Rule'' (Aug. 8), on ideas for safe travel, hit a responsive chord. Her remark that she made deposits in her karma bank by giving directions to tourists struck another chord, but I wonder if the bank is having trouble with its deposit slips lately.

title: At Fort Totten and Elsewhere, Crows Dying Mysteriously
description: For the past year, William Carrasko, a security guard at Fort Totten, has left birdseed at a birdbath by the front gate, attracting pigeons, sparrows and many crows. At least until two weeks ago, he said, when the crows began to disappear. ''Then I began finding them dead all over the base,'' he said.

title: A Fight Over Thinking Big
description: Few things rile residents more than the suggestion that their neighborhood might become more like Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALEXANDER, HANNAH MARGOLIS
description: ALEXANDER-Hannah Margolis on August 19, 1999, of N.Y. City and East Quogue. Beloved wife of the late Josef; loving mother of Gregory, Jonathan, Matthew and the late Lewis.Cherished mother-inlaw of Karen, Hanita and Elaine. Adoring grandmother of Jessica, Gabriel, Daniel, Seth, Benjamin and Ethan. Devoted aunt of Phyllis, Doris, Leslie and Rita. Poet, author and loving friend. She will be profoundly missed. Her life was a celebration of creativity, beauty, kindness and thoughtfulness. Service Sunday 11am at the ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Custer Syndrome
description: WHEN WE WERE WOLVES

title: Another Hit Could Give Witches a Bad Name
description: FOR at least one person who has seen ''The Blair Witch Project,'' the surprise hit movie of the summer did not so much terrify as infuriate. One long slur against witches, said Selena Fox, a witch, or Wicca, as male and female American witches prefer to call themselves.

title: At Johnson Wax, A Family Passes On Its Heirloom; Father Divides a Business To Keep the Children United
description: THERE is no family feud over succession at S. C. Johnson & Company, no pack of obstructionist cousins demanding larger dividend checks. The 113-year-old family business has not gone the way of Milwaukee's Schlitz Brewing Company, collapsing after the family owners lost control. No one has been inquiring about the rise and fall of the storied Johnson empire.

title: August 15-21; A Brownout Hits New England
description: One word that Yankees dread more than ''drought'' is ''drab.'' And a menacing brown is enveloping New England roadsides, as thirsty red oaks and sugar maples shed their shriveled leaves a good two months before the invasion of tourists drawn to the region's foliage show each fall.

title: Can B. Smith Be Martha?
description: It is a hot summer Sunday in the Hamptons, and I am spending the day with Barbara Smith, the restaurateur and cookbook author, the host of a nationally syndicated television show, ''B. Smith, With Style,'' and the editor in chief of an upcoming magazine, that will bear her brandlike name. Her house in Sag Harbor, with its stunning views of the water, its enormous deck and two kitchens, is therefore more than just a house; it's also a set. But today it is a bit of a mess.

title: Ann Marie Yasin, Daniel Richter
description: Ann Marie Yasin, the daughter of Annette and Thomas Yasin of Gaylord, Mich., was married yesterday evening to Daniel Sam Richter, a son of Sara and Morton Richter of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Joseph Goldman performed the ceremony in the Ida Noyes Hall at the University of Chicago, where the couple are doctoral candidates.

title: On Politics; The Money Comes in Handy, Even When There's No Race
description: Like the best used car salesmen, smart politicians generally find a way to make hay from the clunkers that come their way. So when Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat from Long Beach, saw his dream of becoming a senator fizzle this year, he still managed to walk away with something: extra campaign cash.

title: Ms. Sutyak, Mr. Waldrip
description: Gerri-Michele Sutyak, the daughter of Geraldine Sutyak of Cincinnati and the late Michael Sutyak, is to be married today to Timothy Owen Waldrip, a son of Ceil Cleveland of Centerport, N.Y., and Donald Waldrip of Houston. The Rev. Robert Merkle, a United Church of Christ minister, is to perform the nondenominational ceremony in Poipu on the Hawaiian island of Kauai.

title: Sarah Redd and Victor Ekperigin
description: IN the days before Victor Ebisan Ekperigin, 43, married Sarah Frances Redd, 34, he was very, very nervous. ''I didn't have butterflies in my stomach, I had pigeons,'' he said.

Mr. Adams carried a clipboard and wore a pair of blue latex gloves. Like a surgeon about to perform a delicate operation, he approached the open crate, which with its pockets and padding resembled a piece of sculpture itself, and tenderly touched the Giacometti.

description: MOM, can you get this? Honey, can you get that? Oh, we're out of dog food?'' said Kate McEnroe, listing demands women hear regularly.

But in her first two years of competition, the news media throng never came and Davis began to think that maybe she would be allowed to compete as the rest of America's archers do: in peace, in quiet and anonymity.

title: August 15-21; Starr to Leave Soon
description: After five years of investigation, the Whitewater prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr has decided to call it quits. His associates said he would step aside to resume his private law practice as early as October. Mr. Starr plans to stay to put the last touches on a final report on his inquiries -- a document that could embarrass Hillary Rodham Clinton as she moves closer to entering the New York Senate race.

description: BARELY a year after a worldwide deflation scare -- when markets and currencies were crashing, banks and businesses in Asia, Russia and Latin America were failing, and prices of oil and raw materials were plunging -- inflation is back on peoples' minds.

description: Hillary Rodham Clinton will inaugurate a new phase of her exploratory campaign for the United States Senate after Labor Day, breaking from her schedule of listening forums to add other events, such as street walks and visits to centers for the elderly, the First Lady's associates said yesterday.

title: Professor Parcells's Lesson: Good Teams Losing Focus
description: Bill Parcells's dark vision of his Jets -- yes, the team that captivated much of the pro football world with its performance last season -- was at its gloomiest yesterday. Predictably, it came after a Friday night exhibition victory over the Eagles.

description: The five ferries that transport 1.3 million passengers and 400,000 vehicles annually between the beach resorts of Cape May, N.J., and Lewes, Del., have undergone $54.4 million in renovations.

description: Texas clobbered Cleveland three times, but the Indians won the fourth game of their series last week. The Rangers get the Yankees in a three-game series beginning tomorrow night in Arlington. The Indians play two games in Texas on Sept. 7 and 8. The Yankees play four games in Cleveland later in the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBEY, HENRY
description: ABBEY-Henry. We lost a dear friend who enriched our lives. Our love and comfort to his sweetheart Susan. How very much we will miss you, Henry. Joyce and Stan Goodman

title: Carolyn Greenspon, Rick Gershberg
description: Carolyn Dryfoos Greenspon, the daughter of Jacqueline Hays Dryfoos and Stuart Prince Greenspon, both of New York, was married last evening to Rick Arthur Gershberg, a son of Rita and Fred Gershberg of Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony in Darien, Conn., at the home of Marian S. Heiskell and Andrew Heiskell, the bride's maternal grandmother and step-grandfather.

title: Nicole Hazard, Jonathan Brook

Brook and Dr. David W. Brook of New York. Rabbi Edward S. Boraz of the Roth Center for Jewish Life at Dartmouth College officiated at the Echo Lake Inn in Ludlow, Vt.

title: Megastores, Bargain Hunting And Life's Little Indignities
description: FOR years, I resisted the temptations of Costco, the Price Club, Sam's Warehouse and all the rest. My friends would come back from these places with toilet paper representing the output of several forests and wagon-wheel-sized Brie that cost less than a Happy Meal. They bragged about each bargain like hunters who had just bagged a 12-point buck: backyard furniture sets for less than $200, new Anne Rice novels for under $10.

title: Down Under Pullover
description: Went to Australia and all you got was a lousy T-shirt? If it's made by Bond's, a Sydney-based clothing company founded by George A. Bond in 1915, it might not be so shabby a souvenir. Long a staple of blue-collar closets in Australia, Bond's T-shirts, which are often stocked by hardware stores next to the latex paint, have been adopted by New York's high-style circles. ''The fit is so sexy and the cotton is so beefy,'' said the designer John Bartlett, who discovered the shirt, which he called the ultimate white T-shirt, last fall on a trip Down Under. ''I ended up buying five in every color. Now I order them in bulk over the phone and have a drawer devoted to them.'' They will be easier to get later this month, when Barneys New York brings Bond's T-shirts to American shores, along with their cartoon spokesman, Chesty Bond, an Australian icon on a par with Mr. Clean or the Fruit of the Loom guys. Barneys is to stock Bond's A-frames, crews and V-necks for both men and women, at $15 to $20 each. Mr. Bartlett isn't thrilled. ''They were my little secret,'' he said, ''until now.'' BILL POWERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTTERWEICH, FRANCES LEWIS LEVIN
description: BUTTERWEICH-Frances Lewis Levin. On August 20, 1999 in her 97th year. Beloved mother of Eleanor Spector (Edward) and Dr. Alfred C. Levin (Corinne). title: Jobs for Parents
description: The county has initiated a welfare-to-work program to employ parents who do not have custody of their children and are failing to make support payments.

title: Upstarts' Risky Challenge to Baby Bells

Substantially protected from competition until the enactment of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, the Bells and other local phone companies provided steady if unspectacular earnings growth, healthy dividends and next to no surprises.

description: RICHARD SANDS is an avid woodworker. He likes to make furniture. ''But, you know,'' he said, making a circle with his arms, as if he were hugging a bear, ''I prefer to work with logs, cutting them with a chain saw and turning them on a lathe.

title: The Love Interest
description: The first time Woody Allen directed his girlfriend, Mia Farrow, in the 1982 bagatelle ''A Midsummer Night's Sex Comedy,'' he cast her as a radiant, fin-de-si cle seraphim. The last time he directed her, in 1992's dreary ''Husbands and Wives,'' she played a moping neurotic with AWOL hair who looked like a gamine forced to take early retirement because she'd lost her joie de vivre. Shortly before the movie appeared, Allen's romance with Farrow broke up.

title: Fire Call Leads to 91 Kilograms of Cocaine
description: An apartment fire in a Bronx building early yesterday led to the discovery of 91 kilograms of cocaine, law enforcement officials said.

title: Life After Death Row
description: Since capital punishment was reinstated by the United States Supreme Court in 1976, 566 convicts have been executed. Eighty-two awaiting execution have been exonerated, about half of them during this decade. What follows are capsule accounts of death row's living alumni of the 1990's. CAITLIN LOVINGER

title: Maryann Natherson, Andrew Smith

Andrew Fowler Smith, the son of Marianne and Roy C. Smith 4th of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. David R. Wilt performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: A Fresh Approach to Portraying Flowers
description: FLOWERS are an art perennial, but artists are always trying to show that there is something new under the sun. At the Katonah Museum of Art, ''Wildflowers'' contains some fresh manifestations.

title: Pharmaceutical Companies Force Dilemma for Patients
description: Of what possible use is a medication if the recipient cannot afford to use it [''Going Into Sticker Shock at the Drugstore,'' Aug. 15]? Why must anyone be faced with the decision to die of disease or starvation? By their own admission, pharmaceutical companies have forced such issues on the elderly and millions of others whose profit-making H.M.O.'s refuse to cover many prescription drugs. To state with impunity that ''managed-care companies represent three-fifths of the market'' and therefore have leverage, that the ''big problem lies with the 35 percent of seniors who have no coverage'' and that price controls would stifle research and development is self-serving, socially irresponsible rhetoric. To further suppose that pharmacies would not pass savings on to customers emphasizes the profit-above-all mentality that one can only assume is rampant in the industry.

title: Quick End in Russia To Centrist Coalition
description: Sergei V. Stepashin, who was ousted as Prime Minister of Russia this month, was expected to announce yesterday that he would be leading a new political alliance. Instead, he surprised much of the country by declaring somewhat bitterly that he had failed to pull together the disparate group and would now be going it alone.

title: Spirit Lives On After 35 Years
description: IF you were born in 1964, you've probably begun to notice signs of aging: fallen arches, a bald spot, a tummy that no longer tucks. Isn't it inspiring to find a 35-year-old that still looks and feels young?

title: Books In Brief: Fiction & Poetry

title: OUT THERE: San Onofre State Beach, Calif.; The First Family Of Surfing
description: ON a hazy August morning in the parking lot at San Onofre State Beach, Jonathan Paskowitz paced back and forth inside a rickety camper van, wearing flip-flops and salty board shorts. A cell phone was wedged between his ear and his suntanned shoulder as he fielded a barrage of calls from Tommy Hilfiger, the rock star Perry Farrell, his model-girlfriend and, most important, his auto mechanic. The day before, while driving from this Southern California beach to a surf shop in nearby San Clemente, Mr. Paskowitz's 1970 Dodge van broke down, and he had to nurse it back here.

A steady stream of cars was pulling up, picking people up and dropping people off.

title: A Campaign Fund Keeps On Growing
description: When Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d of Massachusetts retired last year and returned to his nonprofit company, which distributes cheap heating oil to the poor, he had $1.4 million in his re-election campaign fund, an impressive amount for a House member. Under campaign finance rules, he could have given the money to charity, he could have used it to help elect other Democrats or he could have salted it away for some future charitable or political use.

title: Food; Slaw and Order
description: In matters of coleslaw, it would be intolerant, or at least suspiciously undemocratic, to insist on a single recipe. For again and again, this mainstay of barbecues, church suppers, county fairs, family reunions and those patriotic holidays bookending the summer months has proved itself a marvel of versatility.

title: On Avenue C, An Upscale Bakery
description: Despite the occasional flurries of street drama -- like the man yelling at passersby or the dogs fighting on the sidewalk the other day -- the gentrification of Avenue C continues. An upscale bakery and coffee shop opened last month at 153 Avenue C (between Ninth and 10th Streets).

title: Hi- Ho Silverlake
description: In a city where architectural landmarks serve as punctuation for run-on strip malls and shopping centers, streetlight banners help define neighborhoods. In Hollywood, now in the midst of a Times Square-like redevelopment, the banners promote the play ''Art'' with the original Broadway cast. Farther south, on the section of La Brea Avenue that slices through elegant Hancock Park -- where Buff Chandler (Los Angeles's equivalent of Brooke Astor) made her home before she died -- they announce the ''Dosso Dossi'' exhibition at the J. Paul Getty Museum. Closer to the newly resurgent Miracle Mile, home to the ultra-hip Conga Room, they trumpet a Diego Rivera show at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

title: On Top of the World, Stuck in Traffic
description: Lindsey Cigarran never thought she would spend her 20's trapped in a Saab convertible. But the 24-year-old group manager of Beyond.com's entertainment software division commutes an average of two and a half hours every day to and from her San Francisco apartment and an office in Sunnyvale, Calif.

Hoyt Jr. of New York and the late Muriel Christie Hoyt, was married yesterday to Michael Munro Crissan, the son of Bonnie Munro Crissan of Westerly, R.I., and the late Michael G. Crissan. The Rev. Robert Ross performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass.

title: Brief Fare Deals Doing an Encore
description: SOME air fares for fall and winter, and a few Mediterranean cruise prices, are making Europe seem nearly irresistible. The low air fares were presented as short term earlier in the summer, but industry officials said that an oversupply of flights to Europe had developed with the delivery of new planes, and the airlines began gradually backing away from higher prices to try to fill the seats.

title: Leslie Silverman, Jon Bernstein

Both players were already superior musicians when they died, and in certain circles their demise still elicits palpable regret.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-22-99; Killers Among Us
description: A friend of mine was murdered last month. We had been much closer in college and had fallen in and out of contact as people do; even though we had lived within 20 minutes of each other for the past three years, we had had dinner once. I came to work one morning and a co-worker told me that a friend of hers was trying to reach me about a friend of mine. I called. Janet was dead. She had been causing trouble for some drug dealers across the street, and the night before last, people had broken into her home and executed her. She was four months pregnant.

He is, refreshingly, an ordinary guy who has not plotted his whole life to end up in the White House. Or is he too cavalier about the office? He is decisive and sees the big picture. title: Vancouver's Lush Landscapes
description: START with a deep green backdrop of imposing Pacific Northwest firs and cedars. Apply broad swaths of loose, bright English cottage garden borders. Add Asian imports like Japanese black pine and cut-leaf maple, Siberian iris, Himalayan magnolia, euphorbia, hostas and primroses. Sketch in dark ponds and mossy fountains, pavilions with upturned Chinese eaves, artfully pocked and cratered rocks. Put it all together and you get a broad-brush picture of the extraordinarily lush landscape that runs between the houses and high-rises of Vancouver, British Columbia. Nowhere is this gorgeous horticultural fusion more striking than in the city's half-dozen wonderful parks and public gardens, four of which I immersed myself in during a recent visit.

In her defense, my mother often suggested that I might want to admire her menagerie of tactile malefactors from a distance. But it was no use. I've always been compelled to reach out and touch things. Which explains why I now find myself gravitating toward plants that provide positive palpable encounters.

title: As the Toll in Turkey Rises
description: It is impossible to grasp the emotional and civil weight of the death count in Turkey even at present numbers, much less at the numbers some observers are predicting -- perhaps as many as 40,000 dead. That estimate, if reached, would place this earthquake in the same category as those that struck Soviet Armenia in 1988, killing 25,000, and Iran in 1990, killing 40,000. The only equivalent for so much destruction in lives and material in such a short time is the 20th-century battlefield, and it is one of the premises of civilized existence, especially in America, that all but those who have been to war -- a small fraction of society at any time -- should find the conditions of the battlefield unimaginable.

I remember distinctly that moment when, flanked by our three young children, I looked up, up, up through the opening in our semicircular staircase-to-be, and imagined putting them to bed on the fourth floor after a day of sibling squabbles and mashed potatoes on the kitchen floor. The event was sponsored by a modeling agency, Wilhelmina Models, and by a magazine called Mode, which is aimed at ''plus-size'' women. The nationwide search will eventually settle on five women. Each will receive a modeling contract and be featured in the pages of the magazine.

description: THE biennial exhibition of international contemporary art that opened here last month was devoted to exploring the meaning of ''place.'' But even before the opening festivities were over, two installations had been shut down precisely because of their locations.

description: BRINGING the vision of an artist to bear, the sculptor J. Seward Johnson Jr. is creating an office and restaurant complex on 2.5 acres of former industrial property behind his 22-acre Grounds for Sculpture here.

title: Palmistry
description: Now that cigarettes have been replaced by cell phones, and secondhand smoke by voice pollution, it was bound to follow. There would have to be an accessory for the millennium -- a talisman that would be sleek, tactile and versatile enough to go practically anywhere, and yet one that would appropriately reflect our technoculture. A cigarette case for a smoke-free world, pocket-size paraphernalia to go hand-in-glove with that age-old vice -- the fetishistic need to fondle.

title: Let's Make a Deal
description: Opportunity knows no boundaries of place or time. The enterprising have found clients, investors, employees and employers in the oddest of settings -- chance meetings on the subway, supermarket checkout lines or even after a fender-bending collision. What is the most unusual place where you managed -- or at least tried -- to further your fortunes? Or where someone else tried to pursue business with you? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: For Faces That Never Blush
description: These days, when every blab-all sex scandal barely serves to shock, subtlety is out. Even names of makeup colors, once dewily evocative, are now as frank and uncloaked as, say, any dialogue from the hit HBO series ''Sex and the City.''

title: Pocketbook Safety Hook
description: A woman may have impeccable table manners and a finishing-school degree, but chances are she's never learned how to keep her pocketbook from falling off the back of her chair. So, for those who want to avoid the mishaps of having their Fendi Baguette crushed underfoot or stolen, Zitomer Pharmacy, 969 Madison Avenue (75th Street), has the Handbag Hanger ($35), a gold-colored metal hook that attaches to a table's edge to keep a bag in view. When in place, a rhinestone-studded disk lays on the table; a rubber pad prevents slipping. Though it held a Gucci shoulder bag that weighed eight pounds when filled with essentials -- Filofax, cell phone, self-help paperback, lip glosses, creams and more -- some may find the hanger, with its clear, red or gold rhinestones, a tad flashy to match their pony-skin shoes. KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: After the Breakup, Here Comes the Joint-Custody Pet
description: LUCA was in heaven. It was a summer evening, and the Staffordshire terrier sat on a couch between Michael Cecchi and Jennifer McConnell. As the couple talked, they constantly patted Luca, who responded by licking their lips. A happier domestic scene you could not find. There was a catch: Mr. Cecchi and Ms. McConnell broke up three years ago. They have continued to share Luca, who is white with grey-brown circles around the eyes. The couch belongs to Ms. McConnell.

title: Crime
description: The themes that stalk Dave Robicheaux through the swamps in James Lee Burke's Louisiana mysteries -- the arrogance of wealth, the corruption of power and the price a man must pay for the sins of his past -- trail Burke's new series hero, a country lawyer named Billy Bob Holland, out to Texas hill country. HEARTWOOD (Doubleday, $24. 95) takes up the burden with a bruising narrative about the lawlessness that erupts in Deaf Smith, Tex., when Earl Deitrich, a rich, cruel man who thinks he can boss or buy everyone in town, tries to cheat a farmer out of his oil-rich land. ''Ain't right,'' one of his victims observes. ''Law punishes a poor man. Rich man don't have to account.''

title: ART/ARCHITECTURE; A Safer Federal Building for Oklahoma City

Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, which was destroyed by a bomb on April 19, 1995, killing 168 people. At heart, the task involves what seems like a contradiction: designing a building that is secure from attack while affording the openness appropriate for a public building.

This isn't merely to criticize his style; there's something far more troubling in his lawyerly reactions than in his often blunt choice of words -- some essential grasp of human nature seems to be missing.

Certainly, in an age of blockbusters, displays of bouquets of flowers, bowls of fruit and slabs of meat may not immediately spring to mind as guaranteed crowd-pleasers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, STANLEY L.
description: ABRAMS-Stanley L., of Syosset, NY and Tampa, FL, on August 18th, 1999 after a long illness. He was the beloved husband of Gloria. Cherished father of their children, Karen Walczuk and son-inlaw, John Walczuk, of Syosset, NY, Andrew Abrams and daughter-in-law, Claudia Abrams, of Irvington, NY, and Alison Okun and son-in-law, John Okun, of Tampa, FL. Devoted grandfather of Matthew, Jesse and Alix Walczuk, Sean, Cooper and Harrison Abrams, Lee, Max and Molly Okun. Born in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Louis and Mary Abrams, Stanley married high school sweetheart, Gloria Harrison of Brooklyn, in 1944. He served as a naval officer in World War II. Following the war he resided in Great Neck, NY where he was a member of Temple Beth-El and was active in UJA. He was a former Director of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corp., President of the Emerson Quiet-Kool Division and Chairman of Mercury Electronics Corp. After his retirement to Tampa in 1987, he furthered his interests in history and biblical archeology at University of South Florida. His gentle manner, compassion and sense of humor will be missed by his family and friends. Donations may be sent to American Israeli Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC), 440 1st St., NW, Washington, DC 20001.

title: Television's Final Frontier
description: Overlooking Thimphu, Bhutan's capital and the closest thing it has to a city, is a 9,000-foot hill called Sangyegang. At the top of it, where the long, thin, spear-tipped prayer flags never stop rippling -- and you can serenely take in the full valley, if not the whole epic impermanent cosmicness of it all -- a red carpet adorned with loose elaborate patterns of dyed rice has been rolled to the door of a modest one-story structure. There, from behind a wood lectern, Queen Ashi Tshering Pem Wangchuck, the second oldest of King Jigme Singye Wangchuck's four wives -- all sisters -- steps up to address an audience of A-list monks, ministers and dignitaries.

title: All the Rage
description: 1 I hate fashion shows -- just send me the slides. 2 I hate trying to make a splash in last year's Gaultier, only to have everyone say, ''You must have gotten that at Century 21!'' 3 I hate it when they're right. 4 I hate the rush of shame that comes over you when you run into a friend at a sample sale. 5 I hate the way someone who wears a jacket backwards at the Oscars can become internationally crucified. 6 I hate salespeople who say, ''Can I help you?'' when you're clearly just browsing. 7 I hate salespeople who don't say anything when you clearly need help. 8 I hate it when a celebrity who's handed all her clothes by some stylist wins Best Dressed. 9 I hate the way fashion phenomena from my youth are now kitschy nostalgia for the teeny set. 10 I hate dresses that make poor, unsuspecting women look like giant artichokes. 11 I hate sunglasses at night -- and the way they've destroyed my eyes. 12 I hate the right outfit in the wrong color. 13 I hate green. 14 I hate thigh-high white vinyl boots, except on prostitutes. 15 I hate clothes designed to look vintage, at six times the price. 16 I hate when women dress so you can see their implants. 17 I hate back cleavage. 18 I hate rich white people dressed like geishas. 19 I hate sunny floral prints on already overly perky types. 20 I hate the way a little black dress is deemed suitable for any occasion. 21 I hate when colleagues complain about being seated in the second row and I didn't even get standing room (not that I want to go anyway; see item one). 22 I hate people who return everything, just so they can get the thrill of buying something else. 23 I hate hearing how painful high heels are, as if that weren't part of the bargain. 24 I hate that mall hair hasn't changed since 1981. 25 I hate when designers wear their own creations, no matter how far removed they are from the intended demographic. 26 I hate the way I'm still waiting for Evita chic to take off. 27 I hate stars who announce, ''I like to dress simply,'' meaning $4,000 denim skirts covered with embroidery and bugle beads. 28 I hate the word supermodels -- all models are super to me. 29 I hate outfits that molt. 30 I hate fashion. 31 And I hate that.

title: Between Pitches (Twist, Tap), a Game Within the Game
description: The Velcro straps on Chuck Knoblauch's batting gloves don't really need tightening, there isn't any dirt in his spikes to be tapped out, and there's nothing wrong with the grip of his bat.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-22-99; Salient Facts: It Isn't Easy Being Green
description: WHAT'S NEW DOWN ON THE FARM?Ever since high-tech agribusiness started tinkering with the DNA of crops, genetically modified foods have been a battleground for environmentalists (who have called them ''frankenfoods''). Americans can buy genetically modified corn, potatoes and papayas, though in Europe, groups like Greenpeace have blocked the importation of some altered produce. But with the latest innovations, producers are betting they can beat the greens at their own game, casting their test-tube advances as the environment's last, best hope.

title: The Outsiders
description: The fight takes place in the bright light of adult view -- on a weekday afternoon, on a tree-lined residential street, within sight of the police station and a block from the middle school. The smaller boy, about 12, waits until there is a safe distance between himself and the other boy, about 13. Then he sends a curse. It lands. He waits. No response. He follows with a homophobic slur. His opponent -- a chubby boy nicknamed Sex Machine -- finally turns around.

title: From Unusually Plotted to Dramatically Unplotted
description: AMONG the surprises of the year have been three unusual full-evening ballets, one notable for its odd plot structure, the others for their strangely dramatic plotlessness.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-22-99; THE NEW ECONOMY: Unreal Estate
description: Earlier this month, the Internet domain name www.drugs.com -- just the name, nothing else -- was sold to an anonymous buyer for $823,456 (which works out to about $103,000 per letter). It was not the highest sum ever paid for a domain name (many addresses, including wallstreet.com and bingo.com, have fetched $1 million or more), but it is evidence of how the supposedly limitless World Wide Web is running short on real estate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BULL, JOAN
description: BULL-Joan. Mrs. Joan Bull lost her battle with cancer on August 13, 1999, at age 76. Joan was born on April 23, 1923, to Gertrude and William Schweitzer. She was raised in Hillside, NJ, and attended the Vail-Deane School and Wellesley College before moving to NYC. Joan began her committment to philanthropy in 1974 with a volunteer position behind the Information Desk at the American Museum of Natural History. She became one of the Museum's most devoted advocates. Working at the museum, she recognized problems she could help address for both the public and the staff. Her gifts to the Museum helped to fund foreign language floor maps, new drinking fountains, office equipment, and air conditioning units. In 1997, she made a gift to fund the Hayden Edition Zeiss Universarium MKIX projector for the Space Theater in the new Hayden Planetarium, which will open in the Spring of 2000. In recognition of her quarter century of dedicated volunteer service to the Museum and her generous support of so many important museum projects, Joan was inducted as a Trustee in 1997. Up until the last year of her life, she continued to work behind the Museum's Information Desks, dispensing maps and greeting visitors. In addition to the Museum of Natural History, Joan also generously supported the New York Presbyterian Hospital, Guiding Eyes for the Blind, Paralyzed Veterans of America, the American Foundation for the Blind, and the Red Cross. She became an involved supporter of the Merchant's House Museum on 4th Street and actively gave to other NYC cultural institutions. Joan was honored at the 1998 Philanthropy Day celebration of NY's finest philanthropists sponsored by the National Society of Fund Raising Executives. Joan is survived by her daughter Penelope, her grandson Christopher, and her brother Peter. Memorial contributions may be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, Yorktown Heights, NY, or to the charity of your choice.

The overworked air conditioner in my apartment has been stuck at max cool for weeks. But it was not too long ago that I did not have a Fedders frosting my Manhattan walls -- and I did not mind.

title: The Bully in the Mirror
description: On an insufferably muggy afternoon in July, with the thermometer pushing 90 degrees and ozone alerts filling the airwaves, Alexander Bregstein was in a foul mood. He was furious, in fact, for reasons that would become clear only later. Working on just three hours of sleep, and having spent the last eight hours minding a bunch of preschool kids in his summer job as a camp counselor, Alexander was itching to kick back and relax. So there he was, lying on his back in the weight room of his gym, head down on an incline bench, earphones pitching three-figure decibels of the rock band Finger Eleven into his ears as he gripped an 85-pound weight in each hand and then, after a brief pause to gather himself, muscled them into the air with focused bursts of energy. Each lift was accompanied by a sharp exhalation, like the quick, short stroke of a piston.

title: Wide Variance Is Found in H.M.O. Drug Benefits for Elderly

title: Suburban Renewal, One Block at a Time

But a group that has fixed up a half-dozen other structures on the block is hoping to make it the centerpiece of a restoration project that, bit by bit, is reclaiming the hamlet from decades of neglect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THROWER, FRED M.
description: THROWER-Fred M., of Greenwich, CT, on August 16th, 1999 of natural causes at the age of 89 in Greenwich Hospital. Born July 15th, 1910, he grew up in Tampa, FL. He lived most of his working life in NYC and Greenwich. Witnessing and contributing to the birth of television, his career in broadcasting spanned 46 years and included 23 years as the Head of WPIX-Channel 11 in NY. In 1942 he was made General Sales Manager of ABC, the youngest major executive at any national network. 9 years later he joined CBS as VP in charge of sales. 4 months later he was elected a vice president of CBS and a member of the Board. In 1965 he joined WPIX as Chairman of the Board. Innovations for which he will be remembered include the Christmas Eve ''Yule Log'' telecast, WPIX multi awardwinning editorials and the impact of his single slide that said ''Shame'' that appeared on the screen for several hours after the death of Robert Kennedy. Mr. Thrower worked as 1st VP of the Americans for Children Relief and was the Trustee of the National Hemophilia Foundation from whom he received the Crystal Award in 1971. During World War II, he served as a Navy Lieutenant on special assignment to the US Army in both the ETO and CBI theaters. Mr. Thrower was an avid fisherman and loved the outdoors, his family and life. Surviving are his son, F. Mitchell Thrower, III of La Jolla, CA, and his daughter, Wendy Thrower Vigars of Mill Valley, CA. His daughter, Stacey Elizabeth Thrower, died in 1982 at age 16. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions should be sent to the Stacey Elizabeth Thrower Scholarship Fund, c/o Staples High School, Staples Tuition Grants, PO Box 665, Westport, CT 06881. Memorial services will be held at 11 AM, Saturday, August 28th, at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Rd., Greenwich, CT.

title: Heir Apparel

The space may be only 200 square feet, but since opening his sky-blue door a few weeks ago, he has already drawn models as customers, among them James King, Kiara Kubakuru and Leilani Bishop. That's in part because Mr. Steinberg is a celebrity downtown, known for emceeing karaoke night at the Elbow Room on Wednesdays and for performing in bars around town as Johnny Fayva, an over-the-hill lounge singer. The quirkier the better for Mr. Steinberg, whose shop window reads ''Steinberg & Sons, since 1999,'' even though he is a bachelor and has yet to produce an heir. The items range from Diane Von Furstenberg halter-top wraps ($115) to lesser-known designs, like Yu Jeans' sparkly pastel camisoles ($130) and a bandana print skirt ($150) by his girlfriend, Tatiana Von Furstenberg, from her Bait 'n' Tackle line. The best-seller so far is an Olga Kapustina cocktail dress with frayed sleeves ($200). ''The sleeves on most of Olga's pieces are roughly cut,'' he said recently, while Ione Skye tried the dress on. ''So some people might think, 'Hey, it's not finished.' But the models understand that it's a look.'' BILL POWERS

title: Pass the Scalpel
description: In American hospitals, surgical supplies that have been removed from their packaging must be discarded, even if they are never used. Debra Dunn, an operating room nurse at Wayne General Hospital, saw sponges, gowns, drapes, blades, tubing and other supplies being tossed out and thought this was a waste in a world where many are in need of medical equipment. About three years ago, she came up with the Recycled Unused Opened Sterile Supplies program. In it, the hospital resterilizes and repackages unused supplies and sends them to humanitarian organizations that distribute them to places they are needed. Supplies have gone to Bosnia, the Republic of Georgia, and countries in South America and Europe. The current collection of recycled articles will go to the Albert Schweitzer Institute for the Humanities, based in Connecticut, which will place them in hospitals in Bulgaria and to medical stations that aid Kosovar refugees in Macedonia.

title: Books In Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Sainthood Is Out of Reach
description: In Susan Dodd's new book, O CARELESS LOVE: Stories and a Novella (Morrow, $22), love sometimes fails the characters but it always reigns supreme among their preoccupations. ''So Far You Can't Imagine'' is a graceful, glancing investigation of E. M. Forster's maxim, ''Only connect!'' Set in Boston, the story illuminates the obscure threads of fear, loneliness and longing that link strangers together as a man named Schachter, a successful banker, searches for someone who can help him feel more human. In ''Lady Chatterley's Root Canal,'' as in several of the other stories, we see a character at a moment of spiritual crisis that occurs in the most mundane of circumstances -- here, a series of visits to the dentist. In ''Ethiopia,'' a novella, a woman named Nola becomes as ascetic as the saint she is writing about, only to discover that holiness is ''an inhuman thing.'' Her platonic but highly charged friendship with Marcus, a novelist and academic, finally teaches her about her capacity to breathe life into her literary creations and to take the risks that intimate relationships require. At times, the territory of these stories feels too superficially explored; a novel might have allowed Dodd's vivid, wisecracking characters the stretching room they need. One of the stories, ''Lokey Man,'' contains the most breathtaking courtship scene I've ever read. Another, ''What I Remember Now,'' is about the ways in which people don't connect -- and the failure of love to mend wounded lives. The moral of all these stories could be: ''Love would, but simply cannot, conquer all.'' Barbara Quick

At the end of the 20th century, modernity (the state of mind), as opposed to modernism (the movement), is about informed choices and judicious editing. title: Books In Brief: Nonfiction; High Life, Grim Work
description: ''In a painting that's even worth looking at, the image must be twisted if it is to make a renewed assault upon the nervous system,'' Francis Bacon (1909-92) once quipped, hinting at the core of his brutal, visceral, distorted portraits of man and beast and shrieking popes. His friend and biographer Michael Peppiatt and two art historians, Dennis Farr and Sally Yard, build a revelatory composite portrait in FRANCIS BACON: A Retrospective (Abrams/ Trust for Museum Exhibitions, $65). Yard's cogent essay gives essential biographical information: Bacon was thrown out of his home at the age of 16 by his father after being caught in his mother's underwear, and thereafter moved peripatetically among the homosexual underworlds in Berlin, Paris and London, where he finally settled. He was a notorious high liver and an atheist who found in subjects like the Crucifixion a way to convey man's butchery. Farr points out that Bacon, who was assigned to clear corpses from bombed houses during World War II, had plenty of ready-made examples for his Crucifixion studies. He also underscores how fiercely Bacon controlled his images, destroying any he thought unsatisfactory and forbidding written commentary on specific paintings (Farr provides such analysis here, with each color plate). In rousingly animated prose, Peppiatt recounts how Bacon was able ''to transmute paralyzing amounts of drink into creative energy,'' rising at 6 each morning to grapple with his canvases while his companions (including Peppiatt) were incapacitated. And while Bacon excoriated religion, Peppiatt trenchantly observes his near-religious fervor about painting, belying nihilistic statements Bacon was prone to make like: ''I have nothing to express.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: OPINION; A Product of Expansion: Roadkill
description: AS usual I was watching the road carefully, even though I wasn't the one doing the driving. So I was able to get a really good look at the eviscerated and motionless pile in the middle of the road. In a violent and most unpleasant manner, a squirrel had met his maker. The bloody mess had started to send shivers up my spine when I glanced a bit ahead and saw another one. It was equally eviscerated and motionless. Abruptly, the shivers stopped and my suspicions rose. I knew that two dead squirrels within a short stretch of road could mean only one thing -- more woodland in the area was being clear-cut. Determined to find it, I looked quickly to my right. It was still somewhat hidden behind a shallow line of trees, but I was able to see the freshly turned dirt and piles of downed trees. Unfortunately, my instincts were correct; another tract of land was being cleared.

description: The Chinese atomic spy scandal, for months a shadowy maze of complex allegations, has been roiled anew by charges of racial bias.

title: The Pipes, The Pipes Are Calling
description: THERE'S no emergency like a plumbing emergency. By contrast, losing electrical power is no big deal. When the power goes off, we react calmly, lighting candles and dusting off the antique survival equipment that we keep for these occasions, like books, pens and paper. But when the plumbing fails, we panic.

title: Special Services Head
description: The Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services has named Frank L. Owens -- himself a former special education student who suffered from a speech impairment -- as director of special services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, EDWARD
description: WEINSTEIN-Edward. We are broken hearted over the loss of our dear brother Eddy. Our love always. Rest in peace. Helen and Larry Weinstein

title: THEATER; Off Off Off Broadway, Way Up Up Upstairs
description: A SUMMER night, New York City. Something is awry in Apartment 4S in an old tenement walkup in the East Village. The shadow play of a struggle in the window is visible from the street and is followed by muffled shouts and the staccato pop of a gunshot. A boy ducks through the window onto the fire escape and a dog whimpers inside. The apartment goes dark.

title: Seeking Textbooks for All
description: As retailers begin to darken the vacation mood with displays of pencils and notebooks, some Park Slope church members are waging a back-to-school campaign of a different sort. A committee at the Park Slope United Methodist Church has been demanding changes in the New York City school system by circulating a ''School Bill of Rights.''

title: POSTINGS: Conversion Near La Guardia Airport; A Once and Future Hotel
description: An eight-story building at 37th Avenue and 114th Street in Corona, Queens, close to La Guardia Airport, is to be restored to its original hotel use.

title: British Airways Coddles Jet-Lagged Passengers
description: Nobody comes off a trans-Atlantic flight looking better than when he got on it. Realizing this, British Airways has added a spa at its Terminal Four arrivals lounge at Heathrow Airport outside London. Capsules on the floor release the scent of freshly mown grass and sea breezes; there's a small gym, power-jet showers and massages for scalp, neck, shoulders, hands and feet.

title: Painter's Portrait
description: One of the screen's most vivid and haunting portraits of an artist and his work is projected in LUST FOR LIFE (1956), Vincente Minnelli's stunning evocation of the sad life of Vincent van Gogh as derived from Irving Stone's best-selling biographical novel. Kirk Douglas gives an extraordinary performance in the title role, and splendidly effective location sequences enrich the atmosphere. The picture spans the years from van Gogh's early, misguided efforts as a clergyman to his final, feverish burst of painting in the South of France. The artist's torment is made more elusive and poignant by Anthony Quinn's Oscar-winning characterization of van Gogh's friend Gauguin - Wednesday at 8 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies. Howard Thompson

title: When the Glitter of Stock Options Turns to Dust
description: WHEN Brian Knapp arrived at Barnes & Noble's new media division, as it was then known, in January 1997, he thought the risks were amply justified by the rewards. He was given a salary in the range of $50,000, a job he liked and, thanks to a generous stock-options package, the prospect of a big windfall when the division became a separate company with its own stock.

description: Kenya has revoked its visa requirements for Americans staying 30 days or less.

title: Newspaper Stocks: An Internet Story
description: THE conventional wisdom of the new economy says newspapers ought to be on their last legs. In this view, it will not be long before the Internet eats the newspapers' lunch by siphoning off readers and advertising to Web sites.

title: A Cheap Thrill
description: The last time I was in Paris, there was a museum strike, and I was starved for objects of beauty (not to be confused with cosmetics, of which I already had plenty). So I shopped. I shopped at department stores, boutiques, flea markets and the gift shops near the Tuileries. My total purchases consisted of a few Petit Bateau T-shirts. When I had exhausted the city of Paris, I put my American brain to work and discovered that two and a half hours southeast, in Troyes, a city that dates back to Roman times and flourished in the Middle Ages, there are outlet stores. Specifically, there is a shopping center called McArthur Glen Designer Outlet Village that contains 60 shops and a McDonald's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTO, RICHARD
description: OTTO-Richard. We join Maria, Richard's children and Richard's many friends in mourning his untimely passing, especially noting his unparalleled will to overcome and persevere. After 50 years of friendship, I will sorely miss Richard's wit and company. His graceful and handsome presence will live on in the memory of all. Richard and Gail Maidman

title: Megan Leitner, Dion Findley
description: Megan Marie Leitner, a daughter of Jennifer and Anthony Leitner of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Dion Brian Findley, the son of Theresa Findley of Delmar, N.Y., and Craig Findley of Minoa, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Wisniewski performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Immaculate Conception Chapel at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.

title: Jessamyn Reich, Jonathan Abel
description: Jessamyn Sylvie Reich and Jonathan Eran Abel were married yesterday at the Downtown Club in Philadelphia. The ceremony followed Quaker tradition, with the couple marrying themselves, and also incorporated elements from the Jewish and Christian wedding traditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENSTEIN, AMY
description: LOWENSTEIN-Amy, 82, wife of Alan V. Lowenstein, died on August 19, 1999 at her home at 285 No. Ridgewood Road, South Orange, New Jersey. She is survived by her three children: John, and his wife Marcia, of New York City; Roger, and his wife Barbara, of Los Angeles; and Jane Forsyth, and her husband Rocky, of Lexington, Massachusetts; a brother, Dr. James Lieberman, and his wife Lucille, of Westport, CT. She is also survived by her six grandchildren: Ethan Lowenstein and his wife Margo, Randy Lowenstein, Geoffrey Forsyth and his wife Elani Zissimopoulos, Jessica Forsyth, Alexis Lowenstein, and Adam Lowenstein, and two greatgrandchildren, Ruby Lowenstein and Zoe Forsyth. The family will receive friends at their home in South Orange on Friday, August 20 from 4:00PM to 6:00PM and 7:00PM to 9:00PM, and on Saturday August 21 at the same times. Contributions in memory of Amy may be sent to the Jewish Community Centers of MetroWest, 760 Northfield Avenue, West Orange, or to the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, 2 Central Avenue, Newark, New Jersey. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 2 at 11:00 AM at the Jewish Community Center, 760 Northfield Avenue, West Orange, NJ

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-22-99; ON LANGUAGE: plainspeak
description: Where do you go if you need help ''re-engineering communications processes'' or ''contextualizing expertise''? What if you want ''improved system efficiencies'' and other ''value-added communications components''? Why, you go to a plain-language consultant, of course.

description: SEADER-Ruth. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Merrick, NY. Surviving her is devoted husband of 51 years, Dr. Saul Seader, three sons, a daughter, their spouses, three grandchildren, one brother and sister. Artist, author, editor, lecturer on spirituality and meditation, her selfless service and devotion in helping others touched many lives. Memorial service to be held Monday, August 23 at 2PM at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton. In the Chicago area, Sunday, August 29 at 12 noon at the Science of Spirituality, Naperville, Illinois.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BASKAS, MORRIS JACK, D.D.S.
description: BASKAS-Morris Jack, D.D.S. Of Bronxville. World War II veteran, Army Air Corps. A graduate of LIU, Brooklyn, and NYU College of Dentistry. Practiced dentistry in New Rochelle for over 40 years. A member of Alpha Omega Dental Fraternity. Volunteer Teaching Attending, Department of Dentistry, Montefiore Hospital. Held many patents for medical devices. Beloved husband of Florence P. (nee Fisch) for 20-1/2 years. Devoted father of Harriet, David, D.D.S., and Elliot (their mother, Florence Baskas, nee Jablon). Dear fatherin-law of Ross Reynolds and Elizabeth Murray. Loving grandfather of Zachary Philip Baskas. Fond brother of Gertrude Edelstein and the late Anne Orbin. Services today, 12 noon, at Weinstein Memorial Chapels, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY. Contributions can be made to the Department of Dentistry, Montefiore Hospital, 111 East 210th St., Bronx, NY, c/o Dr. Norman Trieger. He was a source of strength to us all. He will be dearly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAYER, STEVEN JAY

Though his stay was short, he will long be remembered by his parents, sister, brother-in-law, nieces & nephews, uncles and cousins, friends and all his animal friends. Rest well my son, Mother & Dad. Contributions to the Epilepsy Fund would be appreciated.

title: The Water Is Fine. The Sand Is Pristine. Stay Out.
description: UNLESS you live in a town that is on the state's long coast, there's a good chance that you have yet to experience the state's best beaches. Unlike New Jersey, where the beaches are open to all, the Connecticut shoreline is a mishmash of rules and restrictions set by towns or private clubs meant to keep other residents away.

title: All About Men
description: With a superb cast headed by Norma Shearer, Joan Crawford and Rosalind Russell (as the funniest, meanest cat), George Cukor's Hollywood treatment of Clare Boothe Luce's stage catfest THE WOMEN (1939) is savage and scintillating. The adaptation by Anita Loos and Jane Murfin not only opens up the original play but also occasionally airs it out, as in a shopping scene. Paulette Goddard, Mary Boland and Marjorie Main make notable contributions to all this swank purring over men, from Manhattan to Reno and back - Monday at 8 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies. Howard Thompson

title: At Disneyland, Same Tree, New Tenant

A familiar attraction at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., the Swiss Family Treehouse, has received a new look to take advantage of the success of Disney's latest animated film. Tarzan's Treehouse, part of Adventureland, begins with a trip up a wooden staircase made of items salvaged from a ''shipwreck.''

title: A Smile For a Laugh
description: ''We thought about Bubba, but Billy-Bob just stuck,'' said Jonah White, a co-inventor of Billy-Bob Teeth, a newly popular brand of joke-shop choppers, hillbilly hybrids of the waxen Halloween staple. The acrylic, sepia-colored gums and tobacco-stained buckteeth, which would need rope for flossing, are selling out of chains like Ricky's and Spencer Gifts ($15.99 a set, plus $3.99 for a plastic container) and, Mr. White says, are showing up at Hollywood parties on pranksters like Bruce Willis and Garth Brooks. Mr. White and his partner, Dr. Rich Bailey, an Illinois dentist, also make Deliverance Teeth and in the spring signed with New Line Cinema to market Austin Powers Teeth. At the premiere party for ''Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me,'' the actor-director Ed Burns wore a pair to kiss Heather Graham, his girlfriend, who stars in the film. Absent from the endorsement list, however, is Billy Bob Thornton. Even though images of Mr. White and Dr. Bailey, looking like characters played by Mr. Thornton in ''Sling Blade'' and ''A Simple Plan,'' are on the packaging of Billy-Bob Teeth, Mr. White said the novelty had no connection with the actor. ''It's just a good hayseed name,'' he said. STEVE GARBARINO

title: Executions Made Easier
description: Federal judges from the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals and state judges from the three states of that circuit -- Georgia, Alabama and Florida -- convened last week at an Atlanta resort to discuss how to expedite state death-penalty cases. Though the ostensible goal was to improve the process, there is little doubt that improvement in this context usually means speeding up executions by making it harder for death-row inmates to appeal. Featured speakers included Judge Edward Carnes of the 11th Circuit, an outspoken death-penalty advocate, and Edith Jones, a Federal appeals judge from Texas who has been a severe critic of lawyers who file death-penalty appeals.

title: Corrections

title: Youngest Among the Oldest Sets a Hard-to-Break Record
description: Becoming the youngest person to do something rarely happens by design. When it does, someone younger usually comes along to set a new record. Last month a New York expert saw an opportunity to set a record of this type that could not be beaten. Senior events have a minimum age limit of 55, so R. Jay Becker of Manhattan decided that on his 55th birthday, July 9, he would play in the Long Island Senior Pairs in Smithtown. He narrowly failed to win but tried again two days later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSTL, THEODORE
description: GERSTL-Theodore. Known to most as ''Teddy'' or ''Uncle Teddy.'' Died on Saturday, August 21, 1999, at the age of 87. He is survived by his loving wife of 65 years, Dorothy Gerstl, his daughter Lynne Pariser, his son Robert Gerstl and his wife Karen Gerstl, his two grandsons Michael Pariser and Jeff Pariser and his wife Antigione Potamianos, his niece Ona Adler and husband Joe Adler, and ''son'' Neil Hirsch. Former drummer and owner of ''Teddy's Lamp Parts,'' on Grand Street, Teddy had a way of making everyone who came in contact with him feel good. He will be missed by all of us who had the good fortune to know him and have him as part of our lives. Services to be held Tuesday, August 24, 12 noon, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave, New York City.

title: Drugs for AIDS in Africa

That disparity virtually guarantees that most of the 22 million Africans infected with the AIDS virus will not get the best available treatment. Few will even be able to afford less expensive life-prolonging drugs such as AZT or ddI or -- far cheaper and just as crucial -- medicines to fight the infections that accompany AIDS.

title: Three Rules for a Superpower to Live By

Its potential for good and, if it should mess up, for bad is going to be immense. That being so, it is going to be extremely important -- not only for America itself but for everyone else -- that Americans think clearly about foreign policy. Here are three modest suggestions toward that end.

title: Bowing Out With the Cheery and the Sublime
description: To close the 1999 edition of Mostly Mozart on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Gerard Schwarz looked back at the moment when fate brought down the curtain on Mozart himself. Mr. Schwarz's program, ''Mozart's Last Year: 1791,'' offered an efficient if necessarily selective overview of his final works, from lightweight bread-and-butter pieces to works of sublime beauty and inspiration. For the occasion, the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra played with a level of ardor and clarity undiminished from its first concert of the summer, four weeks ago, abetted by the Dessoff Choirs and a slate of soloists, some starry and established, some relative newcomers of great promise.

title: The Wall Street Casino
description: Feverish transaction activity in the stock market has become one of the hallmarks of our great bull market. So far, on every business day of 1999, investors have traded some 1.5 billion shares of stock. The annual turnover rate of shares has risen to a half-century high of 95 percent, closing in on the all-time high of 119 percent recorded in 1929. In 1960, the turnover rate was just 12 percent. Today, the average investor holds a share of stock for but a single year.

title: Posada Falls Short of the Cycle, but Yanks Enjoy the Ride
description: Coping with his horrible performance in the first half of this season, Yankees catcher Jorge Posada trained himself to focus solely on the challenges directly before him -- the next inning, the next at-bat. Don't think about the past, don't think too far ahead.

title: 2 Passengers Die as Jet Crash-Lands and Burns in Hong Kong

title: Congressional Myopia on Foreign Aid
description: Foreign aid is not among Washington's most popular causes. But it happens to be one of the more effective investments in long-term global security that America can make. Yet Congress now proposes to cut some $2 billion from President Clinton's already modest $14.6 billion foreign aid request for next year, much of it from crucial crisis prevention programs. When the foreign aid bill goes to a House-Senate conference committee next month, the Republican Congressional leadership should work to reverse these shortsighted cuts. What cannot be restored then should be included in a supplemental foreign aid bill later this fall.

title: When Ironman Race Is Just a Warm-Up
description: The Ironman triathlon consists of 2.4 miles of swimming, 112 miles of cycling and 26.2 miles of running. That might seem to be about the upper limit of human endurance, but not for Patricia Buttenheim and Ann Snoeyenbos.

Terms were not disclosed. The move is part of Disney's strategy to develop an audience for its Web sites beyond the United States.

title: A Day of Reckoning in East Timor
description: After nearly a quarter of a century of tragedy, the people of East Timor will vote next Monday on whether to remain part of Indonesia or become independent. I pray that the United States and other nations will do whatever possible to persuade Indonesian forces to allow this choice to be made freely, and, if independence is the result, to accept it without retaliating with violence.

Yet recent increases in fuel prices have created fears that inflation might rise faster than expected.

title: Three Bright Stretches in a Ring of Neptune Defy a Theory
description: For 15 years, planetary scientists have known that there is something odd about Neptune. Like the other large, gaseous planets in the solar system, it has rings. But unlike the others, it also has arcs, bright clumps of debris along one of the rings. And new observations show that the arcs are still hanging around, when by some rights they should be long gone.

description: In a country where there is no vocation more perilous, indeed more radical, than being a voice for peace, Neelan Tiruchelvam had worked to bring an end to the savage ethnic conflict that has tormented this lush island nation.

title: John S. Gottschalk, 86, a Leader In Federal Efforts to Save Species
description: John S. Gottschalk, a director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in the 1960's who oversaw developments like the first endangered species act, the banning of the pesticide DDT and the comeback of the whooping crane, died on Aug. 13 at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 86.

title: Marino Gives Testimony In Trial of a Teammate
description: There was drama today in the Federal money laundering trial of Miami Dolphins wide receiver Tony Martin, with a teammate, Dan Marino, and a former teammate, Nat Moore, testifying on Martin's behalf and Assistant United States Attorney Ron DeWaard delivering his final argument to the jury. DeWaard contended that Martin could not use ignorance as a defense for illegal acts.

title: Amplifying the Opera? I'll Just Stay Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Pioneering Discounter Seeks Court Protection
description: In another sign that the competitive discount apparel sector may be ripe for a shake-out, the Filene's Basement Corporation, which pioneered the business of offering designer clothing at cut-rate prices, filed for bankruptcy-law protection yesterday in Boston.

title: So It's Only Make-Believe. Gotta Problem With That?
description: From time to time in the course of ''Family Values: The Mob and the Movies,'' it is stipulated that most Italian-Americans are honest, hard-working and as averse to violence as other citizens. But this documentary is not a production of some Italian-American Anti-Defamation League. No sooner is ethnic etiquette out of the way than the program settles into tales of larceny and mayhem among gangs led by New Yorkers with names like Gotti, Gambino and Columbo.

title: Sun Microsystems to Buy Forte in $540 Million Deal
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Forte Software Inc., which produces programming tools for developing Internet applications, for $540 million in stock.

title: When the Face in the Crowd Is Grandmotherly
description: At his sellout Tanglewood concerts over the July 4 weekend, James Taylor, crooning ''Sweet Baby James,'' whisked his audience back to the mellow 1960's and 70's, when the Berkshire Mountains were a magnet for young vagabonds craving music and the other arts in rustic surroundings.

title: Turkish Quake Has Lessons for California
description: Teams of American scientists and engineers have joined Turkish colleagues in seeking lessons from last week's devastating earthquake in Anatolia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAIGER, ARMAND JUSTIN
description: BRAIGER-Armand Justin. Noury Goujjane, proprietor of One If By Land, Two If By Sea, announces the passing of the co-owner and founder of the restaurant, Armand Justin Braiger, eternally 39, in Florida, on August 20, 1999. The restaurant staff joins Mr. Goujjane in extending deepest sympathy to Armand's sisters, Adele Wooters and Leonore R. Spinell; and his many nieces and nephews. We will miss his grace, charm, wit, generosity of spirit and wisdom. Mr. Goujjane remains committed to continuing to implement the plans he and Mr. Braiger developed over most of the past decade for the restaurant.

title: CSK AUTO TO BUY PACCAR'S PARTS SUBSIDIARY
description: The CSK Auto Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Paccar Inc.'s retail automotive parts subsidiary for about $143.2 million in cash. CSK Auto, a Phoenix auto parts retailer, said the purchase would solidify its position in the Western states. Under terms of the agreement, CSK Auto will acquire 192 Grand Auto Supply and Al's Auto Supply stores in Washington, California, Idaho, Oregon, Nevada and Alaska. The business reported sales of about $225 million during the latest 12 months. CSK Auto operates 926 stores in 17 states under the Checker, Schuck's, Kragen and Big Wheel/Rossi names. The company reported revenue of $1 billion in its last fiscal year. Paccar manufactures trucks under the names Kenworth, Peterbilt, DAF and Foden.

title: TEXTRON BUYING CONSTRUCTION EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Textron Inc., which manufactures Cessna airplanes, Bell helicopters and Jacobsen lawn mowers, said yesterday that it was acquiring the construction-equipment maker Omniquip International Inc. for $307 million in cash. It will also assume $170 million in debt. Under the terms of the proposed deal, Textron plans to offer $21 a share for each of Omniquip's roughly 14.7 million shares. Omniquip's shares jumped 57 percent, gaining $7.50, to $20.625, and Textron gained $3.3125 a share, to $84.50. The acquisition, if approved by shareholders and government regulators, would be Textron's 40th since 1992. Textron, formerly a large military contractor, has used acquisitions to become a diversified maker of aircraft, auto parts and industrial goods and a provider of consumer loans.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANGERMAN, BEA
description: LANGERMAN - Bea. Redhead. How lucky we were to be touched by you. Never will you be forgotten. Love always, Herb and Brian

title: MAXTOR TO BUY NETWORK STORAGE COMPANY
description: The Maxtor Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Creative Design Solutions of Santa Clara, Calif., for $57 million in stock to enter the computer network storage market. Creative Design produces storage-management software for small-business and home-computer networking applications, as well as off-site offices for larger corporations. Maxtor makes devices that store data and programs on computers. The shares of Maxtor, based in Milpitas, Calif., were unchanged at $6.375. The purchase was announced after the close of United States trading.

title: Tex Banwell Dies at 80; British Wartime Daredevil
description: Keith Deamer (Tex) Banwell, a British Army World War II escape artist whose many exploits included serving as a double for Field Marshal Montgomery and twice facing a Gestapo firing squad and living to tell about it, died on July 25 in a hospital in North London. He was 80.

title: Blass: An American Original, Seen Only in Silhouette
description: A few years ago, in his office at 550 Seventh Avenue -- amid the book-lined shelves, the bound volumes of Vogue and Harper's Bazaar from the 1950's, the portraits of Diana Vreeland and Marlene Dietrich, the bibelots, the awards and the beat and hum of the midtown traffic -- Bill Blass was at his desk scanning another magazine article about himself.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two men who drowned after their boat capsized in the Hudson River off Manhattan reversed the names of one victim and in some copies misspelled the surname of the other. The first victim was Vilaret Joseph; the second was Lionel Monplaisir, not Monplasier.

title: Another Financial Pinch For Nassau Homeowners
description: Nassau County's new 1 percent property transfer tax cannot be listed as an itemized deduction on Federal income tax returns, contrary to the assumptions of some supporters of the tax and many of those affected by it.

title: Umpires' Walkout Remains Possible
description: With the threat of a strike serving as an undercurrent, the division among umpires along league lines grew wider yesterday. At least 8 of the 13 new umpires the National League has hired have joined the umpires' union, a person close to the union said, but none of the American League's 12 new umpires have applied for membership.

description: FOLLOW this trek.

title: Police Victims of Bombing Fight Clinton's Clemency Plan
description: Officer Rocco Pascarella lost part of his left leg when a bomb planted by Puerto Rican nationalists outside Police Headquarters exploded on New Year's Eve in 1982. Later that night, Detective Richard Pastorella lost five fingers and was left blind after he tried to disarm a bomb across the street; his partner, Detective Anthony Senft, lost an eye.

description: To the Editor:

title: Study Calls for Limits on Hearing Tests at Birth
description: A new study, running counter to the nationwide move toward routinely testing all newborns for hearing problems, argues for testing only those infants known to be at risk.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN G.D.P.
description: The gross domestic product of South Africa grew by an annualized rate of 1.7 percent in the second quarter, more than expected, as the country began to shake off the effects of last year's sharp rise in interest rates. The figure exceeded the mean estimate of growth of seven-tenths of a percent in an informal survey of 10 economists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELOCK, JANET BUCHANAN
description: WHEELOCK-Janet Buchanan. On August 21, 1999, at age 85. Beloved wife of the late Thomas G. Wheelock. Loving mother of Thomas G.B. and Stephen B. Wheelock. Contributions in her memory may be made to Vassar College, Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center, PO Box 23, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

description: ENGLISH-Lillian. The Officers, Board of Trustees, Congregation and Clergy of The Jewish Center of The Hamptons, note with sadness the passing of Lillian English, mother of our devoted member, Roberta Roth. We extend condolences to Roberta and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Donald Zucker, President

title: In the 'Valley of the Mummies,' Revelations of a Golden Past
description: At an oasis 230 miles southwest of Cairo, people in Roman times lived well on the wealth they accumulated making wine from dates and grapes. And in death, their bodies were prepared well for the afterlife, mummified and fitted with elaborate masks and waistcoats covered in gold.

title: Trash Giant Skirts Conditions Set for Bronx Station, Critics Say
description: When one of the nation's biggest garbage companies won a permit in 1997 to build a $25 million waste transfer station in the South Bronx, it agreed to two conditions that were intended to ease the burden on surrounding neighborhoods. But with the station set to open as early as next month, community advocates and some elected officials are criticizing how the company, USA Waste Services of New York City, is living up to the agreement.

description: Planet-Eating Stars

title: It's Root, Root, Root, But for Which Team?
description: The question posed to some of the Mets players before their game against the Astros last night concerned the series the Braves and the Cincinnati Reds were playing in Atlanta: Did the Mets want the Reds to beat the Braves, or would they rather see the Braves beat the Reds? The Mets, after all, are competing with both teams for a playoff spot.

title: Chief Executive Resigns at Silicon Graphics
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. announced late today that its chairman and chief executive, Rick Belluzzo, had resigned after a largely unsuccessful 19-month effort to restore the health of the company, which makes computer work stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, HERBERT
description: GLICK-Herbert. Passed away August 20, 1999. Beloved husband ofSylvia. Dear brother of Bernie and the late Paul. Loving father of Philip and David. Loving grandfather of Emily, Stacey and Gregg. A loving man, a friend to all, he will be deeply missed and always remembered.

title: Official Who Led Inquiry Into China's Reputed Theft of Nuclear Secrets Quits in Protest
description: The Energy Department official who led the initial inquiry into China's suspected theft of United States nuclear secrets resigned today, saying he was protesting roadblocks to his pursuit of the case by Clinton Administration policy makers and other Government officials.

title: Families Would Gain From a Shorter Workweek
description: To the Editor:

title: KOREAN STOCKS RALLY
description: Korea's benchmark stock index staged its biggest rally this month after Moody's Investors Service said it might raise the nation's credit rating, surprising investors who were focused on the breakup of the debt-laden conglomerate Daewoo. Korea's Kospi index surged 39.19 points yesterday, or 4.5 percent, to 917.58, led by Kookmin Bank and other lenders. The Kospi has tumbled 14 percent since Daewoo, Korea's second-largest business group, said on July 19 that it could not meet payments on its $57 billion of debt.
