title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHADEK, ARTHUR J.
description: SHADEK-Arthur J. Franklin & Marshall College mourns the loss of its Trustee Emeritus, former Board Vice Chair, and Honorary Alumnus. Mr. Shadek, husband of Katherine Flint Shadek, and father of F&M Trustee Laurence A. Shadek, Class of 1972, and Katherine Shadek Boyle, Class of 1981, greatly advanced the College through his leadership and the generosity of his family. Franklin & Marshall shares in his family's sense of loss, but we are comforted by knowing that his legacy will endure at the College and among others whose lives he touched. Doreen Boyce, Chair Richard Kneedler, President

title: Giants Give Gragg a Jolt: Competition at Tackle
description: Luke Petitgout was a tackle when the Giants drafted him out of Notre Dame with their first pick in April. The plan was to convert him to a guard, because the Giants thought they needed one.

title: SK TELECOM STAKE IS SOLD
description: The $13 billion Tiger Management L.L.C., a huge hedge fund headed by Julian Robertson, reduced its stake in the SK Telecom Corporation, selling shares to the Korean company's parent a month after increasing its investment and vowing to fight management. Two SK Group units bought shares from Tiger and other investors for $820 million, increasing the company's stake in Korea's biggest mobile phone company to 36.5 percent from 27 percent. Tiger, a major hedge fund, earned a 30 percent return by selling shares it bought last month.

title: President Hits the Golf Course, and the Books
description: Under a cloudless azure sky, President Clinton took to the golf course today, attended a fund-raiser for a local hospital tonight and dined again with friends. But the real news from his vacation compound here was the release of the list of books that the President is delving into.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOWITZ, EVA
description: LEBOWITZ-Eva. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue records with sorrow the death of our esteemed member and extends to her family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLI, LEO
description: CASTELLI-Leo. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art, are deeply saddened by the death of long-time friend and Honorary Trustee, Leo Castelli. His commitment to an extraordinary group of contemporary artists, fostered through his gallery, is legendary and secured his unique place as an art dealer of great vision, taste, and humanity. We will long remember his warmth and generosity, and we offer our profound sympathy to his family. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Old Phone Cables Open Seabed to Science
description: Making use of thousands of miles of discarded telephone cables, scientists have begun to wire remote regions of deep ocean floor to create an undersea network of geological observatories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JELLIFFE, ABBIE ENGLISH
description: JELLIFFE-Abbie English. Of Manchester-by-the-Sea, formerly of Tenafly, N.J. Age 92. Wife of George Clark Jelliffe. Daughter of the late Richard W.A. English Sr., D.V.M. and the late Kate (Burrow) English. Mother and mother-inlaw of Nancy J. and Gregory J. Bruett and Andrew Clark & Sharon Jelliffe. Former mother-in-law of Maureen Walsh Jelliffe. Grandmother of Melissa Ann J. Rees, Philip A. Jelliffe, David Clark and Abbie E. Bruett. Private funeral services will be held for the family at the Murphy Funeral Home, 85 Federal Street, Salem, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Need a Used Spacesuit? Here's Your Chance
description: As they go through the rites of passage into the history books, the old-timers of the early days of space flight have had their reunions for John Glenn's nostalgia trip back into orbit and moments of reflection last month on the 30th anniversary of their greatest triumph, the first Moon landing, in 1969. So the next step was perhaps inevitable: some of their stuff of history is headed for the auction block.

title: Reshaping the Image of the Junior League
description: For at least the last decade, the Junior League has been telling anyone who will listen that it is no longer just a clique of former debutantes putting out cookbooks but a group of professional women who start shelters for drug-addicted mothers and volunteer in the 25th Police Precinct in East Harlem. By and large, that's true. And yet the League, based on its statistical sampling of 193,000 members in 295 chapters in the United States, Mexico, Canada and Britain, is still 96 percent white, 1 percent black and 1 percent Jewish.

title: Stay Busy, Live Longer, Experts Suggest
description: It is well established that exercise helps elderly people live longer.

title: NBC Names Ex-ABC Executive to Head TV Production Unit
description: NBC yesterday named Ted Harbert, the former top entertainment executive at ABC, to be the new president of its in-house television production unit, NBC Studios.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, GERSTEN
description: RAPPAPORT-Gersten. On August 21, Newton, MA. Wife Herma, children Martha, Sam and Naomi; children-in-law Kirk, Kevin and Lauren; grandchildren Joshua, Kendra, Lily, Emily, and Max: We know and keep his love. He gave his gentle spirit and quiet learning to all.

title: Turk Minister Criticizes Government's Response to Quake
description: A Cabinet minister asserted today that the Government's response to last week's earthquake was ''a declaration of bankruptcy for the Turkish political and economic system.''

title: Yankees Throttle Rangers In Possible Playoff Preview
description: This series between the Yankees and the Texas Rangers is being touted as a possible playoff preview. If that's the case, the Rangers might want concede the baseball and challenge the Yankees to checkers.

description: VIDEO SERVICES CORP., Northvale, N.J., a video services provider, hired Lazard Freres & Company L.L.C. to explore a sale of the company, as well as a possible merger or joint venture.

title: Giuliani Talks the Talk Of Candidate For the Senate
description: While continually reminding everyone that he is not, just yet, an official candidate for United States Senate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani looked like one today as he stumped energetically in and around Rochester, visiting a housing complex for families struggling to get off welfare, greeting local Republicans and holding two fund-raisers for his still undeclared campaign.

Services are on Wednesday, at 10 A.M., at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ROSE VOGEL
description: KLEIN-Rose Vogel. On Monday, August 23, 1999 in Rockville, MD. Age 92. A beloved wife, devoted mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Rose was a lovely, lively, generous and beautiful woman. Her late husband Eugene was always so proud of her. Her children Judith and Leon, Harvey & Gloria and Barbara and Mason loved and appreciated her goodness and love of life. Her grandchildren Howard, Elissa, Marla, Jill, Bill, Deven, Terri, Phillip and Melanie and their spouses, as they grew up and married, will never forget the fun-loving, cheerful, energetic Nana of their childhood. Great grandchildren Beryl, Erica, Michael, Jason, Lindsay, Matthew, Jessica, Jared, Allison, Morgan, Zachary, Hayley, Rachel and Tara will remember this terrific lady who loved her family so much. For those whose lives she touched, memories of our Rose recalled over time will be a joy always. Services are to be on Wednesday, August 25th, 10:30 AM, I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York 11550.

title: CLOSING TIME IN PUB BRAWL
description: After months of dueling over a suitor, the shareholders of Allied Domecq P.L.C. accepted a $4.45 billion offer from the privately held Punch Taverns Group Ltd. for the company's 3,500 British pubs. Coupled with other acqusitions, the deal puts Punch Taverns close to overtaking Nomura International P.L.C. as Britain's biggest pub operator. It also frees Allied Domecq, the world's second-largest liquor company and owner of the Baskin-Robbins and Dunkin' Donuts chains, to concentrate on developing core brands, including Ballantine's whisky and Beefeater gin.

title: ESKIMO PIE WEIGHS REDUCED OFFER
description: Eskimo Pie Inc., the dessert marketer, said yesterday that it was considering a bid of $35 million from a private investment group that is lower than a previous bid rejected by Eskimo Pie. The new bid is for $10.125 a share. In December Eskimo Pie rejected an offer of $13 a share, a total of $45 million, from Yogen Fruz World-Wide Inc. Eskimo Pie did not identify the group that made the latest bid but said it invited the company's chief executive, David Kewer, to join it. The company also said its second-largest shareholder, Peak Management Inc., holder of 10.7 percent of the company, supported the lower offer. Eskimo Pie's shares rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $10.0625.

title: New Jersey Finally Gets Rain, But in All the Wrong Places
description: The rain in New Jersey over the weekend fell hardest in the southern part of the state, where it is needed the least, while northern reservoirs remained sorely depleted, officials said.

description: Women, who draw on energy reserves of fat more efficiently than men, frequently outperform men on ultraendurance events like the 85-kilometer marathon. description: Yahoo Inc. said today that it had teamed with Beatnik Inc., Emusic.com and Liquid Audio Inc. to start Yahoo Digital, a new music and video site on the Internet.

title: Wily, Patient Defense Wins First Game of Chess Match
description: In the first game of the International Chess Federation's world championship match on Sunday night, Aleksandr Khalifman defeated Vladimir Akopian in a slow, tense demonstration of ingenious defense.

title: Foie Gras Event Is Killed by Protests
description: Yielding to protests from animal rights organizations and celebrities like Sir John Gielgud and Bea Arthur, the Smithsonian Institution today canceled a panel discussion and tasting of foie gras, the fattened liver of a duck or goose, that had been scheduled for next month.

title: Bond Act Mischief
description: The mass confusion caused by Albany's annual last-minute budget scrambles often provides camouflage for mischievous legislation that nobody notices until well after the deed is done. This year was no exception. The budget passed earlier this month includes subtle changes in the rules governing the disposition of certain money under the 1996 environmental bond act. Environmentalists say the changes are fundamentally at odds with the spirit of the act because they would divert money that was originally aimed at fighting water pollution to economic development. Spokesmen for Joseph Bruno, the Senate majority leader, who inserted the new language, say the changes are minor. Even the most cursory textual analysis suggests that the environmentalists are right.

title: Of the Hills But Also Heavenward
description: Death, imprisonment, lost love, grueling work, hard times -- Doc Watson made them all sound bearable, even cheerful, when he performed on Sunday night at the Damrosch Park Band Shell. His voice was genial and knowing, with a calm stoicism behind his homey North Carolina twang, and his tunes had the comforting symmetry of old-timey tradition. When he sang about a hobo dying alone on a cold train ride, he also yodeled. Mr. Watson, 76, is a one-man archive of songs from the Great Smoky Mountains and beyond, many of them first heard from his family's hand-cranked Victrola.

title: For Jones, No Gold and No Controversies, but a Bronze Medal
description: At first glance, the story of the women's long jump tonight was that Marion Jones did not win it and that a Spaniard named Niurka Montalvo did. title: Bradley Vows He'll Support Racial Unity

title: Corrections
description: A report on Sunday summarizing the New York State Legislature's 222d session misstated the fate of two bills. One allows merchants to use devices that scan driver's licenses to verify the ages of people buying tobacco and alcohol; it passed and awaits the Governor's signature. The other limits the ability of inmates to file lawsuits; it passed and is now law.

title: The Germs Fight Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Diving Deep Into Schoenberg, Festival Stays Eagerly Afloat
description: Most summer music festivals are thoroughly commercial ventures that simply offer audiences more of the tried-and-true programming that can be heard during the regular concert season.

title: Kovel Fuller Wins 3 Assignments
description: Kovel Fuller in Los Angeles has won three new assignments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLUTZNICK, PHILIP
description: KLUTZNICK-Philip. Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the loss of its distinguished past chairman who served his country and community with great distinction. May his family be comforted among mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm I. Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Deutsche and Dresdner Weigh Link That Could Lead to Larger Merger : 2 Big Banks In Germany May Create Retail Giant
description: FRANKFURT  Deutsche Bank AG and Dresdner Bank AG on Monday raised the possibility of a merged German superbank by confirming that they had been talking about combining their basic retail operations.

title: Kosovo Albanians Blocking Russian Troops From a City
description: Hundreds of Albanians with tractors, cars and trucks spread out across a hillside and for a mile along a winding road today, blocking an advance column of Russian peacekeeping troops from moving in to take charge of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAYSEK, HELENE C., DR.
description: WAYSEK-Helene C., Dr. Hofstra University is profoundly saddened by the death of Dr. Helene C. Waysek, Associate Professor of Comparative Literature & Language and Coordinator of the University Honors Program. Dr. Waysek, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Douglass College, received an M.A. and Ph.D. from Columbia University. She was an active member of the Hofstra faculty for 36 years, teaching Latin, Greek and comparative literature and serving as Chair of Comparative Literature & Languages for 16 years. In addition to her duties as coordinator of the University Honors Program she served as secretary of the Hofstra Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. A viewing will be held at the Allwood Funeral Home, 660 Allwood Ave, Clifton, NJ Wednesday, August 25, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. For information call 973-773-6666. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Dr. Helene C. Waysek Memorial Scholarship Fund can be sent to the Development Office, 101 Hofstra University, Hempstead, NY 11549. In tribute to the memory of Dr. Waysek all Hofstra University flags have been lowered to half staff. James M. Shuart, President Helene Fortunoff, Chairperson, Board of Trustees Hofstra University

title: High Clouds, No Storm In Sight
description: One thing an economist should never predict is the future. Ignoring that wisdom, I'll boldly do just that: in February of next year, the current economic expansion will, at 107 months, become the longest in United States history.

title: A Thunderous Encore
description: Mark McGwire often says (and no doubt Sammy Sosa feels the same way) that he would much prefer to be playing for a team with a chance to win the pennant, which he isn't, than to be chasing his own record of 70 home runs, which he is. Still, both he and Sosa, who hit 66 last season, must be deriving some private pleasure from the fact that they are once again lighting up the major leagues with a home run race that may not have quite the electricity of last year's chase but, statistically speaking, is every bit as impressive. By Sunday night, Sosa had 51 homers and McGwire 50. At this rate, both will again exceed Babe Ruth's mark of 60 home runs for a 154-game season and Roger Maris's total of 61 for the modern 162-game season.

title: Not An Idle Question
description: There are some questions worth answering, no matter the consequences. And that is the case in Texas, where George W. Bush, the leading aspirant for the Republican Presidential nomination, has evaded reporters' insistent queries on unsubstantiated rumors that he used cocaine in the distant past. He has employed such circumlocutions as, ''When I was young and irresponsible, I was young and irresponsible.''

title: POP MUSIC IN REVIEW
description: Mozart Effect and Earphones, Parts of a Complex Evening

title: Hoping to regain past glory, a campaign for Brut goes politically incorrect, on purpose.
description: THERE'S a new Brut man, and -- to borrow a phrase from the brand's glory days of the 1970's -- he's a male chauvinist pig.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAROLDA, JOSEPH
description: MAROLDA-Joseph. Beloved husband of Rosemarie. Devoted father of Carmela. Cherished brother of Ralph, Gerard and Antoinette. Reposing at Farnega Bros. Inc., Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-9:30pm. Mass of Christian burial Our Lady of Mount Carmel, 10:15am Wed.

title: Bush Is Wise To Avoid Quagmire
description: To the Editor:

title: Guy Durosier, 68, Haitian Singer and Composer
description: Guy Durosier, a versatile Haitian singer and organist whom Edith Piaf once called ''the living breath of Haiti,'' died on Thursday at his home in Bothell, a suburb of Seattle. He was 68.

title: A Flight of Money
description: To the Editor:

title: Rafter Has Confidence He Can Repeat, Maybe
description: The bat boy left his favorite toys -- scuba gear, golf clubs, even the trusty tennis racquet that helped him win the last two United States Opens -- back home in Bermuda yesterday. Plagued at just the wrong time by chronic tendinitis in his serving shoulder, Patrick Rafter was forced to use his left arm for all his heavy lifting this week.

title: Do More to Aid Nourishment Of Very Young, U.N. Tells Iraq
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan told the Iraqi Government today that it could be doing more to help mothers and children under the program that allows Iraq to export oil to raise money for food, medicine and other essential goods.

title: Danaher to Acquire Atlas Copco Unit
description: The Danaher Corporation, the maker of Sears Craftsman hand tools, said today that it had agreed to buy a unit of the Swedish industrial-machinery maker Atlas Copco A.B. for undisclosed terms as Atlas seeks to concentrate on its core businesses.

title: Kansas Utility Deal Advances
description: Western Resources Inc., the largest electric utility in Kansas, said today that it had reached an agreement with Federal regulators on steps that it must take to win approval of a $3 billion buyout of the Kansas City Power and Light Company.

title: Rail Contractor in Deal
description: The Railworks Corporation, a provider of maintenance and other rail-systems services, said today that it planned to buy the closely held W. T. Byler Company for an undisclosed price to expand its rail-construction business in the Southwest. Byler, based in Houston, is a general contractor that performs maintenance services and construction work, including excavation and asphalt-paving, for railroads, subways, utility companies and other businesses. Last year it had $56 million in revenue.

title: Congress Seeks Wide Sanctions For Drug Trade
description: Congress is close to forcing a major expansion of economic sanctions against international narcotics traffickers and the businesses that work with them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, B. MITCHELL
description: PALMER-B. Mitchell. A member of the California State Bar for 65 years, died August 21, at the age of 90. He is survived by his loving wife, Helen, to whom he had been married 60 years; his devoted children, Mark Palmer of Beverly Hills and Stephanie Palmer McClelland, and son-in-law W. Carter McClelland of New York City; cherished grandchildren, Jennifer (Sam Gall) Palmer, Cary Palmer McClelland and William Spencer McClelland; caring niece Carole Gonzales; dear sister-in-law Rita Corwin, and her children, Leni and Miles and daughter-in-law, Diane. Mitch graduated from UC Berkeley and Hastings College of Law in 1933. He practiced law in San Francisco and then was a hearing commissioner for the OPA during World War II. After the war, Mitch and his family moved to Beverly Hills, and he was in hotel business for some years. For the next 22 years, he was a legal officer for the Small Business Administration, until his retirement in 1983. He was a member of many civic and philanthropic organizations. Services are private. Contributions can be made to the ACLU, Hastings College of Law or the American Heart Association.

title: Accounts
description: * Stockgroup.com, Vancouver, British Columbia, and Adatom.com, Milpitas, Calif., to Rocket Science Creative Ltd., New York, to handle the first accounts of the on-line financial news site and the Web-based furniture retailer. Billings were estimated at $1.5 million over six months for Stockgroup.com and $1 million over four months for Adatom.com.

title: ALCOA TO BUY ACX TECHNOLOGIES ROLLING UNIT
description: Alcoa Inc., the world's top aluminum maker, agreed yesterday to buy the aluminum-rolling unit of ACX Technologies Inc., a ceramics and consumer-products packaging maker, for $41 million in cash. ACX's Golden Aluminum Company employs about 200 people at plants in Fort Lupton, Colo., and San Antonio. Last week, Alcoa won a brief bidding contest to acquire the Reynolds Metals Company.

title: Inside Medical Journals, A Rising Quest for Profits
description: A generation ago, leading medical journals measured their profits in the tens of thousands of dollars. They were scholarly publications meant to help doctors keep abreast of scientific advances and share information on new remedies.

title: Debating Cassini
description: To the Editor:

title: In England, Everything Is Cricket  and Everything Is Simply Dreadful
description: LONDON  Conjuring up his idealized image of England, former Prime Minister John Major once wrote of a land of warm beer, dog-lovers and "long shadows on county cricket grounds."

title: PSINET AGREES TO BUY DATA SERVICE PROVIDER
description: Psinet Inc., which provides Internet access for businesses, agreed yesterday to buy Transaction Network Services Inc. for $720 million in cash and stock so it could offer electronic-commerce services. Psinet will pay $22.50 in cash, or about $351 million, and half a share for each Transaction Network share. That is about $45 a share. Transaction Network Services shareholders can choose to receive stock, cash or both. Transaction Network provides high-speed data services for credit card and automatic teller machine transactions, and its number of Internet transactions has risen 20 percent a month this year. The shares of Transaction Network, based in Reston, Va., surged 25 percent yesterday, gaining $9 each, to $43.25, after jumping more than $6 a share on Friday. Psinet rose 31.25 cents, to $45.875.

title: Lessons From Wasps
description: To the Editor:

title: From Homeless to House-Proud: Brazil's 'Other' Music
description: It was logical and fitting that when the Sao Paulo State Symphony Orchestra inaugurated its striking new concert hall here in July, the centerpiece of the debut program was Mahler's Second Symphony. That work, after all, is known as the ''Resurrection,'' and both the Sala Sao Paulo and the orchestra that now resides there were celebrating a rise from the ashes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUSTADTER, MORTON
description: NEUSTADTER-Morton. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Stanley, Michael and Amy. Brother of Ruth and the late Arnold and Mimi. Loving grandfather and uncle. Former President of Acme Folding Box Corp. Services 1:30PM Tuesday at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Intel Reduces Prices on Pentium III Chips
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's No. 1 maker of computer chips, cut prices on its flagship Pentium III chips by as much as 41 percent to spur holiday-season demand and take sales from a rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENKS, ELISABETH R., M.D.
description: JENKS-Elisabeth R., M.D. Died of cancer at Calvary Hospital, Bronx, August 12. Born 1929, Cambridge, Mass. Attended Concord Academy, Swarthmore College, and Albert Einstein School of Medicine. Practiced psychiatry and was on the staff of Gouverneur Hospital. Wife of the late Emery I. Valyi of Katonah, NY. She leaves a sister, Anne L. Jenks, Cambridge. Funeral service at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue at East 80th Street, August 26 at 4PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Nature Conservancy, Arlington, VA. or the National Audubon Society, New York NY.

title: Viacom Said to Be Pursuing a Stake in Kirch
description: Viacom Inc., the big media company, is in talks to buy a stake in the Kirch Group of Germany, according to Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia.

title: Outreach in the Aftermath
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Few States Are Using Settlements In Tobacco Suit to Cut Smoking
description: Despite overwhelming evidence that anti-tobacco campaigns reduce smoking, most states are in danger of wasting an opportunity to fight death and disease with money from the tobacco industry, Federal health officials said today.

title: Political Briefing; Voters Seem Inclined To Forgive and Forget
description: Whether or not Gov. George W. Bush of Texas used drugs may still be good grist for the media mill. But evidence is building that the American public is not overly concerned about the issue and would be inclined to forgive Mr. Bush if it turns out, to use his phrase, that when he was young and irresponsible, he was young and irresponsible, and tried a snort or two of cocaine.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the yen after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to keep inflation in check in the United States. In New York, the dollar settled at 110.80 yen, down from 111.44 on Monday.

title: He Writes, She Shoots, and the Beats Howl
description: WE all have our issues, those little things that set us off, and it's kind of sweet, as John Tytell and his wife, Mellon, have just written a book on the Beat movement, that theirs is the term ''middle class.''

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Madison Avenue Creates Stark Ad About Battering
description: You can see people staring up at them on the subway, finding it hard to look away from those images of women's battered faces and the numbers illustrating a chilling statistic: ''Every 12 seconds, another woman is beaten by her husband or boyfriend.''

title: Circuit City Stores Picks Omnicom Unit
description: Circuit City Stores, the computer electronics and appliances retailer in Richmond, has named TBWA/Chiat/ Day in New York, part of the TBWA worldwide unit of Omnicom Group, to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $60 million to $75 million.

title: Eagle Keeps Esposito In Hunt
description: Frank Esposito Jr. of Shackamaxon Golf and Country Club executed the best shot in the opening round of the 84th Met Open yesterday in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., leading to an eagle that put him two strokes off the lead in the $100,000 tournament at the Tuxedo Club.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, RICHARD L.
description: ROSENTHAL-Richard L. Happy birthday, RLR. One year, two months and twelve days have taught us so much. We have learned so well to appreciate what you have made possible. Love always, HG

title: Fashion Magazine Industry Consolidates With a Big Deal
description: The fashion magazine world consolidated yesterday with the agreement to sell Fairchild Publications Inc. to Advance Publications, the parent company of Conde Nast. Advance will now be the publisher not just of its current stable of Vogue, Vanity Fair and Mademoiselle, but also of Women's Wear Daily, W and Jane.

title: A Handy Gadget Whose Time Is Ripening
description: CUTTING the core out of a tomato is one of the more tedious kitchen tasks, so I was intrigued by the claim made on the package of the Tomato Core-It, which said the tool could ''bite'' the core out. While this seemed a fairly vicious act to perform on the soft, supple tomato, I had to give the Core-It a try.

title: Accounts
description: * Kunzler & Co., Lancaster, Pa., to Kelly Michener Advertising, Lancaster, to handle the account of the meat processing company, which had been at Hull & Schultz, Lancaster. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTCHULER, FLORENCE
description: ALTCHULER-Florence. On August 23, 1999 at the age of 94. Beloved wife of the late Leo Altchuler. Devoted mother of Murray and Fran, and Rita Clark. Loving grandmother of Steven & Debra, Fran and Marvin Schwartz, Michael Abbott and adoring great grandmother of Matthew, David, Joshua, Amy, Samuel & Franklin. Graveside services Wednesday, August 25 at 1 PM, at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, N.J.

title: The Ciprianis Are Accused Of Sex Bias In Hiring
description: The New York Attorney General filed suit yesterday against the Cipriani restaurant family, accusing it of sexual discrimination by hiring only men as waiters, barring women from jobs that can pay as much as $90,000 a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ROBIN
description: WEISS-Robin. A woman of valor, deeply loved. We will miss Robin with all our hearts. Barbara and Arthur Weiss

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING TO ACQUIRE STORK ENGINEERING UNIT
description: Jacobs Engineering Group, the sixth-largest United States construction and engineering company, agreed to buy the engineering unit of Stork N.V. of the Netherlands for an undisclosed price, to expand into northern Europe. Stork Engineering Group operates mainly in the northern European nations of the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium as well as Southeast Asia. Jacobs, based in Pasadena, Calif., currently operates in southern Europe as well as North and South America, Britain and Ireland, and India. Stork is a Dutch industrial-machinery components maker and services company.

title: Atlantic City Casinos See 2d Suicide in 2 Weeks
description: The second suicide at a casino in two weeks occurred on Monday night when a part-time dealer at Caesar's Atlantic City Hotel Casino leaped from an upper tier of the casino's parking garage, the police said.

title: Knee Injury To Scott Has Giants Juggling
description: On Sunday, the rookie Luke Petitgout was a guard. On Monday, he was a tackle. This morning Petitgout was still a tackle. This afternoon he was back to guard.

title: U.S. Says Iraqis Were Killed By Their Own Artillery Fire
description: Intensifying the war of words over civilian bombing casualties in Iraq, the Pentagon said today that Iraq's own antiaircraft artillery, not American fighter jets, killed two people during a clash in northern Iraq on Monday.

title: Decade Later, Grief Returns Over Yusuf Hawkins
description: Moses Stewart, tall, trim and dressed impeccably for a day of grieving, marched once more in Bensonhurst yesterday, and once more the memory of a murdered son and white racists drove him to despondency and incoherence and rage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUSK, PHILIP
description: SOUSK-Philip. Of Queens. Died August 22. Survived by his wife Ethel, son Stephen, granddaughter Jenny and sister Jean. Funeral services will be held at Mt. Moriah Cemetery in Fairview, New Jersey at 12:30pm on August 26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVEY, WILLIAM
description: DAVEY-William, son of renowned American painter Randall Davey of Santa Fe and Florence McCormick of New York was a brilliant poet and writer, as well as a high-goal polo player and amateur astronomer. Presently Foreign Language Editor of The Long Story, his poems and stories have been published and translated world-wide. Always charmingly witty, he was educated at NYU, UC/Berkeley and the Sorbonne. In WW II he was a Combat Officer with Canadian-American Special Forces. He strove for perfection in literature and at 86 was preparing Bitter Rainbow for publication in Italy, translating previously published The Trial of Pythagoras into Greek for printing in Athens, and completing his life-long novel Splendor from Darkness. He and his wife Susan live near Keene, Virginia. The title of his first novel Dawn Breaks the Heart conveys the feeling of all who knew him.

title: Norman Wexler, 73, Writer Of 'Saturday Night Fever'
description: Norman Wexler, a playwright and screenwriter whose credits included the scripts for ''Saturday Night Fever'' and ''Serpico,'' died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 73.

title: INSIDE
description: Bank Inquiry Intensifying

title: Nigerian Writer Returns After a 9-Year Absence
description: The Nigerian author, Chinua Achebe, whose 1958 novel ''Things Fall Apart'' has become one of the most popular works of African fiction in the West, returned here Monday night after a nine-year absence.

title: Ford's Labor Relations Are on Edge as G.M.'s Relax
description: After 13 years without a strike, the Ford Motor Company is facing labor troubles in the United States and Canada even as labor relations at the General Motors Corporation are finally starting to improve after 19 strikes over the last five years, union officials and auto executives say.

title: The Family Dinner, Alive and Well
description: Dan Quayle and Al Gore found something to agree on recently a concern about family dinners.

title: Nordstrom Going on Line
description: Nordstrom Inc., the apparel and shoe retailer, announced today that it would create Nordstrom.com as an Internet and catalogue unit. Nordstrom said it would be the principal owner of the new unit, contributing all of the assets and liabilities associated with its current catalogue business and Internet activities, as well as $10 million in cash. Benchmark Capital and Madrona Investment Group will participate as minority owners, with Benchmark investing $15 million and Madrona investing $1 million.

title: Open Positions of Short Sales on Nasdaq Rise 1%
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose 1 percent in the most recent monthly period, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, said yesterday.

title: Kosovo Albanians Barring Russians From City Stand Firm
description: Negotiations between peacekeeping commanders and local Kosovo Albanians failed today to end the blockade around the town of Orahovac that is preventing Russian peacekeepers from moving into the area.

title: Border-Hopping Music With a Mestizo Soul
description: Three guitars clanked and ratcheted and lurched into syncopated locomotion when Los Lobos played ''Everybody Loves a Train'' to start their set at the Bowery Ballroom. Built on a venerable blues image and shuffle beat, the song turned down-home Americana into a jubilant surge of rhythm and noise.

title: Donald E. Johnson, 75, Dies; Led Veterans Administration
description: Donald E. Johnson, who headed the Veterans Administration under President Richard M. Nixon but resigned under pressure from Congress and veterans' groups, died on Aug. 10 at a hospital in Fredericksburg, Va., where he lived. He was 75.

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC TO BUY EVANS FOREST PRODUCTS
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Evans Forest Products Ltd., a Canadian maker of engineered wood and lumber, for $90 million. The purchase will expand the ability of Louisiana-Pacific to make engineered wood and lumber, which is gaining wide acceptance in the building industry as a substitute for real lumber. Privately held Evans, based in southeastern British Columbia, makes laminated veneer lumber and plywood as well as western red cedar products. The deal includes two forest licenses and a tree-farm license that will provide access to about 21 million cubic feet of wood a year.

title: French Oil Company Seeks Respite From Bidding Wars
description: Under criticism from at least some of his institutional investors, the chairman of Elf Aquitaine S.A. pleaded today for a peaceful deal in the takeover battle with the French-Belgian oil company Total Fina S.A.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., the No. 1 computer maker, said it had won a $235 million contract to run the computer network of Japan's third-largest casualty insurer by assets, Mitsui Marine and Fire Insurance.

title: Survival of the Fittest, in Hollywood and the Heartland
description: Americans accustomed to getting their information on contentious public issues from Broadway and Hollywood were probably startled to learn that, in Kansas at least, creationism was still alive and kicking. The many people who have been influenced by ''Inherit the Wind'' in its various treatments must have long since been left with the impression that William Jennings Bryan, that incarnation of fundamentalism, had been thoroughly bested by Clarence Darrow, champion of scientifically certified free speech.

title: Schools Rank First As Spending Priority
description: Citizen support for education spending has risen over 25 years, to rank first on a list of national spending priorities, according to the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago.

title: Woman Rests in Hospital After Refusing Carjacker
description: An 81-year-old woman who refused to give her car to a carjacker on Sunday was recovering yesterday from a mild heart attack that she suffered after the incident.

title: Political Briefing; In Rhode Island, A Decision to Tell All
description: Some political experts say that the ABC and CNN/Time poll results indicate that the American public may be growing more tolerant of wrongdoing by public figures, in part because so much wrongdoing has been in the news in recent years, especially Presidential wrongdoing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, CHAIM
description: DIAMOND-Chaim. On August 24, 1999. A truly unique individual who touched everyone he met in a very special way. Blessed with a brilliant mind, great love of Judiasm and old world charm, he will forever be missed by his loving family and friends. Funeral service today, 12 Noon at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 St, N.Y.

title: Miscellany
description: * Robert Solomon, who had been president for direct and interactive marketing at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, part of the Interpublic Group, opened Solomon Strategic, New York, an advertising consulting company.

title: Not Quite Talk of the Town: Giants Set for Jets Saturday
description: The Giants have done little to put special significance on their preseason meeting Saturday with the Jets. With starting jobs on the line and key players returning from injury, mythical territorial struggles hardly raise the stakes in the preseason.

title: An Antic Thread Dangles Slyly From the Fringe
description: Clare Byrne opened the dance segment of the New York International Fringe Festival with works that were not just suitably odd but profoundly nutty. A small, deft dancer with a suspiciously earnest face, Ms. Byrne is innately comical. And her choreography, performed on Saturday afternoon at the Soundance studio theater, is just as subversive.

title: Group to Re-examine Tax on Auction Sales
description: Reacting to criticism from the breeders and buyers of race horses, the National Thoroughbred Racing Association has announced that it will re-examine the way it raises money, specifically the 1 per cent tax imposed on the buyers of horses at auction sales.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Old Chatham Inn Closes

title: Treatment Plan Is Sought After Inmates Are Freed
description: A class action lawsuit filed yesterday on behalf of mentally ill inmates in city jails charges that the city and its medical provider on Rikers Island routinely release patients who have received mental treatment behind bars without making any provision for continuing their mental health care and medication in the community.

title: In Turkey, Disaster After Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Used Vagaries of PAC Laws for Presidential Hopes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's two political action committees, one in New York and another in Virginia, were established in January to promote what he called a ''positive message of change'' by helping like-minded Republicans win office around the country.

title: Overtime Policy Earns Date With Law for Justice Dept.
description: Workers for a large and well-known employer in the nation's capital have accused their bosses of juggling the books to cheat them out of overtime pay in violation of the law and then lying about to it to conceal the illegality. Sounds like a case for the Justice Department, except in this instance the employer is the Justice Department, the agency charged with enforcing the law.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Dwight Yoakam Looks Back, Then Peeks at the Future
description: Dwight Yoakam's sound, as he sculptures it with his guitarist and producer Pete Anderson, is big: loud, authoritative and armored. There were times during his show at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Saturday night when four guitars in his seven-piece band were playing at the same time, plugging up all the possible holes in the music. The sound has old-fashioned roughnesses that give it taste, like the scraping of Scott Joss's fiddle and his mountain tenor vocal harmonies and like Mr. Anderson's spiny guitar solos, which lashed out of the mix as if he were ripping duct tape off his strings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, ROBERT
description: McDONALD - Robert. The Gramercy Park Block Association is profoundly saddened by the death on August 24, 1999 of Robert McDonald, our Vice President and Director and a founding member. Bob was devoted to his loving wife, Sperella, and was a wonderful friend and a caring neighbor. Bob's extraordinary contributions to the Gramercy Park community have enriched the lives of countless individuals. We are enormously grateful to have known Bob, and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Bob will remain close to our hearts, and will be deeply missed for all time. The Board of Directors of the Gramercy Park Block Association, Arlene Harrison, President

title: The 'Do It Yourself' Winery
description: Route 29 is the Yellow Brick Road of California wine. Between the city of Napa and the town of Calistoga, about 20 miles to the north, 29 is a display of some of the world's most beautiful and prosperous wineries. From May to October, the road is packed with tourists come to gape at these temples of the good life, with their manicured vineyards and welcoming tasting rooms.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FALLS. Crude oil prices dropped after Germany said it would sell about 32 million barrels from its reserves over the next year. In New York, crude oil for October delivery fell 37 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $21.47 a barrel.

title: Murder Suspect Who Fled U.S. Agrees to Plea Bargain in Israel
description: A Maryland teen-ager who was the subject of a long extradition battle between the United States and Israel has agreed to plead guilty in the murder of another Maryland youth and to accept a 24-year prison sentence in Israel, state prosecutors in Maryland announced today.

title: Police Focus on Jewelry In Killing Suspect's Home
description: Investigators are trying to determine whether several pieces of jewelry they took from the house of Robert Zarinsky, a Linden, N.J., man suspected of killing at least four teen-age girls, are linked to those deaths.

title: Two Firms Plan to Offer Late Trading
description: Two more on-line brokerage firms have struck an agreement to offer customers after-hours stock trades, beginning this evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWACH, WALLACE
description: ROSENWACH-Wallace. On August 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Alice, loving father of Andrew, Barbara and her husband Greg, adoring grandfather of Alissa and Henry. Devoted brother of Ruth Sabowitz, Janet Neiderbach and the late Felix Rosenwach. His deep devotion to family and friends was paralleled by his many civic contributions. He served with great enthusiasm for years as ''Principal For A Day''. Active member of numerous civic organizations including The New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, The Executive Association of Greater New York, The Long Island City Business Development Corporation, The Hundred Year Association of New York, Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, The New York Friars Club, NYC District Council of Carpenters, Local 135, ABO and BOMA. Proud Graduate of NYU School of Engineering and Harvard Business School, Small Business Program. His vision, energy and industry left his mark on the skyline of the city he so loved. His honesty, humor and spirit genuinely touched all who knew him. He will be forever missed and always remembered. Services are to be on Friday, August 27, 11:00 AM, Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

title: Sports of The Times; Normalcy Seems Great To Dierker
description: LARRY DIERKER cannot remember the bad parts -- collapsing in the dugout, the game suspended, the Astros huddling in public prayer, the television cameras capturing all of it.

title: SURGE COMPONENTS DROPS PLAN TO BUY ORBIT NETWORKS
description: Surge Components Inc., a maker of electronic products, said yesterday that it had canceled plans to buy the closely held Orbit Networks Inc., saying Orbit could not meet the terms of their earlier agreement. The transaction was valued about $66 million when it was announced in late December. Orbit, based in Novato, Calif., connects consumers with travel suppliers using the Internet and other networks. Surge also sells electronic products on the Internet. Surge, based in Deer Park, N.Y., said in December that it would buy Orbit for 25 million shares. Shares of Surge closed yesterday at $1.03125.

title: Ferry to Link Manhattan With Monmouth County
description: A new ferry route will link the Belford section of Middletown in Monmouth County, on Raritan Bay, to stops at the World Financial Center, West 38th Street and a pier on the lower East Side at Wall Street, officials said yesterday.

title: With No Surprises, the Markets Show Restraint
description: Financial markets got what many investors interpreted as an all-clear signal from the Federal Reserve yesterday, as the central bank indicated that its latest quarter-point rate increase would be enough to slow economic growth and keep inflation in check. But the reaction was subdued in the stock and bond markets because many had anticipated the Fed's announcement.

title: Councilman Says Organizers Of March Threatened Him
description: Councilman Bill Perkins said yesterday that he was harassed and threatened late Monday night by a group of men who he said were acting on the orders of the organizers of the so-called Million Youth March.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Raises Interest Rates To Help Avert Inflation

title: Newspapers Ask F.C.C. to Suspend Rule
description: A newspaper industry group petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to suspend a 25-year-old ban on newspaper ownership of radio and television stations in the same market.

title: Jack B. Jackson, 83, Ex-Chief at Penney
description: Jack B. Jackson, a former chief executive of the J. C. Penney Company, the retailer, died on Aug. 12 in Dallas, the company announced. He was 83.

title: Skillful, Ferocious and a Bit Wacky
description: It is difficult to miss Sasa Curcic on the soccer field. He is swift, crafty and maintains possession of the soccer ball with such arrogance that he irritates opponents.

title: Walsh Shoots a 69 For a 3-Stroke Lead
description: Ann Walsh shot a three-under-par 69 and took a three-stroke opening-round lead in the Cadillac Women's Met Open at the Spring Brook Country Club in Morristown, N.J.

title: AIRBUS GETS LANCHILE ORDER
description: The European consortium Airbus Industrie scored a victory over its rival, Boeing, when the largest carrier in Chile, LanChile S.A., placed orders for seven long-range Airbus A340-300 aircraft, and took options on seven more. The book price of all 14 aircraft is $1.8 billion, though airlines rarely pay the full price. The four-engine Airbus A340-300 competes directly with Boeing's 777. The order from LanChile was considered especially good news by Airbus, which was hurt in June when Singapore Airlines, a major Airbus customer that was among the first carriers to fly the A340, announced it was phasing out the aircraft in favor of Boeing's 777.

title: L. Ehrenkratz, 65, A Stockbroker And Commentator
description: Louis Ehrenkrantz, who started as a high school English teacher and became a prominent stockbroker and Wall Street commentator, died on Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 65.

title: Private Funding Propels Bangkok's New Sky Train
description: BANGKOK  After decades of debate, delay and broken promises, Bangkok will soon offer commuters an alternative to its traffic-clogged streets. Beginning in November, Sky Train  a privately funded mass-transit railway  begins whisking travelers along 23.5 kilometers (14.5 miles) of track high above the congestion and its syrupy brown pollution.

title: Computer Executive to Run Microsoft Internet Unit
description: Microsoft has selected Richard E. Belluzzo, a longtime computer industry executive, to head its Internet operations, signaling that its future lies more in electronic commerce than in becoming a media company.

title: FED, AS EXPECTED, RAISES KEY RATES BY QUARTER-POINT
description: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates today by a quarter of a percentage point, the second increase in less than two months, saying the action should help avert inflation while allowing the nation's long economic expansion to continue.

title: Why Should Europe Follow Our Lead?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHEF; A Fitting End for Summer's Vivid Fruit
description: THIS is the time of year for straightforward tomato dishes, ones that take advantage of the fantastic spectrum making its way to farm stands and produce markets in the next few weeks.

title: Unabomber Writes Story For Magazine at SUNY
description: Theodore Kaczynski, the man known as the Unabomber, has written a parable for a magazine published by students at the State University of New York at Binghamton. The story, titled ''Ship of Fools,'' was written at the request of Tim LaPietra, a 21-year-old senior and publisher of ''Off!'' magazine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, MINDY
description: GREENBAUM-Mindy. The Auxiliary notes with sorrow the passing of our good friend and volunteer, Mindy Greenbaum, and extends sincere condolences to her family. Andrea Weiss, Pres., Auxiliary North Shore University Hospital

title: Harold Ehrlich, 97, Backer of Kindergarten
description: Harold Brown Ehrlich, a former Republican Assemblyman from upstate New York whose persistence made kindergarten a fixture in New York public schools of the 1940's, died Aug. 11 at his retirement home in Laguna Hills, Calif. He was 97.

Her inner strength and commitment to the community at large is an inspiration to us all. May Hashem comfort Rabbi Polakoff, Ephraim, Yosef, Ilana, Yehudah, Ariella and the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rambam Mesivta Lawrence, NY

title: PROFIT WEAKENS AT MATSUSHITA
description: For the seventh consecutive quarter, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan reported a decline in profit. Matsushita, the the world's largest consumer electronics maker, said the weakness in the April-June period was attributable to low domestic sales, falling demand overseas, price competition and a stronger yen, which hurts the profits of exporters by making their goods more expensive abroad. The company, which makes Panasonic, National and Technics brands, said earnings fell 14 percent, to 9.6 billion yen ($85.3 million), compared with 11.1 billion yen in the period a year earlier.

title: CITADEL COMMUNICATIONS IN ACCORD TO BUY CARIBOU
description: The Citadel Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Caribou Communications Company, owner of five radio stations in Oklahoma City, for $60 million. Citadel Communications, based in Las Vegas, Nev., said it would add the 5 Caribou stations to its portfolio of 124 stations. The deal is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission. Citadel Communications had revenue of $75.1 million for the six months ended June 30. Caribou is based in Denver.

description: GILBERT-George. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Devoted father of Roni & Lona. Dear grandfather of Alan, & loving brother of Beatrice Sopenoff. Memorial service Sunday, August 29, 5:45 PM, Riverside, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to charity of choice.

description: MINUSE-Jean Fairservis. December 26, 1911-August 25, 1998. We used to talk about these notices and wonder if the dead could see them. Now you know.

title: 1,810 Artists Seek Grants From a New Foundation
description: To judge by the experience of a new cultural support foundation, many of the nation's artists are clamoring for financial aid even in these prosperous times.

title: One Airline May Survive Canada Deal
description: In a move that could leave Canada with only one major airline, a Canadian conglomerate, with the help of American Airlines' parent company, offered $3.8 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt yesterday to buy Air Canada and merge it with the rival Canadian Airlines.

title: A Captain Among His Peers
description: The boos lingered in central Pennsylvania all the way into winter and echoed in an arena where quarterback Kevin Thompson was not even a combatant. It was late January, halftime of the Penn State-Indiana basketball game, and some football players were on hand to accept gratitude before the home crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, GABRIEL
description: BRAVERMAN-Gabriel. Age 91. On August 24, 1999 in Philadelphia, PA. Violist with the Philadelphia Orchestra for 35 years. Survived by his wife Shirley, sister Bella Bookbinder, daughters and sonsin-law Bonny and Robert Israeloff, Stephanie and Michael Applebaum, four grandchildren and four great grandchildren. He will be sorely missed.

title: Cruise Liner and Cargo Vessel Collide in Channel
description: A passenger cruise liner and a cargo ship collided in the English Channel early Tuesday, slightly injuring several people on the liner, touching off a fire on the cargo ship and raising fundamental questions about shipping and safety in one of the world's busiest areas of the sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORDWAY, ANNA
description: ORDWAY-Anna. A long time shareholder of 155 East 72nd Street, she will be missed by all. The Board of Directors 155 East 72nd Street Corp Jeb Embree, President

title: Ode to a Southern Grandmother (Gravy, Greens and All)
description: ONE of my favorite places in Harlem used to be Wilson's restaurant and bakery, at 158th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. I'd go there early on Sunday mornings, trying to beat the after-church crowd, and order salmon croquettes, served with eggs, grits and biscuits. At the pace of a Southern drawl, the food would arrive, swimming in butter, the football-shape croquettes crisp yet moist, flavored with onions and parsley, blending perfectly with the grits and eggs (and butter). To finish, I'd have a piece of sweet potato pie or even sweeter peach cobbler.

Devoted twin of the late Michelle Bouvier Putnam. Memorial service at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street, New York City, Thursday, August 26 at 11 AM. Interment private at Woodlawn cemtery. title: Giuliani Praises Huge Tax Cut That G.O.P. Passed and Mrs. Clinton Scorns
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani offered strong praise yesterday for the $792 billion Republican tax cut passed by Congress this summer, saying it would be ''great'' if the plan became law. With his remarks, Mr. Giuliani drew a clear distinction on what could be a central issue in a race against Hillary Rodham Clinton for United States Senator.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Arts pages yesterday about the aging of the cultural audience in the Berkshire region of Massachussetts misidentified an environmental group whose president, George Wislocki, commented on the phenomenon. It is the Berkshire Natural Resources Council, not the Berkshires National Resources Defense Council.

title: Laredo Spared As Spent Storm Goes to Mexico
description: The remnants of Hurricane Bret moved into northern Mexico today after officials in the Texas border town of Laredo blamed heavy rainfall from the storm for a traffic accident in which four people were killed on Monday.

title: KOREAN INDEBTEDNESS STILL HIGH
description: South Korea's 30 largest conglomerates will need more than $21 billion to lower their indebtedness to acceptable levels by the end of this year, the Korea Stock Exchange said. Under South Korea's agreement with the International Monetary Fund, the large conglomerates are required to lower their debt-to-equity ratios to below 200 percent. As of June 30, the average ratio was nearly 235 percent. Excessive corporate debt is considered an important reason for the financial crisis that enveloped South Korea at the end of 1997, which led to an I.M.F.-sponsored bailout.

title: Northport Journal; The Very Determined Meet the Dearly Departed
description: By Ernest Van Den Bossche's count, 18,000 guests have visited his Temple Heights Spiritual Camp this summer. The lodge is empty and the parking lot barren, however, because most of the guests are dead.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY TO CUT 1,600 JOBS IN SINGAPORE
description: Seagate Technology Inc., the world's largest independent maker of computer disk drives, said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,600 jobs in Singapore as it cuts costs to become more competitive. The dismissals will occur at four Seagate plants in Singapore. The company has about 66,000 workers at its Asia operations, which include China, Malaysia and Thailand. Seagate's job cuts come as disk drive makers are battling to keep or expand market share. Earlier this month, a rival, the Western Digital Corporation, the world's No. 3 disk drive maker, said it would cut 2,500 jobs, or 60 percent of its Singapore work force, as it moves manufacturing to neighboring Malaysia to trim costs.

title: Evolution Struggle Shifts To Kansas School Districts
description: Sitting at their students' desks two days before the start of the new school year, four high school biology teachers here were hashing over the vote of the Kansas Board of Education earlier this month: to delete virtually any mention of evolution from the state's recommended science curriculum and its standardized tests.

title: Cleveland Voucher Program Is Blocked at Start of School
description: One day before the start of the school year in Cleveland, a Federal judge issued an injunction today blocking the city's four-year-old voucher program, preventing several thousand children from attending private and parochial schools at taxpayer expense.

title: Belgian Says Serbs Used Gas on Kosovars
description: A Belgian scientist is reported to have found evidence that Yugoslavia used chemical weapons on ethnic Albanian fighters and civilians in Kosovo during the months of the NATO bombing and before peacekeepers arrived.

title: WILLIS STEIN TO BUY AAVID THERMAL AND A BOWTHORPE UNIT
description: Aavid Thermal Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Willis Stein & Partners, a closely held investment firm, for $260 million in cash. Aavid, a maker of devices that keep computer chips from overheating, also agreed to buy the thermal management unit of Bowthorpe P.L.C. for $79.5 million in cash. Chicago-based Willis Stein will pay $25.50 a share for Aavid. Willis Stein will pay $24.50 a share if the acquisition of the Bowthorpe unit does not close. The shares of Aavid, based in Concord, N.H., rose $3.3125, to $23.0625. Willis Stein manages about $1 billion of equity capital.

title: Jets Strong and Deep at Receiver
description: As each day of training camp goes by, as Keyshawn Johnson and Wayne Chrebet and Dedric Ward make Jets fans ooh and ah with tumbling catches and ballet leaps, the wide-receiving corps is becoming the most dangerous part of the offense.

title: Exotic but Accessible, Coconut Milk Earns Its Shelf Space
description: THE time has come to give coconut milk a permanent place in your pantry. One of the keys to the flavors of Southeast Asia, India and much of the Caribbean, this no-frills liquid could hardly be easier to use: just open and pour. Like canned tomatoes, it is the foundation of some essential dishes. Like canned chicken stock, it can turn a dry dish into a pleasantly saucy one in about two minutes. Like both, its usefulness and versatility transcend the stigma of canned food.

description: Bertelsmann A.G., Europe's largest media company, has sold 7.2 million shares of America Online Inc. in order to raise money to finance the expansion of its own multimedia businesses.

title: Corrections

When he announced the charges, John Kaye, the Monmouth County Prosecutor, did not provide details of the acts cited. He now says that they were not sodomy, but he declined to elaborate.

title: Congo Rebels Take Big Step To Reviving Peace Plan
description: The Congo peace negotiations took a major step forward today when two rival rebel factions agreed to sign a cease-fire document already approved by other combatants in the yearlong civil war.

title: U.S. to Allow Inmate to Finish Term in Italy
description: The Justice Department agreed yesterday to allow a woman convicted of racketeering and conspiracy in a 1981 triple murder and armored car robbery to be transferred to Italy to serve the remaining nine years of her sentence.

description: The record high temperatures that blistered much of the East this summer have produced the most severe air pollution of the decade and worsened a long-simmering dispute about how to solve the problem of ground-level ozone.

title: Martinez's 3-Run Shot Spurs Yanks to Victory
description: Many of the Yankees wore expressions of regret after Monday night's game against the Texas Rangers, shrugging smiles. Tino Martinez had four hits and grimaced like a 10-year-old who plugged his big brother in the face with a snowball. Hey, sorry about that.

title: NORTEL NETWORKS TO BUY PERIPHONICS
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Periphonics Corporation, a maker of telephone-processing and call-center systems, for about $436 million in stock. Nortel Networks, a Canadian communications equipment maker, said the purchase was part of its strategy to create technology that combines phone and Internet services. The deal values Periphonics at $29.23 a share. The stock was up $2.50 at $27.75, in Nasdaq trading. Periphonics, which has more than 900 employees in the Americas, Europe and Asia, will become a unit of Nortel and continue to be based in Bohemia, N.Y. Nortel, based in Brampton, Ontario, said the purchase was expected to improve earnings slightly in 2000, excluding one-time acquisition costs.

title: After Marathon First Game, Chess Rivals Quickly Draw
description: The day after their nearly six-hour opener, Aleksandr Khalifman of Russia and Vladimir Akopian of Armenia agreed to a short draw on Monday in Game 2 of their International Chess Federation Championship Match. That gives Khalifman a 1 1/2- 1/2 lead over Akopian in the six-game series, which is under way at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Aid Preferred To Vouchers In New Survey
description: An overwhelming majority of Americans prefer allowing government to improve and strengthen public schools rather than giving parents tuition vouchers for private or church-sponsored schools, according to a poll released yesterday.

title: Bank Inquiry Intensifies; Reno Taking 'Personal Interest'
description: The money-laundering investigation at the Bank of New York is intensifying this week as Attorney General Janet Reno and British authorities step up their interest in the effort, authorities said.

title: PMC-SIERRA TO PAY $400 MILLION FOR ABRIZIO
description: PMC-Sierra Inc., a maker of chips that accelerate telecommunications transmissions, agreed to buy closely held Abrizio Inc. for $400 million in stock to increase its sales of products used in broadband services. Abrizio, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes switch-chip fabrics and systems designed for automatic teller machines, voice traffic and point-of-sale machines, among other uses. PMC-Sierra will pay for the transaction with 4.35 million shares. Shares of PMC-Sierra, based in Burnaby, British Columbia, have climbed fivefold in the last year, driven by the increasing use of the Internet for voice, video and data transmission. Its stock rose $2.6875, to $98.1875.

title: Where Waiters Tell All
description: EVERY bartender, busboy, hostess or waiter has a collection of horror stories from the front lines. Behind ''the customer is always right'' and ''service with a smile'' lurks a backlash of epic proportion beyond the swinging doors.

title: Voila! A Bistro Suddenly Finds Its Footing
description: LET me tell you about tonight's specials,'' the waiter said. Several shining faces looked up at him expectantly. ''Tonight, we got no specials.''

title: Court Is Not Sympathetic To Lawsuit by Legislators
description: Legislators hoping to overturn a law that withholds their paychecks when the state budget is late got little encouragement from the state's highest court in oral arguments today, as four of the seven Court of Appeals judges voiced skepticism at their challenge.

title: Salad Bars: How Clean Are They?
description: A SMALL child snags a piece of melon from a salad bar with her chubby little fingers. A man sneezes, then picks up the tongs resting on a bed of potato salad. A woman runs her finger along the edge of a tuna salad bowl and puts it in her mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLI, LEO
description: CASTELLI-Leo. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art, are deeply saddened by the death of long-time friend and Honorary Trustee, Leo Castelli. His commitment to an extraordinary group of contemporary artists, fostered through his gallery, is legendary and secured his unique place as an art dealer of great vision, taste, and humanity. We will long remember his warmth and generosity, and we offer our profound sympathy to his family. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: A Cautious Rate Increase
description: The Federal Reserve Board is acting cautiously in trying to slow the American economy and head off a resurgence of inflation. Investors appear to be confident that such a gradual approach will have a minimal impact on the economy. In the near term, they are probably right.

title: Tantalizing Flavors
description: HISPANIC restaurants often have long, tantalizing drink menus. There are drinks made with fresh watermelon juice, papaya, lime and tamarind. Some are richly textured, some assertive, some sweet. But they tend to be a little much with food.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Time Warner Shares Hit by Analyst Shift
description: Shares of Time Warner Inc. tumbled about 7 percent yesterday after a Merrill Lynch & Company analyst who has been a strong supporter of the stock reduced her earnings estimates for the company, citing problems in its music business.

title: A Conflicted Detective, A Drug Lord Named God
description: ''In Too Deep'' is the story of an undercover police detective who finds himself with conflicting loyalties, especially where the matter of doing God's business is concerned. That's because God is the blasphemous moniker of a Cincinnati drug lord played by the rapper LL Cool J with impressive bluster. And it becomes increasingly impressive to Jeff Cole (Omar Epps), who has adopted the alias J. Reid for his work at infiltrating God's operation. The film means to be a semi-subtle look at the conflicts in which Cole finds himself entangled.

title: AT&T DEAL IN BRAZIL
description: Making its first major foray into Brazil's $9 billion corporate telecommunications market, the AT&T Corporation announced a $300 million purchase of Netstream, a Brazilian provider of data transmission services. AT&T's purchase of Netstream will give it a way to compete with MCI Worldcom and Sprint, which have already made significant inroads into Brazil's long-distance industry. Netstream, with 400 corporate clients, will enable AT&T to provide services to large multinational companies with operations in Brazil.

title: Martha Rountree, 87, a Creator of 'Meet the Press'
description: Martha Rountree, the co-creator and first moderator of the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' died on Monday at Sibley Hospital in Washington. She was 87 and lived in Washington.

title: People
description: * Ron Benza was named to the new position of vice president for marketing at Brodia, San Francisco, an E-commerce company. He had most recently been executive vice president and general manager of McCann-Erickson San Francisco, part of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, a unit of Interpublic.

title: In Turkey, Disaster After Disaster
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WORTHINGTON, LORNE R.
description: WORTHINGTON-Lorne R. Of New York City on August 21, at the age of 61. Iowa Insurance Commissioner 1967-71. President of NAIC, 1971. Preferred Risk Mutual Insurance 1972-82; President & CEO 1979-82. Executive Vice President of New Hampshire Insurance Company 1982-87. Managing Director Seabury & Smith 1987-91. Youngest ever elected State Rep Iowa 1962. Iowa Auditor 1964. Graceland College Board of Trustees 1978-84; Chairman 198284. Surviving him are seven children: Penelope Thomas of Lincoln, NE; Deborah of Middletown, NJ, Suzanne Menard of Washington, D.C.; Michael of Ashland, VA; Nisa Ulep of Washington, D.C.; Jonathan of Des Moines, IO., and Chad of Washington, D.C. and twelve grandchildren. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions can be made to Graceland College, Lamoni, Iowa. Memorial service will be held at The Williams Club, 24 East 39th Street, New York, NY, Sunday, August 29th, 1:30 PM.

title: More Than Just the Color Purple
description: IT is said in the Middle East that a woman is not ready to marry until she knows 1,000 ways to cook eggplant. It may seem an unreasonable demand to American women, many of whom marry before they know how to cook anything at all.

title: Yes, Homemade Dim Sum
description: THE very thought of preparing dim sum from scratch stops most home cooks before they start. All that painstaking slicing, chopping, wrapping, steaming and frying, just to produce six or eight of these assorted Chinese dumplings and other tidbits, usually leads to one thing: opting to let a restaurant cook these tasty morsels for you.

title: HEALTHSTAR TO TAKE 49% STAKE IN PHYSICIANSITE.COM
description: The Healthstar Corporation, a health care management company with 121,000 physicians, agreed to buy a 49 percent stake in Physician site.com for $42 million in stock and cash to add on-line services. Physiciansite.com, based in Newport Beach, Calif., is an Internet site that will allow doctors to process insurance claims, order supplies and prescriptions, and schedule appointments on line. Healthstar, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., will pay four million shares for the stake, which is owned by an unnamed investment group. Healthstar said Physiciansite.com will provide a single location for doctors, hospitals, insurers and employers to communicate and make transactions.

title: Citing Credit Card Unit Woes, Bank One Will Trail Forecasts
description: The Bank One Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest bank, said today that its 1999 earnings a share could be as much as 8 percent below forecasts because of lower-than-expected revenue from its First USA credit card unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, HARRY
description: KAHN-Harry. It is with great sadness that all of us at CEP will record the passing of Harry Kahn, a longtime member of the Board and past Chairman. Harry's enormous contribution to the CEP philosophy is endowed through the success the organization enjoys today; indeed, his strong sense of values and personal caring form an enduring memory which we, his successors, must always seek to emulate. Until only recently, Harry was helping and encouraging us with his depth of vision and ideas, his seeming endless energy and unbridled enthusiasm for CEP's future. He will be sorely missed. Gavin Anderson, Chairman

description: A chart yesterday with an article about universities' lobbying of Congress for research money referred incorrectly to political campaign donations. The Center for Responsive Politics, which compiled the data from Federal Election Commission records, did not make it clear that the contributions came from individuals at the universities, rather than from the institutions themselves or on their behalf.

title: Chairman of WPP Group raises the ante, the incentives and the potential payout.
description: TO the British tabloids, Martin Sorrell is no ordinary advertising executive. He is ''Mr 35M,'' as the bold-faced headline read in The Sun last week. At the end of next month, Mr. Sorrell, chief executive of the WPP Group P.L.C., will receive shares of the company worth about 35 million [pounds] ($56 million) as part of a much-disputed performance-based compensation package that he created four years ago.

title: Starcom Picks Head Of New-Media Unit
description: Starcom Worldwide in Chicago, the media buying unit of the Leo Burnett Company, has named Bob Kubis, 48, president of Starlink, its new-media-management business. Mr. Kubis had been retail group account director with the title of vice president at Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide in Chicago, part of True North Communications. He began his career at Leo Burnett in 1976 as a media planner and left in 1985 as a senior account executive.

title: Children of Migrant Workers Keep Up Studies on the Internet
description: While other teen-agers were enjoying the dwindling vacation days of late summer, Mario Rangel was sitting in front of a laptop computer, trying to memorize the capitals of Europe for an on-line geography class.

description: BROCKELMAN-Mildred E. On August 23, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Loving sister of Mary Buchan. Funeral service Thursday, 12 Noon at N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 87-34 80 St, Woodhaven, N.Y.

title: For 'Millionaire,' the Question Is What Next
description: The new game show ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire,'' now in its second week of broadcasts, is the talk of the television world this summer. It has surpassed the status of mere hit to emerge as a national phenomenon.

title: A Volunteer Offers Advice, But Ponders Callers' Fates
description: Annie decided to help at the Victim Services domestic violence hot line about five years ago, after seeing its ads in the subway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANNARD, THELMA NUTHALL
description: STANNARD-Thelma Nuthall, 82. Died Sunday, August 22, 1999 at Forrestall Skilled Nursing and Rehab Center in Princeton, NJ. Born in Richmond Surrey, England, she immigrated to New York City some 50 years ago. She worked for British Airways in New York for approximately 30 years and was display manager for the U.S. and Canada at her retirement in 1977. She was preceded in death by her husband Donald and a brother and two sisters. Surviving are a sister Molly B. Harding of Richmond Surrey, England, a brother, John Nuthall of Twickenham, England, a nephew Christopher Nuthall and his wife Jane of Brevard, North Carolina and several nieces and nephews in England. Visitation is from 7 to 9 P.M. Thursday at the Papavero Funeral Home, 72-27 Grand Avenue, Maspeth, NY (1-718-651-3535). Funeral Services are Friday at 10:00 A.M. at the funeral home with burial in Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, NY.

description: UNGAR-Gerald. On August 23, 1999. Brother of the late Gladys Weisbart and Stanley Ungar. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, 7-9 P.M., with service Wednesday, 11:30 A.M.

title: Company Pays $100,000 Over Phone-Billing Complaints
description: A Florida-based company has agreed to pay the state of New Jersey $100,000 to settle complaints that it had billed phone customers for services they never ordered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILENSKY, ESTHER
description: WILENSKY - Esther. Beloved mother of Harris Wilensky and Phyllis Aikens. Loving grandmother of Sheri and Marc. Sister of Lilly Mallon. Services Robert Shoem Memorial Chapel (1-800-426-5869) Paramus, NJ, August 25 at noon. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery. Contributions in memory may be made to your charity.

title: School Board Sees Success In Hiring Push
description: After three job fairs and other recruitment efforts, the Board of Education said yesterday that it had hired enough teachers in the lowest performing schools to reduce class sizes but would all but abandon the goal of replacing unlicensed math, science and special-education teachers in those schools because they do not have enough candidates.
