title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, PHILIP E.
description: EDWARDS-Philip E. Of Key Colony Beach, FL., Haverford, PA., and Avalon, New Jersey, died on Monday, August 23, 1999 at the age of 80. He is survived by his wife of 41 years, Doris Campbell Edwards, two daughters, Robin Marzelli and Jill Hoffman, M.D., four grandchildren, two sisters and two brothers. The service and interment will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 1626 Locust St., Philadelphia, PA, 19103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENKRANZ, LOUIS R.
description: EHRENKRANZ-Louis R. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Dr. Eleanor Mangel Ehrenkranz; father of Pam Zur, Gil, Miles, and devoted alumnus Rabbi David Ehrenkranz; and brother of Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz and William Ehrenkranz. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz, dedicated alumnus and honorary degree recipient, is a YU Guardian in whose honor and name the Rare Manuscript Collection was established at our Mendel Gottesman Library. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Doctors Succeed in Forgoing Antirejection Drugs in Transplant
description: Doctors in Boston reported yesterday that a bone-marrow transplant had enabled a kidney transplant patient to survive without antirejection drugs and that nearly a year later, she was showing no sign of rejection.

title: A Domestic Sort With Global Worries
description: When President Clinton made a televised address to the nation about Kosovo last March 24, he uttered a sentence for which he was belabored that day and every day for the next 10 weeks, until he finally declared victory on June 10: ''I do not intend to put our troops in Kosovo to fight a war.''

title: Body of Ancient Man Found in West Canada Glacier
description: Tribal leaders and archeologists announced here today that hunters have discovered the well-preserved body of an ancient man, partly uncovered by a melting glacier.

title: Second-Half Run Lifts Los Angeles
description: Lisa Leslie and Mwadi Mabika each scored 12 second-half points as the host Los Angeles Sparks overcame an 11-point halftime deficit to defeat the Sacramento Monarchs, 71-58, in a W.N.B.A. playoff game last night.

title: CANAL PLUS SPECULATION
description: Shares in the French pay-television company Canal Plus S.A. jumped on reports that Vivendi S.A. was planning to sell part of its 49 percent stake to the German media company Bertelsmann A.G. Last month, Vivendi increased its stake in Canal Plus to 49 percent from 34 percent but said it was looking to reduce this stake back below 40 percent if it could find a strategic partner. Unconfirmed reports are that Vivendi now plans to sell 8 percent or 9 percent of the company to Bertelsmann for 70 euros ($66.67) a share.

title: Back From the Brink
description: This has been a positive summer for several bird and animal species that human carelessness had once driven to the brink. In July the Interior Department disclosed its intention to remove the bald eagle and the Aleutian Canada goose from the endangered-species list, pending a brief period of public comment. Last Friday the department formally removed the peregrine falcon from the list. One day later the White House announced that it had bought 9,300 acres of land adjacent to Yellowstone National Park to provide critical winter range for the park's fragile bison herd, which has been alternately ravaged by starvation and the animosity of Montana's cattle ranchers.

title: Top Seedings at Open For Sampras and Hingis
description: Pete Sampras and Martina Hingis, each ranked No. 1, were given the top seedings at the United States Open yesterday, as the tournament kept to the the computer ranking for its top 16 players. The strategy for the rest of the field has been to avoid Sampras and Hingis as early as possible, a mission accomplished by Andre Agassi and Monica Seles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNETT, ELWOOD K.
description: GANNETT-Elwood K. Of Teaneck, N.J., on August 23rd, 1999. Beloved husband of Lois (nee Butler), devoted father of Mary Gannett and Nancy Gannett Vickers and their spouses, Henry Zook and Gordon Vickers; loving grandfather of Zachary, Benjamin, Charles and Hannah; dear brother of Robert W. Gannett, and cherished by his extended family of in-laws, nieces, nephews and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Brooklyn Branch of The Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 163 Court St., Brooklyn, NY 11201, or The Teaneck Public Library, Teaneck, N.J. 07666.

title: Drama on the Track, Amateur Hour in the Pit
description: The busiest night yet of this world track and field championship was one for professionals, like Hicham el-Guerrouj and Haile Gebrselassie, who both underscored their dominance by winning gold medals. It was one for amateurs, like the meet officials who mistakenly told the American pole vaulter Jeff Hartwig he had qualified. It was even one for a hobbyist like Anthony Washington, a part-time discus thrower who became the first American to win his technical event at a major championship since Mac Wilkins in 1976.

title: Mayor's Close Aide Is Expected to Be Head of Visitors Bureau
description: Cristyne F. Lategano, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's communications director and one of his closest advisers for the last five years, is the top candidate to lead the private New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, a spokesman for the bureau said yesterday.

title: Late-Inning Lightning Goes Against the Mets
description: Perhaps the Mets had run out of magic tricks or had grown weary of the nail biting surrounding their most recent victories. But when last night's game stretched into the late -- and then extra -- innings, it appeared the stage was set for what is becoming routine drama at Shea Stadium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERR, CHESTER B.
description: KERR-Chester B. Age 87, in New London, NH on August 22, 1999. Former Director of The Yale University Press and President of Tichnor & Fields publishers. Widower of Joan Patterson Kerr; survived by four sons, John of Lincoln, MA, Philip of Ann Arbor, MI, Alexander of Philadelphia, PA and Brooks of New York, NY; an adopted daughter, Claudia Kerr Grose, three stepchildren and thirteen grandchildren. Funeral services on Monday, August 30, 1999 at 11:00 AM in the Riverside Cemetery Chapel, Norwalk, CT. In lieu of usual remembrances, contributions may be made to The Yale University Press, 302 Temple St., New Haven, CT 06520.

title: Astros' Hampton Is an All-Round Threat
description: One of the nicest compliments that Mike Hampton can receive is that he does not look like a typical pitcher. Even though Hampton is one of the finest pitchers in the National League, he does not lumber around the bases, he does not treat grounders like hand grenades and he is not an automatic out with 32 ounces of wood in his hands.

title: Internet's Governing Body Debates Domain Names
description: A major meeting of the Internet's new governing body opened today with the fireworks and controversy that have become its trademark, including protests over a closed session of one of its advisory groups and a dispute over what should be voted on later this week.

title: Editorial Observer; Jesse Ventura Goes to the Mat for Wrestling
description: Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota made headlines Sunday night when he returned to his roots as a professional wrestler, serving as guest referee in a pay-per-view championship match. The combatants included the titleholder, Stone Cold Steve Austin, a challenger named Mankind who never appears in public without a muzzle, and a third contender whom Mr. Ventura penalized for hitting Mankind on the head with a folding chair. When critics protest that Mr. Ventura has degraded his office, fans can retort that he was probably the first referee in wrestling history who actually punished a fighter for using a folding chair as a weapon. Who says the Reform Party is losing its steam?

title: Privacy Questions Raised in Cases Of Syphilis Linked to Chat Room
description: In what health officials believe is the first time a disease cluster has been traced to cyberspace, the department of public health here has tracked an outbreak of syphilis cases to an America Online chat room.

description: They call him the Thorpedo, and Ian Thorpe of Australia created another major splash in the Pan-Pacific swim championships tonight with a world-record performance in the men's 200-meter freestyle final.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the resignation of an Energy Department official who led the initial investigation into allegations of Chinese espionage referred incorrectly to the status of Robert Vrooman, a former chief of counterintelligence at Los Alamos National Laboratory. The Energy Secretary has recommended that Mr. Vrooman be disciplined for mishandling the investigation, but no action has yet been taken.

title: SUBVERSION TRIALS DUE FOR LEADERS OF SECT IN CHINA
description: Chinese authorities announced today that they were preparing to prosecute senior members of Falun Gong, the spiritual movement that was banned last month after it startled China's leaders with its ability to organize potent anti-Government protests.

title: The Spirit Of the Beats, From Cool to None Too Hip
description: ''The Source,'' a stirring, kaleidescopic documentary about the Beat generation and its legacy, spans from the exultant 1940's photo of the young friends Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg and William Burroughs to the ''Jeopardy'' show on which contestants could win money by asking, ''Who were the Beats?'' (''Allen Ginsberg, Jack Kerouac and Lawrence Ferlinghetti were part of this group of writers.'') And it moves beyond, to the point of becoming a ghost story. ''It's eternity all the time, so there's no point being nostalgic for eternity,'' Ginsberg (who died in 1997) is heard saying. But that wisdom runs counter to the moving experience of watching this film unfold.

title: Baseball Discusses Plans In Case the Umpires Strike
description: Officials from the baseball commissioner's office and the league offices held a long meeting yesterday to discuss contingency plans in the event the umpires strike next week. The prevailing feeling, one official said, was that the umpires would have to be ''stupid'' to walk out over the imminent loss of jobs by 22 umpires.

description: MARK-Hyman. Beloved husband and devoted companion of Emma, beloved brother of Nathan (Blanche) and the late Julius and Dorothy.

title: Disney to Buy Biggest Stake In On-Line Toy Retailer
description: Giving a major lift to a small on-line retailer of educational toys, the Walt Disney Company is expected to announce today that it has bought a majority stake in Toysmart.com.

title: Firing on Fortress Northwest; Sun Country Airlines Competes Against an Industry Giant
description: Most cities root unabashedly for their big hometown companies. But here -- where Northwest Airlines has its headquarters, employs 21,000 and controls 80 percent of the airline seats out of the city -- many people are rooting for Sun Country Airlines, a small local charter airline that started flying a regular schedule to a mere 15 destinations in June.

title: Political Briefing; Confusion Follows McCain on Abortion
description: In recent weeks, Senator John McCain of Arizona has been getting some pretty good political reviews as he has crisscrossed the country in quest of the Republican Presidential nomination. His organizing and fund-raising and campaign appearances have been going well, and many political analysts have come to see him as the candidate best positioned to be his party's alternative choice should Governor Bush falter.

title: Corrections

description: America Online Inc. introduced its own free Internet service in Britain today, with the goal of overtaking the growing crowd of competitors that already offer customers access to the World Wide Web at no charge.

description: All around New York City, neighborhoods bear brick-and-mortar imprints from the largesse of the steel magnate Andrew Carnegie: His gift of $5.2 million nearly a century ago built 65 public library branches, laying the physical and philosophical foundation for a rich public tradition.

title: Banking Scandals Rattle Asians and Worry Lending Agencies
description: Banking scandals have rippled across Indonesia and Thailand this month, and bankers and securities analysts predict that they are likely to worsen, intensifying pressure on the two countries' Governments and providing a growing source of consternation to lenders at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

title: Many Cleveland Parents Frantic After Ruling Limits School Vouchers
description: Maria Silaghi did not sleep last night. She scrubbed other people's floors until after midnight. And then she lay in bed and agonized over whether her 10-year-old son, Anthony, might have to leave his Roman Catholic grammar school.

title: BRAZILIAN POWER SALE
description: Portugal's largest power company, Electricidade de Portugal, acquired a 38.3 percent stake in the Brazilian power company Esclesa-Espirito Santo Centrais Electricas for $534.6 million. Part of the stake was sold by Banco Nacional of Brazil through an auction on the Rio de Janeiro stock market. The remaining shares were purchased from the Brazilian banks Banco Pactual and Banco Icatu. After this acquisition, EDP will operate in four Brazilian states, including Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, and will serve 4.8 million clients.

title: BIGGER JAPANESE SURPLUS
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus widened in July, as a decline in imports outstripped a fall in exports. The rising yen also pushed down the cost of imports and crimped export earnings. The surplus widened to 1.233 trillion yen ($10.7 billion), seasonally adjusted, from 1.055 trillion in June, the Ministry of Finance said. Imports fell 6.8 percent and exports declined eight-tenths of a percent. From a year ago, the surplus shrank 4.6 percent to 1.25 trillion yen.

title: 'Unlawful Interference' Cited in 1997 Accident : Report on SilkAir Crash Alludes to Pilot Suicide
description: SINGAPORE  Indonesian investigators have concluded that "unlawful interference" may have caused the mysterious crash of a Singapore jet in December 1997 that killed all 104 people on board, the Singapore government said Wednesday.

description: A Queens man killed his wife on Tuesday night as their children slept in the next room, called his mother to tell her, and drove to Flushing Meadow Park, where he fatally shot himself, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIGG, DR. ERNEST C.
description: GRIGG-Dr. Ernest C. II. Beloved father and grandfather. Died early Tuesday morning at the age of 89. He had been battling cancer for more than 10 years. He is survived by his three grandchildren, Rhema, Christa and Ernie. Dr. Grigg was a career diplomat for the US Mission to the United Nations and held many posts with Save the Children including Director for Africa, Middleast and Europe in the 1970's and Executive Vice President in the 1980's. Dr. Grigg was a true gentleman in every sense of the word and will be greatly missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held Friday, August 27 at 9AM at St. john's Church, 55 Street and 1st Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Time Warner Sets Deadline on Control of the Apollo
description: Time Warner officials notified Representative Charles B. Rangel yesterday that they would abandon their plans to take control of the struggling Apollo Theater unless Mr. Rangel stepped down as its chairman by the next board meeting, officials involved in the negotiations said.

title: CABLE STAKE TO BE SOLD
description: Britain's second-biggest cable company by subscribers, Telewest Communications P.L.C., agreed to buy the 50 percent of Cable London P.L.C. it did not already own for 428 million [pounds] ($685 million) in cash. Telewest and NTL Inc., which jointly own Cable London, agreed last year to place it under a single owner no later than September. The agreement required NTL, based in New York, to set a price at which Telewest could choose to either buy or sell its half. Telewest's American depository receipts rose $1, to $40.50, while NTL's shares jumped $2.3125 each, to $100.0625.

title: Criticism Greets Sign In Atlanta
description: Years ago, the dome of the Georgia State Capitol was Atlanta's golden signature, serenely gleaming above a modest downtown. The hyper-growth of the last decades, however, obscured the dome's glint with a series of undistinguished office towers, leaving the Old South's most prominent city without a man-made identifier so beloved of television backdrops.

The juggling act begins as the user looks up the number on the digital organizer, then tries to dial it on the phone.

title: Balinese Craftsmanship in Silver and Palm Wood
description: One might assume that there's a huge gap between jewelry and cheese knives, but John Hardy, a designer and jewelry maker who lives in Bali, would disagree. A self-proclaimed ''ex-hippie who made good,'' Mr. Hardy has a reputation for unique pieces. The same Balinese artisans and metal smiths who make his jewelry are using their skills for utilitarian things like knives and teapots. The distinctive shimmery weave on some of his designs looks part ancient rope, part futuristic coat of mail.

description: MANHATTAN

title: AT HOME WITH -- Joe Coleman; Saints and Monsters
description: THERE'S little of the great 17th-century cabinets of curiosity, from hand-shaped carrots to human-faced pigs, that Joe Coleman, an artist, can't match in his 20th-century version. He owns a pair of Fiji mermaids and a two-headed prairie dog. He has a framed piece of embroidery sewn by a 19th-century woman in Sag Harbor, N.Y., who had no hands: Mlle. Tunison, ''World's Greatest Phenomenal.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shares Plunge At Bank One Over Earnings
description: Shares of Bank One, the Chicago-based banking giant, plunged 23 percent yesterday after the company stunned the financial community with its warning late Tuesday that intense competition in the credit card business would cause profits to fall short of expectations.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to appoint Anthony V. Carbonetti, a longtime aide, as his new chief of staff, City Hall officials said yesterday.

title: What the Apollo Means for Harlem
description: Harlem was once the center of life for the African-American middle class and a storied gathering place for artists, writers and musicians. Middle-class flight, business closings and the urban disorders of the 1960's robbed the district of its grandeur and have presented a formidable challenge to private entrepreneurs and government agencies that have been striving to restore Harlem as a desirable place to live and work in Manhattan.

title: Like Mother, Like Daughter, Eritrean Women Wage War
description: Like many of her comrades, Senait Tekleab, a 19-year-old infantry soldier, gets a little bored with outsiders who ask too many questions about women in combat.

title: Speeding Up Wireless Computing
description: AS popular as the notion of wireless computing may be, there remains one significant technical snag: speed. The state of the art in sending data to and from mobile devices is woefully molasses-like: around 9,600 bits, or 9.6 kilobits, per second. Even those home computer users still using a 14.4-kilobits-per-second modem are better off than anyone on the move.

title: KOREAN REFORMS PROMISED
description: The heads of South Korea's top five conglomerates pledged in a meeting with President Kim Dae Jung to accelerate their revamping by adopting advanced accounting methods and other measures. Top executives from Hyundai, Daewoo, Samsung, LG and SK agreed to curb the common practice of financing cash-short affiliates within the same business group, increase the number of outside board members and adopt transparent auditing methods.

Once, they even agreed to stash three hand grenades on board, as carry-on baggage.

title: SPRINT TO OFFER LONG-DISTANCE CALLS VIA THE INTERNET
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it would begin a trial offer of long-distance calls to Asian countries over the Internet using Net2phone Inc.'s technology. Financial terms were not disclosed. Sprint, based in Westwood, Kan., said the service would be called Sprint Callternatives and would allow customers to place calls to China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam. Net2phone, of Hackensack, N.J., has a service that lets users place long-distance calls through a personal computer over the Internet. The company went public at $15 a share on July 29; the shares jumped $17 yesterday, to $70.125.

description: A French-speaking man hijacked a Moroccan airliner with 88 people aboard late Wednesday after it left Casablanca en route to Tunisia but surrendered early today in Barcelona, where he had diverted the plane and demanded fuel to fly to Frankfurt, Spanish officials said.

White banners covered with calligraphy billowed out from the stage over the audience. It was clear that one had entered a territory of dreams and memory at the start of ''Empty Tradition/City of Peonies,'' a dance and theater piece by Yin Mei that was performed on Sunday afternoon in the Doris Duke Studio Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

description: When a mayor accuses a university of ''the highest level of arrogance seen in our city in many years,'' it is a pretty good bet that town-gown relations have hit a notable nadir. Around here, it is also a pretty good bet that the university in question is Harvard.

title: A Delicate Grind of a Game Levels Off the Chess Score
description: It took 84 moves over almost seven hours for Vladimir Akopian to wear down Aleksandr Khalifman by delicate positional play and a grinding endgame in the third encounter of their International Chess Federation World Championship Match. That result, at the half-way point of the six-game series at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., evens the score at 1 1/2-1 1/2.

title: Rogers Turns Up the Volume With Victory at Shea
description: Kenny Rogers kept tossing sinkerball pitches on the inside and outside and the Houston Astros kept hitting grounders. The left-hander, who has been his enigmatic self with the Mets, made pitching look simple last night. He did not stray from the cozy spot he found on the right side of the rubber and was robotic in his approach. Wind up, pitch, get another ground-ball out, return to the dugout.

title: In a Time Warp With Pac-Man and Pong
description: IN the second week of August, Las Vegas, Nev., roasted slowly in triple-digit heat. Miles from the main strip, in the half-light of Jackie Gaughan's Plaza hotel, septuagenarians fed the slots. Time was suspended; only the quarters seemed to slip away. Upstairs, for a few hundred Gen-Xers, time stood still as well. But they had better things to do than gamble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWACH, WALLACE
description: ROSENWACH-Wallace. On August 23, 1999. Beloved husband of Alice, loving father of Andrew, Barbara and her husband Greg, adoring grandfather of Alissa and Henry. Devoted brother of Ruth Sabowitz, Janet Neiderbach and the late Felix Rosenwach. His deep devotion to family and friends was paralleled by his many civic contributions. He served with great enthusiasm for years as ''Principal For A Day''. Active member of numerous civic organizations including The New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, The Executive Association of Greater New York, The Long Island City Business Development Corporation, The Hundred Year Association of New York, Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, The New York Friars Club, NYC District Council of Carpenters, Local 135, ABO and BOMA. Proud Graduate of NYU School of Engineering and Harvard Business School, Small Business Program. His vision, energy and industry left his mark on the skyline of the city he so loved. His honesty, humor and spirit genuinely touched all who knew him. He will be forever missed and always remembered. Services are to be on Friday, August 27, 11:00 AM, Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY.

title: In Real Life's Shadows, Virtual Life Can Pale
description: PERSONAL tragedies inevitably rearrange the way we think about our world. One aspect of life I began to re-examine after an unexpected personal sorrow a year ago was the phenomenon of the ''virtual community.'' In recent years, the importance and value of on-line communities, often populated by people who have never met in person but who share a common interest, have captured the public imagination. Stories abound of on-line communities helping people regain a sense of belonging to something, somewhere.

title: Mending America's Acropolis
description: PERCHED on a scaffold five stories above the ground, Gerald J. Miller surveys the crumbling mortar and flaking brick, the jagged six-inch cracks and the scars of swallows' nests dotting the underside of a sagging stone dome, and marvels aloud, ''You wonder what the hell is holding this up.'' Quickly and ruefully, he answers himself, ''It's held up by faith alone.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DELPHI INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC., Rolling Meadows, Ill., a maker of insurance software, said the Hewlett-Packard Co., Palo Alto, Calif., had an option to buy as much as 9.4 percent of the company in the next two years.

description: A new device could cut down on tedious note taking. The C Pen, from the Swedish company C Technologies, works like a digital variation on the popular yellow highlighter except that this highlighter also absorbs information like a digital scanner, carries information like a personal digital assistant and records handwritten words as you write them.

title: Full-Time U.S. Force in Haiti To Leave an Unstable Nation

title: AMATIL STAKE TO BE SOLD
description: A food and beverage concern based in the Philippines, the San Miguel Corporation, said it planned to sell its stake in the Australian soft-drink bottler Coca-Cola Amatil Ltd. The announcement is an about-face for San Miguel, which in June denied media reports that it was planning to sell its 21.5 percent stake. The company has already sold its share of the European operations of Coca-Cola Amatil and its 45 percent stake in Nestle Philippines Inc. San Miguel's holding of 219.1 million Coca-Cola Amatil shares is to be sold through a global offering in late September.

title: Israelis Defend Plea Bargain With American

title: You've Got Romance! Seeking Love on Line
description: TOM BUCKLEY didn't have much use for a dating service, or so he thought. ''I didn't need to pay a company to help set me up to get a date, a girlfriend, a fiancee, a wife,'' said Mr. Buckley, 30, a steel broker in Portland, Ore., who plays rugby in his spare time. But after a lonely Thanksgiving dinner where he was the only single adult at the family dinner table, Mr. Buckley signed up for a free week on Match.com.

title: English Life, Taxidermist's Dream
description: Peter Ustinov (above, far left) has never been in a Merchant-Ivory film. But he knows the territory, having endured many guest rooms in frigid English manor houses. ''People who lived in those places became prisoners of a certain kind of cliche,'' he said over lunch in New York recently to promote his part in Gary Sinyor's period spoof, ''Stiff Upper Lips,'' opening tomorrow. Mr. Sinyor's film begins in a town called Ivory's End and wryly replicates the splendor of colonial India (Mr. Ustinov plays a plantation owner), great Victorian piles staffed by terrified servants, and the stifling stuffiness of it all. As a schoolboy, Mr. Ustinov recalled, he was required wear a top hat and tail coat and carry an umbrella, which he never unfurled, he said, ''for fear of not being able to furl it again.'' RICK MARIN

title: KOMAG TO MAKE ADDITIONAL CUTS IN U.S. WORK FORCE
description: Komag Inc., a maker of disk drive components based in San Jose, Calif., said yesterday that it would cut 480 jobs, or almost half its remaining United States work force, and shift manufacturing to Malaysia to cut costs. It said it would close two plants in San Jose and cut the number of United States workers to 570 from 1,050. It also said it would take a big charge in the third quarter, which ends Oct. 3. Last month, it said it would cut 500 United States jobs in the third quarter because of falling sales and prices. Last quarter, Komag cut 400 jobs. The shares, down 66 percent this year, fell 6.25 cents yesterday, to $3.5625, before trading was halted for the latest announcement.

title: AXENT TO ACQUIRE 2 ALTA VISTA SECURITY SOFTWARE LINES
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, the Houston-based personal computer maker, agreed yesterday to sell two lines of Alta Vista security software to Axent Technologies, further distancing itself from the troubled product family. Terms were not disclosed. Under the deal, Axent will develop the next version of the software products, which restrict access to computer networks and Web sites. The accord follows CMGI Inc.'s completion of its $2.3 billion purchase of a majority stake in Compaq's Alta Vista Internet search site. Compaq inherited Alta Vista when it bought the Digital Equipment Corporation last year.

title: Far Beyond Soundtracks: Sounds Meld With Movies

A string quartet was present, together with other musicians, to give a lengthy program of new pieces in a casual atmosphere to a semiprivate audience of patrons, friends and fellow artists. Perhaps the main difference would be that here, at Here, the artists were the dominant group, since the show involved not only a dozen musicians but about the same number of filmmakers, most of the pieces being new efforts to combine music with moving images.

title: Group Will Expand Program to Help Troubled Schools

title: The Three Faces Of Ruben Blades
description: Gabriel Garcia Marquez once said that the Panamanian musician Ruben Blades was the most popular unknown he had ever met. What he meant was probably not that Mr. Blades was an obscure figure, but that all the work that Mr. Blades had done was not necessarily synthesized in his image or reputation. It often seems as if there are three very busy and separate incarnations of Mr. Blades: the politician who started his own party and ran for president in Panama in 1994 (he placed a respectable third), the actor who appears regularly in Hollywood films and the musician who constantly challenges his audience with his artistic twists and turns.

title: Fools, Idlers and Hotheads But Nary a Villain in Sight

He lightens the early scenes -- with their usurpation, envy, greed and intended fratricide -- to such an extent that the love stories of the later acts lose the customary dark background against which they shine. But for him it pays off handsomely; every movement and line of this version is so well thought through that seeing it is as intellectually pleasing as it is emotionally satisfying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENWACH, WALLACE
description: ROSENWACH-Wallace. The officers, trustees and members of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck mourn the loss of congregant Wallace Rosenwach, who served as a distinguished member of the board of trustees. He demonstrated his belief in the purposes of the synagogue through his generosity and wise counsel. A leader in his own industry and a supporter of numerous philanthropic organizations, he created a bridgehead in so many hearts through his way of dealing with situations and people. Uncomplainingly, he sought to outface personal challenge. He leaves a treasure of memories that will deepen and mellow as the years go by. We express our heartfelt sympathies to his beloved wife, Alice, to his children and grandchildren who were the light of his eyes, and to his family and friends who were always within the purview of his concern. May his memory be a benediction. Dr. Robert S. Widom, Rabbi Lloyd Goldfarb and Sandor C. Schweiger, Co-Presidents Temple Emanuel of Great Neck

title: Red Faces at the F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation now concedes that it used ''pyrotechnic'' tear-gas canisters capable of setting the disastrous fire that ended a standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near Waco, Tex., in 1993. About 80 people were found dead after the fire. The bureau insists that the canisters played no role in the blaze, which they say was set by the cultists themselves. But the revelation that the devices were used at all contradicts six years of unqualified denials to Congress and the public by Attorney General Janet Reno and other senior officials, adding an embarrassing new element to one of the saddest chapters in F.B.I. history.

title: QUESTOR IS BUYING A STAKE IN AEGIS COMMUNICATIONS
description: Aegis Communications Group Inc., a marketing research and services company, said yesterday that Questor Partners Fund II L.P. would pay $46.75 million for the equivalent of about a 30 percent stake in the company. Questor, based in Southfield, Mich., is to buy Aegis's newly issued senior voting preferred shares, which will be convertible into common stock for $1.35 to $1.66 a share. Assuming an average conversion price of $1.51 a share, Questor would own about 30 percent of Aegis's fully diluted outstanding shares. The investment is the first announced by Questor Partners Fund II, an $860 million private equity fund. Shares of Aegis rose 3.125 cents, to 96.875 cents.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Personal History

title: An Estimable Force, in Court and in Print
description: Linda Fairstein, the flashy chief of the sex crimes unit in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, the one in Escada, high heels and the red Miata, is having a swell vacation. She went to Vernon Jordan's birthday party for Bill Clinton here on Martha's Vineyard, is having lunch with Katharine Graham, ate clam chowder at the Bite in Menemsha and saw her new novel, ''Cold Hit,'' the third in a series about the prosecutor Alexandra Cooper -- Ms. Fairstein calls her a ''younger, thinner and blonder'' alter ego -- make the President's vacation reading list.

title: Toys 'R' Us Loses Another Top Executive
description: In a continuation of the turmoil at a company in disarray, Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said yesterday that Robert C. Nakasone, its chief executive for just a year and a half, had resigned effective immediately.

title: Kenny Dorham, From Be-Bop On
description: This week, a secondary figure in jazz is receiving a primary re-evaluation. Kenny Dorham, who died of kidney disease in 1972 at the age of 48, was a trumpet player of authority and great style; he moved from his early days in the be-bop era to the 1960's progressions of the music gracefully, without showing the permanent markings of his youth.

title: DaimlerChrysler Gets Big Truck Order
description: J. B. Hunt Transport Inc., the second-largest United States trucking company, said today that it would buy as many as 15,000 trucks from DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s Freightliner unit during a five-year period for more than $1 billion as it replaces older models.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If they don't reopen the whole thing now and actually use outside investigators, this will be like the Kennedy assassination for the next 50 years. I live in the West and the Midwest and this issue is keeping the militia groups alive.''

title: AIDS Drugs for Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Chances of Boeing Strike Appear to Grow
description: For more than a year, executives at the Boeing Company and leaders of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, the union representing the largest number of Boeing employees, have been meeting regularly to trade ideas and work out disputes.

title: A Friendly Ride
description: At 100th Street and Broadway, a cluster of would-be commuters watched as bus after bus went by, packed so full they didn't bother to stop. One bus finally did stop, and people wrenched open the back door and threw themselves against the mass of bodies inside.

title: Broad Retreat on Wall St. In Wake of Rate Increase
description: Stocks retreated broadly yesterday. A rally based on the belief that Tuesday's interest-rate increase would be the Federal Reserve's last for the year gave way, as traders began to suspect that might not be the case.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Down the Shore and Up the Boardwalk, a Jersey Way of Life
description: I grew up spending summers on the Jersey Shore and, like others of my generation, eventually abandoned Jersey for beaches with palm trees and warmer water: Sanibel, St. Martin, Hawaii. I still have a homing instinct for the Jersey Shore, though not the trendy one currently discovered by the upscale crowd seeking an alternative to the Hamptons. Such exclusive venues as Stone Harbor, Sea Girt, Avalon don't interest me. Rather, what appeals to me as a beachgoer is what makes the Jersey Shore stand out in the realm of cultural kitsch: the boardwalk towns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLAKOFF, GAIL
description: POLAKOFF-Gail. Beloved wife of Rabbi Dale Polakoff of the Great Neck Synagogue and devoted mother and sister. Her personal qualities of mind and heart endeared her to all those whose lives she touched. She was a strengthening influence and support to her husband, taking justifiable pride in his rabbinate. She will be remembered as courageous and uncomplaining, as one who dealt with inordinate challenge with the dignity of a matriarch, refusing to be conquered by it, and never giving in to self pity to insulate herself in a private world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Rabbi Polakoff, his children and the members of the congregation. Dr. Robert S. Widom, Rabbi Lloyd Goldfarb and Sandor C. Schweiger, Co-Presidents Temple Emanuel of Great Neck

title: Tearing Off a Head or Two? What Fun!
description: Grunt, Aargh. Aieeee! If the juiciest bouts of professional wrestling on television leave you feeling unfulfilled and pining for the primal howls of fight-to-the-death combat, ''The 13th Warrior'' just might be the answer to your prayers. And unlike professional wrestling, it is saturated in purgative gore.

title: Johansson Forced To Withdraw
description: Thomas Johansson of Sweden, ranked 18th in the world, will be forced to miss next week's United States Open because of viral pericarditis.

title: Commercials in Class
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Team Shows Overall Weaknesses
description: The United States national team revealed some weaknesses yesterday in semifinal races of the world rowing championships involving men's and women's scullers at St. Catherines, Ontario.

title: At 79, Cardinal O'Connor Is Hospitalized for Tests
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, was admitted to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on Wednesday afternoon for tests after he experienced weakness and nausea, the Cardinal's spokesman said yesterday.

title: Possible Insider Case Is Being Investigated
description: The New York Stock Exchange is examining whether a possible leak of inside information prompted a surge in the stock of Transaction Network Services Inc. before the company agreed to be acquired by Psinet Inc., an executive at Transaction Network said today.

title: Boardwalk Bingo
description: A connoisseur of the Jersey Shore makes a pilgrimage to three of the most storied boardwalks, from the world-class amusements of Wildwood, to the family ambiance of Ocean City, to the sassy atmosphere of Seaside Heights, above, the place for the best boardwalk junk food.

title: Library Users Can't Afford to Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Nassau County Comptroller Predicts New Budget Deficits
description: Even if Nassau County somehow manages to wipe out its budget deficit of about $240 million by using a long list of one-time revenue sources, its deep-rooted financial problems will by no means be solved, the county Comptroller, Frederick E. Parola, warned today. The deficit, Mr. Parola warned, will be up to at least $100 million again by this time next year.

title: Commercials in Class
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Westvaco Buys a Rival
description: The Westvaco Corporation, one of the world's largest envelope manufacturers, acquired a rival, the New England Envelope Corporation, for $13 million in cash yesterday.

title: A Perfectionist With a Raging Fire in the Belly
description: From the Yankees' dugout, you can hear Roger Clemens lecturing himself on the mound. The words are harsh and often profane, delivered with intent. The message is this: You must do better. You must do well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCBEE, JEANNE
description: McBEE-Jeanne. On August 21, 1999. Formerly of Great Neck and East Hampton. Beloved wife of Silas, dear mother of M. Charles and Judith McBee of Richmond, VA, William and Shelley Peters of New York, NY, Mary McBee-Massucco, Manchester, VT and Rita McBee (daughter-in-law), Center Moriches, NY and the late Robert B. McBee. Grandchildren are Matthew C. McBee, Richmond, VA, Monica Elizabeth, Blair Timothy and Mark Edward Massucco, Manchester, VT and William George and Samuel Alexander McBee, Center Moriches, NY. Beloved sister of Charles J. Segui of Huntington Bay, NY. Funeral Mass Friday, 11:15 AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Roslyn Harbor.

title: Saks Plans to Expand Its Presence on Line
description: Saks Inc., owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and other department-store chains, said it would meld its catalogue and Internet businesses into a new division to handle growth on line.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Richard C. Holbrooke's first appearance at the United Nations since his Senate confirmation as chief United States representative misstated the history of the appointment. While his confirmation was delayed for nearly a year, most of the delay was due to a Justice Department investigation, not to Congressional roadblocks. The article also misstated the duration and nature of the Senate hearings. They did not last months and were not grueling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHR, FRANK
description: ROHR-Frank, on August 23, 1999. Beloved son, brother, uncle, husband and friend. Graveside service Friday, Ausust 27, 11 AM, at Mount Ararat, Farmingdale, L.I. Memorial service on Tuesday, September 7, 1999, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: DEUTSCHE BANK INVESTIGATED
description: The world's largest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., said regulators were investigating its Japanese units in the latest examination of a foreign bank. Inspectors from the Financial Supervisory Agency are examining all seven of Deutsche Bank's Tokyo businesses, including units it obtained in its $9 billion acquisition of Banker's Trust early this year. Bank officials said the inspection was routine. The watchdog agency is preparing criminal charges against Credit Suisse Group for obstructing inquiries that led to the closing of its Japanese derivatives arm. Lehman Brothers also faces an inquiry.

title: Smyth Agrees To Contract Terms
description: The Rangers agreed to terms yesterday with right wing Brad Smyth, 26, who was acquired from the Nashville Predators in May for future considerations.

title: MASCOTECH ACQUIRES CLOSELY HELD WINDFALL PRODUCTS
description: Mascotech Inc., a maker of vehicle-engine parts, said yesterday that it had acquired the closely held Windfall Products Inc. for an undisclosed price. Windfall, which has annual sales of about $80 million, makes components from powder metal, which is used to produce difficult-to-form vehicle-engine and drive-train parts. The company, based in St. Marys, Pa., has plants in St. Marys and Ridgway, Pa., and Sao Paulo, Brazil. Mascotech, based in Taylor, Mich., makes parts like automobile gears, pistons and connecting rods, and powder metal parts. It had sales of $1.6 billion in its fiscal year 1998.

title: Britain Rules For the I.R.A. On Truce, Inciting Furor
description: Provoking a furor among Protestant politicians, Britain sought today to prevent the collapse of peace efforts in Northern Ireland by ruling that recent charges of murder and gunrunning against the Irish Republican Army did not constitute a breach of its cease-fire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, HARRY
description: KAHN-Harry. His was a lifetime commitment to international understanding and social justice. He was a man of all seasons. We are immensely grateful for the creative time and leadership he gave so generously to us. May Ruth, Jenny and his beloved family be consoled by the mourning of so many. The Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute William J. vanden Heuvel, Pres. Arthur Schlesinger, Jr., Co-Chair Trude Lash, Co-Chair

title: Anti-Independence Frenzy Leaves 4 Reported Dead in East Timor as Referendum Approaches
description: Opponents of independence for East Timor ran wild in the streets of this tiny provincial capital today, firing guns, throwing rocks and setting fire to at least two buildings.

title: A Rebel Spirit, Some Deco Dash and Accessible Art
description: The Museum of Modern Art and ''period rooms'' are not phrases that you often find in the same sentence, but they make compatible enough bedfellows in ''Abby Aldrich Rockefeller and Print Collecting: An Early Mission for MoMA.'' The show celebrates the 50th anniversary of the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Print Room, founded in 1949, a year after the death of Mrs. Rockefeller, who was famously one of the museum's three founders and, less famously, an avid print collector.

title: Dr. Charles D. Hollister, 63; Expanded Study of Sea Floor
description: Dr. Charles Davis Hollister, a marine geologist who expanded the knowledge of ocean bottom currents and deep sea storms, died on Monday in Wyoming on a family vacation. He was 63 and lived in Falmouth, Mass.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- 'Begols' and 'Dirty Water'; Fast-Food Chains Take U.S. Marketing to Europe
description: Nobody knows when the custom began among travelers to Rome of turning your back to the Trevi Fountain and tossing in a coin over your left shoulder as a means of assuring your return.

title: What is that, Batman, on your new Cadillac? Why, art and science.
description: BACK in the 1950's and 60's, Cadillac built cars with all-American swagger. People aspired to get behind the wheel of a Cadillac with yards of chrome and soaring tailfins. But Cadillac has a problem: those same people are almost the only ones still willing to be seen driving a Caddy.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about drug arrests at Miami International Airport misstated the affiliations of some of those arrested. No United States Customs Bureau agent was arrested, and only one employee of the Immigration and Naturalization Service was arrested, not two.

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES OPPOSED LENIENCY FOR 16 MILITANTS
description: A wide range of Federal law-enforcement agencies that were asked to review a clemency petition filed by imprisoned members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group unanimously opposed any leniency in the weeks before President Clinton offered to commute the sentences of 16 members of the militant organization, officials said today.

title: Foreign Affairs; Whose Web Site Is This?
description: You just knew something like this would happen. China, unable so far to occupy Taiwan on land, has done it in cyberspace. The Internet address Taiwan.com was recently claimed and registered by China.com, an Internet portal that is partially owned by China's state-run Xinhua news agency. According to The Asian Wall Street Journal, several hundred Taiwanese professors and lawmakers have petitioned the Taiwan government to reclaim the Taiwan.com domain name by taking the Nasdaq-traded China.com to court in the U.S. for misrepresentation.

title: Autopsy Shows Birds Were Killed by Pesticide
description: The dozens of pigeons, sparrows and other birds that were recently found dead in two New York City parks were killed after they ingested a restricted insecticide, according to researchers at the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: The Price of Success
description: In ''The Muse,'' his latest mordantly hilarious cri de coeur about contemporary life, Albert Brooks plays a Hollywood screenwriter who has just been honored with a humanitarian award at a black-tie ceremony. ''What's a humanitarian?'' his daughter asks on the way home.

title: Allow Aluminum Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ROBIN
description: WEISS-Robin. A woman of valor, deeply loved. We will miss Robin with all our hearts. Barbara and Arthur Weiss

title: Library Users Can't Afford to Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEER, WALTER E.
description: BEER-Walter E., Jr. was born in 1904 and died in his Brooklyn Heights apartment on August 21. His marriage of 70 years to Florence Fay Beer ended with her death last summer. He was the beloved father of John and David; grandfather of Thomas, Amy, Jeffrey, Elizabeth and Andrew; greatgrandfather of Tea, Nuala and India. He was a founding partner of the law firm of Beer, Richards, Haller & O'Niel and was of counsel at Kelley, Drye, Warren for many years. A former trustee of Montifiore Hospital, he was active in many Brooklyn organizations including the Long Island College Hospital and the Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation. He was equally active in Keene Valley, NY, where he and Florence were very much-loved members of the community. Contributions may be sent to The Keene Valley Neighborhood House, Box 43, Keene Valley, NY 12943.

title: A Permit to March in Harlem
description: Last year's so-called Million Youth March in Harlem was a hateful affair in which the principal speaker, Khallid Abdul Muhammad, paraded his bigotry before a modest audience of 6,000 and tried to instigate a conflict with the police. This year's follow-up march, scheduled for Labor Day weekend, promises to be more of the same. Even so, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani needs to reconsider the city's decision, announced yesterday, to turn down a request from Mr. Muhammad's group to assemble again in Harlem.

title: Album of the Week
description: ARSONISTS: ''As the World Burns'' (Matador). ''When our worlds collide, M.C.'s will get fried,'' the Arsonists intone on this disk, their long-playing debut, and it's clear to whom they're announcing the apocalypse. Mainstream artists like Puff Daddy had better watch their Armani-clad backs because the Arsonists, a five-man version of a large and longstanding Bushwick-based crew, are leading the underground's battle for the soul of a genre old enough to need to return to its roots.

title: Bigfork Journal; A Theater Thrives Near Glacier Park
description: By one measurement, the distance from here to Broadway is nearly 2,000 miles. By another, they are just a few steps apart.

title: As Others Falter, Brown Rallies to Win Met Open
description: Mark Brown has done little wrong this summer, so neither a six-shot deficit nor heavy morning rains could sidetrack him today. He shot a course-record 65 on the Tuxedo Club golf course to capture the 84th edition of the Met Open.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 20 about a suit filed by a Palestinian man who has been held for 17 months by the Immigration and Naturalization Service on the basis of secret evidence referred incorrectly to the United States Attorney's response to an immigration judge's request for testimony by the man's former wife. On the eve of the hearing, the judge modified his request to conform with the United States Attorney's argument: that the former wife respond only to written questions and not be forced to testify in open court. The Government did not defy the judge's request.

title: Indians and Orioles Discuss Major Trade
description: The Cleveland Indians and Baltimore Orioles are discussing a trade that, if completed, would have repercussions for American League playoff contenders. The Indians have been awarded waiver claims on two Baltimore players, Scott Erickson, a pitcher, and Harold Baines, a designated hitter, according to major league officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZ, LEON
description: KURTZ-Leon. Of Kiamesha Lake, NY, died August 25, 1999 in Florida. A retired principal of PS 95. Survived by his wife Sylvia Kurtz at home, one son Evan Kurtz and his wife Livia, one daughter Ellen Schroeder, one granddauther Heather Schroeder,one sister Janet Zinner, several nieces and nephews. Funeral service on Sunday, August 29 at 11:00am at Doulin Newburgh Funeral Home, Inc. Newburgh, N.Y. Burial at King Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, NJ.

title: At 'River City' Junction, No Metro-North Brass to Be Found
description: ''Welcome to River City.''

title: 1990 Census Missed at Least 2 Million Children, Study Finds
description: The census of 1990 overlooked more than two million children, many of them poor and in need of Government help, in an undercount that has cost communities and states billions of dollars in Federal aid, a foundation said today.

title: Foreign, Not Far
description: In Paris, the familiar eight-sided red street signs say ''STOP.'' The Academie Francaise, the guardian of linguistic purity, utters not a peep of complaint. But in Montreal, where these matters are deemed crucial to cultural identity, the signs say ''ARRET.''

title: Robert Indiana's Career: Love and American Style
description: You can't think of Robert Indiana without LOVE, the four-letter directive he made so famous as a logo that the United States Government put it on a stamp. Once a star of the Pop movement, known for clever, hard-edged compositions of highly charged words, phrases and numbers, Mr. Indiana's glow dimmed during the late 1960's while that of Andy Warhol and other Pop practitioners brightened.

title: At Last, Liquid Water Is Discovered in Material From Space
description: It is not quite manna from heaven, but NASA scientists yesterday announced the first discovery of liquid water in an object from space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, JOSEPH
description: GOLD-Joseph. You have always taught me to have inner strength and that is what has carried me through many difficult times. Today will require more strength than I ever knew I had. As I think back over the years and all the wonderful times, it makes me feel extremely proud to be Joseph Gold's granddaughter. You always told me to look for the good in people-no matter how hard you had to look. You always had good words for everyone. Just a few weeks ago we celebrated a very special honor bestowed upon you. Receiving the ''French Legion of Honor Medal'' made you so excited and proud. I could write about you for hours but that could never tell of all the wonderful memories I will always cherish. For everyone who was fortunate enough to have you in their lives they already know this. Papa, you will always be in my heart and mind. I love you so and will truly miss you. You always told me to ''never say goodbye, just so long''-so I must now say...so long. I love you, Papa. Semper Fidelis. Your granddaughter, Sheree

title: BRITISH TELECOM BUYS U.S. DIRECTORY PUBLISHER
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C., Britain's largest telephone company, said yesterday that it had bought Yellow Book USA, the New York-based publisher of telephone directories, for $665 million in cash. British Telecommunications said it acquired Yellow Book USA from VS & A Communications Partners II L.P., an affiliate of Veronis, Suhler & Associates, a merchant banking firm that caters to the media and information industries. Yellow Book USA is the largest independent United States publisher of telephone directories, with a portfolio of 300 directories and a circulation of more than 19 million.

title: Theater's Thrill Rides
description: Frank Wood was an unheralded journeyman actor -- I once saw him in an experimental production of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters'' set in, among other places, a Soviet gulag -- until Warren Leight wrote him a scene that would raise him out of obscurity. It comes in the second act of ''Side Man,'' the story of the disintegration of a jazz player's family. The scene is so achingly transfixing that it almost always ends with applause, a rare reward during a straight play.

title: Amid Changes, ABC's Top Programmer Quits
description: Jamie Tarses, who put her stamp on prime-time programming by championing sophisticated, urban and sexy comedies, resigned yesterday as the president of ABC Entertainment, in reaction to a reorganization of the network's entertainment management.

title: Still Furious at Cult, Japan Violates Its Rights
description: Perched 20 feet up atop a rickety awning, Myoshi Kotani peeped through the surrounding cedar trees to get a better view of the shrouded buildings below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASTELLI, LEO
description: CASTELLI-Leo. The American Foundation for AIDS research (amfAR) mourns the passing of Leo Castelli, a driving force in the creation of Art Against AIDS, a decade-long project that raised vital funds for AIDS research. Castelli generously donated his time, energy and expertise to galvanize the support of countless artists, collectors, dealers and major art institutions in the fight against AIDS. The success of Art Against AIDS was due in large part to Leo Castelli's efforts, and his vision and generosity of spirit will be sorely missed. Mathilde Krim, Ph.D. Founding Co-Chair and Chairman of the Board, American Foundation for AIDS Research

title: 5 Umps to Be Cut Abruptly
description: In the middle of three series next week, two in the American League, one in the National, five umpires will disappear. The five are scheduled to umpire Wednesday afternoon in San Francisco and Wednesday night in Baltimore and Detroit, but they are not scheduled to umpire games between the same teams in those cities the next day.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: He Said, She Said, and the Whole Nation Listened
description: Someone had to be lying. During the Senate hearings on Clarence Thomas's nomination to the United States Supreme Court, Anita Hill testified that he had made graphic sexual remarks when he was her boss; he denied the accusations. And as Jane Mayer and Jill Abramson put it in ''Strange Justice,'' their thoroughly reported and trenchant book, ''Two people with such completely contradictory accounts cannot possibly both be telling the truth.''

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Radio Without Static (Or Songs You Despise)
description: WITHIN two years, a radio button next to the familiar ones marked AM and FM may open a world of possibilities to audiophiles on the move.

title: Sharing Ecuador's Debt Burden, but at What Cost?
description: As Ecuador is beginning the struggle to sell a restructuring plan for $6 billion of its debt to global investors, Wall Street is calculating how much the debtholders might lose. And, at the same time, investors are wondering whether this will set a precedent in future debt negotiations between troubled countries and their private creditors.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International Team Breaks Internet Security Codes

title: Why Do Kazakhs Keep Trying to Ship MIG's to North Korea?
description: The sale of about 40 MIG fighter jets to North Korea has set off a diplomatic furor here, including a possible American threat to cut off aid.

title: Bank Called Long Unaware Of Big, Suspicious Transfers
description: Large sums of money were moved through accounts at the Bank of New York for at least six months before the bank was aware of it, according to individuals who have direct knowledge of an investigation into Russian money laundering.

title: Treasuries Fall as Investors Reassess What Fed Might Do
description: Bond prices fell for the first time in a week yesterday as evidence of strong consumer spending and employment caused some investors to doubt whether the Federal Reserve can keep from raising interest rates again this year.

title: INSIDE
description: Tarses Out at ABC

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS. Cocoa prices dropped on expectations that rain will bolster production in Ivory Coast, the world's biggest grower. In New York, cocoa for September delivery fell $41, or 4.5 percent, to $872 a metric ton.

title: Creditors Grant Daewoo New Delay and a Brief Loan
description: Daewoo's South Korean creditors gave the nearly insolvent conglomerate another reprieve today, deferring repayments on debts owed by 12 of its affiliated businesses for three months and providing $700 million in new short-term loans.

title: White-Collar and Dangerous
description: It was a sticky summer evening in June 1998 when I found out just how dangerous it is to poke around the Russian mob. An agent of the organized crime squad in the Manhattan bureau of the Federal Bureau of Investigation called me with chilling news: he had reliable information that a major figure in Russian organized crime had taken out a contract on my life.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the selection of Richard E. Belluzzo, former chief executive of Silicon Graphics, to run the Internet operations of Microsoft, misstated Silicon Graphics' recent financial performance. The company posted a profit in the quarter ended June 30 after seven consecutive quarterly losses. It is not still losing money.

title: SMALLER BRAZIL DEFICIT
description: Brazil's budget deficit narrowed 1.6 percent, to 119 billion reais, or $61.6 billion, in the first half of 1999, largely because of higher proceeds from privatization and taxes. But at the equivalent of 12.1 percent of gross domestic product, the deficit remains a nagging worry to investors worried the Government may have to print more money to cover costs if foreign capital inflows taper off. The primary budget surplus, which does not count interest payments, was 13.6 billion reais for the first 6 months of 1999, within a target agreed upon with the International Monetary Fund.

title: CANFOR AGREES TO BUY JOINT VENTURE OF MEAD AND NEXFOR
description: The Canfor Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Northwood Inc., a pulp and lumber operation jointly owned by the Mead Corporation and Nexfor Inc., for $635 million (Canadian), or about $425 million (United States). Canfor, a forest products company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said the transaction would make it the largest Canadian producer of softwood lumber. The agreement also calls for Canfor to assume Northwood debt of $113 million. Northwood, based in Prince George, British Columbia, owns and operates a pulp mill, four sawmills and a plywood mill, all in British Columbia.

title: Library Users Can't Afford to Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Casino' Market Is a Guessing Game
description: To the Editor:

title: WELLS ALUMINUM SAYS IT IS CONDUCTING MERGER TALKS
description: The Wells Aluminum Corporation, a closely held aluminum producer, said yesterday that it was in merger talks with several companies, whose names it would not disclose. It also said that it had hired the investment bank ING Baring Furman Selz to solicit offers. Wells, based in Baltimore, had profit of $9.8 million on sales of $251.2 million last year. Prices for aluminum, which is used in cars, beverage cans, baseball bats and other consumer goods, hit a five-year low in March, and producers have been merging to cut costs and enter new markets.

title: So Sunny It Seems Un-Russian
description: Recent showings of contemporary ballet from Russia have tended to be disappointing. But there is good news from the Bolshoi Ballet, that cradle of big, bold, dramatic Soviet ballet. The news came in yet another imaginatively conceived Russian dance program produced by David Eden, in a performance by Nina Ananiashvili and principals of the Bolshoi Ballet on Wednesday night in the Ted Shawn Theater at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

title: Scott's Season May Be Over
description: The Giants announced today that Lance Scott, who was expected to start at left guard, tore the medial collateral ligament and damaged the anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee on Tuesday and could miss the entire season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, PAUL J.
description: CARROLL-Paul J., of Boston and Woodstock, Vt., died August 17. Beloved husband of Janet Finnegan; brother of Joan Conley; uncle to Bryne, Sean and Cathleen, all of California. Graduate of Boston Architectural Center; member of the MIT Department of Architecture class of 1951. Practicing architect for 45 years, excelling in designs of affordable housing, environments for the elderly and commercial real estate. Member of the AIA and BSA; a 1956 Rotch Fellow. Memorial service at 11 AM Saturday, September 18, at Our Lady of the Snows Church, Woodstock, Vt.

title: Largest Telescope Sends First Image
description: The new Chandra X-Ray Observatory, which a NASA shuttle placed in Earth orbit last month, has transmitted its first image, confirming that the telescope, larger and more sensitive than any before it, is in excellent health and performing up to expectations. Its first X-ray image shows in striking detail Cassiopeia A, the 320-year-old remnant of an exploding star. This gaseous shell is about 10 light-years in diameter. The Chandra is named for the late American physicist Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, a Nobel laureate who specialized in the evolution of massive stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, LINDA
description: MORSE-Linda. The administrative staff, faculty, house staff and students of the Department of Medicine at the NYU School of Medicine are deeply saddened by the untimely demise of Linda Morse of a long-standing illness with Lupus. She was a fine lady who was a loyal and devoted member of the staff, a dear warm friend and wonderful colleague for many years. She was a talented sculptress and painter. We will miss her. Donations should be sent to the Lupus Foundation, 149 Madison Avenue, Suite 205, NY, New York 10016. Funeral service will be on Saturday, August 28th at 1 P.M., at Dimiceli & Sons, Inc., 182 Lexington Avenue, NYC. Saul J. Farber, MD MACP Rosaleen B. Brady Andrea E. Cody Catherine A. O'Hara Debbie Perez

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICK, HARRY
description: GLICK-Harry. On August 25. Husband of the late Sylvia. Father of the late Lawrence. Loving brother of Helen Simon. Predeceased by brother Sam Glick & sister Roslyn Glick. Religious service today, 11:15 AM, Parkside Memorial Chapels, Queens Boulevard (corner 66th Avenue), Forest Hills.

title: South by Southeast
description: Thai and Vietnamese restaurants are easy to find in New York, while the number of Malaysian restaurants seems to be growing all the time. Not so with Cambodian and Indonesian restaurants, which you can count on the fingers of one hand. Here are a number of restaurants offering the cuisine of Southeast Asia. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Mr. Asimov and others.)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: No one ever woke up and said, ''Let's eat Swedish tonight.'' But then again there was no Ulrika's. Four months ago Ulrika Bengtsson opened a small, rustic restaurant to showcase the homey food she grew up on in Hyltebruk, a tiny town in southern Sweden. She filled the place with Swedish furniture (the barstools have seats that look like buttons), ordered swanky Swedish flatware, put the work of local Swedish artists on the wall and, with her partner and fellow chef, Mimi Claps, got to work behind the stove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, SALLY S.
description: GREENE-Sally S. August 25, 1999 at the age of 90. Beloved wife of the late Joseph L. Loving mother of Toni and Fred Werblow. Cherished grandmother of Eric and LuAnne, and Adam and Rebecca. Adoring great grandmother of Benjamin Joseph and William Frederick. Loving sister of Bert and Hilda Zibelman, Leon and Edith Zibelman, Libby and the late Dr. Arnold Levine, Sadie and the late Nathan Zibelman, the late Kay Silverman, the late Dr. Sam Zibelman and the late Arthur Zibelman.

title: Mademoiselle's Editor Is Leaving at End of Year
description: After striving for nearly six years to make Mademoiselle a must-read magazine for smart women in their 20's, Elizabeth Crow suddenly resigned as editor in chief this week, a resignation her employers at Conde Nast announced yesterday after persuading her to keep working until December.

title: La Vita E Bella (Dubbed)
description: A film with dialogue dubbed from one language into another has always seemed the aural equivalent of a familiar face beneath a bad wig. It's disorienting, and it can be all too hilarious if the talk and the talking heads are sufficiently out of sync. But dubbing can mean much broader exposure for foreign films that might not have wide theatrical distribution or mainstream television audiences if shown with subtitles. So Miramax is releasing a version of ''Life is Beautiful'' with almost all of its Italian dialogue dubbed into English, within reason. This new version stops well short of turning the cries of ''Buon giorno, Principessa!'' into ''Hey, Babe!''

title: Venezuelan Congress Fights Loss of Power
description: Venezuela braced today for a political showdown, as its Congress threatened to meet on Friday in defiance of a new Constitutional Assembly that effectively shut it down and as opposition leaders accused President Hugo Chavez of manipulating the assembly to bring down democratic rule.

title: Got $2,184 and Chutzpah? Well, Then You've Got a Hit
description: BOWFINGER

title: Martin Acquitted of Money Laundering
description: Miami Dolphins wide receiver Tony Martin was acquitted of Federal money-laundering charges today after a jury had deliberated for three days.

title: Tensions Grow After 2 Indians Are Killed
description: There is a shrine of sorts by the road near here, where the bodies of Wilson Black Elk Jr. and Ronald Hard Heart were found on June 8. Fellow Sioux Indians have decorated the spot with offerings of chocolate bars, cigarettes, plastic flowers and eagle feathers and surrounded it with a simple, triangular fence of wood posts and beams, five feet on a side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELS, IDA
description: DANIELS-Ida (Chaika), on August 22, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Joel. Loving aunt of Paul, Sidney, Max, Henry & Minna. Dear cousin of Elaine. Service private.

title: Reno Admits Credibility Loss In Waco Case
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that her credibility has been damaged by new disclosures of the use of pyrotechnic tear-gas canisters on the final day of the 1993 Government standoff with the Branch Davidian cult near Waco, Tex.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGOTT, JANE
description: BIGOTT-Jane. August 25, 1999. Wife of the late Albert L. Bigott II, sister of the late Susan (Dottie) Coughlin. Beloved mother of Susan Cahill, Maureen Mankowski, Albert L. Bigott III and Eileen Neisheim, all of NY. Reposing, John Krtil funeral home, Yorkville Funeral Service Inc., 1297 1st Ave, Friday 2-5 and 7-9 p.m. Mass of Christian burial, Saturday 10:00 A.N. at St. John The Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 Street, NYC. Interment Calvary Cemetary.

title: AIRLINE CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
description: Chiang Hung-i, left, submitted his resignation as chairman of China Airlines, four days after one of the carrier's planes crashed in Hong Kong, killing two people and injuring 211 others, according to a television report in Taiwan. The move came after the Transportation and Communications Minister, Lin Feng-cheng, called for the airline's senior management to resign. Government-owned China Airlines last shuffled its management in April when Sandy Liu became president.

title: Domestic-Violence Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, RAYMOND A.
description: FITZGERALD-Raymond A. On August 25, 1999 at age 75 after a long illness. Loving husband of Alice Ahrens and adored father of Adrienne. Graveside service at 12:00 PM on Saturday, August 28, at Mount Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge, MA. Memorial Mass to be held at St. Joseph's Church of Yorkville at a later date.

title: He Said, She Said
description: ''Strange Justice,'' the thoroughly reported book about the Senate hearings on Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court, is now the basis for one of the slyest, most unexpectedly fascinating television dramas of the year.

title: Banker Is Cleared in Orange County Case
description: A Federal judge in California has dismissed a Securities and Exchange Commission case against a former Dain Rauscher investment banker who was charged with failing to tell investors the risks of buying $800 million in bonds sold by local governments in Orange County, Calif.

title: Mother of Bessette Sisters Asks to Control Their Estates
description: The mother of Carolyn Bessette Kennedy and Lauren Bessette filed court papers in Manhattan yesterday seeking to become the administrator of her daughters' estates. The mother, Anne M. Freeman, also asked to be given the right to file personal-injury and wrongful-death lawsuits in the future against ''unknown'' people or parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEHER, ISABELLE SCHLIVEK
description: FEHER-Isabelle Schlivek, 84, on August 26, 1999, in Charlottesville, VA. (formerly of New York City). Beloved wife of George; loving mother of Ellen Schlossberg and Peter Kinzler and step-daughter Marta Feher. Loving grandmother of Karen, Judy, Samantha, Jason, Valerie & Kit. Great grandmother of Georgia, Kevin & Andrew. A memorial service will be held at the Colonnades in Charlottesville on Sat., Sept. 4 at 3 p.m.

title: Unions and Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Journal; In Canada's 'Lotusland,' Unhappy Is Premier's Lot
description: Inside the hilltop mansion of the Queen's representative here, portraits of the royal family and gleaming gold maple leafs lent a traditional air as Dan Miller was sworn in today as the new Premier of Canada's Pacific province.

title: Nothing to Do but Wait
description: While the line for cabs outside Penn Station is often long, yesterday may have been a record. The 200-foot line for a rare taxi doubled over on itself along Seventh Avenue, but nevertheless looked downright orderly for a crowd of stressed New Yorkers.

title: Above the Flood, Rare Art Books Still Are Destroyed
description: It never occurred to T. Peter Kraus, the owner of Ursus Books, that yesterday's torrential downpour would touch the vast collection of rare art books stored at the rear of his shop in SoHo. That's because the shop and its 100,000 or so volumes are on the third floor of a building at 375 West Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADDING, GEORGE S.
description: RADDING-George S. On August 23rd, 1999, at the age of 83. He loved and was devoted to his wife of fifty-eight years, Jean, his sons, Ronald and Rory, his daughters-inlaw, Jin Suk and Nina, his grandchildren, Ryan and Christopher, and his art. Witty, charming, young in spirit, and a friend to all. A true gentleman. A good man.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE IS BUYING MAKER OF WATER FILTERS
description: The Procter & Gamble Company agreed yesterday to acquire Recovery Engineering Inc., the maker of PUR drinking-water filter systems, for $35.25 a share, or about $213 million. With the exercise of options by Recovery Engineering's management and outside investors, the deal would total $265 million. Shares of Recovery Engineering, which is based in Minneapolis, nearly doubled, gaining $17.125 each, to $34.75. Procter & Gamble fell $2.375, to $100.25. Recovery Engineering had revenue of $77 million in 1998. Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, has annual sales of $38 billion.

title: He's Still Backward, But Nell's Got Moxie
description: Based on the vintage Jay Ward animated series, ''Dudley Do-Right'' attempts to be both zany entertainment for children and nostalgic fun for those who grew up on this and other deft, snarky Ward creations. (Rocky, Bullwinkle and George of the Jungle are other well-loved Ward characters.) And it works pretty well, too.

title: For Lucas, 'Big Game' Becomes Big Deal
description: The myths about the Jets-Giants game include this one: That players have won jobs by doing something special during this exhibition matchup.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOFFETT, LEE
description: MOFFETT-Lee ('54-'93). The comprehension of love and its loss is one of life's challenges. Be in peace, my angel. Love, Scott

title: The Day Rain Crippled New York
description: New Yorkers are prepared for the city to come to a standstill in a blizzard or even a midsummer blackout. But a rainstorm? As Council Speaker Peter Vallone put it yesterday, speaking for a bewildered city, ''Today we had three inches of rain, and millions of people could not get to work. Unbelievable.''

title: Commercials in Class
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: That's No Dog, That's a Member

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Jones Sidelined Indefinitely
description: Marion Jones will race no more at the world track and field championships. The question now is: when will she race again?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, CHAIM
description: DIAMOND-Chaim. Touro College mourns the passing of Mr. Chaim Diamond, a longtime member of its Board of Trustees. He was a man of vision and incandescent intellect and personality who survived the Holocaust to build a successful new life in this country. Mr. Diamond served with distinction in helping guide Touro's growth over the decades. His insight and commitment to Judaism and higher education will be missed by Touro College and his loss is mourned by his family and many friends. Dr. Bernard Lander, Pres. Dr. Mark Hasten, Chairman of the Board.

title: Researchers Demonstrate Computer Code Can Be Broken
description: An international team of researchers demonstrated this week that it was possible to break the security codes commonly used to protect financial transactions over the Internet.

title: Miami Drug Ring Arrests Raise Alarm About Airport Security
description: WASHINGTON  The arrests of dozens of American Airline employees and other workers at Miami International Airport for their alleged roles in a huge drug and weapons smuggling operation has raised questions about security not only in Miami but also at other airports, officials and analysts said.

title: SULZER TO CUT JOBS
description: Struggling to reverse falling profit at its industrial operations, Sulzer A.G. of Switzerland said it would eliminate 2,000 jobs.
