Sulzer said it planned to realign its industrial activities to focus on businesses that supply the oil, gas and chemical sectors. The job cuts will be completed by the end of 2001. The move comes as the company reported a 20 percent slide in operating income for the first-half of the year. Analysts applauded the plan and the company's stock jumped.

title: A Boy. A Dog. You Know The Rest.
description: Some sugarcoating is only to be expected in a family movie. But when that film is clogged with sticky-sweet pieties cooed to saucer-eyed tots, the product can be difficult to swallow. Virtually every other sentence out of the mouths of the nice grown-ups in ''A Dog of Flanders,'' the story of a boy, his dog and his dream of being a great painter in early 19th-century Flanders, is advice about following your dream, realizing that money doesn't buy happiness and making sure that whatever you do in life is done with ''heart.'' Uplifting sentiments, to be sure, but when they're plied as relentlessly as they are here, they begin to create blockage.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Magazine Publishers Name a New Chief
description: The Magazine Publishers of America named Nina B. Link president and chief executive yesterday, succeeding Donald D. Kummerfeld, who is retiring.

title: Campanile Wins Turf Writers Cup
description: Blythe Miller rode Campanile to his third straight victory when the 5-year-old gelding won the 58th running of the New York Turf Writers Cup, a steeplechase that was run as the feature on the 10-race program yesterday at Saratoga Race Course.

title: Wicks Must Stand Tall for Liberty in the Playoffs
description: Sue Wicks, a power forward for the Liberty, has a deceptively soft, ethereal quality about her.

title: Corretja Reaches The Quarterfinals
description: Perhaps there are other things Alex Corretja of Spain would like to be remembered for, but his four-hour, five-set quarterfinal loss to Pete Sampras in the 1996 United States Open will do for now.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Monday about the 17th Annual African World Festival in Detroit misstated the location of one dancer and misidentified another. Jore McKinney, 18, was the dancer at the left. The other was Ian LeBlac, not Ms. McKinney's twin sister, Sienna.

title: At Young Gang Victim's Funeral, Cries for Change
description: Kelvin McGinnis was not in a gang, unless you could count the school marching band in which he played the drums. But that mattered little to the gang members who, the police said, tried to settle a score with rivals by spraying bullets at Kelvin's Brooklyn housing project last week.

title: A Challenge Looms for Stevenson: Expectation
description: A group of curious fans crowded the court exit on Tuesday and craned their necks to catch one more glimpse of the new It Girl on the tennis scene, Alexandra Stevenson. She's the 18-year-old wonder from Wimbledon who drew coos for her curtsies, raves for her serve and stares from those stunned to find out her father is Julius Erving.

title: Sports of The Times; A Kinder And Gentler Bill Parcells
description: BILL PARCELLS looks fit and rested and, you might be tempted to think, almost content. Nevertheless, he keeps the pressure on his Jets. The theme for this season is Start Over. Last season the Jets went to the conference championship game. Last season does not count.

title: Finally, Clinton Relaxes
description: After a couple of days of relative languor, President Clinton resumed his recreational activities today, riding horses in the morning with his daughter, Chelsea, and playing two rounds of golf this afternoon before attending a clambake tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIDEN, JOSEPH
description: FEIDEN-Joseph. Beloved husband of the late Jewel Eliasberg Feiden. Cherished father of Margo Feiden, owner of the Margo Feiden Galleries Ltd. Died August 26, 1999 at the home of his daughter after a long illness. Brother of the late Raymond Feiden, Martin Feiden and Sally Baker. Loving father-in-law of the late Julius Cohen. He is also survived by his adored grandchildren Bambi and Jeremy, brother The Hon. Murray T. Feiden, former Brooklyn Supreme Court Judge, and loving nephews and nieces. Funeral Service will be held on Friday, 2PM at Knollwood Park Cemetery. The family wishes to thank Dr. Mark Lieb, Vena Lewis, and the Cabrini Hospice.

title: Washington Memo; Appointment Heats Up A Diplomatic Rivalry
description: They have promised each other to be on their best behavior, not to make their famous rivalry the stuff of American foreign policy for the next 18 months.

title: The Urban Un-Jungle
description: To the ordinary ear, the rules on keeping animals in New York City always seemed perfectly clear. Pets must not be ''wild, ferocious, fierce, dangerous or naturally inclined to do harm,'' the Health Department code advised for decades. Over time, however, some residents found such language soft and fuzzy enough to allow creatures that were undomesticated even for the streets of New York. Six adult alligators, for example, once were found living in a Brooklyn brownstone. One renter left behind a python in her apartment bathtub. Then officials nabbed an illegal rooster in the Bronx that might well have escaped detection had it not also broken the city's noise ordinance every morning at dawn.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about merchants who are feeling the effect of China's decision to bar United States Navy ships from Hong Kong misspelled the given name of the lead character in a 1960 movie about the port. She was Suzie Wong, not Suzy.

title: About New York; If a Judge Gets Out of Line: Seeking a Cure
description: OVER the decades, the spartan courtrooms of the sprawling Manhattan Criminal Courts Building have played host to a number of judges infamous for their eccentricity, despotism or breathtaking arrogance. Their reputations, whether deserved or not, became legendary among the prosecutors and defense lawyers who had to tiptoe in court to avoid the reverberations of the gavel.

title: Easy to Confuse a Computer, But Tougher to Defeat One
description: Science fiction aside, there is no evidence that computers are trying to take over the world. But they are making a first, hesitant effort to take over the bridge world: next week in London seven computer programs will play in a two-day individual contest together with a lone human being.

title: Rain Alone Didn't Stop the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown Will Start for Giants
description: Gary Brown will start at running back for the Giants when they face the Jets tonight. It will be his first preseason appearance. Giants Coach Jim Fassel said he would like to get Brown, who had to undergo surgery in training camp because of a badly bruised buttock, as many as 10 rushing attempts.

title: Too Much Government?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASLUN, NORMAN E. JR.
description: HASLUN-Norman E. Jr. Of Park Ridge, NJ, age 69, lost his brave struggle against cancer on August 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Dundorf). Loving father and golf partner of Norman III. Much-loved brother of Marjorie H. Leonard and dear stepfather of Kristine Parry and Robert and Douglas Wilson. Loving stepgrandfather of Jillian and Marlene Parry and Bryan and Amy Wilson. Norm had a long, distinguished career in the plumbing supply and advertising display industries. Visiting at First Congregational Church, 131 Pascack Road, Park Ridge, New Jersey 07656 on Saturday, August 28, 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Service at the Church on Sunday, August 29 at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the First Congregational Church Park Ridge Memorial Garden Fund or the American Cancer Society. For information Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, N.J.

title: Raymond Vernon, a Shaper Of Global Trade, Dies at 85
description: Raymond Vernon, who helped shape the postwar system of international trade as a Government official and influenced thinking about the global economy as a scholar, died on Thursday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85.

title: Journal; And the Winner Is . . . George W. Bush
description: A bump in the road, a setback, a boon to his primary opponents? Puh-LEEZE! The people who dourly predicted dark consequences from George W. Bush's ''mishandling'' of Snortgate were the same geniuses who predicted Bill Clinton's imminent demise 20 months ago. After the avalanche of insinuations that the Texas Governor might have used cocaine and is now engaged in a cover-up, Mr. Bush is in fact, in the words of his campaign adviser Ralph Reed, ''better off'' than he was before the firestorm started. Far from bungling his first encounter with adversity, the front-runner handled it like a master.

title: Applicants for Police Test Are Down Despite Big Drive
description: The largest Police Department recruitment drive ever fell far short of matching even the responses of recent years, but officials said yesterday that they would still consider the campaign a success if most of those who did sign up turn out to be city residents.

title: U.S. Warns Indonesia Over Political Violence
description: President Clinton has warned the President of Indonesia that relations with the United States will be seriously damaged if there is mass violence during next week's referendum on self-rule in East Timor, senior Administration officials said today. The United States effectively has veto power over international loans to Indonesia.

title: Order in Venezuela
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians See Politics in Bank Scandal
description: In the through-the-looking-glass world of Russian society, a high-flying businessman's emergence in a money laundering investigation in the United States has not ruined his career. It has made him a celebrity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, LESTER
description: SMITH-Lester, of Waterford, NY, formerly of New York City. Proud ex-USMC, his humor and intellect appreciated by many. Always there when you needed him. Husband of the late Barbara; father of Bruce, Susan and Randy. Graveside service 11AM Sunday at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens. Contributions to St. Peter's Hospital, Albany.

title: MURDOCH LOOKS AT GERMAN CABLE TV
description: The world's fifth-largest media company, the News Corporation, said it was interested in Deutsche Telekom A.G.'s entire cable television network, the largest in Europe. Details of the company's approach were not disclosed, and Deutsche Telekom declined to comment. The cable business serves 18 million homes. Deutsche Telekom is selling the network to allay European antitrust concerns. The News Corporation, which is headed by Rupert Murdoch, has satellite television holdings in Britain, Asia and Latin America. It has been trying to expand in continental Europe.

title: Commuters Are Back on Track, but a Rainstorm's Fallout Continues
description: As subway and rail lines returned to normal yesterday, transit officials were confronted with lingering anger and questions about why they were so ill-equipped to handle the deluge of rain that paralyzed regional transportation Thursday.

title: Sports of The Times; Doctor J's Amazing Free Pass
description: ON the ninth day of Wimbledon, Alexandra Stevenson sat behind a dais, as isolated as a new kid in the cafeteria. And people stared. Around the world, they inspected her features as closely as fine print. Was there a resemblance? Was she Dr. J's love child?

title: Father Mario Zicarelli, 78, Backer of Secular Education
description: The Rev. Mario Zicarelli, a Roman Catholic priest whose parishioners protested his transfer out of the Bronx in 1972 after he publicly supported secular education, died Aug. 25 in a hospital in Nyack, N.Y. He was 78.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''With grief in our soul, we're abandoning a piece of Russia, abandoning something we constructed in space, and it's unclear what we'll build next.''

title: CALPINE, A POWER PRODUCER, TO ADD COGENERATION
description: The Calpine Corporation, an independent power producer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire an 80 percent stake in the Cogeneration Corporation of America for about $145 million. Calpine said it would pay $25 a share in cash for the interest in the Minneapolis company, which operates cogeneration plants that produce electricity and steam energy from natural gas. Cogeneration's stock soared 39 percent, rising $6.625 each, to $23.4375. Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., said the acquisition would increase its energy output.

title: Gun Control Gains in California
description: California, the scene of the latest shooting spree by a deranged gunman, continues to move far out ahead of Washington and the rest of the country on the issue of gun control. The gun safety measures that Gov. Gray Davis signed into law yesterday were the latest in a series of initiatives that can only shame -- and with any luck will inspire -- an indifferent Congress that is nowhere near agreement on a far more modest package of reforms.

title: A Theater for All
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSTON CHICKEN AND LENDERS END TALKS ABOUT SALE
description: Boston Chicken Inc. and its lenders ended talks yesterday about a proposed sale of the company's restaurants to the Texas entrepreneur Jack Baum. Mr. Baum and a group of unidentified institutional investors offered $105 million in cash and would have assumed $35 million in debt, to acquire Boston Chicken's 865 Boston Markets restaurants in 33 states and Washington. The decision to end the talks follows a United States Bankruptcy Court ruling earlier this month that Boston Chicken could not develop a plan to sell its assets without involving lenders who are financing company operations. Boston Chicken, meanwhile, said its lenders were also working with a number of other groups who have expressed an interest in buying the company.

title: Smothering All Counterplay, Khalifman Retakes the Lead
description: Aleksandr Khalifman of Russia got right back into the lead on Thursday night by smoothly defeating Vladimir Akopian of Armenia in the fourth game of their International Chess Federation Match at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas, Nev. The score is now Khalifman 2 1/2, Akopian 1 1/2. One more victory or two draws will give Khalifman the title.

title: After a Space Jaunt, He's Odd, but He Loves His Wife
description: ''The Astronaut's Wife'' arrived yesterday in a veil of mystery. How could a thriller starring Johnny Depp and Charlize Theron be so bad that New Line Cinema, which has been in no hurry to release this film, would not risk screening in advance for the press?

title: NORTHEAST STATES SOFTENING STANCE ON AIR STANDARDS
description: After years of battling over smokestack pollution that blows from the Midwest and the South, Northeastern states, led by New York, have signaled for the first time a willingness to retreat from their demands that other states significantly reduce their emissions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, ALLAN
description: GEORGE-Allan. 28 August 1979. It is 20 years ago today and I miss you more than ever. An extraordinary man of great intellect and marvelous humor. Kind, loving, witty, you brought light into the lives of all who knew you. With love, your daughter

title: Kampala Journal; A Sigh of Relief for a Royal Walk Down the Aisle
description: The King was growing wide in the middle, and his people began to worry: when would he get married and make an heir? Then the sniping started. Some of his aunts even claimed that the King was not the true heir to the throne.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: MIDDLE EAST

title: Where Does Generation Y Go to Shop?; 70 Million Young Buyers Without a Thing to Wear
description: When Tony Shellman steps outside the midtown Manhattan offices of Enyce, a small clothing designer, he never knows what his trend-spotting antennae will hone in on.

title: G.M. Finance Unit in Deal
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the finance unit of the General Motors Corporation, said yesterday that it would take over the operations of Nippon Asset Management Inc., which was formerly known as the Japan Leasing Corporation. Japan Leasing was affiliated with Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, which was deemed insolvent and nationalized last year. Japan Leasing sold most of its business to the GE Capital Corporation in January and changed its name to Nippon Asset Management Inc.

title: Think Tank; New York, N.Y.: They Say It's a Wonderful Place
description: New York City has always drawn writers, musicians, artists and intellectuals, and they in turn seem never to tire of talking about it. A sampling of what some have said can be found at an exhibition at the New-York Historical Society, aptly titled ''Yadda, Yadda, Yadda: Quotes About New York.''

title: Passenger Killed as Taxi Crashes Into Midtown Building
description: A passenger was killed yesterday afternoon when her taxi jumped a curb and smashed into an office building in midtown Manhattan, sending scores of terrified pedestrians running for safety, the police said. No pedestrians were hurt.

title: Russian Says Officials Funneled Cash to Bank in Laundering Case
description: A powerful Russian industrialist whose empire is under investigation in the money laundering inquiry at the Bank of New York said yesterday that a large part of the billions of dollars moved through the bank was controlled by Russian officials protecting their fortunes by shipping their money abroad before Russian markets collapsed last year.

title: FORTIS PROFIT SOARS
description: Belgium's biggest financial services company, Fortis, said its first-half profit rose 31 percent, beating expectations, as life insurance acquisitions aided growth in its home market. Net income rose to 1.16 billion euros ($1.22 billion), from 886 million euros a year earlier. Fortis predicted full-year profit would rise between 20 percent and 25 percent, though it did not say why earnings growth might slow in the second half. Fortis has expanded its insurance activities, which offer more stable earnings than banking, by buying companies in Belgium and the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDFEIN, PAULINE R.
description: GOLDFEIN-Pauline R. It is now 16 years since you left. Your memory has not faded. Your family and friends still miss you very much. Phil

title: U.P.S. Shifting Cargo to Trucks
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc., the largest United States package-delivery company, said today that it had increased the amount of freight it is sending on trucks instead of on the rail lines of the former Conrail Inc. because of growing delays.

title: CANAL PLUS ITALIAN UNIT
description: Europe's biggest pay-television company, Canal Plus S.A., is in talks to sell about 30 percent of its unprofitable Italian unit, Telepiu S.p.A., to the state electric utility Enel S.p.A. It is also talking to a group of Italian banks about selling a further stake, officials said. While Canal Plus and Enel have not agreed on the stake's size, a 30 percent holding could be valued about 1 trillion lire ($540 million), the officials said.

title: A Mentor in Science To Lead Stuyvesant High
description: An assistant principal at Stuyvesant High School who once guided students' entries in the nation's most prestigious science contest has been named principal of the school, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of the Media Business page yesterday about the appointment of Nina B. Link as president and chief executive of the Magazine Publishers of America misstated the name of her employer. Ms. Link is group president for publishing and interactive software at the Children's Television Workshop, not the Children's Television Network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, ROBERT E.
description: O'DONNELL-Robert E., SJ, Reverend. Of Morristown, NJ, Friday, August 27, 1999. Brother of Rev. James A. O'Donnell, SJ, of Ateneo de Manila, Philippines. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Tuesday, August 31, 1999, at the Church of the Assumption, Morristown, NJ, 8 PM. Hours of visitation at Loyola House of Retreats, 161 James Street, Morristown, NJ, Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM; Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM; and Tuesday, 2-5 PM. Information, contact Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Avenue, Morristown, New Jersey.

title: Greene and Miller Win 200-Meter Gold in Spain
description: Maurice Greene drove all the way from the Kansas City area to Los Angeles to train with John Smith on the campus of U.C.L.A.; Inger Miller had to drive only a few miles west. But they both had to say goodbye to someone special to get to the same place, and tonight the two American sprinters got the same reward: a gold medal in the 200 meters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTERS, LILLIAN
description: WINTERS-Lillian. Our darling Lillian, who was loved so very much by so many. Herman, Mark and Warren. Service Sunday, August 29 at 7 PM, Temple Beth Torah, Humble, TX. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to Save the Children, PO Box 940, Westport, CT. 06881-9948. New York service to be announced.

title: NETRIX SETS ACQUISITION OF OPENROUTE NETWORKS
description: The Netrix Corporation, a provider of voice and data-networking products, agreed yesterday to acquire Openroute Networks Inc. for about $64 million in stock. Netrix, based in Herndon, Va., said it would combine its Internet telephone products with Openroute's Internet security products to offer customers private voice and data networks. Openroute is based in Westborough, Mass. Under the deal, each Openroute share will be exchanged for one Netrix common share.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Little Tribe, Casino Threatened, Battles U.S.
description: A tiny Indian tribe in a sparse slice of northeastern Nebraska found itself today at the forefront of an increasingly heated national debate over the matter of where tribal sovereignty ends and state control begins.

title: Doris R. Schwartz, 84, a Nurse Who Advanced Geriatric Care
description: Doris R. Schwartz, a nurse who did some of the earliest research on geriatric nursing care and whose findings led to improvements in health care for the elderly, died on Sunday at her home in Gwynedd, Pa.

title: Singapore Investor Settles Trading Charge
description: The owner of a Singapore brokerage firm has agreed to pay $2.25 million to settle insider trading charges that he profited from securities of APL Ltd. that he bought shortly before the company announced it would be acquired.

title: HUTCHISON PLANS SALES
description: The overseas flagship company of the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing said it planned to sell more of its businesses to create value for its shareholders. The company, Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., will spin off its 46.7 percent interest in a mobile network operator in Israel, the Partner Communications Company, in the United States this fall. The share sale will raise about $500 million, according to an Israeli newspaper. The company also plans to sell shares in its 49 percent stake in Husky Oil Ltd., an oil and gas company in Canada, although not immediately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, PAULINE (KESSLER)
description: BROWN-Pauline (Kessler), on August 25, 1999, of Needham, MA, formerly of New York City. Beloved Wife of the late Harold M. Brown. Devoted Mother of Marion Just, and the late Tobia Frankel. Dear Grandmother of David Frankel, Margot Frankel Goldberg, Jonathan Frankel, Sara Just Treacy, Marjorie Just Skatoff, & Thomas Just, and Great-Grandmother of Jason & Julia. Graveside Services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY on Sunday, August 29, 1999 at 1:00 PM. Memorial observance will be at the home of Marion Just through Tuesday evening. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be donated to Recording for the Blind. For information, contact Schlossberg & Solomon Memorial Chapel, Canton, MA.

title: 'Don't Ask' Violates Free-Speech Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Charged In Narcotics Case
description: Capping years of investigation in a case that has roiled relations with Mexico, United States prosecutors today detailed a 25-count narcotics and money laundering indictment of Mario Ruiz Massieu, a former deputy Attorney General in Mexico who was arrested in New Jersey in 1995.

title: Rain Alone Didn't Stop the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: An Incandescent Coney Island of the Mind
description: In the all-too-brief best of times at Coney Island, elephants in jeweled blankets sat on their tails and waved their plump forelegs in the warm Atlantic breeze.

title: Mortgage? Mexicans Sign Up for Monthly Raffle
description: When Javier Zavala and his wife, Jenny, began thinking about buying a house, they did not bother going to a bank to talk about getting a mortgage.

title: Another Favorite Falls Shorts
description: Banshee Breeze, the defending filly champion and the winner of seven of her last eight races, joined the long list of beaten favorites at Saratoga Race Course yesterday when she was outrun by Beautiful Pleasure by 2i lengths in the Personal Ensign Handicap.

title: Chancellor Is Considering University Post in Seattle
description: The University of Washington is trying to recruit the New York City Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, to head a new research institute, and Dr. Crew acknowledged yesterday that he was interested in the job.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SFX ENTERTAINMENT INC., New York, the world's largest producer of live entertainment, completed its purchase of most of the assets of Livent Inc., Toronto, the financially troubled theater production company, for about $96 million in cash and future payments.

title: Ex-Detective Is Killed In a Shootout
description: A 69-year-old retired police detective who was working as a security guard was killed in a shootout yesterday morning with suspected robbers outside a meatpacking company in the Bronx, officials said.

title: Rain Alone Didn't Stop the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, LINDA
description: MORSE-Linda. The administrative staff, faculty, house staff and students of the Department of Medicine at the NYU School of Medicine are deeply saddened by the untimely demise of Linda Morse of a long-standing illness with Lupus. She was a fine lady who was a loyal and devoted member of the staff, a dear warm friend and wonderful colleague for many years. She was a talented sculptress and painter. We will miss her. Donations should be sent to the Lupus Foundation, 149 Madison Avenue, Suite 205, NY, New York 10016. Funeral service will be on Saturday, August 28th at 1 P.M., at Dimiceli & Sons, Inc., 182 Lexington Avenue, NYC. Saul J. Farber, MD MACP Rosaleen B. Brady Andrea E. Cody Catherine A. O'Hara Debbie Perez

title: Too Much Government?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALAST, JOHN
description: MALAST-John. Retired Captain NYPD. Of Little Neck, New York. On August 25, 1999. Husband of the late Mary A. Malast. Beloved father of Maryann Rubel and John Malast. Brother of Irene Malast. Also survived by two grandchildren. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway & Northern Blvd., Little Neck, NY, Saturday & Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered in St. Anastasia R.C. Church Monday at 10:45 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: United We Fall
description: Last week's vote by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America to move toward closer cooperation with the Episcopalians represents another unfortunate step down the blind alley of ecumenism. If these denominations hoped that such actions can stanch the hemorrhaging of their members, I can't imagine a less productive strategy.

title: Mideast Peace Prospects
description: Israel and the Palestinians are close to agreement on a timetable for carrying out last year's Wye River peace agreement. Similar progress is now needed in reviving talks between Israel and Syria, which have been suspended for more than three years. Since Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, took office in early July, Israel and Syria have been talking through intermediaries like Jordan and the United States. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright should use her visits to Jerusalem and Damascus next week to speed the resumption of face-to-face talks.

title: RESIGNATION POSTPONED
description: The board of the Taiwan carrier China Airlines has decided to delay a decision on the resignation of its chairman until after the investigation into a recent crash is concluded. The chairman, Chiang Hung-i, whose resignation was reported on Thursday, said yesterday, ''My resignation has been temporarily postponed until the results of the investigation are known.'' Government officials have said top managers at China Airlines could lose their jobs as a result of the crash Sunday in Hong Kong in which 3 people died and more than 200 were injured.

title: Umpires May Strike, So Both Sides Prepare
description: The league presidents and umpires were busy on the strike front yesterday, all acting in anticipation of an event that may never occur.

title: In a Deluge, Treasures Turn Into Pulp
description: The C's were the soggiest. The Caravaggios, Carpaccios and Canalettos -- they had been directly beneath Thursday's indoor rainstorm at Ursus Books, a store for rare art books in SoHo.

title: Bush, Usually Opponent of Gun Control, Backs 2 Restrictions Proposed in Congress
description: Winding up a campaign fund-raising trip in a region stunned by recent bloodshed, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said in Georgia today that he supported two gun-control measures that have been proposed in Congress.

title: ALLIED CARPETS TAKEOVER BATTLE
description: A battle for control of Allied Carpets Group P.L.C. of Britain was set into motion as Saint-Maclou, a French carpet retailer, said it was negotiating to buy the company for $:77 million ($122 million), topping an offer on Thursday by Wassall P.L.C. Saint-Maclou is offering 85 pence a share in cash, which is a 21 percent premium over the company's closing price on Monday, when the bidding began. Wassall offered 80 pence a share. Allied Carpets, Britain's second-largest carpet retailer, said it was considering its options. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Crisis Recedes In Hong Kong, With Economy Back in Black
description: Fifteen months after it spiraled downward into its worst recession in a generation, Hong Kong said today that its economy had stormed back to positive growth in the second quarter this year.

title: CRYSTAL GAS SHARES CLIMB AS SALE IS STUDIED
description: The shares of Crystal Gas Storage Inc. rose 15 percent after the company said it hired an investment bank to help it find ways to raise its share price and was considering selling itself. Shares rose $5.375 each, to $40.125, on the American Stock Exchange. At that price the company has a market value of almost $110 million. Crystal Gas owns and operates two natural gas storage sites near Hattiesburg, Miss., and holds various gas properties, mainly in Arkansas and Louisiana. The company, based in Shreveport, La., hired Goldman Sachs Group Inc. as its adviser.

title: Dotel Bounces Back By Dominating Arizona
description: The seesaw was due to be up for Octavio Dotel, to bounce the rookie pitcher up high after a troubled start. By Bobby Valentine's theory, a young pitcher who throws adeptly in one game is likely to be awful in the next. Emotion and adrenaline combine with the physical and mental toll that a sterling outing can exact on those too inexperienced to know how to cope, and Dotel's recent history proved Valentine's premise.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Says Stocks Influence Inflation Talks

title: Kenny Dorham's Legacy: Hard Bop and Sly Blues
description: Jazz musicians love challenges, and the trumpeter Kenny Dorham, who died in 1972, had a gift for providing them. In the 1950's, Dorham's compositions were definitive hard bop: while some were sly blues variants, others stretched and bent standard structures, put underlying rhythms through improbable transitions and pushed be-bop's choppy syncopations even further. As a soloist, he made his own tunes sound easy, breezing past their odd curves and crevices.

title: After '98 Rally, Harlem Isn't Eager for Repeat
description: Last year, as controversy mounted over an approaching rally called the Million Youth March, Harlem's elected officials, clergy members, youth workers and business leaders, despite grave doubts about the event, pulled together an ad-hoc committee to provide vital support like parade marshals, medical and rest facilities and even supplies of bottled water for the vast crowd of demonstrators that was expected.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCOT, SANDRA A.
description: LUCOT-Sandra A. On August 26, 1999. Devoted partner and friend of Jeanette Bishop. Loving daughter of Mary Trich. Dear sister of James, Edward and Eugene Lucot. Beloved aunt of Joseph Lucot and other nieces and nephews. Visitation at the Della Noce & Sons Funeral Home, 322 South High St. on Sunday, 6-9:00 PM. Funeral Mass to be held in St. Leo's Church, Monday 10:00 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Falls Road SPCA, Baltimore, MD.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Aug. 19 about the grading of health care plans by the National Committee for Quality Assurance included an erroneous report from the committee about the kinds of inoculations received by patients in the Kaiser Permanente plan in Denver and the Cigna plan in Cleveland. The Kaiser plan provided a booster shot for measles, mumps and rubella, three hepatitis B vaccinations and one chicken pox vaccination to about 50 percent of its patients by age 13; the figure for the Cigna plan was less than 1 percent. The figures did not refer solely to shots for measles, mumps and rubella.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Smoke From Indonesia Fires Again Threatens the Region
description: Hundreds of man-made fires are burning again in remote areas of Indonesia, blackening vast areas of rain forest and sending pungent smoke across several countries.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY THE COLLEGE KICKOFF
description: Wide receiver Peter Warrick might be the best player and his Florida State Seminoles might be the best team, too, as college football begins another season. But the Seminoles have plenty of competition, not the least of which is in their own state. During the 1990s, Florida and Miami have combined with Florida State to win 273 games and one national championship each. As usual, all three teams will play rigorous schedules, assuring that, at the least, they will have a say in who plays for the national title. SPORTSSUNDAY

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN AND EURO MIXED. The dollar was basically flat against the yen and the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 111.56 yen, up from 111.54 on Thursday, and the euro traded at $1.0459, up from $1.0445.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Khakpour to Miss Game Against Clash
description: Injury problems continue to plague the MetroStars. They will play tonight in San Jose against the Clash without Mohammad Khakpour, their best defender, who sprained his left ankle in practice and did not accompany the team on its last trip of the season.

title: It's the Irish to the Rescue Of a Festival's Eclecticism
description: Classical ballet seemed to be taking a firm hold on the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival this week, with performances scheduled indoors and out by new young dancers and old hands like the group of principals from the Bolshoi and Kirov Ballets organized by the Bolshoi star Nina Ananiashvili. But the Sean Curran Company arrived in time to preserve the festival's reputation for eclecticism, opening at the Doris Duke Studio Theater on Thursday in a modern dance program that included the world premiere of Mr. Curran's ''Six Laments.''

title: Uncle Sam's Dirty Water
description: To the Editor:

title: There Is No Joy in Toms River as Its Little Stars Bow Out
description: The Beast of the East was knocked down with one devastating swing of the bat today, and it did not get back up. Phenix City, Ala., scored three runs in the second inning to earn a 3-2 victory over Toms River, N.J., pulling off the biggest upset of the Little League World Series tournament.

title: Nasdaq Offers Systems for Use After Hours
description: The Nasdaq stock market said today that it would make its trade reporting and quotation systems available to organizations that intend to offer after-hours opportunities to buy and sell stocks.

title: Senator Told to Stay Out Of New York's Business
description: Gov. George E. Pataki called Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey ''wrong'' yesterday for asking the Federal Government to examine more closely a New York Indian tribe's proposal to build a casino at Monticello Raceway, in the Catskills.

title: Fish Farms Breed Fight Over a Way of Life
description: This is a fish story, but not the familiar elemental battle of man against the sea.

title: An Anti-Milosevic Leader Tries for a Comeback
description: Zoran Djindjic has been refining his plans, and there have been a lot of them, but he now seems ready to roll the dice to try to oust President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.

title: Phelps Dodge Opens Hostile Bid for Smaller Rivals
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, one of the world's largest mining companies, said yesterday that it was embarking on a hostile takeover of two smaller rivals, Asarco Inc. and Cyprus Amax Minerals, after they rebuffed an initial offer last week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LITTON, GLORIA BREVETTI
description: LITTON-Gloria Brevetti. Dear sister, after ten years, your children prosper and honor your memory, and we cling to our memory of your loving kindness, courage, laugh and sweet face. Laura, Virginia and Gig

title: BP AMOCO FABRICS UNIT TO SELL OPERATIONS
description: BP Amoco P.L.C.'s fabrics unit said yesterday that it planned to sell its fibers and yarns operations to Monitor Clipper Partners for about $100 million. The unit, Amoco Fabrics and Fibers, said the fibers and yarns business has headquarters in Greenville, S.C., and about 1,000 employees. It makes polypropylene yarn and fibers for household, automotive, clothing and industrial uses. A BP Amoco spokesman said ''almost all'' employees would be offered positions with the new company, which will be called American Fibers and Yarns. Amoco Fabrics and Fibers said the sale would enable it to focus on its core business of woven and nonwoven polypropylene fabrics. Monitor Clipper Partners is a private equity fund based in Cambridge, Mass.

title: BRAZILIAN EXCHANGE EXTENDS HOURS
description: In an effort to recover trading volume that has migrated to the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market, the Sao Paulo stock exchange will extend trading hours into the evening starting next month. The exchange, Latin America's largest, will allow electronic trading from 6 P.M. to 10 P.M. By catering to investors and brokerage firms that have begun trading stocks on line, the exchange hopes to offset the effect of a tax on financial transactions that has sapped volume. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERROL, EDWARD
description: BERROL-Edward. Of Manhattan. Beloved husband of Selma Cantor Berrol, father of Philip Berroll and Ann Berrol Newman, grandfather of Tracy Newman. Honors graduate of Morris High School, City College, and Columbia University. Senior Vice President of Ogilvy & Mather/Worldwide. A gentlemen of New York, at home in the world. Funeral to be held at The Riverside Chapel, 76th. St. & Amsterdam Ave. 12:15 Sunday.

title: Will TV Stage Live Crash of Jumbo Jet for Thrill of It? F.A.A. Says No, but Stay Tuned
description: It seemed too bizarre to be true: a television network collaborating with a Federal agency to send a multimillion-dollar 747 jumbo jet hurtling out of the sky to crash on the desert floor, for a live broadcast, hoping to attract the biggest rubber-necking crowd ever.

title: Hurricane Dennis Churns Toward Coastal Areas of Southeast
description: Carrying a potential to strengthen significantly, Hurricane Dennis moved toward the Southeast coast today as residents from Florida to North Carolina prepared and simply waited.

title: 'Don't Ask' Violates Free-Speech Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Brushes Up Two Elder Museums
description: Two neglected jewels of the museum world will close here in January for a $60 million, three-year-long renovation during which many of their treasures will tour the country.

title: 5 Rookies Cut by Jets Before Test Vs. Giants
description: The sense of seriousness, if not urgency, heightened this morning on the Jets when the Turk came early and cut five rookies and a second-year player.

title: Lawrie and Franco Grab Attention From Big Names
description: Tiger Woods and Sergio Garcia grabbed their share of the attention today, but Paul Lawrie and Carlos Franco each grabbed a share of the lead.

title: In Basketball Heaven, All Summer Long; Home-Grown Tournaments Lure Street Legends and College Stars
description: ''I got $4.75 we win today. I got $4.75 in my pocket. Any bets? Any bets?''

title: CLARIANT EARNINGS FLAT
description: The world's biggest specialty chemical maker, Clariant A.G., said its first-half profit was little changed, beating expectations, as it cut costs to make up for falling demand. Clariant said net income for the six months was little changed at 260 million Swiss francs ($170 million), compared with 261 million francs a year earlier. Improved profitability in three divisions and reduced expenses also helped Clariant overcome a 5 percent drop in sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, SARAH H.
description: FEINBERG-Sarah H. Survived by her nephew Paul Witkowsky and family of Radford, Virginia, and niece Victoria Feinberg of Port Jefferson Station, New York.

title: Organizers Sue, Saying Giuliani Ignored Court Ruling in Refusing a Permit
description: The organizers of a planned youth rally in Harlem sued the city in Federal court yesterday, saying that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's refusal to grant them a permit for the event ignored an appeals court ruling allowing last year's march.

title: Indians and Rangers Make Trades With Yanks in Mind
description: The Cleveland Indians and Texas Rangers made trades yesterday, and if they did not make the deals strictly to cope with the Yankees, they certainly had the Yankees in mind.

title: CROWN GROUP TO EXPAND USED-CAR BUSINESS
description: Crown Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to expand its used-car business into Florida by taking control of Smart Choice Automotive Group Inc. and merging it with its Paaco Automotive Group Inc. unit, which sells used cars in Texas, in a transaction valued at $52.4 million. Crown, based in the Dallas suburb of Irving, will lend Smart Choice $1 million in the form of secured debentures convertible into Smart Choice common stock and buy four million shares of Smart Choice common stock for $2 million. Smart Choice will exchange about 51 million shares of its common stock, or about $49.4 million worth.

title: Praxair to Cut $100 Million of Costs
description: Praxair Inc., the world's No. 3 supplier of industrial gases, said today that it expected to reduce costs by about $100 million annually through supplier consolidation and other measures to improve earnings.

title: Rival Assemblies in Venezuela Reach a Shaky Accord
description: An agreement brokered today by the Roman Catholic Church averted, at least temporarily, a dangerous political showdown between the Congress and the rival Constitutional Assembly, which earlier this week stripped the legislature of its authority to pass laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICHER, LEONARD
description: TEICHER-Leonard on August 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Rose; loving father of Ernestine, devoted stepfather of Marilyn, Alan, and Bertram. Adoring grandfather of Jeffrey, Jill, Daniel, Howard, Andrew, Rachel, Aaron, Samuel and Naomi. Great grandfather of Noah, Conner, Delaney and Jacob. Chief of the Hearing Bureau of the Office of Legal Affairs, NYC. Treasurer of K. C. Fraternity. Service Sunday 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Rain Alone Didn't Stop the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: In Latest Move to Diversify, Medtronic Will Buy Xomed
description: Continuing to diversify away from its core cardiac device business, Medtronic Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $800 million in stock to acquire Xomed Surgical Products Inc., the leading maker of ear, nose and throat surgical products.

title: Rain Alone Didn't Stop the Subway
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWAT, SAMUEL ABED
description: HAWAT-Samuel Abed, age 60, died August 23, 1999 in Santee, CA. Survived by one brother and three sisters. Services Hempstead, L.I. Funeral Home today at 10AM.

title: AFC CABLE HALTS ITS SALE TO THOMAS & BETTS
description: AFC Cable Systems Inc., which makes electrical and communications wiring, has canceled an agreement to be bought by the Thomas & Betts Corporation, a maker of electronics components and connectors, to accept a higher offer from an undisclosed company. The Memphis-based Thomas & Betts offered in January to exchange 0.83 share of its common stock for each share of AFC, which is based Providence, R.I. The transaction valued AFC at $35.52 a share, or a total of $455.9 million, based on yesterday prices. Thomas & Betts said it would not match the alternative bid that AFC received. Thomas & Betts is entitled to a $16 million termination fee.

title: High and Tight: Clemens Proves Too Tough for Griffey to Handle
description: Roger Clemens's Hall of Fame credentials don't particularly interest his kids. Sure, they're pleased for their father when he pitches well -- ''Nice game, Dad'' -- but like most young baseball fans, they are intrigued with star power. Make sure you don't let Ken Griffey Jr. get a hit against you, his children have said to him.

title: In Africa, War Is What They Know
description: West Africa, Nigeria, 1969, dusk. I am 17 years old and my father and I are driving along an isolated stretch of road heading for home. On both sides of the narrow strip of dusty tarmac, the ''bush'' (as all forest is described in West Africa) is dense and thick.

title: Consumption And Incomes Up Yet Again
description: Personal incomes rose for the seventh consecutive month in July, Government figures showed today, enabling consumer spending to continue to grow and pushing the economy toward its longest expansion ever.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Tex Banwell, who served as Field Marshal Montgomery's double in World War II, referred incompletely to the failed Allied offensive in the Netherlands in September 1944. While American forces probably contributed to the disaster by their inability to reach their objectives on schedule, they were not the sole cause of the failure. Also, it was not just Mr. Banwell and several other paratroopers who were dropped near Arnhem; it was a division of British paratroopers.

title: Stock-Options Listing Battle Heats Up
description: In the most aggressive move yet in the battle for supremacy in stock-options trading, the Chicago Board Options Exchange said yesterday that it would list options on another 29 stocks, including some listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange, which has tried to remain on the sidelines.

title: Weatherspoon's Foul Trouble Leaves the Liberty in a Hole
description: As she walked from the bench to the scorer's table with just over six minutes left in the game, Teresa Weatherspoon barked at the nearby official, ''Let me play!'' The official did not look her way, the argument already lost.

title: CREDITORS RESIST DAEWOO PLAN
description: Resisting pressure to join local banks in an emergency rescue plan for the 12 hardest-hit businesses of Daewoo Group, foreign creditors of the ailing conglomerate postponed a meeting with Daewoo executives over repayment of $6 billion in debts. The meeting was to be the first by a steering committee of foreign creditors set up last week to negotiate a rescheduling of Daewoo's huge debts. Saying they have faced official discrimination in dealing with Daewoo since its crisis erupted last month, foreign banks have threatened to call in debts unless they receive additional guarantees. Samuel Len

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa prices rebounded as expectations for reviving demand outweighed prospects for bumper crops in West Africa. In New York, cocoa for September delivery rose $23, or 2.6 percent, to $895 a metric ton.

title: Garner and Collins Lead Americans
description: Sarah Garner and Christine Collins of the United States, the defending world lightweight women's double sculling champions, led a string of American qualifiers into finals yesterday at the world rowing championships' 2,000-meter Martindale Pond course in St. Catherines, Ontario.

title: U.S. Expands Police Powers To Monitor Cellular Phones
description: Over the objections of civil liberties groups and privacy advocates, the Federal Government today announced new technical standards for cellular phones that will broadly expand the ability of law-enforcement agents to monitor conversations and locate criminal suspects.

title: Valvoline Unit to Be Sold
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation, the third-largest United States waste-disposal company, agreed today to acquire a unit of the Valvoline Company for an undisclosed price to enlarge its used-oil collection business. The company said the purchase of the unit -- Ecogard Inc., doing business as First Recovery -- would add $30 million in annual revenue. Safety-Kleen said the acquisition would solidify its No. 1 position in the used-oil collection and re-refining business. Ecogard has almost 40,000 customers.

title: Trade-Deficit Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: Share Prices Fall on Concern Over Greenspan Remarks
description: Stock prices fell yesterday as some investors took remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, as a warning that shares may be overvalued.

title: Bush Fund-Raising Machine Plows Ahead
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the early front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, today wrapped up a three-state, three-day campaign swing through the Southeast that yielded what aides estimated was another $1.1 million in campaign contributions.

title: 'They're Still Champions' at Home
description: When 12-year-old Mike Casale struck out today, dashing the world championship hopes of his team, the Toms River East Little League, Tony Cohen, the groundskeeper and the only paid employee of the league, choked back a tear.

title: Williams and Davenport Set Up Heavy-Hitting Final
description: Before her semifinal match tonight against Venus Williams at the Pilot Pen tournament, Monica Seles said of her 19-year-old opponent: ''I think she keeps getting better. She doesn't have many weaknesses and she is very powerful. It's going to be a great match.''

title: Tove Hansen, 88, Los Angeles Restaurateur
description: Tove (Musse) Hansen, who presided over Scandia, a popular Los Angeles restaurant in the 1950's and 60's, after helping Jews flee Denmark during World War II, died last Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 88.

title: Panel May Rethink Charter Change to Avoid Affecting Green
description: The commission considering changes to the City Charter will probably soften a contentious proposal that could have thwarted the mayoral ambitions of Mark Green, the Public Advocate, if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani left office early, administration officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILTON, ARNOLD T.
description: MILTON-Arnold T. The Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Sherrill and his family. Jay M. Rosen, President Corey B. Rabin, Secretary

title: What Makes Nations Turn Corrupt?; Reformers Worry That Payoffs and Theft May Be Accepted as Normal
description: As old as the forbidden fruit, and as hardy a perennial, corruption is back in.

title: Central Figure Admits Guilt In Brookhaven Bribery Case
description: Collapsing under what his lawyer called an avalanche of evidence, Joseph Provenzano, the central figure in a case that forced the Suffolk County Republican leader to resign, pleaded guilty today to all 17 charges against him.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on July 24 about Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. of Alabama, whose decisions helped to desegregate the South, misstated the sequence of events in a face-off with Governor George C. Wallace in 1965. Judge Johnson's order permitting a civil rights march came before President Lyndon B. Johnson federalized the National Guard, not afterward.

title: Kafelnikov Upset
description: For Yevgeny Kafelnikov, it's all about quantity. His career goal is pure and simple: to win as many matches as he can.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, LEO L., M.D.
description: ORENSTEIN-Leo L., M.D. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine and the NYU MEdical Center mourn the passing of Leo L. Orenstein, M.D., Clinical Professor of Psychiatry. A 1934 graduate of NYU School of Medicine, Dr. Orenstein was a member of the School's faculty for over sixty years. Dr. Orenstein was a dedicated teacher and a gifted physician who maintained a private practice in psychoanalysis and psychiatry. A researcher in forensic psychiatry and in alcoholism, Dr. Orenstein also conducted pioneering work on the treatment of schizophrenic patients. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, MYRON S.
description: LEWIS-Myron S. Of Weston, Ct., founder and President of Lewis Laboratories, International Ltd., died on August 19th in Norwalk Hospital, Connecticut. He was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Signal Intelligence during World War II at which time he was in command of electronic equipment to intercept German communications at the front. He was in the Normandy invasion, behind enemy lines during the Battle of the Bulge and one of the first to cross the Ramagen Bridge. He was awarded the Bronze Star. Mr. Lewis, son of Aquilla Cornelius Lewis, prominent lawyer who won the famous ''Herrin Massacre'' case in 1922, and Oma Lewis, author and artist, was born in Harrisburg, IL. on April 19, 1921. He was a direct descendant of Francis Lewis, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence (on his father's side) and Ethan Allen (on his mother's side). His family members were among the first colonists to arrive in 1682 and settled in Pennsylvania. He was an ardent defender of freedom and liberty. He was a graduate of Amherst College, class of 1942. Mr. Lewis was V.P. of International Marketing at Richardson Merrill and Vicks International and Excecutive V.P. at Shulton Inc. His wife of 24 years, Diana Lewis, survives him. He is also survived by five children from a previous marriage, daughter, Cornelia Sgoutas, sons, Daniel, Timothy, John, and Tobias; his brother, Dr. Winston B. Lewis of Annapolis, Maryland, and his stepdaughter, Lena. He is also survived by 25 grandchildren. Contributions in his memory may be made to The American Cancer Society, The Free Congress Foundation, 717 2nd St. NE, Washington, DC 20002 and/or Boy's Town of Italy, 250 East 63 Street, NY, NY 10021.

description: It didn't take long for Charles I. Clough Jr., 57, the chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch who announced his retirement last week, to be deemed a casualty of the bull market. He has favored bonds while the stock market has been rising at double-digit rates.

title: Panama Converting Canal Zone for Tourism
description: ON Dec. 31, the United States is scheduled to complete the transfer of the Panama Canal to Panama. The 50-mile passageway -- a wondrous feat of United States engineering -- transports more than 13,000 ships, including cruise vessels, and 190 million tons of cargo a year between the Pacific and the Atlantic.

description: Showdown in Venezuela

title: At Yale, the Great War Recalled
description: BY almost any measure, World War I was the most brutal war fought in modern times.

description: FROM landlubber to old salt, without owning a boat? It happens to students at the New York Sailing School in New Rochelle.

title: Sailor Prefers Old Yacht Over the New for Races
description: One might think that Jim Bishop had struck it rich from the names of his boats: Golddigger, Gold Dust, Nugget, Prospector, Fool's Gold and Motherlode. But you would not know it by the kind of sailboat he races.

title: The Nation: Brownfields; Rethinking the Cleanup Rules for Polluted Sites
description: AARON MAIER, an environmental activist, surveyed the abandoned industrial plant that blights his poor neighborhood here on the banks of the Hudson River. The lot, vacant but for an abandoned factory building, was overrun by weeds, and the soil was soaked with toxic chemicals.

description: In October 1985 Louis Farrakhan brought his message of hate to Madison Square Garden, where he spent a couple of hours ranting about white people in general and Jews in particular before an audience of 25,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, HARRY
description: KAHN-Harry. Harry Kahn's heart was immense and it was in all the right places. He was a brilliant economist who cared deeply about how people are influenced by economic policy. He believed passionately in the first amendment and devoted himself to its protection. He revelled in the beauty that art brought into our lives and our world. We will miss his presence, spirit and his commitment to the American Way. Carole Shields, President, People for the American Way Barbara Handman, Vice President/Director NY Office, People for the American Way

title: A London Season as Unsettling as the Weather
description: WHATEVER else one thinks of that mix of humidity, pelting rain, heat, chill and solar eclipse that has been styling itself the English summer this year, one must admit it has coincided with plenty of startling and disturbing theatrical images.

title: August 22-28; Do as They Say
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has said that under her stewardship the Justice Department would be more worker friendly, but lawyers at the agency have filed a lawsuit accusing the Department of knowingly cheating them out of millions of hours of overtime pay. Internal documents show that even as officials told lawyers they were ineligible for overtime, top personnel managers knew otherwise. The Department even kept two sets of books: One set, on which paychecks were based, credited lawyers with only the official 40-hour work week; the other precisely tracked overtime and was used to lobby Congress for bigger budgets -- but not to pay overtime. DAVID JOHNSTON

title: Now Dancing on a Trail Near You
description: Most people hike the Appalachian Trail. Jacques d'Amboise dances it.

title: Jennifer Nevins, Ian McAllister
description: Jennifer Lynne Nevins, a daughter of Suzy Nevins and Louis H. Nevins, both of Washington, was married last evening to Ian Gerard McAllister, a son of Gerard and Joan McAllister of Cheltenham, England. Rabbi Harold S. White performed the ceremony at Great Oak Manor, an inn in Chestertown, Md.

title: Commercial Property/Jersey Gardens; Outlet Mall Near Newark Airport Prepares to Open
description: JUST across the New Jersey Turnpike from Newark International Airport, workmen are installing artificial rocks and other finishing touches for Jersey Gardens, a two-level, 1.3 million-square-foot discount shopping mall.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report last Sunday about the opening of Unoaerre, a jewelry store at 65 Thompson Street in SoHo, included two erroneous prices supplied by the store. The gold bracelet embedded with diamonds costs $6,215, not $2,485. The gold necklace embedded with diamonds costs $4,998, not $1,999.

title: Tired of London?
description: LIGHTS OUT FOR THE TERRITORY9 Excursions in the Secret History of London.By Iain Sinclair.Illustrated by Marc Atkins.386 pp. New York: Granta Books. $16.95.

title: Critic's Notebook: Taking to the Stage for Sustenance
description: CONNECTICUT'S theater artists take refuge in regional theaters to shut out the all-about-money mentality of Broadway. Turning to films and television and voice-overs can no longer be scorned or resisted as the means to high visibility and good living, especially in hard times when life, as Oscar Wilde said of his, ''is reduced to the barest luxuries.''

title: Despite Wide Support, Bill on Police Discipline Languishes
description: After separate police corruption investigations more than two decades apart, the Knapp and Mollen Commissions arrived at an identical finding: there was a serious defect in the city law that governs how the New York City Police Department disciplines its own.

title: Corrections
description: The Gazetteer chart last Sunday, about Glen Oaks, Queens, misstated the ZIP codes for the area. They are 11004 and 11005.

title: With Cut in Class Size, a District Improvises With Space
description: Pupils returning to schools in Brooklyn's District 15 next month may find first graders reading in what was formerly a computer lab or art studio.

title: . . . And Another
description: To the editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLEECH, BERT, ED.D.
description: MacLEECH-Bert, Ed.D. The Board of Trustees, the staff, and consumers of YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities mourn the loss of Dr. Bert MacLeech. In 1957, Dr. MacLeech and his wife, Pearl, founded the Young Adult Adjustment Centers which later became YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities, one of the nation's largest providers of services to people with developmental disabilities. In contrast with the then prevailing practice of placing people with developmental disabilities in institutions, Dr. MacLeech pioneered the movement to establish community based services for these individuals. His vision that people with developmental disabilities can and should lead productive lives in the community continues to serve as the guiding principle of our agency. Marcella Fava, Chairman Dr. Paul H. Levitz, Vice Chairman YAI Board of Trustees Dr. Joel M. Levy, CEO Dr. Philip H. Levy, Pres. & COO YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities

title: FILM; Alienated, Spontaneous, Nonpolitical: Sounds Familiar
description: IT was in 1951 that Jack Kerouac, glowing with excitement after an evening of Lee Konitz's jazz in a Manhattan nightclub, started hammering out ''On the Road,'' his first major novel. He wrote on a typewriter using sheets of drawing paper taped into a long roll so that absolutely nothing would interrupt the mercurial flow of what he later called his ''spontaneous bop prosody.''

title: With New Store in Park Slope, Computer Chain Eyes Brooklyn
description: Software Etc., the computer software chain that recently opened stores at 106th Street and Broadway on the Upper West Side and on Continental Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens, opened its newest store on July 28 in Park Slope, Brooklyn. ''We've been trying to open up more stores in Brooklyn,'' said the manager, Daniel Stark.

title: Hybrid Lilies: So Much More Than a Novelty
description: WHEN they aren't complaining about the weather, gardeners often like to whine about what awful things the hybridizers have done to this or that venerable plant to make it dwarfer or bushier or possessed of a color that does not exist outside a child's crayon box.

title: Eileen Koretz, Joseph Giampaolo
description: Judge Eileen Koretz of Manhattan Criminal Court was married yesterday to Joseph Giampaolo, a trial bureau chief in the Bronx County District Attorney's office. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Loft.

title: Fault Is Misplaced
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Graf Gave Her All, but Held Back
description: The players of the moment joined Rosie O'Donnell in some hit-and-giggle high jinks for charity yesterday at the National Tennis Center, two days before things turn cutthroat at the United States Open. But Steffi Graf, who recently relegated herself to tennis's has-been heap, declined to dust off her racquet and joke around for Arthur Ashe Kids Day.

title: Retreat Centers Around the State Offer Opportunity for Reflection
description: MERCY CENTER in Madison, Conn., operated by the Sisters of Mercy, is a conference and retreat center with an idyllic location on the shores of Long Island Sound.

title: Edinburgh Puts Planet In Dramatic Light
description: Earthquakes, erupting volcanos and torrential rains are a few of the simulated catastrophes awaiting visitors to Dynamic Earth, a new attraction in Edinburgh's Old Town. Housed in the William Younger Center, a new building with a translucent roof, Dynamic Earth tells the planet's story through interactive exhibits, videos and state-of-the-art special effects.

title: The Spanish Test
description: The idea that it was necessary to get three experts to analyze Al Gore's and George W. Bush's Spanish upset me (Aug. 8). Why should either speak perfect Spanish? Why then were you so picayune about the candidates' attempts to please an audience?

title: Goods Ready to Rent, Stocks Ready to Grow
description: IT was just over a year ago that investors were engaged in an industrial-sized obsession with the stocks of equipment rental companies -- businesses that rent out everything from bulldozers to 100-foot-long telescopic boom lifts to generators and hand tools. At the end of July 1998, the industry's bellwether stock -- United Rentals of Greenwich, Conn. -- was trading at a lofty price of over $48, or 48 times analysts' estimates of earnings per share for the year.

title: The Race to Cash In On the Genetic Code
description: BEFORE there was an Internet bubble, before biotechnology left a bad taste in money managers' mouths, capital was ventured and shares were sold in a group of companies that aimed to leapfrog the Government's multibillion-dollar effort to map the human genome. By sequencing and patenting genes ahead of the publicly financed laboratories, the investors thought, these companies would control the next era of health care -- and make their founders and shareholders rich.

title: A First for Pelham
description: Drawing on its own pool of talent, Pelham has hired its first female police officer -- its former Village Clerk -- Police Chief Joseph Benefico reported last week.

title: The World; Tiny Nations, Grand Ambitions
description: THE East Timorese are voting tomorrow on whether to sever ties with Indonesia, and if they opt for independence, where would this brand-new country rank among the United Nations' 188 members? For those Indonesians who argue that East Timor, occupying only a half of one of Indonesia's 13,000 islands, is too small to be viable, the facts may be surprising.

title: Mother: Free, Equal and Not at Home
description: CARE AND EQUALITY

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: IN THE FAMILY WAY

title: Dorothy French, Elwood Boone 3d
description: Dorothy Mae French, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David French of Barboursville, Va., was married yesterday to Elwood Bernard Boone 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Boone Jr. of Richmond. Canon Charles L. Poindexter performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Orange, Va.

title: Fraud Seeks Out Old and Young
description: SALE of travel climbed into the top 10 categories of complaints made to the Federal Trade Commission in the last year. Sales on the Internet and over the telephone helped to push travel operators into the No. 6 spot, in the unlovely company of organizations that promise to fix bad credit ratings, say you have won the sweepstakes, sell telephone access cards that provide no access, and operate Internet auctions without sending merchandise, among other classic frauds.

title: Ideas & Trends; What's in a Name?
description: Ever dream of having a prominent medical school named after you? If so, New York University would like to talk to you. For a donation of $100 million, the university would consider it. (That was the amount that Cornell University asked from Sanford I. Weill and his wife Joan last year in return for christening its medical school the Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College and Graduate School of Medical Sciences.)

title: Foster Seniors
description: What is to be done with the old and the sick?

title: Bending Geometry: Two of a Kind
description: PERHAPS the sculptor Richard Serra should not have been surprised when he recently spied a woman who, thinking she was alone, danced through one of his ''Torqued Ellipses'' at the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain. His rounded, listing, walk-in steel sculptures and the long arched gallery of the architect Frank Gehry glide and curve together in a pas de deux of balletic grace. Clearly she was inspired.

title: Moose and Elk, Endangered Species?
description: WHEN men were men, men were Moose. Or Elk. Or Masons. Or so the perception goes.

title: Williams's Injury Is a Question Mark
description: Bernie Williams, the Yankees' cleanup hitter, did not take regular batting practice the first two days of the current homestand to ease the burden on his ailing left shoulder. Williams initially hurt the shoulder while attempting a diving catch more than two months ago, but he apparently aggravated the injury Thursday, which was an off day for the Yankees.

title: A Bass Brothers Investment For a New On-Line Broker
description: A firm that plans to start offering brokerage services on line has received the kind of endorsement that many financial companies might envy. The billionaire investors Sid R. Bass and Lee M. Bass paid $40 million for a 40 percent stake in the company, Tradecast Ltd., which now sells software to Internet brokerage firms and is building an on-line brokerage house of its own.

title: Making Chips the Island Can Call Its Own
description: EIGHT summers ago, visitors to Jones Beach might have encountered a guy walking around, asking all kinds of questions about snack food.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Religious Union May Beget Others
description: IT has not been difficult to find Protestants who believed that the ecumenical movement among their churches had entered a season of winter, where new initiatives for formal cooperation among denominations were frozen like ice in January. But that idea waned a few days ago when the nation's largest group of Lutherans approved an agreement for full communion with the Episcopal Church.

title: A Question of Attribution
description: HEADLONG

title: Steven Gordon, Alexandra Robert
description: Tracey Alexandra Robert and Steven Eric Gordon are to be married today by Rabbi Sally Finestone at the Puck Building in Manhattan.

title: The Side Effects of Charter Schools
description: Two recent announcements regarding charter schools have moved this controversial education experiment to center stage. First, the State University of New York has approved the state's first set of charter schools. Second, fourth grade reading and writing test scores show no difference between New York public and nonpublic schoolchildren. Some nonpublic schools scored higher than neighboring public schools, while others scored worse.

title: Rachel Besserman and Golan Weiss
description: IN some ways, Rachel Trigere Besserman is the sort of young woman you would expect to meet in Northampton, Mass., a small college town where it's easy to find a very strong cup of coffee, conversation with strangers and all kinds of psychological counseling and homemade breads.

title: Three Trains Years Behind Schedule: Colorado; Durango to Silverton is a real cliffhanger
description: The train chugged along the edge of the abyss in the San Juan Mountains of Colorado. Far below, the emerald Animas River tumbled between vertical walls of rock. Some passengers, including me, grabbed their cameras and hurried to the open observation car at the back of the train for an unobstructed view. We could see the Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad's coal-fired steam locomotive and its string of eight yellow passenger cars rounding the sharp curves up ahead like a snake slithering along a ledge.

title: Electric Banana's Owner Rebuts Community Board
description: To the Editor:

title: Now, a New Episode Of the Fordice Saga
description: Now for our latest installment of the Fordice saga, in which we learn that while rekindled love for an old high school flame brought Kirk, the Governor of Mississippi, all of his troubles, it was not the heat in that love that saw him through the hard times. It was politics.

title: Fashion Literati
description: Cool, then and now: In ''David Bailey: Birth of the Cool'' (Viking Studio, $60), Martin Harrison tells the story of the cockney photographer who inspired Antonioni's ''Blowup'' -- a man who was shagadelic when Mike Myers was no bigger than Mini-Me. The book showcases Mr. Bailey's evocative portraits of everyone who was cool in Swinging Sixties London, from Jean Shrimpton and Twiggy to Dame Edna's alter ego, Barry Humphries, and captures the glamour of the era through the lens of a man who stood at the youth-quake's epicenter.

title: The View From/Stafford; It Has Been Bumped, Bruised and Broken, but Fountain Survives
description: LIKE a veteran boxer, a 105-year-old water fountain in the center of Stafford, an old New England mill town once famous for its mineral springs and woolen textiles, refuses to stay down.

title: Child Labor: The Wrong, not the Inevitable, Ingredient
description: In ''Cold Facts About Child Labor'' (On the Contrary, Aug. 1), Daniel Akst looked at economic justifications for the practice around the world. He contended that children in impoverished countries ''generally work to support their families, and the people devoted to rescuing them haven't the slightest hope of offering an alternative.'' The only other choice for such children ''isn't school,'' he said; ''it's starvation.'' The column drew many reader responses.

title: Janis Gardner and Charles Cecil
description: Janis Lyn Gardner and Charles Granville Cecil were married in New York yesterday by Canon Susan Harriss at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Fast Boats and Big Flopping Fish
description: It is dawn in the delta, and the heat is already building. We're just south of New Orleans on Lake Salvador, with the rising sun behind us and the setting moon ahead, when it occurs to me that my life could be in danger. We're going 70 miles an hour in an open boat with no seat belts and no helmets. Suppose I fly out of the boat and land on my head. What will my life preserver do? Make my corpse float?

title: Tobacco Largess Is Touchy Subject For Gore and Bush
description: The Presidential campaigns of Al Gore and George W. Bush have this much in common: Both are trying to wean themselves from the money and influence of the tobacco industry, long one of the most generous of political donors.

title: The Sound of One Wheel Turning
description: NOT everyone seeking transcendent peace and spiritual growth can live a life of reflection in a cloistered monastery. In the real world, somebody has to fix flat tires.

title: In the Region/Long Island; The Troubling Effect of a New Nassau Transfer Tax
description: WARREN REDEKER feels it is his hard luck that the three-bedroom ranch in Mineola that he has owned as an investment for the last 10 years and recently placed on the market for $240,000 is in Nassau County and not in Suffolk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, ROBERTA
description: SELIGMAN-Roberta. On August 26, 1999. Beloved wife of Dr. Robert Seligman, mother of Deborah Seligman, Elliott (Andrea) Seligman, and Naomi (Paul) Wolfgang, darling grandmother of Ezra Wolfgang and Ellisa Seligman. Services private.
