description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, GERSTEN
description: RAPPAPORT-Gersten. On August 21, Newton, MA. Wife Herma, children Martha, Sam and Naomi; children-in-law Kirk, Kevin and Lauren; grandchildren Joshua, Kendra, Lily, Emily, and Max: We know and keep his love. He gave his gentle spirit and quiet learning to all.

title: Fastest Sport
description: To the Editor: In the lovely article ''What's Doing in Dublin'' (July 25), the author states that the sport of hurling is the fastest field game in the world.

title: When Laws Shoot Themselves in the Foot
description: TOWARD the end of every year, millions of Americans go on medical shopping sprees. They get their teeth cleaned and their eyes checked. They buy designer eyeglasses, orthopedic shoes and long-term supplies of birth-control pills. Some even make extra appointments with their analysts.

title: Just Lucky to Be Here
description: Is Britain's class system and old-boy network being replaced by hard-charging American-style meritocracy? Quite the reverse, to hear young British executives tell it.

title: August 22-28; Unearthed, a New City of the Dead
description: The tombs of ancient Egypt have by no means exhausted their power to astonish.

title: Maia Samuel and George Olley
description: Maia Tessa Samuel and Prof. George Steven Olley are to be married today at the Inn at Mystic in Mystic, Conn. James Mallove, a Connecticut justice of the peace, is to officiate.

title: A Center Offers a Haven for Gay Teen-Agers
description: WITH a mixture of lassitude and restlessness, a dozen 15- to 20-year-olds sprawled across battered couches, played computer games, drank sodas, ate snack foods and demonstrated the fine art of hanging out.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about airline safety misstated the telephone number for a Defense Department office that lists foreign airlines placed on the Pentagon's ''nonuse'' list. The number is (618) 256-4801.

title: Now You See It, Er, Now You Don't
description: The stock price is everything at many Internet start-ups. And more than a few of them have taken to posting continually updated prices on their internal computer networks, so employees, many of them paid partly in stock or options, can draw minute-to-minute inspiration from how rich the company has made them.

title: For Bulbs, a Smaller Show Can Be Better
description: THOUGH it may be hard to believe, the time has come to start thinking about bulbs.

title: MUSIC; A Mozart Recitative Hidden in Plain Sight?
description: A FEW pinholes in an old musical score -- and a Canadian musicologist's passion for the chaotic world of 18th-century opera -- have led to the discovery of what appears to be a long lost recitative by Mozart. Dorothea Link, a specialist in the operas of Mozart and his contemporaries, came across the setting for strings and voice, 35 bars long, in the Austrian National Library in Vienna a few months ago. The recitative precedes the well-known aria ''Vado, ma dove?'' (K. 583), which Mozart wrote for the singer Luisa Villeneuve. Although the recitative is not in Mozart's hand, all the evidence points to his authorship.

title: From Rock to Rachmaninoff
description: ''It's just a special event,'' a spokeswoman said, deadpan, about the Haddonfield Symphony Orchestra's concert on Saturday night at the E-Center on the Camden waterfront. What makes it special? It will draw the largest audience in the orchestra's history, and it's the first pops concert. And the guest stars are the Moody Blues, the 1960's British pop-rock group known for its lush, psychedelic ballads and its soaring strings arrangements.

title: The Spanish Test
description: Whatever the glottal stops, fricatives and elisions may have been, I would bet their Hispanic audiences understood and appreciated the effort. Your criticism won't encourage others even to try.

title: Common Ground?
description: URBAN EXODUS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAIGER, ARMAND JUSTIN
description: BRAIGER-Armand Justin. Noury Goujjane, proprietor of One If By Land, Two If By Sea, announces the passing of the co-owner and founder of the restaurant, Armand Justin Braiger, eternally 39, in Florida, on August 20, 1999. The restaurant staff joins Mr. Goujjane in extending deepest sympathy to Armand's sisters, Adele Wooters and Leonore R. Spinell; and his many nieces and nephews. We will miss his grace, charm, wit, generosity of spirit and wisdom. Mr. Goujjane remains committed to continuing to implement the plans he and Mr. Braiger developed over most of the past decade for the restaurant.

title: Where Flowers and Fruitcake Don't Cut It
description: THREE years ago, Marnie Lerner and Cynde Cassel started Star Treatment, a company in this Los Angeles suburb that created whimsical, personalized gift baskets. Soon, they moved beyond baskets and into a distinct regional niche: gifts for the stars.

title: Umpires Threw Themselves Out of the Game
description: They said they never really meant it, just kidding, or something like that. So they think they deserve a do-over. Except not only is there no crying in baseball but there are also no do-overs.

title: Each Wave of Immigrants: Their Hard Work, Hard Times
description: IMMIGRATION in the latter half of the 19th century transformed the face of Norwalk and the way it perceived itself.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-29-99: Salient Facts - Origin Of Life; The Secret Creator
description: OPEN YOUR HYMNALSNow that the Kansas Board of Education has dropped the study of evolution from its science curriculum, local school systems are expected to give much more weight to creationism. Just how they might do so, however, is less clear: there is a vast library of anti-Darwinism tracts, but most of them either aren't geared for classroom use or base their arguments on biblical teachings. And that means their use in public schools -- even Kansas public schools -- would violate the separation of church and state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEIFETZ, DR. LESLIE
description: CHEIFETZ-Dr. Leslie. Beloved husband, best friend of Karen, adored father of David, Matthew, and Samantha the bright lights of his life. Loved by family, friends and patients.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A nationwide celebration of a love match, a highly personal story of a woman's spiritual struggle, a tense operatic melodrama and a Hitchcock package chock full of twists and surprises are on tap for the television viewer this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, SHIRLEY (NEE GOLDSTEIN)
description: LESSER-Shirley (nee Goldstein). Of Delray Beach, suddenly on August 25. Beloved wife of Dr. Herbert Lesser. Cherished mother of Betty and Seth Kaye and the late Bob Lesser. Adored grandmother of Andrew and the late Robbie Kaye. Her music and her memory will play on forever.

title: Making Do in Provence
description: JENNIFER and Rand are my Sara and Gerald Murphy. (Or -- a more disturbing thought -- I am their Zelda Fitzgerald.) Like the Murphys, the Americans who almost singlehandedly made the Riviera fashionable in the 20's, these are friends who know how to enjoy life and how to entertain.

title: Purchase College and Ballet Studio Form Pact
description: FOR the last seven years, Purchase College productions of Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker'' have featured a student of the Scarsdale Ballet Studio in the role of Clara, the young girl who gets the magical gift from her uncle. Last month the link between the two institutions was solidified as Carol Walker, dean of dance at the college, appointed the founding directors of the Scarsdale Studio, Christian Claessens and his wife, Diana White, to head Purchase Youth Ballet. The Purchase group, in fact, has become a division of the Scarsdale Ballet Studio.

title: Officials Voice Concern As Crew Mulls a New Job
description: Chancellor Rudy Crew's ability to lead the New York City school system could be damaged by the news -- revealed less than two weeks before the start of a new school year -- that he is considering taking a job in Seattle, school officials and union leaders said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICHER, LEONARD
description: TEICHER-Leonard on August 26, 1999. Beloved husband of Rose; loving father of Ernestine, devoted stepfather of Marilyn, Alan, and Bertram. Adoring grandfather of Jeffrey, Jill, Daniel, Howard, Andrew, Rachel, Aaron, Samuel and Naomi. Great grandfather of Noah, Conner, Delaney and Jacob. Chief of the Hearing Bureau of the Office of Legal Affairs, NYC. Treasurer of K. C. Fraternity. Service Sunday 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: All Packed Up, No Place to Go
description: EIGHT families who bought houses here worth half a million dollars and more continue to wait -- homeless in motels, cramped in small furnished apartments and otherwise making do. While officials and the developer fail to find a solution, which centers on low water pressure to the community, the families' luxury homes are empty and their lives are on hold.

title: Three Trains Years Behind Schedule: North Arkansas; North Arkansas Along the White River, past Ozark peaks and forests
description: The chief advantage to springing for a $35 first-class ticket on the White River Scenic Railroad for the 94-mile round trip between Flippin and Calico Rock in northern Arkansas is that it provides access to the open-air platform at the end of the car. One of my fellow big spenders walked straight out to the deck as soon as we boarded and, perhaps imagining himself Harry Truman, raised his arms and spread two fingers on each hand in a victory sign.

title: Corretja's Hardcourt Practice Pays Off
description: In their first meeting in 1996, Daniel Vacek quickly bounced Alex Corretja, then a 22-year-old clay-court specialist, out of the opening round of the ATP Championship in Cincinnati.

title: August 22-28; So Many Words, So Little Time
description: The war of words in the ordinarily staid dictionary market intensified with the publication of Microsoft's upstart new reference guide, the Encarta World English Dictionary.

title: Too Much a Lady?
description: A WOMAN OF THE TIMES

title: A Revolution Peru's Rebels Didn't Intend
description: At the entrance to this Quechua-speaking Indian village high in the Andes, residents have built a children's playground beside six concrete tombs for 40 people slain by Shining Path rebels eight years ago.

title: Visiting Cuba
description: To the Editor: I liked the article on Cuba. I was there in February and found and observed many of the same things. However, one can get U.S. dollars as a cash advance on credit cards at the Banco Financiero Internacional in the Hotel Habana Libre in the Vedado section of Havana. I was short of cash and got a transfusion.

title: Young Magicians Get Life Lessons
description: STRANGE things were happening on Long Island earlier this month, especially around Central Islip, where 120 young magicians from all over the world gathered to practice their ancient art. Of course, nobody believes in real magic nowadays, except down in the Hamptons where ''New Age'' stores offer crystals, Tarot cards, astrological charts, and other mystical paraphernalia straight out of the Dark Ages. But this modern magic is better than the old-fashioned occult stuff, because it actually works.

title: On the Trail of Coherence and Meaning
description: DAVID IVES, the wunderkind of word play, may not know when to stop already, but he takes a high, untraveled road, before operating in overdrive.

title: At Texas, Signals Are Clear
description: One has a famous name, the other has a catchy one. Both are talented quarterbacks vying for the starter's job at Texas. For now, Major Applewhite has held off the freshman Chris Simms, whose father, Phil, led the Giants to a Super Bowl victory.

title: Psychodrama
description: PERLMAN'S ORDEALBy Brooks Hansen.329 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: Union Leaders Say They Support Boeing's Final Contract Offer
description: Leaders of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers endorsed a contract proposal from the Boeing company yesterday, greatly reducing the chances that its 44,000 members will strike on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the A La Carte column on Aug. 15 about the restaurant Cooking With Jazz Too in Malverne misstated its telephone number. The number is 599-9589.

title: Getting Down to What Makes America High
description: As Mr. Zemeckis remembered it during an interview in his office on the Universal Studios backlot, his immediate reaction was swift and terrible: at 2 A.M. he phoned the local doctor who was on call for the film company, summoned him to the set and proceeded to berate him, loudly blaming him and him alone for the actor's inebriated state.

title: Fashion Literati
description: Obscure reference: Those chroniclers of downtown style, Kim Hastreiter and David Hershkovits, the editors and publishers of Paper, make sense of the 1980's and 90's in ''From Abfab to Zen: Paper's Guide to Pop Culture'' (Paper/D.A.P., $24.95).

title: Editorial Observer; One Serb's Struggle to Awaken Her Country
description: The killings in Kosovo of Serbs who stayed after the war -- many of them elderly -- has made it even harder for their countrymen to confront the far more widespread killings and other crimes that Serbs committed against Kosovo's Albanians. Even the opposition to Slobodan Milosevic has shown little interest in acknowledging these atrocities. Natasa Kandic is a lonely exception. Ms. Kandic, 51, is the director of Belgrade's Humanitarian Law Center. She is now documenting abuses against Serbs in Kosovo. But during the NATO bombing, she made several trips into Kosovo, driving to various towns and cities at great personal peril to take testimony from victims and try to protect her Albanian associates there.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: INVENTING PARADISE

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the leadership succession at S. C. Johnson & Company and a plan to divide the business into three parts misstated the name of the family that has a nearly 40 percent interest in the business but no role in running it. It is Louis, not Lewis.

title: Iran Confronts a Long-Hidden Problem: Drugs
description: The problem of illicit drugs is commonly associated with prosperous, liberty-minded societies in Europe and America, not a theocratic state run by some of the Islamic world's most conservative mullahs.

title: A Pair of Daring Leaps Into Classical Territory
description: TWO wonderful surprises danced their way across stages this summer. The choreographers of both took what seemed like foolhardy risks. Yet, instead of plummeting into catastrophe, both Twyla Tharp and Trisha Brown managed to soar creatively. Ms. Brown, in fact, even levitated a dancer. Ms. Tharp wrestled with Beethoven, and she and Beethoven both emerged with honor.

title: The Politics of the Dinner Table
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PURITZ, MARTIN H.
description: PURITZ-Martin H. At 87, loving husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Elliot and Barry. Adored father-in-law of Baerbel, Matilda and the late Ellen. Dear brother of Edward, Sheldon and the late Sylvia. Cherished grandpa of Adam and Robin, Nanne and Darius, David, and Sascha. Beloved greatgrandpa of Ethan and Benjamin. Services will be today, 1PM at The Schwartz Bros. Funeral Chapel in Forest Hills.

title: Congress Didn't Make Research a Money Chase
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRNES, JAMES E.
description: BYRNES-James E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James E. Byrnes, associated with The Times from 1963.

title: Program for Disabled Children Ends Abruptly
description: Josephine Richards was still on the delivery table when she learned that her newborn son, David, had Down syndrome. Her first reaction was not sadness, although she saw her husband crying. It was, she said, ''I have to do something.''

title: Greenspan Weighs In On Options and Earnings
description: Do stock options distort corporate earnings? Many critics have long made the case that they do. On Friday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said he agreed.

title: Will Post Office Be Last Act for a Vaudeville House?
description: Hamilton Heights, the affluent western section of Harlem, has become such a desirable location in recent years that its tiny post office can no longer serve all the local residents.

title: Chipping Away With Cold Chisels
description: COLD chisels are used to cut through hard materials like metal or masonry. They are often used to cut or shape metal when the stock is thick and where other tools, like a hacksaw or tin snips, would be unsuitable. The striking end of the cold chisel is chamfered to reduce mushrooming and burring caused by constant hammering.

title: Backtalk; Standards for Initial Eligibility Must Be Set. The Question Is, Where?
description: For those who have been on the roller-coaster ride known as Cureton, et al. v. N.C.A.A., one thing is certain: When it comes to initial-eligibility standards within the National Collegiate Athletic Association, there are two polar viewpoints. Although our members are all committed to a ''level playing field,'' most presidents and faculty members of our member institutions, and many in our student bodies and the larger public, are reluctant to see any weakening of academic standards for incoming athletes. I am most sympathetic to this point of view.

title: Khalifman Wins Chess Title In a Draw With Armenian
description: Aleksandr Khalifman won the International Chess Federation's World Championship last night at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., by fighting to a draw with Vladimir Akopian of Armenia. That gave Khalifman 3 1/2 points out of the six games played.

title: Corrections
description: The Coping column on Aug. 8, about enduring this summer's heat wave, misstated the position of Earth this time of year. In the Northern Hemisphere, Earth is farther from the Sun in summer than in winter; the heat of summer results from the tilt toward the Sun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIDEN, JOSEPH
description: FEIDEN-Joseph. Beloved husband of the late Jewel Eliasberg Feiden. Most cherished father of Margo Feiden owner of the Margo Feiden Galleries Ltd. Died August 26, 1999 in his daughter's home after a long illness. Brother of the late Raymond Feiden, Martin Feiden and Sally Baker, loving father-in-law of the late Julius Cohen. He is also survived by his beloved grandchildren Bambi and Jeremy, brother The Hon. Murray T. Feiden former Brooklyn Supreme Court Judge, and loving nephews and nieces. Shiva Will be observed at the home of his daughter.

title: Billboard Haters Mar Many Signs
description: Armed with red paint and using guerrilla tactics, a small group of billboard opponents has defaced more than a dozen signs in and around SoHo in recent months.

title: Triumphs Beyond First Place in the Hurdles
description: The Spaniards who filled Seville's new stadium nearly to capacity tonight for a change will remember the final Saturday of this track and field world championships for two of their own: Abel Anton, who defended his title in a very warm marathon, and Yago Lamela, who won a silver medal in the long jump behind Ivan Pedroso.

title: 'Thuggish' Tactics in Congress
description: Senator Mitch McConnell loves to invoke the First Amendment to justify the way politicians squeeze money from special interests. He and other Republican fund-raisers defend campaign contributions from businesses, unions and rich people as free speech. As it turns out, where they see free speech, others -- including some donors -- see extortion. A group of business leaders is now lobbying Congress to stop the shakedowns and approve campaign finance reform legislation banning ''soft money'' donations to the parties. Some even suggest that business donors just say no. Mr. McConnell is trying to get these executives to shut up. Evidently, for him, free speech has its limits.

title: Visual Puns Set in Folk Art Sculpture
description: NOW and then, the most modest of galleries offers memorable experiences. Such is the case with the current exhibition at the Arts Council of Rockland Gallery here. Its exhibition space consists only of limited portions of an L-shaped hallway and one nondescript display case, but that is where one can find the quirky, and sometimes profound, works of Ruth Geneslaw.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Parties Improperly Given Ballot Slots, Judge Rules
description: Judge Clarkson S. Fisher ruled in State Superior Court last week that county clerks improperly granted the Democratic and Republican parties their own columns on ballots for the November election, after the parties failed in the June primary to attract the minimum votes required for major party status.

title: Fashion Literati
description: Over and over: In an era of Gap style, when good taste has gone mundanely populist, fashion is over. So goes the argument of Teri Agins, a fashion business reporter for The Wall Street Journal, in her new book, ''The End of Fashion: The Mass Marketing of the Clothing Business'' (William Morrow, $25). The dishy treatise, based on 140 interviews done since 1996, focuses on key players on the American fashion scene -- from Armani to Zoran -- and examines the triumph of marketing in an age when Isaac Mizrahi's business fails and Tommy Hilfiger is all the rage.

title: New President of SUNY Downstate Named
description: John C. LaRosa, the chancellor of the Tulane University Medical Center, a researcher in cholesterol and heart disease and a passionate jazz pianist, will become president of the State University of New York's Health Science Center in Brooklyn on Sept. 1.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2000 Chevrolet Impala; Apple Pie Without the Spice
description: OF all the symbols of the 60's -- peace sign, marijuana leaf, electric guitar -- the one that came closest to home for many Americans was a stylized antelope leaping over a chrome hoop. It was affixed to some 8 million Chevrolet Impalas in that decade, out of a phenomenal 1958-85 production run of 13 million.

title: Fashion Literati
description: Charity ball: Remember those soccer balls made of Louis Vuitton monogrammed leather? Last summer, amid World Cup fever in France, the balls were $530 status symbols, quickly selling out in boutiques around the world.

title: CYBER-MAKEOVERS; Chic at Last: The Web Crowd Starts Clicking in Style
description: THE scene outside Torch, a Lower East Side supper club that feels like a Weimar cabaret, was getting out of hand. By 12:30 A.M. on a recent Tuesday night, more than 75 would-be revelers were logjammed at the velvet ropes and growing agitated. Inside, employees of Sonicnet, the music Web site that was sponsoring the party, were beginning to panic.

title: Equal Collaborations
description: To the Editor:

title: Removal of a School Board's President Heightens Tensions
description: Tensions that had been gradually building in Crown Heights since the school board election results were announced in June erupted Wednesday after a new bloc of four Hasidic members ousted the incumbent president and installed a black ally.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE PLEDGE

title: Glitches Aside, Optimism Runs High Around the League
description: Bill Kuharich, the New Orleans Saints' general manager, said his heart did not drop into his stomach when he first heard that Ricky Williams, the man the Saints spent eight draft picks to get, had severely hurt his ankle.

title: Ideas & Trends; As Gold Prices Fall, The Cachet Prevails
description: AS the price of gold hits a 20-year low, diehard gold bugs and others are rushing in to buy the precious metal as a hedge against the day the bear wakes from his prolonged hibernation on Wall Street.

title: In San Francisco, Developers Bet on High-Rises
description: TRADITIONALLY, a home with a view here has meant living on one of the many hills for which the city is celebrated. But a group of developers hopes to convince at least a few thousand residents that living on the upper floors of a contemporary glass and steel high-rise is as romantic and sophisticated as living in an Edwardian building atop Russian Hill or in Pacific Heights.

title: Moore Leads Virginia Tech on the Road to Respect and to the Top
description: He is the best defensive player in the nation that nobody knows, and if Corey Moore has his way, he will become the best lawyer that nobody knows. Huh? Moore, last year's Big East defensive player of the year, does not think about playing professional football.

title: Beyond the Chunnel
description: THIS BLESSED PLOT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARDNER, FREDERICK C.
description: GARDNER-Frederick C. Of Palm Beach, Florida. On August 22, 1999. Survived by his wife Claire Birdsall Gardner. Stepfather of Albert L. Wheeler and Constance Wheeler Geisler. Grandfather of Peter Geisler Jr., Missy Geisler, Chip Wheeler and Weston Wheeler. Born in Pawling, New York. Graduated from Columbia University and Columbia Law School. 1st Lt. in World War II. Counsel to the European Compensation Commission, he was Vice President and Secretary of Chubb and Son. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Commission Plans to Close Its Hackensack Trash Museum
description: The first museum dedicated to trash has been closed by the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission to make way for an expanded interactive museum to show how wetlands can be reclaimed and protected.

title: Strategies for the Genetically Disposed
description: WHEN the first biotechnology companies went public, back in the 1980's, slick stockbrokers likened the investment opportunity to buying Xerox or I.B.M. at its initial public offering. So when the genomics companies tapped the public markets a decade later, it was no surprise that the analogy that brokers made was to Microsoft.

title: Trying to Keep the Sound of Musicals Alive
description: THIS is a story about new musicals -- an ephemeral art form -- and the recordings that make them endure.

title: Early and Often, the Nittany Lions Make Their Statement
description: It was the earliest home opener in Penn State history, an August debut under the clear, sunny skies of central Pennsylvania. And the third-largest crowd in Beaver Stadium history needed barely six minutes to understand that all the talk about a national title returning to Happy Valley was more than just a hopeful forecast.

title: A Venerable Wine Village
description: WINE villages as charming as St.-Emilion may exist but I don't know of any more charming. A compact ensemble of cobbled streets steep as staircases, sun-drenched squares, medieval buildings and crumbling fortifications, St.-Emilion, overlooking the Dordogne Valley about 45 minutes east of Bordeaux, is surrounded by some of the world's most famous wine estates -- Chateau Cheval Blanc and Chateau Ausone, for example. It is a candidate for inclusion on Unesco's World Heritage list.

title: 2 Machines Are Needed: One for Time, One for Cash
description: END-OF-SUMMER Points to Ponder: 1) You can learn from your parents, and you can learn from the past, but can you learn from your parents' past? 2) Shouldn't this country be devoting all its resources to developing a workable time machine?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINMAN, LILLIAN
description: WEINMAN-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Lazarus. Loving mother of Pauline Meyer and Edward Weinman. Loving grandmother. Services private.

title: Lara Mears, Brian Margolis
description: Lara Richmond Mears and Brian Austin Margolis were married in a civil ceremony on Wednesday at the New York Municipal Building. Yesterday, a celebration of the marriage took place at the weekend house of the bridegroom's parents in West Cornwall, Conn., led by D. Terence Netter, the dean of the College of Fine Arts at Jacksonville University in Florida.

title: Smiling Cheese and Other Good Food
description: AN impatient dad tried to coax his toddler daughter into tasting a free sample from the cheese table at Delicious Orchards in Colts Neck. She pushed away his meager offering -- a tiny cube of white cheddar -- and lunged instead for a block of white and yellow mild cheddar molded into a smiley face.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some regional editions last Sunday about waterfront development in Westchester County misstated the name of a planned restaurant in Hastings-on-Hudson. It is Sun Moon and Spoon, not Sun Moon and Stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUMPRECHT, HERBERT
description: GUMPRECHT-Herbert. On August 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Nina Stutter Gumprecht. Father of Mona Stiernstedt, Susan Hjelm, Ivonne Sahlin, and Nicholas Gumprecht. Cherished grandfather of nine and great-grandfather of two. As a member of Seawanhka Corinthian Yacht Club, The Royal Yacht Squadron, and the New York Yacht Club, he was an avid sportsman and sailor having won many world championships and local events. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, September 1, 1999, 11 AM, St. John's of Lattingtown Church.

title: Last of the Midnight Hoops
description: Sweaty and out of breath, Brian Gardenhire, a 17-year-old high school senior who lives on the Lower East Side, strode across the basketball court at a local recreation center and described the importance of midnight basketball to him. ''You learn a lot, not just about basketball, but about how to prepare for jobs and how plan your personal finances,'' he said. ''You're with people who want to do more than just hang out.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRAYER, STEVEN JAY
description: DRAYER-Steven Jay, age 44, passed on August 17, 1999. The family of Steven Drayer wishes to express their gratitute to all who have given their sympathies. Though his stay was short, he will long be remembered by his parents, sister, brother-in-law, nieces & nephews, aunt, uncle and cousins, friends and all his animal friends. Rest well my son, Mother & Dad. Contributions to the Epilepsy Fund would be appreciated.

title: A Parting Look At a Century's Hero
description: CLOSING out the 20th century with an exhibition on Theodore Roosevelt might seem a bit puzzling to some museumgoers. But to officials at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington, it made perfect sense. Who better to bring in a new century than a man who personified the old one?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, ABRAHAM
description: ABRAMSON-Abraham. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Abraham Abramson, associated with The Times from 1944 until retiring in 1975.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLOWE, JAY B., MD.
description: BERLOWE-Jay B., MD. A long time resident of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, passed away on August 12, 1999 at the age of 72. A graduate of Allegheny College, he completed medical studies at SUNY Downstate in 1952. After completing a residency and fellowship in Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at Kings County Medical Center, he began his private practice on Long Island, joining the staff at Huntington Hospital in 1965. In 1988, he was elected as Fellow Member of The American Psychiatric Association. He continued to practice full-time up until his death. Dr. Berlowe is survived by his wife, Nina, and by his two sons, Andrew and Matthew. He was buried at the Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Westchester on August 20. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be sent to Allegheny College, Meadville, PA 16335

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ROBIN
description: WEISS-Robin. Beloved wife of my loving brother, Andrew S. Weiss. Her spirit will be in our hearts forever. In her courageous battle for life she showed devotion. To be with her was an inspiration. She gave so much of herself and left a legacy of bravery and strength. There will never be darkness because her light will always shine. An angel on earth whose halo warmed everyone's heart is now with God. Robin, you will forever be a blessing. We love you. Your big sister Janie Weiss Sturman, Leon Sturman, and your loving nieces, Amanda and Laura Schwartz.

title: Dig They Must
description: THE POLITICAL LIVES OF DEAD BODIES

title: 2 Passengers Are Slashed In Attacks on Subways
description: A 37-year-old tourist from Denmark was slashed yesterday afternoon aboard a subway train in Manhattan, the police said. Two men were arrested for the attack.

title: Town Hopes to See Relief for Kilmer's Tree
description: A copper beech that may have inspired a well-known poem has now inspired efforts to save it from drought.

title: Fraud Worries Greet A Vote-Delivery Bill
description: Voter turnout lags in California, as in most states. But give the Golden State credit for trying to improve participation.

title: Anti-Immigrant Ads Exiled
description: The founder of an anti-immigration group has complained that city pressure caused a Long Island company to tear up his contract and pull down his billboards, which were critical of immigration policy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GEORGE, ALLAN
description: GEORGE-Allan. 28 August 1979. It is 20 years ago today and I miss you more than ever. An extraordinary man of great intellect and marvelous humor. Kind, loving, witty, you brought light into the lives of all who knew you. With love, your daughter

title: For Cow, Little Wiggle Room
description: The minor league Staten Island Yankees are so protective of their mascot, Scooter the Holy Cow, that they forbid taking photos of the man inside the costume. His name, it can now be told, is Fred Alvaro, a sports management major at St. John's University who has donned the Holstein-patterned hide for most of the first season. Mr. Alvaro, 20, said he once shook so many hands that he sprained his wrist -- his ''glory wound.'' He has also suffered leg cramps, stiff necks, dehydration and a sucker punch to the snout. ''You work through it,'' he said last week.

title: Miss Abstoss And Mr. Lynch
description: Alexandra Caterina Abstoss, a daughter of Renate and Klaus Abstoss of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to William James Lynch Jr., a son of Monique and James Lynch of Dallas. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-29-99: On Language; Fancy Speak
description: When memory falters and friends cannot help, when the library has been scoured to no avail, when all avenues of investigation prove fruitless, they come to me. The lexically perplexed. The literally lost. The wordstuck. They're a far cry from the plain-language people discussed here last week.

title: Torn Asunder
description: SOLOMON'S SWORDTwo Families and the Children the State Took Away.By Michael Shapiro.331 pp. New York: Times Books/Random House. $25.

title: Tara Schlesiona, Richard Dircks Jr.
description: Tara Jean Schlesiona, a daughter of Susan and Harold Schlesiona of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Richard Joseph Dircks Jr., a son of Phyllis and Richard Dircks of Huntington, N.Y. The Rev. James F. Toal, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew Avelino Church in Flushing.

title: The World; The Turkish Quake's Secret Accomplice: Corruption
description: IT is common to refer to earthquakes as natural disasters, but the one that took thousands of lives in Turkey this month was more than that. Many of the victims would have survived if their homes had been built in accordance with basic safety standards. Instead they were built with cheap materials by contractors who had learned they could make up in corruption what they lacked in skill and experience.

title: Does Foreign Policy Demand a Vision?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAVANAU, ANNIE ELKAN
description: KAVANAU-Annie Elkan, age 89, died in New York City on August 23, 1999. Born on July 4, 1910 in Berlin, Germany. Beloved mother of Sally Kya-Hill, Lina Steckler, Margaret Kavanau; grandmother of five; great-grandmother of nine. Dear sister of Henriette Sonn, Lore Taussig. She will live on in the hearts of many.

title: Heisman Campaign Is Starting On Level Field
description: If, as in politics, Heisman Trophy campaigns were helped by name recognition, Ricky Williams might be this year's front-runner to win college football's most coveted award. Like last year's winner of the same name, he is a talented running back from the Lone Star State. But this Williams carries the ball at Texas Tech - not Texas - and sports neither braided hair nor the it's-his-to-lose portfolio that helped the Longhorns' Williams to win last year.

title: The Irish Take Advantage Of History and Turnovers
description: The historians among the Notre Dame faithful which is almost all of them -- have been looking forward to the 1999 season for a long time. Not because this year's version of their beloved Irish football team is particularly loaded with talent, and not because the team is coming off an extraordinarily satisfying 1998 season. But because the history books tell them that this is their year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNSTEIN, LARRY
description: BROWNSTEIN-Larry, 61, died suddenly August 24, 1999. Survived by brother David. Will be missed by his many friends. Memorial to be held at later date.

title: August 22-28; A Better Deal
description: As a murderer, Samuel Sheinbein of Aspen Hill, Md., was an amateur; after killing an acquaintance in 1997, the 19-year-old left behind a handwritten note describing the murder plot. But in manipulating the legal systems of two countries, he seemed like a pro, fleeing to Israel and claiming citizenship on the basis of his father's birth in British Palestine. Mr. Sheinbein worked out a plea bargain to serve 24 years in prison, tough by Israeli standards. In Maryland, he would have faced life in prison without hope of parole. PHILIP SHENON

title: Habitats/45th Avenue, Hunters Point, Long Island City; Hell's Kitchen Transplant Extends His Roots
description: BRICK and stone houses built in the late 19th century fill the tree-lined block, shaded by a canopy of leaves that meet overhead in an arboreal dance. Sometimes television crews, among them cameras from HBO's ''Sex and the City,'' set up on the street, using its character as a backdrop for their stories. A plaque identifies the block as part of a historic district, which protects the houses from demolition or inappropriate exterior alteration.

title: Visiting Cuba
description: To the Editor: In ''Island of Forbidden Fruits'' (Aug. 8), Frank Bruni warns motorists in Cuba to ''be prepared to fend off hitchhikers, who seem to number 300 for every car.'' Because of the lack of gasoline, most Cubans are forced to hitch a ride to get to the next town, and it is thus considered good etiquette for drivers to pick up passengers whenever possible.

title: Transforming Derelict Building and Weedy Lot Into Garden Spots
description: Between a vacant lot strewn with debris and a parking lot on Prince Street in Newark's Central Ward sits an 1884 Moorish-style building that is one of the oldest surviving synagogues of its type in New Jersey. The brick building has stood empty since it was abandoned four years ago by a Baptist congregation that converted it into a church. The building will find new life as the home of the Greater Newark Conservancy, a 12-year-old environmental and horticultural organization. Marleny Franco, executive director, and Robin Dougherty, senior program director, talked recently about the new headquarters.

title: Books From The Times
description: The third collection from Pierre Franey's articles showing readers of The Times how to cook well but have some time left over assembles much previously uncollected material as COOKING WITH THE 60-MINUTE GOURMET: 300 Rediscovered Recipes From Pierre Franey's Classic New York Times Column, by Pierre Franey and Bryan Miller (Times Books/Random House, $30). The offerings range from gazpacho mousse to prunes in Beaujolais, without neglecting solid standards like lamb stew or subtleties like the permutations of vinaigrette. The how-to of this book is prefaced by some what-for: Miller, Jacques Pepin and Franey's daughter Claudia Franey Jensen offer tributes to the genius and geniality of Franey, who died in 1996.

title: Return of the Whips
description: A weekend of fun for Newport's preservation.

title: Jumping Into an Exercise Movement That Has the Spotlight
description: THE SETTING A second-floor meeting room at the Park Slope Food Co-op on Union Avenue on Tuesday night, where 25 people crowded to learn Falun Gong, a meditative exercise that has made headlines as the Chinese Government deployed soldiers to ban it.

title: Edgenie Rice, Brooks Thomas
description: Edgenie Reynolds Rice, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald S. Rice of New York, was married yesterday to Brooks John Thomas, a son of Maleen and John W. Thomas of Naples, Fla. The Rev. Krystin S. Granberg performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. John L. McCausland, an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Vancouver Is Astir Over Chinese Abuse of Immigration Law
description: The image of two tramp steamers disgorging 254 undocumented Chinese immigrants on beaches here this summer was enough for a local pharmacist to unleash a tirade about Canada's ''lax'' immigration law and ''silly excuses'' for refugee status, ending with a harsh finale: ''We are being treated like suckers!''

title: Going From Gushers to Geeks?
description: By the early 1990's, traditional Texas-based banking died a colorful but violent death. Huge banks that had concentrated their loans in energy and real estate were taken over by regulators or sold.

title: Crisis Deepens In Venezuela As Legislators Spurn Accord
description: The political and constitutional crisis here deepened today as an agreement to avoid a confrontation between Congress and a new Constitutional Assembly, both of which claim to have supreme legislative authority, appeared to have foundered. Legislators vowed to take steps to cripple the rival constitutional panel.

title: Country Inn Near, but Not Too Near, the Glitz
description: WITH few exceptions, elegance and sophistication are not words that leap to mind when thinking of dining out in the Northeast Corner. But Stonecroft in Ledyard is quietly changing that perception.

title: Dramatics Needed; Dramatics Delivered
description: This was what Curtis Martin's teammates knew he could do: twist in and out, find a blocker, shed an opponent, bounce off one of his guards -- and then scoot 80 yards for a touchdown.

title: An Ulster Treat
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to see the Log Cabin Restaurant mentioned in your article on Ulster County, ''A Worldly Getaway Two Hours From Manhattan'' (July 25); Daisann McLane unearthed one of the area's ethnic gems.

title: Let's See. Billy Mulder? Edgar Simpson? Nah.
description: So, after all that work and worry, you have finally ushered your offspring into this world. There's just one more agonizing thing to take care of, though, something you have been putting off until beyond the last minute. It's time to name your creation. Nobody ever said writing for television would be easy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, MARION HASTERLIK
description: SEGAL-Marion Hasterlik. Of Miami Beach, FL, on August 20, 1999. Age 90. Born in Chicago, IL, past resident of Great Neck, NY. Adored wife of the late Arthur B. She is loved and greatly missed by her daughters Liz Berenson, Susan Glass, and Marjory Sheppard. Beloved mother-in-law to Joel Glass and Stuart Sheppard. Cherished grandmother to Cindy Bernstein, Michael Harris, J.J. Harris, Melissa Sheppard, Arthur Sheppard. Truly a lady, beautiful inside and out. She touched the lives of all who knew her.

title: Don't Go Near the Hamptons
description: It's backlash time for the cult of ''The Blair Witch Project,'' the horror movie about three college students who disappear in the woods while shooting a documentary. Erick King, 30, an administrative coordinator at Cosmopolitan magazine, Laura Gilbert, 23, an assistant editor at the magazine, and their friend David Garfield, 22, a film student, have created a site that pokes fun at the movie and its popular Web site (address TK).

title: Our Towns; Boys of Fall Give Up Slice Of Summer
description: IT is still summer, after all. The stores may be advertising back-to-school specials, but they've been doing that since June, practically, so that doesn't prove anything. Deep in bed and denial, most teen-agers are still sleeping late and pretending that September is weeks away.

title: Versatility in White
description: Riesling has been a page in Paumanok's portfolio from the outset. And often more than one style has been made in a year. The 1998 vintage at the winery, in Aquebogue, produced three versions: dry, semidry and late-harvest.

title: SHORTS
description: JAPAN

title: The Nation; New Technology Brings New Layers of Grief
description: IN hindsight, finding the remains of the 229 people who perished when a Swissair jet crashed a year ago and retrieving them from the ocean floor off Canada's Atlantic Coast may have been the simple part.

title: A Debt Load Grows

title: Allegro City
description: New York served as a songwriters' muse long before Billy Strayhorn advised us to take the ''A'' train or Rodgers and Hart told us they'll take Manhattan. In NEW YORK: Songs of the City (Billboard/Watson-Guptill, $35), Nancy Groce, an ethnomusicologist, has collated almost 1,000 songs about New York spanning three centuries. The city has had its poets laureate for every era: the 19th-century musical comedy-writing duo of Harrigan and Hart; George M. Cohan, ''The Man Who Owns Broadway,'' at the turn of the century; the Gershwin brothers; Cole Porter; Leonard Bernstein, Betty Comden and Adolph Green, who oriented us during the World War II years with ''New York, New York.'' The book is chockablock with historical information, rare songs and lyrics, but is confusingly organized geographically and thematically, rather than chronologically, so that Billy Joel is lumped in with Depression-era songs. The text is often plodding (''New York City has always been a unique place''), but the illustrations provide a visual feast of sheet music covers and tinted postcards that evoke the lost world of Schrafft's, Childs and Horn & Hardart. Although the book attempts to be comprehensive, music from the latter half of this century is treated cursorily. Another volume cries out to be written on New York city music from doo-wop to Brill Building pop and hip-hop. Eric P. Nash

But no new children will be allowed into the program. The injunction is the most recent in a spate of litigation on the constitutionality of using taxpayer-financed vouchers for parochial schools. title: The Precarious Triumph of Human Rights
description: I was a Foreign Service officer when President Jimmy Carter decided to make human rights a cornerstone of his foreign policy (David Rieff, Aug. 8). I thought at the time that his initiative would never amount to much because I did not believe that we would press a major power on human rights problems if other issues were deemed more important. Regrettably, I was proven right. Even the examples cited by Rieff, in support of his contention that human rights drove our policy, involved small powers in which concerns over rights coincided with our national interests. We intervened in Bosnia and Kosovo partly because of enormous human rights abuses, but also because of fears that those conflicts had the potential to destroy NATO. We did not intervene in Rwanda and Burundi, nor have we done much regarding the Hutus based in Congo, because our interests are not affected, not because African lives count for less than European ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLGEL, MILTON IRVING, M.D.
description: WOLGEL-Milton Irving, M.D., died on August 26, 1999, at age 84. Graduate of Downstate Medical School in 1935, Milton completed his residency in Internal Medicine & Gastro Enterology at Beth Israel in 1939. As a World War II vet, he served in Europe as captain of the medical unit for the Military Police Battalion. A respected physician, he cared for generations of families during his successful 30-year practice in Internal Medicine in Kew Gardens. He authored some of the original research articles on the treatment of peptic ulcer. Milton was one of the founders of Parkway Hospital in Forest Hills, New York, and a long-standing member of the New York State Medical Society. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Jacqueline; children, Vicki and Claude, and daughter-in-law, Lisbeth; two granddaughters, Lindsay and Chelsea; brother, Harold, and sister, Marjorie. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

It happened again last February in Los Angeles, at the Grammy Awards. By then both singers had built huge Spanish-speaking audiences and were looking to invade the Anglo market. Anthony's star was ascendant; Martin was, at best, a shadowy blip on the pop-culture radar. But it was Martin who was invited to perform that night, and he did so with such pansexual verve that the world was left panting for more. He also took home a Grammy. title: A Butterfly on the Floor
description: Rahna Reiko Rizzuto's first novel, WHY SHE LEFT US (HarperCollins, $24), is broad in scope, yet its greatest pleasures are small ones. Rizzuto follows three generations of a Japanese-American family, deftly counterbalancing the dramas of World War II (the American internment camps, specifically) and of home life (most crucially, the relinquishment of a child born out of wedlock). The book's structure is equally ambitious: the story is told by four different narrators in several time periods, jumping between past and present tense and third and first person. This method can be intriguing; reading the book is akin to assembling a jigsaw puzzle as the picture gradually emerges. But the multiple voices render the narrative choppy, at odds with the simple, lyrical beauty of the language itself: words ''dropped individually, like stones into dust,'' lips ''arched like a bird's wings,'' a bellicose brother turning on his heel ''left the form of a butterfly in the dirt on the floor.'' A subtly persistent longing for security pervades all the characters and is most poignantly present in Eric, the boy who was given up for adoption and then reclaimed by his grandmother, but never by his mother. Two scenes are rendered all the more moving, and significant, by being parallel -- in 1925, a little girl watches her mother give birth; 17 years later, she bears her own daughter as her mother looks on. The real news in ''Why She Left Us'' resides in the intimate moments. Sarah Saffian

title: Wearing of the Green
description: Despite some recent rain, watering restrictions stand. That leaves the lawn-proud helpless and landscapers idle. Tom Castronovo, a landscaper in Warren County, has an idea to help both parties: spray-painting brown lawns green. He noticed green paint -- called, in fact, Green -- on the shelf of a supply house and noted that it was used to touch up golf courses and football fields for television. Why not offer a paint job to businesses and homeowners? So he picked up a tank and sprayed the grass at a local catering business. The owner of a nearby produce stand noticed and signed him up. Newspapers and television stations noticed, too, and he now Mr. Castronovo has appeared all over, saying things like ''It's springtime all over again.'' He hopes to start a gardening show on cable television and has a Web site, www.themastergardenershow.com. Spraying costs $400 an acre, and the paint holds for four to eight weeks, depending on rain. But then again, if it does rain, the lawn will need cutting.

title: A Seafood Stew That Offers the Taste of Provence
description: THE license plate on a car parked outside the beach club in West Cornwall, Conn., the other day was one of the oddest I've seen: ''AIOLI.'' Had the owner spent a summer in Provence and become addicted to the famous garlicky mayonnaise of the region? Or did the car belong to a local farmer who raised garlic? Whatever, it occurred to me that it had been a while since I had made aioli. It was the perfect sauce to go with summer vegetables: golden beets, baby carrots, string beans, tomatoes and new potatoes. And, all of these, coincidentally, could be bought at the tiny farmstand just down the road, which worked on the honor system. You put your money in a box and helped yourself.

In a modest way, the goofy props placed Ms. Nowottny in the sphere where her songs unfold, an artificial neverland of shimmering synthetic chords and tremulous melodies.

Sampras, the four-time Open champion who will be seeking a career-record 13th Grand Slam title, was practicing with fifth-seeded Gustavo Kuerten when he felt a pain in his lower back while reaching for an overhead. Soon after, a grimacing Sampras left to seek an opinion from the Open's medical director, Dr. Brian Hainline, who said the problem should be solved by rest. In a statement, Hainline said: ''Pete suffered a mild back strain this morning during a practice session. This should not interfere with his play.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, PATRICIA E. (TRISH), R.N., PH.D.
description: GREENE-Patricia E. (Trish), R.N., Ph.D., FAAN, age 50, Senior Vice President, Patient Services, Leukemia Society of America, an internationally recognized leader in oncology nursing, died peacefully on August 27, 1999, at her home in Stamford, CT, after a valiant struggle with cancer. Born in Gainesville, FL, on December 26, 1948, she was the daughter of Joel Greene and the late Marion Hodges Greene. Dr. Greene received her BSN and MSN from the University of Florida. Her doctorate was awarded by Georgia State University. She was the first Robbie Simpson Fellow at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, an honor that enabled her to promote advanced nursing roles in pediatric oncology throughout the country. She was a founder of Cancer Practice, the American Cancer Society's (ACS) first multidisciplinary practice journal and an original co-editor of Oncology Nursing Update. She authored 32 publications and lectured widely in the United States and abroad. Her contributions were recognized by her election as a Fellow of the American Academy of Nursing. Dr. Greene's clinical career emphasized the care of children with cancer. She held advanced practice clinical positions at Shands Teaching Hospital in Gainesville, FL, Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta, North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, and Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City. She was a founding member and the first president of the Association of Pediatric Oncology Nurses. Her leadership guided the formation of pediatric oncology nursing as a specialty. In 1981, Dr. Greene became the ACS's National Nursing Consultant. She left the ACS in 1996 with the title of National Vice President, Patient Services. During her time at the ACS she developed critically important scholarships and professorships for oncology nurses and scholarships for oncology social workers. This program enabled hundreds of nurses and social workers to pursue graduate studies. She had a key role in bringing programs such as Look Good, Feel Better and I Can Cope to national distribution. She guided national and international revisions of Reach to Recovery, the ACS's program of support for women with breast cancer. She worked with Lane W. Adams, then the Chief Executive Officer of the ACS, in creating a program of national awards recognizing excellence in clinical practice and caring. In 1996, Dr. Greene joined the Leukemia Society of America (LSA). She developed the LSA's Patient Services Program at the national level and throughout the LSA chapters. She created the school re-entry program, began First Connections, and established the LSA's National Information Resource Center. Volunteer work was an important value in Dr. Greene's life. She served the Oncology Nursing Society in several key roles. Her work with the State Cancer Pain Initiatives was pivotal in the establishment and dissemination of that program throughout the United States. She chaired the International Union for Cancer Control Nursing Education Project and was involved in bringing educational programs on cancer nursing to five developing countries. Dr. Greene received many awards including an honorary Lane W. Adams Award, and Distinguished Service awards from the Oncology Nursing Society, the Association of Pediatric Oncology Nurses and the Association of State Cancer Pain Initiatives. She was selected as a Distinguished Alumna during the University of Florida's School of Nursing 50th Anniversary Celebration. Besides her father of North Carolina, Dr. Greene is survived by her companion of 14 years, David Lingren of New York City, two sisters, Terry Cox of Athens, GA and Janet Bailey of Greensboro, NC. A memorial service will be held at a later date. There will be a private interment service in Florida. Memorial contributions are requested for a newly created award to honor her, the Dr. Patricia Greene Leadership Award of the Pediatric Oncology Nurses Foundation, care of Association of Pediatric Oncology Nurses National Office, 4700 West Lake Avenue, Glenview, Illinois 60025-1485. For more information, call Nicholas F. Cognetta Funeral Home and Crematory, Stamford, CT.

description: * 1-800-Flowers.com, Westbury, N.Y., to Pedone & Partners, New York, to handle its account, which had been at Kirshenbaum, Bond & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $30 million.

title: The Russian Money Trail
description: The suspected Russian laundering of billions of dollars through the Bank of New York is giving the world a disquieting look into some of the darkest corners of Russian life. The financial threads that American and Russian investigators are now tugging on seem to lead most directly to the international operations of the Russia mafia. But even more important is the possibility that the inquiry will uncover evidence of corruption at top levels of the Russian Government, including illegal diversion of loans from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Soaring Above the Beat: Pride in African Roots
description: If any place in the New World should have a long memory of an African heritage, it is Salvador, the capital of Bahia, Brazil, which was once South America's leading port for the slave trade. Bahia is still the Brazilian state with the largest percentage of African-Brazilians; Salvador's population is 75 percent black. And the city's blocos Afros -- Carnaval groups of drummers, singers and dancers -- have made it their mission to celebrate African roots. Ile-Aiye, which was formed 25 years ago and is the most respected bloco in Salvador, made its New York City debut on Sunday night at the Damrosch Park Band Shell.

title: Disturbed Man Wielding a Hammer Is Killed by Police in Brooklyn
description: A mentally disturbed man wielding a hammer was fired upon at least 12 times and killed by the police in Borough Park, Brooklyn, last evening, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORSO, ANTHONY J.
description: CORSO-Anthony J. On August 27, 1999. Beloved husband of Jean. Loving father of Salvatore, Anthony and Stephanie Granite. Dear father-in-law of Mary, Suzanne and Thomas Granite. Devoted grandfather of Salvatore John, Christopher Anthony and Samantha Rose. Cherished brother of Domenica Guarino, Joseph and Catherine Fillipone. Forty-eight years of service to the Wall Street community. 25 year Member of the New York Stock Exchange. Member of Knights of Malta for his dedication and faith to the Church. Humanitarian and philanthropist. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Members Handicapped Childrens Fund, sent to the New York Stock Exchange, C/O Anthony Corso Jr., 11 Wall St., New York, NY. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa and Sons, 1305 79th Street, Brooklyn, NY. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:30 AM, at St. Bernadette R.C. Church. Interment Moravian Cemetery.

title: Woman Sexually Abused In Her East Side Building
description: A 41-year-old woman was sexually abused on Sunday afternoon by a man who followed her into her building in Stuyvesant Town on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and forced her into the stairwell near the roof, the police said yesterday.

title: Marvin Sands, Winery's Chairman, Dies at 75
description: Marvin Sands, chairman of Canandaigua Brands, the nation's second-largest winery, died on Saturday after a brief illness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTKIN, LEE
description: RUTKIN-Lee on August 29th, 1999 at the age of 81. Beloved husband of Millie for fifty-three years. Adored father of Leslie and Dale. Cherished grandfather of Andrew. A World War II Veteran, avid sportsman, talented woodworker. Everyone loved you and you will always live in our hearts. Funeral service Tuesday, 12PM at Yablokoff Kingsway Memorial Chapel, 1978 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn. Interment to follow at the Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: George Sugarman, a Sculptor Of Colorful Works, Dies at 87
description: George Sugarman, whose animated, meandering polychrome sculptures are among the most inventive if least appreciated three-dimensional artworks of the early 1960's, died on Wednesday at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Focus Is Shifting to Her Elder Son, the Heir to the Dynastic Flame : 2 Years On, Britons Give Diana a Shrug
description: LONDON  Two years after her death, the only monument to Diana, Princess of Wales, is the one the people have adopted, the Flame of Liberty above the Paris tunnel where she died in an automobile accident on Aug. 31, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, DAVID E.
description: LEVY-David E. Of New York City and West Whately, Massachusetts, died in Northampton, Masscahusetts, August 27, 1999. Former partner of Ray JosephsDavid E. Levy Public Relations & later president of David E. Levy, Inc. He is survived by his beloved companion, Alan Damon. Memorial to be held in New York City September 26. Donations to VNA/ Hospice Alliance, Northampton, MA., will be appreciated.

title: Flow of Cash Into Stock Mutual Funds Rebounds in August
description: Net inflows into stock mutual funds rose an estimated 50 percent in August, rebounding from a slowdown in July, as stocks gained and interest rates declined.

title: OIL COMPANY TO SELL COAL UNIT
description: The world's second-biggest publicly traded oil company, Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said it planned to sell its coal subsidiary, completing its exit from mining. The unit has $500 million in annual sales and 1,730 employees. Analysts value the subsidiary, with seven mines in Australia and one in Venezuela, between $600 million and $1 billion.

title: Hurricane Gives Peck to the Carolina Coast
description: Hurricane Dennis began peeling away from the coast of North Carolina this afternoon, apparently sparing the state the kind of damage it had suffered in three other hurricanes since 1996.

title: On-Line Health Care for the Savvy Surfer
description: What do you want to know about health? How to treat your arthritis? Which vitamins to take? How to quit smoking? How to find the best cardiac surgeon? What to do about your anxiety attacks? Are there any promising new cancer drugs? How to join a clinical trial? Or are you looking to join a support group of people who share your health problems? Perhaps you want to buy a prescription drug or consult a physician about a pressing medical matter without ever having to leave your home.

title: Foreign Affairs; Siamese Twins
description: No one knows if China is going to invade Taiwan, but if it does it will affect not only Asian politics but also Asian rock-and-roll. You see, the most popular singer in China today is Taiwan's sexy, silky-voiced Ah Mei. When Ah Mei recently performed in Beijing and thanked the Chinese Ministry of Culture for letting her appear, the Chinese audience reportedly booed at even the mention of their own Government. Rock-and-roll uber alles. Two countries, one Elvis.

title: OUTLOOK SPORTS TO BUY MADISON & WALL
description: Outlook Sports Technology Inc., a maker of golf equipment and apparel, plans to buy Madison & Wall Financial Services Inc., a financial public relations firm, for about $103 million in stock to broaden its business beyond golf. Outlook, based in New York, will pay nine million of its common shares for closely held Madison & Wall, which provides advertising, marketing and Internet-related services to publicly traded companies. Outlook, which sells products under the brand name Tegra, had 1998 sales of $1 million and has four employees. Outlook's shares fell 18.75 cents, to $11.25.

description: Eagerly wondering what will happen to Ross and Rachel and Chandler and Monica after the cliffhanger Las Vegas episode of ''Friends''?

title: Iron Women Complete Test Of Endurance
description: They never claimed to be great athletes. But in Colonial Beach, Va., last weekend, two New Yorkers, Patricia Buttenheim and Ann Snoeyenbos, overcame heat, humidity and schools of stinging jellyfish to become two of the first American women ever to finish a ''double iron man'' triathlon: a 4.8-mile swim, a 224-mile bicycle ride and a 52.4-mile run.

description: In the world of baggage, backpacks are better for joints and muscles than briefcases and shoulder bags. But if worn improperly, the backpack has its own perils.

title: French Chains Plan to Merge Into a Giant
description: Pressed into the defensive by Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s aggressive march into Europe, two of the biggest supermarket operators in France announced a $16.6 billion combination today intended to build a stockade against Wal-Mart's ambitions.

title: Long Dismissed as Piglike, Hippo Gains a Nobler Cousin, the Whale
description: Imagine having always been told that your closest relative is a pig, then waking up one morning to find that no, your nearest cousin is a whale.

title: By Design; Quilting Bee
description: Quilted clothes and accessories are in for a revival this fall. But the newest versions aren't in the bulky ''Michelin tire man'' mode. They have a sleek look in keeping with the current trend for closer-to-the-body silhouettes.

title: 2 On-Line Concerns Choose Agencies
description: Two 'dot-coms' have selected their first agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, PATRICIA, R.N., PHD.
description: GREENE-Patricia, R.N., PhD. The Leukemia Society of America mourns the loss of Trish Greene. Since joining the Society in 1996 as Sr. Vice President, Patient Services, she contributed in major ways to the advancement of the Society's mission. She was a guiding force in the development of the Society's Patient Services Program, including: the Back to School Initiative, which helps children adjust when they return to school after treatment; First Connections, which links newly diagnosed patients with a peer volunteer; and the Information Resource Center. Trish made a positive impact on the lives of many people and those of us who knew and worked with her will greatly miss a fine professional and a warm, caring, and generous human being.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Political Briefing column on Sunday about the coming special election in the 42d Congressional District of California misstated the reason that one candidate, Marta Macias Brown, was endorsed by Emily's List, a national organization that supports Democratic women who favor abortion rights. It was because of Mrs. Brown's stand on abortion, not her support of stricter controls on guns. Emily's List takes no position on any issue except abortion rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGANO, DEBORAH KRAUS
description: PAGANO-Deborah Kraus. Deborah, who until retiring to stay home with her children was a banker for over 20 years with the Chase Manhattan Bank, died on August 27 of breast cancer in Avalon, N.J. She was 46 and lived in Manhattan and Upper Black Eddy, Pa. A member of one of the earliest classes of women to graduate from Princeton University in 1975, she was one of the first women to be promoted to a senior management position at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., a predecessor to Chase Manhattan Bank. Mrs. Pagano was a director of the Creative Center for Women with Cancer, New York, an organization founded on the belief in the healing power of creative activity. She is survived her husband, Vincent, her two sons, Benjamin and William, her parents, Theresa and John Kraus of Mantua, N.J. and a brother, John, also of Mantua, N.J.

title: A Stalled Police Reform
description: For more than five years, a reasonable reform bill that would give the Police Commissioner greater authority to impose punishments on police officers for misconduct has languished in the New York City Council. The principals have been blaming each other for the delay and speculating about base motives. But one conclusion is indisputable. City Council Speaker Peter Vallone had the power to bring the bill to a vote -- and probably assure its passage -- whenever he chose to. His failure to do so has deprived police officials of a useful management tool that could fit into a broader mosaic of reforms needed to address police misconduct.

title: Metro Business; Inquiry on Trash Hauling
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest waste hauler, has come under investigation by the state of Connecticut to determine whether the company monopolizes the local trash-hauling industry.

title: Republic Services Warns of Weak Earnings
description: Shares of Republic Services Inc. fell 32.6 percent in heavy trading yesterday after the company, a Florida-based waste collection concern, said that 1999 earnings would fall below analysts' estimates.

title: Challenging Women to Walk for Healthier Hearts
description: Women do not need to jog, much less run marathons, to reduce their chances of heart disease. A survey of more than 72,000 women ages 40 to 65, published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, showed that women who either walked briskly (20-minute miles or faster) for a minimum of three hours a week, or who exercised vigorously at least 90 minutes a week, had a 30 to 40 percent reduction in their risk of heart disease.

title: BANK TALKS BREAK DOWN
description: Negotiations have broken down over the sale of the ailing Seoulbank of South Korea to HSBC P.L.C. of Britain, regulators said. Lee Hun Jai, head of the Financial Supervisory Commission, said the talks had broken down over differences in the amount of Seoulbank's future bad loans. ''HSBC and Seoulbank are no longer talking,'' Mr. Lee said. ''Their differences are too large.'' He said a deal to sell off the debt-ridden Korea First Bank to the United States investment group Newbridge Capital had also encountered difficulties, but the two sides were trying to narrow their differences.

title: An Arctic Testament to Private Enterprise
description: Scurvy, frostbite, exhaustion, starvation, faulty maps, terror of the unknown -- but of all the adversaries of the Arctic explorers of the 19th century, the most dangerous foe was government bureaucracy, says Dr. Jonathan M. Karpoff, a professor of finance at the University of Washington School of Business.

description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Says He Has Proof Bribes Were Paid to Kremlin
description: A Russian investigator said in a television interview tonight that published accounts of bribes paid to Kremlin officials by a Swiss construction company were ''98 percent true'' and could be backed up by evidence in his files.

title: Patient Suffers From Connotationitis
description: Another aspect of health care is coming up for some needed reform. The chief executive of the King's Fund, an influential British health charity and research organization, says it is high time to abolish the word ''patient.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Prosperity and Counting: A Time to Sell, Many Holders Say of Funds
description: Lately, a lot of investors have found that one of the best things about mutual funds is selling them.

title: Russians Scale Back Research at South Pole
description: As Russia's impoverished scientific institutions face ever more severe cuts in financing, Moscow's main station on the Antarctic continent has been forced to close. If the participation of Russian institutions in Antarctic research is to continue, scientists say, they will require increasing international support.

title: Einstein, Confused in Love and, Sometimes, Physics
description: Our story so far: A quiet mathematical prodigy grows up in a family of high technology schemers into a cocky, charismatic youth. He drops out of school and leaves his country to dodge military service. In college he alienates his teachers by cutting class. He breaks his mother's heart by falling in love with an older foreign woman and fathering an illegitimate child, and eventually marrying her.

title: At Hurley's, Tears in the Beer
description: For decades, Hurley's restaurant bucked the odds. When Prohibition came, the Hurley brothers put a flower shop in front to hide the speakeasy. When Rockefeller Center was planned, the family stubbornly refused to give up their lease, forcing the developers to build the huge complex around them.

title: In Reversal, Court Rules Journalists' Notes Can Be Protected
description: Reversing itself, a Federal appeals court has ruled that journalists' notes and other unpublished or unbroadcast materials are often protected from subpoenas in Federal lawsuits.

title: How Peril Turns Loner Amoeba Into a Social Creature
description: When times are good and there are plenty of bacteria to eat, Dictyostelium discoideum -- a species of soil amoebas -- are loners. These microscopic one-celled animals are content to crawl through their environment, absorbing whatever food they come across.

title: GEORGIA GULF GETTING U.S. VINYL BUSINESS OF RWE
description: The Georgia Gulf Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the United States vinyl business of RWE A. G. of Germany for $270 million as part of its plan to expand in vinyl-based materials used in pipes, siding and other construction products. Georgia Gulf, which had sales of $875 million last year, will purchase the business from RWE's Hamburg-based chemical unit, the Condea Vista Company. The acquisition includes operations at Lake Charles, La.; Aberdeen, Miss.; Oklahoma City; Jeffersontown, Ky., and Mansfield, Mass. Georgia Gulf shares fell 37.5 cents, to $16.3125. The announcement was made after the close of United States trading.

title: At Ease With a Life Of Stuttering
description: PETER REITZES has stuttered for as long as he can remember, which is just about all of his 27 years. Until a few years ago, his was a life of avoidance.

title: Underwood Arrives in Miami
description: The Dimitrius Underwood saga continued yesterday, as the Miami Dolphins waited into the night for the touted, but inscrutable, rookie defensive lineman to report to camp.

title: AIDS Infections Stop Declining, New Study Says
description: The rate of infection with the AIDS virus in the United States is no longer declining, health officials meeting in Atlanta said yesterday. And they said that while the rate of AIDS deaths continues to fall, that decline has slowed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Long-Distance Rate War Heats Up After AT&T Cuts

title: As Students Return, Schools Cope With Severe Shortage of Teachers
description: As children across the United States swarm back to school, principals from Washington to Palm Beach County, Fla., and from Houston to Los Angeles say they are struggling through the worst teacher shortage in recent memory. They describe being whipsawed by swelling enrollments and a push to reduce class sizes at a time when more teachers are retiring.

title: CHINA TELECOM EARNINGS RISE
description: Fueled by strong growth in its cellular business, China Telecom (Hong Kong) Ltd. said its earnings jumped 14 percent in the first half of the year. The company, which dominates China's mobile phone business, reported net income of 3.95 billion yuan, or $477.2 million. The performance surprised analysts, who had predicted earnings growth of 2.3 percent to 4.5 percent. The company attributed much of its success to its booming cellular franchise.

title: Raines Returns, as Do the Laughs
description: Tim Raines of the Oakland Athletics was the center of attention in the Yankees' clubhouse last night before the game. He was standing in the middle of the room, engulfed by the opposing team.

title: For Those Unopposed to Asking for Directions
description: It shouldn't be surprising to anyone who has been following fashion of late that women are more interested in practical clothes than in designers' flights of fancy. In an informal survey last week, women from 19 to 70 had similar reactions to a lot of what they see pictured in fashion publications, calling the clothes exaggerated and the styling extreme and not realistic.
