description: KATARTZIS-Anastasios (Tasso) V. After a long battle with leukemia. On August 29, 1999. Beloved husband of Kathy. Loving son of Vasilios and Efstathia Katartzis. Cherished brother of Fotene Esposito & Demetrios. Reposing Basis Funeral Home, 27-12 23 Avenue, Astoria Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Liturgy Saint Nicholas G.O. Church, Flushing, N.Y. Thursday, 9:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Leukemia Society of America, 475 Park Ave. South, New York, NY 10016 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARDON, JOAN ASCHER
description: CARDON-Joan Ascher. Of Wheaton, MD, age 76, on Sunday August 29, 1999 at home. Born in New York City, daughter of the late Charles S., and Helen S. Ascher, she attended Bennington College and was a graduate of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing, and Columbia Teachers College. She was Assistant Director of Nursing at Chestnut Lodge in Rockville, MD, 1953 to 1954, and Accessor of Peace Corp candidates from 1962 to 1963. Survivors include her husband of 45 years, Dr. Philippe V. Cardon, of Wheaton, MD, daughter, Cynthia Cardon Hughes, of Barrington, RI, son, Charles P. Cardon, of Caliente, CA, brother, Dr. Robert C. Ascher, of New York City, NY, and four grandchildren.

title: Top U.S. Laser Expert Admits Lack of a Ph.D. and Resigns
description: The director of an installation intended to house the world's most powerful lasers resigned his post on Friday after a flurry of anonymous faxes to officials at his California laboratory and at the Department of Energy in Washington disclosed that he lacked a Ph.D. degree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERA, DORIS
description: SILVERA-Doris. The Yeshivah of Flatbush deeply mourns the passing of Ladies Auxiliary Honorary Board Member Doris Silvera, beloved mother of Honorary President Jack Silvera, Dr. Charles Teddy Silvera, member of our Board of Directors, Leon Silvera and Allan Silvera. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire Silvera family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Paul Kopyt, President Dennis M. Eisenberg, Executive Director

description: The roller coaster that malfunctioned Saturday night, killing a 39-year-old woman and her 8-year-old daughter, had had previous problems, according to earlier passengers of the ride who have now reported the incidents to New Jersey investigators.

title: BALLY SHOES SOLD
description: In its second acquisition of a European company this month, Texas Pacific Group announced it would acquire Bally, the Swiss shoe retailer, from Oerlikon-Buehrle Holding A.G. as it pushes to turn around the money-losing fashion company and sell it. Terms were not disclosed. Texas Pacific Group, the acquisition firm led by the financier David Bonderman, offered to buy Piaggio Veicoli Europei S.p.A., the manufacturer of Vespa motor scooters, earlier this month.

title: Russia's Burdensome History, Etched Into Faces and Souls
description: Since the collapse of Communism and the breakup of the Soviet Union, journalists have been producing reports on the new face of Russia. Rebecca Feig, the American director of the affecting documentary ''Bye-Bye Babushka,'' provides instead a few old faces, grandmothers who lived for decades under the Communist system and now are left to their memories.

title: New Jersey Troopers Say They Are Afraid to Testify
description: Officer Marc Stephens knew that if he testified at today's public hearings about racial discrimination within the New Jersey State Police he might face retaliation from a handful of fellow officers or low-level supervisors. But Mr. Stephens was stunned when he received a written notice on Friday from the highest official in the state police, the acting superintendent, warning that he could face disciplinary action if his statements violated the agency's strict code regulating officers' public statements.

title: On Eve of New School Year, Detroit Teachers Vote to Strike
description: Against the recommendation of their union leaders, teachers here voted to strike today, just one day before Detroit's 172,000 public school students were due to return to school.

title: Acquisition by Sara Lee
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said today that it had acquired the closely held D. Canale Food Services Inc. for an undisclosed price. Sara Lee said Canale, which is based in Memphis, had annual sales of more than $55 million. The company distributes groceries, frozen foods, meat and poultry, seafood and dairy products. Sara Lee said the purchase would expand its PYA/Monarch food-service business, which is based in Greenvile, S.C.

title: A Strong Latin Presence Is About to Get Stronger
description: Geraldo Ferregetti was overjoyed when his company, a prominent fruit producer, signed a contract last week to supply 100 tons of papayas each month to Carrefour S.A., Brazil's largest retailer.

description: Dick Schultz will step down as the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee next year as part of an organizational restructuring.

title: In Pursuit of Autoimmune Worm Cure
description: For most of Western history, the average child walked around with a bellyful of parasitic worms: pinworms, tapeworms, hookworms. Then modern civilization came along, put shoes on the children's feet, installed sewers and stopped using human waste as fertilizer, and the worms mostly disappeared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITLOCK, EMMET
description: WHITLOCK-Emmet. On August 27, 1999 at the age of 80. He died of heart failure at Good Samaritan Hospital, Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Gloria. Father of Penny, Emmet, Jr., Frederick, William, Veronica Coleman and Valantina. Dear brother of Bache, Cynthia van Husan and Dorothy Eppelein. Grandfather of six. He was the President of Farr, Whitlock and Dixon, Sugar Brokers. He then wrote the contract for number 2 heating oil and number 6 fuel oil for the New York Mercantile Exchange. He was Senior Vice President in charge of the Petroleum Desk at E.F. Hutton, Great Neck, N.Y. Funeral will be held Wed., September 1 at 11AM St. Edwards, Palm Beach, Fla.

title: For Williams, Neither Foe Nor Wind Is Too Tough
description: All bluster and no balm, the United States Open, inarguably the most chaotic Grand Slam, got under way yesterday at the National Tennis Center. Those who coped with the ball-bullying breezes moved one round closer to a record $750,000 payday. Those who couldn't cope moped home with their $10,000 condolence checks. And anybody in the crowd of 27,809, a record for an Open day session, who neglected to tote a windbreaker along with binoculars was doomed to shiver just the way third-seeded Venus Williams did in her backless blue dress. No wonder she made like a gale-force wind and whipped through her initial assignment in a scant 54 minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTLEWSKI, TEOFILA
description: KOTLEWSKI-Teofila. The beloved wife of Dr. Marian Kotlewski died on August 27, 1999. She is survived by Dr. and Mrs. Adam Kotlewski of Arcadia, CA. and Dr. and Mrs. George Kotlewski of Amherst, NY and five grandchildren. She will be forever remembered and missed by family and friends. Services are at Kahila Chapel on Wednesday, September 1, 1999 at 11AM. (718-332-3311).

description: Six jurors were selected in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to hear an obscure $7 million personal-injury case called Johnson v. Riverton Associates. They included a registered nurse, a student, a communications executive, a financial journalist and the Mayor of New York City.

title: Fritz Shurmur, 67, a Coach Of Innovative N.F.L. Defenses
description: Fritz Shurmur, one of pro football's most innovative and successful assistant coaches never to become a head coach, died yesterday in Suamico, Wis., near Green Bay. He was 67 and was found in May 1999 to have liver cancer that had spread.

title: CHANGE POSSIBLE AT KPN
description: The Dutch telephone company Royal KPN N.V. said it was considering a number of plans that would reshape its business as it reported that its profit fell 9 percent in the first half of the year, less than analysts had expected. Among its plans, Royal KPN is considering selling shares in its cellular telephone unit, which accounted for about a fifth of its first-quarter profits. The former Dutch monopoly also said it was planning to offer free Internet access to its customers.

title: Maybe Beethoven Just Needs a Mosh Pit
description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuelan Congress Stripped of Its Last Remaining Powers
description: A Constitutional Assembly loyal to President Hugo Chavez stripped the opposition-controlled Congress of its last remaining powers today, taking revenge against legislators who had pledged to defy a decree last week that declared a ''legislative emergency'' and gave the assembly virtually unlimited powers.

title: Giants Rely On Lincoln, No. 3 Man, At Corner
description: There is little hope that the Giants' Jason Sehorn will be ready to play in the opening game of the season against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on Sept. 12. There is not even an exact date when Sehorn will be permitted to resume jogging on his strained left hamstring.

title: Study Links Teen-Age Substance Abuse and Paternal Ties
description: Teen-agers who do not get along well with their fathers are more likely to smoke, drink and use drugs than youngsters in average two-parent families, according to a national study released today.

title: NISSAN TRANSACTIONS
description: Japan's second-largest auto maker, the Nissan Motor Company, will sell stakes in two affiliated auto parts makers. Nissan will use the money to repay debt, analysts said. The affiliates will buy the stakes in each other, bringing them closer together to compete more effectively against larger rivals. The sales will distance them from Nissan, which is cutting costs and selling assets to reduce its debt. Nissan will sell 11 percent, or about half its stake, of the Tachi-S Company, a seat maker, to the Fuji Kiko Company, a maker of safety belts and steering parts. It will sell most of its 23.8 percent stake in Fuji Kiko to Tachi-S.

title: Focusing on Prevention In Fight Against AIDS
description: Death rates from AIDS in the United States slowed again in 1998. But the rates are no longer falling as rapidly as they did from 1995 to 1997, after the introduction of combination drug therapy, health officials said yesterday at a meeting in Atlanta.

title: A Hero Firefighter With Cowboy Dreams
description: YOU know the way in ''The Godfather'' the fat guy cooking spaghetti for the guys teases Michael Corleone when his girlfriend calls? This is kind of the way the guys in the kitchen of the Squad 41 firehouse in the South Bronx are teasing Tom Foley, as if he's the younger brother in a big family -- though this big family seems largely Irish -- who did good.

title: Tentative Pact Ends Rainbow Room Picketing
description: For the first time in eight months, the picket lines came down at the landmark Rainbow Room last weekend, signaling an end to the great restaurant war between the Cipriani family and the restaurant workers' union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERMEYER, RICHARD J., MD.
description: SCHERMEYER-Richard J., MD. Of Westhampton Beach on August 29, 1999. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Tuesday, August 31, 1999, 12 Noon at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach.

title: Excerpts From 1998 Speech in Harlem
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Khallid Abdul Muhammad's remarks during last year's youth rally in Harlem, as submitted as evidence by the Giuliani administration in its attempt to persuade the courts to deny a permit for another Harlem rally Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUPONT, EMILY ARDEN
description: duPONT-Emily Arden. Daughter of Michael and Beth duPont of Darien, CT., died peacefully on Saturday, August 28, 1999 from injuries sustained while competing in a horse show in Greenfield, MA. Emily grew up in Darien, graduated from Ox Ridge Elementary School and attended New Canaan Country School. She was a sensitive, fun-loving and caring child, full of vitality, yet firm in her beliefs and strong and true in her friendships. Her warm smile and inspirational energy will be deeply missed by family, friends and all who came to know her. In addition to her parents, Emily is survived by brothers Michael, Ned and Bennett. She is also survived by her paternal grandmother, Mrs. George T. Weymouth of Wilmington, DE; her maternal grandmother, Dodie Diamond of New Canaan, CT; and her maternal greatgrandmother, Mrs. Dorothy Sherman of Toronto, Ontario, Canada. A Funeral Service will be held Wednesday, September 1, 1999 at 11:30 AM at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 1864 Post Road, Darien, CT. The Rev. Laura Ahrens officiating. Emily's parents have requested that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in her memory to: New Canaan Country School, 545 Frogtown Road, New Canaan, CT 06840; Bay State Hospital Pediatric ICU, 759 Chestnut Street, Springfield, MA 01199; or Pegasus Therapeutic Riding, Inc., 45 Church Street, Stamford, CT 06905.

title: UGI Announces Terms of Stock Buyback
description: The UGI Corporation, the largest United States propane distributor, said today that it would pay $24.25 a share, a total of $109.1 million, to buy back 4.5 million shares of common stock.

title: Metro Business; More Limits Sought On Power Shut-Offs
description: A New Jersey consumers group is calling on the Whitman administration to impose a summertime moratorium on power shut-offs to protect residents with delinquent bills from heat-related illness or death, just as a winter moratorium prevents residents from freezing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ROSE. (NEE PESHKES)
description: GOLDMAN-Rose. (nee Peshkes) Of Jersey City, NJ, on August 29, 1999. Beloved wife of the late Henry. Devoted mother of Adele Siegel, Dr. David Goldman and the late Elaine Lichtman. Adored mother-in-law of Stanley Siegel, Elizabeth Goldman and Jerome Lichtman. Loving grandmother of Linda and David, Judith and Jonathan, Daniel, Aviva and Mark, Aron, Alisa and Lew, Jenifer and Angus, Martha and Mark and Adam. Great grandmother of Mollie, Eleanor, Isaac, Harry, Elaine, Patraic, Wesley, Zachary and Eli Henry. Services from Temple Beth-El, Kennedy Blvd. at Harrison Ave., Jersey City, NJ, today at 1:00 PM. For further information ''Wien & Wien'' Jersey City, NJ 1800-322-0533. Contributions to Hadassah, Jewish National Fund or Temple Beth-El, Jersey City, would be appreciated.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Setting Aside History for the Ecstasy of the Moment
description: Pierre Boulez's association with Deutsche Grammophon has given him fine recording conditions under which to reconsider much of his favorite music with some of the world's great orchestras: Debussy and Messiaen with the Cleveland Orchestra, Bartok and Stravinsky with the Chicago Symphony, Ravel and Webern with the Berlin Philharmonic. He has also had opportunities to record new works of his own and of composers he admires, notably Gyorgy Ligeti and Harrison Birtwistle.

title: BATHROOM FIXTURE SALE
description: Spain's top maker of sinks and toilets, Roca Radiadores S.A., said it would buy Keramik Holding A.G. Laufen for 420 million Swiss francs ($276 million) in cash, narrowing the gap with the American Standard Companies as the biggest supplier of bathroom fixtures. The privately held Roca will offer to buy the Gerster family's 42 percent stake in Keramik for 577 Swiss francs ($377) a bearer share. It plans to buy the remaining shares in October. The acquisition will allow Roca to dominate fast-growth regions like Southern Europe, Latin America and Eastern Europe.

title: Malarkey In The Mailbox
description: I had spent the better part of a day researching claims of fraud in sweepstakes mailings, the ''You're America's next millionaire'' kind of promise. It's a timely issue. Earlier this month, the Senate passed the Deceptive Mail Prevention and Enforcement Act, which is intended to stifle Ed McMahon's promises that the recipient of a fancy, personalized envelope is about to become the next Bill Gates.

title: Where Terrorists Belong
description: On April 23, 1995, President Clinton came to Oklahoma to stand with us in the wake of the worst domestic terror bombing in American history. He called that act ''a terrible sin.'' He told us justice must be done. And as we buried 168 friends and neighbors and cared for hundreds who were grievously wounded, we believed him. Today, one of the Oklahoma City bombers, Timothy McVeigh, is awaiting execution. His co-conspirator, Terry Nichols, faces life in prison with no possibility of parole. Those sentences are just.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEAMAN, CECILIA
description: NEAMAN-Cecilia. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society express profound sorrow at the loss of Cecilia Neaman of New York City and Oceanside, CA. Together with her husband, Sam, she was a legendary supporter of the American Technion Society, the Technion and Israel. They founded the Samuel Neaman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology at the Technion, the leading ''think tank'' in the Middle East. An interdisciplinary institute, it searches for solutions to significant Israeli public policy problems through advanced research, workshops and publications. As Technion Guardians, Cecilia and Sam demonstrated the highest level of commitment for the Technion. Admired and loved by many, Cecilia was a master of the ''art of living,'' living every day with creativity and passion. She affected the lives of many who will sorely miss her vibrant presence. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Sam Neaman. American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology Lawrence S. Jackier, President Irving A. Shepard, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom, Exec Vice Pres Dr. Andrew Viterbi, San Diego Chapter Chair Robert Blumberg, San Diego Chapter President Gary Leo, Vice President Western Region

title: BRAZILIAN CAR TAXES
description: An accord aimed at preventing a plunge in car sales was reached between automobile producers and the Brazilian Government, cutting taxes on new-car purchases. In the second extension of an agreement reached earlier this year, officials agreed to reduce value-added taxes on cars in exchange for vows by manufacturers to freeze prices for a month on some models and hold off on employee dismissals for three months.

title: BIOMET IS ACQUIRING IMPLANT INNOVATIONS
description: Biomet Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Implant Innovations Inc., a privately held maker of dental implants, for $175 million in stock. Implant Innovations, based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., generated $70 million in revenue last year. Biomet, a Warsaw, Ind., maker of orthopedic products, said it expected the acquisition to increase operating earnings for the year, and it projected higher increases thereafter. . The company earned $149.3 million, or $1.42 a diluted share, on sales of $757.4 million for the fiscal year ended May 31.

title: Stormy Waters Foil Swimmers, but Please Surfers
description: Hurricanes making their exits and entrances out over the Atlantic Ocean whipped up hazardous waves along the entire Jersey Shore and the southern coast of Long Island yesterday.

title: Looking to the Journals
description: To the Editor:

title: R. K. Mueller, 86, Management Consultant
description: Robert K. Mueller, an authority on how companies create and govern themselves and the former chairman of the management consulting firm Arthur D. Little Inc., based in Cambridge, Mass., died last Tuesday at a nursing home in Acton, Mass. He was 86.

title: Microsoft Shuts Security Breach in E-Mail System
description: The Microsoft Corporation scrambled today to close a security breach that had left tens of millions of personal E-mail accounts freely accessible through Web sites that were created to exploit the vulnerability.

title: Paperboard Plant Closing
description: The Shorewood Packaging Corporation, a maker of paperboard packaging for consumer products, plans to close a North Carolina manufacturing plant to cut $3 million in annual costs and shift production to more-convenient sites. The plant, which is in Stanley, N.C., near Charlotte, had about $22 million in revenue in its latest fiscal year. No charges against corporate earnings are expected. About 130 workers will be dismissed. Shorewood's total work force is about 3,800.

title: Editorial Observer; Helping Embattled Children in America's Cities
description: For almost 20 years, Paramjit T. Joshi, a pediatrician and child psychiatrist at Johns Hopkins University Medical School, has treated black children who suffer from the lives they lead in East Baltimore. It is the poorest, most violent, drug-ridden part of the city, a place of little hope, low employment and high teen-age maternity rates, where guns and murder are familiar, but fathers are not.

title: Even Guerrillas Vote Peaceably
description: In a tiny chapel in this mountaintop hamlet, a large group of men fighting for East Timor's independence cast their votes today.

title: Accord Expected on Plan For Big Board's Offering
description: Securities and Exchange Commission officials say they expect to work out an agreement with the New York Stock Exchange on the thorniest issue involved in its going public -- what happens to the exchange's self-policing unit.

title: AFC CABLE SYSTEMS ACCEPTS ALL-STOCK OFFER
description: AFC Cable Systems Inc., which on Friday canceled an agreement to be bought by the Thomas & Betts Corporation, said it had accepted a $45-a-share all-stock offer from an unidentified party. The transaction valued AFC Cable, based in Providence, R.I., at $576 million, considerably above the Thomas & Betts offer of $35.52 a share, or $455.9 million. Thomas & Betts, a Memphis-based maker of electronics components and connectors, said on Friday that it would not match the offer, opting to take a $16 million breakup fee. The stock of AFC Cable, which makes electrical and communications wiring, rose $5.375, or 15 percent, to $40.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: City Claims That Hate Speech Justifies Denying Rally Permit
description: The city's lawyer argued in court yesterday that the incendiary words of Khallid Abdul Muhammad are so filled with hatred toward Jews and whites -- and are so likely to incite violence against the police -- that he and his compatriots should be prevented from staging a youth rally in Harlem this Saturday.

title: Change in Africa Brings Peace, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR SOARS. Sugar rose almost 9 percent after a warehouse fire at a Brazilian port destroyed 15,000 metric tons of sugar waiting for export. In New York, sugar for October delivery rose 0.54 cent, to 6.7 cents a pound.

title: Shares Fall on Revived Fear Of an Interest Rate Increase
description: Stock prices fell for the third consecutive session yesterday, pulled down by worries that in early October the Federal Reserve may increase short-term interest rates for a third time this year.

title: Ericsson to Shed Holdings in Real Estate
description: The Swedish telecommunications company Ericsson said today that it had decided to sell its real estate holdings in an effort to focus on core business and use its capital more efficiently.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in the Metro Business column on Friday about the sale of the New England Envelope Corporation to the Westvaco Corporation included a sale price erroneously. The terms were not disclosed; $13 million is the amount of New England Envelope's annual sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIKER, BERTRAM J.
description: DIKER-Bertram J. Died August 29, 1999 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Rhona. Loving father of Susan and son-in-law William. Devoted and loving grandfather of Alexandra. He is also survived by his brother Charles. Born in New York on April 6, 1931, he was the son of Helen Hoffner and Daniel Diker. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College and Harvard Business School. We was a retired New York investment advisor, businessman and philanthropist. He was a resident of Southampton, N.Y. and a Director of the Southampton Hospital. Funeral service Wednesday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, NY, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Classifying Racism as Insanity Isn't That Easy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, NORMAN A. DR.
description: SPECTOR-Norman A. Dr. 80. Of White Plains, NY died August 28, 1999. Survived by his wife, Edith (Cohen) Spector, his children, Janice, Joyce, Arnold and Stephen Spector, his brother, Benjamin Spector and 5 grandchildren. Funeral services were held Monday, August 30.

title: THE MARKETS: Prosperity and Counting; Stock Prices Aren't Forcing Fed's Hand
description: Like the narrator in a Greek drama, Yutaka Yamaguchi, deputy governor of Japan's central bank, took the lectern here and sadly described how the booming Japanese economy in the late 1980's came to tragedy. His description of Japan at its peak sounded eerily parallel to America in today's still evolving boom.

title: In Huge, Model Vote, East Timorese Choose Their Future
description: Proud, optimistic, determined to have the last word, almost all the registered voters here in East Timor cast their ballots on Monday in a referendum on the territory's future. A United Nations official said the conduct of the vote was just about as good as it could be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, JACK
description: SUSSMAN-Jack. Of New Marlborough, MA, died on August 29. Loving and much loved, he is survived by his wife, Constance (nee Alter); children, Leon and Michael and Marilyn Arnold; grandchildren, Anne and Peter; and sisters, Lenore and Ruth Laibstain. Services will be private. Donations may be made to New Marlborough First Responders, New Marlborough, MA, 01259.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, MORRIS (JACK)
description: JACOBS-Morris (Jack), 76, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Bayside, NY, on August 30th, 1999. Beloved husband of the late Frances Jacobs. Devoted father of Richard and Wendy. Loving grandfather of Lee and Matthew. Dear brother of Rhoda Jacobs. Donations in his name may be made to American Heart Association.

title: People
description: * Michael Gross, regional financial director at J. Walter Thompson North America, part of WPP Group P.L.C., was named to the new position of chief operating officer at J. Walter Thompson, New York. Stephen Kuehn, worldwide financial director at J. Walter Thompson's Ford Global Business unit, Detroit, succeeds Mr. Gross.

title: Evelyn Shrifte, 98, Publishing House President
description: Evelyn Shrifte, the longtime president of Vanguard Press, which published the first books of Saul Bellow, Dr. Seuss and Joyce Carol Oates, died on Aug. 8 at her home on the West Side of Manhattan. She was 98.

title: In Oakland, There's Some There There
description: Mark McGwire, who last year had the single greatest home run-hitting season in baseball history and is threatening to go there again, is envious of Jason Giambi.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEXTRON INC., Providence, R.I., an automotive, aircraft, industrial and finance company, agreed to acquire the aircraft and commercial-franchise finance divisions of Green Tree Financial Servicing Corp., a unit of Conseco Inc., Carmel, Ind., Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Rearranging the Branches on a New Tree of Life
description: A diner sits down to a salad containing mushrooms and lettuce. In the universal genealogy of life, the mushrooms are more closely related to the lettuce than to the diner, right?

title: DAEWOO IN TALKS TO SELL UNIT
description: The South Korean brokerage firm Daewoo Securities said it was negotiating the sale of an 80 percent stake in its unlisted affiliate, the Daewoo Capital Management Company, to Scudder Kemper Investments of the United States. After the equity sale, Daewoo Capital Management will become a joint venture company focusing on fund management. Daewoo Securities will own a 20 percent stake in the joint venture. Daewoo Securities said it expected a formal agreement by the end of September.

title: Sports of The Times; Light-Years And a Bridge Of Separation
description: THE young ones are coming bigger, hitting harder, learning faster. From one end of the summer to another, London to New York, Mirjana Lucic schooled a former Harvard student on the existential differences between plucky challengers and aspiring champions, between opposite ends of the Whitestone Bridge.

title: Don't Judge Faith by the Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEINFELD, JOSEPH
description: SCHEINFELD-Joseph. On August 29, 1999 of West Orange, NJ. Owner and President of S. Scheinfeld and Son of S. Kearny, NJ for over fifty years. Survived by his wife, Sylvia; children, Steven, Hedy Klein and Debora Eisen; grandchildren, Joshua Laurano and Lauren Klein. Contributions to American Diabetes Association would be appreciated. Services are today, 10:00AM, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANSORGE, ROBERT
description: ANSORGE-Robert. Of New York City, Southbury, Ct. and Longboat Key, Fl., died August 29 at his home in Connecticut. Beloved husband of June (Leder), devoted father of Andrew and Laura (Koopman) Ansorge and Sally and Michael Mulvey and loving grandfather of Alexandra Pearl Mulvey. A gathering of friends to celebrate his life will be held Sunday, September 12 from 2 to 4PM at our Connecticut home. Donations may be sent to Visiting Nurse Service Hospice, Southbury, Ct.

title: First Lady For First Time Gets the Help Of an Old Pro
description: Wading into a sea of candied apples, broiled sausages and fried dough, Hillary Rodham Clinton campaigned elbow to elbow with President Clinton at the State Fair here today -- the first time that this husband has campaigned on behalf of this wife. The Clintons shook hands, hoisted toddlers in the air and addressed a Democratic luncheon in a day filled with reminders that a passing of the family torch was at hand.

title: Umpires Seek Help To Save Their Jobs
description: Nearly reduced to grasping at flimsy foul lines, the umpires union went to court again yesterday in a late effort to save the jobs of 22 major league umpires.

title: Officer Charged in Sexual Abuse of Ex-Companion
description: A New York City police officer was suspended from the force early yesterday morning after she was arrested on charges of trespassing in her former companion's home and sexually abusing her, law enforcement officials said.

title: ITT INDUSTRIES IS BUYING KEYPAD OPERATION
description: ITT Industries agreed yesterday to buy San Teh Ltd.'s keypad business for $118.8 million. The business, STX Pte. Ltd., based in Singapore, had 1998 sales of $64 million. The company makes rubber switches used in mobile telephones, computer keyboards, remote controls and keyless-entry systems. STX Pte., which has factories in China, will operate within ITT Industries' Cannon division. ITT Industries, a maker of pumps, electronics and military equipment, said the purchase would strengthen its position in the Asia-Pacific region. ITT Industries, of White Plains, had 1998 revenue of $4.5 billion.

title: Man Who Chased Car Is Attacked by Occupants
description: A North Bergen man was stabbed several times in the hands, chest and stomach early yesterday in what the police are calling a case of road rage.

title: For Holbrooke, a New Job, but the Old Balkan Difficulties
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, America's new delegate to the United Nations, stood at the edge of a mass grave near Stara Cikatova, 25 miles west of here, up a long and dusty road past Glogovac, facing the television cameras, struggling a little to find apt words to say.

title: Flaw Allows Hackers Into E-Mail Accounts
description: Microsoft scrambled to close a security breach that left tens of millions of E-mail accounts on Hotmail accessible through Web sites created to exploit the vulnerability. It was not clear how much information might have been compromised.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BESS, BARBARA E., MD.
description: BESS-Barbara E., MD. The New York County District Branch of the American Psychiatric Association mourns the loss of their esteemed colleague who departed this life on August 26, 1999. Dr. Bess was a former President, Co-President and Treasurer of the District Branch. Up to her death, she chaired three D.B. committees. She will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. The Executive Counsel

title: AT&T JOINS RIVALS BY LOWERING RATE FOR LONG DISTANCE
description: The AT&T Corporation introduced lower long-distance rates yesterday, reluctantly joining a price war that is bringing bargains for consumers but threatens to cut into phone companies' profits.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about the resignation of Elizabeth Crow, editor in chief of Mademoiselle, misstated a comparison in the magazine's advertising pages. According to estimates by the Publishers Information Bureau, advertising pages rose to 582 for the first six months of this year, compared with 438 in that period in 1994. They did not decline; 960 was the figure for all of 1994.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Tingka Journal; Uncivil Rights: Are Tibetans 'Citizens' of China?
description: Luodeng Chideng was horrified when the police led away his 10-year-old son because the boy refused to repeat the phrase ''I am a Chinese citizen'' in school, insisting instead that he is Tibetan.

title: Marc Lustgarten, 52, Builder Of Media and Sports Empire
description: Marc A. Lustgarten, a principal architect of Cablevision's growth in cable television and programming for the past two decades and the chairman of its Madison Square Garden subsidiary since 1997, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 52 and lived in Manhattan.

title: ARABS AND ISRAEL EXPRESS OPTIMISM OVER PEACE TALKS
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders expressed cautious optimism today that they could forge a comprehensive deal to revive their frozen peace agreement by the time Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright arrives in the Middle East on Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about the trumpeter Kenny Dorham misstated the name of the company owned by the trumpeter, arranger and music producer Don Sickler, which has published arrangements of Dorham's music. It is Second Floor Music, not Third Floor Music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTGARTEN, MARC A.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Marc A. On August 30, 1999. Marcia, his one true love whom he cherished for 30 years. Adored father of Andy Sam and Jessie. Loving son of Irving. Dearest brother of Brian and Scot. Treasured brother-in-law of Phyllis and Neil Koenig. Devoted uncle of Rebecca and Gaby. Beloved son-in-law of Claire and Morty Rothberg. 25 years of devoted service to Cablevision Systems Corp. and the Dolan family. He will live within us, and his strength and spirit will guide us always. Contributions in lieu of flowers to The Lustgarten Pancreatic Cancer Research Foundation, P.O. Box 2141, NY, NY 10116-2141. Services Tuesday, 12:30PM, at Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: MTV to Unite Music Web Sites Ahead of Likely Stock Offering
description: In a likely precursor to a public offering of its on-line music operations, MTV Networks Online, a unit of Viacom Inc., announced yesterday the creation of a subsidiary that will incorporate its three music-related Web sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, MILTON
description: CANTOR-Milton. On August 29th my beloved brother, father, friend died. He was all things to me. He endured much. He will always be in my thoughts. Lydia Safane

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: All Those Dunes Look Alike

title: Renewed Interest Rate Worries Send Treasury Prices Down
description: Bond yields rose sharply yesterday on investor fears that the Federal Reserve would increase short-term rates again in the coming months as evidence of a strong economy continues to mount.

title: Spurning PC's, Sun Challenges Rival Microsoft
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. is planning an ambitious campaign to move everyday software applications like word processing and spreadsheets away from the personal computer desktop and onto the World Wide Web -- a strategy that amounts to a direct assault on Microsoft's biggest business.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the yen on doubts that international finance officials meeting in Berlin would move to weaken the Japanese currency. In New York, the dollar settled at 110.73 yen, down from 111.56.

title: A's Hit Irabu Hard But Yanks Come Back
description: Aside from one speed bump, the Yankees continued to steamroll toward the post-season last night, rallying from a 4-0 deficit to defeat the Oakland Athletics, 7-4, after being held hitless and scoreless into the fifth inning at Yankee Stadium.

title: TRACK AND FIELD: A Track Star's Burden; Proving Innocence Puts Focus on Drug-Test Rulings
description: When the world's best sprinters met in Seville, Spain, last week to test the limits of human speed, Dennis Mitchell was not among them. The veteran American sprinter instead worked out at the University of Florida track, helping younger athletes with their running technique while keeping an eye on his two small children.
